column2: During his years as a member of the faculty of Columbia University (1922-44) the late Wesley C. Mitchell delivered a lecture course that came to rank with the most famous in the illustrious history of that institution of learning.
WASHINGTON, April 27 -Showdown battles over legislation affecting labor are shaping up in Congress.
TIFLIS, U. S. S. R., April 27 -- Two weary teams of United States men and women basketball stars were greeted by 300 Soviet athletes and fans at Tiflis Airport today.
WASHINGTON, April 27 -- Following are the votes of thei members from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on theI major roll-calls in Congress during the week ended April 26:
WASHINGTON, April 27 -- A Government survey of the impact of foreign trade on New York City finds that one worker in every four depends upon international trade for his livelihood.
Secretary of Labor James P. Mitchell reaffirmed yesterday the Administration's opposition to a Federal "right-to-work" law or to extension of the antitrust laws to cover labor.
Albert Lasker Medical Journalism Awards for "outstanding reporting on medical research and public health during 1957" were announced yesterday by the Albert and Mary Lasker Foundation in New York.
Seventh-Day Adventist men, who for religious reasons avoid smoking and drinking alcohol, have 90 per cent fewer lung cancers and 40 per cent fewer heart attacks than other men.
ALTHOUGH they used to be a forgotten group, women who wear junior sizes are being pampered these days. Ohrbach's Campus Junior Shop, on the second floor, proves the point.
The thrift shop committee of the Play Schools Association is sponsoring a tour of New York homes known for their art collections. The visits will take place on the afternoon of May 6.
The future of "Studio One in Hollywood," "Climax!" and "Sid Caesar Invites You" may be decided officially this week by their television sponsors.

The work of the American Women's Voluntary Services will be advanced as a result of a theatre party at the May 12 performance of "The Visit." Alfred Lunt and Lynn Fontanne will open in the play on May 5 at the former Globe Theatre that now bears their names.

LAST night's musical version of "Hansel and Gretel" was a good deal longer on innovation than distinction. The story was elongated and altered, tricky electronic effects were added and Red Buttons and Rudy Vallee were prominently cast.

The Pompei soccer team of Baltimore, although defeated by Eintracht at Eintracht Oval in Astoria yesterday, 6 to 5, reached the Eastern final of the National Challenge Cup competition by the over-all score of 9 -- 8. The first encounter in Baltimore had resulted in favor of the Marylanders, 4 -- 2.
A 22-year-old actor named Andrew Prine, who has never appeared on Broadway, has been chosen from 200 candidates as Anthony Perkins' replacement in "Look Homeward, Angel."
Harlem was host over the week-end to twenty-seven white visitors from Vermont who have opened their homes to Negro children from New York for summer vacations.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 27--By 1961 the Philippines will have a steel industry with a capacity of 300,000 tons a year, capable of fulfilling all domestic requirements, it was reported here last week.

CLEVELAND, April 27 -- A plan to stimulate sales by putting uniform price ceilings on new cars should be in effect by Thursday, David L. Blaushild, president of the Cleveland Automobile Dealers Association, has announced.

ROME, Monday, April 28 -Samuel Alphonsus Cardinal Stritch was facing major surgery in a private clinic here this morning. Preparations were made during the night to operate on his right arm, where a blood clot was blocking the main artery.
ALBANY, April 27 -- L. Judson Morhouse, Republican state chairman, suggested today that Governor Harriman, who had accused him of "a series of big lies," was "deliberately distorting the facts."

Rockefeller Brothers, Inc., will have a new president and senior financial adviser, effective June 30, Laurance S. Rockefeller announced over the week-end. The new executive is J. Richardson Dilworth, who will resign as a partner in the investment banking firm of Kuhn, Loeb Co. to assume the Rockefeller post.

SPACE MAN may be no further away than 1961. That is the confident hope of Brig. Gen. Donald Davis Flickinger, Director of Life Sciences of the Air Forces's Air Research and Development Command at Andrews Air Force base near Washington.

The three juvenile gangs involved in the arrest yesterday of a 20-year-old boy on charges of killing a rival gang member have a characteristic in common. They are the "shookup" generation in sections of the city undergoing their own profound shake-ups in social patterns.
WASHINGTON, April 27 (UP) -- Two Administration officials are opposing a suggestion that overseas foreign aid purchases be shifted to the United States as an anti-recession measure.

The Todd Shipyards Corporation has announced the appointment of James F. Goodrich as general manager of its Los Angeles division. He replaces John T. Gilbride, who was elected president of the corporation last month.

DETROIT, April 27 -- The United Automobile Workers Union is prepared to offer a three-month extension of its present contracts with the Big Three car manufacturers. The proposal is part of a four-part program to combat the slump in auto sales.
The Methodist and the Protestant Episcopal Church jointly announced yesterday that some progress had been made in the long negotiations for intercommunion.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 27 (AP) -- Julian Velasquez, who went into a coma following a tenth-round knockdown last night, was pronounced out of danger today by physicians at Parkview Hospital.
CHARLOTTE, N. C., April 27 -- Clergymen and physicians were urged today to hold "highlevel" talks on how they might cooperate to help cure the ills of mankind.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, April 27 (Reuters) -- The Jakarta radio said today that Indonesian Government forces were launching heavy attacks in the rebel-held Northern Celebes.

TANGIER, Morocco, April 27 Representatives of the insurgent Algerian National Liberation Front took their places today with Tunisian and Moroccan delegates in the International Palace here to open a North African conference.

The cost of moving is going up. An association representing 900 movers of household furnishings in the metropolitan area announced yesterday that it had filed a 12 1/2 per cent rate increase with the Public Service Commission.

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 27 -President Eisenhower awaited word from the other North Atlantic Treaty powers today before dispatching a reply to Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev's latest note rejecting the United States position in the disarmament impasse.
Dr. Albert Schweitzer has again appealed to the world to end the testing of nuclear weapons.

There are 60,000,000 "social drinkers" in this country today, of whom 4,712,000 are "problem drinkers" well on the road "to becoming chronic alcoholics," the Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell asserted yesterday.
NEW DELHI, India, April 27 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru plans to take a long holiday this summer to do something about the "stale and flat" feeling that has been bothering him.

CHARWOMEN, artisans of one kind or another, carpetsewers, decorators, muralists and lighting crews pushed their work to a panting close in the new Lunt-Fontanne Theatre in West Forty-sixth Street over the week-end. The first showing there of "The Visit" is scheduled tomorrow.
Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy announced yesterday that 950 members of the department would be added this summer to patrol duty at the city's parks, beaches and pools.

MILAN, Italy, April 27 -- The number of concerns exhibiting at the thirty-sixth Milan Trade Fair was about 13,400, of which 3,500 were foreign, from forty-nine countries. In 1957 there were 13,082 concerns, of which 3,543 were from forty-seven countries.
Guggenheim Fellowship awards to 322 persons were announced yesterday. The total value of the grants is $1,412,000.
New York City has been the home of several Presidents of the United States, before, after and during their terms in the White House, but only one lies buried here.
PORT OF SPAIN, Trinidad, April 27--Vice President Richard M. Nixon flew here today from Washington to start an eighteen-day goodwill trip to eight nations in South America.
Despite the city's unending outward thrust, it is still possible for New Yorkers and their neighbors to enjoy the primeval face of spring.
ROME, April 27 -- Pope Pius XII concluded tonight solemn rites in St. Peter's Basilica for beatification of a Spanish nun.
WASHINGTON, April 27 (AP) -- The Air Force has told Congress that for an investment of $16,000,000 to $20,000,000 it can "successfully impact a payload on the-moon" this year.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 27 (AP) -- After pulling off the season's first triple play, the Chicago Cubs rallied to chalk up a 5-4 victory over the National League leading San Francisco Giants today. A crowd of 22,696 at Seal Stadium saw the Cubs score two runs in the eighth inning and one in the ninth.
The state's slum clearance and housing construction programs were said yesterday to be in danger of bogging down because of critically low f.unds.

LONDON, April 27 (AP) -- India, Chile and Brazil clinched places in the second round of the European zone Davis Cup tennis competition today. They joined Czechoslovakia, West Germany and Spain, which already had gained the deciding points in their first-round matches.
A decrease from 1956 to 1957 in the number of arraignments and the total fines collected in the magistrate's courts was reported yesterday.
The steel man in Greenwich Village is leaning definitely to the right of center, and he leans a bit more every year, it seems.

SCARSDALE, N. Y., April 27 -- Top Gallant, a black mare owned and ridden by Russell Stewart, scored only one class victory but managed to register enough points to win the open jumper championship of the thirty-fourth annual spring horse show of the Boulder Brook Club.

The Barnard College bulletin for this academic year says in a preface by President Millicent C. McIntosh that Barnard "is proud to be a part" of New York City. New York responds with like pride in Barnard College, and is happy to take note of the historic occasion, at noon today that marks new progress at this fine college.

SCARSDALE, N. Y., April 27 -- Top Gallant, a black mare owned and ridden by Russell Stewart, scored only one class victory but managed to register enough points to win the open jumper championship of the thirty-fourth annual spring horse show of the Boulder Brook Club.

The Barnard College bulletin for this academic year says in a preface by President Millicent C. McIntosh that Barnard "is proud to be a part" of New York City. New York responds with like pride in Barnard College, and is happy to take note of the historic occasion, at noon today that marks new progress at this fine college.

Forty-five thousand persons streamed into the Polo Grounds yesterday afternoon to celebrate the tenth anniversary of the realization of a 2,000-year-old dream -- the restoring of Israel as a nation. They sat through a three-hour program, despite intermittent rain and unseasonable cold, and roared ovations at every mention of Israel.
Former President Harry S. Truman said last night that Americans were "growing more and more aware of the importance" of the problem of discrimination.
AUGUSTA, Ga., April 27 (AP) -- President Eisenhower named Robert K. Gray today as secretary to the Cabinet. He is now White House aide on job patronage.
FOUR hundred teen-age girls from all parts of New York City trooped into Russeks Saturday to see "Young Junior" fashions chosen and modeled by their contemporaries.
HANOVER, Germany, April 27 -- Anastas I. Mikoyan smilingly spread the gospel of Soviet-German friendship today between admiring glimpses at West Germany's industrial accomplishments.

A two-stage program to widen Fulton Street into a ninety-foot thoroughfare from the East River to the Hudson was announced yesterday by Manhattan Borough President Hulan E. Jack. The narrow, congested street thus would become a major crosstown traffic artery with a sixty-foot roadway and fifteen-foot sidewalks.

The shortage of well-qualified engineering teachers will grow even more serious unless the nation is willing to pay the price of attracting top talent into the field, a report made public yesterday declared.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -The 5-cent stamp died after nine minutes in a Senate-House conferences last week. In these affairs, the conferees from each chamber's are expected to fight to the death for their chamber's stand, despite their individual feelings.
CAIRO, April 27 (AP) -- The Arab League Council today denounced what it termed the latest British attacks on Yemen. It reaffirmed its support of Yemen in her frontier struggle against Britain.

THE gloom was so thick it was uncomfortable. A pall had settled over the Yankee clubhouse in St. Pete a month ago yesterday. Only Joe Collins had a smile. But the smile merely was on his lips, not in his eyes. The dreaded moment had come for him. His career as a Yankee player had ended, and parting definitely was not a sweet sorrow.

ADEN, April 27 (Reuters) -- Rebel tribesmen from Yemen have surrounded a platoon of government guards at the fort of Assairir in Britain's Western Aden Protectorate, British military headquarters said tonight.
SAN ANTONIO, Tex., April 27 (AP) -- The United States A team led in the opening event of the international modern pentathlon today, rolling up 2,504 points in riding.
MILAN, Italy, April 27, (AP) -- Mino Bozzano, Italy's young heavyweight hopeful, outpointed Joey Maxim of Cleveland, the former world light-heavyweight champion, in a ten-round bout today.
DENVER, April 27 -- A mouse that might have co-starred in television and theatre newsreels with President Eisenhower lies instead at the bottom of the Atlantic Ocean.

Concerning your editorial of April 23 "The Voice of Africa," reviewing the resolutions of the recent Accra conference, we should like to comment on your observation that "it would seem contrary to the Charter to proclaim the ultramilitant National Liberation Front as the sole legitimate authority in Algeria * * *."
Gov. G. Mennen Williams of Michigan urged support yesterday for a Senate bill that would give "a form of technical assistance" to communities seeking to desegregate schools.
Lee Venora sang the part of Laetitia for the first time Saturday night at the City Center in Gian-Carlo Menotti's comic opera "The Old Maid and the Thief."

LOUISVILLE, April 27 -- Silky Sullivan and Bill Hartack both rested today. But while the late-running colt from California slept and ate in his stall most of the day, the injured riding star fretted in his bed at Sts. Mary and Elizabeth Hospital.

LOS ANGELES, April 27 -Television and radio executives with representatives of associated industries were gathering in Los Angeles today for the opening tomorrow of the thirty-sixth annual convention of the National Association of Broadcasters.

The shrewdest salesman in the Soviet ruling clique, Anastas I. Mikoyan, has been wooing West Germany these past few days. The task assigned him was not an easy one, for Moscow has no intention of making any political concessions to Bonn, especially in the area of German reunification.

WASHINGTON, April 27 (AP) -- Soviet Ambassador Mikhail A. Menshikov was picketed today by three men who said they were protesting against his appearance on a television interview program with a panel of college students.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -The trend of consumer buying holds the key to whether the recession will end soon or continue to get worse, the presidents of the twelve Federal Reserve banks have told the Senate Finance Committee.

The landing of the Australian and New Zealand troops at Gallipoli on April 25, 1915, and the part taken by the Anzacs in all the wars in which their countries have fought were extolled here yesterday afternoon.
Four new films are scheduled to arrive in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:

MILTON, Mass., April 27 -Herb (Stoky) Stokinger, athletic director and head coach of baseball at Milton Academy, this morning was checking the pitching charts made during the Orange and Blue's game with St. Mark's at Southborough yesterday.

The American Jewish Committee warned yesterday of "a revival of racially motivated nationalism and anti-Semitism" in Germany. It said this could endanger Germany's "hard-won position" among the democratic nations.

WASHINGTON, April 27 (UP)--A Negro leader told a conference on voting restrictions today that Negroes "must run the gantlet of apathy, ignorance, fear, bodily harm and racial discrimination" to register or vote in the South.
ATLANTIC CITY, April 27 (AP) -- A Philadelphia team led by Browning Ross won a twenty-mile cross-country relay race today in 1 hour 47 minutes 11 seconds.
WHAT might have been an arid, severe topic, "The Challenge to American Education," was discussed with wisdom and wit on Channel 11 Saturday afternoon.

Net income of the Allied Chemical and Dye Corporation dropped 32 per cent in the first quarter this year from the corresponding three months last year, Glenn B. Miller, president, reported yesterday at the annual meeting.

DETROIT, April 28 -- The General Motors Corporation and the Ford Motor Company rejected today the proposal of the United Auto Workers for a three-month contract extension. Both companies suggested instead that their present contracts be continued for two years.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 28 -- A Federal judge ordered the Immigration Service today to let William Heikkila alone until final appeals were heard in the eleven-year fight of Mr. Heikkila to avoid deportation.
Steel production continued to edge lower last week. But the decline was less than had been expected in the industry, and a slight upturn was expected for this week.
WASHINGTON, April 28 -Twenty-one telephone companies have been informed that they cannot continue a new method of charging person-toperson calls that has resulted in increased costs to the public.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., April 28 (UP) -- A Jewish center and a Negro school were bombed here today. Members of a group called "The Confederate Underground" were said to be responsible for the outbreak, the third such in the South this year.

United States Attorney Paul W. Williams convinced a Federal grand jury yesterday that the Government should not be excluded from its investigation of the tax returns of Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr.
Two new bond issues totaling $75,000,000 were posted yesterday for public offering in the near future.

GENEVA, April 28 -- Poland wants to join the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, it was announced today. If accepted, she would be the first Communist nation to join GATT since its inception ten years ago. (Czechoslovakia was not under Communist control when she participated in the organization of GATT.)
CARACAS, Venezuela, April 28 -- A young military leader who is supported by left-wing groups was dismissed from a key Army post today in a shakeup of commands.
A Kings County grand jury yesterday accused a group of plainclothes policemen of accepting graft to protect two bookmakers operating a $250,000-ayear Flatbush betting syndicate.
ALBANY, April 28 -- The new four-member State Crime Commission will be sworn in Wednesday at the Capitol. The group will then have lunch with Governor Harriman and the Republican legislative leaders.

Committees have been meeting to plan the annual bundle bridge and tea party, which will be held under the auspices of the thrift shop committee of the Children's Health Service on May 13. The event will be at the National Society of Colonial Dames.
FOOTLOOSE teen-agers can pedal away to new adventures this summer on American Youth Hostel bicycle trips.
Jonathan B. Bingham, secretary to Governor Harriman, was chosen yesterday by the Bronx County Democratic organization to run for the State Senate in November.

The American Ballet Theatre, now on a tour of Europe and North Africa, will play a threeweek season at the Metropolitan Opera House, under the direction of Lucia Chase and Oliver Smith, beginning Sept. 16.

On a recent morning my wife and daughter (10 years of age) arrived at Idlewild Airport on a return flight from France. This was my wife's thirteenth Atlantic crossing and my daughter's twelfth. It was their first arrival at the magnificent new International Arrival Building at Idlewild.
WASHINGTON, April 28 -Representative Frank Thompson Jr., Democrat of New Jersey, declared today that President Eisenhower had abdicated his responsibility on the school construction issue.

F. SCOTT FITZGERALD has had thousands of imitators, many rivals and no equals. The world he created out of thin gold moonlight shining on mundane realities remains his own. We are made aware of that once more as we read "Afternoon of an Author,"* a remarkably appealing book of uncollected stories and sketches by Fitzgerald that Arthur Mizener has assembled and festooned with formidable critical commentaries.
LONDON, April 28 (AP) -- Finland went into the second round of European Zone Davis Cup tennis competition today while Chile and India were putting the finishing touches to their victories.
DUBLIN, April 28 -- Prime Minister Eamon de Valera said today he foresaw the possibility of Ireland's association with the British Commonwealth under certain circumstances.
MIDDLETOWN, Ohio, April 28 (AP) -- Earnings of the Armco Steel Corporation declined more than $6,000,000 in the first quarter of 1958, compared with the first three months of 1957.

The Democratic bill to extend unemployment insurance benefits, which is being taken up in the House this week, really hasn't anything to do with unemployment insurance. As the President has suggested at his news conference, the bill would establish a dole, and through its disregard of the principles on which unemployment insurance has been built could lead to ultimate destruction of the whole system.
STAMFORD, Conn., April 28 -- Saks-34th opened a $1,000,000 store this morning at the Ridgeway Shopping Center here.
FRANKFURT, Germany, April 28 -- Anastas I. Mikoyan ended the first Soviet official visit to West Germany today with an appeal for stronger economic and cultural ties.
CHICAGO, April 28 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

On a rainy afternoon and with a day off from their clubs, sixty metropolitan golf professionals gathered yesterday for the annual meeting of their district association. In a session that lasted five and a half hours at the Park Sheraton Hotel, the professionals proved rather critical and even self-critical.
TORONTO, April 28 (AP) -- The hockey Hall of Fame added twenty-one names today and found a permanent home.
The Soviet Union and the United States are having their difficulties in getting together on a meeting at the summit but their athletes are getting thicker and thicker.

ULM, Germany, April 28 (UP) -- Ten former Nazi security officials and Gestapo men went on trial here today charged with the wartime execution of 5,502 prisoners who had been forced to dig their own graves. Most of the victims were Jewish.

Beaunit Mills, Inc., cut its common stock dividend with the declaration yesterday of 25 cents a share for payment June 1. In previous quarters 37 1/2 cents a share was distributed. The company explained that it was building a plant at Elizabethton, Tenn., for production
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange advanced 21 to 30 points yesterday, influenced by strong commissionhouse buying. Three of the options established new highs for the season.
LONDON, April 28 -- A British nuclear device was exploded successfully at a high altitude over the central Pacific today.

A youth said by the police to have been the armorer of a youth gang that was broken up about three years ago was shot in the leg last night in the South Bronx. He told detectives who questioned him at Lincoln Hospital that before the shooting two youths had asked him if he were a member of the Sinners gang.

Wool prices fell to new lows for the life of the contracts in moderatel active trading yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange. Tops fell 2 to 2.9 cents a pound and grease wool dropped 2.5 to 3.9 cents.
Directors of the Pittsburgh Steel Company have deferred dividend action on the common stock for the second time this year.
ELIZABETH, N. J., April 28 -- An eighteen-acre tract of meadowland property here has been bought as a site for a $1,500,000 food distribution center.

Some ships have suffered the ignominious fate of completing maiden voyages at the end of a tow rope. But there are two ends to every tow rope, and the new Holland-America freighter Kerkedyk is making her debut on the "glory" end.
Puget Sound Power and Light Company is in a position today to call in $20,000,000 of 6 1/4 per cent bonds sold last summer and to service the debt instead at an interest rate of 4 1/8 per cent.
TRENTON, April 28 -- The State Supreme Court ruled today that religious, and charitable groups were as liable as any other organizations or individuals in negligence litigation.
The recession claimed the free coffee break as its latest victim here yesterday.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 28 -- "The Temptations of Spring," a forthcoming first novel by Joseph Salemenca, has been acquired for film production by Jerry Wald.
WASHINGTON, April 28 -Following is the text of a speech made today by Allen W. Dulles, director of the Central Intelligence Agency, before the United States Chamber of Commerce:

LONDON, April 28 -- The uncertainty in the stock market extended to British Government securities today. Prices in nearly all principal sections drifted lower in the face of a slight increase in selling.
An international agreement barring the use of outer space for military purposes was urged last night by Representative Kenneth B. Keating, Republican of Rochester.
Sunday afternoon television, an intellectual isthmus connecting Westerns and quiz shows, will seek even greater distinction this Sunday with a twohour program on the "Concept of Freedom."
MOSCOW, April 28 -- Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev has made a new personal attack on Georgi M. Malenkov.

A total of 1,923 pints of blood was given in the last two weeks to the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program by employes of member concerns of the National Board of Fire Underwriters. The donations were made at the board's office at 85 John Street.
SOME curious proposals march under the virtuous banner of conservation, as others do under the conservative flag of virtue. A recent one, aimed at the punishment of duck hunters, is an example.
BUENOS AIRES, April 28 -The week-long festivities here in connection with the inauguration Thursday of Argentina's new President, Arturo Frondizi, began today.
WASHINGTON, April 28 -The House Armed Services Committee moved into full assault today against two major points at the heart of President Eisenhower's Pentagon reorganization program.
Eighty per cent of all children would benefit from some form of orthodontic treatment, according to a nation-wide survey by the American Association of Orthodontists.
Sales of the J. C. Penney Company for the first quarter this year were about 1/2 of 1 per cent better than a year ago, A. W. Hughes, president, told stockholders at the annual meeting here yesterday.

BRASS instruments and the pipe organ are a grand and brilliant combination, especially when they play in the festive fanfare style and the theatrical echo effects long associated with the pomp of St. Mark's Church in Venice.

FORT CAMPBELL, Ky., April 28 (AP) -- Disappointed military commanders called off for good today the repeatedly postponed biggest air drop since World War II because of high winds and weather conditions.
Plans have been completed for a $5,200,000 music and arts building on the Queens College campus that will serve as both an educational facility and a cultural center for the borough.

RISING food prices reportedly are the strongest force in today's record high cost of living. What do home cooks do to economize so that the grocery bill will not soar to impossible heights? Several people questioned on that point came up with suggestions that others may find helpful.

CHICAGO, April 28 (AP) -Wheat futures prices moved slowly but steadily ahead today in Board of Trade dealings on reports of unfavorable weather in both the spring and winter wheat areas and for some export business.

WASHINGTON, April 28 (AP) -- Representative Francis E. Walter said today that the State Department had "deliberately violated the spirit if not the letter" of the Refugee Relief Act in issuing about 6,356 nonquota immigrant visas to the first Hungarian refugees.

THERE hasn't been a major league ball game in our village in a week. For more than half a century the calendar remained crowded from mid-April into October as the three local teams averaged a game and a half a day. But for the first time since the horsecars creaked up Broadway and since ballplayers wore handlebar mustaches, New York has drawn an extended blank.

NEW DELHI, India, April 28 -- K. I. Singh, Nepalese politician with a huge mustache and a mysterious political background, is using a sudden and violent campaign of anti-Americanism to try to climb back to power in the Hindu kingdom in the Himalayas.
WASHINGTON, April 28 -The Government was urged from several directions today to take further action against the recession.
The alertness of a City Youth Board worker enabled the police to solve quickly the adolescent gang killing of Michael Ramos.
Negotiations are proceeding with Jose Quintero concerning his directing T. S. Eliot's "The Family Reunion."

The spring luncheon of the New York Chapter of the Holton -Arms Alumnae Association will take place in the New York Junior League clubhouse at 130 East Eightieth Street on May 7. Proceeds will augment the scholarship fund of the school in Washington.

Events today: Kurka's "The Good Soldier Schweik," New York City Opera Company, City Center, 8:15 o'clock; National Orchestral Association, Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church Choir, Welch Chorale of St. Philip Neri Roman Catholic Church, and Temple Emanu-El Choir, Leon Barzin, Robert Baker, James B. Welch and Lazare Saminsky, conductors, Carnegie Hall, 8:45.

CHICAGO, April 28 (UP) -- A rules change that, in effect, would permit the National League to return to New York with the consent of the Baseball Commissioner was approved today by the major league's territorial rules committee.

Nuclear pellets about the size of cigarette filter tips are being turned out by the thousands by the Westinghouse Electric Corporation at its Blairsville, Pa., metals plant, the company reported yesterday.
PHILADELPHIA, April 28 -The handling of dry cargo remained at a standstill in the port of Philadelphia again today in the dispute over the hiring of six longshoremen.

Metro - Goldwyn - Mayer's "Raintree County" has been added to the list of American motion pictures that will be shown at the Brussels World's Fair. Other films from the United States to be shown at the fair film festival, which will run from May 30 to June 13, are Columbia's "The Goddess" and Warner Brothers' "The Old Man and the Sea."
WASHINGTON, April 28 (AP) -- A bill to make "The Star Spangled Banner" more singable was introduced today by Representative Herbert Zelenko, Democrat of Manhattan.
The April in Paris Ball held on April 10 at the WaldorfAstoria realized $170,000 for various Franco-American charities. This is $35,000 more than was netted last year.

HAVANA, April 28 (AP) -- Scattered skirmishes broke out today between Cuban rebels and Army troops after a week-end of relative calm. Clashes occurred in Pinar del Rio Province in the west and Oriente Province in the east.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, April 28 (AP) -- Bermuda skippers opened International Race Week today by defeating the United States team, 32 1/4 to 28, in the first race of the Amorita Cup series, a best-of-seven competition.
Eddie Arcaro was up early yesterday morning to give his Derby mount Jewel's Reward a 5:45 A. M. workout in Louisville. In his four afternoon races at Jamaica he couldn't get up early enough to win.
LOS ANGELES, April 28 (AP) -- Leaders of two big aircraft unions today stood solidly behind contract demands that one aircraft company said could lead to a strike in the vital defense industry.

The Continental Oil Company has reached an agreement to acquire the producing properties and the nonproducing acreage of the Buffalo Oil Company of Tulsa, Okla., it was announced jointly yesterday by L. F. McCollum, president of Continental, and H. P. Taubman, chairman of Buffalo.
War is expected by 71 per cent of Overseas Press Club members answering a questionnaire. Seventy-four per cent of these forecast war within the next seven years.
VALLETTA, Malta, April 28 (Reuters) -- The Governor of this British colony tonight banned public meetings and demonstrations after a violent, one-day civil strike had halted transportation.

IT is readily seen in the flowing reaches of James Boynton's paintings at the Barone Gallery, 1018 Madison Avenue, his environment, Texas, has made a profound impression on him. And it is a poetic impression drawn off with skill from what, to a less sensitive nature, would appear to be a vast but monotonous landscape.
WASHINGTON, April 28 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission today recommended against exempting proposed small business investment companies from protection it provides to investors.

PARIS, April 27 -- The victory for nationalist candidates in the French Togoland elections was expected here to bring demands for modification of the present statute of the territory toward greater independence.
Buddy Liss, designer for a Madison Avenue shop called "Women's Haberdashers," has been invited to show his fashions to Queen Elizabeth II of England.
Interested in a burro, a trip on the canals of the Netherlands or a $995 telescope? Call the Dry Dock Savings Bank.
HACKENSACK, N. J., April 28 -- Representatives of educational groups advocated tonight such measures as sales, personal income and corporation taxes to obtain additional school funds.

Like politicians awaiting election returns, athletic officials at the University of Southern California and Notre Dame are keeping fingers crossed this week. They're hoping to hear that Michael Giacinto has elected to attend their school this fall.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -Preliminary returns showed today that 77 per cent of the Klamath Indians of southern Oregon had voted to leave their valuable reservation and take cash for a share of the tribal assets.
The Gulf Oil Corporation has announced the election of Archie D. Gray as a senior vice president. The company also announced the election of three administrative vice presidents.
WESTBURY, L. I., April 28 -- A crowd that braved rain and fog, as well as the customary fluctuations of the form chart, saw a harness racing rarity tonight -- two dead heats in one race.
WASHINGTON, April 28 -- A contention by The New Yorker magazine that New York City was unconstitutionally taxing its advertising was dismissed today by the Supreme Court.

KIAMESHA LAKE, N. Y., April 28 -- The head of the Rabbinical Assembly of America appealed here today for the immediate convening of spiritual leaders of all faiths, the heads of the major political parties and scientists to cope with the problems concerning the suspension of nuclear weapon testing.
WASHINGTON, April 28 (AP) -- A missiles expert and the developer of polio vaccine were among seven persons honored as "great living Americans" today by the United States Chamber of Commerce.
CHICAGO, April 28 (AP) -Gov. William G. Stratton of Illinois today urged that Federal and state governments permit the oil and gas industry to operate free of controls wherever and whenever possible.

The Holy Trinity Protestant Episcopal Church in Brooklyn Heights will be reoponed next Sunday for religious services. The church, at Montague and Clinton Streets, has been closed since last July 21 because of a dispute between two factions in the congregation.
The Illinois State Toll Highway Commission borrowed $64,000,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance completion of 187 miles of tollways fanning out from Chicago.
WASHINGTON, April 28 -The Treasury's short-term bill rate rose today to an average of 1.367 per cent. Last week's average was 1.055 per cent.
In the discussion of the Rockefeller Brothers report, the following appears in the city edition of The Times of April 21:
A new classroom and library building, for which Barnard College officials broke ground yesterday, was hailed as promising still higher intellectual standards for the college's students.
Frankie Ryff, a Bronx lightweight, gave Johnny Gorman, a Brooklyn welterweight, a boxing lesson in the main event of ten rounds at the St. Nicholas Arena last night.
WASHINGTON, April 28 -The Administration proposed today a sweeping new subsidy program for the hard-hit mining industry.
WASHINGTON, April 28 -The Senate adopted tonight a union welfare and pension fund reports bill after fighting off a Republican drive to turn it into general labor legislation.
Transformation of the city's Bureau of Real Estate into a full-fledged department was recommended by City Administrator Charles F. Preusse yesterday in a report for Mayor Wagner.
WHEN the average citizen says: "I've got problems," he is suffering. Not so Charles Francis Preusse. Problems make him happy.

The Greater New York Fund marked its twentieth year yesterday with a luncheon for 1,000 of its loyal workers. The first announcement at the luncheon, held at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, was that the fund's goal this year had been set at $11,000,000.

CHICAGO, April 28 (AP) -- Pat Connors, one of Chicago s top polo players and a former member of the United States international riding team, was named chairman of the PanAmerican Games organizing committee for the modern pentathlon today. Harry Daniels of Chicago, a former Olympic swimmer, will organize the swimming section of the pentathlon.

Raincoats were the fashion as Governor Harriman helped educational and civic leaders yesterday in cornerstone ceremonies for the new building of the Fashion Institute of Technology. The building is at Twenty-seventh Street between Seventh and Eighth Avenues.
ALTHOUGH the public is not able to buy any of the Greek handicrafts now on exhibit at the Barbizon-Plaza Hotel, people who feel frustrated can turn to Doris Corcodilos.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 28 -- The United States will make "no attempt to embarrass the Soviet Union" or to press the "cold war" further when it asks the Security Council tomorrow to set up an inspection system of bomber flights over the Arctic.

A four-alarm fire broke out in the Penn Arcade Building on West Thirty-fourth Street at 2:35 o'clock this morning. The building at 154 West Thirty-fourth Street, runs through the block to Thirtythird Street.

LOS ANGELES, April 28 -As the National Association of Broadcasters opened its thirtysixth convention today, a visitor, John C. Doerfer, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, reported he "was out $12 in expenses even before left Washington."
NICOSIA, Cyprus, April 28 (Reuters) -- British servicemen and policemen today were ordered to carry arms at all times as a new terror wave threatened to break out on the island.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- There are plenty of Republican politics and service to personal political ambitions in the effort of Republicans led by Senator Knowland to attach general labor legislation to the Democratic bill, passed by the Senate tonight, requiring unions to make public reports of their pension and welfare funds.

At the request of the United States, the Security Council of the United Nations meets today to consider an American proposal for the establishment of an international inspection system for the Arctic regions. Its purpose is to allay the fear of surprise attacks across these areas.
SAN ANTONIO, April 28 (AP) -- Mexico dominated the fencing today and gained second place in the international modern pentathlon at Fort Sam Houston.
A Roman Catholic priest with a credo of friendly persuasion was persuaded yesterday to celebrate his seventieth birthday. He has been a labor mediator for thirty-five years.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., April 28 -- A Navy attempt to place in orbit an instrumented twenty-inch earth satellite failed tonight when the thirdstage rocket of the Vanguard vehicle did not fire.

WASHINGTON, April 28 (UP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today endorsed, with suggested changes, a bill to make Government-backed loans available to railroads and other common carriers for capital expenditures.
WASHINGTON, April 28 -Dr. Linus C. Pauling, leading biochemist, introduced today a new threat in atomic fall-out -a long-lived radioactive atom known as carbon 14.

Directors of the Bridgeport Brass Company yesterday elected Austin R. Zender president and promoted three other executives to vice president. Mr. Zender was formerly executive vice president. As president he succeeds Herman W. Steinkraus, who will continue as chairman, general manager and chief executive officer.
Two railroad proxy fights have been postponed; a third continues on schedule.

TANGIER, Morocco, April 28 (Reuters) -- Delegates from Tunisia, Morocco and Algeria conferring here on North African unity have reached "identity of views" about the war in Algeria, a communique said tonight.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -President Eisenhower challenged the Soviet Union today to support the United States proposal to set up an international inspection system for the Arctic zone to reduce mutual fears of a massive surprise attack.
DENVER, April 28 -- The idea of using the moon or artificial satellites for missile-launching platforms was discounted tonight by a former Pentagon official in charge of military research.
WARSAW, April 28 -- The word among informed Poles is that the "worst" of the new Belgrade-Moscow dispute is over.

Under the heading of "Unrest in Paraguay," The Times on April 8 gives a description of how things are in that country, based on considerations that could be justified only as the result of complete disregard of the actual facts in today's Paraguay, or as a deviation from the function in society which the press is expected to fulfill in a civilized society.

The military pay and incentive bill, which is scheduled to come before the Senate for a vote today, needs some re-thinking and rewording before passage. On the whole, the bill should help to provide both the material and psychological boost which the services require if they are to retain skilled professionals.

CHICAGO, April 28 -- Dr. Edward Stullken, principal of Montefiore School here and a board member of the Illinois Parent-Teachers Association, believes that P.-T.A.'s are in dire need of masculine influence.
Second thoughts about the future of trans-Atlantic ocean travel have led to the first postponement in more than twenty years of the building of a new passenger liner.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., April 28 (AP) -- The president of the New Haven Railroad said here today that unless the government provide emergency relief, twenty Eastern railroads, including his own, "are going to fold."

ALBANY, April 28 -- The Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court today upheld the State Education Commissioner's policy against requiring teachers to inform on colleagues they had known as Communists.

ATLANTIC CITY, April 28 -Physicians should promptly treat irregularities in heartbeat in patients with heart disease, a team of four researchers at the University of California at Los Angeles Medical School suggested today. They spoke here at the opening of the thirtyninth annual meeting of the American College of Physicians.
ROME, April 28 -- Samuel Alphonsus Cardinal Stritch was resting here tonight after amputation of his right arm, where a bloodclot had plugged the main artery.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, April 28 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon began a goodwill tour of South America today with crowds and officials demanding that the United States mend its inter-American fences.

The sixteen members of the 1958 metropolitan all-scholastic swimming team were honored at a dinner at the New York Athletic Club last night. The twelfth annual affair was held under the sponsorship of the N. Y. A. C. Swimmers Club.
ADEN, April 28 (Reuters) -Rebel Arab snipers attacked a British relief force speeding to the rescue of a lonely fort besieged by 300 Arab tribesmen, wounding one British soldier.

STRASBOURG, France, April 28 (Reutes) -- The ministerial committee of the fifteen-nation Council of Europe voted today to develop cooperation with the recently established European common market and Atomic Energy Community.

Stockholders in the Standard Oil Company (Ohio) elected three new directors at the annual meeting in Cleveland yesterday. They are T. Keith Glennan, president of the Case Institute of Technology; Richard C. Sauer, vice president of supply and distribution, and Sidney A. Swensrud, former chairman of the Gulf Oil Company and a former executive vice president of Sohio.
The Los Angeles Dodgers are running ahead of the record attendance pace while spearheading a National League increase of more than 50 per cent over last season.

-LOME, French Togoland, April 28 (Reuters) -- Thousands of jubilant Togolese danced through the streets of Lome tonight shouting "Freedom!" after a decisive election victory for the National Unity party.
LOUISVILLE, April 28 -Jimmy Jones reached out to the Jamaica Race Track today and corralled Ismael Valenzuela for possible turf fame and glory.

The Women's Committee has formulated plans for the Lambs Spring Gambol and Testimonial Dinner to be held on May 10 in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. Robert W. Dowling will be the guest of honor.

The chief counsel for the rank and file rebels who sought vainly to bar James R. Hoffa from the presidency of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters asked yesterday that the union pay him $209,795 for his efforts.

Some good things may come out of Prime Minister Nehru's decision to get away from his office and from New Delhi for a few weeks and really take a period of rest. He needs it, physically. He has been working too hard, at too much, for too long. He is tired, and there is good reason why he would be.

Thirty-three-year-old Robert Smithdas is deaf and blind, the result of cerebral spinal meningitis that struck him when he was 5. He tells his story in "Life at My Fingertips," which Doubleday will publish Thursday. Inspired by Helen Keller's example, he attended Perkins Institution where the teachers helped him rise above his handicaps.

The Oxford English Dictionary, unabridged, puts a surprising asterisk beside its word "spring fever." It is an Americanism, of course, traced back ninety-nine years on the record, and the * "indicates a word or form not actually found but of which the existence is inferred."

A new program of teaching and research in the industrial and public health aspects of radiation has received a grant of $500,000 from the Rockefeller Foundation. The program is being conducted jointly by New York University-Bellevue Medical Center and the Atomic Energy Commission Health and Safety Laboratory.

A retired former director of the American-Hawaiian Steamship Company is soliciting proxies against the management slate of directors and in favor of liquidating the company or the purchase of outstanding stock at liquidation value, it was learned yesterday.
Vic Buschman has been in town for the last two weeks and he has seen all the musical comedies. So he is going home to Wisconsin today.

The wiretap conspiracy retrial of James R. Hoffa, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, was put off again yesterday because of the continuing investigation of the union by a Senate committee.

Harvey Sorkin and Lawrence Herman, real estate investors, have contracted to buy the sixstory apartment house at the northwest corner of Broadway and 174th Street for cash above mortgages of $430,000. The building, known as 635 West 174th Street, contains sixty-two dwelling units and ten stores.
A surgeon sought in the knife slaying of a Brooklyn nurse talked with a priest Sunday night at St. Patrick's Cathedral, the police said last night.
Dr. Albert Schweitzer is calling for a summit conference whose sole purpose would be to renounce nuclear weapons.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -Allen W. Dulles, Director of the Central Intelligence Agency, said today that rapid Soviet economic progress posed the most serious peacetime challengethe United States had ever faced.
CHICAGO, April 28 -- Daniel Catton Rich, director of the Chicago Art Institute, announced his resignation today.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -Indonesian pilots have been ordered to Egypt for training in the operation of Czechoslovakand Polish-made fighter and bomber planes, diplomatic sources said today. The first Indonesian pilots may already have arrived in Cairo.

DETROIT, April 28 (AP) -- Passenger car output so far this year is more than three-quarters of a million units behind that of the comparable week of 1957, and the factories continue to hold down production.
WASHINGTON, April 28 -The Supreme Court reversed today a lower court order requiring a sharp reduction in Panama Canal tolls.

WASHINGTON, April, 28 -The international bank for reconstruction and development struck out on a new financial line today with a $10,000,000 loan for modernization of eleven relatively small Austrian concerns.

CAIRO, April 17 -- The Soviet bloc has jumped with somewhat heavy feet into the hallowed bourgeois domain of haute couture. As a result, Cairo for the last week has been the scene of an East-West "battle of the sack."
Many people are made actually ill by the lives they lead, a medical researcher reported here yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 28 -The Senate Agriculture Committee heard today that a meatpacking lobby was seeking to kill a bill aimed at compelling humane slaughter of livestock.
Queens Democrats formally demanded last night a place on this year's state-wide party ticket.
WASHINGTON, April 28 -The Senate Judiciary Committee approved today two more proposals by Senator John Marshall Butler to upset recent Supreme Court decisions.

CHARLOTTE, N. C., April 28 -- The first of two efforts to force the Presbyterian Church in the U. S. (Southern) to reverse its antisegregation stand was overwhelmingly defeated here today by the denomination's General Assembly.

The Alabama Gas Corporation reported yesterday that "the coldest heating season through March 31 in central Alabama's history" produced recrord gas sales for the utility. Earnings for twelve months ended March 31 were said to be "higher than could normally be expected, while earnings for the previous twelve months were lower than expected, due to the extremely wide fluctuation of temperature for the heating seasons of each of these two years."

TIFLIS, U. S. S. R., April 28 -- Twenty-five thousand Georgians cheered for rock 'n roll music and equally fast basketball tonight as two of the United States' best-known export commodities came to this ancient Southern Soviet city.
WASHINGTON, April 28 -The Supreme Court struck down a Kansas picketing restriction today as a violation of union members' right to free speech.
DAVID GLAZER, clarinetist, played a sonata recital with Artur Balsam, pianist, at Carnegie Hall last night. It displayed the merits of both artists to good advantage.

AS the first in a series of events celebrating the seventy-fifth anniversary of the opening of the Brooklyn Bridge, the Brooklyn Museum has assembled an exhibition marking the event. Included in the display are paintings, prints, photographs and materials from periodicals, together with memorabilia such as souvenir cards and a silver spoon as well as original plans and drawings for the architectural and engineering enterprises connected with the building of the bridge.
AUGUSTA, Ga., April 28 (AP) -- Following is the text of President Eisenhower's new note to Soviet Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev:
ANNE FOGARTY has cut out her last paper doll. In her new collection for Saks Fifth Avenue, she prefers to take inspiration from a china figurine.

NAPLES, April 28 (AP) -- Mexico's No. 2 player, Mario Llamas, defeated Giuseppe Maggiolli of Italy, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 1, and Eric Lundquist of Sweden defeated Gian Enrico Maggi of Italy, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 4, \ in the opening round of the Naples tennis tournament today.

WASHINGTON, April 28 (UP) -- Dr. James A. Van Allen, who directs all United States satellite experiments, said today that Congress should provide at least $500,000,000 a year for the proposed civilian space agency.

CAIRO, April 28 -- Responsible circles in Cairo speculated today that President Gamal Abdel Nasser might be going to Moscow specifically to seek a substantial reduction in the cost of arms purchased from the Soviet bloc by Egypt and Syria.
"STUDIO ONE IN HOLLYWOOD" offered its viewers a powerful drama and a superb performance last night over Channel 2. Adrian Spies was the author and Paul Douglas the star.
The American steel industry is frozen into the number of producers now in existence, a witness testified yesterday.

HARRIMAN, N. Y., April 28 -- A group of Protestant clergymen was told today that religious leaders should "set the moral tone" in combating racial bias in employment, housing and public accommodations.
The American steel industry is frozen into the number of producers now in existence, a witness testified yesterday.

HARRIMAN, N. Y., April 28 -- A group of Protestant clergymen was told today that religious leaders should "set the moral tone" in combating racial bias in employment, housing and public accommodations.
There may be a rerun of the most thrilling race of last Saturday's thrilling Penn Relays.

The city will get a double benefit from the joint Park and Sanitation Department project for filling in with waste material an expanse of marshlands in a Queens area north of Idlewild Airport and ultimately creating on this site 264 acres in new parks.
Private contributions to higher education have risen sharply in the last two years, a biennial survey disclosed yesterday.
A real estate investment operator that promised investors 15 per cent interest was charged in Manhattan Supreme Court yesterday with defrauding investors of $200,000.

Blood will be collected by the Red Cross today at B. Altman Co., Thirty-fourth Street and Fifth Avenue; Queensview Housing, 21-15 Thirty-fourth Avenue, Astoria, Queens, and Associated Hospital Service of New York, 80 Lexington Avenue.
There's more to the revised college football rules than had met the eye on the basis of initial reports issued after last January's rules committee meeting in Fort Lauderdale, Fla.

BOB HOPE may yet emerge as the Will Rogers of his age. He's stepping up the number of his political jokes, and last night he offered several fairly good ones in a monologue on the "Eddie Fisher Show" over Channel 4.

DEMAREST, N. J., April 29 -- The spring conference on regional planning of the Northern Valleye Planning Association was held here tonight at the Northern Valleye Regional High School. It was attended by 350 persons.

MOST New Yorkers who feed peanuts and popcorn to Central Park's gray squirrels do so out of the goodness of their hearts. It may startle them to learn that this diet may encourage blindness and baldness in the little gray beggars.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- Senator Ralph E. Flanders, Vermont Republican, announced tonight he would not be a candidate for re-election in November. It was Mr. Flanders who initiated the fight in 1954 to censure the late Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin.

WOMEN in West Germany may never be as famous for their chic as Parisiennes, but they are becoming noticeably more well-dressed. According to Gerald Georg, director of the German Fashion Institute, which is promoting West Germany's fashion industry, more and more women there are caring about their clothes.

MOST family Histories are written by industrious spinsters obsessed by genealogy, and even members of the family concerned find them heavy going. A few are written by scholars and men of letters interested in the persistence of hereditary talent among the Lowells or the Adamses or the Plantagenets.

NEWARK, April 29 -- A former insurance executive was given a year's suspended sentence, put on two-year probation and fined $2,000 today in connection with an investigation of kickbacks in union welfare fund insurance.

THE thirty-fourth annual fashion show of the Parsons School of Design, always an interesting event on the spring fashion calendar, was presented yesterday at the school's auditorium, 410 East Fifty-fourth Street.
The Museum of Modern Art, which has been closed since April 15 because of fire, will reopen tomorrow.
The police last night made thirty-five arrests in five hours in a city-wide round-up of narcotics dealers and users.

On May 30 a fifth public links golf course will be opened at Bethpage State Park, Farmingdale, L. I. It will be known as the Yellow Course. The other four courses -- the first opened in 1931 -- also follow the color scheme in nomenclature.

The city never looked gayer. The Department of Commerce and Public Events has helped to bring a full array of spring to many of Manhattan's major avenues. It has dressed them with king-sized planter boxes filled with flowers. Thus is announced to one and all that New York's 1958 "Salute to the Seasons" is under way.
CHICAGO, April 29 (AP) -- The May wheat contract, with a gain of 1 5/8 cents a bushel, was the liveliest grain future in a rather slow day today on the Board of Trade.

CLEVELAND, April 29 (UP) -- The Cleveland Barons of the American Hockey League today traded an all-league defenseman, Steve Kraftcheck, to the Toronto Maple Leafs of the National League for one player and an undisclosed amount of cash.
Quick and admittedly off-hand reaction of an important segment of the metals industry yesterday to the Administration's proposal to subsidize it was that the plan was impractical and too costly.

Futures prices closed generally lower yesterday on the New York exchanges. Potatoes, cocoa, copper, zinc, lead, hides and soybean oil declined; wool and cottonseed oil rose, and price movements for sugar, coffee and rubber were mixed.
The City Council unanimously approved yesterday two bills designed to reduce fire hazards in factory buildings, It also passed a bill calling for mandatory retirement of firemen at the age of 65.
WARSAW, April 29 (AP) -- Poland's Communist Government dismissed tonight Karol Kuryluk, Minister of Culture.
CHICAGO. April 29 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

The third big national Sports Car Club of America championship rally in the East will be run May 9, 10 and 11 in Ohio. This is the intriguing Ohio 24, created some four years ago by Tomi Thompson, now rated as one of the nation's top rally organizers.

Baltimore borrowed $24,225,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance public improvements. The city raised the money by a sale of bonds maturing serially from 1961 to 1982 to a syndicate headed by First National Bank of Chicago and Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., at an interest cost of 2.508 per cent.

LOUISVILLE, April 29 -- Tim Tam of the Calumet Farm won the $16,200 Derby Trial in most impressive fashion today. The son of Tom Fool scored by a mere neck over Ebony Pearl of the Maine Chance Farm, but the manner in which he scored showed clearly that Tim Tam was the best colt on the track.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 29 -- An economic commission for Africa was established today by unanimous vote of the United Nations Economic and Social Council.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 29 -- Following are the texts of statements of speakers before the Security Council today:
LONDON, April 29 -- Prices again declined in all sections of the stock market today.
Representative James J. Delaney of Long Island City, Queens, was proposed yesterday as a possible Democratic candidate for the United States Senate.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- The House of Representatives approved today, 289 to 94, a bill to authorize the building and sale under heavy subsidies of two new passenger superliners for Atlantic and Pacific operations.
LOS ANGELES, April 29 (AP) -- Bob Friend hurled a four-hitter tonight as the Pittsburgh Pirates whipped the Los Angeles Dodgers, 7 -- 1, for their fourth straight victory.

RUTHERFORD, N. J., April 29 -- David J. Brittain, former principal of the high school at Clinton, Tenn., was appointed last night as administrative assistant to the Superintendent of Schools here. He will begin his duties in the $6,000-a-year post on Aug. 11.

MONTREAL, April 29 (UP) -- The Montreal Canadiens, who recently won their third straight Stanley Cup championship, today placed three players on the official National Hockey League All-Star team for the 1957-58 season.
WASHINGTON, April 29 (UP) -- Independent retailers urged Congress today to pass a law forbidding their competitors to sell name-brand appliances and other products at less than list price.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, April 29 (AP) -- Bermuda held the lead in Amorita Cup competition for international one-design yachts today as the second day of competition in International Race Week was completed.
The sponsor of "Sid Caesar Invites You" decided yesterday to discontinue backing the television program May 25, when its current contract expires.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., April 29 -- 'A small component or wire" was blamed today for last night's failure of the final stage rocket in the Navy's satellite-launching vehicle.
The Transit Authority estimated yesterday that it would end the fiscal year on June 30 with an operating deficit of $8,500,000.

The opening of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's interclub team matches was marred by wet grounds and fog yesterday. The matches in New Jersey, Westchester and Long Island usually draw 600 golfers. Only the New Jersey district district, with five series, was able to complete its schedule
CHAPPAQUA, N. Y., April 29 -- Commuters arriving at the New York Central Railroad station here this morning received their morning newspapers free, courtesy of the Chappaqua National Bank.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- A man with many of the classical attributes of the old-line British civil servant has been one of the chief conciliators in the settlement of the Suez Canal compensation dispute.
ANTIQUARIANS may not approve, but the general public will be delighted with the newest antiques dealer on Fifth Avenue.
With leaden skies and raw winds prevailing, the Velvet Acres' First Asking scored a nose victory over the Merrick Stable's Sandy's Joy in the $7,500 Central Park Handicap at Jamaica yesterday.
HARRIMAN, N. Y., April 29 -- Thirty-three Protestant leaders signed a general statement today upholding the right of equal opportunity in housing, employment, public accommodation and education.

Richard C. Patterson, the Commissioner of Comerce and Public Events of the City of New York, was named yesterday as the fifth recipient of the Gold Medal Award presented annually by the Metropolitan Association of the Amateur Athletic Union.
It took some time for Bill Skowron to get around to showing the fans in major-league towns how he had belted homers down South this spring. Yesterday he regained the touch, and then some.

The first new boat in the Fire Department's modernization of its marine division was commissioned yesterday. She is the Smoke II, a speedy fireboat and personnel carrier that looks much like a cabin cruiser. The boat, fully equipped, cost $80,000.

LAUREL, Md., April 29 (UP) -- Mardi, a late-developing 3-year-old colt, showed plenty of speed today in registering a two-length victory in the six-furlong feature. The victor was not nominated for the Kentucky Derby, Preakness or Belmont Stakes.

ONE of the most diverse exhibitions in its history will open to the public today at the Whitney Museum. It will include 180 paintings, sculptures and drawings by 137 artists, and it will illustrate the principal tendencies in American art from the realism of The Eight in the opening years of the century to work by the extreme abstract and abstract-expressionist painting of the postwar period.

AS part of its regular program, a class in contemporary art at Finch College has, for the second time, assembled an exhibition of paintings by ten major Italian painters at 60 East Seventy-eight Street.
WASHINGTON, April 29 -- A White House move to curtail the military services' individual contacts with Congress was disclosed today before the House Armed Services Committee.

BERLIN, April 29 -- Anastas I. Mikoyan, a Soviet First Deputy Premier, told East German functionaries today that his four-day visit to West Germany had furthered friendly relations of his country with the whole German people.
Representatives of American Airlines and the Air Line Pilots Association will resume contract negotiations today. The meeting place was not announced.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission ruled today that railroads and truckers may not refuse service at a plant because of "riots, strikes, picketing or other labor disturbances."

NEW DELHI, April 29 -- The Indian Government has approved a plan under which the Hindustan Motors Company will manufacture trucks in collaboration with the General Motors Corporation of the United States.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 29 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold backed a United States resolution today for international inspection of the Arctic regions as a measure against surprise attack.
LONDON, April 29 (Reuters) -- Pained cries of "nonsense!" echoed in the staid Royal Academy of Arts here tonight.

LOUISVILLE, April 29 -- Silky Sullivan remained in his barn and thoughtfully munched on a bale of hay while they were running the Derby Trial today. For a while it seemed Conn McCreary, a come-from-behind jockey, would try to infringe on Silky's copyright for Garrison finishes. But there is no need for Himself to start a lawsuit.

On a business morning several years ago, just before 9 A. M., Fred J. Zepper's heart stopped beating after fifty-four years. He slumped to the floor of the taxicab he was driving, and the cab plunged into a crowd.
WASHINGTON, April 29 -- The Democratic leader of the Senate went out of his way today to keep the door open for an anti-recession tax cut.

A new two-story office building containing 25 000 square feet at 135-20 Thirty-ninth Avenue, Flushing, Queens, has beenl purchased by investors from the IM. ichael Contracting Company, the builder. The seller leased iback the second floor for its own occupancy.

The answers to many questions concerning United States missile preparedness are given in "The United States Air Force Report on the Ballistic Missile." Scheduled for July 2 publication by Doubleday, it will make public the official policies and programs of the Air Force with reference to the ballistic missile.
ALBANY, April 29 (AP) -- A State Police official said today that accidents on the thruway had increased in recent months because a half dozen troopers had failed to execute their duties properly.
ROME, April 29 -- A preliminary accord on compensation for Egypt's nationalization of the Suez Canal Company was signed here today.
After a lapse of four days the world chess championship match between Vassily Smyslov, the titletolder, and Mikhail Botvinnik was resumed yesterday, according to a report from Moscow.

The stock market yesterday was dull until the close, when United States Steel announced it had covered its 75-cent dividend with an ample $1.04 in the first 1958 quarter. Trading on the Pacific Coast Stock Exchange displayed the life that New York had lacked.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 29 (AP) -- Dave Philley blasted a 370-foot home run in the fifth inning today and sent Philadelphia's Phillies to a 7-4 victory over the San Francisco Giants.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, April 29 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon made a surprise visit to Montevideo University's Law School today and told many skeptical students why the United States had good relations with Latin-American dictators.

CHARLOTTE, N. C., April 29 -- The Presbyterian Church in the U. S. (Southern) voiced overwhelming opposition here today to the use of church buildings for classrooms as a means of circumventing the Supreme Court ruling against segregation in the public schools.

EVERYTHING is shipshape at Altman's. Despite the tangle of wisteria and the profusion of Colonial columns, this store navigated a brilliant show of boating clothes through its dinning room, known as the Charleston Gardens.
WASHINGTON, April 29 -- Orthodox rabbinical and lay groups told Congress today that a bill aimed at compelling "humane'' slaughter of livestock would infringe religious freedom.

WASHINGTON, April 29 (UP) -- A bill to bar interstate advertising of alcoholic beverages was denounced today by the liquor industry as "unfair, un-American, unnecessary, unconstitutional, unwarranted and unsound."

Congressional records of Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr. will be turned over to the Federal grand jury investigating his income tax returns. The records cover his attendance, his employment of office workers and their canceled pay vouchers from 1951 through 1955.
WASHINGTON, April 29 -- The Government published revised rules and regulations for its oil import curbs today.
Helen Hayes will be seen for the first time next season in the theatre bearing her name. She will appear there in Eugene O'Neill's melodrama, "A Touch of the Poet," opening Oct. 2.

NEW DELHI, India, April 29 -- Outside New Delhi's circular Parliament building today about 150 women sat on the lawn beneath the statue of a British viceroy, sipped iced tea and handed printed petitions to passers-by.

KIAMESHA LAKE, N. Y., April 29 -- A Jewish theologian stressed tonight that the future spiritual status of Jews the world over depended essentially on the rapport between them and Jews living in Israel.
The recent suggestion that the Girl Scouts might profitably enhance their public standing by word-of-mouth publicity is a refreshing throwback to an earlier and less complex age.
Net income of the nation's largest steel producer, the United States Steel Corporation, dropped 46 per cent in the first quarter from that of the similar 1957 period.
The American Tobacco Company and its subsidiaries raised their profits by 22 per cent to $12,439,000 in the first quarter of this year, from $10,150,000 in the first three months of 1957.

Under its directors, Dimitri Mitropoulos and Leonard Bernstein, the New York Philharmonic Symphony has begun a seven weeks' tour of Latin America which will encompass twelve countries, twenty-one cities and thirty-eight concerts. It would be hard to make a more intelligent choice of a cultural ambassador than this orchestra.

Mrs. A. Harris Gaines co-chairman of arrangements for the Asphalt Garden Party for the May 22 benefit of the Girls Club of New York, will give a tea this afternoon for committee members at her home at 430 East Fifty-seventh Street.
A seasonal fog disrupted airline schedules yesterday morning and delayed harbor traffic before dissipating during the afternoon.
Frigidaire and Max Factor, two major accounts up for grabs, are still several weeks away from deciding about new agencies.
ADEN, April 29 (AP) -- British planes dropped 1,000-pound bombs and fired rockets on rebel tribesmen near the besieged fort of Assarir today.
WASHINGTON, April 29 -- An economy stand by the Budget Bureau is threatening to revive the Congressional Administration fight over the development of atomic power.

DMITRI SHOSTAKOVICH'S String Quartet No. 6, composed in 1956, received its American premiere last night in Carl Fischer Concert Hall. The work, played by the National String Quartet, was on a program presented by New Music Concerts under the direction of Eric Simon.

James Cash Penney, 83-year-old founder of the J. C. Penney Company, department store chain, yesterday announced that he had relinquished the post of chairman of the board in favor of Albert W. Hughes, former president of the company.
WASHINGTON, April 29 -- The Senate today passed a $577,000,000 annual military pay increase designed to attract and hold a highly skilled career force in the armed services.
WASHINGTON, April 29 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today gave the Union Pacific Railroad Company renewed authority to acquire control of the Spokane International Railroad.

TOKYO, April 29 (UP) -- Three Japanese attorneys stole the ashes of Gen. Hideki Tojo and six other war criminals after their execution in 1948. They will bring the ashes out of hiding this year to enshrine them in a monument, it was disclosed today.

TORONTO, April 29 (Canadian Press) -- The International Petroleum Company, Ltd., in the three months ended March 31, had estimated consolidated net earnings of $7,000,000, compared with $11,000,000 in the corresponding period of 1957 and $8,000,000 in last year's fourth quarter.

It is all to the good that the Senate finally mastered, as it did, the cross-currents -- political, personal and pro or anti labor -- through which it floundered for several days. That the vote in favor of the welfare fund regulation bill was unanimous shows that the Senators themselves felt that way too, in the end.

The trend of consumer buying holds the key to whether the present recession will continue or whether it will soon blow itself out, according to the presidents of the country's twelve regional Reserve Banks. The presidents gave these views in their answers to a questionnaire from the chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, Harry F. Byrd of Virginia.
THE field of cotton on the fifth floor of Bergdorf Goodman is a prize example of how pleasantly the present trapeze-chemise dilemma has resolved itself.

HAVANA, April 29 -- Rural guards have captured thirteen rebels in the district of Quemados de Pineda east of Pinar del Rio, capital of Pinar del Rio Province, a communique of Camp Columbia Army Headquarters said tonight.
Two major offerings of top-grade corporate bonds amounting to $190,000,000 are on the market today.
GENEVA, April 29 -- Ichiro Kawasaki of Japan was elected president of the International Labor Organization's Maritime Conference today.
WASHINGTON, April 29 -- The debate on this nation's atomic energy and arms-limitation policies is reaching a critical point under very odd and unfortunate circumstances.
CHICAGO, April 29 -- Mayor Richard J. Daley today called a of shipping and union meeting officials in an attempt to settle a strike that has tied up foreign shipping in Great Lakes ports.

Ramon Serra, 20 - year - old leader of an adolescent street gang, was indicted yesterday for first-degree murder in the killing of Michael Ramos, 17. Ramos, another street gang figure, was shot in a Bronx candy store last Saturday night.
ROME, April 29 -- Following is the text of the principles of agreement signed in Rome today for settlement of the Suez Canal compensation dispute:
Dental malocclusion seems to be a "disease" of civilization, Dr. Bertram S. Kraus, physical anthropologist at the University of Washington, said here yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 29 -- Unemployment in the nation declined by 78,000 from mid-March to mid-April, from 5,198,000 to 5,120,000.

William A. Hewitt, president of Deere Co., large producer of farm equipment, told stockholders in Moline, Ill., yesterday that the company's business started to improve last month. Sales lagged during several preceding months because of adverse weather.

IF there was a doctor in the house at the Phoenix Theatre last night, he may not have enjoyed himself. Nearly everyone else seemed to at the first performance of "The Imaginary Invalid" by Le Theatre du Nouveau Monde.

Single tickets for next season's "Thursday evening previews" by the New York Philharmonic will sell at the same price as the orchestra's Friday and Saturday concerts, the Philharmonic announced yesterday. Season subscribers, however will be able to purchase seats at greater savings.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., April 29 -- The Eastman String Quartet was the attraction tonight at the Festival of American Music at the Eastman School of Music. Its members are Joseph Knitzer and John Celentano, violinists; Francis Tursi, viola, and George Miquelle, 'cellist. All are members of the Eastman School faculty.
WASHINGTON, April 29 -- The sixteenth National Exhibition of Prints opening at the Library of Congress Thursday has a new look.
MIDDLESEX BOROUGH, N. J., Wednesday, April 30 -- Five-year-old Michael Sickle 3d was believed kidnapped yesterday afternoon from in front of his home at 736 Drake Avenue.
Awards were presented yesterday to winners of the thirty-fifth annual New York City Poetry Contests for high school students.
NORWALK, Conn., April 29 -- Gertrude, a very tired kangaroo, is back home after after a two-day marathon that took her to the neighboring towns of Darien and New Canaan.
The term of a Kings County grand jury was extended yesterday until Sept. 15 so that it could continue its investigation into racketeering in the private garbage collection industry.
WASHINGTON, April 29 (AP) -- Robert T. Bartley was nominated by President Eisenhower today for another seven-year term on the Federal Communications Commission.

WESTBURY, L. I., April 29 -- Following a hearing at Roosevelt Raceway today, Commissioner George P. Monaghan of the New York State Harness Racing Commission said that he would conduct a thirty-night experiment here, permitting an owner or a trainer to start two horses to pace or trot as an entry in tests of AA or higher classifications.
WESTPORT, Conn., April 29 -- The mystery of the missing headstones appeared today to have been solved.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- Employers and unions who use hiring halls or their equivalent have received a three-month grace period to bring their agreements and practices into conformity with the Taft-Hartley Law.

TIFLIS, U. S. S. R, April 29 -- A United States basketball team slid to a 59-41 victory over the Georgian Republic's All-Stars tonight in a sloshy game that no one wanted played except 25,000 Soviet fans.
First New York performances of two large choral works were presented at Carnegie Hall last night by the National Orchestral Association, Leon Barzin conducting.

Texas Eastern Transmission Corporation reported yesterday a 22 per cent increase first quarter natural gas revenues. Orville S. Carpenter, president, told stockholders at the annual meeting at Wilmington Del., that the improvement was "principally because of increased natural gas sales made possible by expanded transmission facilities put into service in the fall of 1957."
The United States has asked Australia and Argentina to take over two Antarctic bases it will discontinue next year for budgetary reasons.

CHICAGO, April 29 (AP) -- Senator Robert S. Kerr, Democrat of Oklahoma, today said it was apparent that oil was being brought into the United States "in such increasing quantities as to threaten the very foundation of the domestic oil industry."
