WASHINGTON, April 29 -- Lieut. Gen. James H. Doolittle sought today to discourage military efforts to curb the role of the proposed civilian space agency.
ATLANTIC CITY, April 29 -- Medical teamwork in the last four years has made substantial progress in improving treatment for stroke victims, the American College of Physicians was told today.

TANGIER, Morocco, April 29 -- The conference of Tunisian, Algerian nationalist and Moroccan political representatives will recommend in its final communique tomorrow the formation of an Algerian revolutionary government in exile.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 29 -- Following are the texts of draft resolutions by the United States and the Soviet Union debated today before the Security Council:
ALBANY, April 29 (AP) -- During March, 116 New York motorists losts their operator's licenses and automobile registrations for driving without liability insurance.

Arrangements of daffodils, forsythia and pansies carried out the blue and gold color scheme for the third annual Heart of America Ball, which took place last night in the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria.
When Van Cliburn returns to New York he will get a ticker-tape reception such as has been accorded channel swimmers, military heroes and statesmen but never a musician.
DETROIT, April 29 -- The General Motors Corporation announced today that it would terminate its current agreement with United Automobile Workers at midnight May 29.

MOSCOW, April 29 -- Andrei A. Gromyko indicated today that the Soviet Union would reject the United States proposal for aerial inspection in the Arctic to prevent surprise attacks by planes flying over that region.
PARIS, April 29 -- Former Premier Rene Pleven turned his attention today from Algeria to France's other major problem -- her economic health.

Frank H. Bowles, president of the College Entrance Examination Board, told a scholarship group last night that school segregation bred differences in education. He said it should be replaced by an integrated, single system of schools.
NEW DELHI, India., April 29 -- Jawaharlal Nehru announced tonight that he wanted to be relieved of the daily burdens of the office of Prime Minister of India.
New York gave a warm and relieved welcome yesterday to the first commercial airliner to arrive here flying the flag of Ireland.

A MAN called yesterday to ask what an angler does when he catches a six-inch trout that is hooked through the eye or otherwise mortally injured. The general trout minimum size is seven inches. The question has been asked many times.
TEHERAN, Iran, April 29 (AP) -- An American oil company has entered the breach in the standard fifty-fifty split of Middle Eastern oil profits created by an Italian company in Iran last year.

Thanks to leadership by the Administration and a number of legislators and to the support of church, civic and other groups and a number of newspapers, including The Times, migrant farm workers who come to New York State this summer can hope for greater protection against unscrupulous crew leaders.

DUESSELDORF, Germany, April 29 -- A current of hope again runs through this partitioned country that perhaps, as the result of negotiations now dimly shaping up between East and West, some formula may be found that leads to German unification.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 29 -- A general membership meeting of the Screen Directors Guild will be held Saturday at the organization's headquarters here. This was the only information that came out of the special meeting last night of board members and the contract negotiating committee that has failed to make headway in collective bargaining discussions with the Association of Motion Picture Producers.

In a story (April 16) on the Geneva Conference on the Law of the Sea your statement that the three-mile territorial sea was based on the range of cannon in the eighteenth century falls short of the mark.

CANNE DELLA BATTAGLIA, Italy, April 27 -- The remains of human bones strewn over a vast plain on the banks of the River Ofanto bear witness to the fact that one of the most famous battles in history was fought here more than twenty-one and a half centuries ago.
The Republican state leadership has been enlisted in a renewed and concerted effort to obtain a Federal judgeship for Representative Frederic R. Coudert Jr.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- A research expert testified today that styling "plays a relatively minor role in increasing the total number of cars sold in a given year." He said, however, that styling was "a big factor in deciding which company" would get the business.
The rank-and-file reform faction in the International Brotherhood of Teamsters found itself almost as deeply involved in controversy yesterday as the union the rebels have been trying to clean up.
CHICAGO, April 29 (AP) -- Warren Spahn yielded two homers by Lee Walls today, but registered his third victory as the Milwaukee Braves defeated the Chicago Cubs, 8 -- 4.

ROME, April 29 -- Samuel Alphonsus Cardinal Stritch was reported today to be recovering "splendidly" from the amputation of his right arm yesterday. He had a good night's sleep without sedatives and appeared to be cheerful.
PARIS, April 29 -- A large group of primary, secondary and university teachers has suggested an Algerian peace plan based on virtual independence for Algeria, now part of France.
NEWARK, April 29 -- The Rev. Donald MacAdie, rector of St. John's Protestant Episcopal Church in Passaic, today was elected Suffragan Bishop for the Episcopal Diocese of Newark.

CHICAGO, April 29 -- Ben Moreell, board chairman of the Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation, was named today winner of the Washington Award, the engineering profession's highest honor. He will receive the award at a ceremony here May 9.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- Dr. Detlev W. Bronk was re-elected today to a third four-year term as president of the National Academy of Sciences at its annual meeting. He also heads the Rockefeller Institute.

I have been horrified within the last few weeks by learning that the old cruel way of slaughtering animals for food is still being widely used, and that still, just as in my youth, there is no law to forbid it.
SAN ANTONIO, Tex., April 29 P--Mexico took the lead in the international modern pentathion today by scoring heavily in the third event, pistol shooting.
GEORGE DAVID WOODS, the New Yorker who helped settle the financial dispute arising from the nationalization of the Universal Suez Canal Company, is chairman of the First Boston Corporation.

After nine weeks of discussion in which 700 delegates from eighty-seven nations participated, the Geneva conference on maritime law and freedom of the seas, sponsored by the United Nations, has come to an end with the adoption of five draft treaties.
WASHINGTON, April 29 -- Following is the text of a statement issued today by the Democratic advisory council entitled "A Program to Meet the Recession:"
WASHINGTON, April 29 (UP) -- Dr. Willard F. Libby, said today that radioactive carbon 14 from nuclear tests was having "a very minute effect" on mankind.
Three railroads serving the New York area yesterday asked for substantial increases in commuter fares on their ferries across the Hudson River.

Stores along the route of last Saturday's Loyalty Day parade reported yesterday the parade had cost them from 15 to 30 per cent of their expected sales. The parade went along Fifth Avenue between Sixty-sixth and Thirty-eighth Streets.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- The B-47 Stratojet bombers, mainstay of the Strategic Air Command, are beginning to wear out. That was the explanation given by the Air Force today for retiring forty-five early models of the $1,900,000 medium bombers.
Dr. Louis J. Long, president of Wells College, was elected chairman of the board of the Empire State Foundation of Liberal Arts Colleges yesterday. He will also continue as treasurer.

LOS ANGELES, April 29 -- Increased efforts to create stronger and more dynamic broadcasting journalism on behalf of the public was urged by industry leaders today at the thirty-sixth annual convention of the National Association of Broadcasters.

First quarter sales and rentals of the American Can Company reached a new high of $220,137,507, William C. Stolk, president, told 1,000 shareholders yesterday at the annual meeting in the Astor Hotel here. They compared with the previous record of $213,083,645 in the initial quarter of 1957.

The House of Detention for Women, termed inadequate since 1932, two years after it was built, was inspected by city officials yesterday. City Council President Abe Stark recommended an immediate search for another building to take its overload of prisoners.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 29 (AP) -- Horace Stoneham, president of the San Francisco Giants, today turned down an offer to televise away-from-home Giant games on a nonprofit basis.

The Allied Stores Corporation, which includes Stern's and Gertz of New York in its department store chain, achieved record sales of $632,813,514 in the fiscal year ended Jan. 31. This was an increase of $17,040,756, or 2.8 per cent, over the $615,772,758 in the previous fiscal year.

It is difficult to escape the impression that something is stirring in the top ranks of Soviet officialdom. Why, for example, did Premier Khrushchev find it necessary to attack Georgi M. Malenkov so vigorously in his Kiev speech last weekend ? Why has Pravda attacked the "Malenkov - Kaganovich - Molotov anti-party group" so often in recent weeks?
The Consulate General of Switzerland in New York and Murray Moss in East Flatbush, Brooklyn, are at swords' points over the Swiss coat of arms.
BERLIN, April 28 -- A proposed general equation of matter, expounded in detail last night by Prof. Werner Heisenberg in Leipzig, East Germany, ran into objections from Soviet physicists.
A majority of the country's sports writers recommended yesterday that any home run record that may be set because of the Los Angeles Coliseum's short left-field fence be declared invalid.
Twenty authors, artists and composers have received cash awards in the 1958 citations of the National Institute and American Academy of Arts and Letters.

MOSCOW, April 29 -- President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic flew into Moscow today aboard a Soviet jet airliner for several weeks of talks and travel in the Soviet Union. The Soviet Government rolled out the red carpet for the Arab leader.
TEL AVIV, Israel, April 29 -- United States Zionist leaders told Israelis celebrating the tenth anniversary of their independence tonight that they still were dependent on the Zionist movement.

CAIRO, April 29 (UP) -- The Government today stripped exiled King Farouk and fifty-eight members of his family of their Egyptian nationality. Eighteen other persons, including journalists, similarly were deprived of citizenship for "security" reasons.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- The Western Big Three will reject the Soviet proposal to include Poland and Czechoslovakia in pre-summit diplomatic talks, officials said today. At the same time the United States, Britain and France will reluctantly agree to separate meetings of their ambassadors with Andrei A. Gromyko, Soviet Foreign Minister, the officials said.
MOSCOW, April 29 (AP) -- Six United States college editors arrived in Moscow yesterday for a one-month visit arranged under the new Soviet-United States cultural exchange program.

CINCINNATI, April 30 (UP) -- Gus Bell smashed a three-run home run in the eighth inning tonight for a 5-2 Cincinnati Redleg victory over the St. Louis Cardinals. Bob Purkey of the Redlegs scattered ten hits.

CEUTA, Morocco, April 27 -- Spain, one of the United States' main allies in the Mediterranean, would like to develop this strategically situated fortress opposite Gibraltar into a key defense base for the West. Rising Arab nationalism in North Africa, however, indicates trouble ahead.

Ten performers have been added to the list of stage luminaries who will participate in the Theatre Guild's "Memory Book" dinner show to be given May 11 at the Plaza Hotel to commemorate the organization's fortieth season.

Net income of the General Motors Corporation for the first quarter of this year declined 29.4 per cent to $184,601,266 from $261,357,742 in the first three months of last year. Sales were down 11.5 per cent, according to the report of Harlow H. Curtice, president, and Albert Bradley, chairman, which will be mailed to some 735,000 stockholders today.
HONG KONG, April 29 -- A split in the ruling party of Burma at a meeting last Sunday in Rangoon was reported today by Hsinhua (the New China News agency) from Peiping.
WORTHWHILE music by the late Erich Itor Kahn formed the first part of a concert presented last night by the Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Association at its Ninety-second Street Auditorium.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, April 29 -- The Shell Oil Company's refinery at Balikpapan on the east coast of Indonesian Borneo has been temporarily shut down following an attack by unidentified aircraft on two British tankers there.
WASHINGTON, April 29 -- Labor was big business at today's second session of the annual meeting of the United States Chamber of Commerce.

The Cities Service Company this year achieved a record for a first quarter in sales of petroleum products, W. Alton Jones, chairman, told stockholders at yesterday's annual meeting at Dover, Del. He placed the volume at 3 per cent above the previous high set in the like 1957 quarter. Cities Service is a holding company.

LONDON, April 29 -- Although they accept United States insistence on avoiding parity of sides in preparations for a summit conference, the British do not believe the West has heard the last of it. They concede that system of individual discussion or, as it was called, "Russian post office," will delay progress.

ANYONE who plans to embark for France -- either now or in the future -- should run, not walk, to the nearest bookshop and purchase a copy of Waverly Root's recently published "The Food of France" (Alfred A. Knopf, $10).

Armino A. Campagna, realty investor and builder, has sold a plot 89 by 100 feet; at the southwest corner of West 231t Street and C0rlear Avenue, in the Riverdale section of the Bronx.' Francis J. Amosio of Malverne, N. Y., the buyer, plans to improve theland with an air-conditioned businessl building.

THREE short operas by Seymour Barab were presented under the title of "Three by One" last night at the Sullivan Street Playhouse, 181 Sullivan Street. They were performed by the group that last week gave an earlier program of short works with the title "From Here to There."
A dozen community groups from Manhattan, Brooklyn and Queens have joined in efforts to halt a variety of Federally aided projects in this city, including housing and highways.
It would be impractical for the Bethlehem Steel Corporation to enlarge its eastern mills as a means of competing more effectively in the Midwest, a company official testified yesterday.

At the annual meeting yesterday stockholders of International Business Machines Corporation were told that a decline in orders that began last September halted in March. Thomas J. Watson Jr., president, reported that the Data Processing division, chief source of the company's revenue, had in March exceeded its selling quota for the first time since last August.
The Surgeon General of the United States announced yesterday a grant of more than $1,500,000 to the Albert Einstein College of Medicine for research in the problems of aging.

Thor Heyerdahl's new book, "Aku-Aku," already a best- seller in five countries, will be published here by Rand McNally in September. In it Mr. Heyerdahl tells how he "solved the Easter Island mysteries which have puzzled the world's scientists for centuries."
Fifty-one of the top 100 national advertisers engage in cooperative advertising, according to a survey by Lester Krugman Associates, Inc.

VALLETA, Malta, April 30 (UP) -- Governor Sir Robert Laycock declared a state of emergency today following an outburst of nationalist strikes and violence protesting against British colonial policies.

WASHINGTON, April 30 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture reported today that farm prices increased 1.14 per cent during the month ended April 15. This brought the farm price level 9.84 per cent above that of a year ago. Primarily responsible for the April increase were record high prices for fruits and vegetables and a substantial rise for cotton.

ATLANTIC CITY, April 30 -- At least a third of human illness -- from cancer to the common cold -- can be traced to man's reactions to his surroundings, the American College of Physicians was told today.
THEY have made something bold and beautiful out of Christopher Fry's "The Firstborn," which was acted at the Coronet last evening.
WASHINGTON, April 30 -- Union spokesmen gave Senate leaders today the boiled-down specifics of a labor law program they will support.
The Flying Tiger Line will ask the Government today for permission to become a scheduled passenger airline.
NEWARK, April 30 -- Officials of St. Barnabas Medical Center here announced plans today for a $10,000,000 non-denominational "hospital of tomorrow" in the Livingston-Millourn area of Essex County.

Metro - Goldwyn - Mayer announced yesterday that "Dunkirk," a British-made drama and Metro release, has been "invited" to enter the current film festival at the Brussels World's Fair. The Balcon-Ealing production stars John Mills and Richard Attenborough.
SIGNS announcing the arrival of May wine in the city's restaurants and bars are blossoming like jonquils and geraniums on local terraces.
Leases for bank branches in office buildings rising in the midtown and downtown areas of Manhattan were announced yesterday.

President Eisenhower has proclaimed May 1 as "Law Day -U. S. A.," a day of national dedication to the principles of government under laws." The legal profession will lead in this observance. This is altogether fitting and proper; for the love held by the legal profession for liberty is notable -- it has always been dangerous to the enemies of freedom.
Van Cliburn's ticker-tape parade up Broadway has been postponed from May 14 to May 20.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- The Federal Reserve Board reported today that the condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities showed the following principal changes for the week ended Wednesday, April 23.
A Beethoven Festival of four concerts will be presented a Lewisohn Stadium July 17 through July 17 under the direction of Josef Krips.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- Admiral Arleigh A. Burke supported the "intent" of President Eisenhower's Pentagon reorganization program today but confessed "misgivings" about virtually all the principal clauses of the bill.
NEW ORLEANS, April 30 (AP) -- Another whooping crane was hatched here today. It was the third rara avis hatched at Audu bon Park in less than a year.

Allen W. Dulles, director of the Central Intelligence Agency, was the principal speaker at the opening day ceremonies of the forty-sixth annual meeting of the Chamber of Commerce. And the head of the C.I.A. chose this occasion, and this audience of 4,000 American business men, to discuss the facts about Russian competition with this country in foreign trade in words that were blunt to the point where they might be described as alarming.

NEWMARKET, England, April 30 (UP) -- Pall, Mall, a 20to-1 shot owned by Queen Elizabeth, won the 149th running of the Two Thousand Guineas Stake today as Bald Eagle, the 7-to-4 American-owned favorite, finished seventh.

John J. O'Rourke, controversial president of Local 282, International Brotherhood of Teamsters, collapsed last night while presiding over a stormy meeting of the local. He was taken to Columbus Hospital in critical condition.
WASHINGTON, April 30 -- Three large natural gas companies and three of their officers were indicted today on charges of criminal violations of the antitrust laws.

An official of the Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company testified yesterday it could not and would not expand its facilities by itself to the extent planned in its proposed merger with the Bethlehem Steel Corporation.
THE technicians responsible for last night's "Kraft Television Theatre" drama on Channel 4 did their work well.

THE strong, hardy outdoors men who infest the trout streams of Westchester and Putnam Counties on the opening days of the trout season apparently are interested in nothing less than trying conditions.
Mack Klosty faces a problem. He has a ship, cargo and places to go. But it can't sail.
A total of 211 cigarette butts was found, after a fire on April 19, on the floor of a West Side garage where smoking is prohibited.

LOS ANGELES, April 30, (AP) -- Ronnie Kline gained his first victory and completed his first game of the season with a three-hitter tonight as the Pittsburgh Pirates won their fifth in a row and their second straight victory here with 3-1 decision over the Los Angeles Dodgers.

Being a Swedish economist visiting this country, I am completely nonpartisan with regard to United States domestic policies. However, I cannot but be surprised at the current reluctance to use deficit spending as a means of getting out of the depression.

BOSTON, April 30 (UP) -- Bob Cerv belted his fifth and sixth home runs of the season as the Kansas City Athletics swamped the Boston Red Sox, 11 -- 4, today. The victory moved Kansas City half a game behind the first-place New York Yankees.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- President Eisenhower said today that April figures on employment and unemployment added to the "continued and emphatic evidence" that the decline in the economy was flattening out.

The Commonwealth Edison Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday gains in operating revenues and net income for the three and twelve months ended March 31. However, kilowatt-hour sales for the March quarter trailed the year - ago level by 1 per cent.

The inauguration today of Arturo Frondizi as President of Argentina is more than a political ceremony at which the Vice President of the United States will represent this country. It is, indeed, a historic day for Buenos Aires and for the collective democracy of the western hemisphere.

WASHINGTON, April 30 (AP) -- The Justice Department expressed shock today at recent dynamite attacks on Jewish and Negro centers in the South. But it said again there was no legal basis now for Federal intervention.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 30 -- William Perlberg and George Seaton have bought a new novel to be published in Paris under the title of "The Hook" and, as a consequence, have rearranged their filming schedule for Paramount.

HONG KONG, April 30 -- U Nu, Premier of Burma, assured his nation last night in a speech broadcast from Rangoon that despite a split in the country's leadership the "leaders will on no account take the path of armed conflict."
JAKARTA, Indonesia, April 30 -- Premier Djuanda said today reports indicated United States and Nationalist Chinese pilots had been employed by the rebels in recent bombings in East Indonesia.
The cotton futures market advanced 2 to 14 points (10 to 70 cents a bale) yesterday in moderate business on the New York Cotton Exchange.
WASHINGTON, April 30 (UP) -- House leaders moved quickly today toward reaching agreement with the Senate on a bill to give a pay increase to most members of the armed forces.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- President Eisenhower took a relaxed and neutral attitude today toward the fighting in Indonesia, but the rising influence of the Communists in that country is causing considerable apprehension behind the scenes in Washington.
MOSCOW, April 30 (UP) -- Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev said today that the "provocative flights of American aircraft in no way tally with the peaceable statements of the United States Government."

The public's right to know about union-management collective bargaining was cited by a labor reporter last night in a lecture at City College. He was A. H. Raskin of The New York Times, who gave the John H. Finley Lecture on "The Newspaper and Society."

WESTBURY, L. I., April 30 -- Go, a 5-year-old brown horse, did not win the third race at Roosevelt Raceway tonight. He missed by a neck. Starita captured the Class B trot in 2:08 1/5 in an event that saw the 1-to-2 choice, Alec Hanover, wind up fourth.
VIENTIANE, Laos, April 30 -- Prince Souvanna Phouma, the Premier, predicted today a clear victory for the Right-Wing parties in next Sunday's national elections.
WASHINGTON, April 30 (UP) -- President Eisenhower modestly described today how he acted as a baseball scout for the Pittsburgh Pirates.
WASHINGTON, April 30 -- A basis for renewed distribution of American films in the Soviet Union was laid at negotiations that were suspended at 4 A. M. yesterday.
The forced resignation of Salvatore Campanella as secretary to the director of the city's Bureau of Real Estate was announced yesterday by William R. Peer, executive secretary to Mayor Wagner.
The nation's oil refineries operated at the lowest level since late 1954 in the week ended last Friday, the American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday.

The American Smelting and Refining Company has sold its smelter near Salt Lake City to the Kennecott Copper Corporation. The price was about $20,000,000 in cash. The transaction involved inventories of materials and supplies, adjacent real estate and other assets.
WHITE PLAINS, April 30 -- The State Supreme Court was asked today to referee or appoint a commission to investigate the "erroneous and illegal" tax rolls of Clarkstown in Rockland County.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- The United States Government will release tomorrow the funds of the Egyptian Government and the Universal Suez Canal Company that were frozen when Egypt nationalized the canal company in July, 1956.
MASSAPEQUA, L. I., April 30 -- A 15-year-old high school freshman was shot and killed by a classmate in a washroom of the Massapequa High School today.
NAPLES, Italy, April 29 -- Naples is one of the most picturesque and colorful Italian cities. It also has one of the most picturesque and colorful figures in Italian politics.
ALBANY, April 30 -- The new State Crime Commission was sworn in today. It immediately got its first assignments from Governor Harriman.
WASHINGTON, April 30 -- There are a "lot of darn good men" the Republicans might nominate in 1960 for the Presidency, President Eisenhower said today.
Old-home-week for fans of the Giants and Dodgers will open May 14.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 28 -- The fruits of economic union with Egypt are developing a bitter taste in Syria.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- He really likes his news conferences, President Eisenhower said today. Then, after he had told why, for thirty minutes he proved his point in unruffled give and take with some of the 241 reporters present.
MOSCOW, April 30 -- Nikita S. Khrushchev, Soviet Premier, and Gamal Abdel Nasser, President of the United Arab Republic, met for three hours today.

KUALA LUMPUR, April 30 -- The difficult financial situation in which the Federation of Malaya finds itself is the result of a drop in rubber prices and lack of buying of tin, it was emphasized in the Legislative Council today by the Minister of Finance, Col. Sir Henry Haushik Lee.

Public passenger transportation is suffering from a sickness worse than the general economic malady. The disaster into which the railroads have been sinking is well known. Now the New York City Transit Authority is finding red ink on the books, and estimates that at the end of its fiscal year June 30 it will have an $8,500,000 operating deficit.

John A. Roosevelt's Metropolitan Political Club, an insurgent group within the Republican ranks here, set up a "Draft Rockefeller for Governor" headquarters yesterday. It is in the Bedford Hotel at 118 East Fortieth Street.
Books and records of payments, complaints and day-to-day reports in the paternity division of the Probation Bureau of Special Sessions Court have disappeared.

TANGIER, Morocco, April 30 -- The dominant political parties of Tunisia and Morocco joined with the insurgent Algerian National Liberation Front today to recommend the formation of a revolutionary Algerian government in exile.
WASHINGTON, April 30 -- Following are the major conclusions of the Senate Subcommittee on Surface Transportation on ways to help the transportation industry, particularly the railroads:
A step toward establishing this city's first modern "industrial park" on a site in the Flatlands section of Brooklyn was taken by the City Planning Commission yesterday.

In the light of the $81,000,000 compensation that Egypt has agreed to pay the dispossessed Suez Canal Company, its shares look underpriced at present market prices, according to estimates in financial circles.

The American Gas and Electric Company expects 1958 to be a good year, despite the recession, Philip Sporn, president, told 160 stockholders at the annual meeting yesterday in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization of parents, lists the following films as suitable for children between 8 and 14 years old. They will be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise noted.
WASHINGTON, April 30 -- President Eisenhower said today that the Soviet Union's denunciation of the United States proposal for military inspection of the Arctic made him feel sad.
Mrs. Randolph Guggenheimer was elected yesterday to a two-year term as chairman of the women's division of the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York.
THE second "All-Star Jazz" program was presented last night over Channel 2. It was a marked improvement over the initial show seen earlier in the season.

CINCINNATI, April 30 (AP) -Frank Robinson's second home run of the game gave a 5-4 victory to the Cincinnati Redlegs over the St. Louis Cardinals in ten innings tonight. Robinson was the first man up in the bottom of the tenth.

ROME, April 30 (UP) -- Samuel Alphonsus Cardinal Stritch, 70-year-old Roman Catholic Archbishop of Chicago whose right arm was amputated Monday, walked around his room at the Sanatrix Clinic for a few minutes today.
Randolph Phillips, a financial consultant who is waging a proxy fight for a seat on the Pennsylvania Railroad's eighteen-man board, has extended his proxy solicitation.
HAMILTON, Bermuda, April 30 (AP) -- America's yachtsmen drew even with Bermuda at two victories each by winning the fourth race today in the Amorita Cup competition. The score was 34 1/2 to 28.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- A coalition of Republicans and Southern Democrats mounted a powerful attack today on a $1,500,000,000 unemployment relief bill that President Eisenhower has assailed as a dole.
AMERICANS have always taken credit for designing the most attractive, the most practical and the best sportswear separates. Now a young Frenchman has invaded their field.
WASHINGTON, April 30 (UP) -- The United States Chamber of Commerce proposed today a general excise tax tantamount to a Federal sales tax on all goods and services except food, rent and clothing.

It is good news indeed that the Museum of Modern Art will open today after the lamentable fire of April 15 -- far less lamentable, however, than it might have been. Had the building not been fireproof, the raging blaze that so quickly fed on the flammable partitions could easily have swept all through the building, with irreparable loss of artistic treasures and even human lives.
DOYLESTOWN, Pa., April 30 (AP) -- Dr. Earl W. Flosdorf, chemist-inventor, killed his wife with a shotgun last night as their 12-year-old son watched. Then he took his own life with the same weapon.
WASHINGTON, April 30 (UP) -- Senators were told today that banning national liquor advertising would mean a return to Prohibition conditions.

BUENOS AIRES, April 30 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon declared here today that Argentina's return to democratic rule would signal the beginning of "a new era in the history of cooperation and friendship between Argentina and the United States."
The Rev. William Howard Melish announced yesterday that he would vacate the rectory of Holy Trinity Protestant Episcopal Church in Brooklyn Heights.
In the face of spreading teenage violence, Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy yesterday exhorted his department to combat with all vigor "the law of the jungle."
WASHINGTON, April 30 -- A prominent seismologist said today that 100 detection stations within the Soviet Union would be needed to monitor an international ban on nuclear tests.

THE epithet "pioneer" was never more justifiably attached than to the name of John Cotton Dana, founder of the Newark Museum and generous-spirited innovator in both the library and museum fields. Before his death in 1929, Dana had put into practice in the Newark Museum a host of startling theories that led directly to concepts only recently adopted in our contemporary museums.
A month-long national campaign for $11,000,000 was opened yesterday by United Cerebral Palsy Associations, Inc.

When the United Nations Security Council resumes debate tomorrow on the American proposal for international inspection of the Arctic, it will do so under conditions which should compel the Soviets to lay their cards on the table. The proposal, which is submitted in all seriousness and good faith, has already been endorsed by nine members of the Council.
Andrew Fletcher, president of the St. Joseph Lead Company, said yesterday the Administration's price support program for the metals mining industry appeared to be "only a temporary expedient."
WASHINGTON, April 30 (UP) -- Following is the transcript of President Eisenhower's news conference today:

Even in defeat the Yankees can be thorough. After winning their first six games in the Stadium, the Bombers yesterday suffered their first setback of the year in the Bronx, and it turned out to be a horrendous performance.

WASHINGTON, April 30 (AP) -- William M. Martin, chairman of the Federal Reserve System, has advised Senators that he sees no reason for concern in a $611,000,000 drop in Treasury gold in the first three and one-half months of this year.

Samuel Knepper, realty investor, has sold the twelve-story store and office building at 1431 Broadway, northwest corner of Fortieth Street, to a syndicate headed by Abramson Bros. The building is in the block north of the Metropolitan Opera House and had been owned by the seller for twelve years.

Heads of Eastern railroads, who by much pressure and reference to threatened bankruptcies got the entire railroad industry to back them in demanding financial aid from Congress, were most happy officials yesterday.
A man who thirty years ago wanted a new American flag for his school auditorium and could not get it, gave one to the school yesterday.

The volume of bonds called for redemption in April before maturity jumped to $66,134,000 from $14,508,000 in March and $16,361,000 a year earlier. The rise in redemptions resulted from the pay off of a big issue of telephone bonds.
LAKEHURST, N. J., April 30 -- It took some trouble, but the Navy finally determined today how far a basketball would bounce if dropped from the height of the Empire State Building.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 30 (AP) -- An outstanding Russian jurist says Soviet lawyers and officials favor a due process of law under which all cases would come before regular courts of law. And he indicates there is a trend to lighter penalties. He says crime has declined in the Soviet Union.
The Fifth Avenue Coach Lines asked the Board of Estimate yesterday for a 3-cent transfer charge on some of its routes and a transfer fee or a higher fare -- or both -- on other lines.
A former secretary to Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr. charged yesterday that he had been threatened with "the most miserable ninety days that any man has ever spent."

LONDON, April 30 -- The trustees of Chequers, country residence of British Prime Ministers, are considering the sale of part of the estate. They want to raise money to meet the rising cost of its upkeep.
WASHINGTON, April 30 (UP) -- Donald A. Quarles said today the Defense Department "would not object" to Soviet reconnaissance satellites' taking pictures of this country.
The Family Counseling Association of Nassau County will be the beneficiary of a Jazz Jamboree to be held on the Whitney Polo Field, Manhasset, L. I., the evening of June 22.
AT 9:45 o'clock this morning ten fashion models will step smartly across the stage of Christ Church auditorium on Park Avenue. The oldest mannequin is 88; the youngest, 71.
WASHINGTON, April 30 -- G. L. Mehta, retiring Ambassador to the United States, warned night there could be no such thing as a limited nuclear war.

PITTSBURGH, April 30 (AP) -- David J. McDonald, president of the United Steelworkers of America, today summoned members of the union's 170- member wage policy committee to meet in Chicago May 14 and 15.
WASHINGTON, April 30 (UP) -- President Eisenhower said today that the survival of civilization depended on the acceptance by all people of the peaceful settlement of disputes in a "framework of law."
For several years the United States Information Service has extolled the United States economic system as "people's capitalism."
City Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa told a Brooklyn grand jury yesterday that he was opposed to the proposed $500,000,000 bond issue for new school construction in New York City.

A possible plan for licensing public relations counselors, similar to the licensing of doctors and lawyers, was proposed yesterday by James L. Macwithey, president of the American Public Relations Association.

Three Manhattan savings banks founded in April, 1848, are joining in celebrating their 110th anniversaries. Dry Dock. East River and Union Square Savings Banks each were granted their original charters by the New York State Legislature in that month and opened for business on New York's lower East Side shortly afterward.
SAN ANTONIO, April 30 (AP) -- A surge of points in swimming today returned the United States to first place in the international modern pentathlon.
KIAMESHA LAKE, N. Y., April 30 -- Six hundred Conservative Rabbis sharply condemned today the "bombings and threats of bombings" of Jewish houses of worship in six Southern cities.
LONDON, April 30 -- "My Fair Lady" arrived triumphantly in her spiritual home tonight.

The bombing of the Jacksonville, Fla., Jewish community center on April 28 and the unsuccessful effort that same day to dynamite a Jewish temple in Birmingham, Ala., represent the fifth and sixth of such outrages in the last six months.
For the first time in the forty-five year history of the Actors Equity Association, there is a strong chance that the performer union may have a Negro president.

Philadelphia borrowed $31,930,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance construction of water supply, sewerage facilities and other improvements. Of the total, $26,250,000 will be spent for water and sewer services.

The Brush Beryllium Company of Cleveland won yesterday a $1,200,000 contract to fabricate two core matrices for Belgium's principal nuclear research group, Centre d'Etude de l'Energie Nucleaire (CEN).

The opening of a new and more hopeful chapter in the United Arab Republic's relations with the West is indicated both by Egypt's agreement to compensate shareholders of the Suez Canal Company for its nationalization and by the subsequent unfreezing of Egyptian assets in the United States.
ALBANY, April 30 -- The State Education Department today made public the longest list of state scholarship winners in its history.
NAPLES, April 30 (UP) -Louise Snow and Mimi Arnold, both Californians, were forced to three sets each today before winning their women's singles matches in the Naples international tennis tournament.
Sanitation Commissioner Paul R. Screvane notified the public yesterday that he would intensify his campaign against careless dog owners.

Only four 2-year-old fillies turned out yesterday before 21,364 fans at Jamaica race track for the forty-ninth running of the five-furlong feature, the $17,325 Rosedale. Warner L. Jones Jr.'s Lawdy Claudy won to complete a consecutive riding triple for Eddie Arcaro.
Mikhail Botvinnik, the challenger, drew the twentieth game of his world championship match with Vassily Smyslov upon resumption of play yesterday, according to a report from Moscow.

Sales of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation in the first quarter this year fell 5.5 per cent from those of last year, while earnings dropped 9.1 per cent, according to the results announced yesterday by Gwilym A. Price, chairman.

Wall Street yesterday interpreted almost all news favorably. It liked the Suez Canal settlement with Nasser, the report that the debt limit would be raised by $10,000,000,000 and signs that the Democratic leadership was pressing for a tax cut.

WASHINGTON, April 30 (UP) -- The Federal Trade Commission today opposed a Federal "fair trade" bill that would bar retailers from selling products below the minimum resale price established by the manufacturer.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- The Senate committee bill, approved today, to reduce the appellate jurisdiction of the Supreme Court asserts a power of Congress that has been used but once and seldom strongly urged in the history of the United States.
A proposal that future Loyalty Day parades be shifted to the Union Square area was made yesterday by Jan Mitchell, president of the Fourteenth Street Association.

The article of your Brussels correspondent appearing in The Times of April 22 was most interesting. It mentions the half dozen United States voting machines among the United States exhibits at the Brussels World's Fair at which, as an illustration of the mechanics of our own political elections, a visitor may step into a booth, draw the curtain and secretly register a choice.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- The nation's railroads have found a dapper champion in the junior Democratic Senator from Florida, George Armistead Smathers. The sun tanned legislator, 6-feet-3, has more than the average share of good looks.
The three members of the reconstituted New York City Housing Authority will be sworn in at City Hall today by Mayor Wagner.

CHICAGO, April 30 (AP) -- Corn futures prices attracted a good demand in late dealings on the Board of Trade today. All corn contracts then moved rapidly ahead and closed with gains of more than a cent a bushel.

PARIS, April 30 -- The decision of the North African political parties meeting in Tangier to go all out for Algerian independence posed grave problems for France in the throes of her Government crisis.

ROCHESTER, April 30 -- The first orchestral program of the current Festival of American Music of the Eastman School of Music here included tonight a performance of the Symphony No. 2 ("Romantic") of Dr. Howard Hanson, director of the school and founder of the festival.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 30 (AP) -- The San Francisco Giants combined four home runs and Johnny Antonelli's six-hit pitching for a 10-1 victory over Philadelphia and Robin Roberts today.

Perhaps hoping to introduce some of New York's stray baseball fans to cricket, Mayor Wagner swung a cricket bat yesterday at City Hall and welcomed to town sixteen Pakistani cricket stars, all of them cosmopolitan tea-sippers who have never seen a baseball game and have never heard of Mickey Mantle.

Future prices closed generally lower yesterday on the New York exchanges. Coffee, wool, hides, rubber and tin declined; cocoa, copper, cottonseed and soybean oil rose, and sugar, lead, potatoes and zinc were mixed.

Mike Giacinto of St. Francis Prep broke his meet record yesterday when he won the open 12-pound shot-put in the fieldevent portion of the eleventh annual Brooklyn College interscholastic track and field meet at Brooklyn College Field.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- President Eisenhower declared today that the policy of the United States was to develop "cleaner" nuclear weapons that would not cause mass destruction by radioactive fall-out.
NEW DELHI, India, April 30 -- Sheikh Abdullah, the Lion of Kashmir, is back in prison after fifteen weeks of freedom in the area he once ruled.
CHICAGO, April 30 -- Twice-yearly gatherings of representatives of the Soviet Union and the Western powers would be preferable to summit meetings on world problems, Adlai E. Stevenson said today.
Francois d'Albert, Hungarian-born violinist and composer who recently joined the faculty of the Chicago Conservatory of Music, played a debut recital of great distinction at Town Hall last night.
One of the "greatest tuberculosis case-finding tools" ever used, chest X-ray, is being unjustly assailed as a radiation hazard, a leading tuberculosis authority said here yesterday.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 30 (AP) -- Sunday sale of groceries, clothing, hardware and similar merchandise was hit today in a State Supreme Court decision upholding state "blue laws."

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- The House General Education subcommittee suddenly approved today the three-year $1,500,000,000 school construction bill that President Eisenhower had sumitted to the last session of Congress.

The sharp reduction in demand for nickel and rolling mill and foundry products, and a further slight decline in copper prices, adversely affected firstquarter earnings of the International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd.
A sharp increase in offerings of bonds for industrial and public utility corporations pushed new bond financing in April in the local market well above March and the corresponding month of 1957.
CHICAGO, April 30 -- Mayor Richard J. Daley set up machinery today for settling a six-day strike that has tied up Great Lakes foreign shipping.
BATHING suits will appear in a greater variety of shapes this summer.
New York University checked a ninth-inning threat to preserve a 6-5 Metropolitan Collegiate Conference victory over Brooklyn College at Ohio Field, the Bronx, yesterday.

William Zeckendorf, chairman of Webb Knapp, Inc., a real estate holding company, was engaged yesterday in two separate deals for corporate acquisitions -- one completed and the other being negotiated.
CHICAGO, April 30 (AP) -- The nation's traffic death toll for the first quarter of this year was 7,730, compared with 8,250 in the first three months in 1957. This was a 6 per cent decrease.
ALBANY, April 30 -- Following are the names of the winners of the 1958 Regents general scholarships and special science scholarships in the New York area:
WASHINGTON, April 30 -- A Senate subcommittee proposed an eight-point program today to help the railroad industry.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 30 -- The United States will accept an amendment to its plan for international inspection of the Arctic to permit the issue to go before a heads-of-government conference.
NEW DELHI, India, April 30 -- Leaders of India's ruling Congress party spent their time today working on appeals to Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru not to leave office.
A 38-year-old Filipino surgeon wanted for questioning in the fatal stabbing of a Brooklyn nurse last Saturday surrendered yesterday.

These menus, which appear each Thursday, use seasonally abundant foods and are moderate in cost. They are designed to strike a balance between appetite appeal and the convenience of the family cook. Dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe. Add bread and beverage as desired, unless specified.
Greater New York Fund Month, proclaimed by Mayor Wagner, gets under way today. Officials of the fund emphasize that there is no public solicitation or door - to - door appeal.
Slight drops in the number of workers drawing unemployment insurance were reported in several major industrial centers last week, but a few showed the volume of claims still on the upgrade.

KOROR, Palau, April 25 -- Micronesia's most advanced legislative body, the Palau Congress, has just concluded its five-day spring session in a thatched building wired for microphones, loud-speakers, and tape recordings of its proceedings.
WASHINGTON, April 30 (AP) -- Mrs. Dwight D. Eisenhower formally opened the annual Mental Health Campaign today.
CHICAGO, April 30 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

LOUISVILLE, April 30 -- Exactly how many horses will "go" in the Kentucky Derby on Saturday has not been decided, but at this moment it appears that more than a dozen can be considered starters. The next step in the weeding-out process will take place tomorrow.

NORWALK, Conn., April 30 -- The Common Council, after a debate that lasted until 2 o'clock this morning, empowered the Norwalk Redevelopment Agency to proceed with a long-delayed redevelopment program.

School children yesterday viewed the private lives of the city's most popular actors -- the Park Department's marionettes. For two hours a class of fifth-grade boys and girls toured the workshop in Central Park where marionettes are made and rehearsed for the shows that tour the city's schools, parks and playgrounds.

WASHINGTON, April 30 (AP) -- The nation's major airports were busier than ever last year. The Civil Aeronautics Administration said that traffic, as measured by take-offs and landings, increased 14 per cent.
WASHINGTON, April 30 -- A four-point bill to curb the Supreme Court and to void several of its recent decisions was reported out today by the Senate Judiciary Committee.

LOUISVILLE, April 30 -- At 5:45 this morning; three minutes before the sun was scheduled to rise, Mrs. Elizabeth N. Graham was feeding a post-breakfast delicacy to her latest equine darling, Jewel's Reward. Oblivious to the bleak chill in the barn area at Churchill Downs, she lovingly gave the bay colt some dandelions and clover.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- Walter P. Reuther, president of the United Auto Workers, said today his union would observe a three-month period of peace with the auto industry after the expiration of its contracts late in May.

Students and staff members of the Baruch School of Business Administration, City College of New York, Twenty-third Street and Lexington Avenue, will donate blood to the Red Cross today. Blood also will be collected at the New York Telephone Company, 88-08 164th Street, Jamaica, Queens.
WASHINGTON, April 30 -- President Eisenhower made these main points at his news conference today:
ST. LOUIS, April 30 -- Alex Hannum today resigned as coach of the St. Louis Hawks, the 1957-58 National Basketball Association champions.

A new issue of $35,000,000 of debentures of the city of Montreal is being offered for public subscription here by a syndicate headed by Shields Co., Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., Savard Hart and Salomon Bros. Hutzler.
The trans-Atlantic airliner St. Patrick took off for Ireland from New York International Airport at Idlewild at 3:49 P. M. yesterday after a bomb scare had held up the flight for more than an hour.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- House investigators heard today that the Federal Communications Commission had refused to act on repeated warnings from its staff that interstate telephone rates might be too high.
Grants totaling $2,000,000 have been awarded by the United States Steel Foundation to 655 institutions of higher learning and to several educational organizations.
WASHINGTON, April 30 -- President Eisenhower made these main points at his news conference today:
ST. LOUIS, April 30 -- Alex Hannum today resigned as coach of the St. Louis Hawks, the 1957-58 National Basketball Association champions.

A new issue of $35,000,000 of debentures of the city of Montreal is being offered for public subscription here by a syndicate headed by Shields Co., Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., Savard Hart and Salomon Bros. Hutzler.
The trans-Atlantic airliner St. Patrick took off for Ireland from New York International Airport at Idlewild at 3:49 P. M. yesterday after a bomb scare had held up the flight for more than an hour.
Unmarried mothers fall into no special social category, but represent a cross section of society, according to Justice Justine Wise Polier of the Domestic Relations Court.
BOSTON, May 1 (UP) -- The Boston Red Sox tonight traded a rookie infielder, Ken Aspromonte, to the Washington Senators for a catcher, Lou Berberet.

MINEOLA, L. I., May 1 -- A first-degree murder indictment against 15-year-old Bruce Zator of North Massapequa will be sought within a week or two, District Attorney Frank A. Gulotta said today. A first-degree murder conviction carries the mandatory sentence of death in the electric chair.

IN the Republic of Vietnam, a long strip edging the mainland of Asia, few people have ever heard of Russel Wright, well-known American industrial designer. In that country of rice bowls and chopsticks, it is not likely that one of the classics modern cups or plates designed by Mr. Wright would be very popular.
WASHINGTON, May 1 -- Secretary of State Dulles said today that the Soviet Union was no market for Middle Eastern oil.
Silk stitches and a plastic patch have repaired a 2-year-old boy's heart so he can look forward to a normal life.

TOKYO, May 1 (Reuters) -- Scientists in northern Japan reported tonight having monitored an unusual series of atmospheric vibrations originating in Siberia they were similar to those recorded during Soviet nuclear weapons tests in February and March.
Mikhail Botvinnik, the challenger, yesterday drew the twenty-first game of his return match with Vassily Smyslov for the chess championship of the world, according to a report from Moscow.

WASHINGTON, May 1 (UP) -- Senator George D. Aiken of Vermont called today for studies of a four-day-work week, profit-sharing plans and guaranteed annual wages as possible solutions to increased unemployment.

Units of the Board of Higher Education have begun interviewing candidates for two $25,000-a-year posts in the municipal college system. The posts are chancellor of the city colleges and president of Queens College.
ALTHOUGH the nation's 17,000,000 teen-agers had an estimated income of $9,000,000,000 in 1956, it is a mistake to think of their purchasing power in terms of a broad "teen-age market."

Dr. Linus C. Pauling's claim, as reported by J. W. Finney in The Times of April 29, that carbon 14 represents "a far more serious long-term menace than all other radioactive by-products of an atomic explosion" is incorrect. Consequently, so are his numbers of genetically defective children and other potential biological effects.
A double disqualification at Jamaica yesterday took the first-finishing Loukenmac from first to last in the $5,000 New Dorp and placed the third-finishing Viscount out of the money.
Twelve automobile salesmen and a cab driver were seized at New York International Airport early yesterday by authorities attempting to halt the "bird dogging" of returning servicemen.
A Government official urged yesterday that salesmen wake up to the fact that they are in their first post-war "buyer's -- or salesman's -- market."

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 1 (AP) -- The United States had better watch out, the president of Columbia University said tonight, lest it fail to educate enough specialists in economic, political and psychological fields.

Lehman Brothers' new mutual unit, the One William Street Fund, Inc., filed yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission an amended registration statement to increase its proposed public offering from 3,000,000 shares to 7,000,000.
James F. Oates Jr., former Chicago utility executive, denied yesterday charges that he and others had conspired to stifle competition in natural gas distribution.

NEW DELHI, India, May 1 -- Jawaharlal Nehru angrily pleaded with his political followers today to be allowed to step out of the Prime Minister-ship for a while and lead the country from a position above office.
LONDON, May 1 -- An unfinished portrait of Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh, by the late David Jagger lends a note that is almost ghostly to this year's Royal Academy of Arts summer exhibition.
WASHINGTON, May 1 -- The House of Representatives handed President Eisenhower a major victory today as it approved his plan for supplementary unemployment compensation to jobless workers.

WHEN Ellen Sarah Southee Poltoratzky died in Rome in 1908 she was 89 years old. In her long life she had known extremes of wealth and poverty, of luxury and privation, such as are encountered by few persons. An English girl who spent her childhood in a large farmhouse near Canterbury, she was born into the world described in Jane Austen's novels.
Balloon-borne "seeds of brotherhood" floated up from Union Square yesterday as the climax of an international-flavored observance of May Day.
The twenty-fifth anniversary of his ordination will be celebrated tonight by the Rev. Dr. David J. Seligson of Central Synagogue.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 1 -- Cecelia Parker, who played the role of Mickey Rooney's kid sister in the "Hardy" family series from 1938 through 1946, will rejoin the actor in "Andy Hardy Comes Home."
Former Deputy Mayor William Reid, Ira S. Robbins and Francis V. Madigan were sworn in by Mayor Wagner yesterday as members of the reconstituted New York City Housing Authority.
A high official in the city Correction Department bitterly criticized his chief yesterday.
The legality of the $205,000,000 Lincoln Square redevelopment project was upheld yesterday by the Court of Appeals.

The dollar marks Dollars which plaster themselves and over so many stories Art about art speak among other things of the personal nature of art itself. One knows what one likes, but public opinion when not actually indifferent is surely fickle.
DETROIT, May 1 -- The General Motors Corporation emphasized today that it was preparing no new offer to present to the United Automobile Workers in the current wage negotiations.
CARACAS, Venezuela, May 1 -- The New York Philharmonic scored a stunning success in its debut here last night at University City.

THERE are draftsmen who isolate an object or the human figure to concentrate on the delimited forms within them. And there are draftsmen who "see" a total atmosphere in which separate figures and things become part of a natural continuum in space.
Mrs. Ruth Goetz probably is the busiest member of the Dramatists Guild.

WASHINGTON, May 1 (AP) -- Peter W. Hoguet, a New York lawyer, submitted a claim today for 25 per cent of any fee awarded attorneys for dissident members of the teamsters union. The members tried to block James R. Hoffa from taking the union's presidency.
The nuclear energy committee of the nation's major public utility regulatory body appealed yesterday to each state to establish full control over the use of radioactive materials within its borders.
NEWARK, May 1 -- Millions of dollars worth of construction was either halted or slowed today in northern New Jersey as trade unions struck over new contract demands.

In reply to Abram Shmoys' letter concerning the unfinished monument to the six million Jews who died under Hitler's oppression, may I statethat many millions of Christians and non-Jews have suffered and died not only under the tyranny of the Nazis but at the bloody hands of the butchers of the Kremlin with whom so many Americans wish us ]to coexist peaceably.
WASHINGTON, May l -- Ezra Taft Benson rejected today a self-help plan for dairy farmers.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, May 1 (AP) -- The United States team of international one-design sailors won from Bermuda by one-fourth of a point today but a series of protests prevented the Americans from clinching the Amorita Cup.

HARRIMAN, N. Y., May 1 -- "Vision, dynamism and fidelity to principle" were prescribed at Arden House here today as the best bulwarks against the challenge to the leadership of the free world in Africa.

GREENFIELD, Mass., May 1 -- Local patriots permit no human to visit this region without being firmly informed that the Deerfield River is the longest trout stream in the East (thirty-eight miles), and that it has long been known as one of the best brown trout rivers.
LONDON, May 1 -- Britain made public today information on an intermediate-range ballistic missile with a nuclear warhead and an advanced naval radar system.

Sales of the eight major department stores in the New York metropolitan area declined in April from the level of the same month in 1957. The figures, on the average, were 2 per cent lower, according to a survey yesterday by The New York Times.
BUENOS AIRES, May 1 -- Arturo Frondizi, who three years ago was a persecuted Opposition politician, took office today as Argentina's first freely elected President in twelve years.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- Fred A. Seaton, Secretary of the Interior, said today that he resented "any implication" that the Administration's plan for subsidizing the production of five metals "is a slick political deal" to win Congressional votes for the foreign trade program.

Business loans outstanding at the seventeen larger New York City banks declined $8,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. They increased $43,000,000 in the comparable week last year.

The election of John E. Finneran as executive vice president and a director of the House of Seagram, Inc., liquor distributor, has been announced by Victor A. Fischel, president. The company is a subsidiary of Distillers Corporation-Setgrams, Ltd.
WASHINGTON, May 1 -- United States satellites have detected a mysterious band of extremely intense radiation some 600 miles in space.
SYRACUSE, N. Y., May 1 (AP) -- Disputes over wage contracts made nearly 2,500 construction workers idle in central and western New York State today.

Seventy-five children, resplendent in costumes of seven foreign lands, yesterday danced folk numbers in separate groups and a maypole dance together on the terrazzo of Rockefeller Center's Lower Plaza.

CHICAGO, May 1 -- The National Merit Scholarship Program announced today more than 1,000 winners of its competition for college scholarships. Among them were sixty-two young men and women from the New York metropolitan area.

BONN, Germany, May 1 -- The East German Government turned May Day festivities in East Berlin today into a demonstration of its military power, according to dispatches received here. It also used the occasion to attack the Bonn Government on its nuclear armament plans.

LOS ANGELES, May 1 (AP) -Frank Thomas belted a pair of home runs over the Coliseum's near-by left-field screen and Vern Law hit a three-run homer over the same barrier tonight as the Pittsburgh Pirates crushed the Los Angeles Dodgers, 8 -- 3.

Henry R. Labouisse, who resigned yesterday as Director of the United Nations Relief and Works Agency for Palestine Refugees, would be the last man in the world to boast of any self-sacrifice in the arduous labors which have taken his time and exiled him from home since 1954.
NAPLES, May 1 (UP) -- Ferruccio Bonetti of Italy beat Gregory Grant of Los Angeles, 6 -- 3, 4 -- 6, 9 -- 7, today to reach the quarter-finals of the Naples international tennis tournament.

WASHINGTON, May 1 (AP) -- Senator Warren G. Magnuson, Democrat of Washington, said today that a Senate Commerce subcommittee would start hearings May 13 on legislation authorizing construction of two large ocean liners.
Two fight managers said to be "front men" for Frankie Carbo, an underworld figure, were directed yesterday to answer questions about Carbo before a New York County grand jury.
ALBANY, May 1 (AP) -- The State Attorney General ruled today that cities and towns may submit bingo referendums to voters in the primary Aug. 12.
After a plodding advance most of the day stocks broke in the final hour yesterday and gave up two-thirds of the gain.

Patricia Neway, who won fame on Broadway several seasons ago as Magda Sorel in Gian-Carlo Menotti's "The Consul,'' sang the leading part in another Menotti opera for the first time at the City Center last night.
CHICAGO, May 1 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 1 -- Henry R. Labouisse announced today his resignation as director of the United Nations Relief and Works Agency for Palestine Refugees in the Near East.
WHEN Charlotte Bronte wrote "Jane Eyre" she never realized what problems she was setting the twentieth century theatre.
SAN ANTONIO, May 1 (AP) -- A second-place finish today in the team running event gave the over-all championship in the international modern pentathlon competition to the United State A team.
SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, May 1 -- A bitter attack on the British Labor party was made at Broken Hill today by Sir Roy Welensky, Prime Minister of the Federation of Rhodesia and Nyasaland.
April figures for auto production carried out March trends -- only more so.
ALBANY, May 1 (AP) -- Following is the text of the Court of Appeals decision today upholding the legality of the Lincoln Square redevelopment in New York:
Michigan announced yesterday plans to borrow $100,000,000 in the bond market on May 27 for highway construction.
LONDON, May 1 -- The Union Jack and the Red flag flew competitively in bright sunshine today above the politically turbulent borough of St. Pancras, in northern London.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, May 1 -- The United States entered the cultural competition of the World's Fair tonight with the European premiere of the color motion picture "South Pacific," presented at the gala opening of the American. Pavilion Theatre.
Thomas J. Curran, New York County Republican leader, said yesterday that a primary fight over Representative Frederic R. Coudert's seat in Congress now appeared unavoidable.

The Chesapeake and Ohio Railway's gross revenues for April plummeted to $26,481,000 from $37,063,000 in the like month of last year. Despite the sharp drop, the road reported a net income of $2,914,000. In April, 1957, earnings were $5,703,000.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, May 1 -- An unidentified plane bombed an Indonesian merchant ship in the port of Kendari, Celebes, Tuesday, killing five persons and seriously injuring twenty-three others, the Antara news agency reported today.
WASHINGTON, May 1 -- The Supreme Court heard today the involved story of the General Aniline and Film Corporation and its former owner, the Swiss holding company, Interhandel.
WHITE PLAINS, May 1 -- A four-man steering committee was set up today to guide the Republican machine in Westchester County while Herbert C. Gerlach, the Republican county chairman, is ill.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 1 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold renewed today his appeal to all nations to seize upon "any honest initiative by any government" to break the dangerous deadlock over disarmament.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., May 1 -- Peggy Glanville-Hicks' "Thomsoniana" Suite, for soprano, flute, horn, piano and string quartet, was a feature of a chamber music program tonight in Kilbourn Hall in the Eastman Schol annual festival of American music.

KOROR, Palau, April 25 -- Seven hereditary chiefs, talking the other evening in the thatched building where the Palau Congress meets by day, had caustic words for the physical appearance of the United States establishment here.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- White House communications experts termed "slightly exaggerated" a report in Britain's House of Commons today that President Eisenhower was in touch with the United States Air Force even while playing golf.
In years when poker was the extra-curricular activity of ball players, they had a caustic comment for any player who, though a big winner, bleated bitterly at the loss of one pot.
College tuition should be financed over the lifetime of the student -- up to forty years -- instead of four years, an economist declared here yesterday.
DUESSELDORF, Germany, May 1 -- May Day demonstrations against the government's plans to equip the West German forces with nuclear weapons were held in many cities of Germany today.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- The President, of whom James Reston once observed that in general, both in politics and golf, his backswing is better than his follow-through, has left no basis for that comment thus far in his drive for legislation to reorganize the military establishment.

FORT WORTH, May 1 (AP) -Arnold Palmer putted spectacularly today to fashion a fiveunder-par 34, 31 -- 65 that tied the course record and made him the first-round leader in the $15,000 Colonial national invitation golf tournament.
CHICAGO, May 1 -- The National Labor Relations Board sought an injunction today that would end the tie-up of overseas shipping in Chicago and other Great Lakes ports.

GENEVA, May 1 (Reuters) -- Flags of convenience are a major factor in the world shipping recession, a British representative today told the International Labor Organization's forty-two-nation maritime conference.
ALBANY, May 1 (AP) -- The State Labor Department issued today what it described as an emergency order "to halt accidents which maim and may kill our future space men."

Former Senator Herbert H. Lehman warned last night of the danger of mankind becoming "enamored of technological progress." He said that scientific achievements must be studied in terms of human value.

LOS ANGELES, May 1 -- The National Association of broadcasters closed its convention today with awards to Dr. Lee de Forest for his contributions as the originator of modern electronics and to Dinah Shore for her work as a broadcasting entertainer.
CHICAGO, May 1 (AP) -- All grains except oats finished with losses on the Board of Trade today.

At the end of autumn 1908, Marcel Proust began an article against the scientific objectivity of Sainte-Beuve. In six months it had become an essay of 300 pages and in the final work, in 1909, the original article was but a single phase of a much broader statement of Proust's intuitive accesses.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., May 1 (AP) -- A conference of Southern Mayors and a mass meeting of Jacksonville Negroes are scheduled this week-end in the aftermath of bomb explosions at a Negro school and a Jewish community center here.

The New York Stock Exchange said yesterday it was considering suspending from trading and delisting the Class A and B common shares of the Bon Ami Company, soap and detergent manufacturer. A public hearing will be held May 20.
The "cold war" notwithstanding, the Russians have the hottest show in town. For the most bitter competition here in recent days has been for tickets to see the Moiseyev Dance Company.

A state report said yesterday that the Apalachin, N. Y., gangland convention last Nov. 14 "presumably" met to discuss "lobbying, including political contributions," as well as to divide jurisdiction over illicit activities.
The recession here is causing the spread of narcotics and teen-age gangs to Puerto Rico, the chairman of the city's Commission on Intergroup Relations said yesterday.

ROME, May 1 -- There is no social concord and justice "without Christ and against Christ" Pope Pius XII said in a May Day address to Roman Catholic workers today. He was marking recurrence of the liturgical Feast of St. Joseph the Workman.
MONTREAL, May 1 -- Nine thousand members of the Brotherhood of Locomotive Firemen and Enginemen have been authorized to go on strike against the trans continental Canadian Pacific Railway May 11.
Many prominent persons attended the dinner dance given last night for the benefit of the Boys Club of New York.
THE best meat buys this week-end include end cuts of pork loins, shoulders of lamb and veal, the city's Department of Markets reports.

WASHINGTON, May 1 (AP) -- The Justice Department said today it would move for retrial of seven Colorado defendants whose Smith Act convictions were reversed last August by the United States Court of Appeals at Denver.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- The Marines went to the Capitol today and opened the first military beachhead against President Eisenhower's program to reorganize the Pentagon. Gen. Randolph McC. Pate, the corps commandant, conducted the assault.
WASHINGTON, May 1 (AP) -Herb Score, Cleveland's ace southpaw, may be out of action for some time because of an elbow injury.
Westchester and Long Island played two series each in the Women s Metropolitan Golf Association's interclub matches yesterday.

LOUISVILLE, May 1 -- It was a soft spring day and the early morning sun whipped the dew off the grass with hungry ardor. The stable area on the backstretch at Churchill Downs seemed bright, fresh and attractive -- although it actually qualifies under none of those categories. This was the scene of pastoral contentment.

The Tidewater Oil Company had a drop of $10,676,000 in first-quarter earnings this year. The results were disclosed yesterday at the annual meeting, held for the first time at the company's new refinery in Delaware City, Del., fifteen miles south of Wilmington.
The Transit Authority yesterday promoted seventy-four members of its police force, with pay increases ranging from $238 to $1,146 a year. All of the promotions involved the detective division.

At the annual meeting yesterday of the New York Chamber of Commerce, the outgoing president, Perry M. Shoemaker, made a sharp attack on the Eisenhower Administration's new rail program as "distressingly full of compromise, omissions and inertia." Mr. Shoemaker is president of the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad Company.

THIRTY years ago, after a young woman had embarrassed fellow Democrats by accusing them of callousness toward social reform legislation, she was summoned be fore Charles F. Murphy, then ruler of Tammany Hall. The taciturn political boss advised: "In politics you must learn not to talk about everything you know."
ATLANTIC CITY, May 1 -- The human heart is a much tougher organ than has been generally believed, it was suggested today at the thirty-ninth meeting of the American College of Physicians.
A DAY in the life of a decorator adds up to this: the problems are always the same, but the people who have them are different.
Governor Harriman said last night that the United States could fulfull its "destined role as the leader of free peoples" only if it banished discrimination and prejudice at home.

MOROCCO, far removed from hot dogs, soft drinks and the chemise, continues to be enmeshed in ancient tradition. So reports Margit Pinter, who has just returned from Morocco with a new collection of rugs, fabrics and native handcrafts. All are available through decorators at Mauretania, 140 East Fifty-sixth Street.

One of the finest phrases of praise that can be said of a boat builder is that he is a "craftsman of the old school." There are not many left. The fast-moving, booming participation sport of pleasure boating needs all the automation and assembly lines it can get.
WASHINGTON, May 1 -- Secretary of State Dulles said today that an East-West agreement on an Arctic inspection zone might well be the turning point in the "cold war."
WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., May 1 -- This city of homes, stores and offices in New York's suburbia is beginning a $9,670,000 "dream school."
WASHINGTON, May 1 (UP) -- J. Edgar Hoover scored today movies and television programs containing what he called "celluloid poison" that glorified crime and criminals.

Future prices closed irregular yesterday on the New York commodity exchanges. Cocoa, wool and rubber advanced; zinc, hides and cottonseed oil declined, and price movements for potatoes, copper, sugar and coffee were mixed.

The Government reinstituted its denaturalization suit yesterday in Federal Court against Frank Costello. If the 67-year-old gambler were stripped of his citizenship he would be subject to deporting to his native Italy.
The American theatre's first lady extended a warm and neighborly welcome yesterday to the theatre's first acting couple. The happy occasion was the formal naming of the Lunt-Fontanne Theatre.

"RUMORS OF EVENING," a World War II story dramatized last night on "Playhouse 90" over Channel 2, was long on nostalgia. It included songs like "Don't Sit Under the Apple Tree" and "As We Go Rolling, Rolling Home" that may have aroused misty memories for some former service men.
WASHINGTON, May 1 -- A preliminary skirmish over a bill to curb the Supreme Court broke out on the Senate floor today.

The Administration's policy of attacking the steadily lengthening business recession by the device of wishful thinking seems to have moved into the desperation stage this week. This is the only logical explanation that suggests itself from the extraordinary action by the Department of Commerce in rushing into print nearly a fortnight ahead of schedule with a partial preview of the employment figures for the month March 15-April 15.
The Society of the Silurians, Lan (rganization of newspaper imen who worked on Nev York papers twenty-five qr more lyears ago, voted last night to admit radio and television newsZmen to membership.
BOGOTA, Colombia, May 1 (UP) -- The Government rushed troops by air tonight to the state of Boyaca to quell a peasant armed revolt.
Wall Street and the philatelic wordld reacted calmly yesterday to the revelation of the theft of Federal stock transfer stamps originally worth more than $48,000,000.
HONOLULU, May 1 -- Four pacifists intent on violating off-limits restrictions guarding the Einiwetok nuclear testing grounds were seized by the Coast Guard and arrested here today.

CAMP LEJEUNE, N. C., May 1 (UP) -- A general court-martial today convicted a marine private from Newark, N. J., of premeditated murder. He had been charged with shooting a sergeant who had accused him of disrespect.

While France flounders in one of its periodic Cabinet crises, the dominant Government parties of Tunisia and Morocco have united with the rebel Algerian National Liberation Front in a program for Algerian independence and the creation of a North African federation aligned with France and the West.
WASHINGTON, My 1 (AP) -- A lack of candor in reporting on unemployment figures was imputed to President Eisenhower and Sinclair Weeks today by Senator Joseph S. Clark, Democrat of Pennsylvania.

How can you score a point after touchdown by a safety? This question has been raised in response to the revelation here that college football's new conversion rule assigns a value of one point to a "successful try by safety."
Two producers of office machines agreed on a merger proposal yesterday.
The House Armed Services Committee continued yesterday to probe into the details of the President's plan for reorganization of the Pentagon.

Every now and then the group of amateur actors who take part in the Presidential press conference pause in their consideration of such items as unemployment, clean bombs, disarmament, junkets in air force planes, the Presidential succession, tax cuts, baseball scouting and the Arctic regions and take a look at themselves -- that is, a look at the institution of the Presidential news conference.

NYACK, N. Y., May 1 -- Assemblyman Robert Walmsley released two men today from their pledges not to run against him in the Republican state Senate race. He acted after the Orange County Republican executive committee refused to give him a blanket endorsement for the seat now held by State Senator Thomas Desmond of Newburgh, who is retiring.
"Kraft Television Theatre," a one-hour live drama series that marks its eleventh anniversary Wednesday, will be discontinued on or about Sept. 17 and replaced by two half-hour programs.
ALGIERS, May 1 (AP) -- The French Army asserted today that it had killed or captured more than 300 nationalist rebels in two battles.
