The Park Association of New York re-elected all of its officers yesterday and seven directors whose terms were expiring, and a new director. The meeting was held at the National Arts Club, 15 Gramercy Park.
Communication media must do more to make the American people and their representatives conscious of the need for basic research and other kinds of research, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt said yesterday.

Federal agents and city policemen raided a gift shop in the heart of Chinatown last night and seized what the police described as $1,500,000 worth of pure heroin. They called it one of the biggest narcotics raids on police records.
ALBANY, May 1 (AP) -- The Court of Appeals today rejected John Steinbeck's argument that a New York City tax on his income from writing violated freedom of the press.
WASHINGTON, May 1 (UP) -- The Government will soon start shipping materials to the Far North for constructing huge radars designed to detect intercontinental ballistic missile attacks.

Throngs of visitors went to the Museum of Modern Art yesterday to stand before the works of Georges Seurat. The museum, at 11 West Fifty-third Street, had been closed since a fire April 15 and reopened its ground floor with the large loan show of the French artist's work.
WESTBURY, L. I., May 1 -Eric's Boy, the 5-year-old black gelding that Billy Haughton converted from a trotter to a pacer late last year, continues to excel at Roosevelt Raceway.
WASHINGTON, May 1 (AP) -- The posthumous award of special Medals of Honor to four Army chaplains who died in World War was approved today by the Senate.
SPERLONGA, Italy, May 1 -- An archaeological find of outstanding importance has been made in a cave facing the sea on the Gulf of Gaeta, about halfway between Rome and Naples.

FIFTH AVENUE window-display designers acquire a following once they've come up with something new. Gene Moore, an artist who came here from Birmingham, Ala., eighteen years ago, probably gets more fan mail than any other designer -- from as far off as Australia, Great Britain and South America.
WASHINGTON, May 1 -- The Secretary of Labor said today that a decision on whether to "bolster the economy" by further Government action would have to be made in the next thirty to sixty days.
A motion by the Waterfront Commission for a contempt citation against Irving Charles Velson was argued yesterday before Justice Thomas A. Aurelio in Supreme Court here.
WASHINGTON, May 1 -- Attorney General William P. Rogers called on the public today to support the courts against a "kill the umpire" attitude.

NEW CANAAN, Conn., May 1 -- Dr. Charlotte R. Brown, New Canaan's Health Director, declined today to provide speakers for a debate Friday night sponsored by the Anti-Fluoridation Committee because of the speakers chosen by the committee.

The National Association of Securities Dealers, Inc., the over - the - counter dealers' own "private eye." reported yesterday that 1957 was its most active year in enforcement work since the organization was founded twenty years ago.

LOUISVILLE, May 1 -- Silky Sullivan "got off'' first this morning The California colt, a very synonym for tardiness, upset all the dope that has gained him this reputation by being the first to have his name dropped into the entry box for Saturday's Kentucky Derby.
WASHINGTON, May 1 -The Export-Import Bank disclosed one of its rare losses today.

Mayor Wagner installed a new top command in the New York City Housing Authority yesterday with William Reid as chairman and Ira S. Robbins and Francis V. Madigan as his fellow-commissioners. They face a task of reorganization, reform, the continuing large-scale construction, the management and maintenance of vast properties as perhaps the world's largest landlord.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- The United Textile Workers was given the choice today of getting rid of Burton Hyman of New York, a vice president, or be suspended as an affiliate of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations.
The Board of Education yesterday voted a $5,000 increase in the annual salary of the Superintendent of Schools.
The Silver Cross Day Nursery will give its benefit spring luncheon and bridge at the Pierre on June 3. Mrs. Ward Warner is chairman.
LONDON, May 1 -- The Government has decided to speed the flow of polio vaccine by eliminating the re-testing in Britain of United States and Canadian vaccine.
Governor Harriman assailed a fellow Democratic Governor yesterday for having defied the Constitution and the United States Supreme Court. His target was Orval Faubus of Arkansas.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- The two Justice Department lawyers who had been closest to the antitrust suit against the American Telephone and Telegraph Company refused to sign the consent decree that settled the case in 1956.
MOSCOW, May 1 -- Moscow celebrated its May Day holiday today in a festive mood dampened only slightly by scattered showers.

Terry Murray came up with an interesting program for his piano recital last night in Town Hall. He had the enterprise to put Weber's Third Sonata on his program, as well as a piece of Wagner juvenilia, the "Album Sonata."
A third United States vs. Russia sports conflict approaches that should provide the fairest athletic testing ground yet between the nations. It's in weightlifting.

A new $7,500,000 electronic freight yard was dedicated at Youngstown, Ohio, yesterday by the Pittsburgh and Lake Eric Railroad, the New York Central Railroad's prosperous coal and steel-carrying affiliate.

Bernsie's Express, interstate trucking company with head quarters in Lyndhurst, N. J., has bought the two-story freight terminal with a capacity for ten trailer trucks at 703 Washington Street. The property has a frontage of 123 feet on Washington Street, northeast corner of Perry Street.

WASHINGTON, May 1 (UP) -- The Senate passed a bill today that gives pensions, for the first time, to the widows of Confederate veterans. The measure also increases the pensions of widows of veterans in all conflicts before World War I.
TUCKAHOE, N. Y., May 1 -Two members of the golfing Turnesa family, Mike and Jim, teamed to share the lead in the Westchester Professional Golfers Association tournament today.
Meade Alcorn, Republican national chairman, met here yesterday with the Republican state chairmen of most Northeastern states to arrange for a coordination of national and state campaigns this fall.
Earnings of Sterling Drug, Inc., for the first quarter of this year rose 9.8 per cent above the 1957 level on a sales gain of 11.2 per cent, James Hill Jr., chairman, reported yesterday.

GLEN COVE, L. I., May 1 -- Two physicians agreed today that "the time was approaching when Roy Campanella will be ready to start a rehabilitation program." The 36-year-old Los Angeles Dodgers catcher suffered a broken neck and subsequent paralysis of the lower body in an automobile crash in January.

Today's new film, at Loew's State, is "Another Time, Another Place," a Paramount drama filmed in England, with Lana Turner, Barry Sullivan, Glynis Johns and Sean Connery. Joseph Kaufman produced and Lewis Allen directed from a screenplay by Stanley Mann, based on Leonore Coffee's novel of the same name.

LEONIA, N. J., May 1 -- The Northern Valley Commuters Organization, representing 1,367 riders of the Erie Railroad's Northern Branch line, asked the road's 19,000 other commuters today to join in combating a proposed increase in Hudson River ferry fares.

VIENNA, May 1 -- Today's May Day celebration in Vienna was marked by a warning by Chancellor Julius Raab that further cooperation with the Socialist party in Austria's thirteen-year coalition government was becoming impossible.

Oxford University Press, Inc., has leased a floor at 417 Fifth Avenue, at Thirty-eighth Street, after thirty years at 114 Fifth Avenue, at Sixteenth Street. The publishing concern was established in 1478 and has had a New York branch since 1896.
A 38-year-old Filipino surgeon was held without bail yesterday when he was arraigned in the Brooklyn Felony Court on a charge of slaying a Brooklyn nurse.
The Baltimore and Ohio Railroad's new $2,000,000 carfloat terminal at the foot of West Twenty-Third Street will be opened on Wednesday.
A solar-powered hearing aid -- said to be the first -- was introduced yesterday by the Zenith Radio Corporation.
LONDON, May 1 -- The stock market continued to advance today on a wide front. Business volume, however, was smaller than yesterday's.
A Bethlehem - Youngstown merger would serve the public interest by increasing steel available for both civilian and defense needs, it was testified yesterday.

An article in The Times of April 20 stated that studies aimed at easing traffic congestion in the city's garment area "have been quietly shelved." One sentence read: "The garment industry wrecked the plan as it did another one ten years ago by responding to it with apathy."
WASHINGTON, May 1 -- Alaska s bid for admittance as a forty-ninth state appeared to be slated for a showdown vote in the House of Representatives by May 15.

Duquesne Light Company and subsidiaries yesterday reported gains in operating revenues and net income for the twelve and three months period ended March 31, although electrical sales in the first quarter trailed the year-ago level by 4 per cent.

WASHINGTON, May 1 (AP) -The Department of Agriculture announced today it would support grower prices for 1959 crop wheat at an average of not less than $1.81 a bushel, provided growers voted to continue marketing quotas another year.
WASHINGTON, May 1 -- Following is the transcript of Secretary Dulles' news conference today as made public by the State Department:

WASHINGTON, May 1 (UP) -- A Government expert on atomic hazards said today that a Federal shelter system would cost too much. He recommended instead that citizens should build their own dual-purpose or wine-cellar shelters at home.
WASHINGTON, May 1 -- A lusty, wordy battle in which George Meany called Joseph Curran a liar was suspended at least temporarily today.
Pravda has reported that the dog Laika revealed an unexpected effect of weightlessness when she was launched into space on Sputnik II last November.
Patrons have been announced for the benefit variety show the Harlem Branch of the New York City Mission Society will present in Carnegie Hall tomorrow evening.
The Navy's ninth annual supply mission to the nation's northern defense system will begin today with the sailing of the auxiliary icebreaker Redbud for Arctic waters.

In courthouses, in schools and in places where citizens meet to discuss their common interests in this free land Law Day U.S.A. was celebrated yesterday. In the rotunda of the County Courthouse on Foley Square here in New York City distinguished speakers extolled the blessings of living in a country dedicated to even-handed justice under laws of our own making.

The Bay Shore Business Center, a taxpayer containing a King Kullen supermarket and seven other stores on Sunrise Highway, Bay Shore, L. I., has been sold by Bayshore Business Center, Inc., for cash over a first mortgage of $225,000.

A Harvard economist testified yesterday that the proposed merger of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation and Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company would increase competition in the steel industry, especially in the Midwest.
VIENTIANE, Laos, May 2 -- Observers here believe next Sunday's elections for the Laos Assembly may well be decisive for the political future of this landlocked Southeast Asian state.

Net sales of Johnson Johnson and its domestic subsidiaries in the first three months this year totaled $64,793,000, or 1 per cent below the $65,421,000 record volume attained in the period a year ago.
DETROIT, May 2 -- Negotiators for the General Motors Corporation and the United Automobile Workers decided today to step up the tempo of their bargaining sessions.

KOROR, Palau, April 25 -- Perhaps the only thing unusual about John Olbedabel's problem is that it exists in Palau, a weirdly lovely chain of islands in the Western Carolines very far from Madison Avenue. John is having a hard time paying off the installments on the electric range.

Walter C. Louchheim Jr.'s letter published April 22 citing the Congressional timetable and maintaining that the good of the country calls for a general reduction of income taxes by June 30, overlooks the relevant current economic facts.
WASHINGTON, May 2 -- The Air Force announced today that it had found structural inadequacies in the B-47 Stratojet bombers that are the mainstay of the Strategic Air Command.

LONDON, May 2 -- The stock market lost some of its recent buoyancy today. With the exception of British Government securities, share prices drifted lower. However, falls reflected the lack of buying rather than an increase in selling, and the undertone was described as firm.

LONDON, May 2 (Reuters) -- World shipyards have orders for 34,000,000 gross tons of ships in spite of a current decline in shipping demand, according to the British Treasury's April bulletin for industry, published today.
Hardly a day passes without producing fresh statistical evidence from Washington that the contraction of economic activity is still proceeding uninterruptedly in this, the second quarter of 1958.
A husband and wife arrested in Chinatown on Thursday were held in $100,000 bail each yesterday on a charge of felonious possession of heroin.
WASHINGTON, May 2 -- The Post Office has appointed a new "judicial officer" to assure a fairer hearing to persons accused of sending obscene or fraudulent material through the mails.

WESTBURY, L. I., May 2 -The dream of all horse players, a $100 -- or better -- winning mutuel became a reality for 752 persons at Roosevelt Raceway tonight when Lite Direct won the third race. There were eighteen $10 tickets, thirty-six $5 pasteboards and 698 of the $2 variety on the victorious 5-year-old gelding, who returned $112.80 for $2.
DARIEN, Conn., May 2 -- The Park and Recreation Commission, bowing before a gale of protest, decided last night to postpone its plan for new beach fees this summer.
RIO DE JANEIRO, May 2 (AP) -- Brazil shipped 1,200,000 bags of coffee in April, compared with 700,000 in the same 1957 month, Finance Minister Jose Maria Alkmim said last night.

Philip J. Schupler, former City Councilman and member of the State Assembly, was found dead yesterday by the police in his home in Brooklyn. An assistant medical examiner said that the probable cause of death was an overdose of sedatives.
ALBANY, May 2 -- The State Board of Law Examiners announced today the names of 373 persons who passed the bar examination held last March. A total of 840 took the test.

Because Americans are growing larger these days, the new concert hall in the Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts will have fewer seats than Carnegie Hall, which it will replace as the home of the New York Philharmonic.

The National Department Stores Corporation, which has been disposing of its store properties for three years, will ask stockholders next month to approve a change in its name to the International Mining Corporation, if the Securities and Exchange Commission approves.
Today's new film is "Boule de Suif," a Russian-made adaptation of the de Maupassant story, featuring the Moscow Art Players, at the Cameo Theatre.

LINCOLNDALE, N. Y., May 2 -- Cardinal Spellman celebrated his sixty-ninth birthday anniversary today two days ahead of time to share festivities with twenty-five other "birthday boys." Mayor Wagner of New York was a guest.

If homemakers loosened their purse strings to buy now what they needed and could afford, the country would be headed back to prosperity, a group of them was advised yesterday. The speaker was Howard S. Cohoon, director of the Homemakers' Forum.

HARRIMAN N. Y., May 2 -- The Thirteenth American Assembly at Arden House here moved toward general agreement today on the proposition that the United States should welcome the nonalignment of the emerging nations of Africa.

The Better Business Bureau of New York City, Inc., began to move yesterday from 280 Broadway to enlarged quarters at 220 Church Street, a few blocks away. The telephone number remains DIgby 9-0475. Growth in demands on the bureau since 1948 caused the move.

NEWARK, May 2 -- Northern New Jersey's strike of construction workers spread today to other parts of the state. Workers in Bergen, Passaic, Union and Morris Counties were joined by 200 bricklayers in Camden.

In the excitement caused by the signing of the bill which was limited to the payment of uncashed salary checks of Professor Hastings, a bill of much wider scope was signed by Governor Harriman two days previously. It has been overlooked by the press.

MINEOLA, L. I., May 2 -- Bruce Zator, the 15-year-old boy accused of a murder at Massapequa High School on Wednesday, waived an examination in court this morning. He was ordered held for the grand jury by Judge Albert C. Moore in Mineola District Court.

Poland's fear of Germany is developing into Moscow's trump card for solidifying Polish-Soviet relations. The propaganda campaign now being carried out in Poland, about the menace allegedly implicit in the atomic arming of West Germany, appears to be successful enough for the moment to neutralize at least partly Polish concern about Moscow's attitude toward Yugoslavia.

Without vetoes or vituperation, a peaceful settlement was reached yesterday in the troubled relations between the Consulate General of Switzerland in New York and Murray Moss of East Flatbush, Brooklyn.

It is a fact, discernible to the dullest eye, that mankind in the springtime becomes divided into two sharply defined classes. They are the doers and the dreamers, the toilers and the thinkers, the persons of accomplishment and the persons of contemplation, the gardeners of the earth earthy and the tillers of the fields of imagination and reflection. And, as was said long ago, never the twain shall meet.

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- Unemployment among workers covered by the compensation system showed in late April the first over-all improvement in many weeks, the Labor Department reported today. Part of the improvement was seasonal.

The cost of providing a single tourist-class accommodation aboard a trans-Atlantic liner has quadrupled in the past twenty years, Arnold Bernstein said yesterday. Meanwhile, he added, tourist fares have risen only 30 per cent.
BONN, Germany, May 2 --The West German Government was reported today to have urged that it be freed of its obligation to break up mammoth industrial combinations.

CHICAGO, May 2 -- Yielding to a Federal court order, 800 Chicago longshoremen today began unloading cargo from foreign flag ships tied up by a week-long pilot's strike. The longshoremen had refused to cross the pilot's picket line.
SAN ANTONIO, Tex., May 2 (UP) -- Five tornadoes smashed homes and a school building in Texas today. At the same time flood waters covered more than a half-million acres in three Southwest states.

The summit is enshrouded in fog. There are the miasmas spread by the Russians, culminating in their veto yesterday; there are our own uncertainties; there are the widening doubts of our allies. This is a good time to look back at the road we have taken and to survey the road ahead. The basic facts are these:
Mayor Wagner yesterday directed Correction Commissioner Anna M. Kross to report to him "as soon as possible" on the disturbance last Saturday night in the Women's House of Detention.

THE demise of portraiture in oils was frequently predicted in the early days of the camera. Undoubtedly a number of humdrum face painters were put out of work, but their loss was small and the high priests of portraiture today continue to thrive as in the past.

LOUISVILLE, May 2 -- It rained here through most of the day, and everyone in the blue grass region started guessing about tomorrow. The conjecture was applied to just about every phase of this big show at Churchill Downs, and how wet weather would affect it.

SEOUL, Korea, May 2 -- South Korea chose its legislators for the next four years in a nationwide election today. The fourth general election since the founding of the republic was held in an orderly atmosphere in good weather. Several incidents of minor violence were reported.
A campaign was started yesterday to enlist the aid of business interests in the project for a $10,000,000 engineering center on United Nations Plaza.
Forecasting the outcome of today's Kentucky Derby shared the interest at Jamaica yesterday with the achievements of two apprentice riders.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 2 -- The United Nations made public today the names of twenty-one physical scientists who will take part in the second International Conference on Peaceful Uses of Atomic Energy. The two-week meeting opens in Geneva Sept. 1.
Science and education will fail society if they produce only technicians whose minds are stuffed with facts, the first president of the Downstate Medical Center in Brooklyn said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- Following is a statement by Dr. Arthur E. Ruark, chief of controlled thermonuclear research of the Atomic Energy Commission, on the four methods being pursued to bring thermonuclear reactions under control:

The new capital market keeps going along at a high level of activity. It lost some demand during the past week, owing not so much to big supply as to pricing of the new securities at the limit of what they might get.
PHILADELPHIA, May 2 -- An agreement was reached this afternoon in the week-long tie-up in the handling of dry cargo in the port of Philadelphia.

KICKING every other foot of the way, Charles Preuss took part in three of the most celebrated explorations of the Rocky Mountain country in the Eighteen Forties. He was an expert mapmaker. His endeavors strengthened John Charles Fremont's flamboyant reputation as the Pathmarker of the West.
An Eastern Air Lines plane was severely damaged yesterday morning when it rolled off the end of the runway after landing through fog at Newark Airport.

Zero Mostel has signed contracts to portray the principal role of Leopold Bloom in "Ulysses in Nighttown." This is the play that Padraic Colum has extracted from the 800-page modern classic "Ulysses," by James Joyce.
BANDUNG, Indonesia, May 2 -- President Sukarno appealed to the United States tonight to reappraise its policy toward Indonesia. He strongly advised Washington "don't play with fire."
Today's teen-ager may have a bright future as a local politician, or administrator, or municipal bond salesman in the late Nineteen Sixties and early Seventies.
WASHINGTON, May 2 -- The chief scientist of the Defense Department's space agency said tonight that the United States should be able to launch recoverable earth satellites in 1959 or 1960.

The senior class of Hunter College won the forty-second annual Sing competition yesterday, their second victory in a row. The winning theme was "Emotions." The junior class production, "Television," took second place.

A one-story industrial building and parking lot at 31-35 West Moreland Avenue, White Plains, Westchester County, has been purchased by Key Liquors, Inc., distributor of Schenley products, for use as a warehoue and distribution center.
FORT WORTH, Tex., May 2 (AP) -Tommy Bolt toured a waterlogged course in par 70 today, to push into first place in the $25,000 Colonial Country Club golf tournament.
The scheduled reopening tomorrow of the Church of the Hoily Trinity in Brooklyn Heights was canceled last night by the Right Rev. James P. DeWolfe, Protestant Episcopal Bishop of Long Island.
Round Hill increased its lead yesterday in Series I of the Westchester division of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's inter-club team matches.
WASHINGTON, May 2 -- Gen. Thomas D. White today put the Air Force unequivocally behind the spirit and letter of President Eisenhower's Pentagon reorganization bill.
MIAMI, Fla., May 2 (AP) -- Three men were under Federal indictment today on charges they had used the mails in operating a scheme to defraud four banks through juggling fictitious balances.
WHITE PLAINS, May 2 -- Westchester's economy, compared with that of the rest of the state and nation, is sound and stable, county leaders in industry and commerce agreed today.
A sweep of first places in three throwing events staged at Ohio Field yesterday sent Manhattan off winging toward its ninth consecutive Metropolitan Intercollegiate track and field title.
Many cocktail and dinner parties were given last night in advance of the Junior Republic Ball held in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria.

ALBANY, May 2 -- Five of six speakers at an abbreviated State Unemployment Conference today favored a reduction in Federal taxes and accelerated programs of public works to lift the nation's economy out of the recession.
HAMILTON, Bermuda, May 2 (AP) -- United States yachtsmen won the Amorita Cup for International One Design craft by taking the seventh and final race today after losing the sixth on fouls.

In the first change of ownership in seventy years, the five five-story buildings at 146-50 Second Avenue, at Ninth Street, were sold by John H. Morris, representing the Morris estate. The buildings occupy a plot 74.9 by 125 feet and contain apartments and nine stores.

RIVERHEAD, L. I., May 2 -- Suffolk County's public health and agricultural officials reported today that the wood tick infestation on Long Island had started earlier because of the late, wet spring and was heavier than usual.

The World Bank made a loan equaling $28,000,000 yesterday for the railways of Nigeria. The loan will help to finance a five-year program to improve the rail systems and to build a new line into the northeastern provinces.

The Electric Bond and Share Company reported yesterday a 5 per cent gain in net assets for the first quarter, over the previous three months. The March 31 total, however, trailed the 1957 figure by almost $16,000,000.

ROME, May 2 (UP) -- Samuel Cardinal Stritch left his bed today to conduct Roman Catholic Church business for the first time since his arm was amputated Monday. He conferred honors off a physician and a churchman.

The Mary MacArthur Memorial Fund will be augmented by the proceeds of a supper ball on Monday. The fete, to take place at the Astor, will follow the premiere of "The Visit," starring Alfred Lunt and Lynn Fontanne, and the opening of the Lunt-Fontanne Theatre, which will house the play.

MORE emphasis has been placed on nutrition in the last few months than ever before. Despite the fact that the American food supply is unsurpassed in volume, nutritional value and variety, authorities note that there are dietary deficiencies at every income level and that 20 per cent of the nation's population is overweight.
WASHINGTON, May 2 (AP) -- A Senate Banking Subcommittee today completed public hearings on small business financing bills. It arranged to start closed sessions next Thursday to draft legislation.
BALBOA, C. Z, May 2 -Fifty Panamanian flags were planted today at various central points in the United States jurisdiction of the Canal Zone by members the Panama Students Union.
WASHINGTON, May 2 -- The Atomic Energy Commission disclosed today three major new approaches by the United States to control the vast power of the thermonuclear reaction.

ANKARA, Turkey, May 2 -Five Ankara editors and a columnist took part today in the funeral of a judge who had imposed prison sentences on them. One was arrested after the funeral and the others awaited orders to begin prison terms.
Anyone who has traveled extensively abroad knows that thousands of hours and many thousands of dollars are squandered on filling out endless forms.
Two contract disputes erupted in the television industry yesterday.
One has only to look at Louise Parker, who made her debut last night with the New York City Opera Company, to sense an unusual warmth, human kindness and dignity.
WASHINGTON, May 2 -- President and Mrs. Eisenhower and Secretary and Mrs. Dulles will make an informal three-day visit to Canada in July.

THE "Spring, 1958" exhibition at the Downtown Gallery, 32 East Fifty-first Street, ranges far and wide from American folk art of the late eighteenth and early ninteenth centuries to a handsome new Stuart Davis painting of symbols and portents of contemporary hurly-burly life.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 2 -- Victor Mature and United Artists have scheduled for production in the fall "Escape From Andersonville," an original screenplay by Norman Corwin.
Plans for the Grand Opera and Civic Auditorium that Frank Lloyd Wright designed for the city of Baghdad were exhibited last night at the Iraqi Consulate, 14 East Seventy-ninth Street.

The Department of Justice was assailed yesterday by the American Jewish Congress for rejecting an invitation to a conference that will consider means of dealing with the outbreak of bombings in the South.

"Memoirs of a Public Baby," the autobiography of Philip O'Connor, will be issued in an American edition by the British Book Centre on May 26. Mr. O'Connor is one of Britain's "angry young men." His book is "an evocation of a wildly unorthodox" childhood, of the literary underworld in the Thirties, of "bitterly involved" personal relationships and of his being on the borderline between sanity and madness.
An eighty-acre dumpsite on Staten Island is the scene these days of a copper rush.
The reconstituted City Housing Authority held its first meeting yesterday and named Gerald J. Carey as acting general manager. Mr. Carey had been assistant to the chairman in the old authority.
Michael Gregory Minsky, a Ukraine-born baritone, made his New York debut last night in Carnegie Recital Hall.
LONDON, May 2 (Reuters) -A tunnel between England and France under the English Channel, first suggested by Napoleon 150 years ago, moved a step nearer reality today.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 2 -The director of the Vanguard satellite program said today that the band of intense radiation discovered in space had not dashed hopes for travel to the moon and distant planets.
NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., May 2 -- The problems of "raising children who may reach for the moon" are not too different from the problems of raising children who may "reach" for the suburbs.

PHILADELPHIA, May 2 -The South Korean parents of Oh In Ho, slain University of Pennsylvania student, today asked Philadelphia authorities to be lenient with the teenagers who waylaid and beat him to death last Friday night.

ALL is not lost to the chemise in the fashion world after all. So long as the five American designers shown at the right are in there pitching, there will always be a well-rounded bosom, a waist nipped in where the waistline belongs and a gently flared skirt to give a flattering hip line.

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- The growing feeling here that Moscow does not want a heads-of-government conference was reinforced today by the Soviet veto of the United States' Arctic inspection plan in the United Nations.
LONG BEACH, Calif., May 2 (AP) -- The first convention of a merged union of public employes announced today the election of thirteen officers.

ALBANY, May 2 -- Thomas A. Murray, president of the State Federation of Labor, collapsed in the Assembly chamber today five minutes after having addressed a conference on unemployment. He died minutes later in an adjoining office.
Three major concerns in the steel, aircraft production and farm equipment manufacturing fields announced stepped-up production schedules yesterday after receiving increased orders for their products.

The Very Rev. James A. Pike, Dean of the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine, will be consecrated Coadjutor Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of California on May 15 in Grace Cathedral, San Francisco.

A young man who tricked the New York Public Library into thinking he was a scholarly novel-writer was charged yesterday with having stolen twenty-one valuable manuscripts from the library. Martin Richard Strich, 26 years old, who lives with his father in an imposing apartment house at 41 Park Avenue, was trapped by an autograph dealer who had bought some of the yellowing papers for $1,863.
CHICAGO, May 2 (AP) -- The report on today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
CAIRO, May 2 -- The Soviet bloc has opened a subtle but intensive campaign to sabotage the current move toward better relations between the West and the regime of President Gamal Abdel Nasser.

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- The United States announced today that it would fire short-range defensive missiles armed with nuclear warheads in operations to be conducted soon at Johnston Island in the Pacific.

BONN, Germany, May 2 -- The most significant accretion of buildings in West Germany is an unimpressive lot of modern or purely temporary structures that have mushroomed up around the dilapidated barracks which formerly served as Bonn's Defense Ministry. For this is where the brain of Free Europe's most powerful army is housed.
MOST nuclear physicists in the United States today may be found in one of two philosophic camps.

Organized labor in New York City has endorsed a suggested standard of giving for the 1958 campaign of the Greater New York Fund, after a conference between the New York City C. I. O. Council, the Central Trades and Labor Council, independent unions and volunteer management representatives.
General Manager George M. Weiss denied yesterday the Yankees were planning any immediate reprisals against the National League for invading New York with a rash of televised games.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 2 -Immigration officials fought contempt action today in a three-hour Federal Court session. They were accused of having sent William Heikkila, a former Communist, to his native Finland in the face of a restraining order barring his deportation.

India's international position in respect to Kashmir will not be well served by the re-arrest of Sheikh Abdullah, formerly Kashmir's most popular leader and political figure. He had been kept in detention, without the filing of any charges, for four and a half years. In January of this year he was released, but kept under close surveillance. Now he is again imprisoned, again without charges against him.

DURHAM, N. H., May 2 -- Secretary of State Dulles asserted tonight that the Soviet veto of a proposal to police the Arctic airlanes kept the world on the brink of war. He termed the significance of the veto "frightening" and said that the result was "tragic." Mr. Dulles added that "we shall have to go on living on the edge of an awful abyss."

LOUISVILLE, May 2 -- Ancient Archie Moore is beginning to find it increasingly difficult to disillusion, disorganize and dismantle the tough young squirts he has to meet these days. But the Ageless One still knows how to defeat them.
NEW CANAAN, Conn., May 2 -- New Canaan has decided to commit its public school system to the theory of grouping pupils according to their ability.
The constitutional right of a newspaper writer not to divulge a source of information was debated yesterday before the United States Court of Appeals here.

The nation's 8,842 state-chartered commercial banks recorded net profits before dividends of $662,982,000 last year, an increase of $79,172,000, or 13.6 per cent above 1956, the American Bankers Association reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 2 -- A patent issued this week lists Dr. Allen B. Du Mont as the inventor of a television set on which father can watch baseball while mother watches drama.
WASHINGTON, May 2 -- It was New Jersey day today in the Federal school fight.

The Barium Steel Corporation recorded a net loss of $422,700 in the first quarter this year, compared with a net profit of $2,058,055, or 51 cents a share in the similar three months last year. J. A. Sisto, president and chairman, announced the results to stockholders at the annual meeting yesterday in Phoenixville, Pa.
SHORTENING slips has got to be more of a national pastime than baseball.
PARIS, Saturday, May 3 -- France's Government crisis took an acute turn for the worse early today.

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- President Eisenhower today praised international golf as a means of easing world tensions. He made a suggestion to golf officials gathered here from thirty-five nations: Let a few duffers play in a world tournament. that the competition calls for a four-man team of experts to represent each country in seventy-two-hole play. Only the three low scorers on each team will be counted.
A Communist party leader, Robert Thompson, called yesterday for a new major purge of the party.

WASHINGTON, May 2 (UP) -- The Association of American Railroads reported today that the estimated net income of major railroads during the first quarter of 1958 dropped 81.5 per cent below that for the same period a year ago.

We have frequently had occasion to speak with enthusiasm of various projects that sent American athletes and athletic teams to foreign countries. This is an important part of the road to better international understanding. For that reason it is a pleasure to welcome a foreign athletic team that has returned the compliment and has come here.
CHICAGO, May 2 (AP) -- James J. Killian, Milwaukee labor leader, was convicted today for the second time of falsely denying that he ever was a communist.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 2 -- The first successful use of bone-marrow injections to protect human patients from the effects of large doses of radiation was reported here this week at the thirty-ninth annual meeting of the American College of Physicians.
The top administrative officials of the United States Merchant Marine Academy have come out in favor of placing the institution's teaching staff under Civil Service.

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- The wholesale price index of average primary market prices declined 0.1 per cent to 119.3 per cent of its 1947-49 level during the week ended last Tuesday, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.
Plainclothes patrolmen in the tenth inspection division rounded up eighty-eight men and one woman yesterday in a series of policy raids in Harlem and East Harlem.
WASHINGTON, May 2 (AP) -- Agreements for construction and operation of demonstration nuclear power plants at Elk River, Minn., and Piqua, Ohio, were announced today by the Atomic Energy Commission.

PORT - AU - PRINCE, Haiti, May 2 -- Haiti's National Assembly voted a state of siege today, giving the Government emergency powers and suspending Constitutional guarantees and the immunity of members of the Assembly.
TORONTO, May 2 (Canadian Press) -- The Mexican Light and Power Company, Ltd., had a net profit in 1957 of $4,889,221, or $1.96 a common share, compared with $4,129,231, or $1.67 a share, in 1956.
The Greater New York Insurance Brokers Association accused the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority yesterday of "favoritism" in the selection of insurance brokers for construction contracts.
ROCHESTER, May 2 (AP) -- Teaching seventh-grade boys how to diaper babies does not meet with the favor of a school commissioner here, the mother of seven children.
TRENTON, May 2 -- Top officials of two of the country's largest insurance underwriters debated here today the merits of legalizing variable annuity contracts.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 2 -- The Soviet Union vetoed today a United States plan to establish an international air-inspection zone over the Arctic regions.

An anonymous telephone call made to the court of Bronx County Judge Eugene G. Schulz warned that an attempt would be made to free Ramon Serra, 20-year-old accused murderer, the judge disclosed yesterday.
CHICAGO, May 2 (AP) -- Moderate liquidation sent nearly all grain futures slightly lower on the Board of Trade today.

In the course of our work with various community organizations in furtherance of the campaign of the Mayor's Committee for Pedestrian Safety we find that there is a misconception on the part of some that this is an educational effort directed at only the pedestrian segment of the population.
WASHINGTON, May 2 -- Ezra Taft Benson is likely to sound out at first hand the possibilities of trade in agricultural products with the Soviet Union during his trip to Russia this summer.

BERNARDSTON, Mass., May 2 -- At long Last, as kings say when they blow their jobs, a vicious old canard has been exposed, exploded, and expunged. Country boys equipped with aboriginal tackle do not always catch the most and biggest fish, and sometimes they catch no fish at all.

Good fortune, good sense and a high degree of civic responsibility and patriotism have combined in Colombia to bring about the best possible solution of the country's internal politics. Alberto Lleras Camargo is being nominated as the bipartisan candidate for the Presidential elections tomorrow.
Your issue of April 28 carries a story regarding an article of mine in the current issue of Fortune magazine. I believe your story is misleading in at least two important respects.

MOSCOW, May 2 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold was accused today of ignoring precedent in supporting a "dangerous" United States proposal for control and inspection of military flights in the Arctic.
With three satellites in space, the United States already has enough basic knowledge to blueprint with considerable certainty our next step into the "wild blue yonder."
TAIPEI, Taiwan, May 2 (UP) -- The United States Air Force fired today a Matador guided missile for the first time in the Far East.

An explosion yesterday afternoon at Lexington Avenue and Sixtieth Street injured a laborer and a passing surgeon. It was apparently caused by gas that had accumulated in an excavation for an underground escalator being constructed to connect the I. R. T. and B. M. T. subway stations.

The Kansas City Athletics moved into the Stadium yesterday amid considerable fanfare. Long held in low regard as favored "cousins" of the Yankees, they were out to prove that their high position in the American League pennant race was no springtime mirage.

WASHINGTON, May 2 (UP) -- The head of President Eisenhower's Council on Youth Fitness said tonight that the United States was becoming a nation of softies because of "buttons, dials and gadgets" and "over-protecting parents."
COPENHAGEN, Denmark, May 2 -- The Western powers have demonstrated their will to prepare for a summit conference and will not be diverted by procedural difficulties, Paul-Henri Spaak said today.
Aircrafts and steels took the lead in an otherwise uncertain stock market yesterday and produced moderate gains for the list as a whole.

Yesterday in the Security Council was one of the worst days the United Nations ever had. The debate, if it could be called that, which resulted in the Soviet veto of the American-Swedish proposal for a system of inspection in the Arctic areas, was as fair an answer as could have been made to the Soviet charge that our planes, armed with atomic weapons, were making forays in the direction of "the Russian frontiers."
WASHINGTON, May 2 (AP) -- Spokesmen for the copper, lead and zinc mining industries told Congress today that what is needed is protection from imports, not a subsidy.
Three Soviet youth officials supplemented their words with deeds yesterday to the delight of Barnard College girls.
Events today: Weill's "Lost in the Stars," New York City Opera 'Company, City Center, 8:15; National Music Week Concert, Julius Grossman conducting, Town Hall, 8:30.

NAPLES, Italy, May 2 (UP) -Mimi Arnold of Redwood City, Calif.. defeated Louise Snow of Bakersfield, Calif., 6 -- 2. 6 -- 0, today to gain the women's singles semi-finals of the Naples international tennis tournament.
State and municipal long-term financing during April totaled $715,122,409, compared with $763,411,449 for April, 1957, according to the Daily Bond Buyer.
BOGOTA, Colombia, May 2 -- Four members of Colombia's five-man military junta were kidnapped this morning, but were freed several hours later.
Futures prices closed generally higher yesterday on the New York exchanges. Trading in most markets was dull. Evening of positions prior to the week-end accounted for most of the volume.
Dr. Morris A. Jacobs, Commissioner of Hospitals, said yesterday that his department had not changed its policy on birth-control information for patients in city hospitals.
CHICAGO, May 2 (UP) -- Constantine Papageorge, 61 years old, was sentenced today to 181 days in jail. He never paid any income tax.
Eight gunmen took $33,428 in cash yesterday in four hold-ups in the midtown area.

WASHINGTON, May 2 (AP) -Walter S. Robertson, Assistant Secretary of State for Far Eastern Affairs, said today that if Congress made drastic cuts in foreign aid, or abandoned the reciprocal trade agreements program, "no one except the Communists would rejoice."

SEBRING, Fla., May 2 (UP) -- five-year-old Michael Sickle 3d, reported kidnapped Tuesday from his front yard in Middlesex, N. J., was found near here today, headed toward Miami with his grandparents and an aunt. Authorities said the "kidnapping" was apparently a result of a family squabble over the child's custody.
VIENNA'S celebrated chocolate cakes, sacher torts, are being flown here especially for the Goddard Gala Monday night.

WASHINGTON, May 2 -Rebel police seized Dr. Alberto Lleras Camargo, the Presidential candidate backed by Colombia's two major parties in Sunday's election, but Army officers later rescued him unharmed early today, Dr. Jose Gutierrez-Gomez, Colombian Ambassador to the United States, said tonight.
MONTREAL, May 2 (UP) -Dave Crosby of Concord, Mass., today won the Canadian 410gauge open title during the opening day of the national skeet shooting championships at the Montreal Skeet Club.
LONDON, May 2 -- Hope that the threatened strike of London busmen would be averted faded today when Iain Macleod, Minister of Labor, declined to intervene.

BUENOS AIRES, May 2 -Vice President Richard M. Nixon said tonight Argentina's chances of receiving United States aid through Government loans and private capital were "better today than they have been for ten years."

ALBANY, May 2 -- The names of the 300 winners of state nursing scholarships were announced today by the State Education Department. A total of 2,544 applicants took the competitive examination on Jan. 23 and 24.
DETROIT, May 2 (AP) -- Chevrolet's return to more nearly normal output this week raised the auto industry's indicated output to 79,661 cars and 18,007 trucks, Ward's Automotive Reports said today.

Manufacturing employment in the Philadelphia area dropped to 517,500 in March, 7,300 below the February level and 41,000 below that a year earlier. Statistics compiled by the Bureau of Employment Security of the Pennsylvania State Employment Service showed food, non-electrical machinery and fabricated metal products accounted for the largest reductions in activity.
BANDUNG, Indonesia, May 3 -- President Sukarno, former Vice President Mohammed Hatta and a $500,000 swimming pool shared the spotlight today in this mountain-framed city.
THE gardener should look over his store of tools carefully. It could be that some new additions -- designed especially for the particular chore -- will make the work easier.

OLDER Japanese who deplore the current craze for rock 'n' roll and its effect on their teen-age daughters are taking immense comfort from the success of sober, sad-faced Michiya Mihashi. This young singer of lugubrious Japanese folk songs, whose instrument is not the guitar but the classical, sweet, three-stringed samisen, is unquestionably more popular with all ages than any of the Japanese imitators of Elvis who have been packing the theatres.

THIS May 23 is recorded as the thirteenth centenary of the birth of the English apostle and Bishop, Saint Willibrord, who in 689 founded the Benedictine monastery in Echternach in northeastern Luxembourg.

CAMDEN, N. J., May 3 (AP) -- Sharpsburg, a Calumet Farm castoff, today turned back the 1957 Kentucky Derby winner of his former owner in taking the $28,750 Valley Forge Handicap at the Garden State opener.
ORANGEBURG, N. Y., May 3 -- Three women and a man were killed early today when an automobile crashed into a car that had been in a head-on collision five minutes earlier.
ROBERT L. JOSEPH and Lester Osterman, collaborating with the new play producing firm of International Playwrights, have found a leading man for their production of George Tabori's "Brouhaha."

Ray, and Dr. C. E. McIlwain, University of Iowa physicists.
A research project aimed at identifying and alleviating some of the social and educational problems confronting changing suburban communities is under way at Columbia University's Teachers College.

EASTON, Pa., May 3 -- The election of Dr. K. Roald Bergethon as president of the Lafayette College was announced today by its board of trustees. The Dean of the College at Brown University, Providence, R. I., will succeed Ralph Cooper Hutchison, who resigned last year.

BALTIMORE, May 3 (AP) -- Brooks Robinson lofted a sacrifice fly with the bases filled in the thirteenth inning today to cap a stout pitching performance by Bill O'Dell of the Baltimore Orioles with a 3-2 victory over the Cleveland Indians.
The participation of countries in the New York trade fair is being reciprocated substantially through United States Government participation in fairs abroad.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 3 -- Syracuse defeated a fast-closing Cornell crew by two feet in the fifth annual Goes Trophy regatta today. Navy finished third, two lengths behind Syracuse.

Rain wiped out the series finale between the Yankees and the Athletics at the Stadium yesterday, but that was a matter Casey Stengel took right in stride. All his managerial acumen was focused on something far more important.
SANTA FE, N. Y., May 3 -- The perennial extravaganza bearing the name of New Mexico politics is heading for its 1958 first act curtain in a primary election May 13.

KOROR, Palau, April 25 -- Ngoriyakl, the Aibedul or High Chief of the Southern Palau Islands in the Western Carolines, has a recession problem on his hands in Peleliu. This is the little island south of here where United States Marines saw some of the fiercest fighting of World War II on Bloody Nose Ridge.

BANGOR, Me., May 3 (UP) -- Senator Clifford P. Case told Maine Young Republicans today that Democratic leadership in the Senate "concentrates on headlines rather than hard remedies" for the recession.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, May 3 -- Current from the new hydroelectric dam and generating plant at La Garita was switched on last night. According to officials of the Costa Rican Electric Institute, it will solve the country's acute power deficit until 1961.

Variable annuities, one of the newer means to provide retirement income, has come in for wider reviewing in recent weeks. They were praised by the head of a teachers' fund, studied by a legislative body and involved in a legal action.

New York becomes the fourth state -- the others are Massachusetts, Rhode Island and Pennsylvania -- to enact modern legislation directed against age bias. The new law prohibits employers from discriminating against employes and job-applicants because of their age.

Former President Herbert Hoover left the hospital yesterday to recuperate at home from an operation for the removal of his gall bladder. Mr. Hoover posed for news pictures for ten minutes at his suite in the Waldorf Towers and talked to newspaper re porters for another ten minutes.

Far from being a dull subject, as it might at first seem, it is vivid, exciting and filled with the sharply bitter-sweet flavor of contrasting cultures, which at first clash and then slowly intermingle with mutual benefits to all.
VENICE, Italy, May 3 (AP) -- Six United States paratroopers burned a Communist election campaign bunting today and caused an uproar.
A five-day art exhibition and sale -- an annual event to aid the Hebrew University in Jerusalem -- opens here today. It features Vincent Van Gogh's "Les Usines a Clichy" (Factories at Clichy).

Retail trade in Kansas City showed some improvement last week against sales in recent weeks. Volume was about on a par with that a year ago. Wearing apparel and household goods, with a specially good movement of small appliances, helped bolster sales.

The Port of New York faces in the next few years the best prospect it has ever had of full-scale modernization of its waterfront facilities.

Unemployment in the Southwest continues to show a smaller increase than normal, state employment officials reported. The Eleventh Federal Reserve Bank, in its monthly summary of business conditions, noted that although the employment decline in March denoted weakness, the rate of decline was less than a month earlier.

IT'S time for the annual springtime reminder of last year's outstanding crime books, as chosen by the Mystery Writers of America at their Edgar Allan Poe Awards Dinner on the last Friday in April. If any of these justly award-winning books have so far escaped your attention, please hurry to rewarding pleasures.
KINGSTON, N. Y., April 30 -- A suave and massive skepticism gripped this Hudson Valley city this week as former Senator Bernard Tompkins opened his investigation of Ulster county kickbacks.

Dr. R. E. Robertson, a chief scientist of North American Aviation, is the latest person to speak out for a reasoned space program. He joins Dr. L. A. DuBridge, President of the California Institute of Technology and Dr. Hugh L. Dryden, Director of the National Advisory Committee for Aeronautics, in urging careful concentration of the nation's resources on first things first.

GREENWICH, Conn., May 3 -- Mrs. Edwin B. Brooks, chairman of the annual dessert-bridge of the Parents Association of Rosemary Hall, has announced the patron list for the benefit on May 14. The proceeds will be applied to the association's annual gift of $1,000 to the teachers pension fund and for purchases for the school library.
DARIEN, Conn., May 3 -- At friendship born of letters written by two women, one an American and the other a Russian, is now, after six months, showing promise of maturing.

The balloting in free Korea has some good object lessons. The party of President Syngman Rhee has again obtained a solid working majority in the Assembly. But it has not gained the two-thirds that would be needed to amend the Constitution.
ON four separate recordings M-G-M is offering excerpts from the works of four writers. With a fine sense of international balance, the list consists of two living Americans and two dead Englishmen.

THE other day, thousands of people began looking for new stars. Not in the heavens; these people were scanning one of the world's most successful guidebooks, the "Guide Michelin," whose 1958 edition has just appeared.

ADMITTING that "The Arrow of Gold" was autobiography, Joseph Conrad told Sidney Colvin: "There are some of these forty-two-year-old episodes of which I cannot think now without a slight tightness of the chest."

What is distinctive of America is that her intellectuals lack confidence in their own standards, and seek recognition in terms of the prevailing Philistinism. Mr. Hacker's plan is itself an illustration of this. His scheme would not strengthen the position of culture in this country, but would merely carry the capitulation to public taste one stage further.
The first model of a plastic and glass-fiber radome designed to protect radar stations in the Far North was assembled for testing recently near Ottawa.

HOLLYWOOD, May 3 -- Members of the Screen Directors Guild of America authorized a strike today against motion picture and television film producers unless they agreed to renew contract negotiations on the basis of demands, which the producers rejected April 25.
A LEAF-TYING insect called the leaf-tier has become a pest on pachysandra. Once established, it can really damage this popular evergreen groundcover.

IN this novel we meet the people who surround and have surrounded that unhappy but wealthy property, the TV star. We inspect, off-camera, the star himself -- stooping, bespectacled, worried about impotence and dat ole debbil ratings; we discover he is a negligent father to his teen-age daughter, a faithless husband, and a pain in the neck.

BUENOS AIRES, May 3 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon said emphatically today that "dictatorships are repugnant to our people." But his audience of Argentine students went away unconvinced that the United States Government shared this sentiment.

HEROES of exploration, like the heroes of ancient times, tend to become legendary and unreal. Rarely is it possible for us to see them objectively, as they really were. The result is that we have become suspicious of such figures.
WASHINGTON, May 3 (UP) -- Representative John E. Moss demanded today that the Air Force give a "full explanation" of why it tried to keep secret that it had sent a mouse aloft in a rocket April 23.

A non-speculative method of determining steamship charter rates is gaining favor here, and it may break down some of the vessel owners' reluctance to commit tonnage to long-term contracts at today's low rates.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -A chief reason for the problems plaguing President Eisenhower and his party may be found in the difficulties in reviving National Citizens for Eisenhower for the 1958 Congressional campaign.
The First Army held its first symposium yesterday for teenagers interested in rocketry -- a booming new hobby with a potential of serious danger, but also with great scientific promise.
A Queens dairy office manager will not know until tomorrow whether $11,700 of his company's receipts -- or a bag of papers -- is with an armed robber who held him up last night.

New York University's Mike Herman interrupted Manhattan's triumphant parade by retaining the broad jump crown yesterday. Then a lashing rain descended on Downing Stadium, forcing the postponement of the remainder of the twenty-fifth annual metropolitan intercollegiate track and field championships until 4 P. M. tomorrow.

SHUSHAN, N. Y., May 3 -- One of the wise old sayings in this part of the country, and in some others, too, is that trout start striking when the apple blossoms appear. A check of fifty miles or so of trout streams around here and in western Vermont revealed today that the apple trees have not yet bloomed.

CHAUNY, France, May 3 (AP) -- Angered at a rebuff by his mistress, a cafe operator, Daniel Delobel, 28, went on a carefully-mapped shooting spree today. He killed his estranged wife, his former partner, the father of his mistress, and a 3-year-old child.

The nation's 520 mutual savings banks with more than $32 billion in deposits, face an uncomfortable choice. They must decide this week whether to cast their lot politically with the fast growing savings and loan associations or remain with the sometimes unfriendly commercial banks.
A varied assortment of commuters saw Governor Harriman start the state's second annual Open House Week yesterday on the lower level of Grand Central Terminal.

By one yardstick -- the growing membership roll of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development -- Soviet Russia's self-imposed exile from the world of finance is becoming daily more conspicuous.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- For the second week in succession the Administration counter-attacked in the partisan war over its programs that the Democrats have been pressing. And twice Southern Democrats crossed over to re-effect the coalition with moderate Republicans that created many Congressional majorities in President Eisenhower's first term.

DANVILLE, Va., May 3 -- Eighty-five cars practiced today for tomorrow's National Sports Car Club of America races on the Virginia International Raceway. The entries range from Lance Reventlow's new all-American built Scarab down to the little English-built Class K Berkeleys.
DETROIT, May 3 (AP) -- Henry Ford 2d said today he would try to protect Ford workers from union demands that would weaken the company competitively or undermine the economy.

Recently a man and a woman who had been hospitalized for mental illness for a total of eighty-two years were discharged from the Osawatomie State Hospital in Kansas. Both, no longer disturbed, are now in nursing homes.

LOUISVILLE, May 3 -- Tim Tam's victory in today's Kentucky Derby was his seventh in a row, including a success by disqualification in the Flamingo at Hialeah. In that race Jewel's Reward finished first and Tim Tam second. But Bill Hartack, on Tim Tam, claimed a foul against Manuel Ycaza, on Jewel's Reward, and the claim was upheld.

A LITTLE known industry, but one becoming increasingly important commercially in the United States, is the cultivation of sesame plants. This tropical herb thrives under practically the same conditions as cotton, and produces a seed which, when toasted, has a nutlike flavor and crunchy texture.

WESTBURY, L. I., May 3 -- One of the most industrious of all harness racing drives is Billy Haughton -- pronounced How-ton, not Haw-ton the nations top sulky pilot. Last year few drove more standardbreds than he did and none won with more of em than did the 34-year-old reinsman, who started 743 times and won 156 in 1957.

IN a country of bustling cultural consciousness, where exhibitions of painting and sculpture bring out rib-crushing crowds and museums compete with major league baseball, architecture is the forgotten art. This does not mean that the architect isn't busy, or that building isn't booming.

NEW HAVEN, May 3 -- The Rev. Dr. Millar Burrows, an authority on Near Eastern civilizations, semitic languages and archeological excavations, will retire from the Yale University faculty on June 30, it was announced today.
FORT WORTH, May 3 (AP) -- Tommy Bolt shot his second straight par-70 today to increase his advantage to three strokes in the $25,000 Colonial national invitation.

THE Boston Symphony Orchestra is trying out an ingenious new fund-raising idea. High fidelity tape recordings of the orchestra's concerts for the entire season, including the twelve forthcoming concerts of the Berkshire Festival at Tanglewood, are being offered to radio stations throughout the country on a rental basis.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- The United States, Britain and France and reluctantly agreed today to permit their Ambassadors in Moscow to negotiate separately on a heads-ofgovernment meeting with the Soviet Union.
WASHINGTON, May 3 -- Following are the texts of President Eisenhower's statement on the Antarctic and the United States' note to eleven countries:

THOUGH it is only recently that the plays of Friedrich Duerrenmatt have begun to excite attention on this side of the Atlantic, he has already established a solid reputation on the Continent and is generally considered to be one of the most interesting living writers in the German language.

LOUISVILLE, May 3 -- Tim Tam of the Calumet Farm won the eighty-fourth running of the Kentucky Derby today, which was more or less a victory for form. Silky Sullivan finished twelfth in a field of fourteen, and as a consequence put the national thoroughbred picture back to normal.

THE piercing by the Allies, on June 6, 1944, of the Atlantic Wall, which Hitler had hoped would make Festung Europa (Fortress Europe) impenetrable from the West, was the crowning achievement of many forces.

THE trouble with fictionalized true-life stories is that the reader never really knows which part is fiction and which part is true life. This is particularly disturbing in adventure tales whose flavor lies primarily in their assurance to the reader that what may seem unbelievable has really happened.
Gentled and bridled, the International Rapids of the St. Lawrence River are almost ready for harness. Soon after July 1 they will start to work.

WASHINGTON -- Two luxury liners, one for the Atlantic and one for the Pacific, were given a big boost toward the building ways last week when the House of Representatives voted to authorize construction of the vessels with a big government subsidy.

PRINCETON, N. J., May 3 -- There was plenty of water -- everywhere -- as Harvard's heavyweight varsity shell captured the twenty-second Compton Cup regatta on Carnegie Lake today. The Crimson sweep-swingers -- five sophomores, two juniors and a senior -- established a course record of 8:40.6 for a mile and three-quarters.
The United States Lines passenger and cargo fleet was responsible last year for the line's biggest income in twenty-one years.
RICHMOND, Va., May 3 (UP) -- Delegates from five Virginia localities under court orders to integrate schools formed a statewide steering committee today to promote segregated private schools.

The National Geographic Society notes that certain varieties of sesame plants, which have been cultivated for 3,000 years in the Old World, have pods that shatter easily when ripe. It conjectures that this might account for Ali Baba's use of the phrase as the key to the treasure cave.
HACKENSACK, N. J., May 3 -- A "home away from home" for the elderly will be inspected here tomorrow by an invited group. It will be opened to the public next Sunday.
IN form as well as content, Archibald MacLeish's "J. B." ranks with the finest work in American drama.
Green lawns and plane trees. Shaded walks and playgrounds. Light and space. Fireproof apartments that are, if not luxurious, at least purposeful. This is low-rent public housing.

THE two-story house, almost forgotten in the postwar of ground-hugging one-story and split-level homes, is returning. And, if what many architects are predicting comes true, it may be the house of the future, for they foresee smaller and plots and suburban areas turned into crowded cities.
CASCAIS, Portugal, April 27 -- Former King Umberto of Italy is planning his first visit to the United States next year.

An unusual program consisting entirely of vocal duets was presented at Carnegie Recital Hall yesterday afternoon by Patricia Connor, soprano, and Howard Fried, tenor of the New York City Opera Company.
LOS ANGELES, May 3 -- Those erstwhile Brooklyn Dodgers are up to their old tricks of fooling quite a few of the people quite a bit of time.
There is a possible doctoral dissertation on the relationship between popular music and intellectual activity in the achievement of Matthew David Edel.
WASHINGTON, May 3 -- Lewis L. Strauss, chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission, denied tonight that the United States was developing "dirtier" nuclear weapons.

The President's program for reorganizing the Pentagon encountered increasingly rough sledding last week before the House Armed Services Committee as a parade of witnesses registered increasing degrees of dissent.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- The interest the Russians have been showing in the Arctic makes it clear that they believe, as did the late Gen. Henry H. Arnold, World War II Air Corps commander, that the North Pole could be the strategic center of another war.

The policies of both major political parties toward the economic recession were denounced here yesterday as a "disgraceful" display of "cynical politics." The observations were made at an all-day symposium of Americans for Democratic Action, a liberal group.

Heavy rain early last week hurt retail trade considerably. Store officials estimated the drop from the 1957 level at as much as 5 per cent. The first four days of the like week of last year were fair. Last week had considerable rain on Monday and a little on Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- Seven months after the first Soviet satellite jolted the national pride, the Administration and Congress are finally getting organized for the race with the Soviet Union for the conquest of space.
The new Irish-flag service that entered the trans-Atlantic air transport field last week was made possible by the United States aviation industry.
WASHINGTON, May 3 -- The North Atlantic Council will meet next week in Copenhagen on the thirteenth anniversary of the ending of the second World War in Europe.
HONG KONG, April 22 -- Fifteen hundred Chinese fishermen and their families have fled from southern Chinese waters in terror in the last month to seek refuge on the island of Cheung Chau.

COLOMBO, Ceylon -- Ceylon's tourist industry broke a five-year record for earnings last year and hopes to do even better this year by cooperating with India and Pakistan in a South Asian Travel Commission.
MAY'S balmy days are ideal for house and garden tours. Indeed, many garden groups have arranged itineraries that will appeal to city, suburban or country gardeners.

Friday's debate in the U. N. Security Council added no new arguments to the discussion between Russia and the free world. It did not even add new words, except a Russian word used by Delegate Sobolev to belittle the American-Swedish proposal for a system of inspection in the Arctic -- and translated as "gimmick."
BONN, Germany, May 3 -- A Soviet purchasing mission was warmly received this week at the Hanover Industrial Fair by more than sixty West German business men.

CRIPPLE CREEK, Col. -- One of the nicest community stories in Colorado concerns the rise to modest affluence, after a long decline, of this proud old mining camp. Gold worth $700,000,000 has been taken from here since it was discovered in 1890.

THE triumph that has been won by "My Fair Lady" in London is as revealing as it is important, for this was a triumph not only for a great musical but also for the American theatre. It proved again that when the United States sends its best abroad, anti-Americanism is forgotten.

Although furniture business in the Chicago area for the first quarter was below that a year earlier, the industry has not suffered as much as some in the recession. In general, there has been good demand for medium to higher price items, a situation that has surprised the trade, an American Furniture Mart spokesman said.

Contemporary painting, sculpture and graphic work in group exhibitions and one-man shows make up most of the attractions in another busy week in the New York galleries. Many well-known European and American artists will be represented in these events.
VIENTIANE, Laos, May 3 -- The weary candidates made their final speeches and tours today in the most intensive election campaign in the ten-year history of representative government in Laos.

BUENOS AIRES, May 3 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon said tonight that President Eisenhower had taken the "proper and only position" in avoiding endorsement of candidates for the Republican Presidential nomination.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 3 -- Dick Farrell, who saved a game for Curt Simmons earlier this week, did it again today. He took over in the ninth inning and halted a San Francisco Giant rally as the Philadelphia Phillies posted a 4-2 victory.

ACTING on the sound principle that the best presents are those we should most like to receive, Miss Streatfeild offers in these cheerful chapters a vivid account of what she loves in her own country. For instance, from her own feeling for the ballet comes a description of people dancing through the streets and in and out of the cottages in a Cornish village on Flurry Day to celebrate spring's arrival.

LOUISVILLE, May 3 (AP) -- "Fine, great," were about the only words Ben Jones could say about Tim Tam's victory in the Kentucky Derby today.

TORONTO -- Canada's first all-paved transcontinental highway is nearing completion. For vacationing motorists looking for new scenery on the east-west trek across North America, the Trans-Canada Highway offers an alternate route with plenty of good fishing and camera shots along the way.

The rich romantic sound of Joseph Eger's French horn playing echoed in memory as one left the concert of the Eger Players late yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Recital Hall.
The State's top judges embarked yesterday on a new effort to draft a politically acceptable plan for reorganization of the state Judicial system.

FREEHOLD, N. J., May 6 Gov. Robert B. Meyner will attend ceremonies opening the Deserted Village at Allaire State Park in Wall Township on May 21.

BOGOTA, Colombia, May 3 -- This city was calm but well guarded by armed troops today after an attempted coup by military police. The attempt was crushed by the armed forces yesterday.

MOST Americans are interested spectators of the political game -- its tricks, its maneuvers, the fascinating mixture of cynicism and high ideals and the ways in which the two combine to achieve constructive purposes. And the reaction of spectators and potential participants in this game is most important.
LONDON, May 3 (UP) -- Mike Davies of Wales and Shirley Bloomer of England won the singles finals today at the Hurlingham hard court tennis tournament with straight-set victories.

WARSAW, April 29 -- The current issue of Polityka, a magazine which sometimes reflects the thinking of Poland's top Communists, summed up this week this country's position and hopes about as well as is possible.

True, the elderly Queen was dead, but the gold twilight of Victorian peace spread its rays from island England through the English-reading world.

MORE than $30,000 worth of prizes in station wagons, home swimming pools, speed boats, TV sets and other equipment, is offered in U. S. Camera's worldwide 1958 contest for pictures in black and white and color classes, with equal prizes in each. Both amateurs and professionals are eligible.

Hepatica is all through blooming, and its cousin, the anemone, is at its fragile peak, the six dainty petals china-white or blush pink and the leaves like maidenhair fern.

Sharply curtailed payrolls, short work schedules and skip-weeks have become the pattern for most of the industry that has made itself bearer, backbone and badge of the American economy.

In all the live program ran for two hours with only a single interruption.
