WASHINGTON, May 4 (AP) -- Two Georgetown University freshmen were swept, into the rapids of the Potomac River from the Virginia side at Great Falls Park today.
WASHINGTON, May 4 (UP) -- Construction activity enjoyed a normal seasonal expansion in April and about equaled the year-ago pace, the Government reported today.

Cherry Hill, an apartment development in Delaware Township, N. J., has been sold by E. J. Frankel and Sylvester A. Lowery of Philadelphia, the builders. It consists of two twelve-story apartment buildings and twelve acres of land. J. I. Kislak, Inc., was the broker.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 4 -- Paul Douglas has been signed by the British Broadcasting Corporation to portray Captain Queeg in "The Caine Mutiny Court Martial."

BOSTON, May 4 (UP) -- Frank Malzone singled home Billy Consolo in the last of the twelfth inning today to give the Boston Red Sox a 2-1 victory over the Indians. Cleveland won the first game of the doubleheader by the same score.

There are now a million people over sixty years old in New York City, out of a voting population of two and a half million, Welfare Commissioner McCarthy pointed out in a recent address. "If the aged," he said, "ever united on their needs they would be the most potent force in the city, state or nation."
FAMAGUSTA, Cyprus, May 4 -- The Cyprus Government re-imposed tonight the mandatory death penalty for all terrorist offenses after two British soldiers had been shot to death here earlier today.

Cotton prices in the domestic market moved onto firmer ground last week, following a moderate decline in the week before. At the close of trading on Friday active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange were up 19 to 58 points from the close of the previous week.

New Yorkers, except for a few essential exempt groups, will be required to take shelter tomorrow from 10:30 to 10:36 A. M., during Operation Alert -- 1958. The state-wide alert is part of a national Civil Defense training exercise.
SEOUL, Korea, May 4 (Reuters) -- The Liberal party, led by 83-year-old President Syngman Rhee, has been returned to power in South Korea's fourth general election.

ONE dictum of decorators this year has a number of women in a dither. Paper your walls, advise the experts. Willing to oblige, the distaff decorator, yardstick in hand, goes out to buy something suitable.

Thomas K. Finletter, Secretary of the Air Force from 1950 to 1953, proposed yesterday the formation of a "single Department of Defense" under one Secretary. He would "legally and practically run the whole show," subject only to Congress and the President.
NICO CASTEL, tenor, made his debut at Town Hall yesterday afternoon as winner of the first recital award of "The Joy in Singing," Winifred Cecil's lecture-recital series.

PLAINFIELD, N. J., May 4 -- Development by the Port of New York Authority of railroad passenger facilities linking New Jersey and New York were advocated today by the Joint Committee of Municipal Groups of Northern New Jersey.
WASHINGTON, May 4 (UP) -- The Democratic Advisory Council today appointed twenty-three national labor leaders to advise the party's top leaders "on the problems and concerns of American workers."
BAGHDAD, Iraq, May 4 -- Iraq will go through the formalities tomorrow of naming a new Chamber of Deputies.

The world premiere of the motion picture "The Vikings" on June 11 at the Astor and Victoria Theatres will be a benefit for the Crown Princess Martha Friendship Fund. The fund is for Norwegian-American exchange fellowships.

In a letter to The Times printed April 29 Prof. Seymour E. Harris takes legitimate satisfaction in the claim, that the Rockefeller report is "virtually 100 per cent Keynesian except for a few platitudes about getting rid of rigidities and monopoly."
MOSCOW, May 4 -- The Soviet press hailed its "freedom" today, pledged itself anew to the cause of communism and attacked the Western press as "a tool of the capitalists."

TRENTON, May 4 -- Ch. Laguna Lucky Lad, a whippet from England owned by the Mardormere Kennels of Glen Head, L. I., came through occasional rain and constant mist to the best-in-show award of the Trenton Kennel Club event today.
In the distinguished list of Pulitzer awards, the ones for "meritorious public service" to The Arkansas Gazette and for editorial writing to its editor, Harry S. Ashmore, deserve special attention.
It was "by now" instead of "buy now" for four hundred tons of nylon stockings, lingerie and other textile items that missed the boat to Venezuela, textile exporters reported yesterday.

When Mrs. Vivian Beaumont Allen announced her gift of $3,000,000 for the construction of a repertory theatre as part of the Lincoln Square development she was breaking ground. This is the first gift from an individual toward the establishment of the Center for the Performing Arts.

TRENTON, May 5 -- The State Supreme Court today ordered Ridgewood to dismantle a 160-foot-high water tower. It was built by that community but it extends into one of the finest residential areas of HoHo-Kus.

Three of the 1958 Pulitzer prizes in journalism were awarded yesterday for coverage of last autumn's school integration crisis in Little Rock, Ark. Two of the three prizes were won by the same newspaper, The Arkansas Gazette, an unusual honor designed to record the high esteem felt by the awards committee for the excellence of this Little Rock paper's achievement.
COPENHAGEN, Denmark, May 5 -- Britain's rejection of the Polish proposal for a nuclear-free zone in Central Europe will he delivered in Warsaw by the end of this week.
MacRae Cook, pianist from Graham, N. C., and a pupil of Sascha Gorodnitzki here at the Juilliard School of Music, made his New York recital debut last night in Town Hall.

With two successes on Broadway ("Look Homeward, Angel" and "The Music Man") and two more on the road ("The Diary of Anne Frank" and "The Most Happy Fella"), Kermit Bloomgarden is about to acquire another prospect.
WASHINGTON, May 5 (UP) -- Paul M. Butler, Democratic National Chairman, predicted tonight that President Eisenhower would resign after the Congressional elections this year.

The Transcontinental Gas Pipe Line Corporation placed in registration with the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday proposed public offerings of $25,000,000 of first mortgage bonds and $15,000,000 of preferred stock. The transactions are to be underwritten by banking syndicates headed by White, Weld Co. and Stone Webster Securities Corporation.
The military pay and incentive bills passed by the Senate and House contain some extremely unfortunate provisions that may nullify the usefulness of this important legislation.

The physical cosmos is governed by natural law for its preservation and order. But man now has the power through the hydrogen bomb largely to destroy the world and the civilization of fifty centuries. We need a modus vivendi of ethical values, which may reach us from a spiritual sphere as cosmic rays do from the material in this new age.

MONTCLAIR, N. J., May 5 -- When the clock strikes midnight here on the twentieth day of next month it will signal the beginning of hostilities between major league scouts and college football coaches for the services of Richard and Robert Haines -- perhaps the finest scholastic athletes in the history of New Jersey.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 5 -- Columbia Pictures has augmented its roster of independent producers by signing a three-picture contract with Stanley Donen, director, to operate his own unit.
Mayor Wagner announced last night that all city agencies concerned with youth would increase their services to teenagers during July and August to counter temptations to crime.

Mayor Wagner is casting an increasingly long shadow over the Democratic Senatorial race these days. The shadow is a compound of doubt as to whether Mr. Wagner wants the nomination himself and of uncertainty as to whom he would favor as a candidate if he decides not to run.

HOBOKEN, May 5 -- Market studies by the United States Steel Corporation point to an improvement in its business in the months ahead, stockholders in the nation's largest steel producer were told today.
LONDON, May 5 -- With the London bus strike completely effective, the Labor party accused the Government today of seeking a showdown with the trade unions.

Commodity - stabilization agreements with Latin American countries have been mentioned in recent issues of The Times as a means of helping these countries over their present export difficulties. More than half of the countries of Latin America export coffee.
LONDON, May 5 (UP) -- Russia today selected seven weightlifters, including two Olympic champions, to go to the United States for a series of contests this month.
The Federation for Railway Progress, the trade association formed in 1947 by the late Robert R. Young in opposition to the Association of American Railroads, has decided to end its activities.
WEST HEMPSTEAD, L. I., May 5 -- A six-day Exposition of Modern Living and Food-oRama will begin here tomorrow in the Island Gardens Arena.
TRENTON, May 5 -- The Republican majority in the State Senate moved today to cut $22,199,542 from Gov. Robert B. Meyner's record $399,474,233 budget for the fiscal year beginning July 1.

COLLEGE graduates will soon be embarking on that all-important first real job hunt. They may approach the problem with scrubbed faces mid hopeful hearts, but this will get them nowhere if they show up in scuffed sneakers.

THE "Islands for Living" exhibition of home furnishings in the United States Pavilion at the Brussels World's Fair was scheduled to reopen last week. The exhibit was closed almost as soon as the fair opened last month.

IN a world that talks a good deal about the dignity of man George Washington will always personify dignity. Yet in a land that can create folk heroes almost overnight, he was seldom folksy. These characteristics create wonderfully challenging problems for his biographers. They are examined in a new book by Marcus Cunliffe that contains many acute insights -- "George Washington, Man and Monument."*
COPENHAGEN, Denmark, May 5 -- The Atlantic alliance foreign ministers agreed today not to let procedural difficulties bar a heads-of-government meeting if other conditions were satisfactory.
WASHINGTON, May 5 -- The underground explosion of a "baby" atomic bomb in Nevada last September knocked the pen of a specially designed seismograph in Michigan clear across its recording roll.
WASHINGTON, May 5 -- Individuals saved more last year than in any year since World War II, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.
PARIS, May 5 -- President Rene Coty tonight charged Rene Pleven for the third time with the task of attempting to form a coalition government

FARMINGDALE, L. I., May 5 -- The St. John's University golf team played as if the sun were shining today. The four-man squad won the Long Island Intercollegiate championship by eighteen strokes at the Bethpage State Park Black Course.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 5 -- The East Coast pine tree, long a symbol of the good life in the woods, was singled out here today as the most probable cause of a mysterious and frequently fatal disease called sarcoidosis.

The Rev. William Howard Melish, ousted supply priest of Holy Trinity Protestant Episcopal Church in Brooklyn, moved out of the rectory at 126 Pierrepont Street yesterday. However, he vowed that his feud with Bishop James P. DeWolfe had not ended.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, May 5 -The thirteen-day-old strike of Government workers ended today. It was called by the Public Service Workers Trade Union Federation to press for increased rent allowances and full political and trade union rights.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, May 5 -- The North Atlantic Council agreed today to attempt a revival of the waning interest of Europeans in the Atlantic alliance through the release of more hard information about the organization and its work.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., May 5 (AP) -- Bing Crosby's son Dennis married Pat Sheehan, showgirl, in a Protestant ceremony between her show performances last night.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- General of the Army Omar N. Bradley and Admiral Arthur W. Radford, former chairmen of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, strongly endorsed today President Eisenhower's proposals for Pentagon reorganization.

NEWARK, May 5 -- Ronald A. Booker, 30 years old, of 498 South Eighteenth Street, was acquitted today on a charge of possessing narcotics. Judge James R. Giuliano of Essex County ruled that detectives of the Sheriff's office had violated the defendant's rights under the Fourteenth Amendment by forcing him to regurgitate a packet of heroin he had swallowed while they were searching him.

The near-by May potato position rose the daily limit of 1/2 cent a pound yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange. There were several hundred unsatisified bids at the close. Forty-three notices were issued and most were stopped immediately.
City Administrator Charles F. Preusse yesterday recommended the construction of three correctional buildings to meet the demands of a rising prison population.
LONDON, May 5 -- Britain has agreed to strengthen her alliance with Libya by increasing military and financial aid to the North African Arab state.

A veteran of twenty years on the docks broke the waterfront "code" of silence yesterday to give testimony about how an ex-convict, barred by state law from the piers, still controlled three gangs of Brooklyn dock workers.

For years the General Motors Corporation reported higher profits than any other United States company. Yet it was no surprise when figures for 1957 showed that the American Telephone and Telegraph Company had seized the lead.
WASHINGTON, May 9 -- Bolivia is suffering the effects of Soviet economic aggression against tin-producing countries, Victor Andrade, Bolivian Ambassador to the United States, said today.

Champagne between acts, sartorial elegance and a break with an old theatrical custom to permit smoking in the mezzanine marked the opening last night of the Lunt-Fontanne Theatre on West Forty-sixth Street, a new and gleaming temple of the drama.
MOSCOW, Tuesday, May 6 -The Soviet Union handed the Western powers another note yesterday about preparations for a summit conference.

DETROIT, May 5 -- Harlow H. Curtice, president of the General Motors Corporation, appealed directly today to employes to study carefully G.M.'s proposal to extend its current contract with the auto union for two years.

HOBOKEN, May 5 -- The cry of an infant stockholder went largely unheard here today at the annual meet ing of the United States Steel Corporation. But no one in the meeting hall could ignore the woman whose voice was magnified by an electronic megaphone.
A new issue of $150,000,000 of bonds of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development -- the second this year -- was placed on the market yesterday and quickly oversubscribed.
Adlai E. Stevenson will attempt this summer to persuade the Soviet Government to pay royalties to American authors and dramatists whose works are published or performed in the Soviet Union.

GATLINBURG, Tenn., May 5 (AP) -- A team of University of California nuclear scientists today challenged a report by an international group of scientists that they had produced in a laboratory the heaviest element on record.

A recommendation that baseball parks built or remodeled after June 1 have minimum dimensions of 325 feet at the foul lines and 400 feet in center field was advanced by Ford Frick, the Commisioner of Baseball, yesterday.

The Commission on Inter-Group Relations has settled its first complaint filed under the new housing law that forbids discrimination in private housing because of race, religion or national origin. The complainant, who had charged religious discrimination, had his application accepted by a real estate management company.
LOS ANGELES, May 5 (UP) -- Granny Hamner batted in five runs tonight as the Philadelphia Phillies scored an 8-3 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, May 5 -- The Indonesian Army high command rejected a recent offer by a pro-rebel colonel to try to negotiate a settlement of the armed strife between the rebels and Jakarta, the army's chief spokesman disclosed here tonight.

The varsity eights of Yale and Harvard were singled out for distinction yesterday at the weekly luncheon of the rowing coaches and writers at Leone's restaurant. They will be participants in the two big races of the week, the Carnegie Cup regatta among Yale, Princeton and Cornell on Princeton's Carnegie Lake and the Adams Cup regatta on the Charles at Cambridge among Harvard, Navy and Pennsylvania.

WASHINGTON, May 5 (UP) -- Maj. Gen. Charles A. Willoughby said today the United States military position would now be "impregnable" if former President Harry S. Truman had not dropped the atomic bomb on Japan. He said Mr. Truman should have "kept the atomic bomb a secret."
WASHINGTON, May 5 -- The Supreme Court took the following actions today:
WASHINGTON, May 5 -- Chief Justice Earl Warren urged a group of New York State law- years today to have the courage to stand up for their view of the Constitution.
VIENTIANE, Laos, May 5 -Votes counted by late today in the elections for the Laotian National Assembly were too few to show any candidates as definite winners.
The number of homes heated with gas throughout the country increased by 1,194,000 in 1957, according to the American Gas Association.
STAMFORD, Conn., May 5 -A bleak picture of people living here amid filth and fear was given to this city tonight.
Huntington, L. I., has been selected to test a plan to integrate new residential and industrial areas in the suburbs.
BOGOTA, Colombia, May 5 -Incomplete official returns from Colombia's Presidential election showed today that Alberto Lleras Camargo had won about 83 per cent of the votes.

A code of ethics prohibiting misrepresentations in advertising and selling has been adopted by the Home Improvement Council. The group consists of contractors, building supply companies, banks and other businesses concerned with home building.

The Aircraft Carrier Franklin D. Roosevelt received the traditional fireboat welcome yesterday afternoon as she returned to the port where she was built for the first time since she was commissioned thirteen years ago.
Wanted: Sprightly Themes A Conference on the Teaching of English usually produces something newsworthy, and the annual Yale Conference on the T. of E. the other day turned out to be no exception.
A defense economist testified as an expert witness yesterday that the proposed Bethlehem-Youngstown merger should be judged "rationally" on the basis of economic facts in the steel industry.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 5 -Representative Patrick J. Hillings said today he would introduce legislation to prevent delays that have marked the deportation case of William Heikkila.
FOR suburban parents, spring brings not merely the voice of the turtle. It also brings the bite of the wood tick.

AUTOMOBILE manufacturers come out with new models every year, but most ice cream producers go them one better. They introduce a new flavor on the average of every two months. The names of the ice creams sometimes are as flamboyant as the car colors of recent vintage.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- It beats me, said Justice Harlan in more elegant language (when dissenting today in company with Justices Clark, Whittaker and Frankfurter), how a Supreme Court majority of five could have reversed a lower court finding in the case of Borg-Warner v. the National Labor Relations Board.

Increasing numbers of political, community and business leaders are showing deep concern for the future of our young people in the armed forces. The impact of military duty on the segment of youth in the services is serious. A young man suddenly removed from his normal home life and assigned to a military base half a world away needs assurance that his service is appreciated. Such a young man is a leader of tomorrow.

CAIRO, May 5 -- President Gamal Abdel Nasser was reported today to have told top Soviet officials he intended to keep the Suez Canal neutral and open to the shipping of all countries in the event of a world conflict.

Musical versions of Louisa May Alcott's "Little Women" and O. Henry's "The Gift of the Magi" will be televised next fall over the Columbia Broadcasting System network. Richard Adler is writing the music and lyrics for both one-hour productions.

LOS ANGELES, May 5 (UP) -- Senator Jacob K. Javits today proposed a "mid-term conference" of the Republican party, similar to its 1943 Mackinac Island meeting, to "establish a party program" for the elections this year and in 1960.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- Senator Clinton P. Anderson charged today that the chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission "seeks to become the apostle of modern McCarthyism" when he impugns the motives of those who favor suspension of nuclear tests.
The New York Central Railroad yesterday reiterated its reasons for discontinuing passenger service on the Putnam Division June 1 and raising fares on the Hudson and Harlem Divisions.
LENINGRAD, May 5 (AP) -- The United States men's basketball team tonight completed a six-game sweep in the Soviet Union by drubbing Riga, the Soviet national champion, 101 -- 58.

LONDON, May 5 -- With investors holding off, routine selling was sufficient to lower most share prices slightly in the stock market today. Much of the hesitancy was attributed to the London bus strike and the possibility of further labor unrest.

The New York Housing Authority will take bids May 20 on two issues of short-term notes totaling $24,794,000 for the financing of Jefferson Houses, in East Harlem, and Baruch Houses, on the lower East Side. Both projects are subsidized by the Public Housing Administration.

Steel production rose last week for the first time since early March. And the steel industry scheduled a further moderate increase for this week, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 5 -- The United States and the Soviet Union have agreed to open closed areas to an exchange of steel experts.
WASHINGTON, May 5 (AP) -- A Federal Maritime Board examiner ruled today that four shipping concerns were entitled to a 15 per cent rate increase on freight handled between the states and Alaska.
PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, May 5 -- Night raiders have wrecked the plants of two newspapers opposing the Government of President Francois Duvalier, and more Opposition leaders have been arrested.
Dr. Arthur S. Link, Professor of History at Northwestern University, has been appointed editor in chief of a comprehensive edition of the letters and papers of President Woodrow Wilson.

THE word "contemporary" has taken on a special meaning in the furniture lexicon. It is used to describe -- in a word -- furniture that is made today, but is not a nail for nail copy of an antique nor a version of the tailored, angular style called "modern."
WASHINGTON, May 5 -- Mrs. Oleta O'Connor Yates, a California Communist leader, won her freedom today from a jail term for contempt of court.

A RELIABLY unorthodox composer, John Cage, is exhibiting a group of unorthodox manuscripts at the Stable Gallery, 924 Seventh Avenue. Since Cage's notations have been invented by Cage, these compositions exist as items in a world of their own.
BAGHDAD, Iraq, May 5 -- Iraq elected today a new Parliament, one of whose first tasks will be to approve the federation with Jordan.
SEOUL, Korea, May 5 -- Several hundred residents of Taegu demonstrated today in protest against the delay in vote counting in their districts after Friday's general election.
The Consolidated Natural Gas Company reported yesterday increases in total operating revenues, net income and gas sales for the March quarter.

ONE of the nicest aspects of the Kentucky Derby to a guy in the sportswriting dodge is that the horse spectacle brings to one place other members of the clan from all over the country. It's a meeting of old and valued friends. Such reunions are usually gay and sparkling but a sad note kept intruding last week.
Directors of the General Motors Corporation, the world's biggest automobile maker, yesterday declared the usual quarterly dividend of 50 cents on the common stock, payable June 10.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- The Supreme Court held today, 5 to 4, that in collective bargaining an employer might not insist on a contract provision requiring a secret ballot among all employes before a strike was called.
Events in the Celebes Sea and the Macassar Strait have aroused a "disturbed" interest by the American Cargo War Risk Reinsurance Exchange, Edward R. King, secretary of the group reported yesterday.

DUESSELDORF, May 5 (AP) -- The crash of Abetz' car took place on the superhighway near Langenfeld. The police said the Volkswagen driven by Frau Abetz had collided head-on with another car. Abetz burned to death inside the car and his wife was hurled onto the road.
About 5,000 persons employed in the making of filmed commercials for television agreed yesterday to end their one-day strike and return to work this morning.

ALBERTO LLERAS CAMARGO, President-elect of Colombia, considers politics the art of peace. For millions of his countrymen, wearied of the political blood feud between Colombia's Conservative and Liberal parties, the winner of Sunday's election is a symbol of national reconciliation.
Princess Astrid of Norway arrived by plane yesterday in an unofficial stop-over. She remained only long enough for luncheon and last-minute shopping.

ROME, May 5 (AP) -- Shirley Bloomer, British women's tennis champion, today breezed past Louise Snow of Bakersfield, Calif., 6--2, 6--1, in the opening round of the Rome international tennis tournament.
BONN, Germany, May 5 -- Barge traffic from West Germany to West Berlin was suspended today as a new East German transit tax went into effect.
LA. PAZ, Bolivia, May 5 Vice President Richard M. Nixon declared today it was too early to go into the question of whether he would be a candidate for the United States Presidency in 1960.

WHITE PLAINS, May 5 -- Westchester rejected today a New Rochelle request to use park land for a high school athletic field, but authorized the construction of a county truck garage on a park lake on the White Plains-Harrison boundary.
PEIPING, May 5 (Reuters) -- The Chinese Communist party called today for "an irreconcilable struggle against modern revisionism" in the current feud between the Soviet Union and Yugoslavia.
RICHMOND, Va., May 5 --James Branch Cabell, the author, died at 6:50 this evening in his home here.
LONDON, May 5 -- Reginad Maudling, Britain's Paymaster General, cautioned today that Europe would get "out of step" if substantial agreement on a European free trade area was not reached by July.
WASHINGTON, May 5 -- Two influential Senators appealed today for prompt action to curb abuses charged to some labor union leaders.
I congratulate you on your editorial in your issue of April 12 on South African elections.
I should like to call attention once again to the inaction on the part of Congress in regard to a tunnel under the Potomac River.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -Every year around Mother's Day, when the spirit of pity and charity envelops the Capital, somebody here always suggests that the only hope for the Washington baseball team is for President Eisenhower to declare Griffith Stadium a "disaster area" and allocate some Federal funds for the relief of the long-suffering local fans.

Mayor Wagner sought yesterday to minimize the scandal in the Bureau of Real Estate. Departing from a prepared address at a luncheon meeting of the New York Building Congress in the Astor Hotel, he declared that newspaper stories had given the public "the impression of a major scandal" in the bureau.

BONN, Germany, May 5 -- A report from the Ministry of Economic Affairs indicated today that West German industrial production would continue to expand substantially in 1958 but at a slower rate than in 1957.

AFTER squandering their time on polite trivialities for a number of years, Alfred Lunt and Lynn Fontanne are appearing in a devastating drama, "The Visit," which opened, appropriately enough, at the Lunt-Fontanne Theatre last evening.

On Sunday the Soviet press went into its annual outburst of self-congratulation about an event which is known officially as Press Day. Of particular interest this time were the boasts about the "freedom" of the press, an alleged freedom Soviet which the Moscow writers contrasted invidiously with what they describe as the "kept press of the capitalist world."
SINGAPORE, May 5 (AP) -The Indonesian rebels, beaten back in Central Sumatra, said today their planes based in North Celebes would bomb key Indonesian cities in continuing the fight.
INDEPENDENCE, Mo., May 5 -- Harry S. Truman, retired farmer, destroyed a myth about himself today.
POLLOCK have at last opened the real game-fish season in Long Island waters. They have made their appearance in such a way as to give good hopes of a big pollock year after several poor ones.
The Arkansas Gazette, fighting against segregationist boycott efforts, reported yesterday that it was recovering from some early circulation losses -- and that its advertisers had stood by it.

The Fire Department found yesterday that some emergency exit doors at the Charles Evans Hughes High School, 351 West Eighteenth Street, were so tightly locked during school hours that it was impossible to open them quickly.
GENEVA, May 5 -- The General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade today protested of West German import restrictions and their "discriminatory application."
Oils, business machines and steel stocks advanced yesterday in a stock market that grouped uncertainly most of the day and moved forward only near the close.

The National Bureau of Economic Research undertook a survey of consumer buying intentions in early April, under the supervision of Dr. F. Thomas Juster, and it has now made public its findings. It can hardly be said that these lend much comfort to Washington in its wait-and-see policy.
Those who come to the fair in the Eddy barn in Southport, Conn., May 16 and 17 will have their choice of antiques, original paintings and many other items.

Joseph T. Sharkey, majority leader of the City Council, called "ridiculous" yesterday a charge by the widow of former Councilman Philip J. Schupler that her husband had been the victim of a political "frame-up."

WASHINGTON, May 5 -President Eisenhower praised delegates to the annual conference of the Association of Junior Leagues today for important volunteer work in health, welfare and education and in good government. He urged the Junior Leaguers to spread this work "throughout the vorld' as a. "magnificent service for yourself, this nation and humanity['

The legitimate theatre, it has been observed, has been declining ever since the first cavemen put on their first performance. Motion pictures have had less time in which to decline and their decline has been arrested, from time to time, by such startling developments as built-in sound, color, realism, and new techniques of projection.

WASHINGTON, May 5 (UP) -- The Senate Subcommittee on Constitutional Rights approved a bill today to prevent Government officials from using a 1789 Federal "housekeeping" law as "an instrument of censorship."
Acy Lellon, former Congressional secretary to Representative Adam Clayton Powell, lost two legal moves yesterday in Federal court.

An account of the exploits of the German airship Graf Zeppelin is told by J. Gordon Vaeth in "Graf Zeppelin: Adventures of an Aerial Globetrotter." It is also the story of the airship's commander, Hugo Eckener, "an outspoken anti-Nazi," who died in 1954 in obscurity.
WASHINGTON, May 5 -- The injection of racial hates and fears into labor-management relations is presenting the National Labor Relations Board with a growing problem.
HERE'S a delightful way to save steps around the house: indoor roller skates.
Record sales but lower earnings were reported yesterday by the May Department Stores Company for the fiscal year ended Jan. 31.
CINCINNATI, May 5 (AP) -John L. Lewis warned today that "the Russian Communists must not be permitted to impair or strike down our American economy, or imperil the liberties of its free system."

Prices of cotton futures underwent few important changes on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday. Closing prices were 10 points up to 1 point lower ) than on last Friday. One point equals 5 cents a bale.
A youth who said on television Friday night that teenagers were "misunderstood" by society was arrested yesterday in a stabbing on the lower East Side.

MONTREAL, May 5 -- Proficient cracksmen broke into a vault of the Brockville Trust and Savings Company, about halfway between here and Toronto, over the week-end and made off with paper of uncertain value.
BOSTON, May 5 (AP) -- Rock 'n' roll musical shows in public auditoriums were banned in Boston and New Haven today.

NEWARK, May 5 -- Earl T. Moore, president of the Jersey Central Railroad, said today that financial aid would help the railroads ride out the recession, but would do little more. He said the ailing industry needed far greater governmental assistance for the long haul.

Tony Anthony, the picturepunching light heavyweight who is looking for another shot at Archie Moore, halted Artie Miller of the Bronx at 1:41 of the sixth round in the main event listed for ten rounds at the St. Nicholas Arena last night.

MILWAUKEE, May 5 (AP) -- Tony Kubek of the New York Yankees,' who issued denials last month when a major said he was Army-bound, was sworn into the Army Reserve Corps for six months today by that same officer.
Last winter Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth X were more or less unconcerned about the up -keep of voluntary hospitals in New York City. They lived comfortably in an apartment on Sutton Place.

Three New York University alumni have been named for the 1958 John T. Madden Memorial Awards. The award honors former students of the university's School of Commerce, Accounts, and Finance for "outstanding achievements in business, industry, or professional life."
BOSTON May 5 (AP) -- The Boston Red Sox made it seven victories in eleven home games today, defeating the Cleveland Indians, 8 -- 5.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- The Pentagon was cautioned today that a strike of 125,000 aircraft and missile workers may be imminent. Contracts expire Wednesday night at Douglas, North American, Lockheed, and Convair plants.
The Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) announced yesterday plans for the acquisition of the minority interest in the International Petroleum Company, Ltd., through an exchange of shares.
" REPORT CARD 1958," seen last night over Channel 7, was a constructive explanation of an experiment in education in six American communities.

WASHINGTON, May 5 (AP) -- The Department of Commerce reported today that United States imports in February were valued at $961,500,000 -- 12 per cent below the January level and 3 per cent below imports for February, 1957.
BALTIMORE, May 5 (AP) -- A $1,272.80 daily-double pay-off overshadowed Sand Boy's victory in the $7,500 Baltimore Spring Purse today as Pimlico opened a twelve-day spring meeting.
Roy Campanella, the paralyzed Los Angeles Dodgers catcher, was moved yesterday to New York University-Bellevue Medical Center to begin treatment that will determine if he ever will walk again.

For the second time in forty-eight hours rain washed out the twenty-fifth annual Metropolitan Intercollegiate track and field championships, scheduled for Downing Stadium on Randalls Island yesterday. The meet, originally listed for last Saturday, was put off until next Monday at 4 P. M.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- Spokesmen for New York State appeared today before a House Appropriations subcommittee on behalf of ten public works projects involving an estimated total of $11,000,000 in Federal funds.
WASHINGTON, May 5 -- The Treasury's short term borrowing rate dropped a fraction today as bids for $1,700,504,000 in ninety-one-day Treasury bills were accepted.
Senator Styles Bridges declared yesterday that the United States was wrong in giving aid to Communist countries like Yugoslavia and Poland.

Tempers exploded at the annual meeting yesterday of Penn-Texas Corporation at the Biltmore Hotel. It may have been the most tumultuous corporate annual meeting ever held. There was constant shouting by stockholders from the floor.
CHICAGO, May 5 (AP) -- Except for a moderate volume of speculative dealings in nearby contracts, grain futures dawdled on the Board of Trade most of today. Changes were irregular.

WESTBURY, L. I., May 5 -Joe Lynch, manager of the mutuel department at Roosevelt Raceway, was reminiscing tonight after looking at the financial figures for the first twentynine days of racing here. The handle came to $48,009,745.

A Great Lakes steamship operator appears to have abandoned plans to operate United States flag cargo ships from that area and United States Atlantic ports to Cuba. He is Troy H. Browning, president of the T. H. Browning Steamship Company of Detroit.

Fast-breaking and front-running horses found the sloppy going at Jamaica to their -- and their backers' -- liking yesterday. For the most part those that broke first from the gate went all the way, as did Maurice Newton's Egotistical in the feature, the Fulton Purse.
KINGSTON, Ont., May 5 (AP) -- Organized labor here threw its support behind the Great Lakes Pilots Association today in its dispute with the Shipping Federation of Canada.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 5 -- Declaring itself on the question of video tape, the Screen Actors Guild today extended an olive branch in its clenched fist.
WASHINGTON, May 5 -- The nomination of Gordan MacLean Tiffany as staff director of the Civil Rights Commission got past Southern hurdles in the Senate Judiciary Committee today.

FORT BRAGG, N. C., May 5 -- The new chairman of the Army Scientific Advisory Panel is Richard S. Morse, president of the National Research Corporation of Cambridge, Mass. He succeeds Dr. Frederick L. Hovde, president of Purdue University, as chairman of the panel.
The New Jersey Bell Telephone Company executed yesterday one of the largest corporate refundings since money rates began to ease last fall.
WASHINGTON, May 5 (UP) -- A Senate Commerce subcommittee approved today a bill that would require all new automobiles to be plainly labelled with the manufacturer's suggested price.
The Little Gardens Club of New York City will take its members and friends on a benefit tour of nine Greenwich Village gardens and terraces on Thursday.
WASHINGTON, May 5 (UP) -The House passed a bill today paving the way for 31,000 Hungarian refugees to become permanent residents of the United States.
Following are brief sketches of winners of the Pulitzer prices:
Unusually colorful mosaics and enamels will go on view today at Living Handcraft, 126 Lexington Avenue. The showing will continue through May 24.

Net income of the Coca-Cola Company in the first quarter of this year totaled $4,699,923, or $1.11 a share, William E. Robinson, president, told the annual meeting yesterday in Wilmington, Del. This compared with a net of $5,256,479, or $1.24 a share, in the corresponding period last year.

sAN FRANCISCO, May 5 (UP) -- The Pittsburgh Pirates survived a nine-run rally by San Francisco in the ninth inning today to defeat the Giants, 11 -- 10, and gain a first-place tie with the Chicago Cubs.
SHOREHAM, England, May 5 (UP) -- Bill Wheal lined up five old armored cars on his lawn today and sent out an order for three surplus army tanks in his private war with the West Sussex County Council.
No trend to a sweeping surge in automobile sales was shown in the first week of the "You Auto Buy Now" campaign here.
Everyone in New York City, with few necessary exceptions, must take shelter at 10:30 A. M. today when 716 air raid warning sirens warble.
ALBANY, May 5 -- The Republican State Chairman predicted today that Governor Harriman would call a special session of the Legislature to act on a program to curb labor union racketeering.
LONDON, May 5 (Reuters) -- Following, in an unofficial translation, is the text of the Soviet note handed today to the United States Ambassador in Moscow on preparations for a summit meeting:

BUFFALO, May 5 -- The state's new law banning discrimination against older workers will be enforced mainly through "education and persuasion,'' the chairman of the State Commission Against Discrimination said today.
WASHINGTON, May 5 -- It was charged in the Senate today that Congressional political coisiderations were blocking the admittance of Alaska as the forty-ninth state of the union.

DETROIT, May 5 (AP) -- The nation's auto makers have built 1,586,987 cars so far this year, compared with 2,415,792 in the corresponding 1957 period. The decline reflects efforts to reduce heavy dealer inventories.
A three-story department store was opened by E. J. Korvette, Inc., yesterday on Forty-fourth Street near Lexington Avenue, a half-block from Grand Central Terminal.
WASHINGTON, May 5 -- The Administration told the House Agriculture Committee today that expansion of barter trading in surplus agricultural products would be a "serious mistake."
WHITE PLAINS, May 5 -A primary fight in the entrenched Republican organization of Westchester County became a virtual certainty tonight. The quarrel extends into neighboring Putnam County.
CHICAGO, May 5 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

Net income of the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company in the first quarter this year dropped 37.1 per cent to $10,857,506, or $1.02 a share, from $17,265,055, or $1.63 a share in the same period a year ago, the company announced yesterday.

Since all young men must register at 18, why not broaden the concept of Selective Service to include young men and young women, and lower the age to 15? Registrants should be required to carry at all times a pocket identification card with information covering name, address, parent or guardian, blood type and thumb print (useful also for Civil Defense purposes), recent photograph and police record, if any.
State Controller Arthur Levitt last night urged that Federal funds be allocated to the states to help deal with juvenile delinquency.
COPENHAGEN, Denmark, May 6 -- The cautious United States approach to an East-West heads-of-government meeting won strong support in the North Atlantic Council today.
An assistant district attorney, Peter D. Andreoli, warned yesterday that indictments would be sought in all policy cases in which there appeared to be a "mob operation."
The Port of New York last year handled 38,436,253 long tons of import-export cargoes with a value of $8,700,000,000, according to Eugene F. Moran, vice chairman of the Port of New York Authority.

MOSCOW, May 6 (AP) -- American and Soviet basketball players and officials tonight agreed that the Yank tour was a rousing success. As a result, the Russians agreed to repay the visit with a series of games in the United States starting Feb. 1.
The metropolitan area's newest television call letters will flash on screen today.
SEATTLE, May 6 (AP) -- Sales rose 40 per cent and net earnings 17 per cent in the first quarter of 1958, compared with the same period last year, the Boeing Airplane Company reported today.
INDIANAPOLIS, May 6 (AP) -Indiana renominated its eleven incumbent Congressmen, nine Republicans and two Demo crats, in a primary election today.
A defense expert testified yesterday that the proposed Bethlehem-Youngstown merger would not lessen competition or tend toward monopoly.
WASHINGTON, May 6 (UP) -- The Census Bureau issued a report today based on 1956 surveys showing in general that income and education moved together.
WASHINGTON, May 6 (UP) -- The House Judiciary Committee approved a bill today that would make it legal to publish pictures of money under certain conditions.

That old bond market bogey -- whether a new long-term Treasury issue is to be or not to be -- again haunts the Government securities market. Until the Treasury announces terms of its $9,553,000,000 refunding in June, the question of length probably will be a major influence on trading.
C. Douglas Dillon, Deputy Under Secretary of State for economic affairs, told representatives of sixty countries last night that "trade and more trade is vital to peace and progress."

A lazy low pressure system brought rain and chilly dampness yesterday for a fourth consecutive day to New York and most of the Eastern Seaboard. More rain was expected today, but the outlook for tomorrow was fair and slightly warmer.

Time and again men have essayed the writing of their own epitaphs. Often they have been witty. Sometimes they have been less than candid. Invariably they have been self-conscious. James Branch Cabell is an exception, as he always was. He wrote his own epitaph, perfectly, and quite unconsciously, in a completely different context.

Stockholders of the U. S. Hoffman Machinery Corporation were assured at the annual meeting yesterday that the financial position of the company had been greatly improved and that the management was trying to restore earning capacity, with a view toward resuming dividends. The Senate intends "sometime this session" to investigate on a broad scale the insurance industry, Donald McHugh, counsel for the Senate Antitrust and Monopoly Subcommittee, said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 6 (AP) -- President and Mrs. Eisenhower entertained Princess Astrid of Norway and Prince Bertil of Sweden today at a White House luncheon.
LONDON, May 6 -- Public pressure for summit talks has eased in Britain.
Millions of persons in the New York metropolitan region took ten minutes out yesterday to practice what to do in case of a nuclear attack.

There will be baseball in the Yankee Stadium when the Yankees are on the road this summer. The Negro American League has scheduled four regular league games there, with options for several more, including some night games.

MONTREAL, May 6 (UP) -- Doug Harvey, a 33-year-old player for the Montreal Canadiens, today won the James Norris Memorial Trophy for the fourth straight year as the outstanding defenseman in the National Hockey League.
PEARL RIVER, N. Y., May 6 -- The Pearl River School District defeated a proposed budget of $1,347,381 tonight by a vote of 121 to 99.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, May 6 -- NATO's problem is not whether but how to negotiate with the Russians. The difficulties posed are more easily discerned by the Western foreign ministers than by the general public. Yet without support from that public, no policy is valid.
WHITE PLAINS, May 6 -- The 10-cent tolls on Westchester parkways will be increased to 25 cents on May 15. The decision was announced today by the County Parkway Authority.
Sponsors have been announced for the symphony concert to be given the evening of May 20 for the benefit of former students of St. Christopher's School in Dobbs Ferry, N. Y., who are in college.

WASHINGTON, May 6 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board today agreed to guarantee 90 per cent of a proposed $1,000,000 loan by four New York City banks to New York Airways, a helicopter line operating in the New York metropolitan area.
The Transit Authority offered only half-hearted resistance yesterday to the proposed sale of its power houses to the Consolidated Edison Company.
WASHINGTON, May 6 -- Representative Clarence Cannon threw new power today into the Administration's drive to get its Pentagon reorganization bill through the House.
Tickets are still available for the Blue Chip Ball, which will be given Saturday to augment the camp fund of the Henry Street Friends Committee.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 6 -- Jack L. Warner, president and production chief of Warner Brothers, had his publicity department busy today spreading the word here and in New York that he had acquired rights in a pre-publication purchase to "Parrish," a new novel by Mildred Savage.
The shoe industry had a spring in its step yesterday as retailers and manufacturers got together for the trade's official volume show.
SHARON, Pa., May 6 -- A Republican organization leader challenged today the Pennsylvania residence qualifications of Harold E. Stassen to seek his party's nomination for Governor.
LONDON, May 6 -- Britain hopes to begin construction this summer of a hydrogen fusion reactor theoretically capable of producing more energy than will be used to run it.

A small greenhouse that for thirty-six years has been a haven for pre-school children on Morningside Heights will be closed for good at the end of the month. To the dismay of the children and their parents, too, later this summer workmen will pull the house down.

Domestic consumption of copper is at the lowest level since 1954, and there is little prospect for improvement in the second quarter, stockholders of the Kennecott Copper Corporation were told yesterday.

Everyone's -- well, nearly everyone's -- best bet, the Cain Hoy Stable's Nile Lily, won the fifth race at sloppy Jamaica yesterday. The 4-year-old filly, her record studded with triumphs on sloppy or off-tracks last season, was a popular winner.

EAST HAMPTON, L. I., Wednesday, May 7 -- Samuel Seabury, a former judge whose nvestigations led to the resignation of James J. Walker as Mayor of New York City, died at 1:30 this morning. He was 85 years old and had been an invalid at Hand's Nursing Home here for several years.

The Waterfront Commission was reported last night to be in possession of wiretaps of scores of conversations involving Anthony Pontecorvo, who was barred from the piers because of his criminal record but allegedly exercised control over some Brooklyn waterfront hiring.
WASHINGTON, May 6 -- The Administration's proposal to create a civilian space agency encountered an unexpectedly critical reception in the Senate today.
WASHINGTON, May 6 -- Marion B. Folsom is planning to resign his post as Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare.

PHILADELPHIA, May 6 (AP)-- The Pennsylvania Railroad won a legal battle in United States District Court today when Judge C. William Kraft Jr. refused to grant an injunction barring management from voting proxies at the annual meeting next Tuesday.
Nine pacifists were arrested yesterday morning for refusing to take shelter during the air-raid drill.

The latest weekly list of leading track and field performances issued by Don Pierce of Kansas on behalf of the National Collegiate Athletic Association freshly emphasizes the extent to which the nation's colleges have embraced "cosmic recruiting."
Final preparations yesterday for the 1958 United States World Trade Fair at the Coliseum combined the color and bustle of opening night at the "Met" and an arrival of the Queen Mary.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 6 -- Screen Gems is making its presence felt in the pre-season market place. The Columbia Pictures TV film-making subsidiary has sold three half-hour series to the American Broadcasting Company.
A program to stamp out "flagrant advertising abuses" was outlined yesterday by Hugh R. Jackson, president of the Better Business Bureau of New York City, at its annual meeting.
CHICAGO, May 6 (AP) -- A group of Chicagoans opposed to nuclear weapons testing went on record today as "sharing the guilt" with the jailed pacifist crew of the ketch Golden Rule.
WASHINGTON, May 6 (UP) -- Senate investigators were told today that business men in the Philadelphia area had been "shaken down" by advertising salesmen for a union-sponsored yearbook.

Irving Auerbach sold the four-story apartment house for seventeen families at 316 East 211th Street, the Bronx, to an investing client of George Noodleman, attorney. The deal was for cash over mortgages amounting to $48,309. Joseph Panman Associates, Inc., were the brokers.

VIENTIANE, Laos, May 6 -- Prince Souphanouvong said today that he favored continued participation of his Communist-oriented party in a coalition Government irrespective of the outcome of last Sunday's special elections for the National Assembly.
WASHINGTON, May 6 -- Dr. Sydney Chapman of England, one of the world's leading geophysicists, said today that the earth's atmosphere might extend out to a distance as great as 200,000 miles.
NEW HAVEN, May 6 (UP) -- An attorney asked for an injunction today to prevent the cancellation of the "Big Beat" rock 'n' roll show that preceded a riot in Boston.

CANNES, France, May 6 (Reuters) -- The Soviet Union has proposed "a very big" program of film cooperation with the United States, the Soviet delegation to the Cannes International Film Festival announced today.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 6 -- Harvard College will place additional emphasis on individual instruction beginning next fall.
MOSCOW, May 6 -- The Soviet Union decided today to perpetuate its international Tchaikovsky violin and piano competition. The contest will next be held here in 1962 and every four years thereafter.
The giant panda has been trapped in the "cold war" of diplomacy and has been denied admission to the United States.

The fact that India's ambitious Second Five-Year Plan will have to be trimmed back at a number of points does not mean that the objectives were not worthy. It means, rather, that the Indian planners in their eagerness to get the most good done for their country in the shortest possible time set goals that were too high.
WASHINGTON, May 6 -- Ezra Taft Benson said today that the price of beef was near the point of causing real consumer resistance.
LEWISBORO, N. Y., May 7 -- In an upset here early today the apparent winner of a three-way contest for the school board lost when a second ballot was required.

OROVILLE, Calif., May 6 (AP) -- A bank robber fainted from hunger today before the teller could count out the money.

Religion and the theatre clasped hands yesterday to honor one of New York's best-loved clergymen.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 6 (UP) -- Mike McCormick, a $65,000 bonus pitcher, hurled a three-hitter tonight while pitching the San Francisco Giants to a 7-0 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- Dr. Hans Bethe, a special adviser to the President on scientific matters, believes the United States would gain "considerably" from an agreement with the Soviet Union to end tests of nuclear weapons.

CALGARY, May 6 (Canadian Press) -- An Imperial Oil Ltd. official said today that if the company had thought a crude oil pipeline from Edmonton to Montreal was possible and economic, "we would have been chasing it before this."

FOURTEEN aspiring Duncan Phyfes have chiseled at least a temporary place for themselves at the Brooklyn Museum. But only time will tell whether their work will ever become a permanent part of the museum's collections.

BOGOTA, Colombia, May 6 -- The Colon Theatre in this capital was filled to capacity last night for the first of the two concerts to be given here by the New York Philharmonic under the direction of Leonard Bernstein.

After an ownership of one year, Klausner Associates, realty operators, sold the eight-story apartment building at 145 East Thirty-fifth Street, between Lexington and Third Avenues, in the Murray Hill district. The buyer, Jillco Associates, acquired the property in a deal negotiated by Jack Stein, broker. The property is 77 by 100 feet. It was sold for cash over mortgages amounting to $410,000. Title was insured by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.
Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy will not have to testify in Supreme Court on whether the Police Department maintains a quota system for traffic summonses.

Glints of good news sparkled in the somber business picture yesterday. These, with the expectation that whatever measures the Government takes will produce more inflation, sent stock prices up on the New York Stock Exchange.
LOS ANGELES, May 6 (AP) -- The Los Angeles Dodgers scored a run with two out in the ninth that sent their game with Philadelphia into extra innings as a 6-6 tie tonight.
LONDON, May 6 -- Sir Hugh Foot, Governor of Cyprus, arrived today for discussions on the political future of the crown colony.

The appointment of Magistrate Hilda G. Schwartz as City Treasurer was announced yesterday by Mayor Wagner. When Mrs. Schwartz is sworn in, at a date to be set, she will become the first woman to hold the office.

Officials of the Radio Corporation of America yesterday discussed with stockholders such disparate matters as the first-quarter profit declines, electronic innovations and provisions for the space age.

THE Moliere fun at the Phoenix Theatre shifted from high comedy to rowdy farce last night. Having put on "The Imaginary Invalid" last week, Le Theatre du Nouveau Monde played three short Moliere comedies in which few of the ingredients of slapstick, ancient or modern, were missing.

The creation of a professional sports-car racing division of the United States Auto Club was announced here yesterday by Thomas Binford, president. In the initial set-up the U. S. A. C. will have four road courses on which to operate such contests -- Danville, Va.; Marlboro, Md.; Riverside, Calif., and Lime Rock, Conn.
KAVALLA, Greece, May 5 -- The National Radical Union, the Rightist political party headed by former Premier Constantine Karamanlis, is expected to win next Sunday's elections easily.
The civil war in Indonesia is becoming a war of attrition, with air power a decisive element.
State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz suggested yesterday to Mayor Wagner that he consider a tighter code of ethics for the city and its application to the Housing Authority.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 6 (AP) -- Pakistan told the Security Council today that Sheik Mohammed Abdullah, former Premier of Kashmir, should be released from jail immediately.
HONG KONG, May 6 -- Communist China accused the United Nations Command in Korea today of attempting to prolong the occupation of South Korea to create further tension.

Some strange things happened yesterday in the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's interclub matches. This was the third in the series and for the second time many matches were not completed because of rain and wet courses.

Connecticut borrowed $29,732,000 in the public bond market yesterday to finance the construction of vocational schools and other capital improvements.
TODAY, one out of every twelve Americans is more than 65 years old. With the life expectancy growing, it is estimated that, that within twenty year our elderly population will total about 21,000,000.

The role of the Community Service Society in recession problems was described yesterday by J. Richardson Dilworth, president, at the spring meeting of the society at the Commodore Hotel.
CHICAGO, May 6 (AP) -- Light scattered buying raised corn futures prices slightly shortly before the close of trading on the Board of Trade today. All other grains were mostly lower.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- President Eisenhower promised his personal support tonight to those Republican candidates in the Congressional elections in November who backed his legislative program to keep the free world free and America's own defenses strong.

For many weeks a yawning excavation has made Columbus Circle a bottleneck and a hazard for northbound traffic at the evening rush hour. The excavation is a necessary part of a project for lengthening the subway platforms on Broadway, and we have nothing but praise for this objective.

The Bank of Sweden has cut its discount rate from 5 to 4 1/2 per cent and Swedish commercial banks have followed suit by lowering interest rates the same amount, according to the American-Swedish News Exchange, Inc. Per Asbrink, governor of the bank, said the measure was a conservative and natural adjustment to a deteriorating economic situation.
CHICAGO, May 6 -- James L. Palmer, president of Marshall Field Co. since 1949, today was named chief executive officer of the merchandising concern.
WASHINGTON, May 6 -- The racial segregation question was raised today in House hearings on extension of the Hill-Burton Hospital Construction Act.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt declared today that America must explore persistently methods of understanding others and living with them as a way to world leadership. A cocktail party and meeting will be held by the Junior Auxiliary of Planned Parenthood of Manhattan and the Bronx tomorrow at the Carnegie Endowment Center.
PARIS, May 6 -- Rene Pleven stopped saying no tonight and agreed to try to form a new French Government. His chances appeared good.
WASHINGTON, May 6 -- Republican Senators squabbled among themselves today over the scope of a labor bill they are trying to draft.

The Brazilian soprano Maria de Lourdes Cruz Lopes made her debut in recital at Town Hall last night. Miss Lopes' first studies were in her native country, after which she received a National Scholarship for study in Europe. She has given concerts in Latin America and in several European countries.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, May 6 (Reuters) -- "We have enough freedom," thirty-one prominent citizens of French-ruled Tahiti declared today in the wake of one of the world's first anti-anti-colonial riots.
Washington, May 6 (AP) -- The Department of Commerce today announced a further easing of restrictions on exports of nickel and nickel scrap.
Annual school district elections took place last night in Westchester, Rockland, Nassau and Suffolk Counties. They will continue tonight.

THE serigraph, or silkscreen print, has a short but varied history. Originally this stencil technique was intended for commercial purposes where simple reproduction was required. But about twenty years ago the serigraph began to attract fine artists, who transformed this basically rude medium into one of considerable range and subtlety.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, May 6 -- Officials of the Federal, state and local governments of West Germany were given a lesson today in the use and purpose of the voting machine.

Two new loans of European and African foreign governmental bodies totaling about $23,000,000 are to be offered for public subscription in the United States market in the near future. LONDON, May 6 -- The strike of London and suburban busmen was fully effective again today. But the city and suburbs are beginning to take the strike in stride.

A SIMPLE but appropriately festive wedding breakfast for thirty people can be prepared at home at a total cost of about $84, or $2.80 a person. The trick is to take advantage of plentiful foods and to buy groceries in the large-size packages.
Martha Bleiberg Veroba, who sang a recital last night in Carnegie Recital Hall, took a little time to settle down. When she finally did, she offered some sensitive and appealing singing.

Directors of the Pittsburgh and West Virginia Railway deferred action yesterday on the regular quarterly dividend. The company explained that the deferment was "in order to preserve working capital and in view of the general business outlook."
A United Airlines pilot of multiple interests has sold his company on a thoroughly noncommercial idea.
RABAT, Morocco, May 4 -- Anti-American feeling is growing among the Algerian rebels, according to four leaders of the insurgent National Liberation Front.

"Lady, next time, you'll walk." I had opened and closed the door both times, pushed my luggage in, yanked it out and made two trips between the parked cars to the curb with it in the rain. By any system of logic, I was entitled to the tip.
The annual Alfred P. Sloan radio-television awards for highway safety were given to twelve business and communications companies last night at a dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

TWO weeks ago in this space I remarked that this spring's output of new books was notable for striking and ambitious first novels and cited three (names on request). Today it is my pleasant duty to applaud a fourth, "A Terrible Beauty"* by Arthur J. Roth. Less grandiose in conception and far simpler and more disciplined in structure than its competitors, "A Terrible Beauty" is a work of sure skill and of sustained emotional tension.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., May 6 -- The Legislature began considering today the impeachment of Judge Raulston Schoolfield of Hamilton County Criminal Court.
The dramatization of James Gould Cozzens' popular novel "By Love Possessed" has been canceled.

WASHINGTON, May 6 (UP) -- Five Soviet housing experts were hurried out of the National Housing Center here today after an anonymous telephone caller warned that a bomb had been planted in the building.
The $200,000,000 redevelopment of Brooklyn's Civic Center area has reached the halfway mark, give or take a few million dollars and a few years.
PORT - AU - PRINCE, Haiti, May 6 -- An ultimatum was issued to the Opposition today by Mayor Windsor K. Laferriere, president of the Haitian People's party, supporting President Francois Duvalier.
One of the nation's largest food processors and distributors, Standard Brands, Inc., thinks, things may well look up in this year.

To all those people now spreading grass seed as blindly and blissfully as money, it is only fair to bring to light certain hitherto unpublished facts concerning lawns. These unrecognized facts of lawn-making are (1) neighbors always have beautiful lawns and (2) what's the matter with weeds, anyway?
Baseball almost has become a lost art in New York.
WASHINGTON, May 6 -- The United States and Australia have agreed to operate Wilkes Station in the Antarctic jointly after the end of the International Geophysical Year on Dec. 31.

Wool prices climbed yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange in sympathy with strength in London and slightly higher prices at the Australian auctions. Tops rose 2.7 to 3.4 cents a pound here and grease wool advanced 2.1 to 2.7 cents.
ATLANTIC CITY, May 6 -- The discovery in spinal and brain fluids of a compound that is apparently linked with degeneration of the nervous system and with schizophrenia was reported here today.
Events tonight: "Lost in the Stars," City Center, 8:15; Third Street Music School Settlement spring concert, Town Hall, 8:30; program of chamber music, Mannes College of Music, 8:30.

The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation increased first-quarter earnings to $5,076,000, from $3,415,000 cleared in the first three months last year. Sales were the second highest for a quarter. They totaled $238,670,000, a gain of 22 per cent above the $195,479,000 volume for the March quarter a year ago.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- The United States Ambassador to Moscow, Llewellyn E. Thompson Jr., is known in the trade as a cool customer on a hot seat. This quality of coolness under fire was one of the considerations that led to Mr. Thompson's designation as General Eisenhower's chief scout on the treacherous road to the summit.

BALTIMORE, May 6 (UP) -- Silky Sullivan, the golden colt that failed to uncork his anticipated stretch run in the Kentucky Derby last Saturday but still rates highly with sentimentalists, was bedded down at Pimlico tonight after his arrival for the $100,000 added Preakness Stakes on May 17.
WASHINGTON, May 6 (AP) -- Two scientists were headed into the lower stratosphere tonight in a balloon launched from an open iron mine near Crosby, Minn., the Navy announced.
LONDON, May 6 -- The stock market was again depressed today and in some sections there were fairly sharp falls.
CHICAGO, May 6 (AP) -- A three-run homer by Bobby Thomson and a four-hit pitching job by Glenn Hobbie provided the Chicago Cubs with a 4-0 decision over the Cincinnati Redlegs today.
WASHINGTON, May 6 (AP) -- President Eisenhower walked to an underground command post today in a practice drill touched off by a mock hydrogen bomb attack on the United States.
Dr. Charles W. Mayo said last night that a progressive domestic and overseas medical program would pay dividends in the form of international good-will and peace.
A RECORD factory in the basement of the New York Public Library branch at 127 East Fifty-eighth Street turns out seven-inch disks that cannot be bought for love or money.
Leonard W. Hall was reported yesterday to be almost ready to announce his candidacy for the Republican nomination for Governor.

Mayor Wagner subjected himself yesterday to a question session on school problems. Representatives of twenty-nine civic organizations, under the auspices of the Public Education Association, quizzed the Mayor for an hour at Freedom House, 20 West Fortieth Street.

MILAN, May 6 -- Italian high fashion designers incorporated themselves last night into the Camera Sindicale Alta Moda Italiana, with G. B. Giorgini, Florence promoter, as president. Headquarters will be established in Rome.

The Department of Health is supplying the Transit Authority with 2,000 posters to be placed in subway cars to urge residents to get polio shots. The department will put 5,000 more of the posters in district health centers and other public places, a spokesman said yesterday.
Three 15-year-old boys were arraigned in Queens Children's Court yesterday as operators of a nickel, dime and quarter shakedown racket.
WASHINGTON, May 6 (AP) -- The Navy announced today a new "Selected Reserve" program to train civilian sailors for immediate action in fully ready ships and aircraft in event of war.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, May 6 -- The first shipment of MIG jet trainer aircraft recently ordered from the Soviet Union has arrived in Indonesia, Premier Djuanda disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, May 6 (AP) -- The Bureau of the Census reported today that 10,880,378 running bales of cotton were ginned from the 1957 crop. This compared with 13,151,208 bales ginned from the 1956 crop.

The sports racing car, Scarab, built by the 22-year-old Lance Reventlow and his associates of Reventlow Automobiles, Inc., Los Angeles, made its first appearance in the East on Sunday at the Virginia International Raceway near Danville, It created a mild sensation.
HUNTINGTON, W. Va., May 7 (AP) -- The Island Creek Coal Company said today it had produced its first carload shipment of stoker coke by a continuous process involving steam generation.
The nation's production of crude oil and condensate in the week ended last Friday dropped 61,350 barrels to 6,227,035 a day, according to the American Petroleum Institute.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- The United States and the European Atomic Energy Community have agreed in principle on a broad-scale cooperative program to promote the development of atomic power in Western Europe.

The Casals Festival comes to a triumphant close in San Juan, Puerto Rico, tonight. To be able to say this will bring much pleasure to the world of music, where the grand old master, Pablo Casals, is so deeply honored, and to all friends of Puerto Rico.
WASHINGTON, May 7 -- The White House said today that President Eisenhower was personally soliciting support for his Pentagon reorganization bill among his friends in the business world.
WASHINGTON, May 7 -- The American Association of University Women announced today awards of $106,500 in fellowships to forty American women and three from abroad.
Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz urged bar associations last night to take the lead in bringing about court reform in New York State.
The formation of a council of business, labor and professional leaders to give advice on fluctuations in the nation's economy was suggested yesterday by Senator Jacob K. Javits.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 7 (UP) -- The San Francisco Giants withstood a Pittsburgh home run barrage and a beanball exhibition today to whip the Pirates, 8 -- 6, and win the series, 3 -- 2.

WASHINGTON, May 7 (AP) -- Senator Charles E. Potter, Republican of Michigan, accused the Administration today of freezing out Great Lakes ship operators from Federal subsidies and confining the program "strictly to salt water interests."
Trans Continental Industries, Inc., a holding and operating company, has formulated a plan under which it would distribute some of its securities assets to its stockholders as dividends.
Wearied puddle jumpers and disgruntled sports fans were declaring belligerently yesterday that hardly ever before had there been so much rain here. They were right.

Special classes for the city's youngest delinquents -- those under 9 years old -- would be established under a plan to be presented to the Board of Education Tuesday.
CHICAGO, May 14 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
BRUSSELS, Belgium, May 7 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner called today for freer world trade and a United States of Europe.
ALBANY, May 7 -- The Public Service Commision tday ordered the New York Central Railroad to continue running its Empire State Express and DeWitt Clinton trains on ther present schedules.

JERUSALEM, May 7 -- Another dispute developed today over Israel's twice-monthly convoy to Mount Scopus, the Israeli, enclave within the Jordanian sector of Jerusalem. The convoy was held up at the Mandelbaum Gate, the point at which it normally enters Jordan.
Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa made public yesterday a two-year-old report charging the city's Bureau of Real Estate with serious administrative failures.
The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company last night gave a dinner honoring a man who joined the concern seventy-five years ago as an office boy and is now honorary chairman of the board.
OTTAWA, May 7 (UP) -- Canadian exports through the first quarter of 1958 were $1,071,000,000, a 2.4 per cent decline from last year, the Bureau of Statistics reported today.
ST. LOUIS, May 7 (AP) -- A professor from India said tonight that the power exercised by white races over the colored during the last 400 years had left "a terrible legacy of racial tensions."

CINCINNATI, May 7 -- The May Festival Chorus and the Cincinnati Symphony Orchestra presented the opening program of the forty-second biennial May Festival tonight, Josef Krips, conductor of the Buffalo Philharmonic, was on the podium in the Music Hall.

LONDON, May 7 -- The Earl of Gosford, Under Secretary at the Foreign Office, gave assurance today that the British Government would not allow the industrial deconcentration agreement with West Germany to be "made a dead letter."

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- The United States Court of Appeals decided today to withhold a decision on the contempt of Congress convictions of Arthur Miller, playwright and eight other persons until the Supreme Court rules on a similar case.
LONDON, May 7 (UP) -- The British Broadcasting Corporation told listeners to its weekly television sports program tonight that "in America, money can buy anything," including the Brooklyn Dodgers.

RABAT, Morocco, May 7 -- A permanent agreement on the status of United States military bases in Morocco appears to have been put off indefinitely by the recent North African conference at Tangier, observers here believe.

LIKE most plays dealing with the conflicting interests of Ireland and England, "A Man in Hiding," the drama on last night's "United States Steel Hour" on Channel 2, was a story of bloodshed and sorrow.

MARIANNE CHARLIER loves Paris in the springtime. Not only because the chestnuts and lilacs are in bloom and outdoor cafes are charming, but because the fashion collection of Mme. Carven was as lovely as she hoped it would be when she flew over to see it last week-end.
GENEVA, May 7 (Reuters) -- The Government of Liberia said here today it had no intention of changing the regulations under which ships could register under the Liberian flag.
WASHINGTON, May 7 -- The chief of the Defense Department's space research program criticized today President Eisenhower's proposal to create a civilian space agency.
WASHINGTON, May 7 -- Broad legislation to let state and Federal agents tap wires in criminal investigations was introduced today by Representative Kenneth B. Keating.
I will always admire Roy Campanella as a great athlete, a fine man and a credit to baseball. Even though I am a Yankee fan, I know of no other man, in recent years, who has meant so much to baseball.
