Everybody talks about juvenile delinquency -- and that is precisely the trouble, a British magistrate complained yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 7 -- The United States began its scheduled series of nuclear tests at the Eniwetok proving grounds in the Pacific nine days ago.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- Arthur S. Flemming, president of Ohio Wesleyan University, was nominated by the President today to be Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare. He will succeed Marion B. Folsom who is resigning for reasons of health.

The preservation of Israel as an "oasis of freedom and democracy" in the Middle East is of concern to Christianity, Dean James A. Pike of the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine declared yesterday.

THESE menus, which appear each Thursday, use seasonally abundant foods and are moderate in cost. They are designed to strike a balance between appetite appeal and the convenience of the family cook. Dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe. Add bread and beverage as desired, unless specified.
NEW YORK'S hunting accident round-up for 1957 has just been published and it affords some hope that the Eastern hunter may not, after all, abolish himself in the end.
HOUSTON, May 7 (AP) -- Joe Brown floored Ralph Dupas three times in the eighth round tonight and scored a technical knockout to retain the world lightweight boxing championship.

The General Motors Acceptance Corporation and its wholly owned subsidiary, the Motors Insurance Corporation, increased its first-quarter net income to $15,123,272 from $12,568,761 in the corresponding 1957 period.

District Attorney Edward S. Silver made public yesterday tape-recorded conversations to show that former Councilman Philip Schupler had not been "framed" on a grand-larceny indictment pending against him.
LONDON, May 7 -- Labor disputes continued to depress many sections of the stock market today. However, Wall Street's recovery steadied industrial shares, but dollar stocks made the best showing.

At the annual meeting yesterday in Milwaukee, shareholders of Allis-Chalmers Manufacturing Company were told that the company's sales of heavy electrical apparatus and farm machinery were ruuning ahead of last year's. Robert S. Stevenson, president, added, however, that "almost everything else is off somewhat." He said:

A six-story building containing fifty-six apartments and occupying a plot 100 by 100 feet at 41-46 Fiftieth Street, Sunnyside, Queens, has been purchased by the Plony Realty Corporation, represented by Irving F. Cohen, attorney.

Douglas W. Hartman, American member of the Validation Board for German Dollar Bonds, said yesterday that a meeting would be held on Monday in Dusseldorf, Germany, of representatives of forty-four German corporations and ten cities.
WARSAW, May 7 -- The new Communist campaign against Yugoslavia has aroused serious fears here for the future of the Polish experiment in liberal communism.

MINNEAPOLIS, May 7 (AP) -- A balloonist and an astronomer returned today from a balloon flight that took them up 40,000 feet. They said they had found that the stars do not twinkle when observed from that height.

A textile research consultant presented a plan yesterday for the regulation of textile imports under which only United States textile manufacturers would be able to import fabrics, and they would have to agree not to sell them under domestic market prices.

LONDON, May 7 -- Queen Elizabeth II and Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh, headed a vast congregation at St. Paul's Cathedral today for a service marking the reopening of the east end of the cathedral.
WASHINGTON, May 7 -- A blow was struck today against the theory that the continents drift toward and away from each other, like great barges floating on the molten interior of the earth.

HAMILTON, N. Y., May 7 (UP) -- Dr. Everett Case, president of Colgate University, has been granted a leave of absence for the first semester of 195859, it was announced here today. WASHINGTON, May 7 -- In the United States Court of Claims. the following proceedings were had today:
OTTAWA, May 7 -- The Canadian Government loosened its tight control over the uranium industry today.

Kraft Foods, which purchased a Milton Berle show last week, is expected to sponsor "Bat Masterson" as the second half of its double-header replacement for "Kraft Theatre." The latter program, a-one-hour live drama series, will be discontinued in September after a run of eleven years.

ROME, May 7 (UP) -- Foreign tennis players eliminated Gregory Grant of Los Angeles and Wayne Van Voorhees of Palm Beach, Fla., today in the second round of men's singles in the Rome international championships.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- A Senate Labor subcommittee wrestled today with the problem of the "no-man's-land" of labor relations -- the area in which the National Lobor Relations Board refuses to act and into which the states are forbidden to enter.
A 13-year-old boy who had tried to run down a detective was shot last night as he was running away from a stolen car after an automobile chase.
Six of the seven Tammany district leaders in Harlem were reported last night to be in favor of dropping Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr. from the Democratic ticket this year.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange advanced 5 to 27 points yesterday. The new October option was the strongest.
A protest was made yesterday by the Automobile Club of New York against the increase of 10-cent tolls on two Westchester County parkways to 25 cents.
A new media measurement, which is said to show for the first time how often readers of a magazine are exposed to pages containing advertising, was presented yesterday by the Saturday Evening Pont.
PORT - AU - PRINCE, Haiti, May 7 -- President Francois Duvalier dismissed Windsor K. Laferriere today as Mayor of Port-au-Prince.

MONTREAL, May 7 (Canadian Press) -- The Bowater Corporation of North America Ltd. and subsidiary companies today reported consolidated profits after taxation of $10,802,000 for the year ended Dec. 31, 1957, compared with $10,273,000 a year earlier.
Annual school district elections were completed last night and early today in Westchester, Rockland, Nassau and Suffolk Counties.
Representative Gordon H. Scherer said last night that patriotic societies were "fast waning" in contrast to those who scoffed at patriotism.

WASHINGTON, May 7 (UP) -- A New York labor paper publisher died today just before he was to testify in a Senate investigation of alleged "shakedowns" by some advertising salesmen for such publications.

BECAUSE I live in California," Fred Haney had said, I had to attend testimonial dinners each winter to fellows like Casey Stengel, Leo Durocher and Charley Dressen while long-winded speakers told how wonderful they were for winning pennants or world championships or both. Last winter I got even. Those three buzzards were forced to attend testimonial dinners for me."
The refusal of the nation's two most powerful maritime unions to agree to the hiring of a Liberty ship's crew by lottery has forced the vessel into lay-up.
The Board of Higher Education, the presidents of the municipal colleges and the faculty and staff of Queens College joined last night in a testimonial dinner for Dr. John J. Theobald.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- Howard Beale, new Australian Ambassador to the United States, declared in a speech this evening that the dangers of the "cold war" were no less menacing than those of World War II.

It is good to realize that even at time of economic recession work goes on in the construction of public libraries. Completion of the new $525,000 Broadway Regional Branch Library in Astoria, Queens, will serve one of that borough's older communities, where the Queens Borough Public Library began providing library service in 1906.
BALTIMORE, May 7 (AP) -- The reserved Preakness barn at Pimlico race track welcomed three new customers today.
WASHINGTON, May 7 -- House investigators heard more criticism today of the 1956 consent decree that ended the Government's Antitrust suit against the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.
Plans were announced yesterday for the construction of a fifty-story skyscraper at the rear of Grand Central Terminal.
WASHINGTON, May 7 -- The Administration was accused today of weakening Federal regulatory agencies by the appointment of Eisenhower Democrats to minority seats.
A new move in court to delay the beginning of relocating Lincoln Square tenants was made yesterday by opponents of the $205,000,000 redevelopment project.
LONDON, May 7 (Reuters) -- A British inventor has produced a portable "harbor" without complicated equipment and sea walls, The Daily Mail reported today.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., May 7 (AP) -- The Air Force launched a Northrop Snark guided missile tonight on what possibly was another 5,000-mile test over the South Atlantic range.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, May 7 -- A top Indonesian military officer charged today that weapons and ammunition were supplied to the Indonesian rebels recently with the knowledge and direction of the United States Government.
INDIANAPOLIS, May 7 (AP) -- Sam Hanks, a retired race driver who won last year's 500-mile Memorial Day race, was appointed today as the Indianapolis Motor Speedway's new director of racing.

Something in The Times of May 1 has cheered me considerably. I refer to the story on "City Maps Battle on Dog Nuisances." In the most crowded city on earth, the Sanitation Commissioner has finally gotten around to proposing an amendment to the Sanitary Code prohibiting dog nuisances on the street.

What is described as the nation's most modern electrical metallic tubing plant was placed into operation yesterday. It is situated in Hicksville, L. I., and belongs to the Circle Wire and Cable Corporation, a wholly owned subsidiary of the Cerro de Pasco Corporation.
CINCINNATI, May 7 (AP) -- The Cincinnati Redlegs and the Chicago Cubs today traded right-handed relief pitchers, with Cincinnati's Hershell Freeman going to Chicago for Turk Lown.

The May potato position fell the 1/2-cent-a-pound daily limit yesterday from Tuesday's settlement price on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Other positions declined 4 to 8 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) on fourteen car lots. Most of the volume, 924 cars, was traded in the spot month. About 100 unsatisfied limit-down offerings were made at the close.
IN his zeal for watching the public purse, Lawrence Ettore Gerosa has crossed swords with many public officials, including Mayor Wagner and that most formidable of antagonists, Robert Moses.

MOUNT VERNON, N. Y., May 7 -- George Kalman, a 12-year-old pupil of the Traphagen Junior High School here, may not have a toe hold in New York University but he has a pen pal there -- Dr. Carroll V. Newsom, the president.
JERSEY CITY, May 7 -- The restoration of rent controls in northern New Jersey will be sought by 2,000 persons on a march to the Legislature in Trenton on May 19.

By most New Yorkers Samuel Seabury will doubtless be best remembered for the dramatic role he played in one of the historic investigations of the early Thirties. This was his role as counsel to the state legislative committee set up "to investigate the affairs of New York City."

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- President Eisenhower's outline last night of the legislation and policies he deems vital to national security was unusually terse, compact and persuasive. But politically it offered a hard buy to candidates for re-election among the Republican members of Congress whom he was addressing.
As the descendant of a long line of rabbis, I was shocked by the stand taken by Rabbi Isaac Lewin on May 3 at a Senate hearing on humane methods of slaughtering animals.
LONDON, May 7 -- Britain moved closer to a nation-wide railroad strike today. The action came as a continuing strike kept all buses off the streets in Greater London for the third day.
Gov. Orville L. Freeman of Minnesota declared last night that the development of good human relations in this country was of paramount importance.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 7 -- Although showing a slight decline, the big income for Hollywood writers still comes from theatrical movies.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- The Commissioner of Labor Statistics said today that he did not believe a rise in housing starts this year was "by any means assured." unless the general economic situation improved.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- The Federal Reserve Board reported today that the condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities showed the following principal changes for the week ended Wednesday, April 30:
WASHINGTON, May 7 -- The United States Information Agency is planning a Polish-language edition of Amerika, the magazine now published by the United States for distribution in the Soviet Union.

MATTHEW DAVID. EDEL, a student at Jamaica High School, Queens, made the headlines in this newspaper twice last week. First, it was announced that he had topped 33,000 candidates for Regents Scholarships -- he got a score of 352 out of a possible 375; secondly, an interview with him revealed his "unusual homework technique."
LIMA, Peru, May 7 -- A Communist-led demonstration by more than 1,000 persons chanting "Out with Nixon!" was staged tonight in front of the hotel where Vice Presi dent Richard M. Nixon is staying.
WASHINGTON, May 7 -- House and Senate conferees agreed today on a compromise $576,400,000 military pay rise bill designed to attract and keep skilled officers and men in service.

MOSCOW, May 7 -- The Government announced today that its first census in twenty years would be held during the week of Jan. 15 to 22 next year. All residents in the Soviet Union will be asked fifteen questions which they will be able to answer orally, without providing documentary proof.
"We're not going to win any pennants, but we're going to scare the other fellows half to death."

HONOLULU, May 7 -- Federal Judge Jon Wiig found four crewmen of the ketch Golden Rule guilty of criminal contempt today for violating his temporary injunction against sailing from Honolulu for the Eniwetok nuclear test area.

WESTBURY, L. I., May 7 -- It's getting so that a horseplayer has to have a sense of humor to go to Roosevelt Raceway. Highland Boy, returning $20 for $2 in taking the feature, warmed the wallets of some, but for most of the hardy followers it was another wet, dreary night.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 7 -- Delegates of Africa's eight independent nations banded into a formal bloc today and prepared to seek a more prominent role in United Nations affairs.
WASHINGTON, May 7 -- Divergent views as to the value of the recently expanded Federal highway-aid program in combating the recession were voiced today at the National Transportation Congress.
EVERY day is feast day at the United States World Trade Fair.

President Hernan Siles Zuazo took the opportunity of Vice President Nixon's visit on Tuesday to place his country's desperate plight in its most dramatic form. We need more help than we are getting from the United States, he said in effect, or Bolivia will turn to one of the extremes of communism or fascism.

The present lamentable political situation in France naturally causes a great deal of concern to those who feel strongly that an entente cordiale must be maintained among the nations of the Western bloc. A strong feeling of sympathy among thinking American people and a desire to seek some means of expressing this sympathy has been evoked.
Even employes who work under tension must obey "No Smoking" signs, the Fire Department said yesterday.

WHITE PLAINS, May 7 -- Governor Harriman offered today to campaign personally in Westchester to persuade the county supervisors and other officials to enlarge plans for the Westchester Community College.
Christopher Fry, author of "The Firstborn," has won the first of the Theresa Helburn Awards "for the best play that records and affirms the unquenchable thirst of the human spirit for freedom."

ATLANTIC CITY, May 7 -- A preliminary report on tests of a new blood-clot dissolving material was presented to the Association of American Physicians here today. It had been injected in patients shortly after they had suffered heart attacks.

Patrons have been announced for the theatre party and supper dance next Thursday to benefit Irvington House, a treatment center in Irvington-on-Hudson, N. Y., for children with rheumatic fever and rheumatic heart disease.
Twelve winners in the "This Is My City" art contest sponsored by the Police Athletic League and the Active Civic Association were announced at exercises yesterday in the New Yorker Hotel.
A big, brown man wearing a sport shirt, who speaks with the accent of the South Seas, paid a visit to Times Square yesterday and found the weather just like home.

WASHINGTON, May 7 (AP) -- The United States Court of Claims today awarded $65,000 to a Savannah (Ga.) housing development as compensation for the nuisance of jet plane noise from adjoining Hunter Air Force Base.
Building construction costs throughout the country rose 2 per cent during the year that ended in March, the F. W. Dodge Corporation reported yesterday.
THE National Association of Women Artists, opening today its sixty-sixth Annual Exhibition at the National Academy, 1083 Fifth Avenue, has grown since 1889 from a membership of five to more than 800.
ETTORE RELLA has written a strange, hypnotic drama, "Sign of Winter," which was well acted last evening at Theatre 74 (334 East Seventy-fourth Street).

TOKYO, May 7 -- The Communist Chinese Navy captured fourteen Japanese fishing boats with 170 men aboard yesterday and today in the East China Sea, according to the Japanese Maritime Safety Board. Some of the boats were fired upon and armed Chinese boarded them.
WASHINGTON, May 7 -- An Administration spokesman urged today the earmarking of some Federal hospital funds to test new types of hospital construction that might prove more economical.
NATIONAL TELEFILM ASSOCIATES, INC., began operation of Channel 13 yesterday and immediately introduced a new element of competition in the showing of films by the city's local stations.

A plot 375 by 100 feet on the east side of Fieldston Road, between West 236th and 238th Streets, in the Riverdale section of the Bronx, has been purchased by the Martense Construction Corporation, George Rabinor, president, for improvement with an apartment house containing 110 suites.

A seven-man Russian weight-lifting team is scheduled to arrive at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, this morning to continue the Soviet-United States sports competitions that have been doing so well lately.
WASHINGTON, May 7 -- Judge Learned Hand came out in opposition today to a pending Senate bill that would curb the power of the Supreme Court and overrule several of its recent decisions.
POCANTICO HILLS, N. Y., May 7 -- The Ladies Aid Society of Union Church here will hold a Japanese Festival on Friday beginning at 2 P. M. in the parish hall and continuing through the evening.

AN ideal of our time is to reduce international tensions -- and whoop it up for tense, dramatic situations on the stage, in the electronic arts and the novel. Posterity, if any, is going to have a devil of a time puzzling that out. Particularly when it sees how effectively our writers use the blaze and havoc of war to bring out the best and the worst in their wildly embattled characters.

LOS ANGELES, May 7 (UP) -- The Los Angeles Dodgers dropped a 9-3 decision to the Philadelphia Phillies today in the finale of a three-week home stand. In last night's game, a fourteen-inning contest that ended a few minutes after midnight, the Dodgers won, 7 -- 6.

Investigations of insurance practices by the Department of Justice have upheld the intent of the McCarran Act of 1945 by increasing competition, according to Victor R. Hansen, Assistant Attorney General.

HAVANA, May 7 -- In view of the present "state of national emergency" and the suspension of constitutional guarantees, the Superior Electoral Tribunal will ask Congress to suspend legislation prohibiting the dismissal of Government employes during the electoral period.
WASHINGTON, May 7 (UP) -- The State Department accused Communist China today of dragging its feet on the question of free elections aimed at uniting North and South Korea.

A report from London published in The New York Times on April 13 may be interpreted to infer that blood tests in Polynesia indicate a Polynesian racial affinity to Asian peoples rather than to American aborigines.
The names of six of the eight amateurs who will operate the America's Cup defense candidate Weatherly for the Henry D. Mercer Syndicate were made public yesterday by Philip L. Rhodes, the designer.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- Congressional leaders told the Administration at a high-level conference today to give some ground or face certain defeat in the fight for extension of the reciprocal trade program.

A new Frigidaire refrigerator-freezer that needs no defrosting, because it never develops frost either in the refrigerator or freezer sections, was announced yesterday by Harlow Curtice, president of the General Motors Corporation. Frigidaire is a division of General Motors Corporation.
LONDON, May 7 (Reuters) -- Britain will accept the United States invitation to an international conference on the peaceful scientific development of Antarctica, it was learned today.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 7 -- Gov. C. William O'Neill appears to face a serious challenge in the fall election from Michael V. DiSalle, winner of the Democratic nomination for Governor in yesterday's primary election.
ST. LOUIS. May 7 (UP) -- Lew Burdette held the St. Louis Cardinals to five hits tonight to gain a 9-2 victory for the Milwaukee Braves.

A proposal to build a tree-lined promenade along West Broadway was made yesterday by the Washington Square Association. At the same time it charged that City Construction Coordinator Robert Moses planned to take over the work on that street.
TRENTON, May 7 -- New Jersey today barred a rock 'n' roll show and dance from being held at the Sussex Avenue Armory in Newark on Saturday night.
The Republican state chairman accused Governor Harriman yesterday of stalling the state highway program in an effort to prolong the economic slump for political purposes.

Texas Eastern Transmission Corporation announced yesterday a major expansion in its top management. The company named three senior vice presidents, a new administrative vice president and a financial vice president.

The biggest one-week drop since the recession began was recorded last week in the number of workers drawing unemployment insurance in this state. The total declined 11,000, with 5,000 fewer workers receiving benefits in this city and 6,000 fewer upstate.
WASHINGTON, May 7 (AP) -- Heidi put on a hilarious show at the White House today. And in the process she both amused and embarrassed her mistress, Mrs. Dwight D. Eisenhower.

"THE OUTCASTS OF POKER FLAT" on Channel 4's "Kraft Theatre" last night had some touching moments and achieved an air of outdoor realism that reflected credit on those who staged it live in the studio.
A "state-wide crusade" of elderly persons to get voter support for two bond issues on the November ballot was announced yesterday by State Senator Thomas C. Desmond.

Electric-power production last week rose to 11,251,000,000-kilowatt hours from 11,206,000,000 in the week before, the Edison Electric Institute reported yesterday. The figure for the week ended May 4, 1957 was 11,286,000,000-kilowatt hours.
A California lawyer was charged with contempt yesterday after he had failed to appear before the special Federal grand jury investigating the Apalachin, N. Y., hoodlum conclave last Nov. 14.
Major differences between the Soviet and Chinese Communist attacks on Yugoslav Communist doctrine seem to suggest there may be less than full unity between Moscow and Peiping on this issue.

The House Foreign Affairs Committee's warning yesterday that a drastic reduction in American overseas aid "would inevitably mean that we would lose the cold war" is an appropriate footnote to President Eisenhower's fighting speech to the Republicans in Congress on behalf of three major items in his legislative program.

LOS ANGELES, May 7 (UP) -- Negotiators reached tentative agreement today on a contract for 16,000 employes at the pivotal Lockheed Aircraft Company. This temporarily eased the threat of a major strike that could shut down missile testing at Cape Canaveral Fla.
Four editors and their literary magazine were suspended at City College yesterday for publishing material deemed "not suitable" by college authorities.
Dr. John Perry Miller, Professor of Economics at Yale University, testified yesterday that the proposed Bethlehem-Youngstown merger would constitute a public service.
The proposed Southshore General Hospital in Nassau County, L. I., will be nearer realization as the result of an Oriental Dinner Dance to be held May 25.

WASHINGTON, May 7 (UP) -- Hal Griggs, a rookie, pitched the Washington Senators to an 11-4 victory tonight after Reno Bertoia's grand-slam homer in the first inning had powered the Detroit Tigers to a 5-1 triumph in the opener of a twilight-night double-header.
WASHINGTON, May 7 -- The Federal Reserve Board asked Congress today to "clarify" a section of the Bank Holding Company Act that has proved a key element in the First National City Bank case.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, May 7 -- The North Atlantic Council promised today to take the first concrete steps to redeem its nine-year-old promise to work for closer economic cooperation within the alliance.
Former Senator Herbert H. Lehman expressed a personal preference yesterday for Thomas K. Finletter as the Democratic candidate for United States Senator.

MONTREAL, May 7 -- The Workmen's Circle ended its quadrennial convention today as David Dubinsky, president of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, pledged an unceasing war against labor racketeers.

The pedestrian is doubtless surprised, but he must have heard the voices raised in his behalf and proposing actual social status for him. A slow fellow and potential jaywalker who ought not to be there, his street-corner mortality rate going up year by year, nevertheless he has friends.

BROCKVILLE, Ont., May 7 (AP) -- The loot in the week-end safecracking at the Brockville Trust Company was estimated today to total as much as $10,000,000.

"Trujillo, Little Caesar of the Caribbean," had been scheduled for publication this month by Thomas Nelson, but has been postponed until June 27. Fulton County, Ga., sold yesterday $10,350,000 of public improvement bonds secured by general taxation to a syndicate headed by Chase Manhattan Bank. The borrowing government required that the bonds should bear 3 1/4 per cent interest.

The American Radiator and Standard Sanitary Corporation experienced a sharp drop in sales and earnings in the first quarter this year. As a result, directors reduced the quarterly dividend 60 per cent to 10 cents from the previous quarterly rate of 25 cents a share.
The National Basketball Association, which has received twelve requests for franchises from San Francisco and Los Angeles, yesterday tabled discussion of expansion to the West Coast until next year.
The eighth annual Columbia Journalism Alumni Awards for distinguished service to journalism will be awarded tonight to F. Fraser Bond, Vance Packard and Ralph B. Smith.

NIAGARA FALLS, N. Y., May 7 -- The Tuscarora Indians again blocked State Power Authority teams from surveying their reservation today. A Federal marshal set the stage for possible court action against them for interference.

The United States Golf Association yesterday released a list of fifty-one qualifying locations to determine the 128 competitors for the boys' junior amateur championship.
BEFORE the year ends, thousands of Americans may pass judgment on Caesar's observation that "the Belgians are the most hospitable of Gauls."

The Pennsylvania Railroad Company has been advised that a second dissident stockholders' group plans to oppose the management's nominees for directors at the annual meeting in Philadelphia on Tuesday.
COPENHAGEN, Denmark, May 7 -- The North Atlantic Council challenged the Soviet Union today to join the West in detailed, technical discussions of means to check on disarmament.

Yesterday marked the official opening of the 1958 United States World Trade Fair in the Coliseum at Columbus Circle. It is the second annual version of this mammoth four-story show in which the principal countries of Europe, Asia, South America and Africa are enabled to bring together under one roof the finest and most representative examples of their products.
BUENOS AIRES, May 7 -- Peronists demonstrations marking the late Eva Peron's birthday were broken up tonight by the police using tear gas.
CHICAGO, May 7 (AP) -- A burst of buying in the final few minutes of Board of Trade dealings carried most grain futures up today after they had drifted along at slightly lower prices most of the day.

Federal, state and city officials joined yesterday in greeting the 1958 United States World Trade Fair as a contribution to peace and understanding among nations. The value of trade in promoting peace and economic progress was hailed in ceremonies that opened the fair at the New York Coliseum. Mayor Wagner and Governor Harriman joined in welcoming the foreign governments and other exhibitors in the fair, which will run until May 17.
BOSTON, May 7 (AP) -- The Boston Red Sox tonight sold Bob Porterfield to the Pittsburgh Pirates.
America's "unofficial ambassadors" were saluted yesterday by Miss Dorothy Shaver, president of Lord Taylor. at the store's twenty-first award luncheon in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

BONN, Germany, May 7 -- The Government majority in the Bundestag killed today a Social Democratic bill to provoke another parliamentary debate on West German nuclear armament. The Opposition sought to put the question on tomorrow's agenda, But the Christian Democratic majority rejected the demand, postponing the matter indefinitely.
NEWARK, May 7 -- Striking New Jersey trade union workers and those working without contracts were faced today with the threat of a shutdown of construction.
ANKARA, Turkey, May 1 -- Spring has burst out all around this capital city in a special way. The wheat is green and the storks are back.

Mayor Wagner yesterday officially opened Pier 63, Hudson River -- the first new pier completed under the city's five-year, $200,000,000 waterfront redevelopment program. It is also the first major municipal railroad pier built in more than fifty years.
Today is opening day for Idlewild Airport's International Hotel, an oasis for fatigued, stranded and other varieties of air travelers.

MONTE CARLO, Monaco, May 7 (UP) -- Prince Rainier of Monaco placed a slight limit on his own absolute power over this tiny nation today. He gave his subjects the right to appeal to him against any of his state decisions.

Fans, folding money and favorites were few at Jamaica yesterday, but foul claims were frequent. Only 14,853 racegoers, the smallest turnout of the year, showed up and wagered $1,518,374, also a 1958 low, and only two public choices lived up to their billing.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- Dr. James R. Killian Jr., president of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, who is President Eisenhower's special assistant for science and technology, is apparently playing an important role in the current review of United States disarmament policy.

Inventory liquidation still is not complete, the Guaranty Trust Company said in its monthly survey yesterday. The bank, dubious about any bottoming of the recession yet, finds that "quite generally throughout industry and trade inventory-to-sales ratios are as high or higher than they were at the start of the recession."
Stocks stumbled through an irregular session yesterday and ended off a little as unimportant losses outnumbered unimportant gains.
BONN, Germany, May 7 -- West Germany granted a credit of 400,000,000 Deutsche marks (about $95,000,000) to the United Arab Republic in a bilateral agreement signed here today.

FLORENCE, Italy, May 7 (UP) -- Msgr. Pietro Fiordelli, Roman Catholic Bishop of Prato who was convicted on charges of slandering a Catholic couple who married outside the church, appealed today for a new trial.

A SMASH hit came to television last night: a superb jazz show. It was presented on the new local station, WNTA-TV, Channel 13, and loyal adherents of the networks missed one of the great ninety minutes of the season.
Following is the text of a statement yesterday by Mayor Wagner commenting on the release Wednesday of reports on the Bureau of Real Estate by Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa:
MOSCOW, May 8 -- The Soviet Union took pains today to point out that nothing had happened to disturb its normal and friendly governmental relations with Yugoslavia.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., May 8 (AP) -- A district Federal judge ruled today that Continental Grain Company of Chicago could not recover $2,700,000 paid to the First National Bank of Memphis by a commodities speculator who now is bankrupt.
A new building with facilities devoted exclusively to the styling of hard surface floor and wall coverings has been opened at Lancaster, Pa., by the Armstrong Cork Company.

The United States women's basketball team returned yesterday from its tour of the Soviet Union with pleasant memories of "red carpet" treatment. They arrived at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens.
Eight Americans who rose from humble beginnings to positions of prominence in business and industry received the twelfth annual Horatio Alger Awards yesterday.
TUNIS, May 8 (Reuters) -President Habib Bourguiba of Tunisia warned today of the danger of war in North Africa unless Algeria was made independent.

The sun shone on the city yesterday. Timorously at first, and in random strikes, it sent fragile rays to soaked spots of the city. Its arrival was recorded by a historyminded pedestrian who spotted the first beams on the south side of West Fortyfourth Street between Seventh Avenue and the Avenue of the Americas and excitedly noted that it was precisely 3:10:42 P. M.

WASHINGTON, May 8 (UP) -The House Rules Committee cleared today the way for House action on President Eisenhower's proposed $3,600,000,000 bill to provide military, economic and technical aid to the Free World countries during 1959.
Russia's seven strongest men, pound for pound, arrived yesterday to match might with the United States' most muscular athletes in three weight-lifting contests next week.

An old Yorkville realty holding passed to new control with the signing of a contract by Louis Goldfarb to buy the twostory store and office building at 1161-71 Madison Avenue, at Eighty-sixth Street. The estate of Alexander D. Duff, the seller, owned the property for more than fifty years.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- A New York utility executive who believed that he had been courting labor to the extent of $93,000 was told today that 91 per cent of the money had gone to a promoter who had since absconded.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., May 8 (AP) -- Harry S. Truman was 74 years old today. About seventy close friends gave a luncheon party for him.
ROME, May 8 (AP) -- Sweden's Sven Davidson was eliminated in both the singles and doubles competitions in the Italian international tennis championships today.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 8 -- Emergence of the Soviet Union as a potential supplier of substantial amounts of tin characterized an already weakened world market for that product in 1957.
WASHINGTON, May 8 (UP) -- The State Department's program for sending scientists to foreign capitals to check on space-age developments has failed to get off the ground.
WASHINGTON, May 8 -- A failure by the Defense Department to choose between two rival Army and Air Force intermediate range ballistic missiles has cost the Government $100,000,000.

The Municipal Art Society yesterday awarded its 1958 medal for outstanding service to Michael L. Radoslovich, Director of Architecture for the Board of Education. Under Mr. Radoslovich, extensive use of art had been made in new public school construction.

Although the twenty-third game of the world chess match between Vassily Smyslov and Mikhail Botvinnik, the challenger, was adjourned after a fivehour session yesterday, according to a report from Moscow, indications were that the championship struggle would be concluded today.

LIMA, Peru, May 8 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon was spat upon, grazed on the neck by a stone, shoved and booed as he marched today into mobs of Communist-led demonstrators demanding his ouster from the country.

BERLIN, May 8 -- Secretary of State Dulles reaffirmed today, "with the express authority" of President Eisenhower, the Western Big Three guarantee to defend West Berlin against an attack "from any quarter."

The Police Athletic League, whose headquarters are at 400 Broome Street, New York 13, provides essential recreation as well as social and cultural activities for 300,000 boys and girls between the ages of 7 and 21 years. About the middle of the year, according to the Washington announcement, Marion B. Folsom will be succeeded by Arthur S. Flemming as Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare. WHEN the King of Belgium holds his garden party on May 13, several hundred of the distinguished women present will be wearing gowns designed by Louis Wittamer of the House of Valens.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, May 8 -- An "industrial park" exhibit was opened in the United States pavilion of the Brussels World's Fair today to illustrate a "bold and dramatic new approach to the complex problems of urban living and working."
ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., May 8 (AP) -- The New Jersey Savings and Loan League was told today that the demand for mortgage money had not kept pace with an increasing supply of funds.

SANTIAGO, Chile, May 8 -The Rightist parties told the Government today that they were now powerless to overcome the "steamroller" methods being used by the Leftist bloc in Congress to adopt legislation favorable to the Leftists, including the Communists.

Red God did a good job of puddle jumping at Jamaica yesterday. The 4-year-old son of Nasrullah was established as the 7-to-20 choice by the crowd of 18,242, and he won the sixfurlong feature decisively.
WASHINGTON, May 8 -- A national speed limit, electronically controlled, was advocated today by Senator Albert Gore.

ELMSFORD, N. Y., May 8 -An increase of 63 per cent in the assessed valuations on real estate in Greenburgh was reported today by tax officials. Some of the increase was attributed to benefits from the New York Thruway.
HOT SPRINGS, Ark., May 8 (AP) -- Tommy Bolt took the firstround lead in the $20,000 Hot Springs open golf tournament today with a six-under-par 66.

The possibility of an international film festival here this summer was offered yesterday as one of the steps contemplated by city officials and film producers to enhance New York's prestige as a film-making center.
The American League should take immediate steps toward expanding to ten clubs. Frank Lane, general manager of the Cleveland Indians, said yesterday.
LODZ, Poland, May 8 (AP) -Sixty-eight Jewish graves were reported desecrated today in Poland's worst outbreak of anti-Semitism in more than a year.

Recent French political crises have had a complexity and duration that seem to frighten everybody except the French. The present crisis is a case in point. Rene Pleven, who belongs to a small, left-of-center parliamentary group, the UDSR, came within an ace yesterday of getting a new government together after twenty-three days had passed since the fall of the Gaillard Government.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., May 8 -Charges that corruption in the Hamilton County Criminal Court extended into the Tennessee Legislature were presented today to the State House of Representatives. The house is considering impeachment proceedings against Judge Raulston Schoolfield of Chattanooga.
United States Attorney Paul W. Williams, was endorsed for the Republican nomination for Governor yesterday by Thomas J. Curran.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The New York Institute for the Education of the Blind maintains and operates Camp Wapanacki for blind children of all races, creeds and colors. Since 1938 thousands of handicapped youngsters have had their first taste of the great outdoors in this Green Mountain playground.
One of the thirty-five members of the board of the New York Philharmonic has donated $500,000 to the Lincoln Center of the Performing Arts.
WASHINGTON, May 8 -- A drop in factory jobs "considerably more than seasonal" was reported today by the Labor Department.
A judge in Brooklyn Federal Court sentenced a former New York policeman to two months in the penitentiary yesterday for defrauding the Government of $512 in income taxes.

Some pleasure boats actually go to college. Boat designs of at least one major manufacturer are taken to the Stevens Institute of Technology at Hoboken for testing in the Experimental Towing Tank (E. T. T.).
The Jewish Theological Seminary of America has established the Herbert H. Lehman Institute of Ethics. It will begin operating at the seminary at 3080 Broadway in July.

The Greater New York Fund, now campaigning for $11,000,000, is available to help all who live or work in the city. It covers about 315 square miles within the city limits. But because of special needs eighteen agencies assisted by the fund and serving New York are located elsewhere in the state.
The quarterly dividend on the common stock of the AllisChalmers Manufacturing Company was cut yesterday to 25 cents from 50 cents. It will be distributed to shareholders on June 30.

A trade group representing domestic woolen textile producers demanded yesterday that foreign imports be curbed by defeat of the proposed five-year extension of the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act. A resolution against the Administration -backed measure was passed at the ninety-third annual meeting of the National Association of Wool Manufacturers at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

The Long Island Little Orchestra Society will benefit from a dinner dance to be held on May 23 at the Piping Rock Club in Locust Valley, L. I. Mrs. Anthony A. Bliss is chairman of the benefit, which has been named "Danse Concertante."

WASHINGTON, May 8 -President Eisenhower saluted the nation's physically handicapped today as a group that had inspired him to carry the burdens of office "without feeling sorry for myself."
WASHINGTON, May 8 -- The Weather Bureau plans to tag the next hurricane it can find with a balloon-borne radio beacon that would be dropped into the storm's eye by a high-flying plane.

LONDON, May 8 -- Strife and crises of one kind or another have long been a part of Gen. Sir Brian Hubert Robertson's life. He was one of Britain's most distinguished soldiers, with a brilliant record in both World Wars, before he became chairman of the British Transport Commission in September, 1953.
Three new films will open at first-run theatres today.
Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr. was indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury on charges of income tax evasion.

PELHAM MANOR, N. Y., May 8 -- Fordham's varsity crew sent Clark University to its sixth straight defeat today at Travers Island. The Rams were nine lengths ahead of the Worcester (Mass.) eight at the finish line opposite the Travers Island boathouse.
WESTBURY, L. I., May 8 -The top handicapper for the past week at Roosevelt Raceway has been Frank Curran. He has batted 1.000 for seven days.

LONDON, May 8 -- Industrials again declined on the stock market today, although selling pressure eased on hopes that the threatened railway strike would be averted. Net losses generally were less than 1 shilling (14 cents) and a sprinkling of equities went narrowly against this trend.
WASHINGTON, May 8 -Communist China has been out of the main stream of the news here for a long time, but it is always present as a major complicating factor in the calculations of the Administration.
Awards for voluntary service in hospitals here were presented yesterday by officials of the United Hospital Fund.

ANYONE who is looking for a lively performance of Synge's "The Playboy of the Western World" is directed to the Seven Arts Center (120 Madison Avenue). It opened there last evening with an ideal playboy acted by Dermot McNamara under the direction of Joseph Gistirak.

DUBOIS, Pa., May 8 -- Many Pennsylvania Republicans consider Harold E. Stassen's persistent White House ambitions a handicap to his chances of winning the gubernatorial nomination in his adopted state.

HANOVER, N. H., May 8 -The Rockefeller Foundation has made a grant of $1,500,000 to Dartmouth College. The money will assist the development and expansion of Dartmouth's new five-year program integrating liberal arts studies and the basic medical sciences, Dr. John S. Dickey, Dartmouth president, said today.
The decline in business lending by banks in the New York area continued in the week ended last Wednesday, but at a moderate rate.
ALBANY, May 8 (AP) -- Two Albany policemen had the misfortune to leave the radio transmitter on in their patrol car while they were discussing their superiors. They were out of jobs today.
MOSCOW, May 8 -- The Soviet Union refused tonight an invitation from the United States to send observers to a hydrogen bomb test in the Pacific this summer.

The new Holland-America Line freighter Kerkedyk arrived here yesterday eight days behind schedule on her maiden voyage from Rotterdam. But her master, Capt. Eduard G. A. Heymans, received only praise from company officials.
ALBANY, May 8 -- Adlai E. Stevenson gave new support today to the Senate candidacy of Thomas K. Finletter.
VIENTIANE, Laos, May 8 -A Communist-oriented party and an allied group had staked a strong claim today to seven new seats in the National Assembly.

TWENTY contemporary British designs embracing a variety of home products received 1958 Designs of the Year awards yesterday. The awards were presented by the Duke of Edinburgh at Britain's Design Center, Haymarket, London.
MANHASSET, L. I., May 8 -Long Island's first public referendum on water fluoridation will be held tomorrow in the Manhasset-Lakeville Water District.

NIAGARA FALLS, N. Y., May 8 -- Surveyors of the state power authority, outnumbering a dwindling force of Tuscarora Indians, completed today a day of preliminary work on the Niagara power project's storage reservoir.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 8 -- One of the biggest independent production deals in recent Hollywood history was completed today by Jurow-Shepherd Productions with Paramount Pictures.
TRENTON, May 8 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner charged today that the Republican party in New Jersey was making a concerted effort to obtain a general sales tax.

CHICAGO, May 8 (UP) -- The Cincinnati Redlegs erupted for eight runs in the ninth inning today and knocked the Chicago Cubs out of first place in the National League with a 10-8 triumph. Smoky Burgess capped the uprising with his first homer of the year, with Gus Bell and a pinch-runner, Harvey Haddix, on base.

Many of the persons who will be going into the Astor Theatre for tonight's premiere of the movie "Paris Holiday" will be entering on the second phase of a three-party evening.

The Masonic order in New York State yesterday elected and installed H. Lloyd Jones of Bronxville as Grand Master. Mr. Jones, a retired insurance executive, succeeded W. Nathan Turk of Owego, former Surrogate of Tioga County.

An unplayable outfield -the infield was all right -- prevented the Yankees from playing the Cleveland Indians at the Stadium yesterday.
