A non-smoking first lady of the stage is the heaviest cigar-smoker of the current Broadway season. Lynn Fontanne, who co-stars with Alfred Lunt in "The Visit," the new play by the Swiss author Friedrich Duerrenmatt, is called on to smoke three cigars a performance in the role of a wealthy woman-ofthe-world.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange advanced 5 to 12 points yesterday. The rise equaled 25 cents to 60 cents a bale.

WASHINGTON, May 8 (UP) -The House Labor Committee agreed today to consider a welfarefund control bill that the Senate had approved. But it rejected Republican attempts to link the measure to general labor-reform legislation.

HACKENSACK, N. J., May 8 -- The construction of homes in Bergen County was at a less rapid pace in 1957 than in the immediately preceding years, according to the County Planning Board's annual report.
WASHINGTON, May 8 (AP) -President and Mrs. Eisenhower presented a little bit of Broadway after their formal state dinner for the Supreme Court tonight.
CHICAGO, May 8 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
ONE of the most polished shows in town is now running just a block away from "My Fair Lady."
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., May 8 (AP) -- A Polaris test vehicle burst apart with a flash of fire shortly after take-off today. But the Navy announced that the rocket had behaved as expected.

GERMANTOWN, Md., May 8 (UP) -- A growing group of demonstrators camped inside the headquarters of the Atomic Energy Commission said today that they would stage a hunger strike until the five atomic commissioners personally heard their protests against nuclear testing.
WASHINGTON, May 8 (UP) -- Representative Coya Knutson declined today to discuss a public plea by her husband that she retire and come home to Minesota.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, May 8 -- Secretary of State Dulles left here this morning for Berlin and yet another appearance as the chief advocate of the Atlantic alliance's policies before the court of world opinion.

Cocoa futures were strong in early trading yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange. Prices rose almost 1/2 cent a pound in active trading before heavy profit taking and hedging lowered prices from the highs.
THE Tower of Babel has nothing on a Manhattan beauty shop where you can have your hair done in any language from Viennese to Brooklynese.

CHICAGO, May 8 -- Social workers, who have sometimes been noted for walking softly and carrying a big question mark on controversial social issues, today served notice that they were going to take a hand in solving as well as assuaging human ills.

Some Federal judges have "taken the law into their own hands" because they are "so incensed at what they consider the inhuman sentences which the law compels them to inflict upon narcotics defendants," Judge Edward J. Dimock said last night.

Before "Jazz Party," station WNTA-TV continued its independent way by offering a ninety-minute reprise on film of the televised hearings involving the late Senator Joseph R. McCarthy and the Army. This program brought the veteran news commentator H. V. Kaltenborn out of retirement, and he has lost none of his gift for sharp observation.

A new book by Dr. Thomas A. Dooley, author of "Deliver Us From Evil," will be published May 22 by Farrar. Straus Cudahy. Called "The Edge of Tomorrow," it is an account of how the author and six young Americans traveled to Nam Tha, a village in Laos five miles from the border of Red China.
WASHINGTON, May 8 -Dean Acheson proposed today that someone other than the President or Secretary of State represent the United States in high-level conferences with the Soviet Union.
WASHINGTON, May 8 -- A State Department official said today there was now probably less danger of "satellization" of any Middle Eastern state than there was several months ago.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Friday, May 9 (AP) -- Indonesian military police today arrested Bernard Kalb, New York Times correspondent, on unspecified charges.
An increase in bookings of new military contracts by the Burroughs Corporation was reported to stockholders yesterday at the annual meeting in Detroit.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: A few months ago Dr. Edward Teller said in a Life magazine article that "the reduction in life expectancy from world-wide fall-out at present levels totals less than two days."
WASHINGTON, May 8 -- The Educational Policies Commission cautioned today against too speedy adoption of any particular method of teaching through television.
Noni Espina, a baritone from the Philippines, made his local debut last night in Carnegie Recital Hall.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- The official who spoke with authority to the National Press Club today on the atomic defense problems of the West, and the Senator who addressed his colleagues last Monday on "nuclear tests and atoms for peace," are the central figures in a bitter personal controversy that has impaired Executive-Congressional relations in a vital area of national policy.
WASHINGTON, May 8 -- Following is the text of Secretary of State Dulles' speech in Berlin today, as made public by the State Department:
Despite the recession, the General Dynamics Corporation in the first quarter this year increased its sales by 12.9 per cent and earnings by 5 per cent over the corresponding period last year.
The recession is slashing the income of unions as well as employers.
LONDON, May 8 -- The leaders of three railway unions agreed today to postpone any decision on a strike until after their meeting with Labor Minister Iain Macleod tomorrow.

Ten-year-old Eddie Rhodes attributes his enthusiasm for folk music to a trio that got out of hand. What started as a lunch-hour humming group two years ago has grown into an orchestra that includes the whole class.

Four suspended editors of Promethean, student literary magazine at City College defended yesterday the publication of the one-act play, "Tea Party." It had been found objectionable on Wednesday by the college administration, which suspended the editors and confiscated all unsold copies.

BOSTON, May 8 -- Despite the fact that thrift institutions remain exempt from direct control by the Federal Reserve System, the nation's money managers exert a commanding influence over the use of credit in all its forms, a member of the Federal Reserve Board and a leading savings banker agreed today.
Eighty-eight members of the Fire Department were promoted yesterday in ceremonies at 60 Hudson Street. Commissioner Edward F. Cavanagh Jr. and retiring Chief Edward Connors attended.
Two medical specialists last night decried the "wave of radiation hysteria" that is sweeping the nation.
Many patrons have been announced for a dinner to aid the Progress Program of the Presbytery of New York. It will be held in the Grand Ballroom of the Biltmore on Monday.
WASHINGTON, May 8 (AP) -The Navy expressed "grave misgivings" today at President Eisenhower's proposal to set up a new civilian space agency.

Rains became lighter and more scattered throughout the nation yesterday. However, crests moving downstream in swollen rivers still posed flood threats in parts of Kentucky and Louisiana, according to The Associated Press.
ROME, May 8 -- More Italian children, especially those in depressed areas, will receive food through a United States-Italian program that will go into operation in October.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The Jenner-Butler bill, aimed at curbing the appellate jurisdiction of the United States Supreme Court, has been reported out of the Senate Judiciary Committee by a 10-to-5 vote. The favorable action by the committee marks the high-water mark achieved by critics of the court in the Congress.
WASHINGTON, May 8 -- A royal midshipman who may occupy the Spanish throne some day took shore leave here today.

It had to come sooner or later -- a new investment company with the name, borrowed from the headlines, of MissilesJets and Automation Fund. A registration statement for the company was filed yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission, covering a proposed public offering of 500,000 shares at $10 a share.
WASHINGTON, May 8 (UP) The House accepted today a Senate bill to provide pensions for about 5,000 widows of Confederate veterans of the Civil War.

WASHINGTON IRVING'S magical legend of "Rip Van Winkle" was transferred to the television screen last night with delightful results. In a fine adaptation by Noel Langley, the story of the shiftless tippler of the Catskills was presented on "Shirley Temple's Storybook" over Channel 4.
PHILADELPHIA, May 8 -- A bronze plaque commemorating the publication of the Robert Aitken Bible in 1782 was presented to Pennsylvania and Philadelphia today by the American Bible Society.
SOCKS up, suits flawlessly pressed and ties properly knotted, leaders in the men's wear field gathered at the Pierre Hotel yesterday to attend an international fashion forum.
PARIS, May 8 -- The North Atlantic Council urged close economic ties between European countries and the whole free world yesterday.

New planting and shrubbery were blessed at the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine yesterday by Bishop Horace W. B. Donegan of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York. "Green things and trees," given by the Cathedral Guild, include evergreens, various flowers and shrubs, and some cherry trees.

FOOTBALL is a year-round conversational topic in California and not even the advent of big-league baseball in the Golden West could divert the touchdown talkers into other channels. Most of the gridiron gab, surprisingly enough, was about the professionals, because the former citadel of collegiate play has gone nuts about the Los Angeles Rams and the San Francisco Forty-Niners.
PARIS, May 8 -- The French political crisis took a grave turn today when former Premier Rene Pleven gave up in his third attempt to form a new Government.
A drive to unionize the white collar workers of steamship lines here has split.
New York International Airport was declared "off limits" yesterday to all automobile salesmen.
LONDON, May 8 (AP) -- Varsity teams from Oxford and Cambridge Universities will meet tomorrow in what is billed as the game of the century to introduce a new intercollegiate sport -- tiddlywinks.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -Tempers flared in the House Armed Services Committee today as the chief author of the Pentagon reorganization bill argued that every word of the controversial draft was essential to the proper defense of the nation.
BALTIMORE, May 8 (AP) -Bullslinger made a Silky Sullivanstyle finish today to win the Virginia Thoroughbred Association Purse by five lengths at Pimlico.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: May I protest that the air-raid "precautions" the public was asked to take part in during the alert were unrealistic to the point of absurdity? In the large corporation's offices where I work I was conducted to a corridor of the building which would not have afforded much protection against a near-miss by a bomb using the high-explosives of the war of 1939-45.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 8 (AP) -- An official of the United States Steel Corporation told the American Petroleum Institute today his company was filed testing a new steel casing and drill pipe that held promise for deep well drilling.
The proposed BethlehemYoungstown merger is needed to help fill a projected increase in demand for steel products in the nation's future economic growth, it was testified yesterday.
The Board of Estimate approved yesterday the street and zoning changes required to establish a proposed $30,000,000 modern industrial park in the Flatlands section of Brooklyn.
THE Alumni Association of the Fashion Institute of Technology will hold its annual dinner-dance tonight at the Plaza Hotel.

PALISADES INTERSTATE PARK, N. Y., May 8 -- Officials of New York and New Jersey today welded a joint organization to provide public recreation areas and facilities for this generation and future ones.

President Eisenhower's order withdrawing Federal troops from Central High School in Little Rock is timed to take effect after the close of the academic year. It would be a mistake, therefore, to draw too optimistic conclusions from the happy circumstance that after May 29 the Federal Government will no longer be employing military strength to enforce integration at this school.

BOSTON, May 8 (AP) -- Alan Freed, New York disk jockey, was indicted by a Suffolk County grand jury today on charges of inciting the unlawful destruction of property during a riot touched off at a performance of his rock 'n' roll show Saturday night.
Baltimore County, Md., announced that it would take bids May 21 on $12,000,000 of various purpose general obligation bonds, due from 1960 to 1998.
Relations between Mayor Wagner and Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa became more strained yesterday, although the Mayor sought to ease the crisis the Controller had created at City Hall on Wednesday.

A gratifying kind of international cooperation is involved in the establishment of a new international passenger carrier over the Atlantic lanes -- Irish Air Lines. Like many foreign air companies before this, the Aerlinte Eireann is getting started with modern Americanmade air equipment and with the help of an established United Statesflag company, Seaboard and Western.

The state's new bipartisan Crime Commission held its first organizing meeting yesterday in the office of the State Commissioner of Investigation, 270 Broadway. The new body will take the place of the commissioners.
THE high cost of beef, lamb and pork has pushed chicken into the limelight at meat counters again this week - end. Roasting, broiling and frying chickens are all economical.

BAGHDAD, Iraq, May 8 -Iraq's Ambassador in Cairo has been instructed to file a "strong" protest against a radio broadcast by Cairo's Voice of the Arabs station before the parliamentary elections here last Monday.

An alleged overcharge on four tickets in the rear of the orchestra for tonight's performance of "The Music Man" at the Majestic Theatre will be the subject of a hearing next Thursday afternoon in the office of License Commissioner Bernard J. O'Connell at 137 Centre Street.

INGLEWOOD, Calif., May 8 (AP) -- The Searcher, overlooked by most of the crowd estimated at 32,000, today won the $22,400 Premiere Handicap, the openingday feature of Hollywood Park's fifty-five-day summer meeting.
LONDON, May 8 -- Terence Rattigan's "Variations on a Theme" opened tonight at the Globe Theatre and disappointed most newspaper critics.
CINCINNATI, May 8 (UP) -President Warren Giles announced tiday that the National League would initiate a voting contest to decide a "player of the month" throughout the remainder of the 1958 season.
MONTREAL, May 8 (UP) -Camille Henry of the New York Rangers capped his best National Hockey League season today by winning the Lady Byng Trophy and the $1,000 check that goes with it.

THAT the human figure is still a favorite subject for representation is demonstrated in an exhibition of drawings, many by artists also well known for their abstract works, at the new Workshop Gallery, 332 East Fifty-first Street.
An aged parking attendant looked like an easy target to two young hold-up men last night. They were never more wrong.

IF Catskill trout fishermen are not getting odd breaks there is no logic in reason. It has been raining pretty steadily up there for days, yet the streams are clear and falling, trout are striking and flies are hatching.
BUFFALO, N. Y., May 8 (AP) -- One of the nation's most advanced electronic laboratories was dedicated today and the company already was indicating expansion.
JERUSALEM (Israel Sector), May 8 -- A towering new center for Israel's religious Jews was dedicated here this afternoon.

WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP) -- The indicated harvest is likely to create a record high reserve and surplus supply unless unexpected markets open up. This year's crop will be supplemented by 880 million bushels of wheat accumulated from past crops, mostly held by the Government under price supports.
WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP) A new underground railway about 1,900 feet long is being built here. It will link the two Senate Office Buildings, one of them still under construction, with the Capitol.
DETROIT, May 9 (AP) -- Passenger car output this week will total 77,128 units against 78,441 last week, Ward's Automotive Reports said today. In the comparable 1957 week 125,924 cars were assembled.
CHICAGO, May 9 (AP) -- Short-covering in May wheat and rye provided the only steady demand in grain futures today. All other contracts on the Board of Trade were weak.
WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP) -- President Eisenhower spent almost an hour and a half in a private railroad car tonight seeing Mrs. Eisenhower off for a Denver visit with her mother.
Democrats started to draw lines yesterday for expected new battles with Republicans over Nelson A. Rockefeller's state committee on Constitutional revision.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 9 -- Dr. Marion E. Kenworthy predicted today a substantial and early growth of psychoanalysis.
RIO DE JANEIRO, May 9 (UP) -- Angry residents in the suburban area where 128 persons were killed last night in a train collision invaded the railroad station today and wrecked it.
QUITO, Ecuador, May 9 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon said tonight he had experienced no fear yesterday morning when he faced a hostile rock-throwing mob at San Marcos University in Lima, Peru.

A race that figures to "Leave Them Happy as They Say Good-By" will feature the card at the Jamaica race track today. The event, the $50,000 added Grey Lag Handicap, has attracted fifteen starters, and if all compete in the mile-and-an-eighth fixture the value to the winner will be $38,400.
DETROIT, May 9 -- Henry Ford 2d warned today that any increases above present labor costs would have to be reflected in immediate price increases on cars and trucks.
SAN JUAN, P. R., May 9 (UP) -- Pablo Casals, 'cellist, said today that he was planning another music festival here next year to continue cultivating the spirit of chamber music.

The dogwood display in the Bear Mountain-Harriman State Park, now reaching its peak, was rivaled in splendor yesterday by an outburst of cherry blossoms in Westchester County, particularly at Tarrytown.
WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP) -- Germs and drugs that would knock out an enemy just temporarily are being sought by United States chemical warfare experts.
LONDON, May 9 -- A painting auctioned for 17 1/2 guineas as a Tintoretto in 1888 brought 36,000 guineas ($105,840) today after it had been reascribed to El Greco.
ALBANY, May 9 (AP) -- Thirteen college students won grants totaling $5,160 from the state today to try to provide answers to questions in a number of scientific fields.

PELHAM MANOR, N. Y., May 9 -- Nick Egan, an 18-year-old St. John's University freshman, broke 92 of 100 targets today to win the doubles title in the forty-ninth annual Amateur Trapshooting Championships of America at the New York Athletic Club's Travers Island range.

The proposed thirty-six-foot roadway through Washington Square Park, which will be the subject of a public hearing by the City Planning Commission on May 14, raises a number of issues which the Women's City Club believes are of citywide concern.
WASHINGTON, May 9 -- The House Subcommittee on Legislative Oversight will return next Tuesday to its investigation of the Federal Communications Commission.

THE monthly exhibitions of painting at the City Center Gallery, 131 East Fifty-fifth Street, are far more than local events as they are contributed to by artists the country wide. They greatly benefit also from having different jurors each time, which insures the shows not being repetitious.

PHILADELPHIA, May 9 -- Randolph Phillips, independent candidate for electron as a director of the Pennsylvania Railroad, today asked the United States District Court to postpone the election at the annual meeting here on Tuesday.
One of the world's outstanding theological libraries will have a new $2,000,000 home in the not too distant future.

BOSTON, May 9 -- Government efforts to offset the recession can be nullified if Congress fails to extend the reciprocal trade program or drastically curtails foreign aid, Senator J. William Fulbright warned today.

PITTSBURGH, May 9 (AP) -- Four industrial concerns, fined last year for violating the Sherman Anti-Trust Act, signed a consent decree to discontinue sales practices that the Government charged were illegal.

The Round Hill team defeated Apawamis yesterday, 10 -- 5, as action resumed in the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association interclub series. Round Hill now leads by 15 1/2 points in Westchester's series I.
QUITO, Eduador, May 9 -- Vice President Nixon received a friendly and colorful reception here today.

The police arrested fifty men yesterday in a series of gambling' raids in the Times Square and garment areas. The charges against them included bookmaking, policy collection, vagrancy and maintaining gambling establishments.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 9 -- The Lebanese capital went into mass mourning this afternoon during the funeral of Nassib Metni, a crusading editor, who was shot down outside his home early yesterday by two gunmen. Most Beirut newspapers have accepted his murder as a political killing.
LAHORE, Pakistan, May 9 -- Dr. Khan Sahib, 76-year-old leader of the ruling Republican party and "grand old man" of Pakistan politics, was stabbed to death today by an assassin.
FONDI, Italy, May 9 (Reuters) -- A Protestant minister stepped out into the open today after having spent three days in an apartment walled in on orders of his Roman Catholic landlady.
Tension continued yesterday between Mayor Wagner and Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa as a result of Mr. Gerosa's release of a 1956 report on the Bureau of Real Estate.

After a lapse of a week, baseball returned to the Stadium last night amid considerable fanfare. A gathering of 18,604 saw the Yankees gain a smashing 9-5 triumph. However, it was the Senators, the party of the second part, who inspired most of the noise in this first nocturnal engagement of the season in the Bronx arena.
CHICAGO, May 9 -- A convention of social workers passed a strong statement on civil rights and liberties here today, then faltered a bit in applying it at home.
BONN, Germany, May 9 -- The last four Nazi war criminals held by the United States have been paroled, the United States Embassy and Army headquarters in Heidelberg announced jointly today.
BOSTON, May 9 -- A Treasury official said today that the money market should not rule out the possibility of the sale of long-term Government bonds in time of recession and credit ease.
A young physician, his wife and their six children left West Hartford, Conn., yesterday for the foothills of the "Mountains of the Moon," the Ruwenzori range.
LONDON, May 9 -- Government securities and oil shares led the recovery in the stock market today. The rise was based on hopes that the impending railway strike would be averted.
The best judgment on the deplorable incident involving Vice President Nixon in Lima, Peru, on Thursday was made by Mr. Nixon himself.

Seventy years ago this week nineteen machinists met secretly in an Atlanta, Ga., locomotive pit to organize a union. Today, the International Association of Machinists has nearly one million members in every state and nine Canadian provinces.
Gottlieb Duttweiler, 70-year-old Swiss crusader for price cuts, said here yesterday that he had completed arrangements for the construction of an oil refinery in West Germany.
Senator Jacob K. Javits said yesterday that tenant relocation in this city was a weak spot in the national slum clearance program.

POCANTICO HILLS, N. Y., May 9 -- Tokyo and Pocantico Hills have discovered a common interest. Both want the International Christian University, opened in the Japanese capital five years ago, to succeed, despite scant finances.
PHILADELPHIA, May 9 (AP) -- The Government should take on the financial burden of railroad commuter service, William White, president of the Delaware and Hudson Railroad asserted today.

Additional advice was given to the city yesterday on the future of Washington Square Park. It was from Morton S. Wolf, president of Washington Square Village, Inc., developers of the apartment and commercial project south of the park.

HEWLETT HARBOR, L. I., May 9 -- A thirty-mile-an-hour breeze over the Seawane Harbor Club course today failed to halt a par-equaling 72 by Arthur Silvestrone. The 26-year-old Great River (L. I.) Country Club golfer won the medal in the William D. Richardson Memorial tourney.
MOSCOW, May 9 -- An "offensive" on the shortage of consumer goods has been officially started by the Government and the Communist party.

WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP) -- Five boys and girls who saved the lives of other school children received gold medals today from Gen. Nathan F. Twining, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, at a Pentagon ceremony. Two other children received certificates.
MIAMI, May 9 (AP) -- A business man, a lawyer and a former banker pleaded innocent in Federal District Court here yesterday to charges of mail fraud in connection with a "check-kiting" scheme.

BALTIMORE, May 9 (UP) -- Silky Sullivan, the California colt that disappointed his many fans when he failed to uncork his usual stretch sprint in the Kentucky Derby, narrowly escaped injury today. He stumbled and fell as he was about to start a workout at Pimlico.

POZA RICA, Mexico, May 2 -- Luis H. Alvarez, 38-year-old candidate of the rightist National Actionist party, has little chance of winning the Presidency of Mexico in the July 6 election. Nevertheless, he is staging a vigorous campaign.
Shirley Booth is interested in appearing as Juno Boyle in the musical version of Sean O'Casey's celebrated play, "Juno and the Paycock."

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- Average wholesale prices in the primary markets rose 0.2 per cent to 119.9 per cent of their 1947-49 levels during the week ended last Tuesday, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.
A 16-year-old high school boy is in custody on charges of beating a fellow student and extorting money from him.
The Federal income tax evasion indictment against Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr. developed ramifications yesterday.
Senator Jacob Javits met Thursday with his committee at the Waldorf-Astoria to plan for the motion-picture benefit for the National Conference of Christians and Jews.

A six-story building containing eighty-seven apartments at the northeast corner of Sheridan Avenue and 171st Street, the Bronx, has been resold after a brief ownership by Hugh K. McGovern and Loomis J. Grossman, realty operators.
WASHINGTON, May 9 -- A bill to require price tags on new automobiles was approved today by the Senate Commerce Committee.
BOSTON, May 9 (AP) -- Mr. Baird questioned whether a cut in income taxes would be an effective way of fighting the recession.
The justices of the Appellate Division in Brooklyn yesterday praised one of their former associates, John MacCrate, who is retiring next Thursday as an official referee of the Brooklyn Supreme Court.
HACKENSACK, N. J., May 9 -- Christmas Seal sale chairmen and their committee members were guests today at a tea given at the Senior Center by the Bergen County Tuberculosis and Health Association.
WESTBURY, L. I., May 9 -- Racing fans show their displeasure if a favorite doesn't seem to try. Tonight at Roosevelt Raceway they booed as an odds-on favorite scored in the feature.
Three thousand additional city employes will be assigned to combat juvenile crime this summer, Mayor Wagner announced last night.

The United States won another small tactical victory when it succeeded in keeping both the Soviet Union and itself out of the membership of the new U. N. Commission for Africa. At about the same time a group of sixty business men, officials and various experts were heading a session at Arden House on the picturesque edge of the Bear Mountain Interstate Park on the topic "the United States and Africa."

The Paramount Pictures Corporation announced yesterday its consolidated net earnings from operations amounted to $1,405,000 in the first quarter this year. It was $1,299,000 for the corresponding 1957 period.
SPRING floods have separated the nuns of the Jemez River from their fishing by wrecking their habitations, and the prospects for innocent sport are blacked out. It is a sore blow to fishing.

SCRANTON, Pa., May 9 (AP) -- The Hollywood, Calif., Y. M. C. A. Comets won their second straight masters-division championship in the National Volleyball tournament yesterday by defeating the Detroit Y. M. C. A., 15 -- 8, 15 -- 9.
Events today: Grete Sultan, pianist, Carnegie Recital Hall, 5:30; Fordham University School of Education Glee Club, Cosmo de Pietto conducting, Town Hall, 8:30.
PASSAIC, N. J., May 9 -- Detectives here pressed their investigation into the slaying of a 28-year-old rookie patrolman today.
The Transit Authority had a happy word yesterday for motorists as well as subway riders.
RIVERHEAD, L. I., May 9 -- The Central Suffolk Hospital Auxiliaries had to cope with a "phenomenon" in planning their annual report luncheon.
THANKS to Milton Miltiades, whose devotion to the Greek classics is nothing short of admirable, there is at least a chance now to behold Euripides' "Electra" on a local stage.

Mill shipments of steel, a basic economic factor, totaled 13,928,675 net tons in the first quarter, compared with 22,689,781 in the similar 1957 period, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. March showed a 4 per cent increase over the shorter month of February.
BERN, Switzerland, May 9 (AP) -- A Swiss Federal Court sentenced Max Ulrich, a former Swiss counter - intelligence agent, to two and a half years at hard labor today for spying for France.
Queens Democratic leaders chose William Kerwick yesterday to make a second attempt to unseat Representative Albert H. Bosch, a Republican. Mr. Kerwick is a former Queens assistant District Attorney.
PHILADELPHIA, May 9 (UP) -- Schenley Distillers, Inc. yesterday lost a suit in the United States Court of Appeals to recover from the Treasury Department $39,296,151 in alcohol taxes.
CHICAGO, May 9 (AP) -- A uniform law for labeling dangerous household and chemical products was proposed today by the American Medical Association's Committee on Toxicology.

Like any loyal citizen interested in the heritage of his country, I was mortified to read of the theft of the several priceless letters of our forefathers which were taken from the New York Public Library.

A raw talent but a real one is the impression that Phillip Evans made in his New York piano debut last night at Carnegie Recital Hall. And how much more interesting a strong raw talent can be than a well-schooled weaker gift.

BONN, Germany, May 9 -- West Germany is prepared to offer the United States accelerated payment on its post-war debt in lieu of further financial support of United States forces in the Federal republic.

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- The House Appropriations Committee gently reproved the State Department today but failed to cut off funds for continued operation of what a key member has called "the Riviera rest cure."

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 9 -- The United States will provide 120 fellowships during the next two years to be awarded through the International Atomic Energy Agency for advanced study in the science and technology of nuclear energy.

About twenty policemen were stationed outside Carnegie Hall last night, where Paul Robeson was giving his first local recital in eleven years. Their presence was unnecessary. The audience, which completely filled the hall, was orderly, and there were no demonstrations outside. And so the police went home about 9:15 P. M.

The new capital market faces a week of moderately heavy requisitions for money from both corporations and local governments. Dealers hold substantial inventories of undistributed new issues of corporate bonds, and investing institutions are stiffening their resistance to the lower yield levels recently touched.

It has been customary for some time now for the Department of Commerce and the Bureau of Labor Statistics of the Labor Department to combine their figures on employment and put them out in the form of a joint release about this time each month.
Six meet records were set yesterday as local school trackmen resumed action, after a annual Mount St. Michael games at Randalls Island.

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- Lucius M. Beebe, long a memher of the Fourth Estate, was granted a patent this week for a newspaper vending rack -- the kind that trusts the public -to put in the money. His co-inventor is Charles M. Clegg Jr., with whom he has collaborated for ten years on such books as "Mixed Train Daily," "Legends of the Comstock Lode" and "Dreadful California."
PORT - AU - PRINCE, Haiti, May 9 -- The Government offered the United States today all facilities necessary for the establishment of guided missile bases on Haitian soil.

Ten sprightly septuagenarians gave glowing golden anniversary recollections of the 1908 Olympics last night. The New York Chapter of the United States Olympians was holding an annual meeting at the Hotel Belmont Plaza and, as guests of honor, had as many members of the team of fifty years ago as were available.
The Public Service Commission yesterday denied the Long Island Rail Road permission to discontinue two of four trains operated on the Rockaway Beach Branch between Rego Park and Ozone Park.
The studebaker-Packard Corporation, Which has been operating in the red for several years, experienced further reverses in the first three months this year.

VIENNA, May 9 -- Wladyslaw Gomulka, whose trip through the Eastern bloc apparently is intended by Moscow to demonstrate the unity of the Communist camp, arrived in Budapest today but said nothing about unity.
CATLETTSBURG, Ky., May 9 (AP) -- The Big Sandy and Ohio Rivers crested here today and caused little damage.

SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., May 9 -- Prof. Christianna Smith of Mount Holyoke College will retire in June, the college announced today. For forty years she has combined research on cell tissue with a full teaching schedule.

NEWARK, May 9 -- Building contractors announced today that, exercising "business prudence," they had shut down construction projects in Bergen and Passaic counties. Similar action will be taken at the end of the work day Monday in Essex, it was said.

Front of the Property All of the yard no doubt has been cleaned for the summer by now, No? Well, it's a little late in the season still to be at it. The grass has been cut at least once, should have been cut twice.
I was disappointed by the manner in which the press, The Times included, and radio and television reported the statement made by the U. N. Secretary General in the Security Council on April 29.
The taking of testimony in the Bethlehem-Youngstown antitrust trial ended yesterday.
Commodity prices closed generally higher yesterday on the New York exchanges. Trading in most markets was dull and evening of positions before the week-end accounted for most of the volume.

MOSCOW, May 9 -- You get the strangest group of adjectives when inquiring around Moscow about Mikhail Botvinnik, who today regained the world chess championship. These are some; frail, retiring, timid, pedantic, nervous.

United States Attorney Paul W. Williams yesterday charged a former assistant United States Attorney with "gross impropriety." He referred to an affidavit by the assistant that supported a defense contention that the Government had used "tainted" evidence to obtain the conviction of three men on income tax charges.
Stocks as a whole did little yesterday but a few specialties, especially in the lower price ranges, swung about and gave an impression of activity.
WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP) -- The Senate Commerce Committee voted today to authorize $512,000,000 in Federal aid to airports over a five-year period.

TRENTON, May 9 -- Acting Attorney General David D. Furman ruled illegal and unconstitutional today the taxation by Philadelphia of wages paid in New Jersey to residents of that city for work performed in this state.
WASHINGTON, May 9 -- The head of a grocery chain testified today that his concern had allowed union officials and their relatives to buy stocks and bonds on a cut-rate basis "to avoid ill will."
Twenty-six eighth-graders from the Manhasset, L. I., Junior High School took a look yesterday at their share of American industry.

John Calamaras, realty operator and owner of the Blue Sea Restaurant at 135 Third Avenue, near Fifteenth Street, has purchased an adjacent parcel at 206 East Fifteenth Street to add to a large plot he controls there.
A new method of making use of faster and more effective catalysts for curing rubber and plastics has been developed by the Linde Company, a division of Union Carbide Corporation.
WASHINGTON, May 9 -- Indonesia is asking the United States to help solve the problem of foreign intervention in the Indonesian civil war, Indonesian diplomats here said today.

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- The Senate Internal Security subcommittee urged Congress today to rewrite a 1954 law designed to force witnesses to answer questions put by investigating panels. Under the law a witness may be promised immunity from prosecution for his testimony.
MOSCOW, May 9 -- Moscow has warned Yugoslavia that Soviet friendship and economic aid can be withdrawn at any time.
WASHINGTON, May 9 (UP) -- Representative Coya Knutson said today that she would seek re-election.
NEW DELHI, India, May 9 (Reuters) -- The Orissa state Government resigned today, ending a twelve-day crisis in the east Indian area on the Bay of Bengal.
GENEVA, May 9 -- The International Labor Organization urged its member governments today to discourage their seamen from working under substandard conditions aboard ships of other nations.
For 15,000 school children yesterday, the Coliseum was a huge candy counter.
BEGINNING tomorrow, another of Manhattan's favored institutions joins the ranks of those expanding to the suburbs.
LONDON, May 9 (AP) -- World copper dealers today opposed any form of international commodity agreement.
Fire Commissioner Edward F. Cavanagh appeared yesterday in Upper Manhattan Court to prosecute the case of the 211 cigarette butts.

Attorney General William P. Rogers, noting that almost half of the persons arrested for major crimes last year were under 18 years old, said here yesterday that there had been a failure to inculcate moral values into the nation's youth.

Statistics dealing with the 425 agencies helped by the current campaign of the Greater New York Fund must seem both monumental and cold. Actually these statistics deal with warm, appealing individual problems, ranging from the boy who desperately wants to go to camp to the middle-aged librarian who learns she is going blind.

Today's new film is "The Bigamist," an Italian-made comedy starring Vittorio De Sica, at the World Theatre. Guido Giambartolomei and Carlo Salsano directed the Luciano Emmer production, which is being released by the Distributors Corporation of America.

EMILY BRONTE'S novel of violence and revenge, "Wuthering Heights," was adapted into a ninety-minute play last night on the "Du Pont Show of the Month" over Channel 2. It proved rather too much for the cast and cameras.
A salty crew of yarn-spinners worked magic in the port last night.
NIAGARA FALLS, N. Y. May 9 (AP) -- The Tuscarora resistance to surveyors for the Niagara power project collapsed today.
MOSCOW, May 9 -- Mikhail Botvinnik recaptured the world chess championship today, not with a bang but with a whimper.

TRENTON, May 9 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner called upon New Jersey judges and law enforcement officials today to increase their efforts toward reducing crime, particularly that involving juvenile offenders.

UTICA, N. Y., May 9 (AP) -- The Utical City clerk said today that he would withhold copies of proposed city ordinances from the Utica newspapers until they changed their policies of reporting municipal affairs.
Russia's mighty weightlifters huffed and puffed through a two-hour practice session yesterday in preparation for three matches against a United States all-star team next week.
From now on New York will be the only city to see the entire Ringling Brothers and Barnum Bailey Circus.
WASHINGTON, May 9 -- A special unit has been organized at the Pentagon to assist officials who appear before Congress in the Administration's battle to reorganize the Defense Department.
MANHASSET, L. I., May 9 -- A public referendum on fluoridation for the Manhasset-Lakeville Water District was overwhelmingly rejected tonight.
WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP) The Federal Trade Commission said today it has charged Snap-On Tools Corporation of Kenosha, Wis., with illegally re-straining trade and hampering price competition.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange advanced 2 to 26 points (10 cents to $1.30 a bale) yesterday. Old May showed the most strength.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., May 9 -- An Administration request for business men's advice on fighting the recession produced split views today on whether taxes should be cut and -- should they be cut -- how should this be done.

A number of items in the news recently have testified to the continued expansion of Soviet-American cultural exchange. The most striking is the agreement to exchange delegations of steel men, an event which will be accompanied by relaxation on both sides of present restrictions regarding areas of each country which nationals of the other may visit.
Ninety per cent of the Transsit Authority's hourly rated workers will share a $5,000,000 wage-inequity fund this year and next under a recommendation made yesterday.
LONDON, May 9 -- A Government attempt to avert a nation-wide railroad strike ended inconclusively today.
SOMETIME after sunup tomorrow, Elinor Gene Hoffman will hear the patter of fourteen feet approaching her bedroom as her children come to wish her a happy Mother's Day.

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- President Eisenhower told Vice President Richard M. Nixon today that his "courage, patience and calmness" in the demonstration against him in Peru yesterday by "radical agitators" had brought him "new respect and admiration" at home.
WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP) -- Kenneth E. Fields has resigned as general manager of the Atomic Energy Commission, effective no later than July 1.

The eight founders of the six-year-old Every Other Wednesday Night Married Men's Poker Club of Tipton, Iowa, came to town yesterday for a four-day visit. With them were their wives, who made the club -- and the trip -- possible.
WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP) -- A bull whip cracks because its tip breaks the sound barrier.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), May 9 -- An Israeli supply convoy went through to Mount Scopus this morning after the Jordanians had withdrawn objections to certain personnel accompanying it.
SHARPLES, W. Va., May 9 (AP) -- Twenty-four coal miners, grime-smeared and grinning, emerged in single file early today from the flooded wreckage of a 30-year-old mine.
ROME, May 9 (AP) -- India's Ramanathan Krishman and Australia's Mervyn Rose today moved into the semi-finals of the Italian tennis championships.

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development increased its loans to Latin America to a record total of $120,800,000 for a fiscal year with the signing today of a $5,500,000 highway loan to Honduras.

MONTREAL, May 9 (Canadian Press) -- A seven-man raiding force burst into a shed in the north end of Montreal yesterday and found a brown suitcase holding $350,000 in bonds stolen from the Caisse Nationale d'Economie in a $1,789,000 safe-cracking job last Jan. 27.

JAKARTA, May 9 -- Bernard Kalb, correspondent of The New York Times in Indonesia, was released after two hours detention today on unspecified charges. He had been arrested by Jakarta military police while he was working on a dispatch in his office.

PARIS, May 9 -- The French political crisis is again proving to be an expensive and dangerous but effective mechanism for promoting the evolution of French policy. The demonstration is taking place this time with respect to policy in Algeria.
SINCE mothers as a group are usually a modest species, it is presumed that they do not care too much about presents on Mother's Day.

ARNHEM, The Netherlands, May 9 -- A problem facing the Western world is the American recession. Experts disagree in assaying its severity. But it has already had repercussions abroad at an unfortunate moment.
An address by President Eisenhower from New York will be broadcast by the major radio and television networks on Tuesday, May 20.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., May 9 (AP) -- Three Federal judges ruled today that Alabama's school placement law could be administered in a lawful manner and could not be held invalid on its face.
PARIS, May 9 -- Pierre Pflimlin seemed assured tonight of having the indispensable support of the key Socialist party should he decide to form a new French Government.
HARRIMAN, N. Y., May 9 -- One of the country's foremost arbitrators tonight proposed vastly increased power for the merged labor federation to curb union racketeering and undemocratic tendencies.

Andrea Towers, a twelve-story apartment house at 70 South Munn Avenue, East Orange, N. J., has been purchased by the 490 Realty Corporation, represented by Morton Greenspan, attorney. The property is on a plot of 140 by 432 feet and contains 207 apartments and a garage for 112 cars.
A smaller scale model of the Sergeant, the Army's solid-fuel missile, went on display yesterday in Grand Central Terminal. It helped to signal the start today of Armed Forces Week.

MINEOLA, L. I., May 9 -- Eight of ten private garbage collectors pleaded guilty today to charges of conspiring to bribe a former Oyster Bay Town official. Judge Paul J. Widlitz of Nassau County Court continued them in $1,000 bail each.

OXFORD, England, May 9 (AP) -- The Oxonian Tiddlers from Oxford University defeated the Cantab Winkers of Cambridge University in tiddlywinks today, 113 -- 111, and immediately claimed the world championship.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, May 9 -- Austria has sent her best to the Festival of the Performing Arts, which parallels the World's Fair here. WASHINGTON, May 9 -- Mrs. George W. Vaughan of Los Angeles was elected president today of the Association of the Junior Leagues of America.

A proposal to merge three Ridgefield, N. J., banks into one institution with assets of $100,000,000 was announced yesterday. Stockholders of Plainfield Trust Company, State Trust Company and Plainfield National Bank will vote June 6 on the consolidation plan.

A portrait of Canada's "fastest growing province" is given by Vera Kelsey in her new book "British Columbia Rides a Star." Miss Kelsey spent almost three years traveling throughout the province studying its economy, people and scenic beauty.
New Yorkers who live in cramped quarters should welcome a new double-duty chair that can be used for both dining and lounging.
SANTA CLARA, Calif., May 9 (AP) -- Gary Heinrich, 17-year-old Hayward High School senior, today bettered the National Interscholastic and American records for the 440-yard free-style swim.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 9 -- Although discussions so far are only exploratory, the announcement yesterday that the National Theatres Corporation and National Telefilm Associates, Inc., are discussing the possibility of an "association" has great significance for the motion-picture and television industries.

NEW HAVEN, May 9 -- The president and members of the Corporation of Yale University paid tribute tonight to a faithful employe. TWO of the more recent newcomers to the non-theatrical film orbit definitely bear watching. David Myers is one, Madeline Tourtelot the other. Their talent is strikingly exemplified in Ansel Adams, Photographer (15 minutes, released by International Film Bureau, Inc., 57 East Jackson Boulevard, Chicago); and Zopatecan Village (20 minutes, from Film Images, Inc., 1860 Broadway).
Bundled in a dark blue warm-up jacket, Don Rose sat in a wooden armchair at Baker Field's Gould Boat House the other day and said he was a little man with a big job.

THIS fascinating book about our first national hero, written by a young British scholar who received much of his historical training in this country, is not biography in the conventional sense. It gives the basic facts of Washington's life and offers an excellent brief introduction to him, but it also describes and interprets him as a legend.
TRENTON, May 10 -- Voters in nineteen New Jersey municipalities will elect local governing officials on Tuesday.

The ultimate in taking non-sense seriously turned up in your magazine. A professor has seen fit to cast slurs upon the word "togetherness." By his caustic criticism of a silly slogan he has chosen to give importance to a nonsensical creation.

FROM simple snapshots to color photography underwater, "Outdoor Adventures in Color Slides," a sixty-four-page 50-cent handbook just published by Eastman Kodak, runs the gamut of subject variety and range of light quality.
BALTIMORE, May 10 (AP) -Greentree Stable's Pop Corn upheld the United States against five foreign-bred horses today by staging a strong stretch run to win the $28,700 Dixie Handicap at Pimlico.

The Thomas Jefferson Memorial Foundation and the University of Virginia have announced an unusually important educational project. Beginning next year, with the support of the Foundation, fifteen graduate fellowships will be set up at the University primarily to carry on further studies about Jefferson and his period.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 10 (UP) -- The son of Generalissimo Rafael Trujillo, dictator of the Dominican Republic, bought expensive foreign cars for film stars Kim Novak and Zsa Zsa Gabor, a Mercedes-Benz dealer disclosed today.

WHILE the ticker tape is being prepared for Van Cliburn's homecoming, Americans should be reminded that the young Texan who won the International Tchaikovsky Contest in Russia is not the only American who has brought honor to his country by winning a big contest abroad.
WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP) -- Five teen-age musicians were picked today as quarter-finalists in the third annual Merri-weather Post contest sponsored by the National Symphony Orchestra.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 6 -A "spread the world" program has been authorized by members of the Sailors Union of the Pacific by a vote of more than two to one.

To the music of "Onward Christian Soldiers" and other hymns, some 2,000 adults and children of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York marched up Amsterdam Avenue yesterday. They entered the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine for a noon service on the theme "One Family in Christ."
HISTORIC is the word for the theatre week that has just passed into the record, or Memorable Monday, if it is necessary to be specific.

PRINCETON, N. J., May 10 -- Ten homes of historical or architectural interest are on the itinerary for next Saturday's Open House in Princeton tour. The event will be for the benefit of the scholarship funds of the Trenton-Princeton Mount Holyoke Club and the Radcliffe Club of this community.

Entry blanks are available at Park Department borough offices for the department's annual barber shop quartet contest. The finals will be held on the Mall in Central Park Tuesday night, June 24. Amateur male quartets are eligible.

Herbert Mitgang left out America's leading pogonotrophist, Burl Ives, whose beard gives him a chameleon quality. It exudes a primitive animal magnetism when he's being Big Daddy on the stage or handling a 40-foot sailboat singlehanded in a wild storm.

WASHINGTON, May 10 -- The Soviet Union has indicated a willingness to meet -- at least in part -- President Eisenhower's proposal to set up technical study groups on disarmament inspection, officials said tonight.

AN astonishing amount of Rossinian opera has been recorded. Not all of it has stayed recorded. Pot-boilers like "The Matrimonial Exchange" and "The Transposed Valises" have gone into the catalogue and out again.
PHILADELPHIA, May 10 (AP) -- La Salle College's varsity crew rallied on the last two strokes to win the Dad Vail Trophy for the third straight year on the Schuylkill.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, May 10 -- One hundred and twenty feet underground, far from the bustle of Stockholm, a visitor must wonder if this is what it all comes to -- if this is the future.

The Stockbridge School, Interlaken, Mass., will hold its annual workshop from June 29 to Aug. 24 with seminars and lectures, featuring leaders in the fields of labor, management, civil liberties and science. Among the seminar leaders will be Dr. Henry David, executive director, National Manpower Council, and Patrick Murphy Malin, executive director of the American Civil Liberties Union.
PHILADELPHIA, May 10 -- The Playhouse in the Park, Philadelphia's municipally operated theatre, will open its seventh summer season June 9 in new permanent quarters.

LANDSCAPE architects have to meet many challenges. Their clients, without exception, have three major requirements: low-cost installation, immediate effect and easy upkeep. Since this is technically impossible, both parties must settle for interesting low-cost gardens with a reasonable maintenance program.

CHICAGO, May 10 (UP) -- Nellie Fox and Ron Jackson batted in four runs today to pace the Chicago White Sox to a 5-4 victory over the Cleveland Indians. Dick Donovan posted his first mound victory of the season.

Manhattan's baseball team collected nineteen hits, includfive home runs, as the Jaspers crushed New York University, 14 -- 3, in a Metropolitan Collegiate Conference game yesterday at Ohio Field, the Bronx. The setback was N. Y. U.'s first in nine games this season.

New York's waterfront rehabilitation program, coupled with trade development, promotion and protection efforts by the Port of New York Authority, are proving effective instruments in securing the port's role as the country's premier foreign commerce gateway.

I am interested in getting information about the construction, operation, management, etc., of marinas and boat-yard businesses. Any advice would be greatly appreciated. Do you know of any articles or discussions on this subject? Please advise me.

Mrs. Joseph P. Nugent of Larchmont, mother of four, became tired of waiting at the swimming pool while her husband and children went sailing. That's why she enrolled when the Larchmont Yacht Club started a women's sailing class last year.
J. Edgar Hoover is quoted in The Times of May 2 as saying that television and moving pictures "applaud lawlessness."

PRINCETON, N. J., May 10 -- Yale remained the crew to beat in the East by winning the Carnegie Cup today in record-breaking time. Fighting off the strong challenge of Cornell in a finish that had the 5,000 spectators on the university shore cheering madly. Jim Rathschmidt's Eli varsity shot across the line the winner by half a length. Princeton, with its finest performance of the year, finished three-quarters of a length astern of Cornell.

Oh Johnny took the $59,000 Grey Lag Handicap at Jamaica yesterday with a powerful closing rush. The 5-year-old son of Johns Joy, running in the silks of Mrs. Wallace Gilroy, overtook Edward Seinfeld's Admiral Vee only a few feet from the wire in the mile-and-a-furlong event.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., May 10 (AP) -- With a line-up liberally sprinkled with ten pros or former pros, the OldTimers today defeated the Notre Dame varsity, 37 -- 36, in the annual game marking the spring football drills here.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, May 10 -- An official guidebook, "This Is America," will be on sale about June 1 to "close some of the gaps" in the United States' World's Fair exhibit.
Two steamship freight conferences have begun an unusual attempt to police rate-cutting practices by their members.

If all passengers were like C. James Proud, the airlines and railroads could stop worrying about deficits. Last year the president of the Advertising Federation of America traveled 50,000 miles; a comparable total is assured for this year.

Regarding the future plans of the New York Philharmonic, I agree with Howard Taubman that the clothes do not make the musician. This, however, is not the point in question. Judging from the latest promises of the management, the Thursday evening "Previews" will be just as formal as in the past, except for the unpredictability of what the conductors will say.
Elected officials studying the oil commuter crisis in the metropolitan area agreed last week the need for a review of rate and local taxes imposed the railroads.

The name of Tom Mboya, the dominant African leader in Kenyan politics today, figured rather prominently in Mrs. Huxley's article. Unfortunately there was an implication in the article that during the period when Mboya was at Ruskin College he was unduly influenced by Left-Wing elements.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, May 10 -- The official spokesman for the Indonesian Foreign Ministry said today that study was being given to the protest filed by resident Western correspondents in connection with the two-hour arrest yesterday of Bernard Kalb, correspondent of The New York Times.

ANKARA, Turkey, May 10 -- The Ankara Opposition party's newspaper Ulus resumed publication today after one month's suspension for press law violation. But it may be shut down again by a second court order that is now being appealed.

The extensive publicity given the release of poet Ezra Pound from St. Elizabeth's Federal hospital and the dismissal of his treason indictment has centered attention on an important civil liberties issue. That is the due-process rights of persons found mentally incompetent to stand trial and therefore confined to mental hospitals.
The annual five-day convention of the Medical Society of the State of New York will open tomorrow at the Statler Hotel.
THE newsboy in San Francisco was so proud that he blurted out the words without thinking as he hawked his papers after the first major league game ever played on the Pacific Coast.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 10 -- The United States Information Services' library in Tripoli was sacked and burned last night by armed men demonstrating against the Lebanese Government.

IN her first book, "I'll Cry Tomorrow" (composed with the help of two collaborators, Mike Connolly and Gerold Frank), Lillian Roth told of her tempestuous life as a stage and screen star -- and her struggle to break out of the fantasy world of the alcoholic who drank two quarts of whisky a day.

IT was Wednesday, May 10, 1933 -- twenty-five years ago yesterday. Midnight was approaching. Thousands of students and Nazi functionaries were assembled on the Opera Square in the heart of Berlin, just a short distance from the university which had been founded by Wilhelm von Humboldt, Germany's greatest liberal thinker.

The New York Clearing House will extend tomorrow the time in which its members may handle checks that have "bounced" or are "not good," as the bankers put it. This will be the first time since 1951 that the period for returning unpaid checks has been changed.

SARANAC LAKE, N. Y. -- One might think that chairlifts would be built along ski trails for the benefit of skiers. They are, but not for skiers alone. One might also think that chairlifts are paid for by skiers, but that, too, is only partly true.
GARDEN CITY, L. I., May 10 -- Teachers College of Connecticut, the ranking power in small-college track and field in these parts, handily retained the Collegiate Track Conference team title today.
IF all the actors and staff people of "The Firstborn" are at the top of their bent, give Anthony Quayle plenty of credit. He has imagined and molded the production.

WITH its new Model B, the ultraminiature 3 1/2-ounce Minox Automatic camera becomes the first in its field to fall in line with the current trend to automation. It has a built-in photoelectric exposure meter, which adds only five-eighths of an inch to the original length.

By implication, Elspeth Huxley seems to be arguing that the presence of white and Asian minorities in Kenya justifies the denial of full democracy for the six million Africans. Ironically, this argument is made in the name of democratic rights for the Asians and whites.

GREENPORT, L. I., May 10 -- This seaside village will be host from Friday through next Sunday to eastern Long Island's first North Fork Boat and Sportsmen's Show. The sponsor is the American Legion's Burton Potter Post No. 185.

Your article on May 4 concerning the River Queen houseboat has set us on a plan for the future. We would like very much to obtain more information from all angles. Are there other companies building such boats and where?

BOSTON, May 10 -- The Boston Globe will publish its last edition on Newspaper Row tomorrow. The Monday editions are scheduled to be published in a new $12,000,000 plant in the Dorchester district.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass, May 10 -- Led by Joel Landau and Pete Reider, Harvard's track team routed Yale today, 85 to 55. The Crimson swept three events to win the annual meet by the largest margin since 1939.

PASSAIC, N. J., May 10 -- The police appealed today to the public for aid in solving the slaying of a 28-year-old rookie patrolman. Robert D. Strone, father of two and a policeman for five months, was shot once in the back of the head around midnight Thursday as he patrolled a lonely beat in this city's east side.
PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, May 10 -- The Haitian Government indicated today that it might grant a safe conduct out of the country to former Senator Louis Dejoie, now a refugee in the Mexican Embassy.

THE "theory of games," to which brief allusion was made here last week, is acknowledged to be one of the most important developments of recent years -- but in mathematics, not in games. The theory applies mathematical logic to a choice of strategies where two or more are available, but the intended use of the theory was in economics and, secondarily, in military problems, games being used only as a simple vehicle for illustration.

IN the April number of John Lehmann's London Magazine there is a hint that its future is again doubt. This is uncomfortable news. We have hardly any literary reviews left as it is. Mr. Lehmann's review has been valuable for its European contacts.

QUERETARO, Mexico, May 7 -- The State of Queretaro, one of the smallest in the Mexican republic, is bumping along very near the rock bottom of its economy. This economy has been deteriorating steadily over the last sixteen years.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., May 10 -- Dr. Paul Dawson Eddy, president of Adelphi College, finished a tour of Long Island this week in search of a site for the college's proposed Suffolk County branch.

PARIS, May 10 -- In a speech yesterday Prime Minister Harold Macmillan referred to the task of "a world-wide slump" that, he said, would require world-wide action to offset it. Preparations must be made," he said.

STORIES, old and new, from places as far in time and distance as China and Disneyland, are related for children on a number of records. "Once upon the time" has yet to be surpassed as the opening words to capture a child's attention, and some of these stories on disks begin just this way.

FIVE of the newly opened one-man shows of paintings by American artists in the younger and middle-age brackets gratifyingly reveal growth. If they have little in common in themes and technical approaches, they nevertheless do possess in common vitally experimental approaches to the problems they have set themselves -- approaches which moreover justify themselves by confident handling of the techniques they have found suited to the statements of their personal visions.

WEST POINT, N. Y., (AP) -- Ron Delany scored a pair of victories then provided the crusher in the final event today as Villanova's Wildcats defeated Army, 82 -- 81, in a track meet at Shea Stadium. Syracuse finished third in the triangular meet with 10 points.

INSTEAD of waiting until each December before making public the ensuing year's stamp-issuing program, as has been the custom in the past, Postmaster General Arthur B. Summerfield is making early decisions during 1958 regarding his plans for 1959.

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., May 10 -- Stony Brook won the Ivy Prep School League track and field championships at the Hofstra College track today. The winning squad, capturing seven firsts on the fourteen-event program, scored 61 points.

DRAMATIC new effects can be achieved by growing plants in containers of sphagnum moss or peat. These soilless containers are ideal for limited planting areas, to cover posts and to create privacy by building plant walls.

Cornell's undefeated varsity lightweight crew took the Ivan Geiger Cup for the third straight year yesterday. The Big Red oarsmen turned in a polished performance in beating Massachusetts Institute of Technology and Columbia on the Harlem River.

Menzel, director of the Harvard College Observatory.

ATHENS, May 10 -- Greece will elect 300 Deputies tomorrow to represent fifty-two constituencies in the new Chamber. There are more than 5,000,000 eligible voters.
