WASHINGTON, May 10 -- The Administration sent Congress today a scaled-down atomic power program. It amounts to a new declaration of war on Democrats of the Joint Congressional Committee on Atomic Energy.

Twenty-five educators will discuss the humanities at a two-day conference beginning Friday at Columbia University. Means of discovering and encouraging potential humanistic scholars will be considered at the meetings sponsored by the American Council of Learned Societies.
AUSTIN, Tex., May 10 -- The first Latin American Senator to serve in Texas has pitched a clear-cut racial segregation-integration issue squarely into the race for Governor this year.
WASHINGTON, May 10 -- The House Armed Services Committee is moving toward a substantial compromise with the Administration on the Pentagon reorganization plan.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., May 10 -- President Eisenhower's directive this week that federalized troops be withdrawn from racially integrated Central High School at Little Rock, Ark., on May 29 came as Gov. Orval E. Faubus was urging the Arkansas electorate to endorse his dramatic use of executive powers last fall to thwart Federal court-ordered desegregation.

WITH his work thrice blessed by the Book-of-the-Month Club, Theodore White is undoubtedly favored by the gods. His first two entries, "Thunder Out of China" (written with Annalee Jacoby) and "Fire in the Ashes," were discussions in depth of the Chinese and European crises respectively.

ROME, May 10 (AP) -- Italy's Nicola Pietrangeli, the defending champion, and Luis Ayala of Chile reached the semi-finals of the Italian tennis championships today. They joined Mervyn Rose of Australia and Ramanathan Krishnan of India, who won their places yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 10 -- Don Taussig smashed a single through the hole into left field with two on and two out in the ninth inning today to enable the San Francisco Giants to post a 3-2 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers. Johnny Podres, a Dodger southpaw, suffered his first defeat of the season.
WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP) -- Thirty-one thousand school children joined today in a safety patrol parade along Constitution Avenue.

Since it is clearly established that demonstrations of ill-feeling against Vice President Nixon in South America are part of an organized Communist scheme it will be wise to keep the whole case in perspective. The Communists want to do us, and our American allies, what damage they can.
WARSAW, May 10 -- Nikita S. Khrushchev is believed here to be engaged in a bitter political struggle for survival as the Soviet Union's Premier and First Secretary of its Communist party.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., May 10 -- Dr. Karl Lehmann, professor at the Institute of Fine Arts, New York University, has been appointed William Allan Neilson Professor at Smith College for the first semester of the next academic year.

FOLLOWING the distinguished example set by Julius Caesar, this autobiographical account of combat in modern Gaul is written in the third person. The author, Col. Glover S. Johns Jr., is thus enabled to view himself with a certain detachment as Major Johns, commanding the first infantry outfit to fight its way into St. Lo after the Normandy landings.

MISSOULA, Mont. -- On Monday, Aug. 15, 1887, Alan Hardenbrook, a pharmacist living in Anaconda, Mont., set out from home with his wife, his 18-year-old daughter and two family friends for a summer holiday in Yellowstone Park.

LONDON, May 10 -- Prime Minister Harold Macmillan has turned his official country residence, Chequers, over to Colonial Secretary Alan Lennox-Boyd this week-end as headquarters for talks on two of Britain's pressing colonial problems.

May is "fitting-out month" for the pleasure boatman. It means work that can be fun. He rolls up his sleeves and gets aches, pains, callouses and tired muscles, transforming himself from office worker to master mariner, painter, varnisher, sander and what-all.

WITH a record-breaking number of motoring vacationists expected on the nation's highways this summer, rather special conditions, both good and bad, will confront them. On the good side, the big post-war rush of toll-road building is practically completed.
GROUNDCOVERS for the small garden must be attractive the year round. Also, they must not spread rampantly.
THANKS to the vision of one of its leading shipowners and the generosity of the French Government, Japan will soon come into possession of a great Western art collection.

Chief Judge Albert Conway of the New York State Court of AppeaLs called last night for a permanent bi-state association of lawyers to eliminate what he called the petty, provincial differences between the legal systems of New York and New Jersey.

WASHINGTON, May 10 -Thirty-four Senatorial seats and thirty-three governorships will be filled by the voters in this non-Presidential year. Some of the 1958 contests will inevitably be decided in the long shadow of 1960.

Department store sales in the nation in the week ended May 3 were 8 per cent below sales in the corresponding week of last year, the Federal Reserve Board has reported. A week earlier there was a rise of 4 per cent.
A tug of war between producers of cocoa and manufacturers who convert the beans into chocolate has been going on about four months.

ALMOST side by side at a World's Fair dedicated to international cooperation and the advancement of humanity stand symbols of an unabashed competition for the minds of men. They are the vast monolithic rectangular pavilion of the U. S. S. R. and the gay, gleaming circular pavilion of the U. S. A.

DETROIT, May 10 -- "During World War II there was no marketing problem. When it was over, we entered the cafeteria era of selling. People were ready and willing to line up. Today a prospect wants to be seated in the main dining room and make his own choice."
LOS ANGELES, May 10 -- Within a few weeks crews of workmen will travel far into the Nevada desert to drill a series of 500-foot-deep shafts into the sagebrush-dotted sand.
NEW DELHI, India, May 10 -- For the first time since India achieved independence ten years ago, Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru's Congress party was out of power today in two states of the union.

JAKARTA, May 10 -- "One down and one to go." Jakarta, perspiring capital of troubled Indonesia, echoed with the local equivalent of that phrase during the week. It was being used -with a kind of "let's get it all over with in a hurry" accent -by many Indonesians in referring to the Central Government's progress toward crushing the two-front rebellion from Central Sumatra and Northern Celebes.

The term Latin America covers the twenty republics south of the Rio Grande which embrace 8,000,000 square miles and about 170,000,000 people. Despite this large population and rich natural resources, most of the Latin-American republis are short of investment capitaI, electric power, transportation and technical personnel.

RAILINGS and columns of ornamental wrought or cast iron can improve the appearance of the inside and outside of the house. Ornamental iron work was once limited almost entirely to luxury homes because it had to be custom made.

WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP) -- The Senate Internal Security subcommittee said today that "the appearance of the Soviet sputnik in the sky in October more sharply highlighted the value of Soviet espionage than any recent happening."

DETROIT, May 10 -- Walter P. Reuther proposed today that economic issues in the current auto industry-union negotiations be submitted to binding arbitration. The proposal was quickly rejected by General Motors, biggest of the auto makers.

STROUDSBURG, Pa. -- Although one of the hotels here advertises with old world courtesy that it will "park your horse or car while dining," this is an isolated reminder of a bygone age. There is little that the Pocono vacationist of today would have in common with his predecessor of yesteryear.

WASHINGTON, May 10 -- Three women who have wrestled with the national nursing shortage since World War II warned today that another war would require a draft that would leave civilian hospitals almost without nurses.

BOOKS about the American Revolution are having a healthy, if modest, revival. No luncheon clubs have as yet been formed for discussions of battles, but a sizable shelf could be made up of publications since World War II.

LODI, N. J., May 10 -- New Jersey public school teachers who use the Carden method to teach reading organized a state-wide body here this week. The method, which uses a phonetic approach, is described as a language-arts program.

Cotton Blossom IV, the 71-foot yawl owned by Walter R. Wheeler Jr. of Stamford, is among the entries in the Larchmont Yacht Club"s race for the Edlu Trophy, says Tom L. Fitzsimmons, chairman of the race committee.

BATTLE CREEK, Mich., May 10 -- Civil Defense officials at national headquarters here emphaised today the need for a campaign to inform people how to protect themselves from fall-out in case of a nuclear attack.

The whole of the United States will wish to join today in a salute to Minnesota. This is the 100th anniversary of its admission as the thirty-second state of the Union. It is the eleventh state in size, the eighteenth in population. And it is -- Minnesota!

THAT rarest of literary rarities, an individualist who is neither freakish nor exhibitionistic, Bernard Malamud is completely himself, Malamud, and nobody else. He has published two memorable novels, "The Natural" and "The Assistant" and in the present volume a handful of magical short fiction including a remarkable story about a rabbinical student and a fish-eating Jewish marriage broker from which the present collection derives its title.

VIENNA, May 10 -- Wladyslaw Gomulka, head of the Polish delegation paying a three-day visit to Budapest, approved Soviet suppression of the Hungarian revolt of 1956 in a speech in Budapest today. The speech was broadcast by the Budapest radio.
BEEBE in his bathysphere never saw such fantastic creatures as will be clinging to this season's beach hats.

AS a creative artist myself, I object with every force at my command to the abortive assumption that the twelve-tone system and atonality "are the prevailing musical idioms of contemporary art music today," as Gilbert Chase would have your readers believe.

T. S. ELIOT is historian of "The Cocktail Party," so what was more natural than to give him one? They did. The time: The afternoon following his recent reading at Columbia University. The place: Home of his publisher, Roger W. Straus Jr.
CHICAGO, May 10 -- The National Association of Social Workers called today on all nations to halt immediately the production and testing of nuclear weapons.

GREAT NECK, L. I., May 10 -- The body of an 8-year-old boy who fell from a raft late yesterday and drowned in Bull Pond here was recovered early today. He was Douglas Nemeth, son of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Nemeth of 21 Arandale Avenue, Great Neck.
A wartime colleague has told President Eisenhower that "if he thinks he has troubles in Washington, he should wait till he really starts farming" on his place in Gettysburg, Pa.

MONTREAL -- The Laurentian resort region is engaged in one of the most extensive and expensive renovation and expansion programs in its history. The estimated cost is more than $2,000,000, and for the most part the work has been stimulated by progress on the new Laurentian Thruway, construction of which is ahead of schedule.

Fred J. Kirkman, formerly executive vice president and general manager of the Burgess Battery Company, has been elected president and a director of the company, Mr. Kirkman succeeds Dan W. Hirtle, who was elected to the new post of vice chairman of the board.

IN a very short time the vacationists will be on the move in every direction -- north, east, south and west. Already ships and planes are carrying record loads of tourists to Europe. Once school is out, the great migration will be on, at home as well as abroad.

LONDON. May 10 -- The remains of gigantic animals, including sheep as big as present-day cart-horses and hogs with tusks like elephants, have been dug out of an ancient gorge at Olduvai in East Africa.

A medical team from Washington University and the Jewish Hospital in St. Louis, led by Dr. Anthony B. Fletcher, reported last week at the annual meeting of the Association of American Physicians in Atlantic City on a purified protein substance which shows promise of being safe for use in human beings to dissolve blood clots.

TELEVISION'S ability to inform and enlighten was impressively demonstrated in last Tuesday evening's live pick-up of a heart operation on a 3-year-old girl at the University Hospital of the New York University-Bellevue Medical Center.
TO THOSE who insist that his career clamors for a title like "The Man Who Came Back," Edwin Justus Mayer observes patiently that he has never been away.

ONE of the more pressing deadlines in town is just three weeks away -- the Decoration Day weekend. By that time many heads of hair have been promised for delivery. More accurately, they're headless heads of hair, or, perhaps most accurately, headlesses of hair. They're wigs.

BOSTON, May 10 -- The Massachusetts Turnpike Authority reported today that turnpike :revenue in April was $810,000, ia gain of $148,584 over the previous month. William F. Callahart, chairman of the Massachusetts Turnpike Authority, said the total mileage use increased from 26.000,000 in Aiarch to 32,000,000 in April.

GREENPORT, L. I., May 10 -- Christopher Crawford, 15 years old, the adopted son of Joan Crawford, the actress, and three other youths, admitted yesterday they had shot out several street lights and school windows in Southold town with air rifles.
HAMILTON, N. Y., May 10 -A solo home run and a clutch double late in the game enabled Colgate to down Fordham's baseball team, 2 -- 1, today in the feature event of Parents' Week-End.
OTTAWA, May 10 -- Prime Minister John Diefenbaker's legislative program will be outlined in the Speech from the Throne by Governor General Vincent Massey at Monday's opening of the new Parliament.

A LANDOWNER on Assunpink Creek in Mercer County, N. J., recently asked a fisherman not to dig bait on his land adjoining the creek because it caused erosion in flood time. The fisherman replied that the state stocked the creek and he would therefore do as he pleased.

Certainly no one of goodwill the should have been opposed to the recent piece of Albany legislation that permitted a retired City College professor to cash checks that had remained uncashed for from fifteen to twenty years.

MIAMI BEACH -- The multi-million-dollar national promotion campaign launched in recent weeks by hotel and transportation interests here, stressing their belief that Miami Beach and its orbit of resort communities is a bargain-buy for a summer vacation, is proving a success. Reservations and inquiries are beginning to mount into record numbers.
GLEN HEAD, L. I., May 10 -- A 41-year-old father of two children is demonstrating here that a severe physical handicap need not deter a person who wants a college education.

BAGHDAD, Iraq, May 10 (AP) -- Sheik Abdullah as-Salim al-Sabah, Ruler of Kuwait and its rich oil resources, arrived here today for a state visit. Some think he may hold tasks on federating with the new Iraq-Jordan Arab Union.
Gas turbine propulsion has proved completely satisfactory during the nineteen months of operation of the Liberty ship John Sergeant, it was reported last week.
WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP) -- The Air Force showed off its 1,300-mile-an-hour B-58 jet bomber today in an Armed Forces Day preview in which the services demonstrated their "power for peace."

WASHINGTON, May 10 (UP) -- Senator Clifford P. Case asked today that the Federal Bureau of Investigation investigate recent bombings and bomb-scares in the South. He said they seemed to be part of a "campaign of terror" against civil rights advocates.

MASTIC, L. I., May 10 -- Erosion has carried Fire Island Inlet six miles westward in the last 264 years, and much of Great South Bay once was fresh water, according to papers discovered here in the Museum at the Manor of St. George at Smith's Point.
OXFORD, England, May 5 -- The face of Oxford University is undergoing its most extensive recasting in three hundred years.

ANCHORAGE -- Last fall, Alaska road construction crews pushed through a wilderness highway which opens up to America's motorist for the first time an area of natural magnificence larger than Switzerland.
BELTSVILLE, Md., May 2 -- New research is under way here to fathom the secrets of bossy.

WASHINGTON, May 10 -- If Lewis L. Strauss is determined to retire from public life, his swan song will come as a fitting climax to five far from placid years as chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission.

I WAS distressed by Dr. Joost A. M. Meerloo's implication in his review of two books by C. G. Jung ("Psychology and Religion" and "The Undiscovered Self") that Freud is more "scientific" than Jung. Dr. Meerloo says, Jung "built up an audacious system of concepts often incapable of being verified empirically.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 10 -- Many creative persons -- painters, writers, musicians and scientists -- feel like impostors and long to be like "ordinary" mortals.

ST. LOUIS, May 10 (AP) -- The American Legion's support of President Eisenhower's Pentagon reorganization plan was pledged today by the organization's national commander. But he said more men and arms were needed to insure the nation's security.

THE hotel night-club entertainers throughout the Catskill resort section in and around Sullivan County will have to compete with horses for audiences and laughs this summer when the new $5,000,000 harness-racing track at Monticello, N. Y., starts operating.

UPTON, N. Y., May 10 -- Again as in 1955, amid widespread discussion of a political summit meeting, plans are now quietly going ahead for another meeting at the scientific summit, much larger than the heads-of-government meeting and possibly of greater ultimate significance.
TRENTON, May 10 -- The State Tax Policy Commission called upon the New Jersey Senate today to delay for at least a month any action on the state budget and new taxes.
ACCRA, Ghana, April 30 -- The public letter writer, that artery of commerce, romance, law and politics throughout the Middle East, Asia and Africa, has mechanized his profession here.
HOT SPRINGS, Ark., May 10 -- Julius Boros of Mid-Pines, ,. C., clipped par by eight strokes today as he carded a 64 for 134 and took a two-stroke lead in the $20,000 Hot Springs open golf tournament.
WASHINGTON, May 10 -- President Eisenhower's speech this week to the Republican members of Congress depressed and disappointed many, possibly a majority, in his audience.
HARTFORD, May 10 -- Political controversy broke out this week between supporters of Chester Bowles and Thomas J. Dodd for the Democratic nomination for United States Senator.

A "cherry heering" colored hull under a cherry petal green superstructure surmounted by a royal blue funnel bearing the letter "H" introduced a splash of color to shipping on the Great Lakes and along the St. Lawrence Seaway last week.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, May 10 -- The Indonesian Army has handed down a number of regulations that have touched off speculation here as to whether they are aimed at checking the freedom of action heretofore enjoyed by the Communist party in some fields.

Six months from now the voters will elect the Eighty-sixth Congress. At stake will be thirty-four Senate seats and all 435 seats in the House. And just over the political horizon from that election are the Presidential and Congressional contests of 1960.

IN his admirable and sympathetic review of my book on Mendes-France and North Africa ("Lost Statesman"), D. W. Brogan quite rightly queries one figure when he says: "I don't believe that any gros colon [in Algeria] has an income of nearly 60 million dollars a year.
The 8,000 graduates from the five municipal colleges will find job hunting this June a little more difficult than their recent predecessors, an official survey predicted last week.
Two New York rabbis -- both in the Reform branch of Judaism -- voiced vigorous dissent yesterday against any proposal that their faith engage in missionary activities.
The clouds that have been hovering over the airplane manufacturing industry appear to be lifting.

The North Atlantic Treaty Organization is the bone and sinew of the Western alliance. The pact, which pledges the fifteen NATO powers to regard an attack on one as an attack on all, represents both the West's defensive shield against Soviet aggression and the political base for its diplomatic and propaganda duels with Moscow.

Cruisers as short as twenty-four feet and as slow as six knots are eligible for the New York Athletic Club's forty-fifth annual predicted log contest to Block Island on July 12. Edward J. Dennis, chairman of the contest committee, is accepting entries at his home, 60 Sutton Place South, New York 22.

THE patriotic song "America the Beautiful" provides the theme for the twelfth annual Flower Show of the Gramercy Park Association. The show will be open from 2 to 10 P. M. on Wednesday and from 10 A. M. to 10 P. M. on Thursday at the National Arts Club, 15 Gramercy Park South.

A glimpse at the problems confronting European secondary education was provided by the recent two-week conference at Sevres, France, in which twenty-six countries, including the Soviet Union, discussed what one delegate called the current "revolution" in education.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 10 -- Details now available indicate to the Food and Agriculture Organization that the European common market will benefit outside countries exporting the main agricultural materials.

Congratulations are due to King Mohamed V of Morocco on the first steps he has taken to abandon his theoretically and legally medieval absolutism and to convert his country into a twentieth-century democracy within the framework of a constitutional monarchy.

THE Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts is a fascinating complex of problems and prospects. One could spend hours contemplating the magnitude of the money-raising challenge, the scope of the architectural possibilities, the meaning to urban renewal, the impact on the dislocated people and the opportunities for fresh artistic policies.

There has been an increase of 160,000 in the labor force of the Philadelphia metropolitan area since 1950. In making this report, Leonard A. Drake, economist of the Chamber of Commerce of Greater Philadelphia, said employment in the area rose from 1,513,600 to a peak of 1,690,100 in 1957.

PHOTOGRAPHS by Dr.Erich Salomon, a founder of the candid camera movement and one of the first to use a miniature camera in what has since become the standard photojournalistic technique, are on display through Friday in the Reception Center on the lobby floor of the Time and Life Building, 9 Rockefeller Plaza.
A former assistant United States attorney said yesterday that the Powell grand jury had become "incensed" when he told it how he had been taken off the case.
CLEVELAND, May 10 (AP) -The Great Lakes shipping season is off to one of its slowest starts.
WASHINGTON, May 10 -- A "permanent policy" against construction of interstate roads that would compete with existing toll roads has been set by Bertram D. Tallamy, Federal Highway Administrator.

THE Parisian novelist, because his city has been dragnetted by his many predecessors, finds his search for new characters almost inevitably extended to unusual persons who might escape portraiture in a less literary place.
LOS ANGELES, May 10 (AP) -- Eight thousand Lockheed aircraft workers overrode the recommendation of their national union leadership today and approved a contract offered by the company.
The first year in a three-year experiment in offering college courses for credit over open-circuit television has been completed with notable results by the Chicago City Junior College.

GALESBURG, Ill., May 10 (AP) -- Many historical Illinois documents, including some papers signed by Abraham Lincoln, were lost last night in a fire that destroyed the Galesburg Public Library and its 122,000 volumes.
The current controversy on nuclear weapons makes interesting reading. The general panic among many of my countrymen (if they are in fact Englishmen) should be disregarded.
WASHINGTON, May 10 -- Last year thirty American manufacturers turned out an estimated total of 5,000 electric cars, compared with 3,500 in 1956, the National Geographic Society reported.

An institution is the lengthened shadow of a man, Emerson once observed. The Theatre Guild, the hardiest producing institution on Broadway, is the lengthened shadow of a man and a woman: Lawrence Langner and Theresa Helburn.

I noticed in The Sunday Times on May 4 that you suggest several places where small power craft may be rented. Can you suggest any places where I might rent a small sailing craft from time to time? Military service has interrupted my hobby of small boat sailing and has also transplanted me here from my West Coast home.

"THE best part about the week of rain," said Charles Dillon Stengel, "is that all my ballplayers are mad. They've been home helpin' the wife take care of the kids, and they're not uster it. Anything is better than that, includin' work. So I got me plenty of fellers which want to play ball."

FOR a man who started his career as a Ph. D. candidate at Oxford, and capped it twenty-eight years later with a Doctorate of Humane Letters from Dartmouth, Theodore S. Geisel has one of the smallest professional vocabularies -- and certainly one of the strangest -- ever to find its way into print.

"THAT parable of the boy down the well," a reader has commented, referring to the column of April 13 ("How Much Should a Child Achieve?"), "did a good job of pointing up some of the philosophical confusions plaguing educators today.

THE HIDDEN PERSUADERS" was a protest against the growing interest professional persuaders are taking in techniques which promise to manipulate the public. Increasingly, they are eschewing rational appeals to us in favor of appeals carefully baited to trigger desired responses at the subconscious level.

WESTBURY, L. I., May 10 -- Jean Laird, the oldest horse in the field five free-for-all trotters, swung clear of a pocket in the final sixteenth and stormed home first in the feature mile race at Roosevelt Raceway tonight. The time, 2:03 3/5, was the fastest clocking for a trot here this season.

LAS VEGAS, Nev. -- Along with being the nation's principal gambling center, this also is probably the only place in the country where the aroma of steaks broiling in midafternoon is now a community fixture.

FRENCH film-makers, apparently on the alert for unusual subject matter, are planning to produce a movie version of "Les Dialogues des Carmelites" ("Dialogues of the Carmelites"), it was learned last week.
New construction of marinas for pleasure boats is dotting harbors and coves in various areas.
Five new films will arrive in local theatres this week. The programs follow:
Cotton prices strengthened materially last week. By Friday's close active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net gains ranging from 16 to 43 points (80 cents to $2.15) a bale.

I doubt if I am the only New Yorker whose choler began to rise at reading in your Letters column the remarks of Elizabeth R. Craft, who characterizes New York cab drivers as "the laziest, least accommodating and most independent group of any in the United States."
CHICAGO, May 11 -- A State Department official told social workers here today that Uncle Sam needed them now.
WASHINGTON, May 11 -Army researchers are proposing the development of a miniature atomic weapon to be carried into combat by an infantryman.
" WIDE WIDE WORLD" reduced its scope yesterday to concentrate its cameras for ninety minutes on New York's Fifth Avenue. It was a realistic and rewarding study of the celebrated thoroughfare.

A visiting fireman discovered a Harlem tenement blaze early yesterday and helped the local firemen fight it. He, six policemen and three of the building's tenants were treated for smoke poisoning or slight burns.

Randolph Phillips, independent candidate for election as a director of the Pennsylvania Railroad, announced over the week-end that he had filed an amendment to a suit in United States District Court in Philadelphia naming Credit Suisse and the Swiss Bank Corporation as additional defendants.

MOSCOW, May 11 -- There were a few empty seats out front as Leonard Warren made his debut in the Soviet Union here tonight -- but it is expected they will need militiamen to hold off the crowds on the rest of his tour.

HEWLETT HARBOR, L. I., May 11 -- Billy Edwards of Cherry Valley, who had not won a tournament since 1950, captured the William D. Richardson Memorial golf honors at the Seawane Harbor course today. Edwards scored in the longest final of the eleven-year-old competition when he defeated John Humm of Rockville at the twenty-first green.

It took Cookie Lavagetto's Senators exactly three games to recapture the novel idea that if anyone, for the present, at least, is to bring some semblance of competition to the American League pennant race, they are the club to do it.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 11 -- Spike Jones and his orchestra lead the contenders for the job of replacing the "Club Oasis" variety show during the summer months. "Club oasis" will return to the National Broadcasting Company Television network next fall.
The receiver for the National Theatre, which has been vacant since the closing of "Winesburg, Ohio" on Feb. 15, has received Supreme Court permission to book a play there for an Oct. 22 opening.
Preaching about juvenile crime too often produces wrong results and "overlooks a basic American premise that youth is America's hope," the Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman said yesterday.

LOS ANGELES, May 11 -- Final prayers for Red Skelton's son will be offered in the Forest Lawn Church of the Recessional Tuesday. The comedian's youngster, Richard Freeman Skelton Jr., died of leukemia last night at the University of California at Los Angeles Medical Center. He was not quite 10 years old.

It is important to work with "the 99 per cent" of children who are not delinquent as well as with the 1 per cent who are, Morgan Dix Wheelock said yesterday. He is president of the Children's Aid Society.

ROME, May 11 (AP) -- Maria Esther Bueno, 18-year-old Brazilian tennis star, today upset Shirley Bloomer, Britain's No. 1 woman player, 1 -- 6, 9 -- 7, 8 -- 6, in the semi-finals of the Italian tennis championships.
THE Hudson River steamboat Mary Powell was to small fry between Rondout (Kingston) and New York City what the massive sternwheelers of the Mississippi were to Huck Finn and Tom Sawyer.

CHICAGO, May 11 -- Former Senator Herbert H. Lehman suggested here tonight that the United States and other powers challenge the Soviet Union to join in sponsoring a pilot disarmament program in the Middle East.
Two men were linked by the police yesterday to a burglary ring believed to have committed more than 100 thefts in Westchester and Nassau Counties and the Riverdale section of the Bronx.
The New York State central school district composed of Massina, Louisville, Norfolk and Brasher, has designated May 21 for the sale of $4,762,00 of bonds due from 1959 to 1987.

CHELAN, Wash., May 11 (AP) -- A home-town boy in a hydroplane fresh from the boat works -- Norm Evans driving Miss Bardahl -- won the second annual Apple Cup speed boat race today on wind-ruffled Lake Chelan.
The 16-year-old daughter of Iran's permanent representative to the United Nations was cut on the hand with a knife and her dress was ripped as she was attacked by two teen-age girls in Bronx Park.
" The Voice of Firestone" concert series has been renewed for the 1958-59 season. Not many thirty-year-old programs can make that statement.
Two alert radio-car patrolmen trailed a man carrying a cloth-wrapped bundle in the deserted financial district early yesterday morning.

Wisconsin Power and Light Company is offering to its common stockholders rights to subscribe to 241,211 shares of common stock and is offering its preferred shareholders rights to subscribe to 30,000 new preferred shares.
Chaminade of Mineola and St. Helena's of the Bronx broke meet records yesterday in the eighth annual Fordham Prep Relay Carnival at Van Cortlandt Park Stadium in the Bronx.
TYLER, Tex., May 11 (AP) -A suit in Federal court to restrain R. G. LeTourneau from returning to the manufacture of certain types of earth-moving machinery is on file here.
MOUNT VERNON, Ohio, May 11 -- Richard Doyen and Clay Gibbs of Milwaukee, engineers with the A. C. Spark Plug Company, today were declared the over-all winners of the Ohio 24 Sports car rally.

PALM SPRINGS, Calif., May 11 (AP) -- Miss Marcia Moore of Hollywood, a buyer for the dress concern of Lanz of California, was killed Friday in a collision between her station wagon and a light truck near here. She was 33 years old.
The Chiropractic Association of New York yesterday ended its annual convention at the Towers Hotel in Brooklyn by re-electing Dr. Vincent P. O'Neill of Merrick, L. I., to a second term as president.

Can business or domestic worries affect your speech? Make you hoarse or even unable to talk. Many who go to the National Hospital for Speech Disorders, on Irving Place, find that they are in need of psychiatry to relieve them of hoarseness or even ulceration.

Jose Ortega y Gasset, the Spanish philosopher, believes that the modern age, which he views as beginning with Galileo, is on its way out. He also believes that looming changes of great historic importance are the cause of chaos in this age.
The letter from Prof. Henry C. Wallich published May 6 I believe deserves comment, particularly when the United States is called to help Latin America solve its tremendous economic problems.
Fifty thousand square feet of space formerly occupied by the Bell Telephone Laboratories at 180 Varick Street has been leased by Samson Rosenblatt to three companies.
Trans World Airlines has hired a Hunter College Negro as a flight stewardess.
A child's delinquency can be traced in part to parents who take their responsibilities too lightly.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., May 11 Howard McMichael sailed Kangaroo to victory in the third International Class spring series race at Larchmont Yacht Club today. The five-race Stanley Trophy series concludes with two events next week-end.

The American Civil Liberties Union yesterday attacked sections of the Educational Development Act of 1958 and the National Defense Education Act of 1958. The union's stand, made known in a message from Patrick Murphy Malin, executive director, was based on a fear that the bills would threaten the Constitutional separation of church and state.

The spring meeting at Belmont Park will start today, with the $25,000 added Withers Stakes occupying the feature spot. A crowd of 25,000 is expected. The eight-race program will show more than 100 horses in competition.

PEIPING, May 11 (Reuters) The Chinese man in the street is being kept occupied by the general election campaign during the few hours he can spare each week from the activities required by the Communist state.
Reports from physicists working with data from accelerators add much to the volume of current scientific publications.

TEN days ago a young friend of mine who had been living in Paris for some time returned to this country and submitted an informal report on the present state of the French novel. It is flourishing, he says, with many talented writers receiving critical plaudits and literary prizes. Their books sell well, too, even if they aren't about the deplorable behavior of morose adolescents.
Strict enforcement of the law is necessary in the fight against juvenile delinquency, District Attorney Edward S. Silver of Brooklyn declared yesterday.

For some time now there have been increasing reports of an intensified power struggle in the Kremlin in which Premier Khrushchev's political head may be at stake. A struggle for power, in which the strongest man with the nimblest mind and the quickest trigger finger wins, is inevitable in a dictatorship, ruling not by consent of the governed but by force and fraud.
A tourist-class passenger had a first-class take-off for Europe early yesterday because of his girth.
LONDON, May 11 -- The labor situation was the chief influence in stock markets here last week. It also was reflected in quotations on the pound sterling.
A recent count puts at about thirty the number of "elementary particles" known to physicists from studies of cosmic rays and accelerator experiments.

EASTCHESTER, N, Y., May 11 -- Members and friends of the Skidmore College Alumnae Club of Westchester will attend the scholarship benefit breakfast and fashion show entitled "Summer in Westchester" at Lord and Taylor's here on Friday.
LONDON, May 11 -- Prime Minister Harold Macmillan held an unexpected "working" dinner party tonight to discuss the rail crisis with his top aides.
AFTER a decade or more in which furniture designers have imposed their style innovations on consumers, the tables have turned.
MADISON, Wis., May 11 -- Dr. Keith Randolph, Symon, whose dream is to build the world's largest atom smasher, is a "sound" man.

PROF. FLOYD ZULLI JR. of New York University, who persuaded television viewers to try English literature with breakfast coffee, became a matinee attraction yesterday over Channel 2. At tea time he was a bit off the pace.
WASHINGTON, May 11 -President Eisenhower is comparing the present Pentagon setup to a business organization doomed to failure against tough competition.
Martial music will ring in the metropolitan air during Armed Forces Week.
CHICAGO, May 11 (AP) -- All the May grain future contracts worked higher last week while almost all others eased off on the Board of Trade.

BOGOTA, Colombia, May 11 -- Communists were outnumbered and outsnouted by pro-United States crowds here today. It all added up to the best and warmest reception Vice President Richard M. Nixon has had on his South American trip.
Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr. avoided public contact yesterday.

Lillian Williams' letter recommending a "living monument to all victims of totalitarian torture" rather than a specific edifice commemorating the death of six million Jews under Hitler strikes me as being typical of the materialistic and impersonal attitudes so prevalent today.

MELBOURNE, Australia, May 11 -- A group of United States contractors finished construction work today on Adaminaby Dam, part of the huge Snowy Mountains irrigation and hydroelectric project, two years ahead of schedule.

CHICAGO, May 11 (AP) -- Jim Wilson, a 36-year-old righthander, pitched the Chicago White Sox to a 5-2 triumph over Cleveland in the second game of a double-header today. The Indians won the first game, 4 -- 2, on a two-run single by Carroll Hardy.

The Crane Company of Chicago, which expected a proxy fight from several quarters earlier this year but conducted its annual meeting last month without one, may still be in for trouble. It has been learned that at least five individual financiers or investment groups have acquired large holdings of Crane stock within recent months.

The Very Rev. James A. Pike celebrated his last holy communion and preached his final sermon as Dean of the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine yesterday. About 2,000 persons attended the service.
PARIS, May 11 -- The guaranteed minimum wage will be increased 3.2 per cent on June 1. It will be the fourth rise in ten months and a further indication of the inflationary spiral.
AGUA CALIENTE. Mexico, May 11 (UP) -- Round Table today became the third horse in history to win a million dollars when he took the $50,000 Caliente Handicap by more than nine lengths.
THE good neighbor policy begins at home. Mrs. Herbert Spires of Stamford, Conn., seems well aware of this axiom. In a recent letter to this department she requests some "sound" advice:
ROME, May 11 (AP) -- Pope Pius XII chatted with Bishop Fulton J. Sheen of New York after a general audience today in St. Peter's Basilica.
PALERMO, Sicily, May 11 (AP) -- Luigi Musso of Italy and Oliver Gendebien of Belgium drove a Ferrari 3,000 to victory today in the 1,008-kilometer (605-mile) Targa Florio road race.
WASHINGTON, May 11 -- A major doctrinal dispute over the kind of war the United States may face continues to trouble officials at the Pentagon.
THE debut piano recital of Julia Rajauskas yesterday afternoon in Town Hall was full of surprises.
The president of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York announced yesterday the appointment of a special committee to make a study of Federal conflict-of-interest laws.
PELHAM MANOR, N. Y., May 11 -- After trying for more than thirty years to win a national trapshooting title, AI Streelman, a 58-year-old Paterson auto dealer, today succeeded.
WASHINGTON, May 11 -Soviet purchases of chemical equipment in the United States, Britain and West Germany could possibly amount to $100,000,000, officials here said today.
The Citizens Union urged yesterday acceptance of Consolidated Edison's offer to buy the Transit Authority's power houses -- provided the authority shares in the proceeds.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 11 --Tripoli, Lebanon's second largest city, was reported still under a state of siege tonight with occasional rifle shots echoing through the almost deserted streets.
WASHINGTON, May 11 -- At least one Cabinet officer is distressed about the mischiefmaking potential of a matchbook cover being used at the White House.

Bayard Allis has been elected assistant secretary and assistant treasurer of the Barium Steel Corporation. Mr. Allis formerly was with James Thomas Chirurg Company, advertising agency, which has handled the Barium Steel account for many years.

During 1957 a total of 12,936 merchant ships arrived in New York. The sailors who brought the coffee, oil, sugar and newsprint for the industries and homes of the nation also brought themselves. Some came ashore to stretch, some had to catch a train home, others had to "live a little."
ATHENS, Monday, May 12 -Former Premier Constantine Karamanlis' National Radical Union was running well ahead of the other parties early today in returns from yesterday's Greek general elections.

College graduates who now are getting gray on top are smiling just a little wryly at the plight of the 1958 college senior. Many of this year's students are diligently looking for jobs instead of waiting on campus for jobs to come to them -- as jobs have come to so many undergraduates during the past few years.

WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP) -Senator George D. Aiken, Republican of Vermont, said tonight that if the Soviet Union shut off its economic aid to Yugoslavia "the United States should do its best to help fill the gap."
Senator Jacob K. Javits disclosed yesterday that he had been giving Nelson A. Rockefeller political advice but was not "pushing" him for the Governorship.

LOS ANGELES, May 11 (AP) -- The threat of a crippling strike in the aircraft industry of Southern California appeared over tonight as Convair and North American both reached contract agreements with the unions involved.

Enkells-Rakoff : Co., realty operator, has contracted to buy the one-story taxpayer containing seven stores at 41 to 55 East 167th Street, corner of River Avenue, the Bronx. The property, occupying a plot' 105 by 90 feet, is being acquired from the Q. W.
Aly Kahn, Pakistan's delegate to the United Nations, said last week, "I see no reason why cricket should not become popular in this country." He went on to say it could be a substitute for baseball.

In his letter published on April 29, A. Grasing Jr. takes it upon himself to choose "'absorbing strontium and other poisons' from the H-bomb," as opposed to "absorbing communism." Even assuming the validity of his alternatives -- which I believe most thinking persons will reject -- I wonder how the 5,000,000 genetically defective children predicted by Dr. Linus Pauling (The Times, same date) may feel about the choice Mr. Grasing has made for them?

A JOINT performance at Carnegie Recital Hall was given last night by Benjamin Oren, pianist, and Leslie Chabay, tenor. Mr. Oren offered three Beethoven sonatas and Schubert's song cycle, "Die Schoene Muellerin," was sung by Mr. Chabay to Mr. Oren's accompaniment.

STATEMENTS by admirals, Senators, university presidents and atomic scientists stressing the importance of better educational opportunities for intellectually gifted children have had their effect on school administrators and parents.

JACK COFFEY always has seemed as much a part of the Fordham landscape as the university's gymnasium. As a matter of fact, he's been on the campus longer. But the white-thatched athletic executive has reached the retirement age, and his friends cannot permit him to go without a formal farewell.
A Brooklyn boy who had been hit by an automobile yesterday afternoon, treated at a hospital and sent home, died last night.
PARIS, May 11 -- Pierre Pflimlin was navigating tonight around dangerous political reefs that had led to the downfall of the preceding Premier-designate in France's current Government crisis.
LONDON, May 11 (Reuters) -- Following is the text of Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev's note to President Eisenhower on technical details for controlling nuclear tests, as distributed in English by Tass:
Southwestern France may hold a solution to French energy and dollar deficits.

CARACAS, Venezuela, May 11 -- Vice President Nixon should be greeted with "serenity" and not with violent demonstrations on his arrival here Tuesday, Venezuelan newspapers said today. Almost all papers published articles asking for "dignity" and "maturity."

Union Theological Seminary at Broadway and 120th Street, the world's largest interdenominational training school for Protestant ministers and specialists in religious education, has embarked on a $16,000,000 long-range development program.

Employment in the New Yorknortheastern New Jersey metropolitan area increased by 6,100 persons in March, mainly as a result of seasonal increases in construction, retail trade and the service industries. This was announced yesterday by Robert R. Behlow, regional director of the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP) -- Admiral Arthur W. Radford sought to assure naval officers today that President Eisenhower's reorganization plan would not mean the end of naval aviation or of the Marine Corps.

PITTSBURGH, May 11 (AP) -Bob Porterfield, a castoff American Leaguer, pitched the Pittsburgh Pirates into a secondplace tie in the National League race today with a 1-0 eleveninning shutout over the Philadelphia Phillies. The Pirates won the first game of the doubleheader, 10 -- 4.
WARSAW, May 11 -- This may well be a week of fateful decision for Poland's Communist leaders.
Sanitation Commissioner Paul R. Screvane complimented about 1,000 members of his department's Holy Name Society yesterday on their "great job" of snow removal last winter.
A slight slip last week in coal cargo rates halted the upward tendency that had marked the field for the previous three weeks.
An American concern that makes tufted carpet has extended its international licensing arrangements to France.

The Right Rev. James P. DeWolfe, Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of Long Island, preached and presided at the 11 A. M. service yesterday at Grace Church in Brooklyn Heights. It marked the twentyfifth anniversary of the Rev. David T. Atwater as rector.
ATLANTIC CITY, May 11 -A leader in the merged labor federation predicted today that the expelled International Brotherhood of Teamsters would oust James R. Hoffa and return to the federation.

UNITED NATIONS. N. Y., May 11 -- The world's industrial output rose to a record in 1957, despite decreased activity in the United States and Canada, according to United Nations statistics published today.

PITTSBURGH, May 11 -- Steel orders were up slightly last week, as was the ingot production rate. It is believed here that this mild upturn will continue through June. But no one in the industry looks for substantial improvement in the near future.
Five high school students expressed doubts yesterday about the ability of ordinary people to promote peace over the heads of governments.

HOT SPRINGS, Ark., May 11 (AP) -- Julius Boros, a former National Open champion, sank a ten-foot birdie putt on the eighteenth hole today to take first money in the $20,000 Hot Springs Open golf tournament.
NOT everyone agrees with the recent ruling of the International Air Transport Association that a sandwich must be nothing more than two slices of dry bread with a filling between.
Major personnel shifts in advertising, which have stolen the thunder from account moves in recent weeks, appear to be continuing.

Supreme Court Justice William O. Douglas said last night that the country had tended to become insensitive to inroads against basic liberties. He said there was a demand for conformity to general patterns of thought.
It will be Frank Harper on the mound and Charlie Shons behind the plate next Saturday, forming the oldest battery in Lawrenceville School's baseball history.

OTTAWA, May 11 -- Most of the Canadian Pacific Railway's 3,000 firemen went on strike today in a last-ditch effort to hold onto their jobs, which have been declared useless. They failed to halt the operations of the 17,000-mile transcontinental railway.

Memorable scenes of the Theatre Guild's forty years in Broadway's hurly-burly were recalled at the organization's "Memory Book" celebration last night in the Plaza Hotel. A dinner and show marked the nostalgic anniversary.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -The Federal Government has run out of funds for its successful program in the new openheart surgery. The technique swiftly restores children born with holes between heart chambers.

Armed Forces Week, with its appropriate theme "Power for Peace," is with us again and it is a pleasure to join in its celebration. It is being observed here in New York and all over the country as well as at the many outposts of that "Power for Peace" throughout the world.

The United States Senate Judiciary Committee is indulging in a new low in legislative senselessness and in disrespect for the courts. Its current tactic is to ask nominees for Federal judicial appointment to state, under oath, that they will not participate in any decision that would "alter the meaning of the Constitution."
PETERSBURG, Va., May 11 -- Rebel forces have won a victory in a two-day battle near here.
WASHINGTON, May 11 -The White House said tonight that the latest Soviet note to President Eisenhower "might serve as the basis for progress toward agreement on disarmament."

ZURICH, Switzerland, May 11 -- Up until last Wednesday the demand for Interhandel common stock was very brisk. Volumes were heavy and every share offered was snapped up. Much of the buying was speculative.

MILWAUKEE, May 11 (AP) -Del Crandall's three-run double in the eighth inning enabled the Milwaukee Braves to post a 7-6 victory over the Cincinnati Redlegs today and ran the world champions' winning streak to seven games.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 11 -- The Kremlin has sent a new ultimatum to President Tito of Yugoslavia, East European diplomats reported tonight.
MOSCOW, May 11 -- Nikita S. Khrushchev, smiling and confident, opened the season at Moscow's agricultural exhibition today with a call for more food production.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, May 11 -- The Soviet Army has been showing its smiling face to Belgians and visitors to the Brussels World's Fair. Through its Red Army Chorus and Dance Ensemble it has been filling the Palais des Sports for a week now with patriotism, nostalgia and a rip-roaring show.
A written agreement seeking to avoid duplication between municipal and voluntary agencies on youth problems was announced yesterday.

KUWAIT, May 11 (AP) -- A Japanese oil company, agreeing to pay 57 per cent of the profits, got rights from Kuwait today to take oil from an offshore area in a neutral zone between Kuwait and Saudi Arabia.

GOLDENS BRIDGE, N. Y., May 11 -- Triple Cross, 3-yearold orange and white pointer who won yesterday's open gun dog stake, captured the amateur shooting dog event today as the annual program of the Southern New York Field Trial Club closed.
WASHINGTON, May 11 -Congress opens a week of far-reaching consequence for America's foreign policy tomorrow.
The United States is developing a method for detecting missile firings and nuclear tests halfway around the world.

MINNEAPOLIS, May 11 -Secretary of State Dulles declared today that the United States and the free world would not "sit idly by to be more and more closely encircled by a hostile despotism which seeks to strangle us."
AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, May 11 -- Interest rates are falling both in the capital and in the money markets.

THIRTY years ago two American composers, one aged 32 and the other 28, joined forces to present a series of concerts designed to give hearings to other young Americans. These composers, Roger Sessions and Aaron Copland, were reunited last night in a program honoring the anniversary of their now famous series.
Mayor Wagner has directed Corporation Counsel Peter C. Brown to draft a local bill to transform the scandal-tainted Bureau of Real Estate into a city department.

The Federal Maritime Board has been asked by the Gulf and South American Steamship Company to provide construction subsidy aid for the replacement of the company's fleet. The line already holds a Government operating subsidy contract for Trade Route 31, which runs between Gulf of Mexico ports and the west coast of South America.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 11 -- Universal-International now is actively competing with other big studios to attract independent movie-makers into its fold. As a first step, the company has worked out a financing and distribution agreement with Kirk Douglas' Bryna Productions for the filming of "Viva Gringo."

In drab university workrooms, from the Atlantic to the Pacific and around the world, the lights burn late at night over blackboards covered with symbols in chalk. The symbols represent man's latest efforts to understand the nature of the universe.
IN addition to being the widow of a famous French painter, Maurice Utrillo, and an artist in her own right, Mme. Lucie Valore Utrillo proclaims: "J'etais nee decoratrice" (I was born a decorator).
WASHINGTON, May 11 -Nuclear weapons, missiles and weapons are being developed with such speed that it may soon be next to impossible to control them, the National Planning Association said today.

PARIS, May 11 -- One interesting world development during the past half year is the sudden emergence of John Foster Dulles as a popular figure. Six months ago the Secretary of State experienced wide criticism in America and was the subject of almost savage mockery in Europe. This is no longer the case.

HARRIMAN, N. Y., May 11 -- A conference on unions was warned today on a shortening of the work week to twenty hours. It was told that this would call for thousands of new psychiatrists to deal with nervous breakdowns among workers who would not know what to do with their spare time.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -Federal grants cannot be made to colleges without Federal controls, according to a report, "National Aid to Higher Education," issued today by the American Enterprise Association. The Association is a nonprofit research organization formed and supported by business leaders.

The American-Philippine Science Foundation is gradually hammering into shape a program for a solid advance in Philippine science. It has several immediate objectives, the first of which is arousing larger interest, both governmental and public, in its program and its goals.
ENGLEWOOD, N. J., May 11 -- The use of an electronic brain has introduced a novel note into a school debate here that will be decided by referendum May 27.

The number of juvenile offenders under the age of 17 coming to the attention of the Federal courts increased by 15 per cent in 1957, Director James V. Bennett of the Federal Bureau of Prisons notes in reporting on the work of the Federal correctional institutions for last year.

At last the House of Representatives has begun to take notice of the mounting demand for the regulation of employe welfare funds and of union operations in general. But in doing so it is raising barriers to action rather than helping to clear the road for it.
HAMBURG, Germany, Monday, May 12 (Reuters) -- Foreign Minister Chen Yi of Communist China said in an interview published today that the 1948 Soviet bloc break with Yugoslavia would not be repeated.

Although most of the standard indices of economic activity were still declining as we moved into the month of May -- the ninth month of the present business recession -- the official attitude in Washington on the moot issue of tax reduction seemed to be as unclear and as non-committal as ever.

The City's Administrator's office is preparing to study the feasibility of staggering hours of Manhattan workers to relieve transit congestion rush periods. Henry Cohen, senior management consultant to the City Administrator, estimated yesterday that 50 per cent of Manhattan's working force used the subways during the four morning and evening peak hours on week days.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 11. -- An American scholar declared today that Israel was facing a serious financial problem unless she accelerated her efforts to offset an expected decline in foreign aid.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, May 11 -- Ground fighting between Government troops and Indonesian rebels has spread to a new area, the army high command disclosed tonight.

Samuel Brouner has sold the five-story building with ten i apartments at 11 West Seventieth Street near Central Park West to Mayer H. Battam The property, assessed at $63,000, was sold subject to mortgages of $45.500. The L J. PhillipsWood. Dolson Company was the broker.

A registered representative of the Dominican Revolutionary party in the United States said last night that he had been detained in customs at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, an hour longer than other passengers.

The real tragedy of juvenile delinquency lies not with the "shook up" 3 per cent, but the indifferent 97 per cent. I am appalled at the poverty of the meet-violence-withviolence technique. I protest the irrational barbaric notion that we can treat sickness without delving into the "why oh whys."
Aluminum Limited, in its first-quarter report issued for publication today, shows a drop of $9,628,107 in earnings from the initial three months last year.
The new Grace Line ships Santa Rosa and Santa Paula will add Port Everglades, Fla., as a port of call on their twelve-day Caribbean cruises.

The growth of branch banking among upstate New York commercial banks generally has not brought them improved earnings, compared with unit banking, according to George A. Mooney, New York State Superintendent of Banks.
WASHINGTON, May 11 -- In the midst of controversy over the Supreme Court's role, Congress is considering a change in one area of the court's authority with the apparent approval of the court itself.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 12 -- That recent skirmish over who would do the first telecast of "Hiawatha" on the National Broadcasting Company next fall has been settled -- again.
MEXICO CITY, May 12 -- Louis Dejoie, exiled leader of the political Opposition in Haiti, told today of six months in which he lived in constant fear of betrayal or assassination.

In the table of organization of the New York Stock Exchange, the president is the "front man" -- the paid administrative officer who represents the exchange to the people. The chairman is the stock broker's broker.
Rose Bampton, soprano, will be the soloist July 1 at the opening of the Evenings-by-the-River summer concert series.
Sales of the nation's major chain and mail order companies turned downward in April, but they still managed to exceed the figure of a year earlier.

Nothing dismays a bowling alley proprietor so much as the bowler who takes one look at the pins and lets fly with a ball that bounces down the lane instead of rolling. It doesn't make the bowler happy, either.
WASHINGTON, May 12 (UP) -- The Air Force announced today it planned to build ten new Bomarc missile bases at existing airfields at a cost of $121,000,000.

Patricia Tiernan of Wheatley Hills led her team to a 15-0 victory Over Glen Head yesterday. This match, which was postponed last Friday because of a soggy golf course, was in series 2 of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's interclub matches.

VIENTIANE, Laos, May 12 -- The counting of votes in the special Laotian National Assembly elections has gone far enough to make it certain there has been a considerable triumph by the Communist-oriented Neo Lao Hak Xat (Patriotic Front).

Share earnings of the United States Plywood Corporation in the year ended April 30 were between $2.45 and $2.50, compared with $3.24 in the 1957 fiscal year, S. W. Antoville, president, told the New York Society of Security Analysts yesterday.

THERE must be some kind of equation to express the relation between the use of small dry flies and the use of the truth. There are men alive today who have used them both, probably, but not at the same time.

RIVERHEAD, L. I., May 12 -- A four-and-a-half-mile section of new highway was scheduled here today as a north-south link to Upton Boulevard that would run along the western boundary of the Brookhaven National Laboratory.
If Sal Maglie's future with the Yankees was at stake last night -- the rumor irritated both Maglie and Manger Casey Stengel -- the Barber probably saved his job.
WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP) -- Legislation to make it easier for the Government to discipline Communist-dominated labor unions was recommended today by the Senate Internal Security subcommittee.

THE latest innovation in 1958 electric ranges is a model that hangs on the wall. Incorporating two ovens and four surface burners, this sleek, compact appliance also can be set on top of a kitchen cabinet to create a built-in effect.
A WHITE collar girl's dreams are made of clothes that she will wear for her wedding, her vacation and her career -- in that order.
The Alleghany Corporation, holding company formerly headed by the late Robert R. Young, is granting stock options to assure it of the continued services of various associates of Mr. Young.

LONDON, May 12 -- A Foreign Office spokesman said today that Britain had not yet received the text of the letter of Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev to President Eisenhower on a possible suspension of nuclear weapons tests.

Mayor Wagner and Controller Gerosa are fighting a battle of diminishing returns over credit for hot pursuit of the scandalous conditions uncovered in the city's Bureau of Real Estate. The fact is that neither of these officials covered himself with glory and they share, with their fellow members on the Board of Estimate, the blame for slow discovery and tardy action. Both have been in office since Jan. 1, 1954.

World sugar positions were strong yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange in the heaviest trading of the year. Prices closed at the highs of the day, advancing 1 to 8 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) on a turnover of 42,650 tons.
WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP) -- Assistant Attorney General Victor R. Hansen, in charge of the Antitrust Division, said in a statement here today:
PHILADELPHIA, May 12 -- A bearded, pipe-smoking Briton told today how he had been brought up as a girl but was changed into a man after a series of operations that began when he was 29 years old.
IN "The News Game," a panel show that started last night over Channel 13, Hildy Parks was at a cruel disadvantage.
ALBANY, May 12 (AP) -- Governor Harriman asked the state's new Crime Commission today to begin its inquiry on vice and crime in Utica promptly.
WASHINGTON, May 12 -- The military services told Congress today that plutonium production would have to be substantially expanded to meet requirements for atomic weapons.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- The death of one man often recalls the career of another because of a historical link between them. But seldom have there been so many circumstances to evoke this linked remembrance as those which vividly recalled Woodrow Wilson at the funeral services today for Joseph E. Davies.

Automatic bedside equipment to prevent fatal bleeding in victims of cirrhosis of the liver was recommended here yesterday. Dr. Louis M. Rousselot made the suggestion at the opening of the 152d annual meeting of the Medical Society of the State of New York.
Alfred Hitchcock's "Vertigo," starring James Stewart, Kim Novak and Barbara Bel Geddes, will be the next attraction at the Capitol Theatre.
The Ford Foundation announced yesterday the award of 180 fellowships in the field of foreign affairs.
PHILADELPHIA, May 12 -- The United States Court of Appeals was asked today whether there was a basis for Federal court action in Philadelphia's tax on a nonresident employed in the Navy Yard here.
BENNINGTON, Vt. May 12 William C. Fels, new president of Bennington College, proposed today that state and independent colleges and universities set tuition at "the same realistic high levels."
The F. L. Jacobs Company has obtained control of the Symphonic Electronic Corporation, a leading manufacturer of phonographs and phonographic equipment.
MOUNT VERNON, Ohio, May 12 (UP) -- Autopsy reports showed today that carbon monoxide poisoning had caused the death of a Kenyon College instructor and a senior student.

As an American I readily agree with your editorial of May 3 "Poland and Germany." To have Poland on the side of our raison d'etre is not only desirable. In the course of time it may prove to be essential.

For several years, Bob Russo had become "ill" over the prospect of becoming a "brown-bagger" -- a student who carries his lunch to one of the city's colleges on one of the city's not-so-rapid transits.
A three-level pool that will have tides will be built soon at the Aquarium.
WASHINGTON, May 12 -- Mrs. Marjorie Merriweather Post confirmed today through her secretary that she would be married before June 28 to Herbert Arthur May of Pittsburgh, a Westinghouse executive.
Steel production increased again last week and was at the best level since late March. An additional rise has been scheduled by steel makers this week.
State banking supervisors may seek new legislation to increase the bad debt reserves permitted to commercial bankers in calculating bank income taxes.
The Chrysler Corporation decided yesterday to terminate "Climax!" on June 26. It has sponsored the program since the fall of 1954 over the Columbia Broadcasting System television network.

The newly built two-story garage at 320-28 West Thirty-sixth Street was sold to a group of investors headed by Phillip Green and leased back to the builder. The building, on a plot of 83 by 100 feet, contains 33,000 square feet of parking area on four levels, including the basement and roof.
ROME, May 12 (AP) -- Australia's Mervyn Rose overpowered Chilian Luis Ayala, 6 -- 4, 4 -- 6, 16 -- 14, 6 -- 1, today in the men's semi-finals of the Italian tennis championships.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- The Administration's battle for a $2,958,000,000 foreign aid authorization opened in the House today and Speaker Sam Rayburn of Texas predicted that it would be passed without major cuts.
The Administration's new military organization plan still under study by the House Armed Services Committee would increase Presidential authority and reduce Congressional authority in several ways.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 12 -- Abolishment of big public mental hospitals as obsolescent monstrosities was advocated here today.

" In Clear and Present Danger," a new book by John W. Caughey, will be published May 27 by the University of Chicago Press. The author contends that since World War II the people of this country have developed a pattern of reaching for internal security by piecemeal surrender of American freedoms.
The national elections in Greece have produced results which the West can welcome, on the whole, but they sound a warning that should be heeded.

Before a distinguished gathering of the city's political, business and sports leaders, Richard C. Patterson Jr., the Commissioner of Commerce and Public Events of the City of New York, received the Amateur Athletic Union's 1958 Gold Medal Award last night.
The report of the Amerada Petroleum Corporation and its subsidiaries yesterday showed that profits in the first quarter were below those a year ago.
The Yale and Harvard varsity eights, both undefeated, were seeded first and second for the heavyweight sprint Championships of the Eastern Association of Rowing Colleges yesterday.
We studied with interest your editorial of April 29 entitled "Bad City Management," in which you considered the New York City Bureau of Real Estate.

ALBERTO MORAVIA'S "Two Women"* is a bleak and immensely wordy novel about Italy during World War II. The story is told in the first person by Cesira, a ruthlessly simple egoist, as an old wives' tale. When Cesira's country is invaded she finds war considerably more appalling than it seemed to her, apparently, in the triumphant days of Italy's conquest of Ethiopia.

THE Modern Jazz Quartet offered at Town Hall last night one of the first justifiably identified "jazz concerts" heard in New York since Duke Ellington abandoned his annual visits to Carnegie Hall a decade ago.

Which is the longest day of the week? At most times of the year, any honest student, pausing to consider the matter of length in depth, undoubtedly would pick Monday. That day has a fearful reputation, deserving every last bad word of it.
OTTAWA, May 12 -- An extensive program for the development of Canada's northern frontier was proposed by Prime Minister John Diefenbaker's Government today at the opening of Parliament.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 12 -- Representatives of 400,000 unionized clothing workers today cheered a call for a Federal law to cut the basic work week in all industries to thirty-five hours as a permanent safeguard against business slumps.
WASHINGTON, May 12 (UP) -- The National Farm Bureau Federation urged Congress today to pass a Federal "right-to-work" law as the best means of combating labor union corruption.

THE exhibition and sale of 200 prints by contemporary Japanese artists is a feature of the annual art exhibition at the Parish House of St. James Protestant Episcopal Church, 865 Madison Avenue. The prints will be a revelation to those whose knowledge of Japanese art stopped with Hokusai.

DR. FRANK C. BAXTER, Professor of English at the University of Southern California, whose stimulating lectures on Shakespeare first opened the eyes of many viewers to the educational possibilities of television, is back again on the local airwaves in another excellent series entitled "The Written Word."

SUMMER is just around the corner, and Hammacher Schlemmer is prepared for it. This store has devoted its entire fourth floor to new outdoor furniture and decorative accessories for the impending shift to garden living.
Old and new "treasures" will vie for favor at a benefit sale and party in the garden of the Spence-Chapin Adoption Service on May 20.

News that there is "fierce" fighting in areas of Indonesia other than Sumatra is hardly a surprise. At the moment the more important clashes seem to be taking place in the eastern part of the archipelago as the news significance of Sumatra dies down.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 12 -- Armed insurrection against the pro-Western Government of President Camille Chamoun was attempted today. The uprising is believed to have been aided by foreign agents.

Hilton Riggio, Inc., has held talks with Kastor, Farrell, Chesley Clifford, Inc., that are expected to lead to a merger. It is expected that final details may be worked out before the end of the week.
Housewives will soon be able to pick from supermarket shelves a "factory fresh" alarm clock, sealed in a can.
DETROIT, May 12 (AP) -- Passenger-car output so far this year is nearly 875,000 units behind the volume in the comparable period of 1957.

BONN, Germany, May 12 -- West Germany, France, Belgium and the Netherlands will establish ten anti-aircraft rocket battalions in West Germany as part of a joint European air defense system, the German news agency reported today.
The "great weakness" of New York Protestantism is its "readiness to identify with a particular social group and treat other groups as outsiders," the Rev. Dr. David W. Barry said last night.
RICHMOND, Va., May 12 -- Virginia's showdown on public school segregation was scheduled today for September.

MONTREAL, May 12 -- David Dubinsky, president of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, said today that the terms of the general strike settlement last March had already served as the basis of gains for 50,000 more garment workers.
WASHINGTON, May 12 -- The Senate racket committee's investigation of the underworld's ties with labor unions and management associations will probably begin about the middle of next month.

THE Coney Island Chamber of Commerce boasts that there has not been a single case of food poisoning among the 750,000,000 persons who have visited there since 1936. This is remarkable because, on a warm, sunny week-end, everybody along the boardwalk munches on something, be it a pizza, a hot dog, spun sugar candy or kasha knishes.
RABAT, Morocco, May 12 -- King Mohammed V installed today a new Cabinet headed by Ahmed Balafrej as Premier.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), May 12 -- Dr. Ralph J. Bunche met today with Premier David Ben-Gurion in a continuation of the talks he began yesterday with Jordanian and Israeli officials.

Aircraft issues held their own in yesterday's session of the New York Stock Exchange but almost every other major group declined. Department stores inched up despite word of the unfavorable tax decision concerning inventories in the R. H. Macy case.
The Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria was the setting last night for the gala May Festival dinner dance for the benefit of Just One Break, Inc.
The Appellate Division in Brooklyn held yesterday that a private welfare agency had the right to reclaim a girl from her foster parents even though the couple sought to keep her.
Salomon Bros. Hutzler and associates are offering today $16,000,000 of 3 7/8 per cent Public Service Company of Oklahoma first mortgage bonds, due in 1988, at 99.56 to yield 3.9 per cent.
Members of society arrived early yesterday at Belmont Park to attend the opening program of the spring meeting of the Greater New York Racing Association, which will continue through July 12.

A dentist's wife in Yonkers who sensed that something was wrong when she telephoned her husband's Washington Heights office while it was being held up yesterday brought about the arrest of two armed suspects.
Race prejudice and class hatred are nonexistent among the severely handicapped, Dr. Howard A. Rusk said yesterday.
Mary G. resented the "new people" moving into the East Side -- people who paid high rents, drove foreign cars and left the block when it got hot in the summer.

For the first time in a decade, three ten-round bouts were staged last night at the St. Nicholas Arena. When the program ended with a draw between Pete Schmidt, a welterweight from Yorkville, and Eddie Lynch of the West Side, the fans, the management and the fighters (even the beaten ones) were happy.

TALL, handsome and youthful-looking at the age of 51, Constantine Karamanlis has gained a reputation in Greece as a man and politician of action, not of words. In a country where the fine art of oratory is every citizen's delight, he has made no secret of his dislike for speechmaking -- by himself or by others.
FRANKFORT, Ky., May 12 (UP) -- Earle Combs, 59-year-old former New York Yankees outfielder, was named Kentucky State Banking Commissioner today.

Manhattan completed its anticipated romp to a ninth straight team title yesterday as the twice-postponed Metropolitan Intercollegiate track and field championships finally were run off at Downing Stadium on Randalls Island.

WASHINGTON, May 12 (UP) -- Thomas K. Finletter, former Secretary of the Air Force, said today that the United States should insist, "primarily within the United Nations," that the Arab countries sign peace treaties with Israel.
The details of $306,569,000 of public housing and slum clearance financing on issues of bonds and notes subsidized by the Federal Government were announced yesterday.

Not every boy wants a dog for a pet. Some want rats. At least that's the case at Columbia College, where the psychology department is allowing some students to take home their experimental white rats this week.

WASHINGTON, May 12 (UP) -- Representative John W. McCormack, Democrat of Massachusetts, called tonight for swift Congressional action to cut individual income taxes and give business a shot in the arm.
Four suspended student editor of the City College magazine Promethean were reinstall yesterday by Dr. Buell G. Gallagher, president of the college.
The special Juvenile Aid Bureau task force set up to combat teen-age crime during the summer made its first arrest last night.

BALTIMORE, May 12 (AP) -- Mrs. Richard E. Lunn's Gone Fishin' nailed down a startling role in Saturday's $100,000-added Preakness today by winning the Prep exhibition at Pimlico with a minimum of effort.
ROME, May 12 -- President Giovanni Gronchi left for London today for the first official visit of an Italian head of state to the Court of Saint James's in thirty-four years.

The Lefcourt Realty Corporation, a New York builder of commercial property, has acquired all the stock in the Florida Boca Raton Housing Association, Inc. Lefcourt gave 1,682,432 common shares, valued at about $3,800,000, for the Florida concern.
WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP) -- Ashoka, a one and one-half ton Indian elephant, sported a king-size brace on his tusks today.

" Strange Partners" has a role that Melvyn Douglas seems to value highly. It must be so because the star is willing to devote eight weeks on the straw-hat circuit playing the father of five daughters in the Caroline Francke - Florence Lowe drama.

ATHENS, May 12 -- The strongly pro-Western National Radical Union headed by Constantine Karamanlis won Sunday's general elections. It has 173 seats of 300 in the Chamber of Deputies, according to Ministry of Interior figures.
TRENTON, May 12 (AP) -- The third hole at the Ramsey Golf and Country Club's course is going to be a little easier from now on -- by court order.
MONROE, N. C., May 12 (AP) -- An insurance company, noting racial unrest in Union County, has canceled automobile insurance of a Negro leader.
WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP) -- The Defense Department presented today its highest civilian award to John D. Hertz for his establishment of a multimillion-dollar fund to train American engineers.

BOGOTA, Colombia, May 12 -- Intelligence reports received here today warned of the danger of a possible Communist assassination attempt against Vice President Richard M. Nixon when he reaches Caracas, Venezuela.
The battle of Washington Square will open tomorrow.
