Our congratulations go to T. W. A. for its hiring of Miss Margaret Grant as an airline stewardess. This is the third time that a Negro has been able to break the barrier of race bias at this particular point, and it is important because T. W. A. has been ready to break it on a major trunk line.

SILKY SULLIVAN is a huge horse with a rich red coat that sparkles in the sunlight. He's a handsome beast and he has both the engaging personality of a small boy and the majestic mien of the true aristocrat. Even the hard-boiled and unimpressionable railbirds stare at him with an open-mouthed wonder that's akin to awe.

WASHINGTON, May 12 (UP) -- R. S. Reynolds Jr., president of Reynolds Metals Company of Richmond, Va., protested today that the Administration's "domestic minerals stabilization plan" discriminated against the United States aluminum industry by favoring copper, lead and zinc.

WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP) -- President Eisenhower today urged all Americans to pay tribute to the Stars and Stripes on Flag Day, June 14, as a banner under which "people of varied heritage, creed and race have found surcease from oppression."
The New York Central charged yesterday that Westchester County exhibited a "difference in attitude" toward commuter fare increases and parkway toll rises.
EAST HAVEN, Conn., May 12 (UP) -- A 13-year-old boy admitted to the police today that he had beaten a 6-year-old girl to death with a rock and raped her.
Seymour M. Wilson, a key figure in the scandals that have beset the city's Bureau of Real Estate, pleaded guilty yesterday in General Sessions Court to stealing $30,380 in city funds.
LONDON, May 12 -- In the Royal Festival Hall tonight the Philadelphia Orchestra, under Eugene Ormandy, its regular conductor, began triumphantly the third and most ambitious of its European tours.

One of the great advantages that the Supreme Court has and which must be preserved within the framework of our American political system is the ability and the necessity to deliberate in calm reflection upon fundamental principles of our government which come before it by reason of litigation.
PHYLLIS Antognini, a young Canadian soprano, made her appearance at Carnegie Recital Hall last night singing a program of contemporary American songs.

W. R. Grace Co. has set capital expenditures this year at $71,900,000, compared with $63,800,000 spent in 1957, J. Peter Grace, president, told shareholders yesterday. About 650 stockholders attended the three-hour annual and special meetings held in the Biltmore Hotel here.

BRUSSELS, May 12 -- When the St. Louis Symphony Orchestra appointed Edouard van Remoortel as its next conductor last winter there was quite a stir in the United States. For the Belgian newcomer was only 30 years old, had made just a few appearances in America and seemed to be getting a post that might have gone to a native son.
Macy's was late in deciding how it would record its goods coming in and going out and so, a Federal Court ruled yesterday, it cannot collect more than $1,000,000 in tax refunds.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- The "ins" and the "outs" of the East and Gulf Coast maritime unions held a secret meeting here today to discuss jurisdiction and other matters of common interest to longshoremen, seamen and teamsters.
GREAT NECK, L. I., May 12 -- Cartons of international friendship will be sent Saturday to the children of Ceylon from the Girl Scouts of this North Shore community.

The scholarship fund of the Encampment for Citizenship will be augmented as the result of a program of international folk songs by Pete Seeger on the evening of May 23. The event will take place in the Ethical Culture Society auditorium at 2 West Sixty-fourth Street.
A woman was killed and her daughter seriously injured in the Bronx yesterday when they were struck by a driverless automobile.
WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP) -- President Eisenhower sent Congress today a report recommending liberalization of travel restrictions as one of the best means of improving international relations.

EPINAL, France, May 12 -- His name forever lost in the mists of battle, an American in a flag-draped coffin became today the symbol of all United States servicemen killed in action in Europe and Africa in World War II. talgic echo known as Silver Taps. The skies were gray and a jet plane could be heard far overhead in the mist.
PEIPING, May 12 (Reuters) -- Communist China, which follows the Moscow line in ideology and foreign affairs, apparently is keeping "hands off" any struggle for power in the Kremlin.

DETROIT, May 12 -- James B. Carey, president of the International Union of Electrical Workers, charged today that the General Motors Corporation had failed to bargain in good faith with his union. He reported virtually no progress after more than a month of negotiations for a labor contract.
Sidney J. Weinberg, senior partner in Goldman, Sachs Co., members of the New York Stock Exchange, will receive the Harvard Club's 1957-58 Business Statesmanship Award.
CHICAGO, May 12 (AP) -- Every grain future contract on the Board of Trade sagged today, some around 2 cents a bushel, as broad liquidation hit all pits. Soybeans advanced.
WASHINGTON, May 12 -- Over mild Republican objections, the House Armed Services Committee ended hearings today on Pentagon reorganization.

Employes at Macy's Herald Square will give blood to the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program today, Thursday and Friday. The donation will be sponsored by the management and Local 1-S of the Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Union.
BUDAPEST, Hungary, May 12 (Reuters) -- Wladyslaw Gomulka, Polish Communist leader, flew to Rumania today, leaving behind him here an indirect declaration of war against Yugoslav "revisionism."

CHICAGO, May 12 (AP) -- Prices for butcher hogs reached their highest level in 45 months today, or since August, 1954. With the market mostly 50 to 75 cents up, buyers paid a top of $23.50 for about 300 head of 190 to 225 pound mixed No. 1 and 2 grades including several lots of strictly No. 1.
A majority of business men are optimistic about the third quarter of 1958, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

Service on part of the Myrtle Avenue elevated line of the BMT was suspended for three and three-quarter hours yesterday afternoon in Brooklyn after a transverse girder had been cracked in a traffic mishap.
Allan Nevins announced yesterday that he would leave Columbia University on June 30 under the provisions of a mandatory retirement rule at the age of 68.

LOS ANGELES, May 12 (AP) -- Willie Mays belted a pair of homers, one his second grand-slam in the majors, as the San Francisco Giants vanquished the Dodgers, 12 -- 3, tonight. A crowd of 29,770 saw the game at the Coliseum.

NEW DELHI, India, May 12 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru criticized today the international Communist denunciation of Yugoslavia as an example of foreign interference in the domestic affairs of a nation.
WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP) -- Following are the rates of average basic monthly pay for Armed Forces personnel and the new average scales approved by Congress today.
WASHINGTON, May 12 -- Personal incomes, primary measure of purchasing power, rose slightly in both March and April despite heavy unemployment, the Commerce Department reported today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 12 -- Yul Brynner's independent company, Alciona Productions, has decided to postpone filming of the Arthur Koestler novel "The Gladiators" until the early summer of 1959. As a result, the company's first picture for United Artists' release now is to be "The Magnificent 7," a large-scale Western.
WESTBURY, L. I., May 12 -- The Daily Double Trouble Turnpike Transit Tour -- also dubbed the Get Even Special -- was begun today.
Directors of the Colorado Fuel and Iron Corporation voted yesterday to omit a dividend on the common stock for the quarter ending June 30.

CHICAGO, May 12 -- Both sales and earnings of Sears, Roebuck Co. in the quarter ended April 30 were lower than last year's. However the company's business improved steadily in the last two months. Theodore V. Houser, chairman, told stockholders at their annual meeting today.
WASHINGTON, May 12 -- The Department of Labor estimated today that this country's shortage of nurses had reached 70,000. The number available was estimated at about 430,000.
Representative Henry J. Latham was designated to run for re-election at a meeting of the Queens Republican executive committee last night.
WASHINGTON, May 12 -- Secretary of State Dulles said today that Soviet willingness to discuss disarmament controls was "gratifying." However he saw no reason for quick optimism.

NEWARK, May 12 -- Moving to meet what it termed daily strike threats by carpenters, the Essex County Building Contractors Association shut down carpentering on all jobs at 3:30 P. M. today. About 2,500 carpenters were put out of work.
PARIS, May 12 -- Pierre Pflimlin, Premier-designate, will go before the French National Assembly tomorrow in an atmosphere made tense by the threat of serious Right-wing disturbances in Algeria.
TRENTON, May 12 -- The Republican-controlled State Senate tonight reduced Gov. Robert B. Meyner's budget by $22,199,000, the largest slash in the history of the state.

A large enough crash program might solve the nation's biggest heart disease problem within "the next few years," Dr. Jere W. Lord, surgeon and president of the New York Heart Association, said yesterday.
The Premiers of Finland and Norway and Norway's Princess Astrid were honored yesterday at separate municipal luncheons.
St. Francis Prep easily won the team championship with 40 1/2 points yesterday in the eleventh annual Brooklyn College interscholastic track and field meet. Three meet records were posted.

QUITO, Ecuador, May 12 -- Before an overflow audience estimated at 3,300 in Quito's Bolivar Theatre last night, Leonard Bernstein led the New York Philharmonic before an enthusiastic audience. The orchestra triumphantly overcame the handicap of Quito's 9,400-feet altitude.

WASHINGTON, May 12 (UP) -- Consumers can expect retail prices of choice beef to begin dropping slightly this spring with pork getting cheaper after midsummer; the Agriculture Department predicted today.
CHICAGO, May 12 -- There is no absence of great social issues; only a lack of leaders for them.
WASHINGTON, May 12 -- Congress passed and sent to the White House today a $576,438,000 pay rise bill designed to hold skilled military men of all ranks at their posts.
Expenditures by ship operators for seafaring fringe benefits quadrupled in a six-year period, according to a report yesterday by the Maritime Administration of the Department of Commerce.
Officials of the five drug concerns charged with having fixed prices on Salk polio vaccine yesterday uniformly -- and in some cases angrily -- denied wrongdoing.

CHICAGO, May 12 (AP) -- Stan Musial doubled in his first time at bat for his 2,999th hit today, then was blanked while his St. Louis Cardinal team-mates defeated the Chicago Cubs, 6 -- 4. The loss was the Cubs' sixth straight and their fifth in a row to the Cardinals.
LONDON, May 12 -- Despite the hesitancy of investors the undertone of the stock market held firm today.

The horses returned to Belmont Park yesterday, and 26,128 fans turned out to see them perform. The crowd was not as large as the 40,000 that watched the proceedings when Belmont held its first race on May 4, 1905, but the betting -- $2,165,164 -- was satisfactorily brisk.
LONDON, May 12 -- Dr. Vivian E. Fuchs received a hero's welcome today on his return to Britain after making the first overland crossing of Antarctica.
TRENTON, May 12 -- Five concerns were charged today with having monopolized the production of Salk polio vaccine and with having fixed prices.

Distress conveyances of real property in Manhattan during the first quarter of 1958 totaled eighteen, the same number as in the equivalent period of 1957. However, the dollar volume was lower this year.
Cotton futures moved 3 points up to 25 points off yesterday in moderate trading. A point is equal to 5 cents a bale.

An emergency committee of the Friends of the Museum of Modern Art has been formed to raise money to help the museum to recover from last month's fire. Funds in addition to the insurance payments are needed to redesign completely all galleries for maximum safety.
BAGHDAD, Iraq, May 12 (Reuters) -- The Arab. Federation uniting Jordan and Iraq was formally born today when King Faisal gave his assent to the bill outlining the Constitution for the federation.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- President Eisenhower told a Negro audience today that "there are no revolutionary cures" for racial discrimination in the United States. In an address to 350 editors and business and community leaders, the President said that human problems depend for their solution on "patience and forbearance" and on more and better education rather than "simply on the letter of the law."
Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr. will plead on Friday in Federal Court to income tax evasion charges. The Harlem Democrat will be represented by Edward Bennett Williams of Washington.

The distressing events in Lebanon during the last four days, with rioting, looting, sacking, a general strike and the sabotage of an Iraq Petroleum Company pipeline, are not easily classifiable. There are complicated internal and external forces at work.
MONTREAL, May 12 (Canadian Press) -- Private talks are proceeding here in an effort to end the strike of locomotive firemen on the Canadian Pacific Railway.
Following is the text of the statement issued yesterday by Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa to amplify his assertion of last Saturday concerning his audit of the accounts of the Bureau of Real Estate:
WASHINGTON, May 12 -- Ezra Taft Benson predicted today that the recent upturn in farm economic conditions would help Administration supporters in the Congressional elections.
An uptown delicatessen owner was slashed and his store damaged yesterday by two teen-agers who had been refused a case of beer.
FAMILIES who complain that their home is not large enough in which to swing a cat may be interested in the fact that five men can live for five days in a space no bigger than a station wagon.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., May 12 (AP) -- The Senate rackets committee has outlived its usefulness and should "pack up its prejudices and go home," the head of the Textile Workers Union of America said today.
IF Shaw's "The Philanderer" is seldom acted, the reason is not difficult to discover. "The Philanderer" is one of his most trifling plays.
WHITE PLAINS, May 12 -- A ban on nonresidents of Westchester at the county's Playland amusement park and beach at Rye was proposed here today.
WASHINGTON, May 12 -- Authorities on Middle East affairs saw today behind Lebanon's anti-American riots a vicious combination of Nasserism and communism.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, May 11 -- Sweden will spare no effort in technical planning or study of atomic bombs. But for the time being the people and Government will avoid any decision on manufacturing them.

CLEVELAND, May 13 (AP) -- United States District Judge Charles J. McNamee yesterday ordered a halt to the promotion of an unusual profit-sharing plan for key employees of the Consolidation Coal Company.

Two new champions were crowned as the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's interclub team matches were finished in their districts yesterday. The Creek in Long Island nosed out last year's Metropolitan champion, Meadow Brook, while Round Hill won in Westchester.
TULSA, Okla., May 13 (AP) -- First-quarter earnings of the Sunray Mid-Continent Oil Company were down 18 per cent from a year ago, stockholders learned today.
NIAGARA FALLS, N. Y., May 13 (AP) -- Mad Bear Anderson, leader of the fight to keep the Niagara Power project off the Tuscarora Indian Reservation, was helping to build the project today.
For the first time women participated yesterday as voting delegates at a convention of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York.
"SPORTS-O-PHONE" emerged as a telecast that was more often interesting than not on Channel 13 last night.
A DAY camp for boys and and girls 13 to 16 years old is being introduced this summer by the Ninety-second Street Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Association.

The American Museum of Natural History has been giving pleasure and instruction to visitors and New Yorkers for nearly ninety years now, since its early days in the old Arsenal Building in Central Park and since 1877 on Central Park West at Seventy-ninth Street.
WASHINGTON, May 13 (AP) -- Seven United States college presidents are preparing to go to the Soviet Union this summer for a three-week study of higher education there.

While standard issues moved down yesterday, low-price stocks were in high revel on the New York Stock Exchange. Of the fifteen most active issues, ten rose. Of those ten, six closed below $10 a share.

Mayor Leo P. Carlin led his closest opponent by a margin of nearly 3 to 1 in yesterday's balloting in Newark, but failed to get the majority needed for re-election. A run-off election will be held on June 17.

Back in 1955 Boston University and Boston College scheduled a night baseball game at B. U. Field, the former home of the Braves. In the bottom of the first inning the late Tom Gastall of the Terriers smashed a bases-loaded homer.

A benefit dinner party on June 3 at the Town and Country Club in Brooklyn will aid the service program of the Association for the Advancement of Blind Children. The party is to be held under the auspices of the Dorothy Schwimmer Chapter in Rosedale, Queens.
WASHINGTON, May 13 -- Conservative and liberal Senate Democrats opened separate attacks today on a House-approved bill for supplementary unemployment benefits to jobless workers.
VIENTIANE, Laos, May 13 -- Will communism come to power in Laos by means of the ballot?
HORROR movies and gory comic books are ideal fare for small fry with literary aspirations, according to a freelance magazine writer who practices psychology.

WASHINGTON, May 13 (UP) -- The Boston Red Sox, aided by Jackie Jensen's grand-slam homer and a neat relief job by Ike Delock, snapped a four-game losing streak tonight by defeating the Washington Senators, 9 -- 6.

REPORTS from travelers returning from a fishing resort in Mexico indicate that men are now faced inescapably with an agonizing reappraisal of their policy toward women. The women have scored notable cold-war victories recently.

FATIMA, Portugal, May 13 -- A fifteen-ton statue of Our Lady of Fatima donated by Roman Catholics in the United States and carved by a Dominican priest there was unveiled here today. Thousands of pilgrims from the United States and many other countries attended the ceremony.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 13 -- A ranking unionist urged today that President Eisenhower appoint a citizens' watchdog committee to investigate Congress in the same manner that Congress is now investigating unions.
Don Larsen has had a tender right shoulder for several days and both he and his manager, Casey Stengel, were uncertain how it would react. Larsen had not pitched since April 21.
WASHINGTON, May 13 -- President Eisenhower's call for "patience" on the part of Negroes in demanding their constitutional rights drew strong criticism today at a convention of Negro leaders.
WASHINGTON, May 13 -- The Administration modified today its proposal for a civilian space agency to meet bipartisan Congressional criticism.

In the elevator stood a thin and rather attractive girl. Every time she coughed she became an enemy to you and your family. She didn't realize that she was one of the thousands of TB carriers who use sub ways, public telephones, trains and buses of New York every day.
The New York State Medical Society yesterday urged the Federal Government to stop television advertising of remedies featuring "doctors."
Morris Kravitz and Dave Norvid of the Hebrew Educational Society scored a second-round victory in the national Amateur Athletic Union one-wall handball championships last night.

A new copper-alloy bearing expected to last several times longer than those now in use in railroad freight cars has been developed by the American Brake Shoe Company. The development also is expected to benefit the copper industry.

The United States is paying the penalty these days for having become the greatest power of the free world. It is not accidental that anti-American demonstrations took place the last few days in South America, Lebanon and Algeria. It is not surprising, either, and Americans must learn to look upon such manifestations philosophically as well as indignantly.

CHICAGO, May 13 (AP) -- Stan (The Man) Musial, hastily summoned as a pinch hitter despite a well-advertised day off, joined seven other baseball greats today by smashing a key double for his 3,000th major league hit and a 5-3 victory for his St. Louis Cardinals over the Chicago Cubs.
WASHINGTON, May 13 -- The House Ways and Means Committee will approve a "liberal" reciprocal trade bill, possibly this week, its Democratic chairman predicted today.

PHILADELPHIA, May 13 -- The second of two proxy fights scheduled for the Pennsylvania Railroad's annual meeting here today collapsed quietly before it began. In the midst of the drama swirling around Randolph Phillips' drive for a seat on the board, a short gray-haired man with a jet black mustache stood up to pledge his proxies to the controversial financial consultant from New York.

William F. Buckley Jr., editor of The National Review, said yesterday he had sent copies of an article in the magazine to a Federal grand jury investigating Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr. at the request of a juror.

WASHINGTON, May 13 (AP) -- A large restaurant in a Chicago suburb was set afire early today and Senate rackets investigators sought to discover whether the aim was to silence an investigation witness.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., May 13 -- New Rochelle Hospital will receive the proceeds from the annual spring luncheon, bridge and fashion show, "A Bouquet of Fashion," which will be held at Glen Island Casino here on Thursday under the sponsorship of the New Rochelle League for Service.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- Representative Oren Harris said today that new House hearings would present some eye-opening information on contested television-licensing cases before the Federal Communications Commission.
An all-Puccini concert commemorating the 100th anniversary of the composer's birth will be presented at Lewisohn Stadium on Saturday, June 28, as a feature of the first week of Stadium Concerts.

The Transport Workers Union's special counsel made a personal appeal to Mayor Wagner yesterday for a public hearing on the proposed sale of the Transit Authority's power houses to the Consolidated Edison Company.
WASHINGTON, May 13 -- A decline in oil exports to the United States in recent months has been a factor in the discontent in Venezuela, officials said today.
Norman Thomas has retired as the only remaining active director who helped found the American Civil Liberties Union in 1920. He has become a director emeritus.

ONE of the abiding values of art is that it can put us in touch with other centuries and make us feel the flavor of other places, no matter how remote in time or location. Drawings are particularly evocative in this sense, as they are often devoted to the slight, but eminently human and repetitive, experiences of the eyes of all epochs.

The first flush green of the lawn in spring is a fine thing to behold. Gone are the doubts about whether or not the lawn came through the winter; it has. One notes that the dandelions have come through the winter too; this is a fine spring for them.

WASHINGTON, May 13 (AP) -- The Senate passed a bill tonight to make available $375,000,000 of Federal funds to cities and rural areas with chronic unemployment. The vote on the bill, which now goes to the House, was 46 to 36.

Next season's schedule for "Desilu Playhouse" has been determined. The filmed drama series featuring Desi Arnaz as host will be televised on Mondays from 10 to 11 P. M. over the Columbia Broadcasting System network.

WARSAW, May 13 -- Poland's Communists are awaiting Wladyslaw Gomulka's approval of a statement that, in a gentle but unmistakable manner, rejects the kind of criticism unleashed on Yugoslavia by the Soviet Chinese and other Soviet bloc parties.
RED SKELTON'S weekly show over Channel 2 was canceled last night because of the death on Saturday of his 9-year-old son, Richard, a victim of leukemia.
A PLEASANT evening of music was offered at Town Hall last night by Nelly Golette, a vivacious French artist who sings, plays and composes music.
LIVERPOOL, England, May 13 (AP) -- Five young Americans will compete with musicians from seven other nations in the first international conductors competition under way here.
MOSCOW, May 13 -- The Soviet Ministry of Culture decided today to permit Kiril P. Kandrashin, conductor of the Moscow Philharmonic Symphony, to accompany Van Cliburn to the United States.
Dudley B. Bonsal, international lawyer, was elected without opposition last night as president of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York.
WESTBURY, L. I., May 13 -- After a discouraging session for chalk players last night, when all nine favorites failed, activities at Roosevelt Raceway became more routine tonight.

PHILADELPHIA, May 13 -- A last citadel of the good old days in railroading, when Vanderbilts spoke only to Harrimans and Harrimans spoke only to Goulds, was challenged here today. For the first time in 112 years, a dissident stockholder of the staid Pennsylvania Railroad sought election at the annual meeting to the company's eighteen-man board.
BLOOMFIELD, N. J., May 13 -- About 150 students at Bloomfield and Glen Ridge High Schools walked out before dismissal time today to attend a retreat at Sacred Heart Church here.
ROME, May 13 (UP) -- Kurt Nielsen of Denmark hurled his racquet at a linesman to furnish most of the excitement today at Rome's tennis tournament.
Steel production in April was the smallest for any month in nearly twelve years, except for periods of major strikes.

Running a sports car rally, be it club, regional or national, is fun, regardless of your position when the scores are posted. But if you hope to finish among the leaders you'll (1) need a lot of experience with the same partner -- driver or navigator -- and (2) you'll have to buy some special equipment.

New forest trails will be blazed today by travelers to the American Museum of Natural History. Twelve woodland communities, seemingly plucked from their far-flung sites and transplanted whole, will be opened.
CHICAGO, May 13 (UP) -- Two world records were bettered and two were equaled last night in the first of a series of exhibitions by Russian and American weight lifters.

Plump girls 5 to 16 years old are invited to attend an Indian powwow at Lane Bryant on Saturday. Starting at 10:30 A. M., the store's fifth floor will be transformed into a "Tepee Town," with Iroquois Indian chiefs officiating over a summer fashion show.

It isn't often that I question the position of the Citizens Union (of which I am a member for over twenty-five years). But I think they are mistaken in urging the sale of the Transit Authority's power stations to the Consolidated Edison Company.
LIMA, Peru, May 13 -- The New York Philharmonic received a great ovation at its concert here last night. The 1,705 seats of the Municipal Theatre were sold out several weeks ago.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- Attorneys for Dr. Corliss Lamont, New York writer and teacher, asked the United States Court of Appeals here today to make the State Department grant him a hearing on his application for a passport.

PHIL SILVERS, whose interpretation of "Sergeant Bilko" has placed him among television's elite, last night ventured into an hour-long variety show over Channel 2. The opening sequences were wonderful nonsense, amusingly wacky and off-beat. But thereafter the presentation went mostly downhill.
Henry Fonda, now in "Two for the Seesaw," may appear in Joseph L. Mankiewicz' dramatization of Carl Jonas' novel, "Jefferson Selleck."
Two young dungaree-clad probationary policemen posed as willing recruits for a gang fight yesterday in Queens to bring about the arrest of twenty-one boys.

Events tonight: "Cosi fan tutte," Ninety-second Street Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Association, 8:15; Works of Stefan Wolpe and Paul Hindemith, Rothschild Foundation, 316 East Sixty-third Street, 8:30; program of operatic excerpts, Educational Alliance, 197 East Broadway, 8:15; Heidi Krall, soprano, Fordham University, 8:30; Leonard Hungerford, pianist, Westchester Jewish Center, Mamaroneck, N. Y., 8:30.
TORONTO, May 13 -- The Toronto Stock Exchange announced yesterday that henceforth surprise audits of member firms would be staggered throughout the year to provide an additional safeguard.
A stepped-up assault on of unionism has developed out the economic recession, a labor leader asserted yesterday.

With the advent of another new skyscraper penetrating the already disordered silhouette of New York, it now appears how great is the need to create a semblance of order to the future growth of the city.

The occasion was fitting for a public show of amity. And Mayor Wagner and Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa, who have had some recent differences over the city's Real Estate Bureau, took advantage of it yesterday as they shook hands at a Big Brother Week reception.
White, Weld Co. and associates are offering today $15,000,000 of United Gas Improvement Company 4 1/8 per cent first mortgage bonds, due in 1983, at 101.5 to yield 4.02 per cent.
Three directors and members of the finance committee of Capital Airlines, Inc., have tendered their resignations to the board.
LONDON, May 13 -- Leaders of the three railway unions expressed optimism today about the possibility of settling the dispute that had led them to consider a nation-wide railroad strike.
Spokesmen for two trucking organizations charged yesterday that terminal operators were responsible for the "chaotic" conditions of truck operations on New York's docks.

WASHINGTON, May 13 (AP) -- The International Brotherhood of Teamsters said today that sixty-four of 104 locals that were under the trusteeship of international officers six months ago had been restored to self-government or were in the process of regaining self-rule.
WASHINGTON, May 13 -- Middle Eastern diplomats expected today that the Lebanese Government would protest to the United Nations Security Council against attacks organized by the United Arab Republic.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- Mr. Mates, who has been Yugoslav Ambassador to the United States since April, 1954, will leave Washington in July for an assignment in the Yugoslav capital. He has been serving in the United States since June, 1950, when he was named Ambassador to the United Nations.

ALGIERS, May 13 -- French troops seized control of Algeria tonight and demanded the return of Gen. Charles de Gaulle as Premier of France. The move was taken by many officials in Paris as a direct challenge to the French Government.
Dancer - Fitzgerald - Sample, Inc., a dark horse, has won the race for the Frigidaire account, estimated at $6,000,000 a year.

The formation of a Catholic Employers and Managers Study Group was hailed yesterday by James T. O'Connell. Under Secretary of Labor. He called it a necessary step toward achieving harmony in labor-management relations.
PARIS, May 13 -- A right-wing mob marched on the French National Assembly today but was stopped just short of its goal by armed security forces.

One reason why the International Longshoremen's Association has been so little in the news of late has been shown by President Vincent G. Barnett of the New York Shipping Association in his annual report -- and the reason is good news in itself. There were fewer "quickie strikes" of longshoremen last year than ever before: only thirteen compared with twice that number in the two previous years and a high of ninety-two.

OMAHA, Neb., May 13 (UP) -- Frank Morrison, Lincoln attorney, held a slight lead over former Representative Eugene D. O'Sullivan Sr. of Omaha, tonight for the Democratic nomination for Senator in Nebraska.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- Marshal Tito's visit to Poland, planned for later this month, will be postponed for sometime, diplomatic sources here said today. It was to have been in return for M. Gomulka's visit to Belgrade last September.
STANLEY FRANK MUSIAL was dubbed Stan The Man "by shuddering Brooklyn fans several years ago," according to one of his many biographers.

PARAMUS, N. J., May 13 -- Plans of the State Highway Department to carry traffic over two main thoroughfares here met no serious opposition today at public hearings. The construction cost for both projects is put at $1,800,000.
LONDON, May 13 (Reuters) -- The Moscow radio said today that Vice President Richard M. Nixon's tour of South America had become an "unparalleled fiasco."
WASHINGTON, May 13 -- The Administration's foreign aid authorization survived its first major test in the House today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 13 -- Montgomery Clift will star in Dore Schary's first independent production, "Lonelyhearts," for United Artists release. Mr. Schary wrote the screenplay from the Nathanael West novel, "Miss Lonelyhearts," and the stage dramatization by Howard Teichmann.

WASHINGTON, May 13 (UP) -- Two House Education subcommittees approved today a $240,000,000 aid program for public elementary and high schools to meet the Soviet Union challenge in training scientists and language experts.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- The Justice Department disclosed today that it was considering a suit for damages against five companies charged with conspiring to fix prices on Salk vaccine sold to the Government.
MIAMI BEACH, May 13 (AP) -- The only way to make President Eisenhower's "Buy Now" program work is to put more money in workers' pockets, a leader of the Textile Workers Union of America said today.

A turnabout in stock buying; psychology is reported by Harold Clayton market analyst for Hemphill, Noyes Co. ,From 955 through 1957 the high-{ price stocks made better perentage gains than the low-{ priced ones, but 'this year, the reverse has been true.
PHILLIPSBURG, N. J., May 14 -- Edward T. Reilly, a Republican and long a bitter foe of Gov. Robert B. Meyner, a Democrat, won a seat yesterday on the all-Democratic City Commission here.
Only the state governments can halt or reverse the rise in insurance rates on automobiles, J. Dewey Dorsett, general manager of the Association of Casualty and Surety Companies, said yesterday.
The board of directors of Middle States Petroleum Corporation yesterday approved an exchange of stock with Tennessee Gas Transmission Company.
Don Juan Carlos Borbon y Borbon, Prince of the Asturias and someday, perhaps, King of Spain, visited New York yesterday in a series of short official sprints.
CHICAGO, May 13 (AP) -- Another rise in butcher hog prices today sent the top to the highest in almost four years.
CHICAGO, May 13 (AP) -- May wheat and rye were the only weak spots in grain futures activity today on the Board of Trade. All soybean deliveries had losses of more than a cent a bushel.
WASHINGTON, May 13 (UP) -- The National Labor Relations Board asked Congress today to give it the power to enforce its decisions.
The Walters Transit Corporation asked for authority yesterday to operate a commuter bus line from Brewster, N. Y., to New York City.

The cost of brand-name drugs has been termed a "real hardship" to middle and low-income dies could be purchased "at a fraction" of the cost if their scientific names were used by physicians writing prescriptions, it was said yesterday by the Citizens Committee for Children of New York City.

BRUSSELS, May 13 -- It is fortunate that Benny Goodman and his band will be along on May 25 to get the American program of live performances rolling. Up to now the Russians have been a dominant force in the artistic phase of the Brussels World's Fair.
CARACAS, Venezuela, May 13 -- Hundreds of fury-spouting demonstrators attacked Vice President Richard M. Nixon's car with rocks and heavy sticks on his arrival today from Bogota.
TEL AVIV, Israel, May 13 -- Israel made a conditional offer tonight to contribute to the solution of the Arab refugee problem.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, May 13 (Reuters) -- Harry Oppenheimer, chairman of De Beers Consolidated Mines, Ltd., said in his annual report to shareholders today that the United States recession had caused a serious drop in demand for gems and industrial diamonds toward the end of last year.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 13 -- A potentially important television exchange between this country and the Soviet Union is being attempted by the "Wide Wide World" Sunday afternoon television series.
BOSTON, May 13 -- The railroads are taking time out from their own economic troubles for a campaign to "polish off the coastal shipping lines," a ship executive charged today.
"PEOPLE who rent apartments don't examine them technically; they rely on their first impression and hope that everything else will be all right."
LONDON, May 13 -- Stock market prices made a late recovery today on the brighter prospects for a settlement of the railway pay dispute.

The southeast corner of Second Avenue and Fifty-first Street, a plot 106 by 100 feet, has been purchased by Henry Kibel, architect, for improvement with a nineteen-story apartment building to contain several duplex suites.

MIAMI BEACH, May 13 (AP) -- A report criticizing the Eisenhower Administration for "a woeful lack of leadership" in the civil rights field and for "ineptness" in the Middle East was handed today to delegates to the American Jewish Congress.

Coffee futures fell in active trading yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. Early trading was influenced by rumors, later denied, that Brazil would not stockpile coffee after June 1. The market also reflected quiet and easier actuals.

OSLO, Norway, May 13 -- The Norwegian Government has learned that Soviet Premier Nikita S. Khruschev believes the United States Administration wishes to postpone a summit meeting until after the Congressional elections in November.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- President Eisenhower sent four companies of marines and paratroopers into Caribbean bases tonight to back White House demands that Venezuela guarantee the safety of Vice President Richard M. Nixon.

EDMUND FULLER, school teacher, former publisher, novelist, literary critic and all-around man of letters, is an angry middle-aged man with a beard. Unlike the angry young men in England who don't seem to know what they are angry about, Mr. Fuller knows very well. He is incensed by a large proportion of the most popular and the most critically esteemed contemporary novels

Hats off to General Humberto Delgado -- a dynamic personality with a brilliant record of international service -- a true liberal and a man of vision as well as action -- who deserves a fair opportunity to voice the opinions of the enlightened of his country.
Better facilities for the aged yesterday received the public attention of two officials.
Senator Irving M. Ives has told friends that he will not seek re-election this year.

Your Cairo correspondent is incorrect in stating in your issue of May 6 that "during World Wars I and II the British occupied the Suez Canal Zone and closed the waterway to all enemy shipping, disregarding the 1888 convention."

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- The State Department has taken measures to end individual contacts between its intelligence officers and newspaper men, and to require reports from other officials on their conversations with reporters.
The Fire Department "poured it on" yesterday as it staged its mightiest display of water power to greet the new fireboat H. Sylvia A. H. G. Wilks.
The largest urban shopping center in the nation will begin to rise next spring on a twelve-acre site in downtown New Rochelle.
TO judge by a drama that is entitled "The Judge," H. C. Branner is an earnest and dejected dramatist.
PARIS, Wednesday, May 14 -- France had a new Government and a threat of civil war today.

Rachel Koefod, a pianist from Minnesota, gave her first local recital in several years last night in Carnegie Recital Hall. She began with Scarlatti, continued to Beethoven's E flat Sonata (Op. 7), the second book of Brahms' "Paganini Variations," Ravel's "Valses nobles et sentimentales" and Prokofieff's Third Sonata, and ended with three Chopin etudes.
WASHINGTON, May 13 -- The Joint Chiefs of Staff have recommended a substantial increase -- as much as $500,000,000 -- in the nation's capacity to produce plutonium for atomic weapons.
WASHINGTON, May 13 -- A natural gas company which was charged two weeks ago with criminal violations of the antitrust laws lost a round today in a related dispute over its expansion plans.

Members of the business advisory council of the Department of Commerce, which has been meeting at Hot Springs, Va., are reported, on the whole, to be "unworried about the economic outlook." Sinclair Weeks, Secretary of Commerce, told newsmen it was his guess that about 70 per cent of the Council members were opposed to a tax cut as a recession remedy.

PARIS, May 13 -- Khrushchev seems at last to be coming up against communism's implacable logic, a logic he sought to deny when first he denounced the brutal methods of Stalin. He now finds total dictatorship cannot become partial dictatorship; freedom is not a commodity capable of being rationed.
MONTREAL, Wednesday, May 14 (AP) -- An agreement ending the three-day-old firemen's strike against the Canadian Pacific Railway was signed a few minutes after midnight.
LOS ANGELES, May 13 (UP) -- The San Francisco Giants, led by Willie Mays and Daryl Spencer, each of whom hit two homers, today scored a 16-9 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers before 10,507 fans.
The two French generals who moved yesterday in separate actions to bring order to rebel-torn Algiers represent contradictory types in professional soldiery: the cautious and the daring.
The United States will "lose the world-wide economic struggle with Soviet Russia if Congress kills or multilates the reciprocal trade bills," Eric Johnston said last night.
WASHINGTON, May 13 (AP) -- Following is the roll-call vote by which the Senate passed tonight the depressed areas bill:
The Appellate Division yesterday unanimously affirmed a two-to-four-year sentence imposed upon John G. (Steve) Broady, former private investigator and lawyer, for unlawful wiretapping.
NEXT Monday night the main auditorium in Carnegie Hall will be packed with an audience for Van Cliburn's piano concert.
The Carnegie Endowment for International Peace called yesterday for new efforts to "revitalize existing machinery" for the peaceful settlement of international disputes.
CAIRO, May 13 (UP) -- The United Arab Republic drew up new legislation today abolishing Egyptian and Syrian citizenship and designating the people solely as "Arabs."
ALGIERS, May 13 (AP) -- General Massu, in announcing the formation of his group, said:
Cotton futures declined on the New York Cotton Exchange 2 to 18 points (10 to 90 cents a bale) yesterday in modest business.
WASHINGTON, May 13 -- An early Senate decision on the construction and sale by the Government of two superliners was foreshadowed today.

The burden of odds-on favoritism proved too much for the Cain Hoy Stable's Red God at Belmont Park yesterday. The 4-year-old son of Nasrullah was unplaced in the mile race that featured the program, the victory going to the Bohemia Stable's Ambehaving.

The National Jewish Hospital at Denver presented its 1958 honor award last night to Adam L. Gimbel, president of Saks Fifth Avenue. The exercises were held at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel during the fifty-ninth anniversary dinner of the hospital.

PHILADELPHIA, May 13 -- Mayo Smith's slumping Phillies, knocked by local critics following four straight setbacks and seven reverses in their last nine outings, did a bit of knocking of their own tonight. They knocked the world champion Milwaukee Braves out of first place in the National League, as Robin Roberts hurled the home side to a 5-2 victory.
Queen Elizabeth II of England, who usually adheres faithfully to an iron-bound schedule, broke it the other day to admire an American-designed chemise dress.

The intense effort within the Ways and Means Committee to force the Administration to make further compromises on the reciprocal trade bill before the measure is even reported out to the House floor may look like realism but actually is defeatism and ought to be firmly rebuffed.

THIS may be, as some sociologists contend, the era of expense account dining; that is, when a company foots the bill for a dinner for two that may add up to $60 or more. But many people who eat out -- by inclination or necessity -- must do so on a limited budget.
LAGOS, Nigeria, May 13 -- Crude oil exports from Nigeria have reached 90,000 tons since the first shipment left Port Harcourt three months ago.

LEVITTOWN, L. I., May 13 -- The foster parents of 4-year-old Laura Neuberger said today that they would appeal a court decision that a private welfare agency had the right to reclaim her. The decision was made yesterday by the Appellate Division.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 13 -- Foreign Minister Charles Malik accused the United Arab Republic today of having instigated and aided the rebellion here against the pro-Western Government.
Herman Katz, 58-year-old Assemblyman from Manhattan's Tenth Assembly District, was appointed by the City Council yesterday as City Clerk. The post pays $15,000 a year.
CHICAGO, May 13 -- The executive director of the National Urban League said today that President Eisenhower's statement on racial discrimination was "thoroughly disappointing."

The Charpaul Holding Corporation has sold the fifteen-story and penthouse apartment building at 47 Plaza Street in Brook lyn. It had owned the building only three months. The building occupies a plot 157 by 135 feet and contains forty-seven apartments with four to nine rooms. The tax valuation is $570,000. Samuel Schwartz, the buyer, resold his contract of sale to an investor for cash over mortgages amounting to $590,000. Irving Bira was the broker.

Today's new film is "Cry Terror," a Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer melodrama, at the Victoria. James Mason, Rod Steiger, Inger Stevens and Neville Brand have the principal roles. The producers are Virginia and Andrew L. Stone. Mr. Stone wrote and directed.

GERMANTOWN, Md., May 13 (UP) -- A group protesting nuclear tests ended a seven-day hunger strike today after a "long and friendly" meeting with Lewis L. Strauss, chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission.
A stiff new Code of Ethics for city officials, designed to avoid conflicts of interest in city government, has been nearly completed, Mayor Wagner made known yesterday.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 13 -- A psychiatrist said today that encephalitis, a comparatively mild brain disease, contributed to the nation's juvenile delinquency problems.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 13 -- E. S. Shersnhev of the Soviet Union asserted today that the recession in the United States "may not have reached its nadir."

New York banking sources expressed no surprise at reports from Rio de Janeiro that the Brazilian cruzeiro, as quoted on the free market, had fallen to a new low of 137.5 to the dollar within the last two days.
ONLY forty-five minutes from Broadway -- in the cross-town traffic -- is Seventh Avenue, the goal of aspiring fashion designers.

BONN, Germany, May 13 -- The use of former Marshall Plan funds to finance long-term credits for industrial development programs in the Middle East was reported in reliable quarters today to be under Cabinet consideration.
Mrs. Albert D. Lasker received the annual award of the Park Association of New York City yesterday for her contribution toward beautifying the city.

Mayor Wagner and representatives of foreign nations praised the second United States World Trade Fair yesterday as an outstanding success. The Mayor announced that the international exhibit, currently in progress at the Coliseum, would return next year.

Reflecting substantially larger sales, net income of the United Aircraft Corporation and its domestic subsidiaries increased to $11,543,934 in the first quarter this year from $10,967,663 in the corresponding period a year ago.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- Gross national product, the measure of the nation's output of goods and services, was even lower in the first quarter of the year than preliminary estimates had indicated, the Commerce Department reported today.

EXCEPT for the Milwaukee Braves all the serious National League pennant contenders are wallowing in the second division. It's still much too early for definite conclusions, but there are enough telltale signs for folks to interpret, if they are so inclined. The Braves popped into Yankee Stadium on Monday night for an exhibition game with the Yanks, and everybody was thinking much the same.
There was a discordant note at the headquarters of the Board of Education in Brooklyn yesterday as Charles H. Silver was elected to his fifth term as president.
WASHINGTON, May 13 (UP) -- Representative Francis E. Walter, chairman of the House Immigration Subcommittee, introduced a bill today designed to prevent long delays in the deportation of aliens.

The American Die Casting Institute yesterday announced its support of the Administration's minerals stabilization plan and urged President Eisenhower to recommend the bill to Congress. Proposed recently by Secretary of the Interior Fred A. Seaton, the plan calls for subsidies to domestic producers of lead, zinc, copper, tungsten and acid-grade fluorspar.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 13 -- The founders of CARE honored Arthur C. Ringland as "father" of the organization today at a luncheon commemorating the twelfth anniversary of the delivery of its first food package to Europe.

New York State borrowed $40,000,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance the construction of highways and mental health institutions. The money was raised by the sale of obligations due serially from 1959 to 1978.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- A public inquiry will begin tomorrow into the circumstances of a labor relations contract negotiated by the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company and Max Block, president of two local unions of the Amalgamated Meat Cutters and Butcher Workmen.
GARDEN CITY, L. I., May 13 -- The present record-breaking efforts in research leave no doubt that the recession is only an interval between booms, a Government business official said here today.

Hamilton-Madison House Settlement will gain from a supper dance to be held Saturday in the ballroom of the Pierre. E. Irving Stankman, Harvey J. Chanler and Andrew Rosenthal are co-chairmen of the event.

First-quarter earnings of M. Lowenstein Sons, Inc., were "about twice the amount we earned in the last quarter of 1957 but were down from the first quarter last year," Leon Lowenstein, chairman, reported to stockholders at the annual meeting here yesterday.
Forty United States college students will go to the Soviet Union in July and twenty Soviet students will arrive here to see how Americans live.

SPRING LAKE, N. J., May 13 -- Fred Baker of Maplewood, a former champion, took the first round lead in the New Jersey Professional Golfers Association's 72-hole medal play golf championship today with a 35, 38 -- 73 at the Homestead Country Club.

LONDON, May 13 -- Britain gave a welcome of traditional pageantry today to President Giovanni Gronchi of Italy and Signora Gronchi upon their arrival for a three-day state visit. It was the first such exchange between the two countries since the days of Mussolini.
The Moiseyev Dance Company from Moscow will give eight performances instead of the four originally scheduled at Madison Square Garden in its return engagement here beginning June 20.
There is no evidence of a recession in the lively and steady activity of commercial buyers "shopping" at the second United States World Trade Fair at the New York Coliseum.

First-quarter earnings of the International Paper Company declined to $16,159,746 from $18,634,515 in the corresponding period last year. John H. Hinman, chairman, reported at the annual meeting here yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 14 -- A proposal approved by President Eisenhower today would make available to the states about $150,000,000 a year to finance functions now performed by the Federal Government.
WASHINGTON, May 14 (UP) -- The nation's airlines complained today that red tape on the ground was fouling up their flights.

CHICAGO, May 14 (UP) -- Lee Walls, the National League home run leader, hit his eleventh of the season, batted in two runs and scored three today as the Chicago Cubs broke a seven-game losing streak with a 7-3 triumph over the Los Angeles Dodgers.
One of the six harp seals in captivity -- all are at the Aquarium -- has been on a hunger strike since Sunday.

ST. LOUIS, May 14 (UP) -- Vinegar Bend Mizell turned in his best performance of the year, a four-hitter, for a 3-2 St. Louis Cardinals' victory over the San Francisco Giants tonight. It was his second victory in five decisions.
LONDON, May 14 -- The British capital was watching tonight for indications of whether the seizure of power in Algeria by the French Army commanders would lead to an upheaval in France.
WESTBURY, L. I., May 14 -- Selection, a 13-1 shot, had to race on the outside much of the way to win the Summer Rose Pace at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- Supporters of the Administration's reciprocal trade bill perfected a two-part package of concessions to tariff protectionists today in an effort to ward off crippling amendments in the House of Representatives.

Four floors in the new office building at 635 Madison Avenue, at Fifty-ninth Street, have been leased to Vision, Inc., magazine publisher. Joseph P. Blitz, Inc., is the builder and owner. The lease was negotiated by Matthew Stacom, vice president of Cushman Wakefield, Inc., agent for the building.
BOSTON, May 14 -- Support in the United States for the establishment of Churchill College at Cambridge University will be led by Carl J. Gilbert, a Boston industrialist.

The Esso Standard Oil Company, domestic affiliate of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey), announced yesterday the development of two premium grades of gasoline designed to reduce deposits in combustion chambers.

There seems to be a fairly general impression that there is a way to reverse the present recession quickly, if we could only discover the remedy and apply it. Is it not possible that such an assumption is unwarranted and that a somewhat different approach is called for?

Happy Princess refused to slow down when she was expected to in the $24,500 Distaff Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday. The 6-year-old daughter of Princequillo maintained the lead throughout the seven-furlong handicap and scored a surprise victory over Outer Space and Searching.
BOSTON, May 14 (AP) -- A $120,000 breach-of-contract suit against Herbert A. Philbrick, former counterspy for the Federal Bureau of Investigation, opened today in Federal Court.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- The Library of Congress celebrated today the facsimile reproduction of one of its greatest treasures. It is the scrapbook that Lincoln made and annotated as his historical record of the debate with Stephen Douglas.

Irving M. Ives has devoted himself to the public service for more than a quarter of a century. Elected to the New York State Assembly in 1930, he became in turn minority leader, Speaker, then majority leader. In 1946 he was elected to the United States Senate, and is now completing his second term.
Ralph Bellamy, reconsidering an earlier decision, has decided to accept the independent ticket nomination for a third term as president of Actors Equity Association.

CHICAGO, May 14 -- Following is the text of a proposal submitted in Federal District Court today by E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co. in the Federal suit for disposal of the company's General Motors stock:
President Eisenhower sent his best wishes as 150 students last night at a surprise dinner in in honor of Lawrence H. Chamberlain, who is retiring as dean of Columbia College next month.

DETROIT, May 14 (AP) -- Cleveland staged a five-run rally in the ninth inning to defeat the Detroit Tigers, 9 -- 8, today. Billy Harrell stole home for the third run in the Indians' uprising and Roger Maris blasted his second two-run homer of the game for the last two tallies.
Unemployment insurance claims in many industrial states continued their general decline last week but the data were too mixed to be conclusive.
NEVER before have expectant mothers been so accommodated by a fashion trend.
The withdrawal of Senator Irving M. Ives as a candidate for re-election added a new dimension yesterday to New York's political campaign this fall.
CHICAGO, May 14 -- The public is rightfully alarmed about juvenile delinquency, the chief of the United States Children's Bureau declared here today.
WASHINGTON, May 14 -- Senate and House conferees, after more than two months of jockeying, reached an agreement tonight on postal rate and pay increases.

Bob Turley of the Yankees appears to deal only in shut-outs when he pitches against the Orioles. Yesterday at the Yankee Stadium he blanked Baltimore for the third time this season and ran his scoreless string against the Birds to twenty-seven innings, which just matches his age.

ROSCOE, N. Y., May 14 -- Dark flies, both wet and dry, did brisk business for a while today, but not for long. The patterns didn't seem to make much difference. Light flies were useless. The water was cold, the air was cold and no flies were hatching.

The great advantage of air mail service is that the Post Office moves letters more rapidly over the long jumps between cities here and abroad, but when the idea of using airplanes to carry mail was first brought up for discussion by a Congressional committee speed was scarcely mentioned.

These menus, which appear each Thursday, use seasonally abundant foods and are moderate in cost. They are designed to strike a balance between appetite appeal and the convenience of the family cook. Dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.

WASHINGTON, May 14 (UP) -- John C. Doerfer, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, said today that no television station could meet F. C. C. standards without using equipment patented by the Radio Corporation of America.
DUBLIN, May 14 -- Seaboard and Western Airlines of America plans to invest 500,000 ($1,400,000) in Irish Air Lines, (Aerlinte Eireann Teoranta), it was announced tonight.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- The Federal Reserve Board reported today that the condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities showed the following principal changes for the week ended Wednesday, May 7:

Harry Canelstein, New York realty operator and builder, has contracted to buy the one-story taxpayer containing 15,000 square feet of space at Queens Boulevard and Sixty-second Avenue, Forest Hills, Queens. Safeway Food Stores is the major tenant.
A new policy to increase the number of regularly appointed teachers in the city's "difficult" elementary schools has been approved by Dr. William Jansen, Superintendent of Schools.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, May 14 -- The army high command tonight banned barter trade in South Sumatra. The move seemingly was aimed at shoring up Indonesia's deteriorating economy.
WASHINGTON, May 14 (UP) -- The United States Conference of Mayors asked Congress today to spend $5,000,000,000 over the next ten years to clear away city slums.
WASHINGTON, May 14 (UP) -- President Eisenhower said today he believed all states could participate in liberalized unemployment benefits under a watered-down House version of his jobless pay bill.

Top leaders in industry and finance have supported the Greater New York Fund with out stint since its founding twenty years ago. They realize that support of the voluntary agen cies affiliated with the fund is vital to the community and those who work in it, resident and commuter alike.
WASHINGTON, May 14 -- President Eisenhower approved today the purchase of three jet transport planes for use by him and other top Government officials.
Business men were chided by a trade official yesterday for talking about "hard sell" but doing little about it.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., May 14 (AP) -- Leaders of the American Jewish Congress today linked new demands for solving the nation's racial and minority issues to violence in Venezuela against Vice President Richard M. Nixon.
SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, May 14 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon landed at San Juan's international airport tonight, having cut short his visit to Venezuela.

BROWNSVILLE, Tex., May 14 (UP) -A Federal Grand Jury has indicted eight persons, arrested Feb. 17, near Houston with an arsenal and a yacht, on charges of having violated the Neutrality Act by plotting to overthrow the Cuban Government, it was disclosed today.
LONDON, May 14 -- The British Government declined tonight to ask the United States to move its naval base in Trinidad to make room for a capital for the new West Indies Federation.
The economic recession was attributed yesterday by a labor leader to a "handful of people who control our economy."
The "float" of undistributed corporate bonds is visibly down from the uncomfortable level of a week ago, but the break-up of two syndicates had something to do with it.
ALGIERS, May 14 (Reuters) -- General Massu said today that the Committee of Public Safety "could not make any decision itself because everything must be approved by General Salan."
CAIRO, May 14 -- The Government of the United Arab Republic curtly refused today to accept a Lebanese note of protest charging it with "massive interference" in the crisis in Lebanon.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 14 -- The first working arrangement between a Japanese and an American film company was announced here today. Hugh Harman, president of Harman-Ising Productions, reported that the company would join with the Doei Motion Picture Company in the production of animated movies for both the world theatre market and industrial purposes.
The American Smelting and Refining Company yesterday cut the price of lead one-half cent a pound to 11 1/2 cents to meet competition of lower-priced metal available abroad.
WASHINGTON, May 14 (AP) -- The Federal Reserve Board said today that production by the nation's mines and factories declined in April for the eighth straight month.
DUBLIN, May 14 -- Twenty bachelors of Gowna, in County Cavan, have brought fame to this Irish village by beating the best-looking and best-baking of its girls in a baking contest.
ATLANTIC CITY, May 14 -- George Meany reported today that private talks between labor and Senate leaders had resulted in a "considerable area of agreement" on legislation to stamp out union rackets.

TWO period pieces, one composed only last year, the other in 1929, were presented last night at the little auditorium of the Baron de Rothschild Foundation for the Arts and Sciences at 316 East Sixty-third Street.

A SINGLE element -- the triangle -- serves Robert Kabak as the formal basis for his paintings at the Salpeter Gallery, 42 East Fifty- seventh Street. This ubiquitous triangle alters only in color or elongation. It is repeated in combination that at times accent the faceted character of Kabak's forms and at times appear patchwork quilt flat.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- It is neither surprising nor unusual that in the discussions in official circles today of the violent foreign demonstrations on May 13 against various symbols of the United States there was widespread agreement as to causes and very little as to cures.
A tour of nine penthouse gardens and town houses is being arranged by the women of St. Thomas Church. The event will take place Tuesday and Wednesday from 2 to 5:30 P. M.
TOKYO, Thursday, May 15 (UP) -- The International Olympic Committee chairman, Avery Brundage, said late yesterday that the 1960 Winter Games at Squaw Valley, Calif., would be held from Feb. 18 to 28.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- The Senate rackets committee began hearings today on allegations that the Great Atlantic Pacific Tea Company in metropolitan New York made a collusive five-year labor agreement in 1952.
WASHINGTON, May 14 (UP) -- Following is the transcript of President Eisenhower's news conference today:

The Mutual Broadcasting System was reported last night to be undergoing another shake-up in management -- the second in less than three months. Two executives are known to have resigned and the status of several others was said to be in doubt.

At least one ambitious industrial expansion plan will be carried out despite the business recession. The Linde Company, a division of the Union Carbide Corporation, is erecting a huge oxygen plant and pipeline system to serve the United States Steel Corporation.

The public dispatch of 1,000 marines and paratroopers to Caribbean bases in reply to the outrageous attack in Venezuela on Vice President and Mrs. Nixon could not do anyone any good and seems certain to do the United States harm.
The Administration's proposal to subsidize the ailing nonferrous metals mining industry received the enthusiastic support yesterday of Robert P. Koenig, president of the Cerro de Pasco Corporation.

On Feb. 12, 1956, Mayor Wagner told a television audience that the city administration and the Port of New York Authority would "get together in the not too distant future" to discuss the possibility of turning over New York City's waterfront properties to the authority for modernization.

The General Public Utilities Corporation reported yesterday an increase of about 4 per cent in first-quarter revenues of domestic subsidiaries. This was despite a decline of 3.4 per cent in industrial revenues.

FLEMINGTON, N. J., May 14 (AP) -- Steel production, a major barometer of United States industrial health, should improve in the final three months of 1958, Charles M. White, chairman of Republic Steel Corporation, said today.
WHITE PLAINS, May 14 -- The 10-cent toll on Westchester County's parkways will become 25 cents at midnight. Few seemed happy about it today.
The $1,000,000 painting by Georges Seurat, "La Grande Jatte," was sent back to its owner, the Art Institute of Chicago, yesterday after nearly two months of separation.
A man believed to have been burglarizing a seventh - floor apartment on West Fifty-fifth Street plunged to his death last night when the occupant of the apartment returned home.

MADRID, May 14 -- Generalissimo Francisco Franco has decided to restore the monarchy in Spain eventually, on condition that it fits into the "framework" of the Falangist regime he has headed since 1938.
Physicians in New York State have been authorized by the State Medical Society to increase their charges in workmen's compensation cases by 30 to 35 per cent after July 1.
WASHINGTON, May 14 (AP) -- Angry criticism from Canada hit the United States today, after a Senate committee had revived the Norman case that aroused Canadians a year ago.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., May 14 -- Dozens of crew-cut college boys cut classes with blithe impunity this morning, stashed golf clubs into their automobiles and churned up the narrow road into the Bonnie Briar Country Club about 9 o'clock. Then they began a tense, sober day in the annual Metropolitan Intercollegiate golf championship.
LA PAZ, Bolivia, May 14 (AP) -- Revolutionists have seized the city of Santa Cruz and much of the surrounding province in the oil region of eastern Bolivia, the Government said tonight.

PARIS, May 14 -- The danger of civil war in France and Algeria receded slightly today with the adoption of conciliatory positions by a dissident military-civilian junta in Algiers and a new Government in Paris.

MOSCOW, May 6 -- A Soviet biologist somewhere in Siberia could snuggle up in bed and read comfortably about the whistling habits of bobwhites in Iowa, the annual report of the Calcutta inland fisheries research station, a Japanese study of the effects of radioactivity in bikini waters and the isolation of a rabies virus from native Ohio bats.
More men were homeless and hungry in New York last winter than at any time since 1941, the Community Council of Greater New York reported yesterday.
LONDON, May 14 -- The railroad dispute moved closer to settlement today as one union accepted a pay rise offer and the Executive Committee of another recommended acceptance.
Dean Edward W. Barrett of the Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism announced yesterday the appointment of an advisory committee for the school's advanced science writing program.

CHICAGO, May 14 -- E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co. proposed in Federal District Court here today a plan designed to satisfy a Supreme Court ruling that it divorce itself from the General Motors Corporation.
CHICAGO, May 14 -- The United Steelworkers of America voted today to seek higher wages and improved fringe benefits for 214,631 union members in metal fabricating plants.

WASHINGTON, May 14 (AP) -- The number of children attending half-day sessions in city grade schools has risen 20 per cent in two years and is still climbing, the National Education Association reported today.
Curb space along the city's nearly 6,000 miles of streets is becoming so scarce that it is difficult to find a place to park, even illegally.
WHITE PLAINS, May 14 -- Westchester's expanding facilities for the elderly were inspected today by state legislators. They liked what they found.

LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., May 14 -- Mrs. F. K. Thayer of the home club fired a 79 to take low-gross honors today in the Women's Long Island Golf Association's opening one-day tournament of the season at the Piping Rock Club.
HARRIMAN, N. Y., May 14 -- Leading electronic engineers were challenged today to develop a device that would stop a car if the driver were drunk.
WASHINGTON, May 14 -- President Eisenhower virtually ruled out today the use of additional public works as a cure for the recession.

Early this month the Department of Commerce "beat the gun" by about ten days to spread the word that unemployment had turned down slightly in April, a point that drew an optimistic comment from the President at his news conference of that day.

Most commodity futures markets here were dull yesterday. Prices moved irregularly higher. Cocoa, wool, rubber, lead and soybean oil rose; hides, copper and zinc declined, and price movements for potatoes, sugar, coffee and cottonseed oil were mixed.

Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz warned the public yesterday against buying "worthless" stock in the Texas Union Oil Corporation. He said that "suckers" had already paid more than $1,000,000 for it through over-the-counter securities dealers who used "typical boiler-room tactics."
New Yorkers donated 1,320,000 pints of blood through the Red Cross in the first ten years of the organization's regional blood program here -- May 5, 1948, to May 5, 1958.

In an exciting match that was decided on the last green, Montclair defeated Ridgewood, 8 1/2 to 6 1/2, to win the New Jersey title of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's inter-club series yesterday.

ALBANY, May 14 -- James E. Allen Jr., State Commissioner of Education, declined yesterday to set aside a decision reached by a controversial school bond referendum in Glen Cove, L. I. In the special election last Oct. 22, a bond issue of $2,800,00 for a new high school was approved by nineteen votes.

PASSAIC, N. J., May 14 -- Two brothers, picked up early today in near-by Clifton, N. J., have confessed the slaying of Patrolman Robert Strone here on May 8, according to Deputy Attorney General John G. Thevos.

The work of the Association for the Help of Retarded Children will be furthered by the proceeds from the organization's ninth annual dinner dance. The event will be held Sunday in the Grand Ballroom of the Astor.
As District Attorney Frank S. Hogan put it yesterday: "A laundryman took six investors to the cleaners."

LONDON, May 14 -- The Royal Opera House at Covent Garden, now playing as great a role as ever in the history of the theatre world, will be 100 years old tomorrow. But the birthday party will not be held until June 10.

MANKIND has gloried in feats of strength from the Neanderthal days onward. But once machinery began replacing biceps, muscles went slightly out of style and the emphasis switched from brawn to brains. Even in the realm of sport considerable respect always has been accorded to athletes who have the mental agility to go with their physical prowess.
New England vacationlands will get more air service this summer than ever before, Northeast Airlines has announced.
A decline of 1,280,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks in the week ended last Friday was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute.

Three high school marching bands will participate in next Tuesday's ticker-tape parade in honor of pianist Van Cliburn. The bands are from the High School of Performing Arts, Samuel Gompers High School and St. John's School.
Intercontinental troubles caught the stock market in a relatively defenseless posture yesterday. The total market value of New York Stock Exchange issues dropped about $2,400,000,000.
BONN, Germany, May 14 -- The West German Government bowed today to the demand of the East German Government for official negotiations on the inland waterways linking the two states.

Henry Korn of Archbishop Stepinac, White Plains, established a meet record in the 12-pound shot-put yesterday in the field-events competition of the Bronx - Manhattan - Westchester Catholic High Schools Athletic Association championships at Mt. St. Michael Field, the Bronx.

A public hearing yesterday on a new road for heavier traffic through historic Washington Square Park produced an overwhelming array of witnesses against such plans. Most even favored closing the square to all vehicles.
WASHINGTON, May 14 -- Senator Irving M. Ives announced this afternoon that he would not seek a third term this fall.

CHICAGO, May 14 -- Martin R. Gainsbrugh said today that a new survey by the National Industrial Conference Board of New York pointed to a decline in spending by manufacturers on plant expansion, not only through this year but into next year as well.

France is going through what the French call "a crisis of the regime." Of all the things that can be said about the startling developments in Algeria, where the equivalent of a military revolt took place on Tuesday, that is the most important. The very foundations of the Fourth Republic are being shaken, and no one can say yet whether the precarious structure will stand.
ALGIERS, May 14 -- The nightmare that seized Algiers yesterday appeared to have spent itself in twenty-four hours.
BEING in a cheerful frame of mind George Panetta has written an exuberant low comedy, "Comic Strip," which had a hearty performance at the Barbizon-Plaza last evening.
PITTSBURGH, May 14 (UP) -- Vernon Law pitched his fifth straight triumph tonight as the Pirates edged the Cincinnati Redlegs, 5 -4, for their sixth victory in a row.
Net income of the Ingersoll-Rand Company for the quarter ended March 31 was reported yesterday at $7,594,000, against $8,974,000 in the first three months last year.
An actor who was with Frank Costello when he was shot a year ago testified yesterday that he did not see anyone leaving the scene just after the shooting.

John R. Inglis, the professional at the Fairview Country Club, Elmsford, N. Y., is a record-holding job-holder. He's been at Fairview for fifty years. The course has had three locations since J. R. assumed his post in 1908. During that span he estimates he has given approximately 10,000 golf lessons.
WARSAW, May 14 -- Poland registered a mild but noticeable dissent today from the Soviet bloc's campaign of vituperation against Yugoslavia.
An admiral took command of the Propeller Club of the Port of New York last night when Rear Admiral George Wauchope of the Reserve was elected president for the coming year.
WASHINGTON, May 14 -- President Eisenhower made these main points at his news conference today:
WASHINGTON, May 14 -- It was made plainer than ever today by President Eisenhower that he would use his full powers whenever necessary to enforce school integration orders of the Federal courts.
Confidence in the future of the Port of New York as a foreign trade gateway was expressed here yesterday as construction was begun on a $7,500,000 Brooklyn waterfront cargo ship terminal.

The first Theresa Helburn prize of $2,500 for the best play with freedom for its theme was awarded yesterday to "The Firstborn." Miss Helburn, co-administrator of the Theatre Guild, made the presentation after the matinee on the stage of the Coronet Theatre. The tribute was witnessed by the afternoon theatregoers.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- The Senate Interstate and Foreign Commerce Committee today scheduled quick hearings on only one phase of its subcommittee's broad program for aid to the railroads, the rate making aspect.

WASHINGTON, May 14 (AP) -- Representative Emanuel Celler, Democrat of New York, cracking out again at top officials of major league baseball, declared today a House committee report undermined critics of his sports bill.
LONDON, May 14 (AP) -- The British Government refused permission today for a thirty-five-story Hilton Hotel to be built on London's fashionable Park Lane.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 14 -- Charles E. McKeogh, deputy chief of the New York Fire Department, has accepted a three-month assignment with the United Nations. Beginning June 1, he is to teach fire-fighting techniques in Israel under the world organization's Technical Assistance Administration.

The American Legion national commander, John S. Gleason Jr., last night urged support of President Eisenhower's plan to reorganize the Defense Department. He said at a dinner in his honor at the Commodore Hotel that the Legion held the plan "imperative."

A TWO - PART television treatment of "All the King's Men" began promisingly last night on Channel 4. The adaptation by Don Mankiewicz of Robert Penn Warren's Pulitzer Prize novel of eleven years ago was shown on the "Kraft Television Theatre."
" Gigi," Metro - Goldwyn-Mayer's film version of the Colette novel, with new songs by Frederick Loewe and Alan Jay Lerner, will open at the Royale Theatre tonight at 8:30.

State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz, charged yesterday that Govenor Harriman had wielded his veto power solely to strip the Republican majority in the Legislature of credit for an "outstanding" legislative record.
CHICAGO, May 14 (AP) -- Short interests in the May wheat futures contract apparently began chopping away in earnest today on the Board of Trade in an effort to even their commitments.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, May 14 -- Wladyslaw Gomulka, Polish party chief, made a speech tonight at the Bucharest Sports Stadium and signed a joint declaration as the climax of his three-day solidarity visit.
Plans have been announced for a celebrity cocktail party for the benefit of the New York Arthritis and Rheumatism Foundation. It will be held in the Roof and Penthouse of the St. Regis on June 3.
WASHINGTON, May 14 (AP) -- Four Senators described a bill to curb the Supreme Court's powers today as based on a "kill the umpire" philosophy.
