These are days when I find myself getting a little impatient with people in responsible places who are upset by reports of Russia's growing industrial strength and yet do nothing about our infinitely greater economic potential. I think what we are suffering from is the consequence of indecision.
WASHINGTON, May 14 -- Scientists are seeking ways to sterilize their first lunar rockets so as not to contaminate the moon with worldly forms of life.
PARAMUS, N. J., May 14 -- The New Jersey Highway Authority set out today to prove that its Garden State Parkway offered the best route from northern New Jersey to White Plains.

PHILADELPHIA, May 14 -- Warren Spahn, the $60,000-a-year southpaw ace of the Milwaukee Braves, is baseball's highest-paid pitcher and no one around here asks, "Why?" Tonight at Connie Mack Stadium the 37 - year - old left - hander hurled the world champions to a 4-1 victory over the Phillies: The last time the Phillies faced Spahn here they were blanked, 5 -- 0.
The first public distribution of shares of The One William Street Fund, Inc., a new investment company sponsored by the banking house of Lehman Brothers, is scheduled today.
DETROIT, May 14 (UP) -- John D. Leary, vice president of the Chrysler Corporation, told Walter P. Reuther today that members of the United Auto Workers were not giving Chrysler a fair day's work.
A convicted labor racketeer, who had balked at testifying before a Senate investigating committee about a shakedown, pleaded guilty yesterday to a charge of coercion.
NEWARK, May 14 -- The State Attorney General's office opened its inquiry into the operations of the Passaic Valley Sewerage Commission today.
WASHINGTON, May 14 (AP) -- The United States Chamber of Commerce urged Congress today to prohibit compulsory union membership and make unions subject to antitrust laws.
James Caesar Petrillo announced yesterday that he would lay down the baton he has wielded over 260,000 union musicians for eighteen years.

South Carolina borrowed $25,000,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance highway and port improvements. The money was raised by the sale of serial bonds due from 1959 to 1978 to a syndicate headed by the Chase Manhattan Bank and the Bankers Trust Company.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 14 -- The United States will ship arms to Lebanon by plane within the next two days to help the Government keep order in the face of a revolt stirred by outside forces.
A 14-year-old Brooklyn boy was shot three times last night and critically wounded when, according to the police, he tried to flee from custody after a loaded zip gun had been taken from him.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., May 14 (AP) -- The textile industry, already with its back to the wall, can expect the situation to worsen unless mill owners create new products and markets, union men warned today.
WASHINGTON, May 14 (UP) -- The Senate passed today and sent to the House a bill to require all new cars to carry retail price tags and other information for prospective buyers.

Dr. Robert S. Woodworth faced a class last night for the last time. At 9:15 o'clock in a lecture room at Columbia University the 88-year-old dean of American psychology concluded a teaching career that started sixty-seven years ago.

Events tonight: "Cosi fan tutte," Ninety-second Street Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Association, 8:15 concert of music by John Cage Town Hall, 8:40; New York Recorder Ensemble, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:30.
WASHINGTON, May 14 (AP) -- President Eisenhower said today he favored revising the Administration's civilian space agency bill to meet objections.
LONDON, May 14 -- The stock market lost some of its recent buoyancy today, although prices closed higher in most of the principal groups except oils.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- The United States said today it was doubling the amphibious marine strength of the Sixth Fleet. It also started an airlift of police equipment to Beirut and spoke words of encouragement to the Government of Lebanon.

Glore, Forgan Co. and Dominick Dominick head an underwriting group that is offering today $60,000,000 of National Distillers and Chemical Corporation 4 3/4 per cent sinking fund debentures due 1983, priced at 99.25 to yield 4.8 per cent.
The pleasant Teutonic features of Pierre Eugene Jean Pflimlin were familiar to his countrymen long before he became France's twenty-fifth post-World War II Premier yesterday.

Visitors to the World Trade Fair were treated to an added attraction yesterday. Prince Juan Carlos, who may someday be the King of Spain, trudged around the New York Coliseum, where the fair is being held.
EVERY man thinks of his wife as "the little woman." But until now, few dress manufacturers have sized her up that way.

Residents of Manhasset are to be congratulated for giving a landslide vote to the opponents of fluoridation in that Long Island district. If it starts a landslide of intelligence throughout the length and breadth of the island, so much the better for the health of adults and the dental well-being of children.
PARIS, May 14 -- Paris had the appearance of an armed camp today as police and rioters clashed for the second time in twenty-four hours.
Motorists from New Jersey found it four times easier at the Holland Tunnel here yesterday to pierce Manhattan's traffic curtain.
CARACAS, Venezuela, May 14 -- Caracas was quiet tonight after the departure of Vice President Nixon.
WASHINGTON, May 14 -- The capital will turn out tomorrow to give Vice President Richard M. Nixon a triumphant "welcome home" from his trip to eight Latin-American countries.

Medical care for those in New York State unable to pay themselves costs $240,000,000 annually, a hospital association was told last night. Raymond W. Houston, State Commissioner of Social Welfare, made the tabulation.

On a nation-wide television program, "Meet the Press," on May 11, one of our most distinguished creative scientists, Prof, Linus Pauling, was subjected to slander by insinuations from an obviously hostile panel of journalists.

A FOOD that is finding increased acceptance in the northern and northeastern states is rabbit. In its wild state, this animal has appeared for centuries on the tables of European gastronomes. However, it never has received a similar reception here, possibly because of certain considerations engendered by the Uncle Remus stories.
WASHINGTON, May 14 -- The House passed and sent to the Senate today a bill providing $2,958,000,000 in new authorizations for the foreign aid program through the fiscal year 1959.

LONDON, May 14 -- Sir Winston Churchill called today for the establishment of a men's college at Cambridge University to train an elite corps of scientists and technologists. The college would bear his name.

WESTBURY, L. I., May 15 -It was a long time and there were many starts between victories for Dick Wilcox. But the streak of "bad luck" ended for the 29-year-old Ohioan at Roosevelt Raceway tonight as he won with Wingsaway in the third race, a trot.

Tammany district leaders in Harlem voted 11-to-1 yesterday to read Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr. out of the Democratic party. They said their reason was his support of President Eisenhower in 1956.
WASHINGTON, May 15 -House investigators accused the Federal Communications Commission today of indifference to the public interest by permitting "trafficking" in television licenses.
Former President Herbert Hoover yesterday gave his full support to President Eisenhower's plan for Defense Department reorganization.

With commendable statesmanship the House of Representatives has approved by a two-to-one majority a mutual security program authorizing the expenditure of $3,603,000,000 during the next fiscal year to strengthen the defenses of the free world.

Cocoa futures climbed to new highs for the life of the contracts yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange. Trading was influenced by reports that Bahia grades again sold at prices higher than the minimum established by Brazil on Monday.
A quick but temporary tax cut was proposed at the annual meeting of the National Industrial Conference Board yesterday in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
WASHINGTON, May 15 -The National Labor Relations Board ruled today that organizers of the merged labor movement were nonmanagerial employes.

RABAT, Morocco, May 15 -If Gen. Charles de Gaulle is able to negotiate a cease-fire in Algeria by recognizing the independence of that country he will render an immense service to France, a spokesman of the Algerian National Liberation Front declared today.

THE thread of one young weaver's work has wound back and forth from fashions to furnishings. Currently (and permanently, he says) he is looming miles and miles of window shades and fabrics for draperies and upholstery.
DETROIT, May 15 (AP) -Roger Maris hit his fourth home run in three games and drove in two other runs with a double today, leading the Cleveland Indians to an 8-5 triumph over the Detroit Tigers.
Mikhail A. Menshikov, the Soviet Ambassador to the United States, upheld his "diplomacy of smiles" last night in addressing 600 journalists here.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -The House of Representatives passed a $570,722,613 StateJustice appropriations bill today. It acted after a squabble over whether the Central Intelligence Agency had given sufficient warning of the troubles Vice President Richard M. Nixon might encounter in Latin America.

JAKARTA, May 15 -- It was reported tonight that the Indonesian Air Force had destroyed six rebel planes and bombed two airfields in the defiant Northern Celebes in a series of raids apparently aimed at knocking out the rebels -air potential.
Awards for excellence of design in men's sportswear and accessories were announced yesterday by the sponsor of the competition, Caswell-Massey, perfumers and chemists.
BUFFALO, N. Y., May 15 (AP) -- The management of the Niagara Frontier Transit Company, Buffalo's only bus system, scored a victory today over a Philadelphia group seeking control.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 15 -- Dag Hammarskjold said today that he was "keenly interested" in the recent exchange between the United States and the Soviet Union on the possibility of technical disarmament studies.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 15 -The Very Rev. James Albert Pike exchanged today a deanery on Morningside Heights for a bishopric on Nob Hill.
Dr. Howard A. Rusk yesterday characterized creative work for the elderly as "the preventive medicine of the future."

Directors of Smith Kline French Laboratories yesterday elected Walter A. Munns president of the Philadelphia pharmaceutical concern. Mr. Munns, formerly executive vice president, succeeds Francis Boyer, president since 1951, who will reach the retirement age of 65 next month.
KANSAS CITY, May 15 (AP) -Four suits seeking an aggregate $186,750 under the Sherman Antitrust Act were filed in the United States District Court here yesterday against The Kansas City Star.

CHICAGO, May 15 (AP) -- After eleven consecutive days of advances, prices of butcher hogs turned downward today and the market was mostly 25 cents lower but as much as 50 cents lower in some instances.

It is spring now, and the country never has looked better. Flowers are in bloom, leaves are growing on the trees and, due to daylight saving, gardeners have an extra evening hour to examine all the work that must be done.
ATLANTIC CITY, May 15--A major victory for labor in military procurement policies was disclosed here today by Secretary of Labor James P. Mitchell.

The Merrimack-Essex Electric Company, a subsidiary of the New England Electric System, sold in the public market yesterday $20,000,000 of 4 1/2 per cent bonds that will take the place of a similar amount of 5 5/8 per cent bonds put out by the company during the money shortage period in 1957.
WASHINGTON, May 15 -- The possibility of an attempt by Gen. Charles de Gaulle to return to power caused apprehension in the State Department today.
A moderate rise in domestic deliveries of refined copper last month failed to prevent a further accumulation in producers' hands. Unsold stocks rose to the highest level since July, 1939.
Most communicable diseases will be wiped out the world over "within the foreseeable future," Dr. M. G. Candau, director-general of the World Health Organization, declared yesterday.
HONOLULU, May 15 (AP) -- An American Army sergeant selected today the Unknown Soldier of the Korean war.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -United States officials estimated today that it would be at least two years before this country would duplicate the Soviet feat of firing a scientific satellie weighing one and onehalf tons.
A brilliant object, believed to be the third Soviet satellite, was seen high in the sky yesterday over the Rocky Mountains in Colorado.
WASHINGTON, May 15 (AP) -- America's post-war boom in the price of farm land has hit a new high this year and shows no sign of slackening, the Agriculture Department said today.
CAIRO, May 15 -- The Nasser Government has rejected a strong protest by Iraq against propaganda attacks by the Cairo and Damascus radios, it was reported today.

Encouragement in the construction figures for April is found by George Cline Smith, vice president of the F. W. Dodge Corporation. He reports that awards for nonresidential building in thirty-seven states east of the Rocky Mountains were up 18 per cent over April, 1957.

In the midst of the rain and cold that caused postponement of yesterday's series finale with the Baltimore Orioles at the Yankee Stadium came the first definite report on the condition of Bill Skowron.

ONE day last week, Lord Taylor staged a showing of summer clothes in its Young New Yorker Shop. With the exception of Marie Mirisola, most of the designers' names sounded familiar. Not only was this name new, but the fashions shown by this designer also had a new look about them.
Most of the major steamship passenger lines of the country have applied to the Maritime Administration for the right to operate the new atomic cargopassenger liner Savannah.
Considerable interest is developing in some segments of the maritime industry for an unusual piece of legislation now before Congress.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -former employes of the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company testified today that supervisors whipped up support for a union in New York stores in 1952 and 1953 after having fought off other unions for years.
WASHINGTON, May 15 -The House Ways and Means Committee reached informal agreement today on a bill to continue the reciprocal trade program for five years.
WASHINGTON, May 15 (UP) -- The Department of Justice said today there appeared to be collusion in the newsprint industry to stifle competition. But it said antitrust action was difficult.

On Jan. 30, 1947, the Board of Estimate adopted unanimously a resolution declaring a city policy not to approve "the erection of a new bus terminal, or the permanent enlargement or extension of any existing bus terminal" east of Eighth Avenue in the congested midtown panel of Manhattan.
WEST POINT, N. Y., May 15 -- A tall young man in a Spanish midshipman's uniform gazed curiously today at a plebe of the United States Military Academy.
MANILA, May 15 -- The United States and Philippine Governments announced an agreement today on liaison with United States military bases here.
MOST Europeans don't credit Americans with "more taste than money," but Vogue magazine may change their opinions.
NEW DELHI, India, May 15 (AP) -- A Convair plane of the Pakistan National Airways crashed and burned after a take-off today. It fell in flames near the airport here.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- By reason of a fortuitous circumstance the Senate subcommittee inquiry into the soundness of the Administration's decision to send Vice President and Mrs. Nixon to South America, in view of information it had of adverse conditions there, will be directed by one of its harshest and most incessant critics, Wayne Morse of Oregon.
The fabled unicorn and the maiden, in whose sole power it lay to subdue him, became a recent permanent installation in terra cotta in an otherwise conservative new office building at 405 Park Avenue.

Three meet records were broken as Mount St. Michael won the team title yesterday in the twenty-ninth annual track and field championships of the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association Bronx-ManhattanWestchester division at Van Cortlandt Park Stadium.

Television rights to the late James Agee's "A Death in the Family" have been purchased by the Columbia Broadcasting System. A posthumous Pulitzer Prize for the novel was awarded to Mr. Agee last week.
PARIS, May 15 -- Paris was in a state of armed alert tonight after a day of uneasy calm.

PHILADELPHIA, May 15 -Sheriff William Lennox of Philadelphia denied today a charge that his deputies were arresting alleged evaders of the city's wage tax in "retaliation" against members of the New Jersey Wage Tax Protest League.

With rain-soaked Central Park as a set and a horse-drawn surrey and a mule as props, actors from nearly every show in town yesterday opened the fourth annual softball season of the Broadway Show League.

Premier Khrushchev did a little public gloating yesterday following the Soviet announcement that Sputnik III had been sent into space. The United States satellites, he said, are only the size of oranges and it would take many of them to equal the ton-and-a-half bulk of the latest Soviet device.

The first reaction to the return of Vice President and Mrs. Nixon to Washington must be thankfulness that they are back safe and unharmed. The reception that they received in Washington yesterday was a well-earned tribute to courage, persistence and good humor in the face of great provocations.
BOSTON, May 15 -- A manager of a good baseball team should not be content with a bunting and base-stealing strategy but should instruct his players to swing away.

Arthur H. Schwartz was elected president of the New York County Lawyers Association at the group's annual meeting at the Biltmore Hotel last night. The former justice of the New York Supreme Court succeeded Ben A. Matthews.

WASHINGTON, May 15 (UP) -- Wendell B. Barnes, director of the Small Business Administration, recommended today that Congress allow the Government to loan money to groups of private individuals to invest in the stock of small business concerns.
LONDON, May 15 (AP) -- Britain, Italy and Denmark, strong contenders for European Zone Davis Cup tennis honors, took 2-0 leads over their opponents today in second-round matches.

WASHINGTON, May 15 (UP) -- Representative Francis E. Walter, head of the House Committee on Un-American Activities, said today that there was "a tremendous lack of understanding of communism's true nature" among the American people.

DETROIT, May 15 (AP) -Russia's weightlifters defeated an American team in four of seven classes tonight. It was the same United States team that lost six of seven matches to the Russians on Monday night in Chicago.

New York City borrowed $47,300,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance school construction, street paving, the payment of claims against the city and the city's share of certain social security benefits for city employes.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -Biologists discussed today the possibility of using satellites to determine why birds and turtles head for home and why living organisms follow a twenty-fourhour cycle.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 15 -- A Yugoslav Communist theoretician hurled back tonight accusations of revisionism flung at President Tito by Moscow and Peiping.

CHICAGO, May 5 -- The Christiana Securities Company and the Delaware Realty and Investment Corporation today filed a joint memorandum in Federal District Court here endorsing the plan of E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co. to divest itself of control of the General Motors Corporation.
A dramatic increase in violent crime in a one-square-mile area of Morningside Heights near Columbia University was reported last night by Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy.

DISPLAYS of new decorating fabrics this week showed a continuation in the trend toward stripes, textures and architectural patterns, and a rise in impressionistic florals.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 15 -The capital of Lebanon has been a city of contrasts for the last few days.

ALBANY, May 15 (AP) -- The Court of Appeals refused today for the second time in two weeks to block New York City's Proposed Lincoln Square project. The state's highest court denied a new motion without comment.
ALGIERS, May 15 -- A spokesman for the junta in this city said tonight that delegates from other areas of Algeria would meet here tomorrow to form a governing council for all the territory.

No law says the Hudson must be cruised in May. This majestic canyon, which is more like a fjord or a Rhine than anything else in America, beckons pleasureboat owners throughout the season -- for a week-end, a week or a month. It's almost too good to be true.

INTO a loft of a many-storied building in Manhattan, a young man and an attractive blonde furtively enter. She apparently is running away from something, while he obviously is anticipating a sociable evening.
Miss Dorothy Shaver, president of Lord Taylor, Fifth Avenue department store, was honored yesterday for her "notable services to the mercantile interests of New York."

WASHINGTON, May 15 -The Director of the Budget formally confirmed today reports that the Government was expecting a budget deficit of $8,000,000,000 to $10,000,000,000 in the fiscal year that begins July 1.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., May 15 (UP) -- Ben Hogan sank a 25-foot putt on the eighteenth hole for a five-underpar 65 and a tie with Stan Mosel of Essex Fells, N. J., today in the opening round of the $10,000 Greenbrier open golf tournament.
PHILADELPHIA, May 15 (UP) -- Guy Rodgers, Temple University's all-America forward, today signed a one-year contract with the Philadelphia Warriors of the National Basketball Association.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon was welcomed home with extraordinary honors today from his turbulent Latin-American tour. HARRIMAN, N. Y., May 15 -- A bonus to states to plan electronically controlled highways was recommended here today. The suggestion was made at the first national conference on electronic controls and highway safety at Arden House. The advocates said it could follow the incentive plan recently adopted by Congress that provides a small bonus to states that agree to ban billboards from the new Federal Highway System.
Federal Judge Gregory F. Noonan yesterday dismissed a new trial application for three men convicted of conspiracy in the evasion of $850,000 in income taxes.

ALBANY, May 15 (AP) -- The Court of Appeals upheld today a state ban on showing of the motion picture "Lady Chatterley's Lover." By a 4-3 vote the state's highest court reversed a decision of the Appellate Division, Third Department.

Broadway has been promised another drama by John Osborne next season. One of his early works, "Epitaph for George Dillon," written in collaboration with Anthony Creighton, is to be imported from London. After spirited competition from rival managements, signs indicate that the rights will go to David Merrick and Joshua Logan.
Leaders in religion in New York, of both the clergy and the laity, have given of their time and abilities to The Greater New York Fund since its founding in 1938.
The Post Office motto notwithstanding, the mail did not go through yesterday.
DETROIT, May 15 -- The United Auto Workers union has instructed its members at General Motors plants to be prepared to continue work after the current contract expires on May 29.
United States satellite plans fail to cover four of the nine experiments being performed by Sputnik III, a well-informed scientist said yesterday.
Plans for the establishment of a repertory theatre in the Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts were advanced yesterday with the naming of a consultant and an Advisory Council on Drama.

Loans to business outstanding at the seventeen larger New York City banks declined $26,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. This compared with an increase of $49,000,000 in the comparable 1957 week.

A 38-year-old Filipino surgeon waived examination yesterday when he was arraigned in Brooklyn Felony Court on a charge of killing of a nurse. He was taken back to Brooklyn City Prison to await action of the grand jury.

CHICAGO, May 15 (AP) -- Activity in grain futures on the Board of Trade today was little more than a contest between longs and shorts in the May contracts, particularly in wheat.

I refer to the statement that "some Indonesian pilots have been training in Egypt, but there are few, if any, in the islands qualified to fly jets."
MIAMI BEACH, May 15 (AP) -- United States "appeasement" of Gamal Abdel Nasser, President of the United Arab Republic, was declared here today to be a factor in the anti-American riots in Lebanon.

HONOLULU, May 15 -- Competitors are beginning to chisel at the monopoly of Hawaii's surface freight traffic enjoyed by the Matson Navigation Company. It handles 98 per cent of freight on territorial docks.
MOSCOW, May 15 -- The Soviet Union roared back into the satellite race today by launching a new space vehicle that weighs nearly one and one-half tons.

BALTIMORE, May 15 (UP) -The eighty-second Preakness Stakes Saturday shaped up with twelve starters today as Martins Rullah joined the field and Staysail bowed out. The early favorite was Calumes Farm's Tim Tam, the Kentucky Derby winner trying to sweep the triple-crown races /or 3-yearolds. The Belmont Stakes on June 7 completes the series.

CARACAS, Venezuela, May 15 (AP) -- The police arrested three men today on charges of planning to kidnap Vice President Richard M. Nixon. The exiled security police of former dictator Marcos Perez Jimenez were linked to the alleged plot.

Sixty-five thousand Girl Scouts trooped to neighborhood street corners yesterday to distribute leaflets outlining "rules to live by." The activity marked the start of Neighborhood Pedestrian Safety Month here.

PHILADELPHIA, May 15 -Lew Burdette, the Milwaukee right-hander about whom Mayo Smith, the manager of the Phillies, used to say a nasty word -until silenced by Warren Giles, president of the National League -- was saved by the weather tonight.

The New York East Conference of the Methodist Church voted unanimously yesterday to admit a Negro congregation into membership. It was the first such action to be taken by any of the four conferences in the New York Area.

A hearing will be held in Surrogate's Court today on how descendants of Joseph Pulitzer, founder of The New York World, should divide a $5,411,811 balance from his Newspaper Trust.
PARIS, Friday, May 16 -Gen. Charles de Gaulle declared yesterday that he was ready to assume power again in France.

LONDON, May 15 -- considerable number of high-class industrial issues put on a few pennies today despite the hesitancy of buyers.

The Fedders-Quigan Corporation will start a six-day production week on some of its room air-conditioning units next week, Salvatore Giordano, president and chairman, announced yesterday. The company has been working a five-day week.
The United States Golf Association yesterday announced a record total of 2,140 entries for the 1958 National Open championship. The previous high was 1,928, in 1954.

ST. LOUIS, May 15 (AP) -- Willie Mays and Jim King hit home runs today as the San Francisco Giants topped St. Louis, 4 -- 2, ending the Cardinals' winning streak at seven games.

The Sunbeam Corporation, producer of household electrical appliances, had the third largest sales and earnings in its history in the year ended March 29, according to the annual report of H. C. Wright, chairman, and R. P. Gwinn, president.
THE fall fashion look can be summed up in two words: trapeze and chemise. This is the message Seventh Avenue delivered before the Fashion Group yesterday at a showing at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

A Puerto Rican setting will provide the background for the annual spring benefit party of the New York chapter of the National Multiple Sclerosis Society. The fete will be held on Tuesday from 5 to 7 P. M. on the second floor of the Carnegie Foundation Building at 345 East Forty-sixth Street.

New York's mysteriously vanishing baseball fans will begin today to feel the full impact of the departure of the Giants and Dodgers. That is, they will if their apparent apathy hasn't produced complete numbness. The Yankees, rained out yesterday, leave town and won't be back at the Stadium until June 2.

Haydn's "Lord Nelson" Mass was performed last night by the Oratorio Society of New York in St. Thomas Protestant Episcopal Church. The Amherst College Glee Club and a quartet of soloists provided assistance.

CHICAGO, May 15 -- A psychiatrist and two children's agencies declared today that the New York City courts had not put into effect a juvenile delinquency prevention program that had been tested and approved by the city two years ago.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 15 -- Two graduate students in the Theatre Arts Department at the University of California at Los Angeles today received warm handshakes and cold cash prizes from Samuel Goldwyn as winners of the "creative writing competition."
WASHINGTON, May 15 -The Federal Government claimed today all rights to undersea oil beyond the threemile mark in the Gulf of Mexico.

Member banks continued to operate with little pressure on their reserves in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

Our congratulations go to President Meany of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., and to Senator Kennedy also, for working together now, instead of sparring over proposals for labor union regulation. Steeplechasing dominated the racing at Belmont Park yesterday, with the royally-bred Narcissus II scoring a five-length victory in the Charles H. Appleton Memorial at two miles and an eighth.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 15 -The chairman of the central inspection board of the American Psychiatric Association declared today that one-third of the public mental hospitals inspected so far had been "approved either fully or conditionally."

ATHENS, May 15 -- The Constantine Georgokopoulos caretaker Government resigned today but will stay in office until Constantine Karamanlis, to whom King Paul handed a mandate to form a government, has done so.
LONDON, May 15 -- The threat of a strike on the nationalized railway system ended today with the acceptance of a pay offer by a third union.

EAST MORICHES, L. I., May 15 -- Three cast-iron kettles of steaming eel chowder were consumed a few miles north of here today at the annual spring luncheon of the 120-year-old Hunters Garden Association.

LOS ANGELES, May 15 -A 350-year odyssey in quest of freedom culminated in the picturesque arrival at the Los Angeles International Airport today of eighty-two Russian refugees, bound for a new home in Brazil.
Generating capacity of the nation's private utilities topped 100,000,000 kilowatts for the first time last Sunday, Edison Electric Institute reported yesterday.

Yachts from England, Uruguay, Argentina, Bermuda, Cuba, Canada and the Virgin Islands were among the 121 entries for the Newport-to-Bermuda race made public yesterday by Daniel D. Strohmeier, chairman of the sponsoring Cruising Club of America race committee. The event will begin on June 14. The distance is 635 nautical miles.

The New York State Medical Society should be commended for adopting a resolution that calls on the American Medical Association to make further efforts to stop the abuse of the word "doctors" on radio and television commercials. We hope that some pressure can be brought to oblige the networks and their sponsors to do some badly needed housecleaning.

DENISON, Tex., May 15 (UP) -- A driver and sixteen passengers sat helplessly in a wrecked bus today as a mother and small daughter were electrocuted by the current from a 2,400-volt power line broken by the crash.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, May 15 (UP) -- A revolt in the eastern Bolivian cities of Santa Cruz and Choreti collapsed today and the rebels fled to the Brazilian and Argentine frontiers, the Government announced.

MOSCOW, May 15 (AP) -- Van Cliburn, prize-winning pianist of Kilgore, Tex., and New York, left Moscow "tonight for home via Copenhagen, Denmark. His plane is scheduled to arrive at 9:10 A. M. tomorrow at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens.
The doorman of the apartment building where Frank Costello lives identified Vincent (The Chin) Gigante yesterday as the man who shot and wounded the gambler a year ago.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, May 15 -- Poland and Rumania are to set up a joint commission to develop their productive capacity and broaden their exchange of trade, it was announced today at the close of a three-day visit by Wladyslaw Gomulka, First Secretary of the Polish Communist party.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., May 15 -- The Association of American Law Schools put in effect today its formal censure of Rutgers University for its handling of a Fifth Amendment case.
HONG KONG, May 15 -- Communist China said today it was prepared to intervene in the Indonesian revolt.

Emotional disturbances and personality characteristics are definitely related to the incidence of ulcerative colitis, a meeting of physicians was told yesterday. Ulcerative colitis is the chronic inflammation of the large intestine.

Mayor Wagner predicted yesterday "a great new era" for industry in Brooklyn.
In the Yankees' clubhouse yesterday, following their workout, Hank Bauer paused outside the door of Manager Casey Stengel's office and called Bob Fishel, the club's publicity director.

WASHINGTON, May 15 (AP) -The United States Court of Appeals voided today a deportation order against Harry Carlisle, identified as editor in chief of the West Coast Communist party newspaper in the mid-Nineteen Thirties.
Cotton futures market yesterday moved 3 points off to 1 point up on the New York Cotton Exchange.

YONKERS, May 15 -- Traffic decreased 16.5 per cent and revenue rose 108.9 per cent today when Westchester County's 10-cent toll was increased to 25 cents on the Saw Mill River and Hutchinson River Parkways.

PARIS, May 15 -- The French paratroopers who took charge in Algiers Tuesday under their commander, Brig. Gen. Jacques Massu, are among the toughest, finest, war-sharpened fighting men in the world.

NORWALK, Conn., May 15 -After an acrimonious six-hour session the Board of Estimate voted 4 to 3 at 2:30 this morning to slash the 1958-59 school salary budget by $226,368. This is about half the increase sought this year by the Board of Education, most of which was for rises in teachers' pay.

The International Business Machines Corporation has sold the seven-story store and office building it formerly occupied at 310 Fifth Avenue, near Thirtysecond Street. The Jackson Flannery Realty Corporation was the buyer.
The Greyhound Corporation formally asked the city yesterday for authority to build a $10,000,000 bus terminal on the east side of Eighth Avenue between Thirty-third and Thirtyfourth Streets.

In the last days of December, 1942, Capt. R. St. Vincent Sherbrooke of the Royal Navy was escorting a convoy of four British and ten American merchantmen through the Barents Sea. His command consisted of four destroyers.
WASHINGTON, May 15 (AP) -- The House space committee has unanimously decided in favor of a strong civilian space agency.
The 55-year-old doorman who identified Vincent (The Chin) Gigante as the man who shot gambler Frank Costello a year ago stuck to his story yesterday under cross-examination.

ARNOLD SCAASI, evening gown designer, is working in the daylight for a change. He has created a collection of daytime clothes for Townley Frocks, Inc.

Frank G. Clement.

TO refreeze or not to refreeze meat that has partly thawed is a question put to this department. A cut of meat that is partly defrosted can be refrozen without noticeably lowering the quality, that is, provided a sub-ezro temperature is used.

Cocoa prices advanced 92 to 100 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) on the New York Cocoa Exchange yesterday. The July, September and December positions were up the 1-cent-a-pound daily limit.

LISBON, Portugal, May 16 -The arrival of Gen. Humberto Delgado, independent Presidential candidate, in Lisbon this evening set off a demonstration resulting in injuries to many hundreds of people.

William Alfred White, Inc., was the broker in the recent sale of the New York University Medical College building at 463 First Avenue at East Twentyseventh Street to the Grace Downs Model and Air Career School.

WASHINGTON, May 16 (AP) -- The Naval Research Laboratory announced today that the new Russian satellite, Sputnik III, would pass over the following major United States cities on May 17, 18 and 19. All times are Eastern daylight:
ATLANTIC CITY, May 16 -The convention of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America closed today on a demand for prompt Government action to achieve full employment.
Round Hill captured the metropolitan inter-club women's golf title yesterday on its first attempt.
WASHINGTON, May 16--The largest drop this year in joblessness among workers covered by the unemployment compensation system was reported today by the Labor Department.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 16 -- The Yugoslav League of Communists ruled out tonight any idea of surrender to the Kremlin, even at the risk oil economic and political reprisals.
WASHINGTON, May 16 -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt predicted today "an end to Government ruled by big business" by 1960.

PHILADELPHIA, May 16 (AP) -- United States District Judge J. Cullen Ganey dismissed today indictments against five Philadelphia area Communists. They had been convicted four years ago of conspiracy to teach and advocate overthrow of the Government by force and violence.

One workman was killed and another critically injured yesterday when a section of scaffolding collapsed. They fell to the street from the fifth floor of a building under construction at 1010 Sherman Avenue, the Bronx.
From the beginning of the Greater New York Fund in 1938 leaders in organ ized labor and other employe groups in New York City have given of their time and energies in its organization and management.

Frederick Brisson has settled the question of who will make the stage adaptation of his forthcoming production, "The Loving Couple," the best-selling novel written by Patrick Dennis under the pseudonym of Virginia Rowans.

In his letter to The Times published May 9 Robert L. Carter general counsel of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, makes a strong point against the Jenner-Butler bill. That bill, due to come before the Senate within the next few weeks, is designed to undo the results of a number of recent Supreme Court decisions giving broader scope and vitality to some of our most important constitutional guarantees.
PARIS, May 16 -- More than 35,000 armed police stood guard in Paris tonight to assure the security of this troubled city.
A plea for free trade among the countries of Western Europe and also between Denmark and the United States was voiced here yesterday by the Premier of Denmark.

President Nasser has returned from his eighteen-day visit to Soviet Russia with Premier Khrushchev's accolade as the "outstanding leader of the Arab people" and a pledge of Soviet aid in carrying out his design of uniting all Arabs in a pan-Arab empire.

NEW DELHI, India, May 16 -- The Pakistan International Airlines announced today that the death toll had reached twenty-one in the crash of a Karachi-bound plane last night near New Delhi's Palam Airport.

DETROIT, May 16 (AP) -- Ward's Automotive Reports said today the car industry would start shutting down its plants for model change-overs in six or seven weeks. The shutdowns, it added, will last into September.

Relations between the strong European Common Market nations and surrounding countries must be solved if there is to be real trade cooperation in Europe, the annual meeting of the National Industrial Conference Board was told yesterday.

The six-story building at 1884 Broadway, northeast corner of Sixty-second Street, has been sold by the Drosemor Corporation, Sam Diamond, president, to an investor. It was occupied until recently by the Ford Motor Company. The sale was made through Charles S. Oakley, vice president of the Cross Brown Company, broker. The building was held at $875,000.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 16 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold shook up his top-level staff today and took personal charge of all questions in the world organization relating to disarmament.
WASHINGTON, May 16 -- A scientific symposium heard proposals today that the disjointed knee or the posterior of a cockroach could be used as a scientific instrument in satellites.

The Sidney Hillman Foundation's awards for distinguished writing in the daily press, magazines, books, films, radio-TV and drama are notable not only in themselves but because they mark the foundation's tenth anniversary. In the decade's short span it has won a unique place in American philanthropy -- not by the bulk of its resources, which are modest, but by the uses to which they have been put.

WASHINGTON, May 16 (UP) -- House of Representatives investigators said today lack of coordination between military and civilian flight controls was responsible for the collision between a jet fighter and commercial airliner near Las Vegas, Nev., last month.
PARIS, Saturday, May 17 (AP) -- In an address before the Advisory Council of the Republic early today, M. Pflimlin challenged General de Gaulle to explain his position.
NEWARK, May 16 -- A teenage ex-convict was shot and killed here tonight after he slashed a policeman's hands with a knife in two attacks.
PARIS, May 16 -- France's grave political troubles are also troubles of the Atlantic alliance and of half a dozen European regional organizations.

PARIS, May 16 -- It has long been evident that the lowering Algerian storm would some day sweep northward. And it was equally evident that when it was blown across France's sweet fields by the high winds of destiny, its political epicenter would focus on Charles de Gaulle.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 16 -- Lebanon was fighting today armed bands wto were filtering in from Syria in an effort to overthrow the pro-Western Government at Beirut.
CHICAGO, May 16 (AP) -- Moderate profit taking weakened corn futures today on the Board of Trade, but most other grains finished with gains of a fraction of a cent a bushel. Trading was dull.

LONDON, May 16 -- Britain relinquished today her tentative claim to having achieved the world's first controlled thermonuclear reactions. But her top nuclear physicists made clear they were still running hard in the international race to tame the hydrogen bomb for peaceful use.
BOSTON, May 16 (AP) -- Alan Freed, New York disc jockey, pleaded innocent in Superior Court today to two indictments in connection with disturbances that followed his rock 'n' roll show here May 3.

BOSTON, May 16 -- Scientific studies suggesting how the cost of Air Force logistic operations might be cut in half under some conditions were described today at the sixth annual meeting of the Operations Research Society of America.
WASHINGTON, May 16 (AP) -- The House Appropriations Committee cut $65,581,000 today from the $982,721,000 requested by the Administration for the Commerce Department and related agencies.

LOS ANGELES, May 16 (UP) -- Smooth-striding Herb Elliott of Australia ran the Miracle Mile event of the Coliseum Relays tonight in 3:57.8. It was the second fastest mile in history and two-tenths of a second faster than the listed world record.
WASHINGTON, May 16 -The Latin-American diplomatic corps here today invited Vice President Richard M. Nixon to a banquet honoring him on his return from an incident-marred South American tour.
Condemnation of the iproniazid drug was criticized yesterday at the 152d annual convention of the Medical Society of the State of New York.

PARIS, May 16 -- A taxi driver speeded through dense traffic along the Quai d'Orsay today, swerved violently around a weaving cyclist and braked to a jolting halt before the Palais Bourbon, seat of the French National Assembly.

WIESBADEN, Germany, May 16 (UP) -- Jack Frost of Monterey, Calif., reached the men's singles semi-finals of the Wiesbaden international tennis tournament today with 6 -- 3, 6 -- 1 victory over Fritz Sehmrau of Germany.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -Although the nation's outstanding scientific minds are watching Russia's latest sputnik, still later developments tonight indicated they also should be casting an eye in another direction.
MOSCOW, May 16 -- Scientists in the Soviet Union's earth satellite program said today that the variety and complexity of the instruments aboard their new Sputnik III were its outstanding feature.

It is hard to believe that Communist China's flamboyant announcement that it is ready to intervene in Indonesia to support the Jakarta Government will be of permanent assistance to the people of Indonesia. One of the reasons for the present revolt is protest against Communist interference in the Sukarno regime.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., May 16 (AP) -- A battery of Army artillery men sent a Redstone medium-range ballistic missile thundering toward space at dusk tonight.
PATCHOGUE, L. I., May 16 -- Suffolk County's powerful Republican party tonight pledged its full support of Leonard W. Hall as a candidate for Governor.

WASHINGTON, May 16 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture today accused a grain concern and two individuals of manipulating the price of cash corn and corn futures on the Chicago Board of Trade last Sept. 13.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, May 16 -- The United States informally broached to Indonesia this week the possibility of a cease-fire between Jakarta and the rebels, a high Indonesian diplomatic source said tonight.

WESTBURY, L. I., May 16 -Horsemen agree that Demon Rum -- the horse, not the drink -- is superb on a mile track. Tonight they had to concede that the son of Demon Hanover and Rapture could do a betterthan-average job on a half-mile track, too.
WASHINGTON, May 16 -- Tunisia and Morocco expressed their concern to the United States today over the junta that has taken control of Algeria.
BORDEAUX, France, May 16 (UP) -- The Philadelphia Orchestra received applause and cries of "bravo" tonight with the first of two concerts at the Bordeaux Music Festival.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- Indications of collaboration between the merged labor movement and some of the unions it had expelled for corruption were denied today by George Meany, president of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations.

The election of William P. Hilliard as a vice president of General Precision Laboratory, Inc., was announced yesterday. The company, a subsidiary of General Precision Equipment Corporation, develops and manufactures airborne navigation systems, industrial, miliary and broadcast television equipment, and motion picture projection apparatus.

Henry C. Alexander, chairman of J. P. Morgan Co., urged yesterday an "across-the-board" cut in personal and corporate income taxes of $5,000,000,000, "or perhaps more" as the best anti-recession move.

Supreme Court Justice Jacob Markowitz gave tentative approval yesterday to a referee's recommendation that the Guaranty Trust Company be authorized to sell $50,000,000 in securities of the Universal Oil Products Company.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 16 (AP) -- The United Nations Commission of International Commodity Trade closed a two-week session today with a warning from its chairman that 1958 is a "very crucial and alarming year' for producers of primary commodities.

Revere Copper and Brass, Inc., announced yesterday that it would trim prices of some copper water tube products again on Monday in an effort to meet foreign competition. The company announced an earlier price cut of 10 per cent on the same items a week ago.

WILLIAMSBURG, Va., May 16 (UP) -- Carlisle H. Humelsine, former Assistant Secretary of State was elected president of Colonial Williamsburg today. Mr. Humelsine, now executive vice president, succeeds Kenneth Chorley, who is retiring May 21.
PHILADELPHIA, May 16 -The Phillies didn't believe what they saw when they faced Bob Porterfield last Sunday at Pittsburgh and were blanked, 1 -- 0, in eleven innings.

GEN. RAOUL - ALBIN - LOUIS SALAN, supreme French commander in Algeria, stepped sharply out of character when he gave his blessing to the rebellious Committee of Public Safety headed by his rough-and-ready subordinate, Brig. Gen. Jacques Massu.
Cotton futures advanced 16 to 19 points (80 to 95 cents a bale) yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange. Trading volume was moderate.
Events today: Concert Artists Guild, Steinway Hall, 3 P. M.; Handel's "Sampson," Jewish People's Philharmonic Chorus, Eugene Malek conducting, Carnegie Hall, 8:30.
The heavy blanket of stratus clouds that formed over New York night before last and pelted the city with rain broke up yesterday and was pushed out to sea.

CHICAGO, May 16 -- Sputnik III was hailed here today by the United States chairman of the International Geophysical year as a major contribution to man's attempt to learn more about the world in which he lives.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., May 16 -- A father-and-son situation developed in the best-of-breed class at the specialty of the Poodle Club of America today when the Puttencove Kennels' Puttencove Moonshine from Manchester, Mass., gained the award.

Directors of the Copperweld Steel Company took no action yesterday on the common stock dividend usually due at this time. Shareholders of the common stock had been receiving dividends of 50 cents a quarter. The most recent one was distributed last March 10.
DRESSES and bath towels made in America sold like hot pizzas last week at La Rinascente, a Milan department store. In fact, the supply, which was due to last a month, was depleted in a day.

TWENTY years ago and more, all international art news centered on Paris. Since the end of World War II, and with the disappearance of all but a few of the grand old men, the focus has shifted to New York, Rome and London.
TORONTO, May 16 -- A team of Royal Ontario Museum scientists has found in a Peruvian quarry tens of thousands of bones of the late Pleistocene age, or glacial epoch, 20,000 to 50,000 years ago.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 16 -William Heikkila, Finnish-born draftsman and a former member of the Communist party, lost a bid in Federal Court today for a permanent order that would keep him in this country.

The mightiest muscles in the United States and Russia will be on display in Madison Square Garden tonight. The seven strongest men of each nation will match power in a weightlifting contest that promises to be an epic event of its type.

The president of the American Association of Blood Banks predicted yesterday than an agreement would be reached this year with the American Red Cross to establish a nationwide system of blood credits.

SCARSDALE, N. Y., May 16 -- Used continuously for Sunday services since 1842, a little white clapboard church on Central Park Avenue in near-by Greenburgh is about to be supplanted by a new Georgian colonial church of brick and steel atop an-Ardsley Road hill a few blocks to the south.

A defiant Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr. of Harlem pleaded not guilty yesterday to charges of evading Federal income taxes and then set up a political forum at the courthouse to open his battle against Tammany Hall.

" FROM QUEENSLAND TO THE GREAT BARRIER REEF,"* by Noel Monkman, is an adventurously galvanic memoir of a naturalist's experiences in the wilds of northern Australia. One of his trophies is a sequence of scenes he made for the filmed version of Rachel Carson's "The Sea Around Us."

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- Dr. Edwin H. Land of Cambridge, Mass., won his 109th patent on one-step photography this week. It covers a modified form of the Polaroid Land cameras.
LANSING, Mich., May 16 (AP) -- A Circuit Court Judge who defied a State Supreme Court order was ruled in contempt by the Supreme Court today. He was fined $250.

BALTIMORE, May 17 -- The Johns Hopkins lacrosse team lost a four-goal lead, then scored twice within twenty seconds at the start of the fourth quarter to edge Maryland, 11 -- 10, today. By winning, Hopkins now has a strong claim for a second straight intercollegiate championship.
The historic significance of the Gramercy Park area will be featured at the Gramercy Arts benefit ball and exhibition next Saturday.
ALBANY, Calif., May 17 (AP) -- Barouche held on under pressure today and won the $25,000 Dumpty Humpty Handicap at Golden Gate Fields. The time for the six furlongs on a fast track was 1:09 4/5.

These are fine days for asking questions, whether we get answers or not. Questions about dandelions, for instance. Why is a dandelion? There is no answer, really. A dandelion just is, persistent, determined, ubiquitous. Livestock won't eat dandelions.
International advertising is undergoing major changes.
Van Cliburn returned to New York International Airport yesterday barely twenty-four hours after he had arrived.

THESE books add two informative and interesting titles to the "Wonderful World" series. As in other volumes of the series, writers and artists have combined to produce stories well told and lavishly illustrated in color.

TRENTON, May 17 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner called upon the Democratic-controlled State Assembly today to restore a cut of $22,199,000 in his $400,000,000 budget. The reduction has been voted by the Senate.

MAY is a good month to get things settled in the garden. Planting will be finished. The last trees and shrubs are moved. Only those that are container grown can be transplanted later in the year with safety.

THE miniature camera is now passing through an era of basic change and innovation perhaps unequaled in any other period of photographic history. Recently the pace has been accelerated and murmurs of still more change and more new camera models toward the end of the year already prevail in the industry.

The city's attraction for summer visitors will be enhanced this year by special events. The official calendar planned for "New York Is a Summer Festival" will open just before the season does, on June 19.
PHILADELPHIA, May 17 -The Mastbaum Theatre, Philadelphia's largest motion-picture house, with a seating capacity of 5,000, is slated for demolition.
WASHINGTON, May 17 -- Department of Labor officials denied today a union charge that Mexican seasonal laborers posed a job threat to Americans available for farm work this summer.
PARIS, May 17 -- This city remained calm today.

WASHINGTON -- The major domestic airlines agreed last week to scrap a hard-to-enforce $3 penalty for booked passengers who fail to show up at flight, time. But they extended other measures to protect the carriers against "no show" passengers.

FORMERLY a musician, now a photographer, naturalist, microscopist and writer, Noel Monkman is a remarkable man. I don't know that these skills should be put in any particular order; he is good at all of them and he has given a clear demonstration of his abilities in "From Queensland to the Great Barrier Reef."
MOSCOW, May 17 -- In a final tribute to Van Cliburn here today, the newspaper of the Ministry of Culture ran a series of articles hailing the young American pianist as one of "the best of the best."

Five United States clergymen will leave May 27 to visit religious and political leaders in thirteen countries, incuding the Soviet Union. The trip will be under the auspices of the National Conference of Christians and Jews.

THE tulips in front of the main Public Library, at the Plaza and along Park Avenue are part of the city's "Salute to Spring." This is the first installment of an over-all "Salute to the Seasons" sponsored by the Department of Commerce and Public Events.
A Reform rabbi suggested yesterday that Judaism present its moral and ethical principles to "those who have no religion at all."

Enactment of the Bank Holding Company Act of 1956, Congress said in writing the law, should not take from the states any present or future powers they might have over banks, bank holding companies or their subsidiaries.

New York University clinched at least a tie for the Metropolitan Collegiate Baseball Conference title yesterday by beating second-place St. John's, 5 -- 4, at Ohio Field in the Bronx.

WITH an eye for the beauty and significance of things in the Far North, Theodora Stanwell-Fletcher has written a leisurely, chatty but discerning account of a voyage on the Hudson's Bay Company's steamer Rupertsland, from Montreal to Churchill, Man.
THE pest and blight control program is beginning. A brush-up on the "when and what" to use will keep gardens healthy all summer.

FLAGS of the seven countries that took part in the International Festival of Arts flew in front of festival headquarters in downtown Osaka, the commercial metropolis of Japan. The countries were the United States, Austria, Belgium, Japan, the Soviet Union, Britain, Spain and unofficially, Red China.

The days when Peter Stuyvesant stomped about New York were re-created yesterday at the annual tulip festival of the Protestant Episcopal Church of St. Mark'sin-the-Bouwerie, Second Avenue and Tenth Street.
LONDON, May 17 -- The "anarchy and lawlessness" among the nations of the West demand increased governmental responsibility from Britain and her allies. Viscount Hailsham declared today.

RIVERSIDE, Calif., May 17 -- The growing industrialization of the West was typified here recently. A twenty-eight-acre tract, which for generations has produced orange juice, turned to producing the paper containers in which a lot of orange juice is served.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 17 -Crowds were still flocking to hear the Rev. Billy Graham at the end of the first three weeks of the evangelist's Bay Area crusade at the Cow Palace.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- The surge of anti-American sentiment in Caracas, Venezuela, culminating on Tuesday with the mob attack on Vice President Richard M. Nixon, may go down in the annals of United States diplomacy as a textbook example of how to lose the goodwill of a nation.

CARACAS, Venezuela, May 17 -- Barry MacKay and Bill Quillian scored a straight-sets doubles victory that enabled the United States to gain a clinching 3-0 lead over Venezuela today in their first-round Americanzone Davis Cup tennis elimination series.

THAT busy shuttler between biblical and medical novels, Frank Slaughter, dons his operating suit again for "Daybreak." On the surface this is the crisisridden story of Dr. Jim Corwin's efforts to save a lovely young schizophrenic named Lynn Thorndyke from destroying herself.
The election of George M. Sullivan and James S. Royds as administrative vice presidents of the Continental Oil Company was announced yesterday.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 17 -- While the rest of Cornell's student body was celebrating house party week-end back in Ithaca today, the Big Red's track squad did some frolicking of its own at Navy's stronghold. The occasion saw the Ithacans triumph in the twenty-fourth annual Heptagonal Games Association's outdoor championships at Thompson Stadium.
BAR HARBOR, Me. -- Nature herself is putting the finishing touches on preparations for the fortieth annual season at Acadia National Park.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., May 17 -- The Tennessee Senate agreed today to meet next Wednesday and fix a date for the impeachment trial of Judge Raulston Schoolfield of Chattanooga.

PARIS, May 17 -- The French Army's assumption of total power in Algeria is viewed by most observers here as the climax of years of chagrin and frustration over political fumbling by successive Governments in Paris.

THE distinguished French author of "The Second Sex" and "The Mandarins," Simone de Beauvoir, accepted an invitation at the Bandung Conference in 1955 to visit Communist China. As a guest of the Government, she spent six weeks in September-October of that year traveling the well-beaten trail of the "invited" visitor.

A drop of 12,000 in employment in Pennsylvania in March has been attributed to a work stoppage caused by a labormanagement dispute in a segment of the women's apparel industry. Otherwise, according to the Bureau of Employment Security of the Pennsylvania Department of Labor and Industry, seasonal employment gains in the agricultural, construction, service and retail trade industries offset further employment losses in manufacturing industries.
MOSCOW, May 17 -- The 1956 Hungarian revolt was held up to the Soviet Army today as a "vivid example" of the danger of Yugoslav "revisionism."
LONDON, May 17 (AP) -- Britain's surprisingly strong team completed its advance into the third round of the European Zone Davis Cup tennis competition today without losing a set against Brazil.

A COMPOST heap need not be a pile of rubbish, discreetly hidden in a corner of the garden behind the shrubbery. A few years ago, after experimenting along various lines, I devised the "doughnut" plan of building a heap.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., May 17 -- Sammy Snead fired a five-under-par 65 to tie Ben Hogan for the lead in the Greenbrier open golf tournament today.

Vice President Nixon's eighteenday trip to South America will rank as one of the major events in hemispheric history. Its repercussions will be felt for years and its significance is already the subject of sharp debate. The last three weeks are likely to have a more profound effect on United States relations with Latin America than anything that has happened since the Good Neighbor policy was hammered out in the Nineteen Twenties and Nineteen Thirties.
LONDON, May 14 (AP) -- British engineers have designed a strange hinged-wing airplane intended to fly the Atlantic in two hours.

THE helping hand that contemporary composers are getting in America from the development of LP recording is cause for rejoicing, especially among composers. This help is still far from solving their problems of how to be really widely heard.

Fragrant wistaria, lacy dogwood, lilacs and azaleas are at their best. Tree peonies, which precede herbaceous kinds by a week or so, are especially fine this year. Some of the loveliest wild flowers also belong to May. The woodland visitor can watch for trilliums, lady's slippers, star flowers and the many kinds of native violets.

MADRID, May 17 (UP) -- Generalissimo Francisco Franco reaffirmed today that Spain was a "Catholic, traditional and representative" monarchy. But he failed to shed any light on who would succeed him as the nation's ruler.

Justice John Warren Hill took issue yesterday with the assertion of a psychiatrist that a juvenile delinquency prevention program tested and approved by the city two years ago had not been put into effect.

Memories of Woodrow Wilson were refreshed through the centennial observances of 1956 which culminated in the commemoration of his birth on December 28. Led by the Woodrow Wilson Foundation and the Congressionally authorized Woodrow Wilson Centennial Celebration Commission, programs to honor his memory were held in all parts of the country, sponsored by colleges and schools and by labor, business, professional and other citizens' groups.

LIKE William Rawle Weeks in last year's Edgar-winning "Knock and Wait a While," Henry S. Maxfield has wisely decided to base a spy novel, not upon the glamorous conventions of fiction, but upon his own experiences -- perhaps less picturesque, but no less exciting -- as a counter-espionage agent in Europe; and the resultant LEGACY OF A SPY (Harper, $3.50) is one of the more credible recent tales of international intrigue.

ADEN, May 14 -- There are signs that some rulers of the Aden Protectorate states are overcoming their mutual jealousies and suspicions in the face of the increasing threat of Yemeni domination. The recession continued to bump along last week, and where it was going remained unclear. William McChesney Martin Jr., chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, expressed what appeared to be the consensus when he said it would be a mistake to be either "overoptimistic or over-cautious."

DETROIT, May 17 (AP) -- The auto industry is down in production and sales but it is far from out.

CLEVELAND, May 17 -- Consumption of Lake Superior iron ore by iron and steel plants was approximately 9,000,000 tons less in the first quarter of this year than in the corresponding period of 1957, the American Iron Ore Association reports.

WEST KILL, N. Y., May 17 -- After an afternoon of no-good fishing, Art Flick spent this evening trying to get into trouble. He did this by selecting six dry flies to carry him through a summer of fishing without the aid of any others.

THE drama program, regrettably absent from the City Center's stage last winter, is free to return next season -- and will. WASHINGTON, May 17 -The American consumer -- the fellow who absorbs two-thirds of the total output of the economy -- has played a big role in the recession. And yet there is no solid evidence that he has engaged in a buyers' strike.

TOKYO, May 13 -- Japan exported 1,194,375 tons of iron and steel goods valued at $232,866,000 in the fiscal year ended March 31.

For what but chance and a very small world could bring these two 15year-old French boys of identical appearance to the Marseilles waterfront at the same time and with the same plan -- to run away to sea?

PRESIDENT EISENHOWER is exerting extraordinary political pressure to reorganize the headquarters of the massive U. S. military establishment. This is centered in the Pentagon, a five-sided mass, with five concentric rings of five stories, in Arlington, Va., across the Potomac from Washington.
BOSTON, May 17 -- Commuters along the right-of-way of the Boston and Maine Railroad will begin to feel the affects of a drastic curtailment in service Monday morning.
TO many gardeners, May is the prettiest month. The scheduling of house and garden tours to take advantage of this benevolent season continues.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 17 -- Harvard's baseball team clinched its first outright Eastern League title in twenty-nine years with a 12-7 victory over Yale today. The Crimson's league record is 7 -- 0.

In city after city, they documented the sorry record of bossism, bribery and graft, the degradation of officials, police and public. Mayors were either the venal bosses of dishonest machines or figureheads for the bosses.

NEW DELHI, India, May 16 -- Jawaharial Nehru has been goading and pulling his Congress party into facing a problem most Indian politicians prefer to forget: the position of the huge Moslem minority and its fears and feeling of disquiet.
MIAMI BEACH, May 18 (AP) -- Gov. G. Mennen Williams of Michigan proposed tonight a United States-Soviet partnership pact to withhold arms from the Middle East.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 17 -- The United States is considering a suspension of nuclear weapons tests at the close of its current series in the Pacific, informed quarters said here today:

CHICAGO, May 17 -- Robert B. Anderson, Secretary of the Treasury, who became an assistant scoutmaster thirty years ago, was one of twelve men honored today with the award of the Boy Scouts' Silver Buffalo.

WARSAW, May 17 -- Poland's Communist-party has run into a new kind of cultural crisis. The regime's problem is no longer to silence dissident voices but to find effective spokesmen for "Marxist culture."
LAWN care for the summer follows a simple schedule. Mowing continues week after week. Weeds are kept to a minimum. Raking goes on occasionally. Sometimes the hose is brought out.

A filmed dramatization of the seasonal cycles on a Swedish farm will be presented tomorrow at the Tremont Branch of the New York Public Library, 1866 Washington Avenue, the Bronx. The showing will start at 8 P. M.

NEW CITY, N. Y., May 17 -Forty families who have signed leases for apartments in Oakdale Manor will be permitted to move in at once. They may occupy the garden apartment house in Suffern as the result of a decision today by Supreme Court Justice Robert Doscher.

LONDON, May 17 (Reuters) -- Non-smokers get a 15 per cent reduction in auto insurance premiums under a plan disclosed here today. To qualify, they have to sign a pledge that they will not raise cigarettes or pipes to their lips during the life of the policies.

THE international tourist made the grand tour last week from the White House to the halls of Congress, the first excursion he had made in such exalted company in a long, long time. The occasion was the transmittal by President Eisenhower to Congress of the report by Clarence B. Randall on international travel.

CONTINUING its policy of acquiring both contemporary work and examples which fill in the background in the permanent collection, the Guggenheim Museum has opened a varied and provocative display of recent acquisitions supplemented by related items from the collection and several loans from Europe.

RABAT, Morocco, May 17 -Although calm prevails in Morocco, there is deep concern in Government circles over repercussions from the disorders in neighboring Algeria.
Trackers on the roof of the R. C. A Building failed to spot the Soviet Union's third satellite on its scheduled pass over New York City last night.
WASHINGTON, May 18 (UP) -- Senator Sam J. Ervin Jr. declared today that the nation faced the danger of being ruled by "a Federal oligarchy" unless Congress put some restraints on the Supreme Court.
BEIRUT, May 18 -- Heavy fighting between insurgents penned in the old section of the northern port city of Tripoli and Government forces was resumed last night.
Mayor Wagner said yesterday that the recession might have an unhealthy effect on the city's crime rate this summer.
The National Association of Manufacturers issued yesterday an ethics guidebook for management to parallel organized labor's Ethical Practices Codes.
WASHINGTON, May 18 -The American Association of University Women reported today that about 13,000 women graduates in its membership were willing to teach school.
The American Accordionists Association presented the winner of its Accordion Olympic Contest, Don Lipovac of Kansas City, Mo., at an "Accordion Day" concert last night in Carnegie Hall.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, May 18 -- The stockmarket last week showed weakness under the lead of a Royal Dutch selling wave. Middle East developments, generally less optimistic views regarding the world oil situation, and the growing competition from American independents were other factors in the decline.
The armed forces ended their week yesterday with a roaring jet show over Coney Island.
GARDEN CITY, L. I., May 18 -- Billy Edwards of Cherry Valley captured his second tournament in two weeks today, this time with the aid of a partner.
Robert Moses criticized the Greyhound Corporation yesterday but avoided a stand on the bus company's recent application for authority to build a $10,000,000 terminal in mid-Manhattan.

Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr. began laying the groundwork yesterday for what might become his own political organization. At the same time he publicly challenged two top Tammany leaders to stay out of Harlem.

Park Commissioner Robert Moses hinted yesterday at strategic retreat in the Battle of Washington Square as a means of insuring ultimate triumph. Several seeming indi cations of a planned, but not necessarily voluntary, withdrawal cropped up during a radio interview in which Mr. Moses contended there was a compelling need for a forty-eight-foot-wide highway through the park.

A MAN who has made women's faces his fortune believes in do-it-yourself beauty aids so long as the doer first reads the directions on the box.

WASHINGTON, May 18 (AP) --The Americans for Democratic Action voted nearly 2-1 today for an immediate start on negotiations looking toward recognition of Communist China.

ALGIERS, May 18 -- The French Army appeared today to be moving toward the removal of rebelling civilians from all posts of authority in Algeria.

CHICAGO, May 18 (AP) -Plans to consider a merger of the Iowa-Illinois Gas and Electric Company and the Iowa Power and Light Company of Des Moines were announced over the week-end.
