BELLMORE, L. I., May 19 -- About two years ago Mrs. Thomas Hayes was looking about for a painter to apply a fresh coat to the Hayes house here. She telephoned one of her old neighbors at Valley Stream to see if her husband was interested in the job.
TOKYO, May 19 -- The Third Asian Games will open here next Saturday in one of the most modern and beautiful stadiums in the world.

Walt Disney Productions and its domestic subsidiaries had $6,041,817 in increased in gross income in the six months ended March 29. However, higher operating costs held earnings to little more than those of the half-year ended March 30, 1957.

CURRENT decorating trends are reflected in the furniture and accessories at Flair Interiors, which opened recently at 241 Sullivan Street, a block south of Washington Square. The owners of this design and accessory shop, Eloise and Al Litman, also will undertake decorating projects.
WASHINGTON, May 19 -President Eisenhower was told today by the Republican leadership of the House that further concessions to protectionist elements were needed to asve his reciprocal trade program.
PORT - AU - PRINCE, Haiti, May 19 -- The Interior Ministry today ordered a former Presidential candidate and his brother to surrender to the army to answer charges of complicity in a bomb plot.
Mickey Crawford of Saginaw, Mich., slugged his way to a unanimous decision over Andy Figueroa, a West Side welterweight, in the ten-round feature at St. Nicholas Arena last night.

WASHINGTON, May 19 (UP) A House Agriculture subcommittee approved today a plan that would probably push up prices of bread, cereal and other wheat products by shifting the cost of wheat price supports from taxpayers to consumers.
CAMDEN, N. J., May 19 -- (AP) The Green Dunes Farm's Cavan today won the Wildwood Purse at Garden State Park and probably gained a starting berth in Saturday's $50,000 added Jersey Stakes.
WASHINGTON, May 19 -- The Supreme Court took the following actions today:
WASHINGTON, May 19 -The Treasury bill rate dipped below 1 per cent today for the first time since the recession year of 1954.
Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., charged New York City yesterday with "waste and mismanagement" in its operation of power plants for the Transit Authority.
WASHINGTON, May 19 -- The Supreme Court summarily reversed today the conviction of Harry Sacher, New York attorney, for contempt of Congress.

WASHINGTON, May 19 (AP) -- Senator James O. Eastland, Democrat of Mississippi, the Senate Internal Security subcommittee chairman, denounced last night the decision on Mr. Sachet. He accused the court of substituting "judge-made law" for statutes enacted by Congress.
TRIPOLI, Lebanon, May 19 -- Lebanon's second largest city, was still in a state of siege today.

Government leaders headed by President Eisenhower joined yesterday in a tribute to Stanley P. Davies, retired general director of the Community Service Society. Mr. Davies, who has been associate in planning for the society since last June, will leave the agency at the end of next month.

The New York City Housing Authority plans to sell $20,741,000 of temporary loan notes on May 27 for the financing of Mill Brook Houses, a stateaided, low-rent development nearing completion in the Bronx.

A large group exhibition, such as the Brooklyn and Long Island Artists exhibition at the Brooklyn Museum, has the virtue of cataloguing the style tendencies of the moment. Since such a show is geographically limited, it would be an error to look for a uniform plateau of originality.
Two Brooklyn youths, convicted on a first-degree murder charge for "a thrill killing" more than three years ago, won a reversal yesterday in the Appellate Division in Brooklyn.
DUBLIN, May 18 (UP) -- Britain's Brian Hewson spoiled the homecoming of Ron Delany tonight by upsetting him in a half-mile run. Hewson also broke Delany's Irish record for the event.

Americans may be tightening their belts figuratively but not literally. Paul S. Willis, president of the Grocery Manufacturers of America; reported yesterday that food business is booming beyond expectations.

Some of Richard Rodgers' dexterity in the musical field must have rubbed off on his daughters, Mary Rodgers and Mrs. Linda Melnick. Both have blended their know-how in turning out a miniature revue, "It Takes Three to Make Music," designed specially for children.
WASHINGTON, May 19 -- Following are a statement and an exchange of notes released by the State Department on the future organization and operation of the North American Air Defense Command:

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Tuesday, May 20 -- President Sukarno declared here this morning that Indonesia was faced with a "counter-revolution" and outside aggression aimed at frustrating the ideals of Indinesian independence.

John A. Ewald, president, told the annual meeting of Avon Products, Inc., that sales in the first four months of 1958 were 13.4 per cent higher than in the 1957 period and for April were 19.6 per cent above the 1957 level.

THE Old Grads assembled in the Fordham gymnasium just before the testimonial dinner to Jack Coffey the other night and exercised the constitutional rights of all alumni to reminisce fondly about the good old days. But when they got to talking about the present, at least one listener was struck by an inescapable fact.

PHILADELPHIA, May 19 -- A hearing in the suit of Randolph Phillips, independent candidate for the board of the Pennsylvania Railroad, was postponed today until the election board completes its count of the votes cast at the annual meeting last Tuesday.
WASHINGTON, May 19 -- Venezuela and the United States postponed "by mutual agreement'' today a ceremony here Thursday at which Vice President Nixon was scheduled to be a principal speaker.
OMAHA, Neb., May 19 -- Interference through medical progress with the processes of natural selection in humans "may be a step toward racial suicide," a research biochemist said today.
KANNAPOLIS, N. C., May 19 (UP) -- Two football players said today that the $1 each they had won wrestling a carnival gorilla was not enough to cover their doctor bills.

MOSCOW, May 19 -- Ever since this writer's arrival in this capital people have been telling him, "wait till you hear Richter." The reputation of Svyatoslav Richter, indeed, had reached the United States months ago.

VAN CLIBURN, as tall as the top edge of the upward tilted lid of his grand piano, faced a major test last night at Carnegie Hall. He played for the first time in his own country after being catapulted to world-wide fame by winning the International Tchaikovsky Competition in Russia.

Cartoonists have often depicted Gen. Charles de Gaulle's craggy face as the unanswering part of a sphinx. There is always a decided element of bafflement and bewilderment about what he means and what he intends to do. Now that he has given his eagerly awaited press conference in Paris, one is still left wondering.
DETROIT, May 19 -- Lewis G. Castle called today for the speedy development of improved port facilities and traffic patterns in cities along the Great Lakes.

The fifteen-story, glass-and-aluminum office building now rising at 20 East Forty-sixth Street will gain 6,000 extra square feet of usable space in the basement because of a turnabout in architecture.

The two-story garden-type apartment building at 105-31 East Eighty-sixth Street in Brooklyn has been sold by Ditmas Gardens, Inc. The purchaser is an investing client of Simon J. Boss, broker in the deal.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- The State Department informed Congress today that last week's world-wide outburst of anti-United States demonstrations was "largely accidental" and not a result of a coordinated Soviet plan.

Wool prices soared yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange. Tops rose 2.3 to 4.5 cents a pound and grease wool gained 2.2 to 4 cents. The market registered the sharpest advance of the year. Trading was moderately active.
LOS ANGELES, May 19 ((AP)) -- Today's developments in the City Council must have stunned Walter F. O'Malley.

HOUSTON, Tex., May 19 (AP) -- The Delhi-Taylor Oil Corporation is seeking to exchange an interest in the Coastal Transmission Corporation for common stock of the Houston Corporation. Delhi-Taylor owns 285,000 shares or about 96 per cent, of Coastal Transmission's stock.

Business men who comprise the Advisory Council of the Department of Commerce held a meeting, it will be recalled, at Hot Springs, Va., the week before last. No formal poll was taken of their opinions to indicate just where they stood on the question of the present business recession.
WASHINGTON, May 19 -- A closely divided Supreme Court held today that the states are constitutionally free to try a man more than once for a single act constituting several crimes.
WASHINGTON, May 19 -- The woman college graduate often gets her man, and more than twice as often gets a job.

All hands are combining to have arrangements ship-shape for the Moonlight and Stars cruise up the Hudson on the evening of June 4. The proceeds of the event will be shared by the Greater New York Chapter of the American National Theatre and Academy and the Spence-Chapin Adoption Service.
MIAMI BEACH, May 19 -- Dag Hammarskjold, Secretary General of the United Nations, called on all nations tonight to renounce any territorial claims to outer space.
CHICAGO, May 19 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- In this era of violent threat and violent change all over the world, the purposes of H. R. 10154, just approved by the House and awaiting Senate action, probably will impress the reader as the dullest and least important topic that could be presented for his consideration.
ROCHESTER, N. Y., May 19 (AP) -- The Schine theatre chain put fourteen movie houses up for auction today, but there were no buyers.
WASHINGTON, May 19 (UP) -- The Senate gave final Congressional approval today for the Navy to use five ships to check the effects of anti-submarine atomic weapons in the current Pacific tests.

PURCHASE, N. Y., May 19 -- A cancellation today of plans for President Eisenhower to come here tomorrow for golf and relaxation affected several hundred policemen, Republican leaders, golfers and club employes.
Three men were found guilty of manslaughter and conspiracy last night in Bronx County Court in the deaths of two persons from wood alcohol poisoning. A fourth defendant was acquitted.

The second annual film festival at Stratford, Ont., will be expanded, according to an announcement by the Stratford Shakespearean Festival committee. The event, which will run from June 30 to July 12, will include at least twenty feature films from various nations.

WASHINGTON, May 19 (AP) -- The State Department said today, in effect, the the University of California's request to hire an Australian law professor had been rejected to avoid strained United States-Australian relations.

Cyrus S. Eaton, the Cleveland industrialist who said two weeks ago that Adolf Hitler had never had a spy organization equal to the "snooping" systems current in this country, has been ordered to appear before the House Committee on Un-American Activities.
State Department policies in the Middle East were attacked last night by James B. Carey, president of the International Union of Electrical Workers.
WASHINGTON, May 19 (UP) -- The House today passed a bill closing a legal loophole unplugged recently by a giraffe named Moneybags.

President Nasser's attempt to seize Lebanon with the aid of his Communist allies, as he attempted to seize Jordan and did seize Syria, is not going too well, but this has only prompted both Cairo and Moscow to step up their joint campaign against American aid to the embattled Lebanese Government.
YOKOHAMA, Japan, May 19 (AP) -- A Chinese Communist song and dance troupe suddenly canceled its final performance in Japan and returned home today aboard a Soviet ship.

The six-story loft building at 223 East Eightieth Street, which was built in 1874 by the seller and occupied by him ever since, has been purchased by the P. R. M. Corporation. Walter J. Dickerson and Leo J. Dropkin were the co-brokers.
WASHINGTON, May 19 -- Ezra Taft Benson's political stock in the Midwest is rising with farm prices.

BARCELONA, Spain, May 19 (AP) -- Spain defeated Sweden today in the doubles match of their second round Davis Cup tennis series in the European Zone. However Sweden still led by a 2-1 margin on the strength of its two victories in yesterday's opening singles matches.

MONTE CARLO, Monaco, May 19 -- Claude Reichenbach of Switzerland won the 1958 Monte Carlo rubber bridge championship last night, finishing well ahead of the invited field of 112 expert and amateur players.

PARIS, Tuesday, May 20 -- The French Government imposed censorship early today on outgoing stories filed by United Press. It was understood that censors would be assigned to the two other agencies, The Associated Press and International News Service this morning.
State Superintendent of Insurance Julius S. Wikler has announced revisions in workmen's compensation rates of private insurance companies that will "effect huge savings."
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 19 -- Warner Brothers may be first among the major studios to take the big step in the reorganization of film-distribution operations.
New issues of debt and equity securities of Gulf States Utilities Company totaling $30,350,000 will be offered for public subscription today by investment banking syndicates.

" Steve Canyon," a film series about the adventure of an Air Force officer, will make its debut in the fall over the National Broadcasting Company television network. The halfhour program will be presented on Thursday evenings, but the time period has not been determined.
The United Packinghouse Workers Union said yesterday it was ready to renew merger talks with the Amalgamated Meat Cutters and Butcher Workmen.
MIAMI BEACH, Fla., May 19 -- A do-it-yourself solution to the problem of extending the duration of unemployment insurance benefits appeared to be gaining favor among state governments today.
WASHINGTON, May 19 -- The United States and Canada have formally established a joint North American air defense command.

Ambassador Corrigan is right when he attributes the anti-American violence during the Nixon South American tour to minority action. He and those who think as he does unfortunately are wrong if they ascribe a knowledge and understanding of "the need for friendship and confidence between the sister republics of America in this time or world crisis" to "the overwhelming majority of Peruvians, Colombians and Venezuelans."

There were 2,760 persons seated and eighty standees in the audience at Carnegie Hall last night for the homecoming concert of Van Cliburn, the 23-year-old Texan who won last month's Tchaikovsky Piano Competition in Moscow.
The French have long had a saying that "the Republic doesn't amount to much, but it defends itself well."
Mayor Wagner's Special Committee on Major League Baseball is still hopeful it can bring a National League team to New York.
Stockholders of the Hertz Corporation approved at their annual meeting in Chicago yesterday an increase in the authorized common stock to 7,000,000 from 3,000,000 shares.

" THEY GATHERED AT THE RIVER,"* a study of old-time religious revivals in the United States by Bernard Weisberger, is written with appropriate zeal. The book gives us a bountiful lot of our history from what I can only call a coolly enthusiastic point of view. It presents with wit and fervor the celebrated and the forgotten spellbinding, stem-winding revivalists who have waxed and roared and waned through two centuries or so.
ATLANTIC CITY, May 19 -The president of the Maryland Bankers' Association today advocated use of good common sense to help "lick the recession."
PARIS, May 19 (Reuters) -- Following, in unofficial translation, are the texts of Gen. Charles de Gaulle's statement and the questions and answers that followed at his news conference today:
Following is the State Department statement on the expulsion of a United States Embassy official from the Soviet Union:

WASHINGTON, May 19 (UP) -- The Supreme Court refused today to reconsider its rejection of the appeals by two former Truman Administration officials from criminal conspiracy convictions in an income tax case.

WHITE PLAINS, May 19 -- Plans for the biggest shopping and business center in Westchester County were filed with city officials here today. It would embrace the 162 acres on the northwest side of the Hutchinson River Parkway in the Rosedale residential area of White Plains, extending from Mamaroneck Avenue to North Street.
LONDON, May 19 -- The British Government today blamed subversion and incitement from "outside" for the current disorders in Lebanon. "Outside" means Egypt, a spokesman said.
WASHINGTON, May 19 (UP) -- The Supreme Court today reversed a narcotics conviction of Joseph George Sherman of New York with some harsh words for the Federal prosecutors involved.

WASHINGTON, May 19 (UP) -- The Supreme Court today ordered a new trial for Frank Andrew Payne of Pine Bluff, Ark., who had been convicted of clubbing his boss to death with an iron bar. He was given a death sentence.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were unchanged to 16 points (80 cents a bale) up yesterday, with the summer contracts showing the most strength.

The action of the President of the United State in ordering marines and soldiers to the Caribbean at the time of the reprehensible attack on Vice President Nixon in Caracas may be considered as a hasty decision which will further weaken our relations with Latin America.

WASHINGTON, May 19 (AP) -- The Supreme Court refused today to hear an appeal by a Pennsylvania farmer who said his religious beliefs prevented him from complying with the Federal marketing quota imposed for the 1954 wheat crop.
WASHINGTON, May 19 -- The United States and Britain have agreed to consult and try to act together if the integrity of Lebanon should be threatened.

LONDON, May 19 -- Share prices held steady in the stock market today, although trading was at a low ebb. Most share groups regained much of their early losses and closed with minor movements either way.

WASHINGTON, May 19 (UP) -- Congress should curb "unprincipled unions" that use picketing by outsiders to force unwilling employes to join unions, William P. Treacy of the Illinois Chamber of Commerce declared today.

ROME, May 19 -- Samuel Alphonsus Cardinal Stritch suffered a stroke here today in the clinic where he was recovering from the amputation of his right arm three weeks ago. His condition, which is causing concern, was described tonight as "stationary."
WASHINGTON, May 19 -The Supreme Court in two cases today restricted the authority of the Interstate Commerce Commission to regulate transportation within a single state.

WARSAW, May 19 (Reuters) -- Poland has rejected a British Government suggestion that the International Supervision and Control Commission in Laos -- of which Poland is a member -- should be dissolved immediately, the Polish news agency P. A. P. reported today.
Six newsmen were named yesterday as the recipients of the first fellowships in an advanced science writing program at the Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism.
PARIS, May 19 -- Gen. Charles de Gaulle offered today to rule France by "exceptional" but legal means and disclaimed any intent to impose himself as dictator by force.
The Richmond - Petersburg, Va., Turnpike Authority sold $6,150,000 of turnpike revenue bonds, due July 1, 1995, yesterday. The bonds were priced at 97 with a 4 1/2 per cent coupon.

TUNIS, May 19 (Reuters) -The Tunisian Government said tonight that French troops in thirty armored vehicles from the army post at Remada, in southern Tunisia, kidnapped six Tunisian soldiers yesterday from a frontier post.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 19 -- E. Roland Harriman, chairman of the American National Red Cross, called today for the correction of "weaknesses that still exist in our fund raising."
MINNEAPOLIS, May 19 (AP) -- The San Francisco Giants walloped the Chicago White Sox, 10 -- 1, in an exhibition game at Metropolitan Stadium tonight before 12,659 fans.

VIENNA, May 19 -- The three-day congress of the Slovak Communist party, which ended today in Bratislava, expelled two prominent communists for "bourgeois nationalism" and repeatedly condemn the Yugoslav Communists for "departing from Marxist-Leninist principles."
" Did you see the ad showing a couple washing a Rolls-Royce?"

STUTTGART, Germany, May 19 -- The withdrawal of all foreign troops from Germany and the removal of the two rival German states from the Atlantic and Warsaw alliances were advocated today by Social Democratic leaders at a party congress.

In yesterday's Books of the Times a review was published of "The Marches of El Dorado," by Michael Swan. The review was highly favorable, but it failed to mention that Mr. Swan's book was published by the Beacon Press.

WASHINGTON, May 19 (AP) -- Senator Albert Gore, Democrat of Tennessee, said today that an eleven-state check had shown "a disturbing lack of uniformity" in procedures for preparing cost estimates for the interstate highway network.
CHICAGO, May 19 (AP) -- Trading in grain futures became brisk near the close on the Board of Trade today and prices of most May contracts moved well ahead on short covering.

THE revolution on Seventh Avenue has subsided. The war of the chemises, touched off in Paris, is won. The newest "new look" in ten years not only stirred the inevitable furor that goes hand in hand with any radical change in fashion but, more important, it rescued a languishing dress business.
The Port of New York Authority warned yesterday that the proposal for an Upper New York Bay bridge connecting Jersey City and Brooklyn was "shot through with basic misconceptions and defects."
WASHINGTON, May 19 (AP) -- The United States is going to set up four production lines at Poland's Poznan International Trade Fair this year. They will turn out textiles, clothing and wood products.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- President Eisenhower will fly to New York tomorrow to brief the nation on the recession and to do what he can to bolster Republican chances in the Congressional elections next fall.
Two of the nation's largest electric utility systems were joined today with the highest voltage connection ever used in this country.

Advance word about the design of the 1959 model automobiles has stirred up speculation as to whether Detroit car manufacturers are in step with current tastes among car buyers. Matters of styling and automotive engineering are best left to the specialists and need not concern us here.
Riverdale residents in the Bronx will give blood today to the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program at Public School 141, Independence Avenue and 237th Street.
Joseph Curran, president of the National Maritime Union, accused the Bureau of the Budget yesterday of "usurping the administrative and Congressional functions of our Government operations."
WASHINGTON, May 19 (AP) -A railway labor spokesman, accused the railroads today of putting on a fictitious poor mouth in seeking Government aid.
WASHINGTON, May 19 (AP) The Department of Agriculture said today that the amount of sugar that may be marketed in the United States in 1958 was being increased by 100,000 tons to 8,900,000 tons.
MIAMI, May 19 (AP) -- Representative Dante B. Fascell, Democrat of Florida has asked the Air Force to investigate the soliciting of gift yachts in Miami by the New York Wing of the Civil Air Patrol.
The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People denounced Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr. yesterday for "extreme racialism."

May 19 -- A warning that segregation in housing mixed with population growth could ultimately destroy suburban communities was made here tonight by Dr. Frank S. Horne. Dr. Horne is executive director of the New York City Commission on Intergroup Relations.
WASHINGTON, May 19 -- The State Department disclosed today that the Soviet Government had expelled a young United States diplomat from the Soviet Union.
Gustave G. Rosenberg was re-elected unanimously last night as chairman of the Board of Higher Education, governing body of the municipal college system.
I would like to take this opportunity to commend your newspaper and staff on the fine section "The News of the Week in Review" offered in your Sunday issue.
Two television mechanics were fined $250 each and received one-year suspended sentences in the Brooklyn Court of Special Sessions yesterday for padding customer repair bills.

HOME cooks might pick up some culinary tricks if they could peek into the kitchens of a large, busy hotel. Here, for example, is what went on one recent morning at the Essex House on Central Park South:
PARIS, May 19 -- Gen. Charles de Gaulle strode into a Left Bank hotel today and back onto the French political stage after almost three years of self-imposed obscurity.

The reduced flow of European immigrants to Canada through Canadian ports has resulted in a substantial decline in westbound trans-Atlantic ship passenger traffic in the first four months of this year.

ALGIERS, May 19 -- Gen. Raoul Salan, commander in chief of French forces in Algeria, offered a pardon today to any of the Algerian nationalist forces willing to surrender their weapons to the French Army.
Trunz, Inc., put on a luncheon yesterday to show what it was offering at Brussels World's Fair and to defend the prices.

The Wasco Chemical Company has signed an agreement to purchase the Celastic Corporation of Kearny, N. J., from its joint owners, E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co. and the United Shoe Machinery Corporation. The purchase is to be for an undisclosed amount of cash.
The nickel shortage -- a headache for industry and defense planners for several years during and after the Korean war -- has become an oversupply of substantial proportions.
An emergency anti-recession meeting of business and union leaders at the White House, was urged yesterday by Lansing P. Shield, president of the Grand Union Company.
The muzzle of a rifle poked slowly through a partly opened window in a suburban dwelling. It stopped, was steadied in careful aim. Then came a sharp report. "Darn!" a woman's voice said. "I missed."
The Columbia Gas System, Inc., announced plans yesterday to acquire substantially all the assets of the Gulf Interstate Gas Company.
Zionism would do "an enormous service to mankind" if it would give up attempts to bring Jews from every land to Israel, Norman Thomas declared last night.
PARIS, May 19 -- Workers of the Communist-dominated General Confederation of Labor pulled switches at 3 P. M. today and left the city's subway system paralyzed for an hour.
WASHINGTON, May 19 -- An order requiring admission of seven Negro children to all-white schools in near-by Arlington County, Virginia, was left standing today by the Supreme Court.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 19 -- President Tito's Yugoslav Communist League has drafted a moderate but firm reply to the recent ultimatum from the Central Committee of the Soviet party, reliable sources said tonight.

The St. Louis-San Francisco Railway board took no action yesterday on paying a dividend on the common stock. The road, which last year paid four quarterly dividends of 37 1/2 cents a share each on the common stock, omitted the payment during the first quarter this year.

CINCINNATI, May, 19 (UP) -- Red Schoendienst's dash home on Hank Aaron's foul fly in the twelfth inning enabled the Milwaukee Braves to defeat the Cincinnati Redlegs, 4 -- 3, tonight and recapture the National League lead.
COTTON is now traveling in silk-stocking circles. Where it was once stamped Purina Chows, it now carries the label of Christian Dior and Pauline Trigere, among other designers.
CARACAS, Venezuela, May 19 -- The Venezuelan Government crisis was partly resolved tonight by the appointment of two new members of the ruling junta.
School truancy and broken homes were listed last night by two public officials as twin causes of juvenile delinquency.
DETROIT, May 19 (AP) -- Passenger car output so far this year totals 1,750,493 units, compared with 2,663,689 in the comparable 1957 period.
Either Yale or the University of Washington seems likely to be the crew to represent the United States in the rowing exchange race to be held in Moscow July 20.
WASHINGTON, May 19 (AP) -- The Teamsters Union said today its members employed by Montgomery - Ward Company had authorized a strike by overwhelming vote. No date was set for a walkout.

A quiet but significant gain has been made on the question of the status of the United States military bases in the Philippines. The formal negotiation on the most difficult points has not been resumed. But our Ambassador, Charles E. Bohlen, and the Philippine Foreign Secretary, Felixberto Serrano, have been having a series of unpublicized talks and have come out with something concrete on which there is full agreement.
Mayor Wagner joined yesterday a growing list of municipal officials who will not attend a meeting of the New York State Conference of Mayors at Lake Placid, N. Y., June 1 to 4.
Senator Jacob K. Javits warned yesterday against "a new isolationism possibly arising from Vice President Richard M. Nixon's South American tour.
Following is the text of the statement yesterday on Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr. by the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People:
WASHINGTON, May 19 -- The dual rate system, a familiar practice in ocean shipping for many years, was struck down today by the Supreme Court.
April earnings statements of leading railroads are due today and tomorrow. Since no good news is expected, the rails led the stock market lower yesterday.

MOSCOW, May 19 -- The Soviet Government warned all officials in its far-flung industrial empire today that failure to meet production and delivery quotas could henceforth be treated as a criminal offense.

The Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) said yesterday it had received a favorable ruling from the Internal Revenue Service on an offer to exchange its shares for those of the minority interest in the International Petroleum Company, Ltd.

PORTLAND, Ore., May 19 (AP) -- Washington and Southern California were returned to good standing today by the Pacific Coast Conference. Their football teams will thus be eligible for the Rose Bowl in 1959.
BEIRUT, May 19 -- An effort at compromise by the Lebanese Opposition with the Government was reported tonight. It could not be confirmed.

An experienced TV producer, Robert Herridge, is thinking of a change of pace by switching those activities to the Broadway stage for the first time. He has an option on "The Sign of Jonah," which is scheduled for fall production.
A prisoner who served seventeen years of a life sentence as a convicted murderer was ordered freed yesterday by the United States Court of Appeals.
PHILADELPHIA, May 19 -- Kanamycin, a new drug is being used "with promising results" against tuberculosis, the National Tuberculosis Association was told today.

RYE, N. Y., May 19 -- An attempt to stir interest in the nation's foreign problems will be made Wednesday night when Thomas K. Finletter, former Secretary of the Air Force, is "cross-examined" at a forum in the Osborn School here.

PANAMA, May 19 -- A student died today of injuries received in a disturbance created by several thousand high school students and others around the Presidential palace and the near-by office of the Ministry of Education. At least half a dozen Other students and four national guardsmen were treated at a hospital for injuries.
President Eisenhower and Vice President Richard M. Nixon will both spend the day in New York today.

Councilmen Stein and Hearn of Brooklyn, in a letter published on this page today, seem to have set out on the arduous task of trying to prove that the Port of New York Authority is not a success, and hence should not be entrusted with modernization of the city-owned waterfront.
Positive American action in the Middle East to counter Arab and Soviet influence there was urged here last night at a dinner marking Israel's tenth anniversary as a nation.
GARDEN CITY, L. I., May 19 -- The sixty-fourth annual convention of the New York State Federation of Women's Clubs opened here tonight at the Garden City Hotel with 400 club women attending.
UTICA, N. Y., May 19 (AP) -- The State Police captain assigned to reorganize this city's scandal-rocked police force says that he found gambling and prostitution operating unmolested.
The Navy, in a new and dramatic general order, has reemphasized to its officers that the "proper study of mankind is man."
Shakespeare has an outdoor stage in Central Park and his producer has a problem -- whether to get Othello to Cyprus by sail-topped raft or oil-drum pontoon at the opening of Act II.
TRENTON, May 19 -- The Democratic-controlled State Assembly moved today to restore $22,199,000 deleted from Gov. Robert B. Meyner's record $399,873,233 budget by the Republican-dominated Senate.
WASHINGTON, May 19 -California will have a chance next fall to tell the Supreme Court why it should hear her challenge to the liquor laws of the State of Washington.

The fourteenth annual spring book drive of the American Merchant Marine Association was opened yesterday. A book donated by Mrs. Dwight D. Eisenhower was placed in a steel lifeboat on the sidewalk in front of 630 Fifth Ave., near Fifty-first Street.

Three offers are being juggled by Timmy Everett, young actor who made a personal hit in "The Dark at the Top of the Stairs." Although Timmy is under contract to "Stairs" through Nov. 11, the new firm of Milton H. Greene and Louis d'Almeida has him in mind for the central role in a musical, which they hope to tie up.

Two old battlers met in the winner's circle after the feature race at Belmont yesterday -- the former heavyweight champion, Jack Dempsey, and the 9-year-old Mr. Turf, who won the $7,500 Whitestone Handicap.
Ranked as the nation's leading participant sport, bowling last week made the grade as a spectator sport, too, in Bergen County, N. J.

BIG INDIAN, N. Y., May 19 -- Another secret bait that may well prove to be a trout-killer of fearsome scope has turned up at the headwaters of the Esopus Creek. Probably the Indians and Kit Carson used it, but no doubt it has been lost from the Age of Buffalo Bill to the Age of the TV Jollyboy.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, May 20 (UP) -- The Philadelphia Orchestra received a warm reception here tonight as it presented its first behind-the-Iron-Curtain concert of its current fourteennation goodwill tour.
ALBANY, May 20 -- The Democratic leader of the state Senate today accused Senator MacNeil Mitchell, Manhattan Republican, of being "bullheadedly" bent on wrecking the New York City transit system:

GLADWYNE, Pa., May 20 -A prelude to the Griscom Cup team matches between women golfers of Boston, New York and Philadelphia was held today over the Spring Mill course of the Philadelphia Country Club. The preliminary tourney was won by Mrs. Edward McAuliffe of Boston, Mrs. Joseph Nesbitt of New York and Mrs. Earl Scott of Philadelphia with a four-under-par 33, 37 -- 70.
Further cutbacks in the production of copper and aluminum were announced yesterday by two major producers.
On the first enforcement day of the 1958 Big Sweep campaign yesterday, the Sanitation Department issued 892 summonses.
REHOVOT, Israel, May 20 -Two nuclear physicists who made major contributions to the atomic bomb pleaded today that their discoveries be used only for the benefit of mankind.

The battle lines in France were drawn with greater clarity yesterday when Premier Pierre Pflimlin won a resounding majority for himself, his Government and the present political system. The fact that his majority was great enough to permit him to have dispensed with Communist support was especially significant.

"Othello" went into rehearsal on Monday without an Othello. Frank Silvera, who was chosen for that part in the New York Shakespeare Festival's impending presentation, has accepted a Hollywood starring offer, which, he said, he could not afford to reject.
WHITE PLAINS, May 20 -George S. Haight, manager of the Westchester Parkway Authority, reported today he was seeking a reduced-toll plan for regular users of the county's toll parkways.

MILWAUKEE, May 20 (AP) -- Duke Snider, at peace with the Dodgers once more, crashed an eleventh inning pinch double that scored the deciding run tonight as Los Angeles gained a 6--3 victory over the Milwaukee ' Braves. Milwaukee was stQpped on two hits by Sandy Koufax, who yielded three runs in the first inning.

Some degree of economic recovery in the oil industry may be expected before the end of this year if consumer demand develops as expected, Albert L. Nickerson, president of the Socony Mobil Oil Company, Inc., told stockholders at their annual meeting held here yesterday.

THIRTY-ONE years ago next August I stood on the green turf inside the few remaining, ruined walls of the great church of Glastonbury Abbey and wrestled with my disappointment. It was raining steadily. But so it had been at Kenilworth Castle, which is also thoroughly demolished, and there I had not felt nearly as depressed. The reason for my different reactions, I now know, was a matter of preparation.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 20 -- Apathy, lack of imagination and failure to make the public conscious of the "good job" the organization is doing were ascribed to many Red Cross chapters today.

A group of four five-story apartment houses at 420-26 East Eightieth Street between First and York Avenues has been resold by David S. Meister, realty operator, to an investing client of Leon London, attorney. The property of 103 by 100 feet was acquired recently by the seller.

PERHAPS the most poignant aspect of yesterday afternoon's twin bill at the Theatre de Lys is that it was a one-performance venture. The major offering, a dramatization of Frank O'Connor's lyrical short story, "Guests of the Nation," deserves to be seen by many more people than could be crowded at one matinee into the cozy theatre on Christopher Street.

Ella Koblo Guama, a member of the Legislative Council of Sierra Leone, British West Africa, and Paramount Chieftainess of Kaiyamba Chiefdom at Moyamba, arrived yesterday for a four-month visit under the State Department's leadership exchange program.

ST. LOUIS, May 20 (AP) -The St. Louis Cardinals reinforced their pitching staff today by acquiring a righthanded hurler, Jim Brosnan, from the Chicago Cubs in return for Al Dark, a shortstop. No money changed hands.

WHEN Robin Roberts finally registered his 191st victory for the Phillies not long ago, he set a club record. But the significance of the feat rests not so much in the mark that was broken as in the name of the man who had held the record. He was Grover Cleveland Alexander and any time a record of Old Pete's is broken it is a singular achievement.
The American Civil Liberties Union yesterday assailed the House Un-American Activities Committee for issuing a subpoena to Cyrus S. Eaton, the Cleveland industrialist.
RABAT, Morocco, May 20 -The Moroccan Government renewed its request for evacuation of French troops today as anxiety rose here over the possible spread of the dissidence in Algeria.

Dr. Benjamin Fine, former education editor of the The New York Times, was honored yesterday by the Urban League of Greater New York. He was cited for his "courageous, objective reporting" in connection with the implementation of the United States Supreme Court decision on integration.

Reform Jewish congregations of this area condemned bingo yesterday as a way of support for synagogues. They called upon other synagogues, churches and representatives of religious institutions to "reject and bar bingo and similar games as a means of maintaining the house of God."
JERICHO, L, I., May 20. -- The new Meadow Brook Club course was put to its first major test today with the start of the Long Island open golf tournament.

Four Sports Car Club of America national championship races have been run this year -- Miami, Marlboro, Md.; Danville, Va., and Cumberland, Md. Thirteen remain on the calendar. Ten of them are firm dates, three are tentative.
A middle-of-the road group in Local 88, International Organization of Masters, Mates and Pilots, is seeking to end strife that has existed between other factions of the local more than two months.
L. Judson Morhouse, Republican state chairman, called upon party workers yesterday to go to work to get out a big vote in this year's election for the governorship.
Wheaties, which was associated with sports for many years, will return to the field next month with a $3,000,000 advertising program.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 20 (UP) -- Lebanon deported at least 1,000 Syrian nationals today amid renewed Government charges that the United Arab Republic was engineering the uprising against the pro-Western regime here.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -The Department of Commerce announced today that export licensing for shipment to East Europe was lower in the first quarter of this year than at any time since the second quarter of 1956.

MOSCOW, May 20 -- The Russians are aggrieved that none of their leading singers have been invited to appear at the Metropolitan Opera next season. They would like to send Ivan Petrov or Pavel Lisitsyan and would agree to send both of these leading baritones.

The Metropolitan Educational Television Association will cease production of public service programs and make a "large-scale" reduction in its personnel staff June 1. The staff numbers about forty-five.
The Federal Maritime Board acted yesterday to insure compliance with the United States Supreme Court decision outlawing the dual rate system.

WASHINGTON, May 20 (AP) -- James B. Carey said today that a labor bill sponsored by Senator John L. McClellan, Democrat of Arkansas, "would be a major move in the direction of Fascist-type and Soviettype unionism."

WASHINGTON, May 20 (UP) -- Former President Truman led a group of top Democratic leaders tonight in making fun of and criticizing the Eisenhower Administration to feature the Democrats' annual party night celebration.
The annual Army Yotmgl Men's Christian Association's l spring party, which this yeart honors the British, will be held today at the Officers Club on Governors Island.

The short interest on the New York Stock Exchange last Thursday, May 15, was the highest since May, 1931. Aggregating 5,472,027 shares, it was 704,164 shares above the April 15 level of 4,767,863 shares.
ALGIERS, May 20 -- Jacques Soustelle, idol of the European street crowds of Algiers, called tonight for the complete integration of the Moslem and European populations of this disturbed land.
NOW that summer is approaching, babies, as well as their parents, can be in the swim of things.

Warner Brothers announced yesterday that the "backroom work" at its twenty-eight film exchanges throughout the country would be taken over by National Film Service, Inc. The move to simplify the complex and costly system of distributing theatres is the most decisive to be made by any major Hollywood studio.

PARIS, May 20 -- The French drama has assumed the aspects of a ritual play in which all principal actors seem obligated by some code to deceive both themselves and the audience. The reason for this pretense, of course, is the desire to avoid provocation and fratricide. But nevertheless the spectacle seems strangely sham.

BRIDGETON, N. J., May 20 (AP) -- A 19-year-old man was killed and his wife seriously injured tonight when the cars they were driving smashed into each other with terrific impact at a rural crossroads near here.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -Official Washington has reacted to the anti-Americanism of its allies in Latin America, Europe and the Middle East with extraordinary patience, but this is not necessarily representative of the true feelings of the American people.

PARIS, May 20 -- Apart from the experts, few are worrying about France's economic and financial crisis, accentuated by the war in Algeria. But it may be still further accentuated by the struggle for power within France resulting from that unfinished and ever more costly war.
Bertha Levy in her letter to The Times published May 8 misunderstood completely my position before the Senate Agriculture Committee.
Cocoa futures opened lower yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange, but recovered to register substantial gains at the close. Carryover selling and liquidation depressed prices early in the session.
WASHINGTON, May 20 -The American Bar Association's board of governors came out today against pending Senate legislation to curb the Supreme Court.
Following is the text of President Eisenhower's address last night at the economic mobilization conference at the Astor Hotel, as recorded by The New York Times:
WASHINGTON, May 20 -- Opponents of the Lincoln Square urban renewal project in New York challenged its constitutionality today in a petition filed with the Supreme Court.
GLASGOW, Scotland, May 20 (UP) -- A crowded commuter train collided with a switching locomotive on the outskirts of Glasgow today. Eighty-three persons were injured in the morning rush-hour wreck.
Like the theatregoer who has missed the first two acts, the reader who tries to understand current French affairs out of their historic context often finds them unintelligible.
ALTHOUGH "N. B. C. Matinee Theatre" has been notified that it will not be returning to television next season, the program showed yesterday that it has not yielded to bitterness or despair.

The Twentieth Century - Fox Film Corporation had consolidated net earnings of $2,147,711 in the first quarter. This is equivalent to 84 cents a share on the 2,564,686 shares of common stock outstanding and compares with $2,171,680, or 82 cents a share, on 2,644,486 shares outstanding a year ago.

Blyth Co., Inc., Lehman Brothers, Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., B. J. Van Ingen Co., Inc., and the Ohio Company are joint managers of a group, that is offering today $32,000,000 State of Ohio Major Throughfare Construction Bonds.
CAMDEN, N. J., May 20 (AP) -- Mark L. Stucker's Count Swedak scored his second straight triumph today, winning the Sundialer Purse at Garden State Park.

BALTIMORE, May 20 (AP) -One of the victims of the plane collision over the Potomac River today was a Johns Hopkins psychiatrist who had earned, a high reputation only a few years out of medical school.

HACKENSACK, N. J., May 20 -- The fifth annual spring house tour of the BergenPassaic Mount Holyoke College Club will be held on Saturday. Proceeds of visits to six earlyAmerican homes will go to the college.

The Eastman Kodak Company announced yesterday the election of three sales and advertising executives as vice presidents. They are Gerald B. Zornow, director of sales for the apparatus and optical division; Theodore F. Pevear, director of sales administration, and W. B. Potter, director of advertising.

CAIRO, May 20 -- The Government of President Gamal Abdel Nasser was reported today to have given strong assurances to the United States that it had no intention of trying to force Lebanon into the United Arab Republic.

From the day American troops landed in Oran, Algeria, in November, 1942, they attracted street urchins by the thousands, as was the case throughout their invasion operations in World War II. One of the little fellows of Oran, Lahouari Godih, who knew his heroes as only a lot of men in khaki, made the most of his chances with the Americans.

KIAMESHA LAKE, N. Y., May 20 -- Philip M. Klutznick president of B'nai B'rith, challenged tonight "any theory which suggests that only bigger satellites and deadlier missiles will rocket us into guarantees of peace with justice."

LONDON, May 20 (Reuters) -- The program for the visit of Prime Minister Harold Macmillan to the United States and Canada was announced here tonight. He will leave London by air June 6 and arrive in New York the next morning. He will then fly to Washington, where he will spend the night.
Frank Costello yesterday lost his appeal for a new trial as an income-tax dodger. The United States Court of Appeals unanimously upheld a decision of Federal Judge John F. X. McGohey.

PARIS, May 20 -- Premier Pierre Pflimlin won tonight a new endorsement of his struggle to maintain the parliamentary regime under attack by Gen. Charles de Gaulle and the military-civilian dissidents in Algeria.
MOSCOW, May 20 (AP) -- Six United States women physicans touring Russian medical institutons told today of having watched Soviet scientists bring a dead dog back to life.

All the horses that cleared the jumps in the Belmont Spring Maiden Steeplechase at Belmont Park yesterday finished in the betting pay-offs. In the winner's spot was John S. Schiff's Muguet II. A half-dozen lengths back was the Whitewood Stud's Arywa. Nizam's Pet, owned by C. Randolph Snowden, was third.
CHICAGO, May 20 -- If the Yankees needed anything else to assure themselves of a nice long easy ride to another American League pennant they got it tonight.
WASHINGTON, May 20 (AP) -- A majority of the Senate Judiciary Committee today urged passage of a bill to curb the Supreme Court. It said Congress had a duty to restore "a proper balance of powers."

Prices of nylon tire yarn were reduced 10 cents a pound yesterday by the largest producer as reports circulated that a major automobile maker had found nylon tires too expensive to be adopted for original equipment tires on a large scale.

In the fall of 1954 Park Commissioner Robert Moses wrote to Mayor Wagner that the Soldiers and Sailors Monument on Riverside Drive at Eighty-ninth Street, one of the finest examples of memorial architecture in the city, was crumbling so badly that "repairs to this monument cannot wait."
Harlem Democratic leaders met again yesterday, but still could not agree on a candidate to run for Representative in the Sixteenth Congressional District.
OMAHA, Neb., May 20 -- A lack of vacation jobs may result in a sharp increase in juvenile delinquency this summer, the chief of the Federal Children's Bureau warned today.
LONDON, May 20 -- The upper echelons of British politics, industry and finance contemplated the possibility today of Gen. Charles de Gaulle's return to power in France.

For the good of the New York City public school system Mayor Wagner should release Dr. John J. Theobald, his Deputy Mayor, from City Hall responsibilities so that he can devote full time to preparing for his new job of Superintendent of Schools.
WASHINGTON, May 20, -Secretary of State Dulles said today that despite the recent cloudburst of international trouble he believed there was no need for a basic change in United States foreign policy.
The Newspaper Reporters Association of New York had an unexpected guest last night at its tenth annual dinner.
A motel with 400 rooms, play areas, wading pools, shuffleboard courts, gardens -- and lots of parking space -- is planned for the West Side of midtown Manhattan.

CINCINNATI, May 20 (AP) -San Francisco's Giants snapped a tie with an eighth-inning uprising good for two runs and gained a 4 -- 2 victory tonight over Cincinnati's Redlegs. Mike McCormack, a bonus southpaw, yielded five hits in posting his fourth victory in a row.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 20 -- Piston-engined commercial airliners have become the model-T's of the intercontinental airlanes, according to a report issued here today.
WASHINGTON, May 20 (UP) -- The Senate Internal Security subcommittee called for new laws today to make desertion to the West more appealing to citizens of Communist countries.

NOT all the off-Broadway shows are off Broadway. One of them opened last night at the Adelphi Theatre, and under the auspices of Gilbert Miller, who brought it all the way from France. It is Francoise Sagan's "drama ballet" called here "The Broken Date," produced by the Ballet-Theatre Francais, with Toni Lander, Adolfo Andrade and Noelle Adam heading the cast.

COLUMBIA UNIVERSITY archivists, digging around the other day for material for the Theodore Roosevelt Centennial, came across an item dating back to 1881, when young Teddy, a student at Columbia Law School, worked himself into the race for a seat in the New York State Assembly.
WILMINGTON, Del., May 20 (AP) -- Earnings of Consolidated Natural Gas Company for the full year may equal last year because of a good first quarter, James Comerford, president, said today.
Frank Costello insisted yesterday that he never saw the gunman who wounded him a year ago.
RYE, N. Y., May 20 -- Educational television was hailed tonight as a major hope in the development of national skills to keep this country abreast of the Soviet Union.
Chiffon stoles in contrasting or ombre shades can give a costume look to summer evening dresses.
BRIDGEPORT, Conn., May 20 -- Antiquarians met defeat today in their long campaign to preserve the Harral-Wheeler mansion here.

The New York Central Railroad recorded a $3,068,598 loss last month, as its gross revenues plunged more than 20 per cent to $51,383,994. In April, 1957, when gross was $64,309,144, the Central cleared $2,315,591, equal to 35 cents a share on its common stock.
Socially prominent waltz devotees from two cities combined last evening to hold the first New-York-Boston Waltz Evening.
Thousands of home-bound commuters were delayed last night when two cars of a Long Island Rail Road train became uncoupled shortly after it left Pennsylvania Station.
President Eisenhower received a warm reception here yesterday as he rode in a motorcade from La Guardia Airport in Queens to the Astor Hotel in Times Square.

David B. Solove, realty operator, bought the five-story apartment house for twenty-one families on plot 50 by 100 feet at 1049 Simpson Street, the Bronx. The sale was the first involving the property in fifteen years.
SCARSDALE, N. Y., May 20 -- A benefit breakfast and fashion show sponsored by the Westchester Alumnae Club of Kappa Alpha Theta will be held at Lord Taylor's in Eastchester Thursday morning.
GARDEN CITY, L. I., May 20 -- Two candidates were entered today in a contest for president of the New York State Federation of Women's Clubs at the group's convention at the Garden City Hotel.

The city's housekeeping costs for the fiscal year beginning July 1 will be $1,991,952,986. This was the amount of the 1958-59 budget approved yesterday by the City Council.

PARIS, May 20 (AP) -- American entrants advanced in the women's singles and the men's singles and doubles as the French international tennis championships -- rated the world's top clay court event -opened today.

President Eisenhower stayed indoors yesterday afternoon in his seventh floor suite at the Astor Hotel. Except for luncheon with members of his personal staff, he held only one scheduled appointment. That was with members of the 1958 National Citizens for Eisenhower and Nixon committee.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -Demands for greater air safety were voiced in the House today as members approved a $949,892,000 appropriations bill to run the Commerce Department, Civil Aeronautics Board and related agencies through the fiscal year 1959.
Borough President John Cashmore of Brooklyn asked the Board of Estimate yesterday to hold a public hearing on the Transit Authority's proposal to cut service on thirty-five Brooklyn bus routes.

WHITE PLAINS, May 20 -Joseph F. Gagliardi, District Attorney of Westchester County, said today he was undecided whether to retry or appeal a United States Court of Appeals decision freeing William Wade, who has served seventeen years of a life sentence.
World events of the last ten days have been "the most serious this country has suffered since the early days of the Korean War," Senator William Proxmire said yesterday.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, May 20 -- Government forces have wrested the big Morotai airfield from the rebels, a communique announced here tonight.
Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz informed Mayor Wagner yesterday that unless the City was prepared to start civil court action in the Real Estate Bureau scandals he would do so.
Amherst College students and alumni note with regret the imminent retirement of a man who has made outstanding contributions to the philosophy of small college athletics.
THE State of Maine has come up with a set of fishing-survey figures that ought to make everybody happy and statisticians delirious.
CHICAGO, May 20 (AP) -- The longs outlasted the shorts in their waiting contest for price breaks on May grain futures contracts on the Board of Trade today.
French and American patriotic societies joined yesterday in commemorating the 124th anniversary of the death of General Marquis de Lafayette.

BALTIMORE, May, 20 (AP) -Mayor Thomas D'Alesandro swept to victory over George P. Mahoney, paving contractor, and five others tonight in Maryland's bitterly contested primary for United States Senate.
The only way to slash the air - collision hazard overnight would be to enforce bad-weather flight rules in good weather, most aviation experts agree.
Nine representatives of the United States plastics industry will visit the Soviet Union next month as a part of the cultural and technical exchange program established last January.

Earnings of American Airlines, Inc., for the first four months this year were $2,909,000. This compared with $2,991,000 in the similar period of 1957, C. R. Smith, president, told shareholders at the annual meeting yesterday in Wilmington, Del.

Col. S. J. Simon, Northeast regional commander of the Civil Air Patrol, said yesterday that there was "nothing irregular" about the soliciting and donation of yachts to the New York Wing of the C. A. P. by wealthy Miami residents.

DRIED mushrooms, which figure importantly in many European cuisines, are somewhat of a rarity in this country. To buy them, it usually has been necessary to make a trip to some shop that specializes in the foods of France or Italy.
Van Cliburn yesterday became the first musician to ride the hero's route up lower Broadway to City Hall.

DUBLIN, May 20 (AP) -- Ireland's Ron Delany, who attends Villanova College near Philadelphia, gave 15,000 homefolks something to cheer about tonight when he won the mile race in 4:07.5 at the Clonliffe Harriers' international meet.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 20 -- Lebanon's pro-Western Government is consulting the United States and Britain on the possibility of an appeal to the Security Council.

BARCELONA, Spain, May 30 (UP) -- Sweden split the concluding pair of singles matches with Spain today to gain a 3-2 victory in their Davis Cup tennis series and advance to the quarterfinal round of the European zone eliminations.
WASHINGTON, May 20 -- The Development Loan Fund announced today that it had authorized eight loans totaling $39,386,000 for five countries.
MOSCOW, May 20 -- The Soviet press has begun a strong campaign against officials and economic managers who have been placing local interests above those of the state.

Vice President Richard M. Nixon said yesterday that there was a "better than even chance" that Congress would enact new labor legislation this year. He said Congress would be "very irresponsible" if it did not.
WESTBURY, L. I., May 20 -As money goes -- and it surely goes at a horse park -- a double sawbuck is not a lot. But did you ever try to borrow $20 at the track?

PHILADELPHIA, Wednesday, May 21 -- Arthur T. McGonigle, the "new face" candidate of the Republican organization, defeated Harold E. Stassen for the gubernatorial nomination in yesterday's Pennsylvania primary.
Cotton futures prices declined 29 to 38 points ($1.45 to $1.90 a bale) on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday.

Fieldston captured the private schools' team title in its own relay carnival yesterday and Mountain Lakes of New Jersey took the public schools' honors. The meet was held on the Fieldston track in Riverdale.
The American Heart Association announced yesterday the award of three new career subsidies to scientists engaged in basic medical research.

There is pending before the Senate a bill passed by the House in the last session of the Congress. The declared purpose of this bill is "to protect producers and consumers against misbranding and false advertising of the fiber content of textile fiber products, and for other purposes."

President Eisenhower's speech last night on the economic situation seems likely to arouse a variety of reactions. For those who may have hoped that the President would use this occasion to make some dramatic new announcement of forceful initiative against the recession, the speech was doubtless disappointing.
The Alleghany Corporation, which until Robert R. Young's death last January was most often thought of as Mr. Young's holding company, took on a full Allan P. Kirby complexion yesterday.
New issues of public utility securities totaling $41,000,000 will be placed on the market today by investment banking syndicates.

CLEVELAND, May 20 (AP) -Car loadings on the New York, Chicago St. Louis (Nickel Plate) Railroad were off 25 per cent in the first four months of this year, but the railroad still earned 47 cents a share, Lynne L. White, board chairman, said today.
The Board of Education is hoping to start construction next year on a new $5,000,000 high school project adjacent to the planned Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts.

Recent closings of tuberculosis hospitals for want of patients have given the public the impression that this disease has been all but conquered by the use of modern drugs. The 1957 report of the Tuberculosis Preventorium for Children has done a real service in helping to correct this mistaken idea -- not to mention in telling a moving story about the work and the need of the institution.
HARTFORD, May 20 (UP) -The president of the United States Chamber of Commerce charged tonight "a union label" was sewed in the lining of the present recession.

In spite of amply demonstrated damage to merchants from previous parades on business days Mayor Wagner sponsored and approved amendment of law to open midtown Fifth Avenue permanently to one more annual parade, that of Loyalty Day.
PORTLAND, Ore., May 20 (AP) -- The Pacific Coast Conference failed to decide today just who would be eligible for the Rose Bowl bid in 1960.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 20 -- A novel effort to save an expiring television show by appealing for public financial support yesterday received the endorsement of the Hollywood Local 53 of the National Association of Broadcast Employes and Technicians.

TOKYO, Wednesday, May 21 (AP) -- Joseph P. Crowley, a former Yale football star, was arrested today by the Japanese police in connection with the death of his brother-in-law, T. A. D. Jones Jr.
MOSCOW, Wednesday, May 21 -- Officials of all Communist governments except Yugoslavia have gathered in Moscow for meetings of an undisclosed nature.
ROME, May 20 -- Samuel Alphonsus Cardinal Stritch, who suffered a stroke here yesterday, showed a slight improvement today. His doctors declared he was out of "immediate danger."

The supply of short-dated Treasury securities is apparently in for some shrinkage. That is what the market for Treasury bills seems to be saying. The longest-dated issue of the ninety-one-day paper at the close last night sold at a yield of about seven-eighths of 1 per cent.
LONDON, May 20 -- Britain moved on a wide front today to curtail large imports of butter from Europe and Ireland that have made British housewives happy and New Zealand dairy farmers unhappy.

The Western Electric Company and Litton Industries, Inc., announced yesterday completion of preliminary negotiations for the purchase by Litton of the Westrex Corporation, a wholly owned subsidiary of Western Electric.

The Offenbach Kickers of West Germany last night completed an undefeated tour of this country by beating the German-American League AllStars, 5 -- 0 for the second time. The Kickers won their sixth game at Eintracht Oval, Astoria, Queens, before a crowd of 4,500 soccer fans.

Senator Wayne Morse of Oregon should be encouraged in his efforts to investigate why official ignorance of Latin-American conditions caused Vice President Nixon to be exposed to such bitter humiliations.

PARIS, May 20 -- Where do the French military services stand? This was a vital question here today as the gravest crisis under the Fourth Republic entered its second week.

Every important group showed an inclination toward the plusside yesterday and the aggregate value of issues listed on the New York Stock Exchange rose more than $1,750,000,000. It was the best gain since March 6.
WASHINGTON, May 20 (AP) -- A House Education subcommittee agreed today on a multimillion - dollar program of Federal aid to education, including scholarships and student loans.
WASHINGTON, May 20 -- The Attorney General of Pennsylvania told Congress today that he favored an outright ban on all wiretapping.

THIS is the season for group exhibitions, and the Fine Arts Associates, 41 East Fifty-seventh Street, is making the most of it with a broad show of paintings and sculptures by European and American artists.

Van Cliburn's Carnegie Hall concert next Monday will be broadcast live by radio station WQXR.
LONDON, May 20 -- The stock market was quiet today. Prices moved somewhat irregularly, although the undertone was firm.

Drilling has been resumed at the natural gas well in Mitchell Hollow in the town of Windham in Greene County.

Gulton, president of the Metuchen, N. J., concern, predicted that the welder would have a significant impact in the packaging industry.

Net income of the Minute Maid Corporation and its consolidated subsidiaries rose to $1,285,816 for the six months ended May 4 from $79,645 in the corresponding period of last year, the semi-annual report disclosed yesterday.

RICHMOND, Va., May 21 -Roman Catholic editors were urged today to help preserve the United States as a Christian nation.
PARIS, May 21 -- The current political crisis seems to have had little effect on American tourists in France. They are already here by the thousands and the incoming flood is continuing.

AS every parent knows, most teen-age girls are apt to be creatures of impulse. They are fairly intense about getting what they want -- be it a new record or a party dress -- when they want it.
