Stockholders in the New York Central Railroad, gathering at their annual meeting in Albany today, may feel that they have already had all the bad news -- a $20,000,000 loss in the first four months this year.
A drop of 2,928,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks in the week ended last Friday was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute.

The election of Dudley Dowell and Richard K. Paynter Jr. as directors of the New York Life Insurance Company was announced yesterday by Devereux C. Josephs, chairman. Both men are executive vice presidents.

JERICHO, L. I., May 21 -- For a man who didn't know the Long Island open golf tournament was being held until last Friday, John Cleary, a personable, 29-year-old player, fared well today at the Meadow Brook Club.

WITHIN the last decade there has been a veritable Roman revolution in America's kitchens. A dozen varieties of pasta -- virtually unknown on the domestic scene ten years ago -- and the pungent spices that are part of certain Italian dishes have played a highly palatable role in this gastronomic conquest.
SYOSSET, L. I., May 21 -- A marching song in praise of Russian power, assigned to an elementary school's glee club here for memorizing, has stirred a minor storm among some of the parents.
Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy ruled out yesterday any unions or formal collective bargaining machinery for the uniformed police force.
Former Attorney Genera Herbert Brownell Jr. called yesterday for the nomination of John V. Lindsay as the Republican candidate in the Seventeenth Congressional District.

Representative Carl T. Durham, chairman of the Joint Congressional Committee on Atomic Energy, last night suggested international negotiations to limit the amount of radioactive material sent aloft in nuclear weapons tests.

HARTFORD, May 21 (UP) -- Two convicts who escaped last night from the state prison at Wethersford, Conn., by squeezing through a ventilator surrendered today. They were trapped in a cellar by thirty policemen armed with machine guns, tear gas and rifles.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 21 -Violinists in a symphony orchestra must play somewhat apart in pitch and timing to achieve a richness of tone, according to acoustical scientists at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. They intend to find out just how far apart.
WASHINGTON, May 21 -- Activity has slackened in two of the Government's anti-recession programs, Federal agencies reported today.
The State Department's chief for international economic affairs warned yesterday that the leaders of the Soviet bloc meeting in Moscow were engaged "in a large-scale economic offensive."

Twenty-one public housing authorities subsidized by the Public Housing Administration furthered the permanent financing of low-rent projects yesterday by borrowing $69,870,000 in the public bond market.
AT least 5,000,000 out-of-towners are expected to visit New York this summer and, for many women, the trip will be preceded by a shopping spree.
BUYING a mattress can be a nightmarish affair, especially to the woman about to become a homemaker for the first time.
The Gotham Chapter of the National Foundation for Muscular Dystrophy will give its annual luncheon in the ballroom of the Sheraton-East on Saturday.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 21 (AP) -- The United States declared today it was prepared to examine all proposals for using arbitration as a means of settling disputes in foreign trade.

CINCINNATI, May 21 (AP) -- Willie Mays opened the tenth inning with a home run into the right-field bleachers off Hal Jeffcoat that gave the San Francisco Giants a 5-4 victory over the Cincinnati Redlegs tonight.
WASHINGTON, May 21 -- The two largest record companies strongly opposed today proposed legislation that would prohibit any connection between them and radio or television broadcasters.
Parking lot operators in downtown city areas "are the beneficiaries of disaster and are likely to become its next victims," 300 of them were told yesterday.

The appointment of Richmond P. Gardner as co-chairman of the $75,000,000 campaign for the Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts was announced yesterday. He will serve with Clarence Francis on the campaign committee.
OTTAWA, May 21 (UP) -- Canada's commodity trade deficit for the first four months of 1958 was $174,300,000, down 57 per cent from $405,500,000 a year earlier, the Bureau of Statistics said today.
WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture issued two formal complaints today charging Swift Co. with violations of the Packers and Stockyards Act.

A floor in the building at 49 West Forty-fifth Street has been leased for ten years by the Life Circulation Company, a wholly owned subsidiary of Time, Inc. The deal was negotiated by Joseph B. Rogers Of Brown, Harris, Stevens, Inc., broker.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- The Federal Reserve Board reported today that the condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities showed that in the week ended Wednesday, May 14, there were:

The Washington Square problem lends itself to a simple solution it we will only deal with it with s sense of proportion as to the dimensions of the various proposals. Increased traffic through the Square will afford little relief to the traffic problem. For that other solutions must be found.

ROME, May 21 -- Pope Pius XII upheld today the right of a nation to defend itself militarily against an aggressor. At the same time he said the Roman Catholic Church did not believe war was either inevitable or desirable.

A tie for first place in the final event -- the broad jump -- gave the team title to Benjamin Franklin yesterday in the Public Schools Athletic League Manhattan track and field championship at Van Cortlandt Park Stadium in the Bronx.

The Senate Foreign Relations Committee is serving a great need in the investigation now beginning into United States policies in Latin America. It was not to be expected that Secretary Dulles and others in the State Department would or could concede that all is not well with our policies toward Latin America.

These menus, which appear each Thursday, use seasonally abundant foods and are moderate in cost. They are designed to strike a balance between appetite appeal and the convenience of the family cook. Dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.
IN its second and concluding installment on the "Kraft Theatre" on Channel 4 last night, "All the King's Men" was a telecast with moments of great emotional force.
Direct dialing of telegraphic messages from here to offices in Canada began yesterday.

" Let us face it," sighed the man from the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, "a chicken is not a tidy animal." There was no argument yesterday on the contention that live chickens shed a lot of feathers while being shipped in coops on an open truck. And when the wind blows, the feathers fly all over the street.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., May 21 -- Democrats teamed up with Republicans here today to endorse a local Republican for City Manager. They said it was time to explode the "myth of an expert stranger" being needed to run the city.
Martin L. Smith and Leo Greenland are leaving Gore Smith Greenland, Inc., to form their own agency. They said that they would open with $2,500,000 a year in billings.

The number of workers drawing unemployment insurance in this city rose slightly last week, but most other major industrial centers showed a continuation of the slow downward trend that began three weeks ago.

Correspondents who accompanied Princess Margaret on her recent tour of the Caribbean will endorse your editorial of May 13 suggesting that the action of T. W. A. in engaging a Negro as a stewardess is a praiseworthy one.

Public institutions shared more than $900,000 from the estate of Mrs. Ada Small Moore, who died Jan. 29, 1955. Mrs. Moore left a gross estate of $33,035,903 and a net of $29,129,046, it was disclosed yesterday in an estate tax appraisal.
WESTBURY, L. I., May 21 -Daily Gallon, a gallant gelding who acknowledges applause with polite bows, won the Class AA trot in tonight's harness racing program at Roosevelt Raceway.
Stocks passed an undistinguished day yesterday and ended with the averages a bit lower but with more stocks up than down.

New York Airways, operators of passenger helicopters, expects to gain soon a permanent mail rate covering the next five years. This information was contained in a letter to the company's stockholders by Robert L. Cummings Jr., president of the line.
CHICAGO, May 21 -- No matter what the game is or how it's played, the Yankees somehow manage to play it better than the other team.
Major blood-receiving agencies here took steps yesterday to establish a non-profit organization to coordinate their activities as recommended by the New York Academy of Medicine.
LONDON, May 21 (AP) -- Staid old Wimbledon today banned gold lame panties from its tennis courts.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, May 21 -- Indonesia's Foreign Minister saw evidence today of improved relations between his Government and that of the United States.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- The Department of Justice has registered its opposition to the bid of the First National City Bank of New York for authority to form a new bank holding company, it was learned today.

WASHINGTON, May 21 (UP) -- The Senate Rackets Committee heard sworn testimony today that officials of the Butchers Union in New York had forged several hundred signatures to help them win bargaining rights for A. P. grocery clerks.
TAIPEI, Taiwan, May 21 (AP) A new one-year pact was signed here today for the barter of $82,000,000 worth of Japanese manufactured goods for an equal amount of Taiwan (Formosa) raw materials.

WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP) -- A Congressional committee has asked John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, to explain instructions to State Department officials to regulate or limit their contacts with newspaper men.

Another example of the city in slow motion: On June 6, 1957, the Transit Authority announced that the mistakenly and "permanently" closed sidewalk entrance to the Times Square subway shuttle at the Forty-third Street site of the city's new visitors' information center would be rebuilt and reopened.
PARIS, May 21 (AP) -- The French Government abolished all censorship today on news leaving and entering France. But censorship continued on news published in France.

THE Dodgers had nothing to do with it. But the race was held in their ball park and the Dodger affinity for the bizarre is so communicable that even the slightest contact is likely to produce screwball behavior. That's how the unnecessary rabbit popped into the wrong brier patch and messed up Herb Elliott's sub-record mile of 3:57.8.
Hundreds of litterers were penalized yesterday as Sanitation Department patrolmen combed the city on the second day of the 1958 "Big Sweep" enforcement program. A total of 862 summonses was issued.

ANKARA, Turkey, May 21 -- The Foreign Minister of Turkey suggested today that the new Greek Government open "a new era of agreement" among Turkey, Greece and Britain by accepting the Turkish proposal to partition Cyprus.

TOKYO, Thursday, May 22 -Premier Nobusuke Kishi, head of the pro-American political forces in Japan, will undergo today the first test of his popularity at the polls since he became chief of the Government fifteen months ago.
EDISON, N. J., May 21 (UP) -- A New York business executive whose bruised body was found beside railroad tracks near here last night apparently fell from a train, the police said today.
A pair of purple-crested touracos, unrepresented among the Bronx Zoo's birds since 1943, arrived there yesterday in time to win support for those who argue they are not cuckoos.

New York City's crackdown on litterbugs has now begun. It follows an intensive five-week educational campaign that received wide publicity and featured the issuance of nearly 100,000 warnings to pedestrians littering the streets, to careless property owners and to storekeepers failing to sweep their sidewalks.

EVEN "air-borne bacteria" will find life very short if a floor is covered with Amtico's new all-vinyl tiles called "Care-Free." Each vinyl tile is impregnated with an antiseptic that is said to prevent the growth of bacteria.
A Negro leader urged organized labor yesterday to crack down on local unions that discriminate against minority groups.
JACK FROST can take a back seat to that man-made chill, air-conditioning, as an inducement to buying furs.
WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP) -- Lucy Monroe recommended today that Congress make it easier to sing "The Star-Spangled Banner."
WASHINGTON, May 21 -- Alaska won its first round today in its latest bid to become the forty-ninth state. It has been trying since 1916.

Protests against the merger of the High School for the Performing Arts with the High School of Commerce into a general school were applauded last night. About 250 persons attended a meeting in the school's auditorium at 120 West Fortysixth Street.

The Greek Line passenger vessel Arkadia will make her debut in the line's Europe-toCanada service today. She will sail from Bremerhaven, Germany, and is due to arrive at Montreal on June 3 after calling at Southampton, Cherbourg and Cobh.

WINDSOR LOCKS, Conn., May 21 -- Shad fishermen are assembled in their annual silent convention on the banks of the Connecticut. In spite of high, dirty water they are catching fish, but that is not important; congregation under the respected rules of protocol is the thing.
SRINAGAR, Kashmir, May 21 (AP) -- Sheik Abdullah, former Premier, was officially accused today of trying to overthrow the Government in the Indian-ruled part of this disputed border state.
I have read with much interest the dispatch in your issue of May 11, "Swedes Prepare Atomic Defense," by Drew Middleton.
ROME, May 20 -- The legend of Rome's foundation in 758 B. C. by the twin brothers Romulus and Remus has received unexpected support from science.

BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N. Y., May 21 -- The appointment of Harper Woodward as chairman of the board of trustees of Briarcliff College here was announced today by Mrs. Ordway Tead, president of the college.

NEWARK, May 21 -- Plans for a 1,255-acre park area along a six-mile stretch the Passaic River in western Essex was announced today by the Essex County Park Commission. The property is expected to cost more than $1,100,000.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 21 -- Delegates to the American National Red Cross convention called today for an "aggressive program of assistance and guidance" to chapters in connection with federated fund raising.

The Georgia-Pacific Corporation said yesterday it had asked the Federal Government for a five-year extension to submit plans for a pulp and paper mill in Alaska. The mill would be supplied by timber from national forests there.

MOSCOW, May 21 -- Communist leaders of eight countries are putting the finishing touches in Moscow on a program for increasing the integration and interdependence of their national economies, some observers here believe.
During the last week we were informed that tolls on the Hutchinson River and Saw Mill River parkways would be 25 cents instead of the previous 10 cents.
The annual meeting of the New York State Conference of Mayors and Other Municipal Officers will be held at Lake Placid but not at the Lake Placid Club.

PHILADELPHIA, May 21 -- Thirty-eight years ago, at the age of 13, Arthur Toy McGonigle faced his first challenge. His father, a Baltimore and Ohio Railroad freight conductor, died, leaving his wife and two young sons.
Directors of P. Lorillard Co. yesterday declared a 70-cent quarterly dividend on the common stock, payable July 1. This compared with 50 cents a share paid in April.
Unemployment, generally regarded as a symptom of recession, also can be a symptom of emotional problems, a psychiatrist said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 21 -- President Nasser's assurances that the United Arab Republic was not responsible for subversive activity against Lebanon left United States officials unimpressed today.

WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP) The I. C. C. said today it would not interfere with a 7 per cent rate increase made effective by Rocky Mountain area truckers May 5 on shipments moving to, from and between points in the Intermountain and Pacific Coast territories.

There are in the Bronx thirty-eight hospitals and health and welfare agencies helped by the Greater New York Fund. The fund also helps 221 other agencies that serve the Bronx as part of their city-wide services.

A guard was critically injured yesterday by a prisoner in the Brooklyn Remand Shelter. The incident, which shelter officials first reported as "just a prisoner taken ill," occurred as Mayor Wagner was confronted with charges that the jail situation was "a powder keg that could explode at any moment."
ONEIDA, N. Y., May 21 (AP) -- A section of this mid-state city was placed in a state of emergency today when an explosive chemical was found oozing from a derailed freight tanker.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- The rapid turnover of an Indiana television station in a $10,000,000 "package deal" was questioned today by a staff report to the House subcommittee investigating the Federal Communications Commission.
A NEW unit, housing a multitude of basic appliances, has been created for the home by the American Gas Association.

BREWSTER, N. Y., May 21 -- "Open House in the Brewster Area," a tour of five homes and gardens of celebrities in the vicinity, has been arranged by the Brewster Garden Club. It will take place May 31 from 11 A. M. to 5 P. M.
Whenever the Garden City (L. I.) Golf Club celebrates "open house" on New Year's Day, the women guests drink their eggnogs outside the clubhouse in the parking area.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 21 -- Paramount's independent-producer associates apparently will be making movies almost everywhere but at the studio in Hollywood during the next year or so.

MONTREAL, May 21 (UP) -- Yvon Durelle, the Canadian and British Empire light-heavy-weight champion, scored a unanimous ten-round decision over Germinal Ballarin of France tonight in a televised bout at the Forum.
PARIS, May 21 (UP) -- Budge Patty of Los Angeles and Paris and Mrs. Dorothy Head Knode of Forest Hills, N. Y., were the only American winners today in the French international tennis tournament.

JERSEY CITY, MAY 21 -- Superior Court Judge Furman W. Reeves made permanent today an injunction restraining municipal authorities from enforcing a stop-gap rent-control ordinance passed by the Jersey City Commission last Dec. 20.

A 55-year-old exporter of metals was called a "cheap chiseler" yesterday by Federal Judge Frederick vanPeit Bryan, who sentenced him to four years in prison and fined him $5,000. The exporter's company was fined $30,000.
FARMINGDALE, L. I., May 21 -- A sandy-haired seventh-grader will be the first passenger in a guided missile -- if he has his way.
During World War II more than 500,000 Jews were methodically ground to death in an area of 1,000 acres known as Warsaw's Ghetto.
A "cross-at-your-own-risk" game at Forty-third Street, Broadway and Seventh Avenue ended last evening, Traffic Department officials hoped.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee restored $220,000,000 to the foreign aid authorization bill today and endorsed assistance to help India complete her economic development program.

HACKENSACK, N. J., May 21 -- Alfonse J. Begyn, sanitary inspector of Fair Lawn, was convicted today of misconduct in office. To be sentenced on June 13 by County Judge Arthur J. O'Dea, he faces a penalty of three years in prison and a $1,000 fine.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., May 21 (AP) -- Textron, Inc., told its stockholders today that it was "weeding out" its money-losing companies and replacing them with other businesses that would improve the company's profit picture.
WASHINGTON, May 21 -- John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, agreed today to make a "full analysis" of the question:

WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP) -- Federal air officials turned down tonight a Congressional demand for an immediate emergency air safety rule to combat the increasing number of tragic mid-air collisions between civil and military planes.

LONDON, May 21 -- An account of daredevil British espionage activities on the Soviet frontiers published in the Oxford undergraduate magazine Isis was described today by a British prosecutor as partly true.
Continued expansion of foreign trade and improvement of its transportation were urged yesterday at the city's third annual observance of Marine and Aviation Day.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 21 -- President Camille Chamoun said tonight he would serve out his legal term in spite of all challenges to his continuance in office.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- The Senate approved today by 88 to 0 the compromise bill on an increase in postal rates and field-service pay. The bill would raise the first-class letter rate from 3 cents to 4 cents.
TORONTO, May 21 (Canadian Press) -- Two wealthy hotelmen, Benjamin and Harry Smith, 44-year-old twin brothers, were charged today with theft and fraud of $257,263 from Brilund Mines, Ltd.

A. Whitney Griswold, president of Yale University, said yesterday that the security of this country depended as much on its ability to command respect and hold out hope to the unfree as on military prowess.
WINNIPEG, May 21 (Canadian Press) -- Canada should walk softly but carry a big stick in regulation of oil and gas movements and prices, the Manitoba Government said today.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon called today for a greater effort to convince Latin American students and workers that the United States does not favor dictators or making the rich richer.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- By a 15-to-15 vote, Federal aid to school construction was stalled today in the House Education and Labor Committee, probably for the session. All committee members voted, either in person or by proxy.

A strong drive has developed in recent weeks for clarification of the policy of the city Hospitals Department regarding the prescription of birth control where deemed necessary by the physician. A decision is believed imminent.

PARIS, May 21 -- Premier Pierre Pflimlin turned his efforts today to a reassertion of Government control over Algeria, the key both to the survival of his Government, and to blocking Gen. Charles de Gaulle's return to power.
Although he withdrew as candidate for president of Actors Equity Association last week, Frederick O'Neal's name will be on the ballot.

WASHINGTON, May 21 (UP) -- An investigation is planned into the status of the sanctuary granted to Brig. Gen. Marcos Perez Jiminez, the Immigration Service announced today. But an immigration official said no date had been set for a hearing.
New issues of mortgage bonds of New York State public utility enterprises totaling $40,000,000 are being offered for public subscription today by banking syndicates as follows:

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- The Justice Department is "considering the possibility" of seeking to modify the consent decree that ended a suit against the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, the chief of its Antitrust Division said today.
NEW DELHI, India, May 21 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru, resting in the Himalayas, has left behind him a party still stumbling and still groping for leadership.
WASHINGTON, May 21 (UP) -- The State Department has granted export licenses for shipment of small arms to the Indonesian Central Government of President Sukarno, officials disclosed today.

In his address Tuesday evening President Eisenhower suggested that the worst of the recession may be over and that an economic upturn may be in the making. Though qualified, these statements suggest an optimistic evaluation of the present situation.
The oil industry is headed for greatly improved conditions, P. C. Spencer, chairman of the Sinclair Oil Corporation, told stockholders yesterday at their meeting held at the Biltmore Hotel.

A leading argument for foreign aid is the necessity to meet the pressing capital needs of the underdeveloped countries. These countries, it is stated, are not able to accumulate the capital needed for economic growth because of low living standards and low per capita incomes.
PHILADELPHIA, May 21 -- Harold E. Stassen shrugged off today his defeat in his bid for the Republican Gubernatorial nomination in his adopted state.
WASHINGTON, May 21 -- Public hearings on a Senate bill to aid the railroads ended today with testimony covering the full range of opinion on a controversial proposal to change the law on rate-making.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- The political corpus of Harold E. Stassen is being buried again in the comment on his latest unsuccessful vote-getting venture. The gag that forty-six states would remain in jeopardy of his future search for office if the Pennsylvania Republicans rejected his bid for Governor will probably be revived.

Rudolf L. Doelicke, an actor and former state trooper, related yesterday in Federal Court that he had helped install telephone wiretaps and electronic eavesdropping equipment in the Detroit headquarters of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.
HOUSTON, May 21 (AP) -- Stan Musial, at the height of acclaim for his 3,000th hit in major league baseball, has made Mr. and Mrs. R. H. Kerr of Houston very happy.
WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP) -- The United States is assembling a shipment of light tanks for delivery to Lebanon this week. Officials said the tanks were being collected from stocks in West Germany.
NEW DELHI, India, May 21 -- India and the Soviet Union are concluding negotiations on setting up a New Delhi-Moscow air service.

One reason why the State Assembly killed court reform this year was a split in the legion of citizen organizations and individuals fighting to streamline the state's judicial structure. The plan which finally reached the Assembly floor was so diluted, for the sake of political expediency, that the enthusiasm of those who felt they must support it -- to get at least a good deal done -- was also diluted, often to the vanishing point.
A possibility arose last night that the Liberal party might join forces with the Democrats in an effort to unseat Adam Clayton Powell Jr. in Manhattan's Sixteenth Congressional District.

MOSCOW, May 21 -- The Soviet Union has offered Italy a fully drafted treaty of friendship and nonaggression. The move appears to be the start of a new round of separate peace appeals to the European members of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., May 21 -- Delegates to the convention of the New York State Federation of Women's Clubs voted today their dissatisfaction with the postal service, progressive income tax rates and the destruction of topsoil in suburban developments.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- The American Heritage Foundation and the Advertising Council jointly announced today a $10,000,000 nonpartisan advertising campaign to encourage $1 contributions to the Democratic and Republican parties.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., May 21 -- The Governors Conference appealed today to President Eisenhower to develop a nonpartisan program for meeting the nation's economic needs in consultation with the Congressional leaders of both parties.
The appointment of Dr. Harold Walter Stoke as president of Queens College was announced yesterday by the Board of Higher Education.
WASHINGTON, May 21 -Basic research has led to a method of giving wool-like qualities to cotton and of producing gelatin that could be useful as blood plasma or for photographic film.
GLADWYN, Pa., May 21 -- The Philadelphia women's golf team of seven won the intercity team matches against New York and Boston today to capture the Griscom Cup.
ALGIERS, May 21 -- The French Army charged today that Tunisian forces were trying to provoke French forces into "bloody incidents that could be turned against France."
CHICAGO, May 21 (AP) -- Most grain futures closed substantially higher today on the Board of Trade after drifting along most of the session at prices near the previous finish.

ANACONDA, Mont., May 21 (AP) -- First-quarter earnings of the Anaconda Company were $6,130,898, or 59 cents a share, a drop of 66 per cent from the same period last year, Clyde E. Weed, chairman, reported today.
The alleged delay in the city's public school integration program was attributed yesterday to Dr. William Jansen, Superintendent of Schools.
Of about 28,000 New York City families whose monthly rent is $200 or higher, more than 20,000 live in Manhattan.

The City Council has completed its idle annual gesture, imposed by the Charter, of purporting to examine the Mayor's executive expense budget and then passing it undiminished by so much as a penny. The Democratic majority report commending its passage described the $1,991,952,986 budget as a "happy medium" between city needs and available funds, a description fitting the mediocrity of the Council as well as the nature of the budget.
NEW ORLEANS, May 21 (AP) -- Josephine, the whooping crane who became the first of her species to reproduce in captivity, laid another egg today -- her third this spring.
WARSAW, May 21 -- The "Yugoslav question" was reported today to be the first and major item on the agenda of the conference of Communist leaders going on in Moscow.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), May 14 -- After ten years, the relationship between religion and state in Israel is still being debated with passion and, at times, with violence.

" Eased up, and with the wind in her face," was the way an exultant bettor described the performance of Lawdy Claudy in the $17,600 Fashion Stakes at Belmont Park yesterday. The little black filly, running in the silks of David Reynolds, was the very essence of style as she stepped to a seven-length success in the five-furlong test on the Widener course.

SANTIAGO, Chile, May 21 -- The New York Philharmonic, conducted by Leonard Bernstein, scored a success last night before an audience of 2,000 at the Astor Theatre. This was the first of four concerts to be given in Chile and the eighteenth in the orchestra's Latin-American tour.
WASHINGTON, May 21 -- Robert Frost was appointed today as consultant in poetry at the Library of Congress, starting Oct. 1.
NEW HAVEN, May 21 -- A scientist at Yale has succeeded in keeping a chick with a transplanted head alive for seventy days, according to a report from the university.
ALBANY, May 21 -- A member of Governor Harriman's Cabinet proposed today the repeal of the 3 per cent Federal tax on transportation of goods by common carriers.
BROOKVILLE, L. I., May 21 -- The C. W. Post College Horse Show, a benefit for the scholarship fund, will take place June 1 on the show ring of the campus.
WASHINGTON, May 21 -- The Secretary of Defense, apparently siding with the Air Force, has told Congress he believes war with the Soviet Union would inevitably be "an all-out military struggle."
Althea Gibson, the Wimbledon and United States tennis champion, yesterday gained two distinctions.
WASHINGTON, May 21 -- Some Government experts on Latin America were reported today to favor the postponement of Dr. Milton S. Eisenhower's official visit to Central America next month.
Members of the President's Committee on Government Employment Policy expressed optimism yesterday about the task of eliminating discrimination on Government jobs.

Two new features will open today. "Ten North Frederick," a Twentieth Century-Fox version of the novel by John O'Hara, with Gary Cooper, Diane Varsi, Suzy Parker and Geraldine Fitzgerald in the leading roles, is at the Paramount Theatre, Broadway at Forty-third Street.
LONDON, May 21 -- Buckingham Palace denied tonight a newspaper report that Princess Margaret might become engaged to Group Captain Peter Townsend.

OMAHA, Neb., May 21 -- A plan to remove problem pupils from classrooms temporarily and put them to work under school supervision was offered today before the sixty-second annual convention of the National Congress of Parents and Teachers.
WASHINGTON, May 21 -- The long teacher-salary controversy in Hawthorne, N. J., was attributed today primarily to "a pervading atmosphere of politics."

NANCY HALE has been looking back at New England folkways from the vantage point of her present life in Virginia. She sketches the quaint and curious customs of Bostonians as she knew them when she was growing up there two or three decades ago. The social anthropologists will doubtless find valuable material in her book, "A New England Girlhood."*

MOSCOW, May 21 -- The Soviet Union unveiled today its answer to America's 15year-old chess whiz, Bobby Fischer of Brooklyn. But a man who ought to know told the Russians to put their discovery back under wraps.
WHITE PLAINS, May 21 -- A "ground swell of interest" in liberal adult education was reported yesterday by C. Scott Fletcher, president of the Fund for Adult Education.

There were growing indications yesterday that at least some steel producers would raise prices this summer. But how much the rise might be, or whether enough competing companies would join in an increase to make it stick were still up in the air.
A ceremony honoring Americans who helped keep the United States' memory of Lafayette alive was held here yesterday.
New York University, the Metropolitan Collegiate Baseball Conference champion, and Manhattan, last year's titleholder, placed four men each on the league's 1958 All-Star squad.
WASHINGTON, May 21 -- The events of the last few weeks have emphasized once more the difficulties of conducting modern diplomacy in a coalition of democratic states.

BUENOS AIRES, May 21 -- In his first press conference, Argentina's new President, Arturo Frondizi, summed up the country's rapidly worsening economy tonight and gave some hints as to how he hoped to improve it.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 21 -- The president of the New Jersey Bankers Association said today that if the Legislature passed the proposed 1 1/2 per cent corporation income tax, the state's "relative tax climate for industry would still rank favorably."
WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP) -- A program of Federal aid to educate children on the effects of tobacco and alcohol was proposed today by Senator Richard L. Neuberger.
Mayor Wagner yesterday honored retail stores, hotels, banks and other institutions that helped contribute to the success of the city's Salute to Spring.
A $14,000,000 fourteen-story office building will be built by Erwin S. Wolfson on the block bounded by West Broadway, Park Place, Greenwich Street and Barclay Street in downtown Manhattan.

A neurotic, says A Little one dictionary, is a Neuroticism person suffering a in Us All functional derangement arising from disorders of the nervous system, especially such as are unaccompanied by organic change.
The Pennsylvania Railroad, the nation's No. 1 rail carrier, operated at a $4,727,327 loss last month. In April, 1957, it cleared $3,033,148, equal to 23 cents a share.

OTTAWA, May 21 -- The Canadian National Steamship Company has decided to sell the fleet of eight ships formerly operated in the West Indies service. The ships have been idle for nine months as a result of a strike by the Seafarers International Union.
BONN, Germany, May 21 -- The Federal Cabinet approved today legislation that would subject West German publishers to fine and imprisonment for defaming leading personages of friendly countries.

A special report on the current crisis in France that threatens the country's parliamentary regime will be presented on Sunday from 6 to 6:25 P. M. over the Columbia Broadcasting System television network.

No more seats are available by mail for the return engagement of the Moiseyev Dance Company from Moscow, consisting of eight performances at Madison Square Garden between June 20 and June 28, according to the American impresario, S. Hurok.
WASHINGTON, May 21 -- A bipartisan majority of the House Ways and Means Committee approved today a bill for a five-year renewal of the reciprocal trade program. The vote was 18 to 7.
WASHINGTON, May 21 -- Hope was fading in diplomatic circles here today that French Premier Pierre Pflimlin could quell the tempest stirred up in Algeria.
LONDON, May 21 -- South African gold mining stocks again were strong today in an otherwise quiet market. Nearly all the leading issues had gains of up to 1 shilling (14 cents).

BRIDGETON, N. J., May 21 -- Conflicting versions were given today of the prelude to the collision last night of automobiles driven by Lester Wright and his wife Vera, both 19 years old. The impact killed Mr. Wright.
CHICAGO, May 21, (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
A major fire hazard exists in Rockaway Beach, Queens, because of underground gasoline leaks, Fire Commissioner Edward F. Cavanagh Jr. said yesterday.

On various occasions since 1950, when Michael J. Quill made the first of several efforts to organize the police force, we have taken the position that unionization within this city department cannot be permitted. Commissioner Kennedy, as have several commissioners before him, has now stated the same policy, and we support him heartily in it.
Newbold Morris said yesterday that the New York City Center of Music and Drama had a "healthy surplus of $86,886.86" for the fiscal year 1957-58.
ITHACA, N. Y., May 22 -- A heated, but discreet, battle is being waged on the Cornell University campus. Morals are involved.
RIDGEWOOD, N. J., May 22 -- W J Sloane, Inc., opened its fifth suburban branch at noon today with a ribbon-cutting ceremony here.

NEW DELHI, India, May 22 -- The Supreme Court ruled today that several clauses in the Kerala state education bill offended constitutional guarantees given to minorities to establish and administer educational institutions of their choice.
The International Chamber of Commerce has called on Europe's six common-market countries to take steps toward coordinating their banking policies so as to establish a "monetary community.''
WASHINGTON, May 22 (UP) -- President Eisenhower dedicated today the National Broadcasting Company's new $4,000,000 television-radio center here.
WASHINGTON, May 22 -- George Meany asked Congress today to help labor clean its house, not wreck it.

MANCHESTER, Vt., May 22 -- The recession on the Vermont part of the Battenkill, which began twenty-one days ago when the trout season opened has leveled off now and anglers are doing a brisk business. They are when they have the right flies.
WASHINGTON, May 22 -The United States and Britain will back Lebanon's complaint in the United Nations against interference in her affairs by the United Arab Republic, officials indicated today.
ROD SERLING and Robert Cummings were the principal contributors to last night's "Playhouse 90" drama on Channel 2.
CHICAGO, May 22 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

FIFTY years ago this week A. M. Kidder Co., stockbroker, one flight up at 14 Wall Street, took on a new hand, Jimmy Mount Jr., 18 years old. Jimmy was a provincial from Brooklyn's Bushwick district. His first job, at 14, had been as office boy for Parker-Wilder, a Leonard Street woolen merchant.

BARTLESVILLE, Okla., May 22 (UP) -- The meter-pay plan for showing movies on television, which has had rough sledding since its opening last fall, will suspend operations June 6, it was announced today.
Dr. Milton S. Eisenhower said yesterday that he was going ahead with his contemplated official visit to Central America despite anti-United States incidents.

THE Dance Drama Company, directed by Emily Frankel and Mark Ryder, opened what is historically the first off-Broadway dance repertory season last night at the newly set up little St. Marks Playhouse on Second Avenue at St. Marks Place.

ST. LOUIS, May 22 (UP) -- A pair of European hoopoes have hatched two eggs for the first time in captivity at the St. Louis Zoo -- to the surprise of zookeepers who did not know the birds were a pair.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- Senator Mike Mansfield said today that the United States should support "international efforts to put at rest any genuine fears of aggression, Arab of Israeli, Israeli of Arab or, indeed, Arab of Arab."

ALGIERS, May 22 -- The revolutionary fervor that has gripped Algiers began abating today. The Committee of Public Safety appealed to all French deputies to stay in France and press for a government headed by Gen. Charles de Gaulle.

MONTCLAIR, N. J., May 22 -- The public educational system was defended vigorously here today by Dr. John J. Norton, director of the Division of Administration and Guidance, Teachers College, Columbia University.
Six records fell as Andrew Jackson High captured the team title yesterday in the Queens Public School Athletic League track and field championship at Downing Stadium, Randalls Island.
A SOUTH AMERICAN melody that children will strum and sing in American camps this summer was authenticated last winter by a pert United Nations secretary who gathered data in Paraguay's bars.

Commodity futures closed irregularly yesterday on the New York exchanges. Wool, copper, lead, zinc and burlap rose; cocoa, cottonseed oil, potatoes and rubber declined, and price movements for coffee, sugar and hides were mixed.
THE homemaker's burden of a heavy weekly laundry will be lightened soon with a new group of attractive, disposable products made of Dura-Weve.
ALBANY, May 22 -- Governor Harriman approved today the appointment of a special prosecutor to supersede the Oneida County District Attorney in the investigation of vice in Utica and the county.

GREENWICH, Conn., May 22 -- Dr. Howard A. Rusk, director of the Institute of Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation of the New York University-Bellevue Medical Center, was cited here today for meritorious service in the employment of the physically handicapped.

WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP) -The United States Court of Appeals ruled today that variable annuity contracts -- based in part on the value of stocks -were not subject to regulation by the Securities and Exchange Commission.
PARIS, May 22 -- President Habib Bourguiba warned Tunisia today that she must be prepared for possible aggression by "certain French forces."

WILMINGTON, Del., May 22 (AP) -- The four members of the Securities and Exchange Commission have been directed by a Federal District Court to answer charges they are in comtempt for disobeying a court order.
Pleasure-boat skippers are always exploring the unusual. And most skippers want variety in their voyaging.
LONDON, May 22 -- The reduction in the bank rate from 6 to 5 1/2 per cent had a buoyant effect on the stock market today, although net gains among industrials were small.

The police arrested yesterday a middle-aged man whom they charged with a number of jewel thefts from fashionable East Side apartments. The suspect was George Feld, 49 years old, who lives at 1531 West Twelfth Street, Brooklyn.
WASHINGTON, May 22 (UP) -- Thirteen representatives of North Atlantic Treaty Organization nations will witness a United States nuclear test in the Pacific, the Defense Department announced today.

MILWAUKEE, May 22 (AP) -The second-place Milwaukee Braves defeated San Francisco, 9 -- 3, tonight, gaining a full game on the National League-leading Giants, whose five-game winning streak was broken by the eight-hit pitching of Lew Burdette.

ALBANY, N. Y., May 22 -The New York Central Railroad has seen no signs of a recovery in heavy industry, according to Alfred E. Perlman, president, and Arthur E. Baylis, vice president of freight traffic.
Ralph Helstein of Chicago was re-elected yesterday to a two-year term as president of the United Packinghouse Workers of America. He has held that office since 1946.
PANAMA, May 22 -- A rebellion against the Government broke out today. The National Guard restored order after seven persons had been killed and about sixty-wounded.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- Wilber M. Brucker, Secretary of the Army, described as combat-ready today the nose cone that was successfully tested last Sunday in a Jupiter intermediate range ballistic missile.

Events tonight: Paul Robeson, bass, Carnegie Hall, 8:40; Oratorio Society of New Jersey, Louise Natale, soprano, Violet Serwin, contralto, Howard Jarratt, tenor, Thornton J. Marker, bass, Peter Sozio, conductor, McMillin Theatre, Broadway and 116th Street, 8:15.
WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP) -- The House agreed today to end general debate on the Alaska statehood bill on Monday. The agreement paved the way for a possible final vote on Wednesday.
UMTATA, South Africa, May 17 -- The South African Government is trying to put tribal chiefs back into positions of authority.

The Peter Stuyvesant, a twelve-story apartment hotel at 2 West Eighty-sixth Street, southwest corner of Central Park West, has been sold by Hotel Peter Stuyvesant, Inc. It was bought by a syndicate of investors represented by Bernard Resnick, a Brooklyn attorney.
A strike of 15,000 elevator operators, janitors, handy men and other service employes in Manhattan's towering apartment buildings was threatened yesterday.

On April 30 you published a letter from the president of the Consumers League of New York, Inc., relative to action taken at the last legislative session with regard to the migrant farm labor problem. Unfortunately, the letter fails to present the full picture.
A plea for increased instruction in the humanities and sciences in the high schools was made yesterday by Dr. Hans Albert Einstein, son of the late Albert Einstein, the scientist.
Underwriting earnings declines in the fire insurance business were attacked yesterday as "unfortunate," "inadequate" and "below the permissible margin."
GENEVA, May 22 -- An Algerian insurgent leader said today that Gen. Charles de Gaulle might be able to solve the Algerian problem, but he criticized supporters of the general.
Cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 14 points up to 4 points off yesterday.
American industry can take a lesson from horse racing in combating the recession by borrowing touts to whisper: "Buy Now."
Lee Higginson Corporation, manager of an underwriting group, yesterday offered for public sale 112,500 shares of $1-par common stock in the Simplicity Pattern Company, Inc., at $13.50 a share.

A pair of seldom-heard operas was given last night by the Hunter College Opera Workshop in the Hunter College Playhouse. They were Milhaud's "Les Malheurs d'Orphee" of 1926 and Rossini's one-act "La Cambiale di Matrimonio" of 1810, sung in a smart English translation by Charles Lloyd Holt. The Milhaud opera, in three short acts, was sung in French.

BONN, Germany, May 22 -- Erich Ollenhauer was re-elected chairman of the Social Democratic party today at the party congress in Stuttgart. Herbert Wehner of Hamburg and Waldemar von Knoeringen of Bavaria were chosen deputy chairmen. All three were unopposed.
CHICAGO, May 22 (AP) -- All grain futures moved ahead in moderately, active dealings on the Board of Trade today, with wheat and corn having the best gains.
NIAGARA FALLS, N. Y., May 22 -- Robert Moses informed members of the State Power Authority today that the cost of the Niagara Power Project would run in excess of the es-was $565,000,000.

CARACAS, Venezuela, May 22 (AP) -- Venezuela's military-civilian junta announced today that it would establish a nineteen-member Consultative Council to advise it on running the Government until the Presidential elections.

An automobile driven by a woman with a learner's permit yesterday afternoon backed into a group of children on a sidewalk in Queens. One boy was killed, another was critically injured, one girl's leg was broken and two other girls were knocked down.

IT was a conversational fragment that was tossed carelessly over his shoulder by Freddie Hutchinson, the manager of the St. Louis Cardinals. It came in the late stages of spring training at St. Pete. Hutch was discussing his experiment of having Alvin Dark, his regular shortstop, trade jobs his with Eddie Kasko, his regular third baseman.

WESTBURY, L. I., May 22 -- Rick Hanover, a 6-year-old brown gelding who has been guided by John Simpson since he was a yearling, captured the $8,000 Magic Moon free-for-all trot at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.
Talk of inflation and of a large, nervous short interest sent the stock market higher yesterday, with steels, metals and rails in the lead.

With all sides apparently anxious to avoid a showdown that could plunge France into civil war, Premier Pflimlin is moving on two fronts to strengthen the French Government, to reassert its authority over the rebellious dissidents in Algeria and to avert an authoritarian regime under General de Gaulle.
PEOPLE who live in glass houses should buy oriental rugs.

Indian Truce won the feature race at Belmont Park yesterday and, in doing so, he adhered to the pattern that obtained throughout the afternoon. The feature event was the Belmont National Maiden Hurdle Stakes. The pattern was the complete predominance of non-favorites as winners.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 22 -A Federal health official said today that the one-third of the United States population that does not have health insurance of any kind "is the group that needs protection most."

INDIANAPOLIS, May 22 (AP) -- The United States Auto Club, which sanctions the 500-mile Memorial Day Race, the championship circuit of 100-mile events and other speed programs, today stepped up its campaign against racing injuries.

Under Nate Cartmell and the incumbent Chick Werner, Penn State long has made a specialty of developing outstanding track and field athletes. There's now an imposing new candidate for listing on an honor roll that includes Schuyler Enck, Larry Shields, Bill Cox, Crip Moore, Barney Ewell, Curt Stone and Horace Ashenfelter.
WASHINGTON, May 22 -- Another increase in the food sector pushed consumer prices to another record in April, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.
CHICAGO, May 22 -- Harry S. Truman predicted today that the Democrats would make President Eisenhower's ordering of troops to the Caribbean an issue in this fall's political campaign.
WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP) -- Van Cliburn, winner of the Tchaikovsky Piano Competi-in Moscow, will meet President Eisenhower at the White House tomorrow.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 22 -- "Studio One In Hollywood" will start its summer schedule of live programs on June 9 with "The Strong Man," a Western drama starring Everett Sloan.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- Ricardo M. Arias, Panamanian Ambassador to the United States, said today that Opposition groups appeared to have converted student disturbances in his country into a political attack against the Government.
Until yesterday the Army's Air Defense Command had not lost control of a missile left inactive on a launching site, an Army spokesman said last night.
STRATFORD, Conn., May 22 -- A turbine-powered amphibious helicopter was demonstrated today at the Sikorsky Aircraft Division of the United Aircraft Corporation here.
A ring of eighteen to twenty Nike launching stations protects the New York area from potential enemy bombers.

James Talcott, Inc., commercial factoring concern, is planning to issue 100,000 shares of new common stock through a public offering to be managed by F. Eberstadt Co. and White, Weld Co. The issue was registered yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission.
THE final, or nearly final, bloom of the art season downtown takes the form of a number of group exhibitions, a one-man show and a three-man show.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -The Court of Appeals here held today that the Federal Power Commission had the right to certify a natural gas pipeline project without investigating the validity of the price to be paid for the supply of gas.

At the shameful bottom of the totem pole among New York City's employes are the full-time internes and residents of our city hospitals. No teen-age baby sitter would deign to sit before the television set for what these people are getting to care for the sick.
WASHINGTON, May 22 -- The memorial services for Elmer Davis in the Washington Cathedral today were something more than a tribute to a great reporter.
EVEN queens are traveling light this year. Take the case of Carol Christensen, New York City's 1958 Summer Festival Queen, who will tour twelve American and Canadian cities this month.

DETROIT, May 22 -- The Tigers who, like the Chicago White Sox, have been traveling with a wrong-way compass virtually since the American League race began, made a valiant effort today to straighten themselves out. But they lost, 5 to 4, in the opener of a three-game series with the Yankees, who never lose sight of where they are going.

The purchase of the Standard Variety Stores, with headquarters in Haverstraw, N. Y., by Butler Brothers, Chicago, owner, operator and franchiser of various type stores, was announced yesterday by A. O. Staffey, president of the latter concern.

The Port of New York Authority announced yesterday plans for the sale of $35,000,000 of bonds to finance capital outlays at Newark Airport, N. J., the Brooklyn-Port Authority Piers and the building of second decks to the George Washington Bridge.
WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP) -- The Administration's bill to subsidize domestic producers of copper, lead, zinc, acid-grade fluorspar and tungsten was sent to Congress today.
Democratic and Republican leaders in New York County share a similar headache today -- the need to make important choices of candidates for primary battles over two seats in Congress.
WASHINGTON, May 22 -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee tentatively restored today all the $399,000,000 cut from the Administration's request for a foreign aid authorization of $3,941,192,500.
Alice and her friends from Wonderland took a long step yesterday toward tenancy in Central Park.
RABAT, Morocco, May 22 -- At the request of the Soviet Union, the Moroccan Government decided tonight to authorize the establishment of a Soviet economic mission here.

The Curtis Publishing Company experienced a sharp decline in earnings in the first quarter of this year from the 1957 level. Curtis publishes the Saturday Evening Post, the Ladies' Home Journal and Holiday.

PARIS, May 22 (UP) -- Bill Quillian of Seattle, Jack Frost of Monterey, Calif., and Bob Perry of Los Angeles scored second-round men's doubles victories in the French hard court tennis championships today, but Malcolm Fox of Baltimore was eliminated.
A FEW years back a man suggested that perhaps his psychoanalyst could be replaced by a papier-mache ear on a wooden stick.

Loans to business by major New York City banks declined $55,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. The drop compared with a decline of $128,000,000 in the corresponding week last year.

Mayor Wagner was informed by Investigation Commissioner Charles H. Tenney on April 9 that contractors engaged by favored management agents handling city property for the Bureau of Real Estate had heavily padded their repair bills.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 22 -Alfred Hayes, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, struck out today at critics who have accused the nation's money managers of doing nothing to halt the recession.

The Red Cross will collect blood today at Sacred Heart Roman Catholic Church, 215-35 Thirty-eighth Avenue, Bayside, Queens. Blood will also be collected at Socony Mobil Oil Co., Inc., foot of Kingsland Avenue, Brooklyn.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, May 22 (AP) -- Communist party leaders from East Europe gathered in Moscow are discussing a plan for economic cooperation covering seven to ten years, the official Hungarian news agency M. T. I. said today.

It is not exactly surprising that a number of persons of less than moderate mental talents are politically ignorant. Politics is getting complex. This is not to imply that a knowledge of politics is entirely a matter of intellect, because it sometimes rather obviously is something else; politics often is charged less with logic than emotion, which catches up alike the intellectual and those with lesser cranial capacity.
The following article is by Pertinax, diplomatic correspondent of the Paris newspaper France-Soir. It was distributed by the North American Newspaper Alliance.
MOSCOW, May 22 -- The Government entertained today a strong plea that the Soviet divorce law be liberalized again to prevent injustices to children born out of wedlock.

Madison Square Garden resumes its regular Friday boxing series tonight with a ten-round main event between Lahouari Godih, French lightweight champion, and Johnny Busso of Astoria. Except for a few dates weekly shows are scheduled through August.
Elements of the proposal for construction of the $260,000,000 Narrows Bridge and its approaches came under heavy attack yesterday before the Board of Estimate.

It is hardly happy news that the cost of living, as measured by the Government's consumer price index, reached another new high last month. If there are any pleasant aspects to the matter, they arise from the fact that the latest rise was comparatively small -- two-tenths of 1 per cent -- and from the belief expressed in Washington that no important additional increases are likely in the months immediately ahead.
ROME, May 22 -- All parties were making their last appeals of the current campaign to the Italian electorate today.
WASHINGTON, May 22 -The school construction bill, apparently deadlocked yesterday by a 15-to-15 vote in the House Education and Labor Committee, was revived today.
WILLIAMS LAKE, B. C., May 22 (AP) -- Thirteen children were burned to death tonight when fire engulfed the hospital and school at the Anaham Indian reserve, sixty miles west of here.
BUENOS AIRES, May 22 -- The Chamber of Deputies enacted an amnesty law today that will leave it up to the courts to decide whether Juan D. Peron and his followers may return to Argentina.
LONDON, May 22 -- Prime Minister Harold Macmillan emphatically reaffirmed today the British Government's resolve to retain the nuclear deterrent and to continue nuclear tests.

There are a great many different ways in which Stan Musial of the Cardinals could have celebrated his 3,000th hit in the major leagues. It was the biggest milestone in a truly great baseball career. By coincidence or accident he chose a method of celebration that is perhaps unique, but that is typical of a great athlete and a fine man.

MOSCOW, May 22 -- There is a strange ambivalence in an article appearing in today's Sovetskaya Kultura (Soviet Culture). What it seems to be saying at the same time is that Soviet musicians are not studying deeply enough because they are busy with international contests and that they are not willing to take part in contests.

MARI SANDOZ, who was born and reared in the Sand Hills cattle country of northwest Nebraska, has been writing about the Old West for twenty-three years, ever since "Old Jules," a biography of her pioneer father. A good writer and a diligent researcher, she has long ranked high among our regional historians.
MIDDLETOWN, N. J., May 22 -- Eight Nike missiles exploded today on the grounds of an Army missile launching base here. Ten men were killed and three were injured.
From 2 to 6 o'clock tomorrow afternoon the holiday mood traditionally associated with the approach of summer will prevail on Murray Hill.

AS once he undertook to bring the French National Railways out of their war ruins, former Premier Antoine Pinay undertook yesterday in talks with Gen. Charles de Gaulle to get political France back on the tracks and rolling again.
WHITE PLAINS, May 22 -- Nelson A. Rockefeller was supported as the Republican choice for Governor here tonight.
After a lapse of nearly four years the United States greets again the Austrian Chancellor, as a distinguished visitor -- Julius Raab.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- The House of Representatives approved and sent to the White House today a program for postal rate and pay increases that seemed veto-proof. The vote was 379 to 0. Yesterday the Senate supported it, 88 to 0.
WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP) -- Colombia today decorated United States industrialist J. Peter Grace for his efforts in the development of Latin-American countries.

The election of Thomas J. Watson Jr. as a public governor of the New York Stock Exchange has been announced by Keith Funston, president. Mr. Watson, president of the International Business Machines Corporation, succeeds Charles E. Wilson, former president of the General Electric Company and former chairman of W. R. Grace Co.

For the first time since 1950, graduate schools of social work report an encouraging increase in enrollment. A survey made by the Council on Social Work Education discloses that more than 4,100 college graduates are now working toward a master's degree in accredited schools of social work.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 22 -- Lebanon sent a formal complaint today to the United Nations Security Council charging the United Arab Republic with endangering peace in the Middle East by meddling in Lebanon's internal affairs.
WASHINGTON, May 22 -- Loadings of revenue freight last week totaled 560,765 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.

ATLANTA, May 22 (UP) -- The Southeastern Conference ruled today that Auburn had violated its recruiting rules and joined the National Collegiate Athletic Association in placing the college on probation. Auburn's football team was undefeated last season.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- President Eisenhower ordered today the quickest action possible to reduce the hazard of commercial air travel arising from operation of military jet planes along civilian airways.
A proposal to enlarge the Lincoln Square cultural center to make room for a museum and library moved ahead another step yesterday.
Members of the American Fur Merchants' Association were told last night that insolvencies in the industry had declined materially last year.
An endowed program of teaching and research in civil liberties will be established next fall in New York University's School of Law.
John Forget is a detective who doesn't. His photographic memory led to the capture of an alleged hold-up man yesterday hours after the crime.
LONDON, May 22 (AP) -- The Moscow radio broadcast a condemnation of the Moslem faith tonight.

Robert Rounseville must be one of the few tenors today who can take an audience on a tour of the lyric theatre from Mozart's "Don Giovanni" to Bernstein's "Candide," or from Debussy's "Pelleas" to "The Song of Norway" after Grieg.
Larceny hovers over the two whooping cranes at the Audubon Park Zoo, in New Orleans.

CINCINNATI, May 22 (AP) -- Warren C. Giles, president of the National League, said today that if the Los Angeles Dodgers didn't get the Chavez Ravine for a new stadium he would recommend moving the franchise to another city.
A wooden reminder of pre-Revolutionary seaport days has been uncovered on Lower Manhattan.

THE chronic audiophile should have been in seventh heaven last night. "Jazz Party" was presented in both sight and stereophonic sound, and it was one of the season's most exciting experiments in broadcasting.
