The Roman Catholic population of the United States, Alaska and Hawaii was put at 36,023,977 yesterday, an increase of 1,460,126 in a year.

June Lockhart and Hugh Reilly will portray the new foster parents on the "Lassie" television series. It will be the second time in a year that Lassie's young master, Timmy (portrayed by Jon Provost), has had to accustom himself to new parents.
WASHINGTON, May 22 -- Six Congressmen who represent Minnesota in Washington are under investigation to make sure they are fit to represent Washington in Minnesota.
CAMDEN, N. J., May 22 -- The United States entered a new epoch for merchant shipping today when the keel of a nuclear - propelled commercial ship was laid here.
WASHINGTON, May 22 -- A Negro leader said today he would tell Negro children facing possible violence in integrated schools to "walk in there like the Vice President of the United States."
GARDEN CITY, L. I., May 22 -Delegates to the New York State Federation of Women's Clubs turned down today the official choice for president and elected instead Mrs. Vernon B. Level of Corning.

"The Great Arms Race," a new book by Hanson Baldwin, is planned for July 28 publication by Frederick Praeger. Subtitled "A Comparison of U. S. and Soviet Power in 1958," the volume gives a facts-and-figures analysis of the world's two great arsenals as of the present.
An automobile company official let his bumpers down, so to speak, yesterday and came out with a few frank comments.
Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt asserted yesterday that this country was basically responsible for outbursts in South America against Vice President Richard M. Nixon.
WASHINGTON, May 22 -- The Senate Finance Committee approved without change today the Administration-backed bill for supplementary unemployment compensation to jobless workers.

Frank Productions, Inc., has added "Specter of the Rose" to its string of great expectations. The musical version of the motion picture (written, directed and produced by Ben Hecht in 1946) has been promised for Broadway next winter.
WASHINGTON, May 22 -- Department store sales in the week last Saturday were 2 per cent below the level of 1957.

Contract negotiations between the National Maritime Union and representatives of thirty-two tanker operators with 231 vessels opened yesterday at the Lexington Hotel. The union demanded substantial wage and overtime increases.

McKesson Robbins, Inc., increased sales in the fiscal year ended March 31 to a record, but earnings dipped below those in the preceding year, the preliminary annual report of George Van Gorder, chairman showed yesterday.

SYRACUSE, May 22 (UP) -- Leonard W. Hall today labeled Governor Harriman one of the "gloom and doom" preachers and charged the Democratic Governor had done nothing to help the state's business climate.

The Mayor's first assistant, Stanley H. Lowell, said yesterday that he favored a city income tax tacked on the state income tax, on the condition that city sales and other "nuisance taxes" be dropped.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- Robert E. Lee of the Federal Communications Commission was accused today of having changed his vote in a television case in the face of political pressure from leading Republicans.
International Minerals and Chemical Corporation has a new president. He is Thomas M. Ware, who succeeds his father, Louis Ware who, in turn, has been named chairman and chief executive officer.
The United Jewish Appeal of Greater New York yesterday began an intensified effort to raise large sums of money for Jewish needs throughout the world, particularly in Israel.

WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP) -- Subsidy payments to domestic trunk airlines would be banned permanently under identical bills proposed in the House of Representatives today by John E. Moss of California and Peter F. Mack of Illinois, both Democrats.
BROWNSVILLE, Tex., May 22 (AP) -- A Federal District Court jury today found thirty-four men guilty of conspiracy to run arms to the leader of the unsuccessful Cuban revolt, Fidel Castro.
ALBANY, N. Y., May 22 (AP) -- The Public Service Commission rejected today Westchester County's bid to stop the New York Central Railroad from abandoning passenger service on its Putnam Division.

Lumber production last week was 7.6 per cent below the level of last year, according to reports wired yesterday to The New York Times by regional associations. Shipments were down 6.3 per cent, compared with the same week last year, and orders were down 3.2 per cent.

Dr. William Vogt, national director of the Planned Parenthood Federation of America, said yesterday that "contraception, like any other medical procedure, should be available to all families, regardless of income, color or nationality."
In space-conscious Washington plans have been completed to put the Statler Hotel into outer space -- figuratively, of course.

TOKYO, Friday, May 23 -- Japan was assured of a conservative pro-Western Government for another four years today, with more than three-fourths of the returns counted from yesterday's record-breaking vote for a new House of Representatives.

WASHINGTON, May 22 (UP) -- The Senate rackets committee produced evidence today that companies doing business with the butchers union had invested about $500,000 in a country club owned by two union officials.

The apparent success of the second World Trade Fair, held this year in New York's Coliseum, is most gratifying to those who, like this writer and his colleagues, pioneered the idea of organizing international trade fairs in the United States.

PHILADELPHIA, May 22 (UP) -- Ernie Banks broke out of a mild slump with his eighth homer and a pair of doubles to bat in four runs tonight as the Chicago Cubs topped the Philadelphia Phillies, 7 -- 4, and moved back into the first division.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 22 -- Lebanon asked for an urgent meeting of the Security Council tonight to take up her charge that the United Arab Republic is interfering in her internal affairs.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, May 22 -- Government authorities emphasized tonight that settlement of the Indonesian rebellion could be only on the basis of unconditional surrender by the rebels.
A leading spokesman for the steel industry called yesterday for an overhaul of Federal tax laws rather than "tax reductions resulting in Government deficits and inflation."

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- The United States Army has now organized a formal and active program for supplying retired regular and reserve officers as teachers in the science and mathematics departments of those public high schools (more rarely colleges) that may wish to avail themselves of this largely unused source of education.
LONDON, May 22 -- The bank rate, which governs most other British interest rates, was reduced today from 6 to 5 1/2 per cent.
A de Havilland Comet jet left London yesterday to begin a series of flights on this side of the ocean in connection with possible regular commercial service later this year.
Governor Harriman heard confident election predictions from Brooklyn Democrats last night.

The California Oil Company will spend $2,100,000 for an advertising program beginning Monday to announce the change of the name of its Calso gasoline in this area to Chevron. The Chevron name has been used for the company's products in the West.
BEIRUT, May 22 -- Thirteen days of general strike and armed insurrection against the Government has cost Lebanese business and industry about $3,000,000.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 22 -- Although reported to be almost as far apart as they were two months ago, the Screen Directors Guild has agreed to hold another contract negotiating meeting next week with the Association of Motion Picture Producers and the Alliance of Television Film Producers.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- William F. Knowland of California said today he consid-sidered Vice President Richard M. Nixon the leading and only "major" candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination in 1960.
WASHINGTON, May 22 -Senator Strom Thurmond said today that "bloody interracial warfare" in New York City's "crime-ridden integrated schools" had aroused "glee" among this country's foreign enemies.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 22 (AP) -- The California Olympic Commission and a Squaw Valley land-owner, Wayne Poulsen, today came to terms. This removed the major obstacle to construction of the facilities for the 1960 Winter Olympics.
PARIS, May 22 -- The confusions and divisions that swirl around the looming figure of Gen. Charles de Gaulle are as apparent in the press as they are in the National Assembly.
The twentieth floor in the building rising at 200 East Forty-second Street has been leased by the Prudential Insurance Company for a branch office now in the Chrysler Building.
PARIS, May 22 -- The French Government proposed today sweeping constitutional reforms to shore up the parliamentary regime against assault by Gen. Charles de Gaulle.
WASHINGTON. May 22 -- A Cornell University professor urged Congress today to allow "tightly limited" wiretapping by the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

The Board of Higher Education is to be congratulated on several counts in its appointment of Dr. Harold Walter Stoke as president of Queens College. It chose an excellent man and it made the exhaustive search -- examining in five months the qualifications of 140 prospects -- that the filling of such a position warrants.
THE continued high cost of beef makes chicken and turkey very attractive buys this week-end, especially as these two commodities are priced to fit the modest budget.
A settlement has been negotiated, covering defaulted outstanding bonds of two issues totaling $32,500,000 that were floated by the savings banks of pre-Hitler Germany in the United States market.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 22 -- The Rev. Dr. Billy Graham urged a California legislative committee here today to strengthen laws against pornography. He said this nation had become "absorbed and obsessed with sex."
GREAT NECK, L. I., May 22 -- The Long Island division of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's interclub challenge round was completed today over the Deepdale Country Club course.

A parade of merchant marine cadets and military units along the Avenue of the Americas to Rockefeller Plaza, precision drills, the blare of a Navy band and acres of flags marked yesterday's twenty-fifth observance here of National Maritime Day.

DETROIT, May 22 (UP) -Henry Ford 2nd, president of the Ford Motor Company, told a meeting of stockholders today that odds were in favor of "at least a modest recovery" in the nation's economy toward the end of this year.

Today's new film is "Reaching for the Stars," a German-made drama with Erik Schuman, Lisa Pulver and Oliver Grimm, at the Seventy-second Street Playhouse, between First and Second Avenues. Carl Heinz Schroth directed the import, which has a scenario by Helmut Kautner and Maria von Osten-Sacken.

Beginning its thirteenth year, the Fifty-two Association of New York expands its services to hospitalized veterans and service men on the town. Teams of volunteers go into the hospitals and ply soldiers and sailors with food and small gifts. Professional entertainers are recruited to bring some fun into hospital wards.

Willamette showed her liking for the Belmont track by taking the mile-and-a-sixteenth main race yesterday. The 4-year-old daughter of Doswell, campaigning for Christopher T. Chenery, improved steadily to score by five lengths over the favored Dotte Line of the King Ranch in the good time of 1:43 2-5.
WASHINGTON, May 23 -- A former teamsters' lawyer was appointed chairman and neutral member of the Board of Monitors of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters today.
Dr. Maurice H. Greenhill, who once incurred the displeasure of Mayor Wagner, resigned yesterday as director of the New York City Community Mental Health Services.
The underground gasoline leaks that have been troubling Rockaway Beach and creating a fire hazard for the last nine years could not be traced again yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- The Senate Labor subcommittee closed its hearings on labor legislation today after receiving another plea by Secretary of Labor James P. Mitchell for adoption of the Administration program.
The Lehigh Valley Railroad had operating revenues of $4,735,625 in April, compared with $5,520,970 a year earlier. There was a net loss of $529,091, against one of $345,247 in 1957.
New flotations continue at a lively rate although a further slight decline in activity is in prospect.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 23 -- Dr. Masashi Enami, a distinguished Japanese zoologist, plunged to his death today from the second floor of a hotel. The circumstances led the police homicide detail to investigate.
FLAGSTAFF, South Africa, May 17 -- A fashion note from Pondoland: the well - dressed "mine boy" is wearing collar buttons in his ear lobes this season.

The recent article by The New York Times correspondent concerning the demonstration of voting machines at the United States pavilion at the Brussels World's Fair has elicited great comment. Allowing Europeans to use the same voting machines we use in our democratic elections has made a strong impression on their minds.

PARIS, May 23 -- The greatest paradox in this paradoxical French crisis is the position of the army. The army is the only remaining cohesive force in both metropolitan France and Algeria. It argues it is not involved in conspiracy against the Republic.

The twelve-story loft building at 55 East Eleventh Street, between University Place and Broadway, is being acquired by Louis and Bernard Jacobs, investors. They have signed a contract of purchase with an estate represented by the Hudson Trust Company of Hoboken, N. J. The plot is 27 by 103 feet. The sale, the first involving the property in forty years, was negotiated by Gerhard Kuehne of L. V. Hoffman Co., brokers.
RIVERHEAD, L. I., May 23 -- The will of Samuel Seabury was filed for probate today with the Suffolk County Surrogate here. He left most of his estate to four nephews and six nieces.
WASHINGTON, May 23 -- Relations between the United States and Indonesia have taken a turn for the better, Dr. Mukarto Notowidigdo, Indonesian Ambassador, said today.
WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture said today Hawaii and Puerto Rico would fall further short than expected of filling their 1958 sugar quotas.

The effort to obtain economic integration among the nations of the Soviet bloc, particularly among those in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union, has a long history going back to the founding of the Council for Mutual Economic Assistance in 1949.
Changes in futures prices were mixed yesterday on the New York exchanges. Trading in most markets was dull. Evening of positions prior to the week-end accounted for most of the volume.

MILWAUKEE, May 23 (AP) -- The San Francisco Giants tonight smashed Warren Spahn's bid for a perfect game as they rallied to defeat the Milwaukee Braves, 5 -- 3. The Giants increased their National League lead to two and one-half games.

PHILADELPHIA, May 23 (AP) -- The Philadelphia Phillies' shortstop, Chico Fernandez, muffed a possible double play tonight with one out in the fifth and the Chicago Cubs put on a seven-run inning. The Cubs won, 11 -- 4.

Justice John Marshall Harlan of the United States Supreme Court will hold a hearing Monday on an application for a stay of the Lincoln Square project, Corporation Counsel Peter Campbell Brown announced yesterday.

Warren C. Giles, president of the National League, who said on Thursday that he would recommend the Dodgers' leaving Los Angeles if they didn't get the Chavez Ravine site for a new stadium, yesterday poured more fuel on the fire he started.

Abraham Lincoln's religious development is discussed in a volume to be issued in the fall by Longmans, Green. Entitled "Lincoln Finds God," it has been written by Ralph G. Lindstrom, president of the Lincoln Fellowship of Southern California and a trustee of the Abraham Lincoln Association of Springfield, Ill.
WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP) -- Tightening of laws dealing with subversion, passports and deportation of aliens was recommended today by the Senate Internal Security subcommittee.

In the last college regatta in the East for heavyweight crews prior to the Yale-Harvard classic on the Thames and the Intercollegiate Rowing Association championship on Onondaga, Pennsylvania and Cornell row today on Cayuga Lake at Ithaca.
An Army board of inquiry and ordnance experts combed the Nike launching base near Middletown, N. J., yesterday for clues to the cause of the eight-missile explosion that took ten lives Thursday.
STAMFORD, Conn., May 23 -- Construction is under way on a series of center strip steel-rail barriers on the Merritt Parkway.
Republicans in Manhattan's Seventeenth Congressional District set the stage yesterday for a primary battle over a nominee for the seat of Representative Frederic R. Coudert Jr.

Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz demanded yesterday that New York City sue to recover overcharges allegedly made by contractors in padded bills. The state official charged "widespread irregularities" in the city's scandal-torn Bureau of Real Estate and repeated his demand for a strong code of ethics for city employes.

MARISSA, Ill., May 23 (AP) -- A car crashed into a concrete bridge siding today, killing five university students returning from a field trip in St. Louis. A blowout apparently threw the car out of control.
A five-story apartment house for fifty-four families at 2758 Cruger Avenue, the Bronx, was sold by Philip Zipes, realty operator, to a client of Robert Stillman.
WASHINGTON, May 23 -- The White House announced tonight that the military services would put into effect tomorrow tighter controls on non-tactical jet flights below 20,000 feet.
WASHINGTON, May 23 -Average prices in primary markets declined 0.2 per cent to 119.3 per cent of their 1947-49 level during the week ended last Tuesday, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

LIKE eighteenth - century English portraits, English sporting pictures are under the weather of fashion. A generation ago no prosperous country house was complete without an array of Derby winners, fox-hunting scenes and champion trotters on its walls.

When Vice President Nixon was interviewed between games of a double-header in Washington he reported that he had heard in Latin America the frequently expressed wish that some of our major league teams could make post-season tours in that area.

The Scholarship Fund of Sarah Lawrence College will benefit from a tour of ten homes in southern and northern Westchester County on Tuesday and Wednesday. The Sarah Lawrence Club of Westchester is sponsoring the event.
Standard issues made a little progress on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, but ebullience among the specialties made the market seem brighter than the averages.

WESTBURY, L. I., May 23 -- What makes a harness horse go off stride? It's an important question because it is agreed that off-gaited standardbreds annually cause more anguish among fans than even beaten favorites.
A vice president of the Columbia Broadcasting System conceded yesterday that television was not as free to cover the news as is the press.

Petitions seeking involuntary bankruptcy for the North Atlantic and Gulf Steamship Company, Inc., of 120 Wall Street, were filed yesterday in Southern District Federal Court by three steamship operators. Their claims aggregate almost $2,000,000.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., May 23 (UP) -- First unofficial returns in the biennial election of the International Typographical Union showed Elmer Brown of New York leading Howard C. Murray of Richmond, Va., for the presidency by a slim margin today.

Roy Campanella, the Los Angeles Dodgers catcher, has made some progress in his rehabilitation program at the Institute of Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation of New York University-Bellevue Medical Center. But there is no change in the degree of paralysis.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 23 -- A big spurt in production at Twentieth Century-Fox next month was announced today by Buddy Adler, studio chief. He reported that six pictures, representing an investment of $17,000,000, were scheduled to go before the cameras the first three weeks in June.
LEXINGTON, Ky., May 23 (AP) -- The Circuit Court dismissed a ninety-six-year-old treason indictment against a former Vice President today. The prosecuting witnesses could not be located.
WEBSTER, N. H., May 23 -- Dry flies are working pretty well in middle New Hampshire ponds now, but, generally speaking, it is the wets and streamers that do business in the streams.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- The first satellite patent was issued this week. It went to the Navy for the structure of the twenty-inch Vanguard satellites to be launched at Cape Canaveral, Fla. The inventor is Robert C. Baumann, head of the satellite structures group for Project Vanguard at the Naval Research laboratory here.
WASHINGTON, May 23 -- The House Armed Services Committee today rejected President Eisenhower's request for important changes in its compromise bill on Pentagon reorganization.
WASHINGTON, May 23 -Large-scale enlargement of the Suez Canal and large-scale World Bank or other financing for it are at least five years off, Middle Eastern diplomats said today.
ALBANY, May 23 (AP) -- The State University will send seven educators to Indonesia in September to help Indonesian colleges improve teacher-training courses.

The Committee on Un-American Activities of the House of Representatives continues to pursue its wayward course of folly. Its latest contribution to a long series of un-American activities on its own part is a subpoena served on Cyrus Eaton, the Cleveland industrialist, because of certain remarks made by him on a recent television program.
Full statutory collective bargaining rights for employes of the state's thirty-three authorities were recommended yesterday by a group of Democratic legislators.

Twenty-three agencies affiliated with the Greater New York Fund have their principal offices in Queens. Eighteen other agencies have district offices there, thirty-six serve other boroughs as well as Queens and 314 make their services to Queens on a citywide basis.
BONN, Germany, May 23 -- Newspapers and the National Journalists Union sharply criticized today a proposed press law that would send West German publishers to jail for defaming a foreign statesman.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 23 -- Lebanon's Cabinet showed cracks today at a critical time. Two members have resigned, for reasons not made public immediately. The resignations are not expected to cause a general Cabinet change.

ALGIERS, May 23 -- Gen. Raoul Salan, military ruler of Algeria, gave formal recognition today to a system of public safety committees, or juntas, established in Algeria since the anti-Paris uprising on May 13.

" WHAT it really means," one character says to another toward the end of A. J. Cronin's "The Northern Light"* -- "is that one sensation has been knocked out by a bigger one." And that's the way Mr. Cronin has written his dourly melodramatic novel about a family harrowed and then harrowed again during a newspaper war in northern England.

Directors of the Illinois Central Railroad cut the dividend yesterday with the declaration of 50 cents on the common stock, payable July 1. Shareholders received 75 cents in April. Wayne Johnston, president of the road, indicated to stockholders at the annual meeting on Wednesday that the dividend would be cut.
A ten-foot African rock python laid twenty-one eggs yesterday morning and then indifferently allowed Bronx Zoo officials to take away eight of them.
ITHACA, N. Y., May 23 -- Frank C. Baldwin, dean of men at Cornell University, was spattered with an egg today in a student demonstration.

CINCINNATI, May 23 (AP) -- A three-run outburst plus Ed Bailey's home run helped Cincinnati's Redlegs keep out of the National League cellar tonight with a 4-1 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers. A relief pitcher, Hal Jeffcoat, pitched his way out of trouble in the eighth inning to protect the triumph.

It was heartening to see in the article on the use of computers in the Englewood school construction referendum (The Times, May 12) evidence of the increasing participation of natural scientists in social affairs.
Billy Brown yesterday resigned as the matchmaker for the International Boxing Club. In recent weeks Brown had testified before a New York County Grand Jury investigating professional boxing.
PARIS, May 21 -- The French political crisis seems to be having no effect on the French habit of going to the fair.
ALGIERS, May 23 -- A French detective halted an American shopper today in the doorway of a large store here.
BAYONNE, N. J., May 23 -- A Coast Guard helicopter and members of the Bayonne police and fire departments today saved a man sunk to his armpits in the mud flats of New York Bay.
PARIS, May 23 (UP) -- Following is a translation of Premier Pierre Pflimlim's broadcast speech tonight:
HOUSTON, Tex., May 23 (AP) -- Southern Baptists opened today a special, religiously oriented inquiry into how they can promote world peace.

The Creole Petroleum Corporation, Venezuelan affiliate of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey), had a net income of $86,221,000, or $1.11 a share, in the first quarter of 1958, H. W. Haight, president, told stockholders at their meeting yesterday.

The dismissal of a 65-year-old Department of Public Works employe three years ago when he was under investigation as a possible security risk was characterized yesterday by the Appellate Division as "harsh and unwarranted."

CHICAGO, May 23 (UP) -- Trust funds that Joe Louis, former heavyweight champion, set up for his children in the late Nineteen Forties have been ordered turned over to the Government to help pay the huge tax bill the ex-fighter owes the Government.
DETROIT, May 23 -- The Yankees roared to their tenth straight victory tonight. Behind another powerful mound performance by Bob Turley, they brought down the Tigers, 8 to 1.
CHICAGO, May 23 (AP) -- Prices of all grain futures except oats eased today on the Board of Trade, mostly under pressure of profit taking.
THERE still is time for the June bride to order her monogrammed linens.

BROOKVILLE, L. I., May 28 -- Mrs. Bernard Freeman of the Inwood Country Club carded a 38, 39 -- 77 to take the low gross honors in the low handicap division of the Women's Cross County Golf Association tournament at the Brookville Country Club today. A field of eight-six participated.
WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP) -- The Government is reported to have taken steps to prevent Pedro Estrada, ousted Venezuelan secret police chief, from re-entering the United States.
NIAGARA FALLS, N. Y., May 23 -- Governor Harriman said today that he had "no intention" of replacing Robert Moses as chairman of the State Power Authority.
NEW DELHI, India, May 16 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru did some thinking out loud recently about a word Indian politicians use much and define little: "socialism."

KANSAS CITY, May 23 (UP) -- Ernie Vossler of Midland, Tex., a former plumber putting as if he had laid a pipe to every hole, shot a seven-under-par 65 today for a 132 total and the halfway lead in the $22,000, seventy-two-hole Kansas City open.
Tramp shipping men in this country announced yesterday their opposition to the transfer of foreign-flag ships to United States registry at this time.
Two hundred persons arrived here from Washington yesterday for the annual Congressional tour of the city.

WILMINGTON, Del., May 23 (AP) -- Despite a 20 per cent drop in sales, Harlow H. Curtice, president of the General Motors Corporation, told stockholders today that G. M. sees only "optimism for our own future."
ROME, May 23 -- Italy's national election campaign, which has been carried on listlessly by ten major parties for the last two months, came to an end tonight.

SPRING and summer brides-to-be who are planning small, informal weddings have a wide choice of dresses to wear. The style, material and color of the dress depend on the bride's age and type of ceremony.

Top executive pay exerts a fascination for the millions who receive somewhat less. Business Week magazine in its annual survey finds that "raises for the top brass were not so substantial in 1957 as in past years." In fact, some executives took cuts.

SUFFERN, N. Y., May 23 -The Suffern Board of Trustees voted 3 to 1 today to appeal a decision of Supreme Court Justice Robert Doscher, who last Monday permitted tenants to occupy their leased premises in Oakdale Manor, a new apartment house in the east end of this village.

Elsewhere on this page we publish a letter from Professor Slichter of Harvard commenting on a recent editorial entitled "Personal Income." Our only purpose in writing this editorial was to anticipate the possibility that the average reader might make the natural mistake of confusing "personal income" with "wages and salaries."

There is no denying or disguising the fact that most Americans will be gratified by the sweeping election victory of Premier Kishi in Japan. His positions have been endorsed by a large part of the electorate and 75 per cent of them turned out to vote.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 23 (AP) -- Four pacifists, now in Honolulu, who want to protest United States nuclear tests by sailing their thirty-foot ketch, Golden Rule, into the Eniwetok testing area, lost another court battle today.
MOSCOW, May 23 -- "Mothers, are you having troubles feeding your baby?" asked an unctuous voice on a television program one evening this week. "Get baby kasha [porridge]."
LONDON, May 23 (Reuters) -In a strike connected with that of the dockers, 6,500 men were out at Smithfield, London's wholesale meat market, and 1,700 meat truck drivers were idle.

RABAT, Morocco, May 23 -- The new Moroccan Government published today its program for transforming this under-developed country with a colonial economy into a modern, self-supporting, independent state.
Christians and Jews will mark important festivals of the religious year tomorrow.
SOMETHING new has not been added but taken away from the permanent wave to make it more than ever a boon to woman.
HAVANA, May 23 -- The police announced tonight the arrest of ten persons and the capture of a quantity of arms and ammunition.

The Times gave a distorted picture of personal income when in its editorial entitled "Personal Income" on May 15 it described the increase in transfer payments as "the key to the upturn in personal income."

At Wednesday's Senate hearing President George Meany of the A. F. L.-C. I. O. showed a more cooperative attitude toward legislation to curb labor union abuses than he has in the past -- which is all to the good, both for labor and the public.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 23 -- Ferry service on San Francisco Bay was doomed today. A ruling of the Interstate Commerce Commission in Washington apparently marked the imminent end of a sentimental attraction, for tourists and bay area old-timers alike, that rivals the cable car and Chinatown.
GUZELHISAR, Turkey, May 20 -- The fifty village families here refused to let a tractor shortage stop a face-lifting project to conserve soil and increase its yield.
LONDON, May 23 -- Most principal snare groups except South African gold mining stocks continued to advance on the Stock Exchange today.

One of the most publicized players in the history of basketball, Wilt (the Stilt) Chamberlain, yesterday announced he had decided to quit college basketball and that he would not return to the University of Kansas this fall.
WASHINGTON, May 23 -- A report of the National Health Survey indicated today that about 25,000,000 Americans had been accidentally injured in the last six months of 1957.
LONDON, May 23 (Reuters) -- Soviet Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev offered industrial aid today to Finland to help ease the Finnish unemployment problem.

CHICAGO, May 23 -- Dr. Willard F. Libby, the only scientist member of the Atomic Energy Commission, said today that a by-product of hydrogen bomb explosions could be determining whether a well was likely to run dry.
BUENOS AIRES, May 23 -- President Arturo Frondizi announced today that an Argentine fleet might have sunk a foreign submarine Wednesday.

ATHENS, May 22 -- The proposal that Cyprus be partitioned has raised sharp reaction here. According to a New York Times dispatch yesterday, Fatin Rustu Zorlu, Turkey's Foreign Minister, called it the only solution to the Cyprus issue acceptable to his Government.
Klausner Associates, realty operators who bought the sixstory apartment house for 130 families at 789 St. Marks Avenue in Brooklyn, have resold it to an investing client of Isidore Mandel, attorney.

LONDON, May 23 (AP) -- Agatha Christie solved today the real-life mystery of a lost forty seconds that gave her latest play an unhappy ending. The final curtain came down on "The Verdict" nearly a minute too soon and added to the disappointment of an already disgruntled first-night audience. A few boos were even heard.
WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP) -- President Eisenhower's reply to the May 9 letter of Nikita S. Khrushchev on disarmament is to be released tomorrow.

HAVING a picnic? It's open season for same starting Decoration Day. Meanwhile there isn't a moment to lose shaking out the picnic blanket, checking thermos bottles and baskets and, for once, finding an alternate menu to ham sandwiches and boiled eggs. For further tips, see below.

WARSAW, May 23 -- Jerzy Morawski, a member of the Polish Communist party's Politburo, indirectly warned the Roman Catholic Church today against activities that he said "far transcends the church's proper functions."

Montgomery Ward Co., the nation's second largest mail order concern, showed a 32 per cent decline in earnings in the quarter ended April 30, despite an increase of 2.6 per cent in sales over the preceding year's period.
HAROLD MACMILLAN, the British Prime Minister, appeared on Channel 2's "See It Now" last night with Edward R. Murrow and Charles Collingwood.

ST. LOUIS, May 23 -- A tradition 122 years old gave way here this week before the advance of a woman. Holdouts in the St. Louis Merchants Exchange yielded and members voted 77 to 17 to permit women to become members with the right of trading on the floor.
LAFAYETTE, Ind., May 23 (AP) -- The Olympic broad jump champion, Greg Bell, led defending Indiana to an impressive preliminary showing in the Big Ten track and field meet today.
BINGHAMTON, N. Y., May 23 (AP) -- A Protestant clergyman called today for less emphasis on denominations in missionary work and more unity.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- President Eisenhower extended personal congratulations today to Van Cliburn, the tall, bushy-haired young Texan who won first honors in the international Tchaikovsky Piano Competition in Moscow a month ago.
Johnny Busso of Astoria, Queens spoiled the first New York appearance of Lahouari Godih by soundly whipping the Algerian fighter in a ten-round bout at Madison Square Garden last night.
SCHENECTADY, N. Y., May 23 (AP) -- The New York State Association of Chests and Councils began today an effort to keep within its ranks forty local chapters of the American Cancer Society.

DETROIT, May 23 -- The United Automobile Workers indicated today it would place primary emphasis in the final days of auto contract bargaining on measures to help distressed workers rather than on straight economic matters.

SCHROON LAKE, N. Y., May 23 -- The Republican state chairman pictures Governor Harriman tonight as incapable of furnishing the dynamic leadership needed to keep New York in the forefront of the states.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee approved today a modified foreign-aid authorization bill. It cut military and defense funds by $235,000,000 and authorized the President to furnish economic assistance to any Communist-bloc nation except the Soviet Union, Communist China or North Korea.
Peter Brook, whose staging of the Lunts' vehicle, "The Visit," drew high praise from the local reviewers, will direct "The Balcony," by Jean Genet.
MOSCOW, May 28 -- The Soviet Union declared today that any Italian soldiers still listed as missing in action on the Soviet front in World War II must be considered dead.

WASHINGTON, May 23 (UP) --President Eisenhower will express the nation's gratitude to the dead of two ware when he bestows the Medal of Honor on the unknown soldiers of World War II and the Korean War on Memorial Day.

CAIRO, May 23 -- Sources close to the Government reported today that President Gamal Abdel Nasser had implied approval of compromise moves in Beirut just before the Lebanese Government decided to make charges in the United Nations against the United Arab Republic.

BUENOS AIRES, May 23 (AP) -- Rear Admiral Isaac F. Rojas, who played a key role in ousting General Peron in 1955 and later served as Vice President, said he had "no doubt at all that a submarine was detected."
PHILADELPHIA, May 23 -- Delaware's baseball team won the Middle Atlantic Conference baseball championship today by defeating Lafayette, 9 -- 6, in a play-off test at Temple University stadium.

PARIS, May 23 -- Premier Pierre Pflimlin rejected tonight a renewed demand from dissident Algiers that Gen. Charles de Gaulle be called to power in France. In a bid for nation-wide support, Premier Pflimlin declared over national radio and television networks that "it would notbe tolerable that a fraction of the nation should attempt to impose its will on the entire country."

Since the House members who voted for foreign aid are internationalists, it is axiomatic they would vote for the Eisenhower give-away programs. With the exception of Nationalist China, South Korea, the Philippines, the United States has had good evidence that recipients of foreign aid will not contribute to the security of the United States.

Final decision as to the name of a new baby is generally deferred for various reasons until after the baby is born. With new bridges the reverse is almost invariably true. Here in New York the names of two bridges, Throgs (once Throgmorton's) Neck and the Narrows, are widely recognized, although neither bridge may exist in fact for a long time to come.
PANAMA, May 23 -- Student snipers fired tonight on National Guardsmen manning a checkpoint on the Trans-Isthmian Highway. There was no immediate report of casualties.
CHICAGO, May 23 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

JAKARTA, Indonesia, May 23 -- Government forces continued their offensive against Indonesian rebel areas in the Celebes today, with damaging dawn air attacks at Menado and gains against rebel troops in land fighting.
LIEUT. GEN. ELWOOD RICHARD QUESADA, who is in charge of the Government's program for air safety, has been one of the nation's outstanding pilots as well as Air Force administrators.
The Soviet expedition ship Ob is reported to have discovered an island in the vast open sea area between Australia and Antarctica.

PRESTWICK, Scotland, May 23 (AP) -- Harry Bradshaw of Ireland fought his way through icy winds and hail today for a 75 to take the lead in a professional golf tournament here. He had a 54-hole total of 217.
TOKYO, Saturday, May 24 -- Japanese voters have overwhelmingly endorsed the pro-Western policy of Premier Nobosuke Kishi's Government.
CARACAS, Venezuela, May 23 -- The electoral statute that will govern the choosing of a new Venezuelan President at the end of this year was formally promulgated today by the governing junta.
RICHMOND, Va., May 23 -- John J. Daly, editor of The Catholic Virginian, was elected today president of the Catholic Press Association.
Irving Maidman, realty investor and builder, has added two parking lots and a former store building to his holdings on the West Side.

WASHINGTON, May. 23 (UP) -- The House Space Committee accused the Administration today of trying to pinch pennies on the nation's civilian space program. It said this country should spend one billion dollars a year by 1962 to surpass the Soviet effort.

WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP) -- The Army today awarded the second multimillion dollar contract in a week for production of components for the Nike-Hercules antiaircraft missile. The Hercules is the successor to the Ajax type that blew up in New Jersey yesterday.

Measles is now epidemic in the city, with 22,536 cases and thirteen deaths since January, the Health Department reported yesterday. The department generally estimates that 97 or 98 per cent of those affected in a measles epidemic are children.
Opposition to the application of the Greyhound Corporation to expand its bus terminal on West Thirty-fourth Street between Seven and Eighth Avenues was expressed yesterday by the Citizens Union.

One of the copper industry's best-known executives unexpectedly celebrated his sixtieth year in the business yesterday. Unexpectedly because a score of his associates surprised him with a luncheon at the Racquet and Tennis Club.

PHILLIPPEVILLE, Algeria May 23 (AP) -- French authorities said today that they had released an Italian ship carrying United States-made military material for the Algerian nationalist rebels. The French seized the cargo.

CHICAGO, May 23 -- Julius Raab, Chancellor of Austria, held out hope today for a quick solution to an involved three-year dispute over compensation for two United States oil company properties now in the Austrian Government's hands.

ALBANY, May 23 (UP) -- Two recently dismissed State Compensation Court referees asked the Appellate Division today to stay a Supreme Court order dismissing their application for reinstatement. The Appellate Court reserved decision.

BELGRADE. Yugoslavia, May 23 -- The Yugoslav Communists, who are being attacked daily in the Soviet bloc's press, still are not certain whether Nikita S. Khrushchev will resort to political and economic reprisals, as Stalin did in 1948.
WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP) -- The House of Representatives considered the Alaska statehood bill for only twenty minutes today before adjourning until Monday.

" There's Always a Price Tag," a Rank Organization melodrama starring Michele Morgan and Daniel Gelin, opens tomorrow at the Fifty-fifth Street Playhouse near Seventh Ave nue. The feature, based on James Hadley Chase's novel, "Retour de Manivelle," was produced by Intermondia Films and directed by Denys de la Patelliere.
It is unusual for an apprentice rider to become a leading rider and to draw a ten-day suspension in the same week.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 23 -The former general manager of New York City's Transit Authority proposed today that railroads serving the city give up their short-haul passenger business. He suggested that a semi-governmental body be established to carry commuters over the same tracks.
Daily newspapers plan to spend $62,911,986 for plant expansion and new equipment this year, the American Newspaper Publishers Association reported yesterday.

LAKEHURST, N. J., May 23 -- The Naval Air Station here is adding to its national defense role a secondary role as a fish and game preserve. The assist to nature is being led by a small group of volunteers.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., May 23 -A fleet of thirty-eight cruising craft, ranging in size from the N. Y. Maritime College's seventy-three-foot ketch Ticonderoga down to Geoffrey Hazard's twenty-four-foot Pennant sloop Kari sailed from Larchmont at twilight tonight on the Larchmont Yacht Club's fourth overnight race to Mattituck, L. I., and Six Mile Reef.
The Women's City Club recommended yesterday that three Board of Education bureaus dealing with delinquency problems be consolidated into one.
IS it really necessary, a reader has asked, to soak dried beans overnight before cooking, as some recipes direct?
An urban renewal project that would transform Manhattan's Chelsea area into distinct residential, shopping, play and industrial districts was proposed yesterday.

ADEN, May 23 -- Officials here contend that Britain would be happy to quit Aden tomorrow if it were not for the strategic importance of her presence in the political field within the context of Communist-backed pan-Arabism.
NEW ORLEANS, May 23 (AP) -- The United States Fifth Circuit Court of Appeals today threw out of Federal court a school integration appeal from the Dallas (Tex.) school district.

BUFFALO, N. Y., May 23 (AP) -- The president of the Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation announced last night that the utility would ask the Public Service Commission for a substantial rate increase soon.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, May 22 -- Three Arab states have come together under one roof at the Brussels World's Fair to tell a single story: how they are improving their land and the welfare of their people while advancing into the age of industry.
James S. Ottenberg was sworn in yesterday afternoon as executive director of the New York City Council on Port Development and Promotion.
Two hundred pairs of bridge experts began play yesterday afternoon to open the thirtieth annual Eastern States Bridge Tournament here at the Park Sheraton Hotel.
LONDON, May 23 (AP) -- Public ownership of Britain's movie industry has been suggested by the head of the National Association of Theatrical and Kine Employes.
By way of footnote to your fine editorial on the occasion of Elmer Davis' death, it seems appropriate to recall two of his less known activities in the field of writing.

This is the twentieth year of humanitarian service for the United Jewish Appeal. In the past nineteen years the national campaign has provided help to more than 2,600,000 persons in need all over the world. This help has included relief, medical assistance, vocational training, emigration and resettlement aid.

WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture reported today that farmers had received about $9,100,000,000 from sales of their products in the first four months of this year, 8 per cent above receipts for the like period of last year.
Federal Judge Irving R. Kaufman yesterday sentenced an 18-year-old youth to twelve years in prison for robbing Hudson, N. Y., branch of the Federal Reserve Bank of $13,051 last March 28.
GETTYSBURG, Pa., May 23 (UP) -- President Eisenhower plunged immediately into a fast eighteen holes of golf. He emerged from the round rubbing his left shoulder.
NEWARK, May 23 -- The Newark law faculty of Rutgers University urged the university today to retore Prof. Abraham Glasser immediately to his position as Associate Professor of Law.
MACAO, May 12 -- A refugee from Communist China described today the rigors of life he endured in a forced-labor camp. Millions of Chinese have been sent to such camps.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 23 -- There is a strong possibility that the George Gobel and Eddie Fisher shows on the National Broadcasting Company will return to the same Tuesday evening period on the television network next fall, but at the rate of one a month rather than the weekly alternations of this season.

New special purpose ships, airborne television and the repatriation of a scientific team high above the Arctic Circle will be among the highlights of the Navy's ninth annual supply mission to the Far North.
IROQUOIS, Ont., May 23 (AP) -The Iroquois Lock, at the western end of the St. Lawrence Seaway, is officially open.

Atlas Powder Company yesterday dedicated its new technical center near Wilmington, Del. The facility, built at a cost of $3,000,000, will house the company's basic research and chemical product development activities.
WILLIAMSBURG, Va., May 23 (AP) -- The Aircraft Industries Association relented today and removed the top secret tag from a three-day-old spiritual address by Cardinal Spellman.
ROME, May 23 -- A painting attributed to Correggio, sixteenth century Italian painter, reported to have been offered as a gift to President Eisenhower, was the center of a controversy today.
WASHINGTON, May 23 (UP) -- President Eisenhower signed today a law to give Federal pensions to veterans of the Confederate Army and their widows.

BERKELEY, Calif., May 23 (AP) -- Pacific Coast Conference records fell to Rafer Johnson of the University of California at Los Angeles in the javelin and Rink Babka of Southern California in the discus today in the P. C. C. track and field championships preliminaries.
WASHINGTON, May 23 -- The number of workers receiving unemployment insurance registered its biggest drop of the year in the week ended May 10, the Labor Department reported today.

Nine American-made short films submitted in the experimental division at the Brussels World's Fair are scheduled for presentation Tuesday in the auditorium of the Museum of the City of New York, Fifth Avenue at 103d Street.
WASHINGTON, May 23 -- Ezra Taft Benson told employes of the Department of Agriculture and local farm committeemen today to quit competing for more authority over conservation programs.
A group of steers, Brahma bulls and buffalo boarded a ship yesterday for a one-way trip to the World's Fair in Brussels.
WASHINGTON, May 23 -- What is foreign aid? Who gets it ? How much? For what?
WHITEHOUSE, N. J., May 23 -Ch. Artru Hot Rod won, best-of-breed honoz:s in the l twenty-first annual specialtyl show of the Cocker Spaniel: Club of New Jersey today.
WASHINGTON, May 23 -- The Army announced today the suspension of its trigger modifications of Nike antiaircraft missiles throughout the country.
A final decision on the sale of the Transit Authority's powerhouses to the Consolidated Edison Company appears to be many months away.

Draft indebtedness of Latin American importers to United States exporters increased during April by $4,500,000, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. The bank's monthly survey of fourteen large commercial banks, showed collections outstanding on Latin America amounted to $168,500,000 last month, a new high for the year.
Seventy-five years ago today the guns on Governors Island and at the Navy Yard crashed out the news that the Brooklyn Bridge had been opened.
Stephen B. Gibbons, Assistant Secretary of the Treasury from 1933 to 1939, plunged to his death from a window in his apartment here yesterday. Friends said they believed it was an accident.

WASHINGTON, May 23 (UP) -- Representative Charles E. Chamberlain of Michigan said today that preliminary results of a poll in his district indicated that most workers favored more strict supervision of labor unions.

PARIS, May 23 (AP) -- Karol Fageros of Miami was eliminated today, but two other Americans, Budge Patty and Mrs. Dorothy Head Knode, advanced to the fourth round of the French international tennis tournament.
WASHINGTON, May 23 -- The belated announcement this week of the organization of a Strategic Army Corps stems from weakness rather than strength.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 23 (AP) -- The East Central Nuclear Group, Inc., filed articles of incorporation today with the Ohio Secretary of State. Headquarters of the group will be in Columbus.
The Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick will observe his eightieth birthday today.
LINCOLN, Neb., May 23 (AP) -- Charles Starkweather, 19 years old, was sentenced today to die in the electric chair for one of eleven slayings attributed to him.
Labor should outdo industry in its sense of dedication and commitments to honesty, a prominent labor leader said yesterday.
COLONIA, Yap, Caroline Islands, May 9 -- Inflation, it is said, has devalued the famous stone money of Yap.
The big question about the economy last week was still this: is the recession leveling off?
The United Press Associations and the International News Service announced yesterday they had merged into a new agency called United Press International.

The new 15,000-ton Grace liner Santa Rosa will sail from the yard of her builder in Virginia tomorrow afternoon for forty hours of testing and trials at sea. Launched last August for Grace's Caribbean service, she is scheduled for delivery to New York June 16. Her maiden voyage is set for June 26.

In his survey of the installment credit system Senator O'Mahoney made many worthwhile observations. One area he barely touched upon deserves further comment: the role of the merchant as a responsible element in the credit structure.

SCRATCHES on furniture can often be obliterated by wiping with a solution which consists of equal parts of boiled linseed oil, turpentine and white vinegar. Stir the ingredients well, and apply with a soft woolen cloth. Then polish with a dry cloth.

Beneficiaries of college scholarships sometimes have to fit into bizarre categories in order to qualify under terms prescribed by donors. Some colleges, such as Carleton at Northfield, Minn., have scholarships for farmers' daughters, while Tufts in Medford, Mass., has them for the sons and daughters of fishermen.

DEVON, Pa., May 24 -- The Best Child Rider Challenge Trophy of the sixty-second annual Devon Horse Show was awarded tonight to Joan Draper of the Fairfield County Club, Westport, Conn.

GENOA, Italy -- Tourists wishing to be sidewalk superintendents on foreign soil can watch the first airport being built in this pre-Roman city which has been a busy seaport ever since ships first sailed the waters of the blue Mediterranean.

Unfairly, because its elders, in judging it by the forms of youthful expression current in the Nineteen Thirties, are misinterpreting its realism and prudence as ominous evidence of apathy and lack of idealism.

CHICAGO, May 24 (UPI) -- Walt Dropo's first home run of the year today broke an eight-inning tie and helped the Chicago White Sox to a 4-3 victory over the Baltimore Orioles and a sweep of the three-game series.
Dr. Lillian M. Gilbreth will be guest of honor at a dinner tomorrow celebrating her eightieth birthday.

PARIS. THE three thousand or more students in the big Paris art schools are at present getting ready for their end-of-the-year exams. There are six hundred of them at the Beaux Arts (l'Ecole Nationale Superieure des Beaux Arts).

ALONG with lobster festivals, covered bridges and quaint ocean coves, the "down-east" provinces of Canada are now promoting their local handicrafts as a tourist attraction and this year there is even a do-it-yourself course for the visitor who seeks a change but not necessarily a rest.

IF there are any Western fans who don't know Whitey, that indomitable young cowpoke who helps Uncle Torwal on his ranch, this is a good time to get acquainted. His new adventure is less dramatic than some of his earlier ones, but it is strenuous enough and has its own suspense.
With customary abruptness the art season annually abandons its hectic pace at the end of May. This week a scant dozen group and one-man shows will be added to the current attractions.

CERTAIN things are clear from the first few days of opera-going and theatre-going in Moscow. Works of the Russian repertory are done with a musical and dramatic authority unmatched anywhere in the world. Whatever reservations one may have of the individual caliber among some of the singers, there is no gainsaying the conviction of the performances as a whole.
MILWAUKEE, May 24 -- The Wisconsin Republican party closed its two-day state convention this afternoon with a call for the support of conservative programs.

LONDON, May 21 -- Britain has again been urged to launch a satellite. The appeal has been made by her leading radio-astronomer, Prof. Alfred C. B. Lovell, director of the Jodrell Bank Observatory in Cheshire.

PARIS, May 24 (AP) -- Earlier today there was a demonstration in Ajaccio. The police chief was removed to a post in northern France for permitting a motorcade to drive through the streets carrying portraits of General de Gaulle.

PITTSBURGH, May 24 (UPI) -- The Pittsburgh Pirates, who make a habit of scoring with two out, exploded for five runs in the eighth inning today to sweep an abbreviated two-game series from the St. Louis Cardinals, 6 -- 1. This made Bob Friend the first National League pitcher to win seven games this season.

WATERTOWN, N. Y., May 24 -- Plans for the summer training program of National Guardsmen and Reservists at near-by Camp Drum are being mapped there this week-end by nine generals of the First Army area.

THERE is no more shattering event in the history of the American West than the Mountain Meadows Massacre, which occurred Sept. 11, 1857, in southern Utah. A group of Mormons and Indians tricked an emigrant train into disarming, fell upon the one-hundred-and-sixty helpless men, women and children and murdered them with guns, scalping knives and axes -- all but a few babies.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- The failure of the United States and its Latin-American neighbors to agree on economic development is the basic problem facing the Administration in its current review of inter-American relations.

ALGIERS, May 24 -- The Committee of Public Safety, which sparked the revolt here May 13, urged today the establishment of a "triumvirate" to coordinate "civil and political affairs." The new group is expected to start work tomorrow.

BALMY weather inspires everyone to start digging and planting. When children get this outdoor feeling, parents may think they will have to dash out and rescue a section of the garden.

SAN FRANCISCO -- Two attractions in the San Francisco Bay area are now drawing 1,200 to 1,500 visitors a week even before the summer tourist season gets under way in earnest. One of these is a reminder of the Bay's storied past; the other offers a shadowy glimpse of its future.
The packaging industry, a fast-moving giant, enters New York this week with the opening of the twenty-seventh National Packaging Exposition at the Coliseum tomorrow.

GARDENERS are profiting from the efforts of dahlia hybridizers in Australia, Holland and the United States. Newly developed varieties are more beautiful than ever. Also, they are almost foolproof to grow.

Price cuts at the retail counter -- on ships and shoes and sealing wax, apparel, appliances, anything at all -- are scarce. WHEN an improvement-minded home owner notices that the outside of his house looks dingy or dirty he usually jumps to the conclusion that a new paint job is required. Yet in many cases the old paint film is still in perfectly good condition. It has merely been clouded over with accumulated dust and dirt.

KANSAS CITY, May 24 -- Ernie Vossler of Midland, Tex., protected his lead in the Kansas City open golf tournament today with a two-under-par 70. This made his fifty-four hole total 202, two strokes better than that of his closest challenger.

Gregory Solon's second book -- his first, "The Three Legions," was set in ancient Rome -- is a bold effort by an American writer to get inside the minds of a handful of modern Russian soldiers stationed in East Germany.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., May 24 -- Fred Lorenzen's new fiberglas yawl, Seal, won the Larchmont Yacht Club's annual Edlu Trophy long-distance race tonight. A report card that rates school systems, not pupils, has been devised for those who want to know how good their schools are and what they can do to make them better.

THE annual Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival, directed by Ted Shawn in the foothills of the Berkshires just outside Lee, Mass., will open July 2 and last for nine weeks. This will be the twenty-sixth year of the festivials at Jacob's Pillow and the seventeenth year in the Ted Shawn Theatre there.

PHILADELPHIA, May 24 (AP) -- The German sculling protege of Jack Kelly Jr., a former United States champion, won the national junior title today at the twenty-fourth national scholastic rowing championships on the Schuykill.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- Informed guessers were still betting today against passage of a labor reform law this year, but the odds have dropped sharply. A few observers thought the situation warranted an even money bet.

CAIRO -- One group of Egyptians is probably happier than any other because of the betterment of relations with the United States and Western Europe. This group is Egypt's hotel owners and tourist agencies.

OUT of the most barren wastes, as poets since Chaucer have observed, come the most beautiful flowers. A barren urban waste is the Lincoln Square area on the west side of midtown New York. Old-law tenements stand, blowsy and rundown, in silent shoulder-to-shoulder misery, full of filth and vermin.

MIAMI BEACH, May 24 -- The Governors who spent the greater part of this week here at their fiftieth annual conference left two strong impressions behind as they returned to their home states, These were: (1) Democrats expect to score strong gains this fall in the predominantly industrial states; and (2) Republicans hope to improve their position in farm areas.
PARIS, May 24 -- Overt insurrection in Corsica tonight struck a hard new blow at France's parliamentary regime and appeared to increase the chances that Gen. Charles de Gaulle soon would replace it.

WARSAW, Sunday, May 25 -- Communist China has agreed to begin the integration of its economic planning with the rest of the Soviet bloc. So have the other Far Eastern Communist countries -- North Korea, North Vietnam and Outer Mongolia.

STAMFORD, Conn., May 24 -- A performance by a 342-piece orchestra composed of pupils from this city's elementary schools was a highlight today of Stamford's annual "Fair in the Square."

The Rockaway Hunting Club of Cedarhurst, L. I., no longer is a center for those who would ride to the hounds. Its steeple-chase and race course are gone; its polo field gave way a generation ago to form part of the site of an enlarged clubhouse.

MILWAUKEE, May 24 -- The Milwaukee Braves exploded for four runs in the eighth inning today to defeat the San Francisco Giants, 6 -- 3, and move within a game and a half of first place. An error by the Giants' shortstop, Daryl Spencer, set off the Braves' rally. Three of the runs were unearned.
BEAR MOUNTAIN, N. Y., May 24 -- James A. Farley said tonight that Democrats would achieve national victories this year like those of the Thirties. He advised them to work "through party machinery."

TEANECK, N. J., May 24 -- The Bergen Community Museum will hold open house tomorrow afternoon to begin its second season. The museum is located on Fort Lee Road.

A team of dental research workers at Ohio State University reported at the recent meeting of the Society of American Bacteriologists at Chicago that they have isolated a chemical substance, from the saliva of individuals resistant to dental caries, which inhibits or destroys the types of bacteria commonly associated with tooth decay.

PROVINCETOWN, Mass -- A walk through this town's narrow, winding streets at this time of the year is to evoke childhood memories of being in the meadow watching the Big Top go up. The workmen are still busy and the visitor has a faint feeling of being a trespasser.

ALGIERS, May 24 -- After twelve days of shouting and horn honking, the crowds which gather every evening in the forum before the Government General Building of Algiers are beginning to diminish. DETROIT, May 24 -- The United Automobile Workers, bargaining without an effective strike weapon, will welcome a new offer from the big three auto companies.

RAIL fares to the West Coast have gone up. From New York to Los Angeles or San Francisco, the round-trip first-class rate has jumped from $224.65 to $237.40, coach from $157 to $159.90; to Portland or Seattle, first class from $212.50 to $224.75, coach from $148.05 to $150.95.

THE Eastern Championships are on again for the thirtieth consecutive year; they are being played at the Park Sheraton Hotel and will last through the week. Today there is a two-session mixed-pair game for the William E. McKenney Trophy; during the week teams of four will play for the Curt H. Reisinger Cup, and next week-end, May 31 and June 1, there will be the pair contest for the Julian Goldman Trophy.

NEW YORK CITY'S new independent television station, WNTA-TV, is affording an illustration of how different a video program can be when it finds a way to avoid the tyranny of the studio clock.

Former President Harry S. Truman said he had been moved almost to tears last night while watching a dramatization here of the late President Franklin D. Roosevelt's struggle against infantile paralysis.

PARIS, Sunday, May 25 -- The anti-Government movement ruling Algeria seized control of the island of Corsica yesterday. The French Government declared early this morning that Corsica was in a state of insurrection.

There are tentative grounds for hoping that Lebanon's complaint to the United Nations against the United Arab Republic will bring at least a temporary easing of tension. When the complaint was submitted Thursday night the Lebanese delegation said it was asking for an urgent meeting of the Security Council. After considerable hesitation Lebanon decided yesterday to go ahead with the complaint, and the Security Council is scheduled to take it up Tuesday.

WEST POINT, N. Y., May 24 -- Army won every field event and all but two running events today to trounce the Air Force Academy track team, 114 -- 17, at Shea Stadium. The meet marked the beginning of athletic relations between the two service schools.

FRANCES ARVOLD, a petite young woman with large eyes and a small voice, has been referred to as "the girl who does Murrow's beard."
WARSAW, May 24 -- Poland's Roman Catholic Church is under persistent attack these days for "meddling in politics."

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- It would be less than the truth to report that since last Feb. 6 when Mikhail A. Menshikov, the new Soviet Ambassador, arrived, the Soviet Embassy on Sixteenth Street has been a nest of jolly good fellows.
ATHENS, May 24 -- Public opinion here was shocked by news that a British offer of a solution to the Cyprus problem, expected last week, would not materialize for awhile.

A National Workshop on Economics for Science and Social Studies Teachers will be held at Sarah Lawrence College, Bronxville, N. Y., Aug. 3-22. It will be sponsored by the Joint Council on Economic Education, the National Science Teachers Association and the National Council for the Social Studies.

HARRY DICHTER is a Philadelphian who works as a waiter in the Ambassador, Philadelphia's only dairy restaurant, from 5 P. M. until 2 A. M. The rest of the time, except for three or four hours devoted to sleep, he is a musical researcher who has all to himself a corner of the publishing field -- facsimile editions of rare early American music.

CAMDEN, N. J., May 24 -- Lincoln Road, thoroughbred racing's most successful failure, located the winner's circle today for the first time this season. With no Tim Tam around to play the role of spoiler, Lincoln Road's speed held up all the way in the mile-and-an-eighth $59,100 Jersey Stakes at Garden State Park.

BERKELEY, Calif., May 24 (UPI) -- Southern California won its seventeenth Pacific Coast Conference track and field title today, but some of the Trojans' glory was overshadowed by California's Don Bowden and Willie White.

Boston appears to be headed for transportation troubles. Unless some last-minute plan is worked out, which is considered unlikely by civic officials, the Old Colony branch of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad and the Highland branch of the Boston Albany Railroad will suspend service at the end of this week.
Green, amber and red traffic lights -- but ne candles -- will shine today at the Lincoln Tunnel.
RABAT, Morocco, May 24 -- French military contingents will no longer be permitted to enter Morocco, well-informed Moroccan sources said today.

WESTBURY, L. I., May 24 -- Duane Hanover, the rangy bay from the Pine Acre Farm of nearby Garden City, demonstrated again that he was one of the nation's top pacers by taking the $8,000 feature at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.

OTTAWA, May 24 -- Relations between the United States and Canada have reached a precarious stage. Whether they will deteriorate further or improve seems to depend upon the patience of Canadians and understanding by the United States Administration and Congress.

Only a handful of fugitives from Communist persecution and two families of Jewish refugees from Egypt have so far been granted visas to the United States under special provisions of a new immigration law. President Eisenhower signed the measure last Sept. 11.

AT last we have a novel from England by a young man who does not appear in the least angry. True, he is Welsh, though not of the Celtic twilight variety, and that may account for some of the sprightliness with which he presents his story.
WASHINGTON, May 24 -- A comprehensive study of the nation's capabilities and needs for limited war is being conducted by a joint State Department-Pentagon group.
ENGLEWOOD, N. J., May 24 -- The people of this city like their home town. They say it is beautiful, has adequate shopping facilities and is neither too big nor too small.

JULIUS CAESAR had a low opinion of Britons, but, two thousand years after his invasion, the "thick wood enclosed with a rampart and a ditch" which he scorned was a great city successfully resisting a fiercer foe.

The joint American Heritage Foundation and Advertising Council effort to get Americans to contribute at least $1 to the party of their choice in political campaigns is an event of first importance in our national life. The voice of the persuaders -- in this case far from "hidden" and serving no private interests -- will have a prodigious range.
WASHINGTON, May 24 -- Do the figures bear out President Eisenhower's statement this week that the decline in the economy "is slowing down"?

America's first full-scale central-station atomic-power plant devoted exclusively to civilian uses will be dedicated tomorrow at Shippingport, Pa. The event will be a landmark in the development of the peaceful uses of atomic energy in the Western Hemisphere.
WASHINGTON, May 24 -- The United States and British Governments have cautioned France and Tunisia to do their utmost to avoid further military lashes.

The 200 visitors on the annual Congressional tour of the city went sight-seeing for the second day yesterday. The delegation is composed of members of the House of Representatives and their wives and children, Government employes and several Senators' wives.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- The Joint Congressional Committee on Atomic Energy is moving toward a compromise on the Administration's long-delayed proposal to share atomic weapons secrets with European allies.

RACING driver and racing-car designer, J. A. Gregoire, has written a perceptive and enthusiastic novel, filled with historical tidbits and knowledgeable details about driving psychology and the hazards of the route.

The General Electric Company set forth yesterday its belief that recovery was being held back by the automatic wage increases to which General Electric and other big companies have committed themselves.
Resident buying offices report that most of the summer merchandise has been sold and manufacturers are turning to transitional lines.

SAN JOSE, Calif., May 24 -- California industrial development is bringing to manufacturing plant employes an outdoor living atmosphere, with paintings and sculpture, reflecting pools with Japanese foot bridges and patios with umbrella-covered luncheon tables.

NOTHING like a second chance, and nothing like Off Broadway for that second chance. Tennessee Williams discovered that when he permitted the Circle in the Square to redo his "Summer and Smoke"; Truman Capote's "The Grass Harp" did better off Broadway than on;.

LOVE, as Maude Hutchins pointed out, is a pie -- and the ingredients that go under the crust can sustain, sicken or, on occasion, kill. Hans Koningsberger's tale of Zurich in 1944 starts out as a bit of a Sachertorte, one of these sweets -- a pie of a sort -- that brim with nostalgia amid the sugared layers.
THE summer - flowering bulbs represent an unexplored phase of gardening to many people. Yet these tender plants offer great rewards. Blooms are easy to achieve and eye-catching in effect.
