INDIANAPOLIS, May 24 -- A field of thirty-three cars was filled today for the forty-second 500-mile race at the Indianapolis Speedway Friday, but the relatively slower machines still were liable to elimination in the final qualifying sessions tomorrow.

A LESS sensitive, less dedicated man would have relinquished the unequal struggle months ago, but Henry Page, the embattled owner-editor of that beacon of provincial independence, The Northern Light, possessed one of those gentle natures that react surprisingly to adversity and grow more determined as the pressure mounts.
Members of the Police Honor Legion -- winners of the department's highest award for bravery -- held their annual memorial service for deceased members yesterday.
TOKYO, May 24 -- Emperor Hirohito of Japan formally opened the third Asian Games today in a vast new stadium where Tokyo hopes to hold the 1964 Olympic Games.

DETROIT, May 24 -- On this rather late date in the campaign, a baseball season opened in the Motor City. At least, that was the impression one gained from the uproar that arose from a crowd of 18,535 as Jack Tighe's reeling Tigers picked themselves up from the floor to produce a startling result today.
Professor Hirsch has, in my opinion, overlooked one important aspect of the question, "Could history repeat itself and Germany come again under the spell of a maniac?"

WITH the advent of Memorial Day, thoughts turn naturally to dining outdoors -- by the sea, a mountain stream, in a leafy park and even at home on the terrace, roof or lawn. Wherever and whenever, one thing is certain -- food will seldom taste better, even if it is only a burned frank-furter hastily retrieved from glowing coals.
ROME, May 24 -- The general elections will take place in Italy tomorrow and on Monday morning to decide the political complexion of the Italian Parliament for the next five or six years.

The Soviet Union placed five objects into orbit around the earth on May 15, according to a diagram that has been published in the Soviet newspaper Pravda. Four of them have been seen in the United States.

SINCE the first of the year, ten books on the Civil War or its personnel have been reviewed in this section. All of the reviews have ranged upward, from the pleasantly favorable to the enthusiastic. One of the books, "First Blood," back in January, was a Book-of-the-Month Club selection.

In Walter H. Waggoner's article "We Look at Them, They Look at Us" (May 4), a picture of the Soviet pavilion at the Brussels Fair shows the letters "U. R. S. S." over the entrance. Why is this? Don't the Russians know that it should be "U. S. S. R."?

BACK in 1919 Ossip Gabrilowitsch led the Philadelphia Orchestra in Haydn's "The Creation." The performance was in a church and a young trumpeter, who had joined the orchestra the year before, was very impressed.
WASHINGTON, May 24 (AP) -- The Public Health Service has found in a year's study that all milk from five metropolitan areas examined for radioactivity was safe, a spokesman said today.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 24 -- United Nations officials are discussing with Mayor Wagner the possibility of housing the United Nations International School temporarily in an unused New York City primary school building.
KIEV, U. S. S. R., May 24 -- The great gate of Kiev, so vivid to people everywhere who know Mussorgsky's music, swung wide open tonight to the Philadelphia Orchestra.
WASHINGTON, May 24 -- The Justice Department warned the United Press and International News Service today that their merger "may raise a serious question under the antitrust laws."

CAIRO, May 25 (Reuters) -- An Arab League spokesman said here today the Arab League Council would meet Saturday in Tripoli, Libya, to discuss Lebanon's complaint of interference by the United Arab Republic in Lebanese affairs.

RIO DE JANEIRO, May 24 -- Money brokers fear Jose Maria Alkmin, Minister of Finance, plans to suspend or restrict the free exchange market in Brazil. This has been used to remit profits, dividends and royalties abroad.
LONDON, May 25 (UPI) -- Gerald Patrick O'Hara, Archbishop of Savannah-Atlanta and the Pope's delegate to Britain, was reported out of danger in his illness, a hospital spokesman said tonight.

The Host Realty Corporation sold the apartment house for fifty-eight families at 278-80 East 152d Street, the Bronx, to the Newkov Realty Corporation for investment. The property is 50 by 117 feet and was sold for cash over mortgages amounting to $91,000.
WASHINGTON, May 25 -- A number of the Army's infantry division commanders believe that the artillery strength of the new pentomic division should be more than doubled.

CHICAGO, May 25 (AP) -- After the closing out of the May contracts last Tuesday following a furious speculative race in short-covering and liquidation, activity in grain futures the rest of last week on the Board of Trade was light.
The Rev. Dr. Daniel A. Poling, in a sermon last night at Marble Collegiate Church, criticized persons who call for an end to nuclear weapons testing. Dr. Poling is editor of The Christian Herald.

The twenty-fifth anniversary of the Barter Theatre, which was founded by Robert Porterfield at Abingdon, Va., will be celebrated there June 8. The ceremony will include the presentation of the annual Barter Theatre Award.

PITTSBURGH, May 25 -- Steel order volume last week was a bit stronger than it was the week before. Producers expect new business to rise slightly for the next several weeks. While many mills look for a slump in July, this opinion is not held throughout the industry.

SYRACUSE, May 25 -- A group of the nation's leading bowlers has formed the Professional Bowlers Association of America, an organization aimed at "promoting the benefits and welfare of the top money-earning bowlers in the country."
The cotton futures market continued its downward drift last week.

Ten persons, including story editors, readers and researchers, were dismissed last week from the television story department of the Columbia Broadcasting System because of a budgetary cutback. The reduction in the number of live dramatic shows for next season prompted the action.
WASHINGTON, May 25 (AP) -- Lewis L. Strauss, chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission, said today that the United States was testing both "dirty" and "clean" bombs in the Pacific.

ZURICH, Switzerland, May 25 -- Firmer confidence dominated stock exchange business in Zurich last week. Neither the long-expected lowering of the London bank rate from 6 to 5 1/2 per cent nor the rift between the Paris Government and the military powers in Algeria had any visible effect on the course of business.
Rainy weather and the shift of the Giants baseball team to San Francisco caused some rearrangements yesterday in New York's traditional pre-Memorial Day services honoring the nation's war dead.

Representative Alvin M. Bentley, a member of the House Foreign Affairs Committee, said yesterday that it was only a matter of time before 31,000 Hungarian freedom fighters in this country on parole would be granted citizenship.
WASHINGTON, May 25 -- The United States will celebrate belatedly tomorrow the completion of its first large-scale atomic power plant.
PARIS, May 25 -- The Government reacted today to the insurrection in Corsica by imposing stricter censorship on all newspapers and other media dispensing information in France.
Department stores have been less affected by the recession than other parts of the economy.

After some considerable hesitation on the part of both the Lebanese and their Western friends, Lebanon has brought her complaint against President Nasser's United Arab Republic before the Security Council of the United Nations. It will be taken up in the Council tomorrow.

As publisher of the Encyclopaedia Britannica, former Senator William Benton traveled to Russia in 1955 specifically to observe Russian education and political indoctrination. On the basis of the information he gathered, he has written "This Is the Challenge," which will be published June 16 by Associated College Press, a division of New York University Press.
Two new attacks on the riddle of the successive Ice Ages are to be made by expeditions preparing to study a critical portion of the Greenland ice sheet.
LOS ANGELES, May 25 (UPI) -- The three-month-old pilots' strike against Western Air Lines has been settled and the 268 pilots will return to work June 1, it was announced tonight.

KANSAS CITY, May 25 (AP) -- Bespectacled Ernie Vossler of Midland, Tex., won his first major golf tournament today by shooting a 5-under-par 67 that gave him a 72-hole total of 269. This enabled him to take top prize of $2,800 in the Kansas City open.
ALGIERS, May 25 -- Admiral Philippe-Marie Auboyneau, top French naval commander in the Mediterranean, hailed today the Gaullist movement sweeping Algeria.
A call for action to combat "triple-spotting" in television has been issued by the Association of National Advertisers.
SALT LAKE: CITY, May 25 (UPI) -- Pancho Gonzales defeated Ken Rosewall, 10 -- 8, today in the final of a one-day tournament on Jack Kramer's realigned professional tennis tour.

ROME, May 25 -- About 20,000,000 Italian men and women balloted today at the start of the third post-war parliamentary election, which is to decide the course of Italian politics for a number of years. governing Italy. If the Center fails to get a majority in the new Parliament, the road would perhaps be open for a return to the Government of the Left-wing Socialists, who are associated with the Communists.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, May 25 -- NATO has two undisguised worries in the event de Gaulle assumes power in France. The first is that he might encourage French nationalism by drumming up feeling against the alliance. The second is that he might seek a direct deal with Russia.

The Manhattan Stars and Marshall Stars, the leaders in the annual contest for the championship of the Metropolitan Chess League, won sixth-round matches yesterday. With one round to go, the championship, which is being defended by the Manhattans, rests between these two clubs.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- The Democratic Advisory Council charged today that the Republican Administration, led by "an obviously aging and incapacitated man," was failing to provide vigorous leadership to meet the challenge of Soviet power.

VAN CLIBURN, the Texas pianist who won international fame in Moscow, appeared last night on Steve Allen's show over Channel 4. It was one more triumph for the young man; only the closing commercial stopped the studio audience's applause after he had finished the finale of Tchaikovsky's Piano Concerto No. 1.
ROME, May 25 -- The condition of Samuel Alphonsus Cardinal Stritch "remains most grave," physicians said tonight.
PRINCETON, N. J., May 25 -- A poll conducted by the class of '48 of Princeton University revealed today that the average member was now earning $8,000 to $10,000 annually.
Under conditions that were more suitable for water skiing, crew racing or perhaps even skin diving, a picked New York track squad sloshed to a 101-to-60 triumph over a Philadelphia team yesterday.
Rate increases and decreases virtually balanced each other last week in the steamship charter market, although a hairline drop in the index did result.

The first Columbia award for "singular journalistic performance in the public interest," will highlight two days of lectures and panel discussions beginning Wednesday at the university's Graduate School of Journalism.
WASHINGTON, May 25 (AP) -- Tight money and higher interest rates helped raise the after-tax profits of commercial banks 13 per cent last year to a record level.
Youthful crime is becoming more deadly with each passing hour. Strong and determined measures are necessary -- where brutal and senseless murder has been committed capital punishment must be invoked.
PARIS, Monday, May 26 (AP) -- The French police seized today's issue of the European edition of The New York Herald Tribune.
HARTFORD, May 25 -- Senator Theodore Ryan of Sharon, president pro tempore of the State Senate, announced today his candidacy for the Republican nomination for Governor.
Tammany Hall leaders appeared ready last night to choose City Councilman Earl Brown to run against Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr. of Harlem.
WASHINGTON, May 25 -- Uncle Sam, who is up to his beard in just about everything else, is now being urged to challenge Madison Avenue in the battle for children's minds.
The active merchant fleet under the United States flag comprised 952 vessels May 1.

PITTSBURGH, May 25 (UPI) -- The league-leading San Francisco Giants swept a rhubarb-ridden double-header from the Pittsburgh Pirates today, 5 -- 2 and 6 -- 1, with a near free-for-all thrown in as the teams rekindled a simmering "duster" feud.
An 81-year-old physician, still active in his fifty-eighth year of practice, has been named Doctor of the Year by the New York County Medical Society.
Borough President John Cashmore of Brooklyn announced yesterday that the widening of Adams Street, between the Brooklyn Bridge approach and Fulton Street, would begin in the next few days.

In the News of the Week section of The New York Times on May 11 your article about Vice President Nixon's tour in South America stated: "Rumors had circulated that Peru's small but vocal Communist party planned a violent demonstration if Mr. Nixon made a scheduled visit to San Marcos University.
IN its seventh and concluding program yesterday, "The Great Challenge," on Channel 2, again demonstrated admirably that important and sometimes profound ideas need be neither complex nor forbidding.
Individual confirmation of the "law of liberty" is a prerequisite for survival, the Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman declared in a sermon yesterday.
DETROIT, May 25 (AP) -- Some 250 Ford Motor Company executives discussed today "various situations that could prevail" when the United Auto Workers Union contract expires next Sunday.
The Saturday night cruise of the excursion steamer Knickerbocker was either a bad dream or a simple hangover yesterday to most who had shared it.
AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, May 25 -- The Government's announcement last week that the investment rebate would be restored stimulated the stock market.

President Eisenhower's latest letter to Soviet Premier Khrushchev represents an important step forward in the effort to secure progress toward ending nuclear tests. Whether this progress will actually be achieved now depends on the Soviet Union.
WASHINGTON, May 25 -- Congress plans to debate four of the most controversial items of the session this week. Three may be voted on before the lawmakers quit for Memorial Day.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- The board of directors of the National Association of Concert Managers wired President Eisenhower today urging that he lead a movement for official recognition by the United States of young artists.
The Atlantic seaboard area from north of Boston to south of Washington is "the largest and most complex urban system in the world," Prof. Jean Gottmann of the University of Paris reported yesterday.

Jerome Robbins and his company of sixteen American dancers who will appear under his direction in the Festival of Two Worlds at Spoleto, Italy, left yesterday by plane from the New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens.

EAST HAMPTON, L. I., May 25 -- A man of mystery who came to this eastern Long Island village for a self-imposed thirty-year exile from his native Scotland was honored here today by the church he helped found a century ago.

WONDERING what to wear to a wedding in Tangiers next Thursday? To a dinner party in Johannesburg this June? Puzzling about how to dress for shooting in Scotland, for the Ascot, for tramping through the Brussels Fair?

HAMMERTHWACK and clackety echo drew passers-by the other day to the Seventh Avenue wall of the untidy old Metropolitan Opera House. Inside the cavernous stage was bare. Carpenters on hands and knees fitted new floorboards into place, fresh new pine insets alongside ancient, splintery strips.

ALGIERS, May 25 -- A spokesman for Gen. Raoul Salan, French military commander in Algeria, said today that dissident committees of public safety had been formed at Toulouse , in France, and in French West and Equatorial Africa.
BALBOA, C. Z., May 25 -- President Ernesto de la Guardia Jr. claimed a decisive victory today in the Panamanian uprising.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 25 (UPI) -- Dempsey Wilson of Hawthorne, Calif., and Bill Cheesbourg of Phoenix, Ariz., today became the final two qualifiers for the 500-mile Memorial Day automobile race as the trials ended.

CLEVELAND, May 25 -- A new baseball season may have opened yesterday in Detroit when the Tigers upended the Yankees to snap a ten-game Bomber winning streak. But another season just about came to a close today for Cleveland.

In his very suggestive article, published May 10, "The Cold War's Economic Aspect," C. L. Sulzberger enumerates various suggestions as to how to meet the Soviet challenge in the underdeveloped regions. As a good answer depends on a good question, so a good answer to the Soviet challenge depends on a clear notion of the nature of the challenge.
Six new films are slated to arrive in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:
The United States lacks political leaders with a deep penetration of the problems of society, a leading psychologist said last night.
ROCKPORT, Tex., May 25 (AP) -- Seven persons including a mother and her daughter drowned today while trying to save a little girl caught in deep water off a crowded beach.
The Institute of International Education announced yesterday competitions for more than 1,000 scholarships for graduate study abroad.

A spokesman for the Algerian Front of National Liberation said yesterday that the Algerian rebels would negotiate for peace only with a French Government that had "real authority" and was willing to accept the fact that Algeria must become independent.

"Aye, laddie, it were a braw game." That was a Scotsman's opinion of the soccer game played between Hearts of Midlothian, Scottish First Division champion, and Manchester City of the English First Division at Ebbets Field yesterday. The Hearts rallied for a 6-5 victory.

MORRISTOWN, N. J., May 25 -- Electronics won a decisive victory over the weather here today. Forty-three model aircraft enthusiasts from eastern states sent their planes through maneuvers despite rain, a ceiling at times below 200 feet and visibility of less than 800 feet.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., May 25 -- Undaunted by driving rain, low - hanging fog and winds that varied from eight knots to nothing, Peter R. Smyth's Nepenthe, an S Class boat, today was one of two official finishers in the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound racing.
BELGRADE, May 25 -- President Tito received an unexpected birthday present from Moscow today. It resembled an olive branch.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 25 -- The Screen Actors Guild proposed today that George Meany, president of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations, arbitrate its jurisdictional dispute with the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists over actors in television commercials made on magnetic video tape.
WASHINGTON, May 25 -- The United States has proposed to the Soviet Union a mutual relaxation of travel restrictions.
ATLANTIC CITY, May 25 -- A food industry leader said today that the American housewife by budget shopping can feed her family well at a cheaper cost than a year ago.
LONDON, May 25 -- Thursday's reduction in the bank rate from 6 to 5 1/2 per cent helped the stock markets a bit. But on the whole business was quiet.

NO one writes an autobiography unless he is cursed with a little more than his share of original egoism. Unless his only motive is exhibitionism he must believe that he has something to say that will interest perfect strangers. He must think that his life has some significance more than the ordinary and that his opinions are worth hearing.

For more than thirty-seven years the American Merchant Marine Library Association has been providing seagoing library service to the crews of American flag vessels. During those years the familiar "Public Library of the High Seas" has maintained a mobile policy. Indicative of that mobility, the association now undertakes periodic exchanges of library units with the Distant Early Warning fleets in Arctic waters.

The Massachusetts Mutual Life Insurance Company has made a mortgage commitment for $1,500,000 on a fourteen-story apartment house to be erected at the southwest corner of First Avenue and Fifty-second Street.
LARCHMONT, N. Y., May 25 -- "It's nice to win with a fat family cruising boat," Fred W. P. Lorenzen said at the Larchmont Yacht Club's awards breakfast this morning.
A Protestant churchman said yesterday that "persons of Protestant background and faith should not be deprived of accepting medical therapeutic information," including birth control prescriptions.

YESTERDAY, for the second time in his career, Admiral Philippe-Marie Auboyneau has offered his services to Gen. Charles de Gaulle in a moment of crisis. On the first occasion he was 41 years old and a commander; now he is 59 and one of the three admirals in the French Navy.
PARIS, May 25 -- The French Government struggled today to prevent Gen. Charles de Gaulle's return to power on a tide of insurrection in Algeria and Corsica and international combat in Tunisia.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 25 -- The president of the Pennsylvania State Bankers Association said today "there is conclusive evidence to be seen everywhere that our current recession is temporary and that our recovery will be rapid."

The Sun Oil Company announced over the week-end that it would challenge the finding of a Federal Trade Commission examiner holding the company guilty of violating the Clayton Act and the Federal Trade Commission Act.

There are twelve agencies affiliated with the Greater New York Fund that have their principal office in Richmond County. Ten more have branches that serve other boroughs as well as Richmond, six more that serve the borough specifically and an additional 268 serve the residents of Richmond on a city-wide basis.
New York University has announced plans to construct a $2,000,000 engineering and technology building on its University Heights campus in the Bronx.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 25 -- When a new industry triggers a series of subsidiary enterprises, the "chain reaction" in the economic field is as effective as in the nuclear sphere. The Technical Assistance Administration of the United Nations can report success in the process it started some years ago with investments in plants handling medical materials in under-developed countries.
NESHANIC STATION, N. J., May 25 -- A branch of Koinonia, the prayerful little band of farmers and craftsmen who settled in the Sourland Mountains here a year ago, has failed and all but moved away.

Left-wingers are moving ahead with plans for a state ticket in this year's election. This would pull together elements of the defunct American Labor party and the continuing Socialist Workers party, a Trotskyite group.

We have no doubt that somewhere along the line, perhaps sooner, perhaps later, the Wagner administration will reject the Greyhound Corporation's application to build a new bus terminal of enlarged capacity on the site of its present operations east of Eighth Avenue at Thirty-fourth Street.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 25 -- Otto Preminger, independent producer-director, has formed a new association with United Artists to film "Exodus," a recently completed novel by Leon Uris about the founding of the State of Israel ten years ago. The book is to be published in September by Doubleday.

MANILA, May 25 (AP) -- The Indonesian rebel movement has announced the formation of a new "caretaker Cabinet," with Col. Joop Warouw as acting Premier. Last night's news broadcast reporting this development came from the North Celebes rebel capital of Menado.

CUSTOM designers, who have been called the "lonely aristocrats of the fashion world," are more frequently seeking new horizons. Perhaps many of these couturiers who are now creating styles for mass production long for the old days.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., May 25 -- A baccalaureate address was delivered here without incident tonight before Central High School's first racially integrated graduating class.
WASHINGTON, May 25 -- The Administration has decided to give serious consideration to the "Monroney plan" for establishing a second World Bank to make easy-term loans to underdeveloped nations.

CARACAS, Venezuela, May 25 -- Pablo Casals said here today that the recent attack on Vice President Richard M. Nixon by rioters in Caracas was "lamentable." The 81-year-old cellist said he had delayed his own visit here because his arrival immediately after Mr. Nixon's would have caused confusion.
PARIS, May 25 -- Official statistics on commercial exchanges between France and Germany in 1957 show an increase in France's deficit.

A French picnic on June 3 at the summer home of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Flamm in Closter, N. J., will benefit the Fountain House Foundation. This event will differ from the American variety in that the guests will partake of chicken prepared in the Gallic manner and vintage wines instead of hot dogs and soda pop.
NORFOLK, Va., May 25 (AP) -- Chopin's Funeral March will be played tomorrow at a rendezvous in the Atlantic of three unknown American fighting men who died in their country's last two wars.

Since Friday afternoon more than 1,200 bridge players have been trying to win assorted trophies and master points in the thirtieth annual Eastern States Regional bridge championships at the Park-Sheraton Hotel.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- Key Congressional Democrats and the Secretary of the Treasury have informally agreed that a general tax cut should be ruled out at least for the present and probably for the rest of this year.
PARIS, Monday, May 26 (AP) -- Diplomatic informants said early today that France had agreed to regroup her Tunisian-based troops in the Bizerte area in line with demands by President Bourguiba.

Memorial Day is traditionally the time of the opening of the grass courts for play at the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills, Queens. The season then is officially on. On hand Friday for the forty-fifth anniversary opening of the green, lush lawns will be the man who has greeted the club members and taught most of them since West Side first opened its doors on Long Island.
STUTTGART, Germany, May 25 -- Two hundred thousand Sudeten Germans met here this week-end to reaffirm their solidarity and hear their leaders promise an eventual return to their homeland.

On May 21 The Times published on its first page a sketch of the proposed Motel City to be built over the New York Central tracks on the West Side. It is unquestionably the most unimaginative monstrosity to be foisted on the city in a long time.

AJACCIO, Corsica, May 25 -- Corsicans marched in the streets of their capital today singing the Marseillaise and shouting "Vive de Gaulle!" Their island government was in the hands of a Committee of Public Safety like the one ruling in Algeria.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 25 -- Lebanese armed forces launched drives against rebel troops on three fronts today.
PHILADELPHIA, May 25 -- With band, bus and banners, William Gruen, a frustrated Manhattan press agent, led a troupe of Brooklyn baseball fans into town today, but everything went wrong.

WASHINGTON, May 25 (AP) -- David Sarnoff envisioned today the possibility that compact electronic devices might be developed some day to replace body organs that have become defective through injury or age.
The isolation of a hormone from the mysterious pineal gland, once thought by philosophers to be the "seat of the soul," is reported today in the Journal of the American Chemical Society.
National Securities and Research Corporation reported over the week-end new highs in assets, shareowners and shares in fiscal 1958 for the seven funds sponsored and managed by the company.

An old Roy Campanella fan is arranging a new job in the sports world for the Dodger catcher, hospitalized since Jan. 28 when an automobile accident broke two vertebrae in his neck.
A new committee has been set up to speed the city's off-street parking program -- a project that has attracted many sidewalk superintendents and not infrequently a chorus of dissent.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., May 25 -- Kathy Whiteside and Mari Frank, White Plains High School students from Hartsdale, and Sandye Berger of Scarsdale, were the chief winners today at the Harrison Junior Saddle Seat Horse Show.

This is the season of the year when King Cotton is ubiquitous. In the southern and southwestern portions of our country, known to all as the Cotton Belt, thousands of farm hands are tenderly implanting the seeds of the coming crop into the soil.
A sharp rise in juvenile delinquency was reported in official police figures for 1957.
Cardinal Spellman advised eighteen mission-bound members of the Society of Jesus yesterday to pattern their lives after "Cardinal Stritch, who has done so much for the church."

New York University will graduate 5,800 students on June 4. Among them will be Sidney Becker, a 40-year-old traffic patrolman, who has been elected to Phi Beta Kappa, national scholastic honorary society.
WARSAW, May 25 -- The communique of the Warsaw Pact conference held in Moscow Saturday will renew a Soviet proposal for a nonaggression treaty with the Atlantic alliance.

PIETRO F. MIGONE, Italy's Commercial Consul here, is a Genoese who, like most people of that city, has unshakable pride in its cuisine. A dapper, intelligent man with lively brown eyes and a trim mustache, he speaks of food with authority. Eating well is one of his pleasures; cooking well a favored diversion.

Mrs. Helen Pritchard and Don Dacosta, both of Toronto, led a field of 182 bridge pairs yesterday after the first session of the two-session Mixed Pair Championship. The event was part of the twelve-day Eastern States tournament, conducted at the Park Sheraton Hotel by the Greater New York Bridge Association.

The French National Assembly meets in emergency session today in an effort to control the swift tide of events that is now engulfing France and is beginning to affect France's relations with other nations and the North Atlantic alliance.

LINDEN, N. J., May 25 -- Mrs. Joseph Barnes' 4 1/2-year-old Sealyham terrier, Ch. High Orchard Pearmain, of Westfield, N. J., was best of a soggy collection of dogs in the show of the Plainfield Kennel Club today. It poured when it didn't merely drizzle to uphold the club's distinction for bad weather on its show dates.

HARRISON, N. Y., May 25 -- Experimental programs in reading and foreign languages and a greatly expanded science seminar for abler students were announced today by Louis M. Klein, superintendent of schools.
LOS ANGELES, May 25 -- Five supporters of the Cuban rebel leader Fidel Castro were arrested here last night for manufacturing machine guns in a garage in a quiet residential area.

WASHINGTON, May 25 (UPI) -- The Government plans to establish five air lanes across the country in which all planes would operate under instrument flight rules to cut the risk of collisions, it was disclosed today.
PHILADELPHIA, May 25 -- The official Dodger explanation of the club's disastrous start is a cliche: There's nothing the matter with the one-time Brooklyn heroes that timely hitting won't cure.

BEIRUT, May 25 -- At least three persons were killed today in fighting between security forces and rioters in Saida, the ancient Phoenician city of Sidon in southern Lebanon. Seventeen persons were reported wounded.
TUNIS, May 25 -- French Air Force planes, operating out of Algeria, bombed and strafed Tunisian forces battling French troops in southeastern Tunisia today.

Rate wars or other stiffer competition among international carriers will not result from a United States Supreme Court decision last Monday against a dual-rate system, steamship conference spokesmen predicted over the weekend.

ASHEVILLE, N. C., May 25 (UPI) -- Mrs. Marlene Bauer Hagge rallied from four strokes behind today to catch the pacesetter, Jo Ann Prentice, to force a sudden-death play-off. Mrs. Hagge sank a six-foot, birdie-3 putt on the first extra hole to win the $5,000 Land of the Sky women's open golf tournament.
The labor relations of the A. P. food store chain in the metropolitan district, already under fire by Senate rackets investigators, were enveloped in a fresh enigma yesterday.

Industrial Enterprises, Inc., is diversifying its operations further through the acquisition of the Pennant Corporation, its first consumer products line, Walter E. Bronston, president of Industrial, announced over the week-end.

The Minneapolis-Moline Company had net income of $816,136 in the quarter ended April 30. Net sales were $15,571,505. In the corresponding three months of last year the tractor and farm equipment manufacturer cleared $803,836 on sales of $17,005,911.
KIEV, U. S. S. R., Monday, May 26 (UPI) -- Leopold Stokowski and the Philadelphia Orchestra met for the first time in seventeen years today in this Ukrainian city.
A new musical comedy called "Jump for Joy," possibly with Eddie Foy in a principal role, is being planned for Broadway production late next season.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, May 25 -- Benny Goodman, his clarinet and a group of superb musicians shook the United States world fair cultural effort out of the doldrums tonight with a rousing jazz concert at the American pavilion theatre.
TOKYO, May 25 (AP) -- Japan took two gold medals while Ceylon, the Philippines and Nationalist China gained one each today in the opening track and field competition in the Third Asian Games.
Generalissimo Chiang Kaishek declared yesterday that Hungarian-type uprisings had been going on "continuously" for the last two years in remote parts of Communist China.
With the advent of the European Common Market, an Italian school teaching American management methods is turning out to be more than a successful experiment.

PARIS, May 25 (AP) -- Robert Haillet of France eliminated Budge Patty of Los Angeles and Paris from the French international tennis championships in the fourth round today and virtually ended American hopes of taking one of the titles.
The World War I complaint, "How Ya Gonna Keep 'Em Down on the Farm After They've Seen Paree?" has a modern counterpart in New York's suburbia.
WITNEY, England, May 25 -- Two hundred and six persons arrived here tonight more than midway through a protest march from Oxford to the United States air base at Brize Norton, Oxfordshire.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon endorsed Senator William F. Knowland today for the Governorship of California and predicted that the Senator would lead his state's Republican ticket to a "smashing victory" in November.
Events tonight: Van Cliburn, pianist, Symphony of the Air, conducted by Kirill P. Kondrashin, Carnegie Hall; Elena Valdi, soprano-guitarist, Mannes College of Music, both at 8:30.
WASHINGTON, May 25 -- A little-noticed bill that experts believe could have drastic effects on the economic system seems likely to pass at least the House of Representatives in this session.

MAY is traditionally the month for the mass movement of moths and carpet beetles into homes across the nation. Homemakers in defense of their domiciles indicate, in the sizable number of inquiries reaching this department every year, bafflement over the products to use and the methods of application.
WASHINGTON, May 25 -- Secretary of State Dulles is concentrating during the French crisis on maintaining his freedom of action to deal with any government that may come to power in Paris.
Army investigators yesterday found two leads that may prove significant in determining the cause of last Thursday's Nike explosion near Middletown, N. J.
The Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts announced yesterday that the James Foundation of New York had donated $250,000 toward its goal of $75,000,000.
Dorothy Bullock, pianist from Tennessee who made her New York debut a year ago this month, gave her second Town Hall recital late yesterday afternoon.
The Port of New York Authority has embarked upon an aggressive program to increase the volume of grain handled in the port.
Pentecost was observed yesterday in the city's Protestant churches. The holy day, also called Whitsunday, marks the descent of the Holy Spirit upon the Apostles.
LOS ANGELES, May 26 -- The University of Southern California today named as its seventh president Dr. Norman H. Topping, vice president of medical affairs at the University of Pennsylvania.
GROTON, Conn., May 26 -- Two atomic submarines, the Skate and the Sea Wolf, have set records' for continuous submerged operations.

BISKRA, Algeria, May 26 -- In this once-famous tourist town on the fringe of the Sahara it was possible to gain further proof today of the response of the Moslem population to the Algerian insurrection.

The first Alaska statehood bill was introduced in Congress more than forty years ago, and the question has been under active consideration in one or both houses many times during the past decade. Both parties have endorsed statehood in their platforms, and the House even passed an Alaska bill in 1950.

CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, May 26 (UPI) -- Juan D. Peron, former Argentine dictator, said today he was not opposed to the new Argentine amnesty law for Peronists, but to the magistrates who would administer it.
PANAMA, May 26 -- Friends of students, occupying the National University have appealed to the Canal Zone Red Cross to assist in sending food into the university grounds.
First-quarter revenues and earnings of the Hilton Hotels Corporation dipped slightly, Conrad H. Hilton, president, reported yesterday.

PARIS, May 26 -- Among the topics for debate and conjecture here are the validity and importance of what has been called the "miracle" of French-Moslem reconciliation set on foot since the May 13 uprising in Algiers.
ABOARD THE U. S. S. CANBERRA, Off Cape Henry, Va., May 26 -- An unknown American service man was selected today to represent all Americans who lost their lives in World War II.
The scandal-stained International Brotherhood of Teamsters demonstrated again yesterday that it never had so many friends inside the labor federation as it had after it was cast out.
Sugar, cocoa, wool and copper were strong in active trading yesterday on the New York exchanges. Other commodities were featureless in dull trading.
CHICAGO, May 26 (AP) -- Midwestern railroads reduced their Lake cargo rates 30 cents a ton on coal shipments from western Kentucky and Southern Illinois mines to Chicago today.
A couple of Broadway prospects are vying with each other for Jose Ferrer's attention. They are Felicien Marceau's "L'Oeuf" ("The Egg") and Sam Spewack's "Under the Sycamore Tree."
The General Foods Corporation set new records in earnings, sales and physical volume of products sold in the fiscal year ended March 31, Charles G. Mortimer, president, reported yesterday.

A drug manufacturer announced yesterday that it would halt the production of Salk polio vaccine after June 1. Public apathy to the use of the vaccine and large supplies on hand led to the decision, a spokesman for the manufacturer said.

Lord Nelson, whose birth 200 years ago is observed this year, is one of that small group of heroes in whom interest never wanes. A new biography of him called "Victory," by Oliver Warner, will be published June 16 by Atlantic-Little, Brown.
WASHINGTON, May 26 -- The Supreme Court reaffirmed today the right of Negroes to serve on grand juries, ride on unsegregated buses and attend integrated public schools.

VALLETTA, Malta, May 26 -- General Norstad said here tonight he had been advised of an order recalling French warships from Malta yesterday after he had departed from his Paris headquarters for Malta.

TUNIS, May 26 -- President Habib Bourguiba said tonight he had asked the United States and Britain to intervene directly with the French Government to ease the explosive situation between France and Tunisia.
WASHINGTON, May 26 (AP) -- The Department of Justice announced today it was appealing a local district court's dismissal of its efforts to reduce the dividend rates of three large pipeline companies.

Motorists traveling through their city and its environs often find themselves suddenly aware of new chain stores springing up in large numbers. Few of them know about the intricate real estate dealings that precede the opening of such chain establishments.
RABAT, Morocco, May 26 -- The Moroccan Government insisted today on the "absolute necessity" of the immediate withdrawal of French troops from the eastern part of the country bordering Algeria.
LOS ANGELES, May 26 -- Chess has its fifty-games-at-once wizards, but Walter F. O'Malley may well go down in history as the man who took on 2,000,000 people at once in a game of high-stakes poker.
Field Marshal Viscount Montgomery called last night for a public reaffirmation of the close ties between London and Washington.
ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., May 26 (AP) -- Pennsylvania should increase its efforts to attract new industries, a Pittsburgh manufacturer declared today.

AJACCIO, Corsica, May 26 -A delegation from the Algerian Committee of Public Safety extended the fraternal greetings of Gen. Raoul Salan, French Commander in Chief in Algeria, to rebellious Corsicans today.

In your issue of May 9 I found an announcement that seemed to me highly significant. The event there recorded was the establishment by the Jewish Theological Seminary of America of the Herbert H. Lehman Institute of Ethics.
ALTHOUGH Thomas Dooley cannot play Bach as well as Albert Schweitzer, he shares with that illustrious humanitarian a dedication to the establishment of harmony in the unquiet spirit of man.

PHILADELPHIA, May 26 -- Brooklyn, so far as baseball is concerned, is a ghost town. It is also a town where today a Kings County judge adjourned a murder trial so he could get here to see a "live" baseball game tonight.

NEW ROCHELLE; N. Y., May 26 -- Congressional acceptance of the Senate-Foreign Relations Committee's $3,700,000,000 mutual security program would be "a turning point in our slump in national morale," Senator Jacob K. Javits said today.

John Foster Dulles will attend graduation exercises tonight at Union Theological Seminary, where he will see his daughter Lillias receive her Bachelor of Divinity degree. She is Mrs. Robert Hinshaw, the second of the Dulles' three children to study theology.
WASHINGTON, May 26 (AP) -- The Senate today passed a bill suspending for another year import duties on major types of metal scrap including iron, steel, aluminum, magnesium and nickel.

The graduate of a liberal arts women's college often finds she needs a fast secretarial-typing course as a job clincher. Nov Vassar College offers some of its mathematically inclined students a new job getter - undergraduate training in the use of electronic computers.
ROME, Tuesday, May 27 -Samuel Alphonsus Cardinal Stritch died here at 1:35 A. M. today. The Roman Catholic Archbishop of Chicago was 70 years old.

WASHINGTON, May 26 (UPI) -- The Senate passed a bill today to speed and tighten administrative procedures of the anti-dumping act, which is designed to protect United States producers from "unfair" foreign competition.
NICOSIA, Cyprus, May 26 -- Another Greek Cypriote was slain today as Left-Wing workers began an island-wide strike and demonstrations to protest the killing of their members by Right-Wing fanatics.

The Texas Pacific Coal and Oil Company has acquired, in exchange for 275,400 of its shares, the assets of the Rowan Oil Company, H. B. Fuqua, chairman and president of Texas Pacific announced yesterday.

CHICAGO, May 26 (AP) -- Continued dry weather over large areas of the northern Great Plains and western Canada brought out aggressive buying of wheat futures on the Board of Trade today. Prices advanced well over 2 cents a bushel on all contracts.
ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., May 26 (AP) -- Secretary of Agriculture Ezra Taft Benson said today food prices had reached their peak and that a decline in some areas could be expected shortly.
ITHACA, N, Y., May 26 (UPI) -- Cornell students planning a campus sitdown strike wore black armbands today protesting the suspension of four upperclassmen.
WASHINGTON, May 26 (AP) -- Senator John L. McClellan denounced in the Senate today an opinion by the Federal Court of Appeals challenging the powers of his Senate investigating subcommittee.
WEST POINT, N. Y., May 26 -- Continuing a tradition begun in 1914 under John McGraw, the San Francisco Giants returned to the Military Academy today for their twenty-first game with Army.

VAN CLIBURN, the Texas winner of the Moscow Tchaikovsky Piano Competition, gave New Yorkers their second chance to hear him in Carnegie Hall last night in his prize-winning interpretations of the Tchaikovsky First and Rachmaninoff Third Concertos.
KANSAS CITY, May 26 -- Are the Yankees insuperably strong, or is the rest of the American league incredibly weak?

PHILADELPHIA, May 26 -- Unlike the modern ballplayers whose interests are so diverse that he discusses a variety of subjects, Charlie Dressen talks baseball around the clock. The enthusiastic little coach of the Dodgers had plenty of conversational room over the past couple of days, with a rainout and a night game giving him a matchless opportunity to make with the words.

LOS ANGELES, May 26 -- A rebel faction in Los Angeles Musicians Local 47 swept to a convincing victory today over the administration forces of president Eliot Daniel at a membership meeting. The meeting instructed delegates to the American Federation of Musicians convention next week in Philadelphia.

Dr. Harry D. Gideonse, president of Brooklyn College, indicated yesterday his disapproval of a nomination made by members of the English department of a new department chairman. The present chairman is Dr. George A. Peck.
The Long Island Rail Road, which increased its commutation fares an average 5.9 per cent on April 8, finished last month in the black.
Davy Crockett Lake, in the lush green hills of northeastern Tennessee, is the scene of a mica-mining venture unlike any other known to the industry.

The Metropolitan Educational Television Association, which had faced a halt in program production because of a lack of funds, announced yesterday it had made arrangements to continue operating through the summer.
WASHINGTON, May 26 -- Alaska's forty-two-year effort to attain statehood is due again for voting tests in the House of Representatives, beginning tomorrow. A final decision is likely Wednesday.

Organized New York physicians were called upon last night to develop "a peaceable and working relationship" with insurance plans, union funds, industrial clinics, hospitals and schools in the health field.
CORPUS CHRISTI, Tex., May 26 (AP) -- A Navy Douglas F4D-1 Skyray supersonic fighter has set five official world records for climbing speed, the Navy announced today.

A two-day blood donation to the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program will be started today at 195 Broadway by employes of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and the Western Electric Company, Inc.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., May 26 -- The case of a white senior accused of spitting on a Negro girl at Central High School baccalaureate exercises last night was postponed today until June 12.
The city's fleet of excursion boats and sight-seeing craft is building up steam for another summer season.

Brooklyn-born Joe Quigg, a 21-year-old, 6-foot 8-inch player, became the first of the New York Knickerbockers' 1958 draftees to be signed by the National Basketball Association team yesterday. Quigg lives in Levittown on Long Island.

As a past president of the Parents Association of P. S. 165, Manhattan (109th Street and Broadway), it was heartening indeed to read in The Times of May 21 that the Board of Education hopes to begin construction next year of a new high school in the Lincoln Square area.
SYRACUSE, May 26 -- When is a professional not a professional? Or put in another way, is anyone more professional than someone else ?
Industrialists, merchants and consumers in Ridgefield, N. J., are opening a plan to combat the recession. They hope the idea will spread to other communities.

TOKYO, May 26 (AP) -- Japan moved far ahead of nineteen other competitors today in third Asian Games. The team won six gold medals, three silver and two bronze in thirteen events in the second day of competition.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- Governor Collins of Florida, though the complexity of the problem of effecting racial school integration in his state was reflected by an ambiguity and an inconsistency in his statements during a television interview yesterday, made the following reasonably clear:

ALAMEDA, Calif., May 26 (UPI) -- All jet planes based at the Alameda and Moffett Field naval air stations were grounded today by Rear Admiral Murr E. Arnold as the result of confusion over new Federal flight regulations.
The anti-recession campaign of the Advertising Council has received space and time contributions worth $10,000,000. The total is expected to reach $25,000,000 when the drive ends in August.
WASHINGTON, May 26 -- The United States will launch a satellite later this year to explore the nature and intensity of a newly discovered layer of powerful radiation in space.

Police Commissioner Kennedy sums up his annual report for 1957 with this comment addressed to the Mayor: "With the major and distressing exception of youth crime, it appears that the post-war trend toward higher crime rates has been slowed.
WASHINGTON, May 26 -- The Senate Interstate and Foreign Commerce Committee approved today a bill to grant up to $1,000,000 to each state to construct educational television facilities.

ALGIERS, May 26 -- Four French warships, including the aircraft carrier La Fayette, have entered Algerian ports and their officers will obey the orders of Admiral Philippe-Marie Auboyneau, it was announced here tonight.

WESTBURY, L. I., May 26 -- This was "the big night" for Istvan Inokai, the Hungarian reinsman with the name that seems to be a typographical error. The 46-year-old Inokai drove in his first American betting race.
MOSCOW, Tuesday, May 27 -The Soviet Union and its seven East European allies in the Warsaw Pact have decided that all Soviet troops will be withdrawn from Rumania "in the nearest future."
Mrs. Lawrence W. Smith found herself the object of attention yesterday because she had set off a hand siren Sunday night near Governor Harriman's town house at 16 East Eighty-first Street.

Some horseshoers follow the sun (in late model cars with Florida license plates), wear their age well and are given to silence. Other horseshoers stay put, also wear their age well and are garrulous about their trade.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), May 26 -- Lieut. Col. George A. Flint, Canadian officer serving as chairman of the Israeli-Jordanian Mixed Armistice Commission, was killed today during an exchange of fire by Jordanian soldiers and Israeli policemen on Mount Scopus.

An interesting idea in the paper of this morning, said the gentleman on the train as he took his usual seat. What he referred to was a story in which Dr. Paul Wilcox of Traverse City, Mich., was quoted as suggesting a wide-scale study of man.
A man who was about twelve feet away but survived last Thursday's fatal Nike explosion in New Jersey told his story to Army investigators yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 26 -The Senate Commerce Committee today endorsed an eleven-point program, including Federally guaranteed loans of as much as $700,000,000, to aid America's ailing railroad industry.

The nation's steel - making operations last week were at the second-highest level so far this year, topped only by those in the third week of January. An output was scheduled to be maintained at that level this week despite the Memorial Day holiday.
ZANDVOORT, the Netherlands, May 26 -- Stirling Moss' big green Vanwall, leading from start to finish, easily won the Dutch Grand Prix today.

EARL LOUIS BROWN, who entered the ring yesterday against Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr., is a spunky challenger originally from Charlottesville, Va., wearing Tammany trunks and weighing 168 pounds.
JUNE brides who are traditionalists and plan to serve champagne at their weddings are fortunate. The '53 vintage, an exceptionally good year, is just now appearing on the market.
Former President Harry S. Truman and Mrs. Truman sailed for the Mediterranean yesterday aboard the American Export Liner Independence.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- The bill rate dropped sharply again this week to the lowest point since June 24, 1954, the Treasury, announced tonight. The average interest rate on $1,800,000,000 of ninety-one-day discount bills was 0.635 per cent, compared with last week's 0.931 per cent and 0.634 per cent on the 1954 date.

Councilman Earl L. Brown was designated officially yesterday by the Tammany district leaders in Harlem to oppose Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr. for the Democratic Congressional nomination in the Sixteenth District.
MILWAUKEE, May 26 (AP) -- A three-run homer by Frank Torre and a tie-breaking homer by Eddie Mathews propelled the Milwaukee Braves to a 4 -- 3 victory over the Chicago Cubs tonight.
WASHINGTON, May 26 -- The United States faced the problem today of what to do to halt French-Tunisian fighting in Tunisia and to stave off a collision in the Security Council.

PHILADELPHIA, May 26 (AP) -- The Philadelphia Eagles today acquired Norman Van Brocklin, the quarterback of the Los Angeles Rams, for two first-string players and their No. 1 choice in next year's National Football League player draft.
Never have so many reasonable people been so unnecessarily mystified as they appear to be over General de Gaulle. His record is clear.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 26 -- Tunisia plans to discuss her dispute with France tomorrow in a series of private consultations with Security Council delegates.
Reproductions of famous paintings will be sandwiched between advertising posters on subway stations next week.
BOSTON, May 26 -- The Channel 5 case is another chapter in a struggle for newspaper survival in Boston.

WASHINGTON, May 26 (AP) -- The amount of new corporate securities offered in the first three months of this year was close to last year's first quarter record, the Securities and Exchange Commission said today.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 26 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold declared today that a "radical change" of attitudes was needed to restore peace in the Middle East.
There was everything from adhesives to wrapping paper at the National Packaging Exposition, which opened yesterday in the New York Coliseum. But plastics stole the show.

PARIS, May 26 (UPI) -- Belgium's Jackie Brichant upset second-seeded Neal Fraser of Australia today, 5 -- 7, 5 -- 7, 7 -- 5. 6 -- 0, 6 -- 3, to gain a berth in the singles semi-finals in the French international tennis championships.
Pennsylvania's favored varsity and junior varsity eights yesterday drew outside lanes for the fifty-sixth championship regatta of the Intercollegiate Rowing Association.

Francis Cardinal Spellman issued last night a statement expressing his deep grief on the death of Samuel Alphonsus Cardinal Stritch. He said that Cardinal Stritch "has given a pattern of living and a design for dying to all of us and in a brief time he proved to be a model missionary."
The measles epidemic that has affected more than 22,000 New Yorkers since January is now on the decline, Dr. Morris Greenberg of the Health Department reported yesterday.
The curtain went up yesterday on a new effort to save the High School of Performing Arts.

TRENTON, May 26 -- David Dickson Furman was named Attorney General of New Jersey today by Gov. Robert B. Meyner. It appeared tonight that the appointment would be rapidly confirmed by the Republican-controlled State Senate.
DEVON, Pa., May 26 -- First Chance, a chestnut mare from Oak Ridge Farm, Pittsford, N. Y. captured the open jumper sweepstake at the sixty-second annual Devon Horse show tonight.
TODDLERS cuddled up to a Brontosaurus last week when Steiff, makers of stuffed toys, previewed its latest venture: the taming of the prehistoric beast.

H. Lloyd Jones of Bronxville, I recently elected Grand Master of the State Grand Lodge of Masons, announced yesterday the appointment of his staff for the year. It includes twenty-two district deputy grand masters for the metropolitan area, which has 452 Masonic lodges with a membership of more than 150,000.

A stronger case can be made for the belief that the recession is at or near its end than at any time since it began, Martin R. Gainsbrugh, chief economist, National Industrial Conference Board, declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- In the Supreme Court of the United States, Meyer Groug, Harold Manheim, Robert Braunschweig, J. Edward Davey Jr., Stuart Sprague, Isidore Scheinman, Paul Morton, and Alex J. Soled, all of New York, N. Y., among others, were admitted to practice today and the following proceedings were had:

A VACATION home that can be folded up and put away for the winter stole the Vinyl Fabrics Institute show last week. The exhibit was held in the photography studio of Hans Van Nes at 431 East Ninetieth Street. It was not open to the public.

DUNBARTON, N. H., May 26 -- Nothing makes the modern hunter, who follows the trail of Natty Bumppo in an air-conditioned station wagon, feel so much like Natty Bumppo as shooting a muzzle-loading rifle. To kill a deer with one is a little better than to be President.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -The Supreme Court held today that an employe kept out of a plant by the threats of striking union members might sue the union for damages in the state courts instead of going to the National Labor Relations Board for relief.

On the "full cost" accounting basis required by the Interstate Commerce Commission, the nation's railroad experienced a record $723,500,000 loss last year in providing passenger services. Prior to 1957, the greatest deficit year for passenger operations was 1953, when the figure was $704,500,000. The loss in 1956 was $696,900,000.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange fell 9 to 20 points (45 cents to $1 a bale) yesterday.
INDIANAPOLIS, May 26 (AP) -- Progressive party candidates led their opponents by widening margins in the International Typographical Union election today with 603 of the some 800 locals reporting.
CARACAS, Venezuela, May 26 -- The entire Cabinet presented its resignation to the governing junta today. A new Cabinet will be named Wednesday.

WASHINGTON, May 26 (UPI) -- President Eisenhower today named Admiral Harry D. Felt, naval airman and vice chief of naval operations, to succeed Admiral Felix B. Stump as Commander in Chief of United States forces in the Pacific and Far East.

CHICAGO, May 26 -- An Administrator for the affairs of the Chicago Archdiocese of the Roman Catholic Church is expected to be selected here within the next twenty-four hours, high church officials said tonight.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 26 -- Louis A. Novins, president of the International Telemeter Corporation, today reaffirmed the company's plans to have three experimental pay-television operations under way early next year.
OTTAWA, May 26 -- Canada's powerful atomic research reactor, known as N. R. U. has been shut down following an accident, it was announced today.
The removal of the Women's House of Detention from Greenwich Village was urged last night By Edgar T. Hussey, president of the West Side Savings Bank.

Committees and several chairmen of former years will meet today in the home of Mrs. Francis B. Thorne Jr. of 39 East Seventy-ninth Street, a vice chairman for the tenth annual "La Fete des Roses" ball. They will advance plans for the event to be held on Oct. 16 at the Plaza.

WHEN all the American artists, or almost all, painted barns, city streets and studio interiors there was naturally a broad level at which one barn or studio looked dismally like the next. Few are the painters whose genre scenes of yesterday can be held up to the critical light of today.

COLOMBEY - LES - DEUX - EGLISES. France, May 26 -- The sudden departure of Gen. Charles de Gaulle hardly caused a ripple in this village today among his 350 fellow citizens, but it created pandemonium among watching newspapermen.

Rail stocks rolled ahead yesterday as the Senate Commerce Committee approved a plan to aid the carriers, but the rest of the list found going uninspiring on the New York Stock Exchange. The close was irregular, either a little higher or a little lower, according to the index used.
WASHINGTON, May 26 (UPI) -- President Eisenhower plans to return to Gettysburg, Pa., Friday for another week-end at his farm, the White House said today.
WASHINGTON, May 26 (UPI) -- The United States staged the fourth nuclear test of its current series at the Eniwetok atoll proving grounds last night, the Government disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, May 26 (AP) -- The New York, Chicago St. Louis (Nickel Plate) Railroad said today it was still unhappy about the Delaware Lackawanna and Western Railroad's holdings of Nickel Plate stock in view of current discussions of a merger by the Lackawanna.

A moonlight cruise on the Hudson on June 20 will benefit the school of the George Junior Republic. For the tenth consecutive year the Foreign Commerce Club Of New York, whose members are executives in various maritime companies, will sponsor the event.
WASHINGTON, May 26 -Orders depriving two naturalized Americans of their citizenship because of Communist party membership were set aside by the Supreme Court today.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -Justice Department officials conferred separately today with representatives of the two news agencies -- The United Press and International News Service -that were merged last week as United Press International. No decision was reached on the legality of the merger.
WASHINGTON, May 26 -- The Supreme Court agreed today to reconsider next fall the question whether a person acquitted by a Federal jury could thereafter be tried for the same crime in a state court.
