The Police Department will make extra efforts to protect pedestrians and motorists over the Memorial Day week-end from 4 P. M. Thursday through Monday midnight.

COLD SPRING HARBOR, L. I., May 26 -- The complex process that impels migratory birds to their northern breeding grounds at the right time each spring is triggered by the pattern of day and night of the previous fall, a biologist said here today.
LOS ANGELES, May 26 (UPI) -- The Dodgers will remain in Los Angeles if Walter F. O'Malley, the club president, has anything to say about it.
WASHINGTON, May 26 -- The Supreme Court took the following actions today:
WASHINGTON, May 26 -President Eisenhower asked Congress today to maintain corporation income taxes and excise levies at present levels beyond June 30.
SHIPPINGPORT, Pa., May 26 -- This country's first full-scale atomic power station devoted to peaceful commercial uses was dedicated by President Eisenhower today.

Through President Eisenhower the United States has now formally celebrated the opening of its first large-scale atomic power plant exclusively for peaceful purposes. It will be a pity if the atmosphere of acrimony which has surrounded the plans for the occasion obscures its significance.
WASHINGTON, May 26 -- Max Block, New York labor leader, ran the Butchers Union by telephone and drew $117,817 in salary and expenses in the last three years, the Senate rackets committee heard today.
MELBOURNE, Australia, May 26 -- The Australian - Japanese trade Agreement is operating effectively and is mutually advantageous, Trade Minister John McEwen said tonight.

A ruddy-faced, brawny youngster attired in the latest Ivy League fashions visited the city from Rye the other day to spend an afternoon listening to jazz at the Metropole and to decide whether Charlie Shavers' double-tonguing and virbratto were as "hot" as ever.

TRENTON, May 26 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner and legislative leaders agreed tonight on the state budget and proposed new taxes to balance it. Both the Republican-controlled State Senate and the Democratic-dominated Assembly immediately enacted the compromise program and sent it to Mr. Meyner.

KANSAS CITY, May 26 (UPI) -- Forty - one - year - old Murry Dickson won his own ball game today by driving the first pitch of the tenth inning over the left-field wall. The blow enabled the Kansas City Athletics to defeat the Baltimore Orioles, 5 to 4.

A justice of the Court of Domestic Relations yesterday threw a contradictory statistic at Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy's report of a 13.3 per cent increase in juvenile arrests last year. She reported an increase of 35 per cent in the dismissals of delinquency charges in Children's Court during the first half of 1957 over the like period in 1956.

District Attorney Frank S. Hogan threatened yesterday to subpoena Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa to obtain records needed in Mr. Hogan's inquiry into the city's scandal-ridden Bureau of Real Estate. At his office, Mr. Hogan asserted in an interview that the situation in the bureau was an example of "maladministration."
FATHER'S Day is June 15 and the great scurry to find him a gift has already begun.
The Northern Natural Gas Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday gains in operating revenues, net income and volume of gas sold for the three and twelve months ended March 31.

HACKENSACK, N. J., May 26 -- A man apparently defeated in the Teaneck election on May 13 was elected to the Township Council today by an absentee ballot. The victor is S. Bradford Menkes, an Associate Professor of Mechanical Engineering at City College, N. Y.
MINNEAPOLIS, May 26 -- Dag Hammarskjold, Secretary General of the United Nations, said tonight that the accomplishments of United Nations specialized agencies had been "modest."

LONDON, May 26 -- British concern about the French crisis has been heightened by the recent events in Tunisia. The British know that if the French Army and Air Force in Algeria take action against Tunisia, the crisis, no longer can be considered as an internal affair confined to France.

Few persons, perhaps, will regard as completely surprising the news from Washington that the Secretary of the Treasury and key Congressional Democrats -- who had agreed between them that neither would act unilaterally in the matter -- have decided that a general reduction of taxes should be ruled out, "at least for the present and probably for the rest of the year."

Play began last night in the contract-bridge team contest for the Curt Reisinger Trophy. The event is part of the thirtieth annual Eastern States Tournament, held this week at the Park Sheraton Hotel by the Greater New York Bridge Association. Forty teams were entered.
ROME, Tuesday, May 27 -The moderate pro-Western Center parties appear to have suffered a defeat in Italy's general elections, according to figures made public up to 3 A. M. today.

Otis Woodard scored his second straight victory over Eddie Andrews of Lowell, Mass., in the feature bout at St. Nicholas Arena last night. Referee Arthur Mercante stopped the scheduled ten-rounder at 2:41 of the fifth round.
Many prominent persons attended last night's performance of "Say, Darling" at the ANTA Theatre and later a supper party in the ballroom of the Sheraton-East, both benefits for Medico.

The City Housing Authority took the first official steps yesterday in a new approach to various social problems its three Commissioners inherited when they took office on May 1 from the old five-member agency.

There are outstanding thirteen issues of Treasury bills totaling more than $22.4 billion. A debt of this magnitude ought to be enough to go around, but evidently it is not. The money market has grown to such size that even all these billions can represent scarcity.

LIFE may be more leisurely in Spain than in this country, but the women there work harder on their wardrobes. Although virtually no ready-made clothes are available in Madrid, it is inexpensive and reasonably simple, even for American tourists, to recruit a dressmaker.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 26 -- The Lebanese Foreign Minister will not go to the United Nations Security Council's meeting tomorrow on Lebanon. He will wait until after the Arab League meets on the same question Saturday in Tripoli, Libya, a Government source said today.

Net railway operating income of the Southern Pacific Company fell $392,497 last month, to $3,883,589. However, "other income" of the road was $1,921,943, some $435,832 more than the 1957 month. Net income was $4,131,074, or $2,793 above the year-ago level.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, May 26 -- Indonesian rebel forces continued to hold Jailolo airfield on Halmahera Island, the Army Information Bureau said here tonight.

With the specter of civil war hovering over France the divergent forces which have plunged that distraught country into its present crisis are now being compelled by events to face up to the realities and to seek a showdown which should determine the destiny of the nation.
A Brooklyn personnel director last night became the biggest money winner on a single television quiz program.

Another round in the running fight over union representation of unlicensed seamen on vessels of new American shipping companies has begun between the National Maritime Union and the Seafarers International Union.
The special magic of Johann Sebastian Bach appeared yesterday to have made a contribution to medicine.
PARIS, Tuesday, May 27 -Gen. Charles de Gaulle arrived in Paris last night on a secret mission that might produce a climax in the two-week-old French crisis.
DETROIT, May 26 -- The Ford Motor Company does not plan to continue to check off union dues if it is forced to operate without a contract with the auto union next week.
Bold Ruler and Gallant Man will resume their rivalry Friday in the $50,000 Carter Handicap at Belmont Park.

PEIPING, May 26 (Reuters) -- A "technological and cultural revolution" was called for by a Communist leader in a speech published here today as Communist China launched its second five-year economic plan.
WASHINGTON, May 26 -- The Boston Herald-Traveler Corporation refused today to honor a subpoena issued by the House subcommittee investigating the Federal Communications Commission.

WASHINGTON, May 26 (AP) -- The Supreme Court refused today to review a decision that barred California from collecting from a Texas resident for the care of his mentally ill mother, who was committed to a California state hospital.
WASHINGTON, May 26 -- A troubled Supreme Court wrestled today with the problem of a 12-year-old girl whose divorced parents are contending for her custody.
NEW HYDE PARK, L. I., May 26 -- Leonard W. Hall of Oyster Bay received a pledge tonight of Nassau County's full support for the Republican nomination for Governor.
Mayor Wagner said yesterday that he disapproved of any labor union for the uniformed police force.

Thirty-nine graduate students received advanced degrees in theology and Christian education last night at the Biblical Seminary in New York, 235 East Forty-ninth Street. The students were from eight countries; fourteen were from the United States.

TOKYO, May 26 -- Two leaders of free Asia blueprinted a model economic relationship today for Japan, the industrial giant of the Orient, and other countries of the East that produce mainly raw materials.

Luxury-liner row on the Hudson River will be the scene today of one of the largest inbound passenger movements of the early trans-Atlantic steamship season. More than 5,000 travelers from Europe will debark from five liners.
The Girls Service League, 138 East Nineteenth Street, elected Mrs. D. Nelson Adams president of the board of directors yesterday.
The installation of Hercules anti-aircraft missiles, armed with either nuclear or conventional warheads, will begin in the metropolitan area in about a month, the Army reported yesterday.

Six alumni will receive New York University's Meritorious Service Medallions at commencement exercises next Wednesday. The medallions are presented annually by the N. Y. U. Alumni Federation for service to the university.

DEVON, Pa., May 27 -- Adolphe Mogavero, a trainer-rider from the Oak Ridge Farm, Pittsford, N. Y., had a perfect score of three blues in three open jumper events of the sixty-second annual Devon Horse Show, which continued into its third program today.
Directors of the National Gypsum Company approved a proposal yesterday for the acquisition of the American Encaustic Tiling Company, Inc., through an exchange of stock.
ALBANY, May 27 (AP) -- New York State reported today the first increase in ten years in the tuberculosis death rate.
THE sky's the limit in decorating today. Now, outer space has been brought down to earth to provide the newsiest of wall hangings.
The appointment of a seven-member Urban Renewal Board was announced yesterday by Mayor Wagner. James Felt, chairman of the City Planning Commission, will head the new group.
The Bank of Montreal devoted most of its monthly business review, issued yesterday, to highlights of a report by the Royal Commission on Canada's Economic Prospects.
College baseball's "world series," a two-losses-and-out tournament among teams representing each of the National Collegiate Athletic Association districts, is beginning to take shape.
PARIS, Wednesday, May 28 -- Following is the vote in the National Assembly last night on the resolution to reform the Constitution:
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 27 -- Communist China's prominent role in the current Soviet-bloc campaign against Yugoslavia was bitterly criticized here tonight.
HONOLULU, May 27 -- The Sugar Management Negotiating Committee today accepted Gov. William F. Quinn's proposal to settle the 116-day-old sugar strike.
WASHINGTON, May 27 -- The events in France that culminated in Premier Pierre Pflimlin's submission of his resignation kept official Washington alert and disturbed today.

PHILADELPHIA, May 27 -- The Giants may have been lulled into a feeling of false security by that 17-1 victory in an exhibition at West Point yesterday. Then again, they may have been pressing tonight because of the proximity of their erstwhile habitat.

Business spending for new plant and equipment will continue to decline throughout 1958 and into 1959, according to a survey made for Newsweek magazine by the National Industrial Conference Board. A sampling was made of 1,000 manufacturers.
HONG KONG, May 27 -- The Chinese Communists are now directing religious persecution at a number of previously unmolested leaders of various Protestant faiths, a reliable source reported here today.
CHICAGO, May 27 (AP) -- A blaze set off by masked arsonists under circumstances paralleling a similar fire two weeks ago, destroyed a suburban restaurant today with a loss of about $300,000.
WASHINGTON, May 27 -- The scheduled airlines said today that flights above 10,000 feet would be put under the Federal air traffic control system, starting July 1.
FARMINGDALE, L. I., May 27 -- The first American fighter-bomber capable of carrying a thermonuclear device was turned over to the Air Force here today.
PARIS, May 27 -- Gen. Charles de Gaulle was understood to be in his home at Colombey-les-Deux-Eglises tonight waiting for "the call."

LONDON, May 27 -- By emphasizing cuts in armed forces and military disengagement in Central Europe, the Soviet Union and its satellites in the Warsaw Pact have struck a shrewd blow at Western unity, diplomats said today.
Two new films will arrive at first-run theatres today.
The Mack Truck Company disclosed yesterday it had developed tractor-trailer rigs capable of hauling up to 250 tons of freight.
CHICAGO, May 27 (AP) -- Grain futures traders who wanted to buy every offering in sight yesterday were almost as eager today to be rid of them.
MILWAUKEE, May 27 (UPI) -- Joe Adcock's two-run pinch-homer capped a three-run ninth-inning rally tonight for a 3-2 victory by the Milwaukee Braves over the St. Louis Cardinals.

SURBITON, England, May 27 (AP) -- Althea Gibson of New York and her United States Wightman Cup team-mate, Mimi Arnold of Redwood City, Calif., won matches today in the Surrey lawn tennis championships, a tune-up for Wimbledon.

Eight teams resumed play last night in the second session of the annual bridge team play for the Curt Reisinger Trophy. Twelve other teams drew byes and will play tonight with the four winning teams from last night's session.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- The Senate Banking Committee approved a bill today to permit up to $250,000,000 of long-term Government loans to public or private corporations that are set up to finance small businesses.
The burning of worn-out automobile bodies is slated to be severely restricted under a local law passed yesterday by the City Council.

John Donald MacKenzie Brownlee, Australian-born baritone familiar to Metropolitan Opera audiences as Count Almaviva and Papageno, made his appearance at Town Hall yesterday afternoon in a new dress, the tartan of the Clan MacKenzie.

Gen. Alfred M. Gruenther, president of the American Red Cross and former supreme commander of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization forces, received the first gold medal of the Lafayette Fellowship Foundation last night.
Gas supplies to 5,400,000 residents of Brooklyn, Queens and Staten Island were threatened yesterday by strikes of employes of two Brooklyn gas companies.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 27 -- Gilbert and Norman Wright, sons of the late Harold Bell Wright, plan to produce a motion picture based on their father's autobiography, "To My Sons," published in 1934.
The first upturn in home-building in the state in two-and-a-half years occurred in April, State Housing Commissioner Joseph P. McMurray said yesterday.

For more than ten years sale of the city-owned subway power generating plants has been periodically discussed. But the case for disposing of these plants was never conclusively argued in an official document until the Preusse report, for the Mayor's Committee on Transit Power Plants, was made public on April 9.
MOSCOW, May 27 -- The Soviet Union has demonstrated great caution and expressed solemn concern about events in France the last two weeks.

ROME, May 27 -- The pro-Western Center parties triumphed in the general elections held Sunday and yesterday. They won a comfortable majority of twenty seats in the Senate and a fifty-two-seat majority in the Chamber of Deputies.

The Times is to be congratulated for the outstanding public service it has rendered through its constructive editorials concerning the problems of prepaid voluntary health insurance plans such as Blue Cross and Blue Shield.

SINCE the time for summer dining is at hand, a consideration of stuffed eggs seems in order. This versatile dish with its contrast between the white and the filling is as at home on an hors d'oeuvre tray as it is in a picnic hamper.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange advanced 4 to 24 points (20 cents to $1.20 a bale) yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 27 -- The trucking industry accepted today a compromise version of the controversial rate-making amendment in pending legislation to aid railroads.
For motorists it is June, July and August that are the cruelest months. And the month of June is no farther away than Sunday.
LOS ANGELES, May 27 -- The sale of the Biltmore, Los Angeles' only downtown legitimate theatre, received court approval today. It may be torn down to make way for an office building.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 27 -- Lebanese rebels are getting increased aid, including even medium artillery, from Syria in the United Arab Republic, a reliable source said tonight. Interference by the United Arab Republic was said to be increasing.
WASHINGTON, May 27 -- The widely held educational view that small classes are better than large ones was challenged today.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), May 27 -- United Nations truce supervision officers began this afternoon an investigation of the shooting yesterday on Mount Scopus.
TRENTON, May 27 -- Charges of mismanagement and misjudgment were made here today against the Passaic Valley Sewerage Commission and its consulting engineers.

JACKSON, Miss., May 27 (AP) -- Pickets at a project to build a lake for a power plant turned back seven or eight carloads of non-union Negro workers today. The Operating Engineers Union accuses the contractor, Gerald Smith Company of Jackson, of paying wages below the scale of $2.80 an hour for men operating earth-moving equipment.
TOKYO, May 27 (AP) -- India won its first two track and field gold medals of the Asian Games today, led by Milka Singh's eased-up romp in the 400-meter final.
IF Italy's fashion exports to the United States have increased appreciably during the last five years, no small credit should go to that brilliant, tightly knit empire known as Fontana of Rome.

Barring sudden alterations in Elia Kazan's plans, the director of "The Dark at the Top of the Stairs" will be responsible for the staging of three Broadway entries next season. In chronological sequence, they are "The Night Circus," "J. B." and "Sweet Bird of Youth."

NEWARK, May 27 -- The first major break in the three-week construction tie-up in northern New Jersey developed today. Bricklayers and masons in Bergen and Passaic Counties agreed to a total hourly wage increase of 30 cents in a three-year contract.
WASHINGTON, May 27 -- President Eisenhower signed the combined postal rate and pay bill today. His action means that first-class letters will require 4 instead of 3 cents postage starting Aug. 1.

WASHINGTON, May 27 (AP) -- The Federal Trade Commission today accused Encyclopaedia Britannica, Inc., of Chicago, of falsely claiming to offer its encyclopaedia at a bargain price for a limited time only.

MUSEUM directors, curators, and staff members may seem a stiffish lot in their work habitat, and many are, but they're astonishingly relaxed and joyous at regular meetings of the Museums Council of New York, which has been in existence for twenty years.

PHILADELPHIA, May 27 -- Bill Rigney bowed his head in thought and scuffed the floor of the dugout in Milwaukee with his spikes. What should he do? As he hesitated in a moment of indecision, his mind raced back over the game.

MOSCOW, May 27 -- The Soviet Union has started a new peace offensive to garner support for its position on world problems. Moscow also seeks to place the blame for continued tension on the Western powers.
Many prominent persons are among the patrons and patronesses for the Crown Princess Martha Friendship Fund benefit on June 11.

WESTBURY, L. I., May 27 -- Russell Valles Key wasn't at Roosevelt Raceway tonight. He was off plying his driving skills at the Rosecroft harness track in Maryland, so a substitute had to take the reins of Little Myrtle in Roosevelt's fourth race.

Well-oiled Federal and municipal machinery operated smoothly yesterday along the North River waterfront in handling crowds totaling 25,000 persons in the area between West Forty-fourth and West Fifty-seventh Streets.

CAMDEN, N. J., May 27 -- A package increase of 15 cents an hour in wages and welfare benefits for 16,500 employes of the Radio Corporation of America was provided in an agreement today between the company and the International Union of Electrical Workers.
WASHINGTON, May 27 (UPI) -- James P. Mitchell said today the public was "aroused" over labor-management abuses and expected Congress to adopt reform legislation.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- The merger of The United Press and the International News Service came under further attack in the Senate today. Senator Estes Kefauver, Democrat of Tennessee, urged the Government to obtain a speedy temporary injunction against the merger of the organizations into United Press International.
Vincent L. Gigante was acquitted last night of the charge that he attempted to murder Frank Costello.
In three nations -- France, Lebanon and Indonesia -- the armed forces held yesterday the key to future history.
OTTAWA, May 27 (Canadian Press) -- Eldorado Mining and Refining, Ltd., Government agency that supervises Canada's uranium program, today reported net profit on 1957 operations of $5,055,920.

MOBILE, Ala., May 27 -- Hiring of a crew for the S. S. Atlantic proceeded in orderly fashion today despite charges by the National Maritime Union that a conspiracy existed between the shipping company and a rival union.
LONDON, May 27 -- The stock market was depressed today by the events in France and North Africa, labor disputes in Britain and Wall Street's uncertainty.

BERKELEY, Calif., May 27 (UPI) -- Walt Arlt of Washington State College was declared the winner in the low hurdles of the Pacific Coast Conference meet last Saturday after a review of pictures by meet officials.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, May 27 -- Indonesia announced today her forces had shot down an American while he was flying a B-26 bomber for the Indonesian rebels.
The City Planning Commission put off action yesterday on an application by the Greyhound Corporation for permission to build a $10,000,000 bus terminal at Eighth Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street.
RENO, Nev., May 27 (AP) -- Charles S. Howard Jr., millionaire sportsman, married Mrs. Louise A. Carroll of Hillsborough, Calif., at his home here today. Mr. Howard is 55 years old; his wife is 43.
ITHACA, N. Y., May 27 -- A student committee of public safety went ahead today with plans to circulate a statement of grievances against Deane W. Malott, Cornell University's president.
PARIS, Wednesday, May 28 -- Premier Pierre Pflimlin submitted his resignation early today, with Gen. Charles de Gaulle waiting offstage to return to power either by constitutional means or by a coup.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Wednesday, May 28 -- The Navy launched a Vanguard rocket last night containing a twenty-inch instrumented earth satellite.
Dr. Joseph E. Colaneri was sworn in yesterday as medical director of the State Insurance Fund despite the opposition of the New York County Medical Society.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 27 -- The director of research for the Super Market Institute said today that the nation's supermarkets were getting bigger, doing more business and selling more to the customer than ever before.

ALGIERS, May 27 -- The death of Ramdane Abbane, one of the nine men on the early committee of the insurgent Algerian National Liberation Front, may change the direction of Algerian nationalism, North African observers believe.

PARIS, May 27 -- Everything seems over with the Fourth French Republic in the precise form familiar to us. That is to say, everything seems over but the shouting -- or the shooting. This aspect will soon be clarified.
Organized labor decided yesterday to drop its fight against letting its organizers organize.
LONDON, May 27 -- Britain agreed today to terms for the transformation of the colony of Singapore into a self-governing state similar to a protectorate.

Michigan borrowed $100,000,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance construction of trunk highways. The money was raised by the sale of serial obligations secured by motor vehicle fuel taxes and other special revenues. The borrowing cost the state 3.30732 per cent in interest.
NORTH CALDWELL, N. J., May 27 -- Mrs. Joseph A. Frelinghuysen Jr. of Somerset Hills took a three-point lead in the first round of the Elizabeth Goss Memorial round-robin golf tournament today.
NORWALK, Conn., May 27 -- A boycott of separate fund-raising campaigns is under consideration by the Norwalk Council of Community Associations.
Theodore Roosevelt, the only President of the United States born in New York City, was honored by his birthplace yesterday.
NEW LONDON, Conn., May 27 -- Seventy-nine cadets of the United States Coast Guard Academy received commissions as ensigns today at the academy's seventy-second commencement exercises.
A medical graduating class was urged yesterday to cooperate eagerly with various groups taking part in "sound health programs."
WASHINGTON, May 27 (AP) -- Hundreds of relatives of men killed in World War II and Korea are demanding -- without avail -- tickets to Friday's burial ceremonies of the unknowns of the two conflicts.
Animal experiments are helping scientists in their efforts to understand how radioactive materials can cause bone cancer in humans.
WASHINGTON, May 27 -- Max Block, New York's butchers' union boss, pleaded memory trouble and cloudy understanding today as the Senate rackets committee delved into some of his financial operations.

WASHINGTON, May 27 (UPI) -- House Speaker Sam Rayburn said today that he thought Vice President Richard M. Nixon had learned his lesson and would never again wage as "cruel" a campaign against the Democrats as he did in 1954.
WASHINGTON, Wednesday, May 28 -- The Navy launched a Vanguard satellite last night from Cape Canaveral, Fla., but early today was uncertain if it had been hurled into orbit.
WASHINGTON, May 27 -- Congressional leaders undertook today to enforce a decision against any tax reduction for the rest of the session.
TUNIS, May 27 -- Tunisians by the tens of thousands demonstrated today, calling for the evacuation of French forces and for arms from the United States and Britain.

Even if the unfortunate events of Lima and Caracas are now beginning to recede into the gray past and before they vanish altogether from men's minds, may I congratulate you on the stand you have taken about them.

The fundamental crisis of the Fourth Republic moves irresistibly toward its climax. As the world watches in fascination, France wrestles with herself, writhing in the throes of a reluctant revolution. Whatever the outcome, French political institutions will not be the same as they were before.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 27 -- An American in Beirut becomes quickly aware of the state of half hot and half cold war that confounds and cripples this crossroads of the Middle East.
Parking at seven of the eight beaches in the city will cost twice as much this year as last. Private autos will be charged 50 cents at the fields, which open Saturday.

PARIS, May 27 (UPI) -- Australia's Ashley Cooper defeated Giuseppe Merlo of Italy in a three-and-one-half-hour match today and reached the men's singles semi-finals in the French international tennis tourney.

The Scranton Corporation of Scranton, /Pa., until three months ago engaged principally in the lace and plastic fabrics business, has acquired the Hal Roach Studios of Culver City, Calif., motion picture producer. The terms involved an undisclosed amount of cash and stock and an employment contract with Hal Roach Jr., president and executive producer of the studios.

Two decisions involving labor unions handed down by the Supreme Court on Monday dealt with important issues -- which they did not wholly settle. But the decisions will have wide consequences, especially for organized labor, now subject to a multitude of damage suits which it otherwise might have avoided.
WASHINGTON, May 27 (AP) -- A nuclear scientist said today that the construction of a 540,000,000,000 - volt equivalent atom smasher would permit a major breakthrough in the field of atomic knowledge.
COLOMBO, Ceylon, May 27 -- Governor General Sir Oliver Goonetilleke proclaimed today a state of emergency throughout Ceylon. The action was caused by the continuing rioting over a language issue.
ALBANY, May 27 -- Governor Harriman said today that four of the five non-judicial places on next fall's Democratic state ticket were "wide open."
Kenyon Eckhardt, Inc., has won the race for the $3,000,000-a-year-advertising account of Max Factor Co. The account had been sought by about thirty agencies in the two months that it was loose.
Federal aid to public and private housing can be a lever for better interracial relations, Senator William Proxmire of Wisconsin said last night.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 27 -- The National Broadcasting Company is considering the possibility of taking eight of the best pilot films made in the past that found no sponsors and scheduling them as an eight-week anthology series in the 8 to 8:30 P. M. period Fridays.
An issue of $11,000,000 of bonds of Oslo, Norway, is being offered for public subscription by a syndicate headed by Kuhn, Loeb Co., Harriman Ripley Co., Inc., Lazard Freres Co. and Smith, Barney Co.
LITTLE ROCK, May 27 -- The first Negro in racially, integrated Central High School was graduated tonight. There were no untoward incidents.
WASHINGTON, May 27 -- The Senate Foreign Relations committee today defended its proposal for economic aid to Communist nations as a means of widened divisions in the Soviet bloc.

Week-end bus service will be halted on nine Bronx routes and Sunday service on one Bronx and one Manhattan route, it was announced yesterday by Surface Transit, Inc. The new schedules will go into effect in June.

British naval salvage operations in the Mediterranean in World War II are discussed by Peter Keeble in "Ordeal By Water," which Doubleday will publish June 19. The author was a lieutenant commander who saw heavy action in the Crete campaign.

Vincent F. Aiello will shortly join MacManus, John Adams, Inc., in an executive capacity. He has been an executive vice president and creative director on the Buick, General Motors institutional, National Distillers and Goodyear accounts at the Kudner Agency, Inc.
George Gobel and Eddie Fisher, who alternated top billing on their weekly television series this season, plan to present separate productions during the 1958-59 season.

Directors of Food Fair Stores, Inc., voted yesterday to split the common stock on a three-to-two basis by issuing an additional share of common for each two held by stockholders. The payable date for the split will be Aug. 15 for holders of record July 11.
Improved financial and health benefits for the aged through Federal legislation extending social security was recommended yesterday at a meeting sponsored by the city's older citizens.
COLUMBIA, S. C., May 27 (UPI) -- Doctors today termed "a success" an operation to help South Carolina's shot-put star. Dave Coates, straighten his deformed right arm.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 27 -- Col. John F. McMahon was elected national commander of the Volunteers of America today.
MINNEAPOLIS, May 27 -- Dr. Milton S. Eisenhower proposed today a world-wide medical "science for peace" program under the United Nations to conquer cancer and heart disease.

BONN, Germany, May 27 -- The United States Army and Air Force in Europe abolished today the military scrip that has been the servicemen's currency in West Germany, France and Italy for the last ten years.

Six floors and sub-basement space in the building rising at 660 Madison Avenue at Sixtieth Street have been leased by the Tidewater Oil Company, which has been in downtown Manhattan since 1879. Robert H. Byrne, senior vice president of the Cross Brown Company, arranged the lease for 135,000 square feet of space as rental manager of the twenty-two-story structure, which will be completed early in 1959.
WASHINGTON, May 27 (AP) -- A domestic parity plan for wheat marketing was advocated at a Senate Agriculture Committee hearing today by the National Association of Wheat Growers.

The Carrier Corporation cleared slightly more in the quarter ended April 30 than a year ago. But the net in the half-year ended on the same date was less, the report of the air conditioning equipment manufacturer showed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- Representative Oren Harris rejected today a proposal by the Boston Herald-Traveler Corporation that it screen information requested by the House subcommittee investigating the Federal Communications Commission.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- The Senate gave the Administration a victory today on the unemployment compensation bill. It defeated, 63 to 21, an attempt by liberal Democrats to broaden the measure's coverage.

From the point of view of the democratic West it is disappointing to note that the Communists and Left-Wing Socialists have hung on to, and even slightly increased, their popular vote in Italy's national election. After Hungary, after Khruschev's unmasking of Stalin, after the substantial measure of reform and prosperity that has been achieved in Italy, there had seemed reason to hope for some substantial falling away of Italian support for the Left.

HALIFAX, N. S., May 27 (Canadian Press) -- Captains and officers of eight Canadian National Steamships vessels anchored here have asked Claude Jodoin, president of the Canadian Labor Congress, to make a new effort to prevent the sale of the ships.

MOST American citizens of voting age know something about New York City's most famous streets -- that Wall Street means finance, that Broadway means show business and that Fifth Avenue means fine stores. Some citizens who keep up with new verbal usages know that Madison Avenue now means the advertising business.

CLIFTON, N. J., May 27 -- Community planning must consider the broad functional composite of the entire region if it is to be successful, Hugh R. Pomeroy, director of the Westchester County Planning Department, said here today.

An organization dedicated to helping orphans overseas proved yesterday that when it said "Food for Waifs" it meant food for waifs, not for people interested in waifs. It held a tea-less, sandwichless, cookyless tea party at Gracie Mansion.
WASHINGTON, May 27 (AP) -- President Eisenhower expressed today deep regret at the death of Cardinal Stritch. The President made this statement:
A new lamp that promises substantial savings in maintenance costs, power and air-conditioning for the printing and publishing industry was introduced yesterday by the General Electric Company.

Joseph L. Steinfeld and Frederick Katzenell, New York realty operators, contracted to buy the two-story taxpayer building at 54-02 to 54-06 Roosevelt Avenue, Woodside, Queens. Lester Voght, the seller has owned the property ten years.
OTTAWA, May 27 (AP) -- United States and Canadian officials hope to announce a toll schedule for the St. Lawrence Seaway by July 1.
WASHINGTON, May 27 -- A Congressional Atomic Energy, subcommittee approved today a modified version of the Administration's proposal to provide European allies with atomic weapon secrets.

New York Airways puts an attractive new helicopter, the twin-rotor Vertol 44-B, into service here today. The five-plane fleet will bring to local operations the "flying banana" silhouette, improved capacity (fifteen passengers each) and cabins with most of the comforts of fixed-wing airliners.
PARIS, May 27 -- The nationwide strike called by the French Communist party in opposition to Gen. Charles de Gaulle appeared tonight to have been only partly successful.

A significant contribution was reported yesterday to the medical profession's efforts to combat infection from a strain of staphylococcus bacteria.

Dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe. Add bread and beverage as desired, unless specified.

LONDON, May 27 (Reuters) -- Following, in translation, are excerpts from the communique and other statements by the Warsaw Treaty powers at their meeting last week-end, as made public today by Tass, Soviet news agency:

PITTSBURGH, May 27 -- Two Protestant denominations formally closed their books here today after a century of independent existence. Tomorrow they will merge into the 3,000,000-member United Presbyterian Church in the U. S. A.
WOODFORD, Vt., May 27 -- One of the keenest pleasures available to the strong, hardy outdoorsman of the Slot-Machine Age is to explore the fishing in what appears to be a piece of unknown water.
WASHINGTON, May 27 (AP) -- The Justice Department said today that a Federal grand jury had been impaneled at Cleveland to investigate the pricing of new automobiles and parts in the area.

TOKYO, May 27 -- Top-ranking officers of seventeen nations, including several so-called "neutralist" states of Asia, witnessed a display last week of the United States mobile arsenal in the Asian and Pacific regions.
Federal Judge Irving R. Kaufman last night urged lawyers to exhibit "personal courage" by undertaking the defense of unpopular defendants.

KANSAS CITY, May 27 -- Although the rest of the American League may be of a mind to roll over and play dead for the Yankees, Harry Craft's rambunctious Athletics erupted tonight with a vigorous minority report that brought thunderous cheers from a crowd of 29,704.

Nothing short of an international development authority to channel a substantial portion of all forms of assistance to the newer nations is capable of meeting both the rapidly growing challenge of the Soviet bloc and the needs of the underdeveloped areas.
AT the center of France's governmental crisis is a husky Norman, President Rene Jules Gustave Coty, a man of vigor and stamina despite his seventy-six years.
A technical reaction to Monday's sharp rise lowered wool and copper futures prices yesterday and reduced the gains in cocoa and the world sugar contract.

With gross revenues, down 11.7 per cent to $12,492,868, the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad ended April with a net loss of $455,408. In April, 1957, when gross was $14,141,818, the carrier had a net income of $7,075.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 27 -- A leading financial authority said today that commercial banks will require a higher level of profits in the future if they are to attract on favorable terms the additional capital needed to keep pace with economic growth.

A $325,000 judgment was returned against the New York Central Railroad yesterday in Bronx Supreme Court. The award is said to be one of the largest ever made for the death of one person in a negligence action.

Sales of the West Virginia Pulp and Paper Company in the six months ended April 30 were higher than in the corresponding period of 1957 but earnings declined 24 per cent, David L. Luke, president, reported yesterday.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 27 -- A small group of earnest women moved into the United Nations today with cartons of radio equipment and miles of recording tape. For the next three months, they will make their headquarters from 10 A. M. to 7 P. M. in a series of small, windowless booths where they will record foreign language grammars and other textbooks urgently needed by blind students.

When Union Dime Savings Bank opened May 18, 1859, in a small frame building at Canal and Varick Streets, ten of its founders were textile men. Many of the small savers the bank sought to attract came from the near-by Worth Street textile center.
Harlem Republican district leaders called on their party last night to endorse Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr., a Democrat who is facing a primary fight in his own party.
"Idun ain't unbeaten no more." Such was the trenchant, if inelegant, comment that one horse player offered after the seventh race at Belmont Park yesterday.
Cardinal Spellman gave diplomas to 104 women of Marymount College, 221 East Seventy-first Street, yesterday at the ninth annual commencement exercises.

SCARSDALE, N. Y., May 27 -- A record field of 180 participated in the annual spring tournament of the Westchester Senior Golf Association today. One of the reasons for the unusually large turnout at the Quaker Ridge Golf Club was the pleasant weather.
ALGIERS, May 27 -- The leadership of the insurgent French in Algeria expressed its "profound joy" here tonight over the turn of events in France during the last wenty-four hours.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- Authoritative military sources dismissed as insignificant today the Soviet bloc's announcements of troop reductions in Eastern Europe. But they ex pressed worry about Western defenses should civil strife develop in France.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 27 -- The Security Council postponed today a debate on Lebanon's complaint against the United Arab Republic to give the Arab League time to consider the charges.
John Foster Dulles last night pictured ministers of the gospel as guardians of mankind's "material safety" in the atomic age.
Suburbanites have found what New Yorkers have been vainly seeking -- free parking in the heart of the city.

Pan American World Airways plans to start transatlantic jet passenger service late this year, Juan T. Trippe, president, told stockholders at the annual meeting yesterday in the Sheraton-East Hotel here.

Steels, a few stocks with missile connections and a handful of oil producers pushed ahead in a sluggish market yesterday. Most of the list, however, showed little ambition and the close was a trifle lower.

ROME, May 27 (AP) -- The body of Samuel Cardinal Stritch, who died far from home but near the center of the church he served all his life, lay in state tonight high on Janiculum Hill, overlooking Rome and the Vatican.

AMMAN, Jordan, May 27 (AP) -- King Faisal of Iraq opened the first Parliament of the new Arab Federation of Iraq and Jordan today. He said the Government wanted to strengthen its ties with other Arab nations and continue cooperation with friendly powers.

Although the actual date of the first skirmish is indistinct it might be said, judging by the intensity of the fray, that the battle over the latest women's fashions is now fully joined. The cause seems to have taken shape -- or shapelessness, depending on one's point of view -- over the merits of the chemise, the sack and the trapeze.
The total of insured pension plans recorded its best gain in 1957, the Institute of Life Insurance reported yesterday.

BOSTON, May 27 (AP) -- The American Unitarian Association affirmed today its Judeo-Christian heritage but at the same time expressed hope that "all religious truth seekers may come together in the spirit of freedom."
GREENWICH, Conn., May 27 -- Twenty-four young women will be presented at the Greenwich Debutante Ball June 14 at the Greenwich Country Club.
Dr. Grayson Kirk, president of Columbia University, announced yesterday the appointment of three new deans in the university.

Tenants in the Lincoln Square redevelopment area were assured yesterday that no attempt would be made to relocate them before the United States Supreme Court decided whether it would review state court decisions upholding the legality of the $205,000,000 project.
BARGAIN hunters will find a good array of holiday table fare for this coming week-end. In addition to some attractively priced hams and turkeys, a few scattered beef cuts are economically priced.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 27 (UPI) -- Three of four Kentucky Representatives seeking renomination won tonight in a primary election. A fourth, Representative Noble J. Gregory, trailed in his race despite backing by Gov. A. B. Chandler. The voting was light.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- The House Judiciary Committee approved today a broad "States' rights" bill intended to permit state laws to operate despite the existence of Federal legislation in the same field.
When Reiko Kase sits down to write a short story, she is, like her father, very much the career diplomat.

MOSCOW, May 27 -- This city likes to think of itself as the sophisticated capital of a world power, but by the end of tonight's first concert here by the Philadelphia Orchestra the audience was carrying on like the crowd at "futbol" in the Dynamo Stadium.

The forty-second 500-mile race at Indianapolis will be run on Friday. The average speed of the winner will almost double that of the first victory in 1911. Ray Harroun won that long-ago contest in an Indianapolis-built car -- the Marmon -- at 74.59 miles an hour.

The General Telephone System reported yesterday consolidated revenues of $171,369 000 for the first four months of 1958. This compared with $160,832,000 a year earlier. Figures for both periods included those of manufacturing and sales subsidiaries.
LONDON, May 27 (AP) -- The elevated high-jumping shoe -- used by Russians to break an American athletic monopoly -- was declared illegal today and banned throughout the world.
WASHINGTON, May 27 -- Senator Lyndon B. Johnson urged the Voice of America today to muffle "Columbia, The Gem of the Ocean" and keep East Europeans out of jail.
WASHINGTON, May 27 -- The House of Representatives voted tentatively today to kill the bill to admit Alaska as the forty-ninth state. The vote was 144 to 106.
Secretary of State John Foster Dulles put a finger to his lips yesterday when newsmen sought to question him on the situation in France.

LONDON, May 28 -- Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh, has commissioned Feliks Topolski, Polish-born artist, to paint a ninety-five-foot-long mural of the Coronation of Queen Elizabeth II. It will go in the royal family's private apartments in Buckingham Palace.

REYKJAVIK, Iceland, May 28 (Reuters) -- An Icelandic Communist newspaper gave details today of new regulations that it said the Government had approved to extend Iceland's territorial waters from four miles to twelve.

A decline in the week ended last Friday of 2,554,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end, total supplies were 195,753,000 barrels, compared with 198,307,000 a week earlier, and 194,373,000 a year ago.
For the second year the Bagby Music Lovers Foundation has chosen a Metropolitan Opera performance as its annual fundraising event.
PARIS, May 28 -- The Left unleashed a massive nonviolent demonstration in eastern Paris today in support of the republican Government.

Stocks closed virtually unchanged yesterday after a day of small and uncertain movements. As a group, only electronics showed a generally higher tendency. Most of the important classifications were well mixed.

The second section of The Times of May 21 carried an article, "Educational TV Faces Blackout," stating that the Metropolitan Educational Television Association would stop its program on June 1 for lack of funds. In my opinion this disaster rated front-page news.
SYRACUSE, May 28 (AP) -- Tom Hennessey of St. Louis won the American Bowling Congress masters' tournament tonight by defeating Lou Frantz of Louisville, 789-749, in the final.

Two rulings designed to guarantee greater stability in the billion-dollar-a-year dress industry were handed down yesterday by Harry Uviller, the industry's impartial chairman.
WESTPHALIA, Kan., May 28 -- About 3,000 Old German Baptists who live by a creed of simplicity and friendship have made their peace with modern unionism.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 28 -- Eighteen United States Army Bulldog M-41 light tanks were delivered to Lebanon today under the military aid program.
FLEMINGTON, N. J., May 28 (AP) -- Unionized dairymen hissed tonight a speech by Herbert W. Voorhees, president of the state Farm Bureau.
Sixty members and friends of the Park Association held their annual outing yesterday by visiting several parks in the Bronx and the proposed park site at the former Seton Hospital.
Two new films open at first-run theatres today.

WASHINGTON, May 28 (AP) -- Senator Thomas C. Hennings Jr., Democrat of Missouri, told the Senate today that any effort to pass a bill restricting jurisdiction of the Supreme Court would cause extended debate.

A famous American ornithologist, who has spent the last five years in the Congo, returned to the United States yesterday and learned, first hand, about a Hoboken ritual as curious as anything he had seen in many trips to Africa.

WASHINGTON, May 28 (AP) -- The Army said today it planned to install the low-flying Hawk, another type of missile, to defend cities already protected by the Nike.
The political crisis in France has not caused any great activity here in shares of French companies.

CHICAGO, May 28 -- Chief Justice Earl Warren and his British counterpart, Viscount Kilmuir of Creich, Lord High Chancellor of Great Britain, took part today in laying the cornerstone of a law school building at the University of Chicago.
JERICHO, L. I., May 28 -- Mrs. R. M. Torgerson of the Cherry Valley Club posted a 79 to take the low gross award at the Women's Long Island Golf Association's one-day tournament today.
LONDON, May 28 -- The stock market was quiet again today. Losses were generally limited to pennies and the undertone of nearly all sections was said to be firm.
ANKARA, Turkey 28 (AP) -- Turkey's Grand National Assembly defeated today an opposition bill intended to give amnesty to all offenders against the stringent National Press Law.
TOKYO, May 28 (AP) -- Japan increased its lead in the Third Asian Games today by winning all seven swimming races on the card.
The Ohio Oil Company and the Continental Oil Company announced yesterday the formation of the Wabash Pipe Line Company, a common carrier of petroleum products in Illinois and Indiana.
NEW DELHI, India, May 28 -- In the Himalayan village of Rankhila a tiger nine feet long from tail to tooth was killed, and in Agra a policeman said some sneering things about Indian dogs.

LONDON, May 28 -- The Scots, who seldom are wrong in matters of golf, today rated the well-known British amateur, Harold Macmillan, 3 to 5 strokes better than the prominent American player, Dwight Eisenhower.
A. E. Riddle, director of office administration, ColgatePalmolive Company, here, has been elected vice president of the National Office Management Association, Willow Grove, Pa.
WASHINGTON, May 28 -- The Government established today an experimental system of transcontinental air routes on which all flying will be subject to ground control regardless of weather.
WASHINGTON, May 28 (AP) -- Two unknown heroes of World War II and Korea were laid in state today beneath the Capitol dome.
COLOMBO, Ceylon, May 28 -Schools were closed today and strict censorship was imposed on news and editorial comment on disturbances resulting from communal strife.

The appearance of the Tuskegee Choir on the stage of the Music Hall today marks the beginning of the theatre's new policy for the presentation of vocal musical entertainment. The stage and film showcase will disband its male choral group and henceforth utilize singing talent "from all over the world," according to Russell V. Downing, president of the Music Hall.

Chicago, Kansas City, Cincinnati and Akron pay a 25-cent bus fare. Pittsburgh pays 23 cents. The 20-cent fare is a commonplace all over the country, in cities too numerous to mention. In this state Buffalo, Rochester, Binghamton and Niagara Falls already have a 20-cent fare.

Stanford University and Boston University have canceled their entries in the fifty-sixth regatta of the Intercollegiate Rowing Association. The championships will be held June 21 on Onondaga Lake, Syracuse.

ALFRED LUNT, who is currently appearing on Broadway with his wife. Lynn Fontanne, in "The Visit," is not only a fine actor, he is also an exceptional amateur chef. He has a searching interest in fine cuisine and recently completed a five-week course at the Cordon Bleu school of cookery in Paris.

The election of John S. Routh Jr. as executive vice president and a director of the Pittston Company was announced yesterday. The company's subsidiaries produce and distribute soft coal and natural gas, conduct trucking, armored car and warehousing activities, and transport and distribute petroleum products.

PARIS, May 28 -- When Gen. Charles de Gaulle assumed power in France in 1944, it was not through a parliamentary vote or any official mandate. He simply walked down the Champs-Elysees and listened to the wild cheers of the crowd. That was enough.
A DARK brooding story of miserably unhappy people, this one concerning a forlorn and lonely little Dutch boy and his alcoholic mother, was presented last night on the "Kraft Theatre" over Channel 4.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- The Senate passed today and sent to the White House a bill extending unemployment compensation an average of thirteen weeks, after defeating liberal Democratic attempts to broaden both the bill's coverage and time period. The vote was 80 to 0.

An issue of $12,000,000 of first mortgage bonds of the Pennsylvania State University was offered for public subscription yesterday by a syndicate headed by First Boston Corporation. The bonds were oversubscribed.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, May 28 (Reuters) -- An American pilot accused of flying bombers for Indonesian rebels will be tried in public by a military court, the Antara news agency of Indonesia reported today.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -The chairman of the Senate labor rackets committee accused New York butchers' union leaders today of "gross misuse" of funds and of exploiting members.

WASHINGTON, May 28 (AP) -- Senator John L. McClellan said today he still wanted action held up on President Eisenhower's nomination of W. Wilson White to head the Justice Department's new civil rights division.

Dr. Grayson Kirk, president of Columbia University, will confer honorary degrees on ten men and women from this country and abroad at commencement exercises next Tuesday.

The Grand Union Company, which operates 383 supermarkets in the East, has acquired forty-one Empire Super Markets in eastern New York State and Massachusetts, operated by Schaffer Stores Company, Inc., in a deal effective Monday.
WASHINGTON, May 28 (AP) -- A bill to extend the life of the Civil Rights Commission to June, 1960, was introduced today by Representative Kenneth B. Keating.

Tribute was paid yesterday by The Lambs, an organization consisting mostly of actors, to the six members who died in both World Wars and the 398 who served. The ceremony was held at the clubhouse, 128 West Forty-fourth Street.

PARIS, May 28 (AP) -- An English tandem upset favored Mervyn Rose and Warren Woodcock of Australia today in the men's doubles quarter-finals of the French tennis tournament championships.
KANSAS CITY, May 28 -- The Yankees' gay dash through the West came to a jarring, not to say surprising, end today.

Expansion of producing capacity by the nation's private utilities, while not matching 1957 year-end predictions, is nevertheless proceeding at a record pace, the Edison Electric Institute reported yesterday.

FARMINGDALE, L. I., May 28 -- Volume production of Republic Aviation Corporation's new F-105 supersonic jet fighter-bomber will mean increased employment on Long Island. Mundy I. Peale, president of the aircraft manufacturing concern, said today that Republic would hire 1,100 additional employes next month.

A "GOOD Yankee Republican right down to his toenails." That is how associates describe Frazar Bullard Wilde, president of the Connecticut General Life Insurance Company. They add that he is a man eager to listen to new ideas and quick to adopt them if they prove sound. Yesterday he was named to coordinate the ideas of a private commission that will study the nation's monetary policies.

DETROIT, May 28 -- The United Automobile Workers expressed willingness today to modify its contract demands further. However, the General Motors Corporation said the union did not appear willing enough.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- The head of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee opened floor debate on the aid authorization bill today. He cautioned against military cuts below the $2,400,000,000 set by the committee.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 28 -- The Soviet Union has reneged again on its two-year-old commitment to help Yugoslavia with credits amounting to $285,000,000.
Earnings of the General Instrument Corporation in the fiscal year ended Feb. 28 were doubled as sales rose 17 per cent to a new high, Martin H. Benedek, chairman, reported yesterday.

WOODFORD, Vt., May 28 -- It is possible to report now with good clinical evidence that when flashboards are removed from a dam and water allowed to escape, a good twenty-five-acre fishing lake may become a dead lake.
The Liberal party resorted to song last night to tell Governor Harriman it wanted Lieut. Gov. George B. DeLuca and Controller Arthur Levitt renominated this year on a joint Democratic-Liberal ticket.
WASHINGTON, May 28 -- Each of the United States military services is reviewing the disposition of its forces and their requirements in view of the French and North African crises.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- The White House today broke its long peace with Congress on Pentagon reorganization.

Cedarhurst Park House, a two-story garden apartment building on Cedarhurst Avenue between Fifth and Oak Avenues in Cedarhurst, L. I., has been sold by Montgomery Equities, Edward Benenson, president. The buyer was the Arstay Realty Corporation represented by Jerome Barr. Murray Adler was the broker.
WASHINGTON, May 28 -- President Eisenhower refused to discuss the French political crisis today, but made a friendly personal reference to Gen. Charles de Gaulle.

WASHINGTON, May 28 (AP) -- The House Appropriations Committee called today for an end to the military practice of allowing officers with desk jobs to fly a few hours a month so that they can get higher pay.

WASHINGTON, May 28 (UPI) -- The Congressional Atomic Energy Committee approved today President Eisenhower's plan for sharing weapons data and nuclear materials with free world allies. However, it included a provision for Congressional veto.
The Committee for Economic Development has formed a twenty-five-man commission to make the first over-all study of the nation's public and private monetary policies in a half century.
WASHINGTON, May 28 (AP) -- President Eisenhower asked Congress today for an additional $334,000,000 for military and civilian expansion of the atomic energy program.

LAWRENCEVILLE, N. J., May 28 -- Top executives of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) are optimistic about the nation's economic prospects and the long-range outlook for the petroleum industry.
ROME, May 28 -- The new Parliament elected Sunday and Monday meets for the first time June 12 and must immediately set up a government to replace the present one headed by Premier Adone Zoli.

GREENWICH, Conn., May 28 -- The fourth annual Greenwich Junior Horse Show will take place June 7 and 8 at the estate of Mr. Harry S. Moore on Round Hill Road.

Electric power production last week rose to 11,316,000,000 kilowatt hours from 11,257,000,000 in the week before, the Edison Electric Institute reported yesterday. The figure for the week ended May 25, 1957, was 11,574,000,000 kilowatt hours.
Bay E. Estes Jr. has been promoted to vice president for marketing of the United States Steel Corporation. He had been director of staff administration.

ALBANY, May 28 -- Lieut. Gov. George B. DeLuca and Controller Arthur Levitt, who ran with the Governor in 1954, predicted today that they would be renominated and re-elected, even if Governor Harriman chose not to endorse them. Fair and mild weather is expected to accompany tomorrow's Memorial Day services and continue for the rest of the three-day holiday week-end, the Weather Bureau reported yesterday.

ALBANY, May 28 (AP) -- Lobbyists spent $174,359 in attempting to get their favorite measures passed at the 1958 session of the Legislature.
CHICAGO, May 28 (AP) -- Oats and rye attracted the main interest today on the Board of Trade and prices of both advanced on broad demand.

A ninety-minute production of "Hamlet" by London's Old Vic Company will be televised early next year over the Columbia Broadcasting System network.
WASHINGTON, May 28 -- The House Appropriations Committee urged new money on the Administration today to step up futuristic weapons programs.
