ADEN, May 28 -- The Sultan of Lahej, in Britain's Western Aden Protectorate, has been represented as wishing to become ruler of a South Arabian state allied to the United Arab Republic.

Americans have flocked to the country's waterways in increasing numbers in recent years for their leisure entertainment. More than twenty-five million Americans are expected to take to the water in 1958.
CHICAGO, May 28 (UPI) -- Irish Bobby Scanlon, an unbeaten San Francisco lightweight, outboxed Bobby Rogers of Chicago tonight to gain an unanimous ten-round decision at Chicago Stadium.
A model-boat basin in Central Park became a rescue laboratory and swimming pool yesterday to promote safety over the Memorial Day weekend.
MOBILE, Ala., May 28 -- A National Maritime Union delegation protested today to the American Banner Line about hiring conducted here for the liner Atlantic.
Deere Co., second largest agricultural equipment maker, increased sales and earnings in the six months ended April 30 over the previous year's period, according to William A. Hewitt, president.

Going to the movies was made more pleasant, if not more sober, yesterday by Thomas J. Lipton, Inc., which presented a handsome film about the America's Cup. In addition, Lipton, Inc., had abundant scotch and champagne on hand for those guests who perchance wanted something stronger than tea.
HELSINKI, Finland, May 28 -- Some of the best American, Russian and Finnish ballet is being presented by the Finnish National opera in a ten-day Festival.

MONTCLAIR, N. J., May 28 -- The Memorial Day observance this year at Montclair State Teachers College will have added significance for many members of the audience. Music for the services on Friday in the Memorial Auditorium will be played on a pipe organ purchased with their contributions of $50,000.

Food prices, which have accounted for the greater part of the rise in the consumer price index in recent months, are now "pretty well stabilized," according to Secretary of Agriculture Benson. As a matter of fact, he told a news conference in Atlantic City that price declines may be looked for in certain areas where special circumstances have resulted recently in price advances of abnormal amplitude.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were unchanged to 19 points (95 cents a bale) up yesterday. The far off months showed the most strength.

Although gross revenues of the Canadian Pacific Railway fell to $39,104,239 in April from $43,072,350 in the like 1957 month, the management cut costs sharply and managed to limit the decline in net earnings.

The first Columbia Journalism Award for "singular journalistic performance in the public interest" will be presented today to John N. Heiskell, editor and president of The Arkansas Gazette of Little Rock.

New Yorkers have already been warned by Police Commissioner Kennedy: juvenile delinquency rises with the mercury. Through its newly released 1957 annual report, entitled "What About the 99 Per Cent?," the Children's Aid Society, 105 East Twenty-second Street, New York 10, assures us that its program is being geared to meet this annual "heat wave."
A new investment company of the mutual fund, open-end type has been formed under the name of the Lazard Fund, Inc.
ALGIERS, May 28 -- Studied efforts by leaders of the insurrectionist movement here to create a friendly climate between Europeans and Moslems appear to be bearing fruit.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., May 28 -- Federalized Arkansas National Guard troops were withdrawn today from Central High School. Their departure ended eight months of surveillance ordered by President Eisenhower to enforce a racial integration directive of the United States District Court here.

WASHINGTON, May 28 (UPI) -- The Congressional Atomic Energy Committee today gave an immediate go-ahead to plans for construction of nuclear power plants for Carolinas-Virginia Nuclear Power Associates, the city of Piqua, Ohio, and the Rural Cooperative Power Association of Elk River, Minn.

Maurice Evans has made a bid for the American rights to a successful twin bill now running at London's Garrick Theatre. The two short plays are "The Dock Brief" and "What Shall We Tell Caroline?" written by John Mortimer, English novelist and lawyer.
DISTINGUISHED old hands at retailing, Bergdorf Goodman has been up to its chandeliers these last weeks searching out fresh talent in designing.
WASHINGTON, May 28 -- The House of Representatives voted 208 to 166 today to admit Alaska as the forty-ninth state of the Union.

ALGIERS, May 28 -- A guerrilla chief, commander of a private Algerian army of 3,000 men fighting as an "ally" of France, was reported today to have disappeared four days ago. It was not known how many of his men had left with him.
Degrees were granted to forty-nine students yesterday in commencement exercises at General Theological Seminary, a major seminary of the Protestant Episcopal Church.

The United States Attorney General's office filed a civil suit yesterday in the Federal court, Brooklyn. charging Chas Pfizer Co. with trust law violations in the manufacture, distribution and sale of citric acid.

A construction contract total of $2,881,011,000 throughout the country in April was described yesterday as "highly encouraging'' by the F. W. Dodge Corporation. The figure represents an increase of 4 per cent over the volume of $2,776,431,000 in April of last year.
Those who stop for a round on the Saddle River Golf and Country Club's public course at Paramus, N. J., often see squads of men and women receiving golf instruction.
CANBERRA, May 28 (AP) -- Prime Minister Robert G. Menzies today made another attack on United States trade policies.
PHILADELPHIA, May 28 -- "Of one thing I'm sure," Bill Rigney, the manager of the Giants, said before the game with the Phillies tonight. "This team of mine can make runs."
Arvin Industries, Inc., makers of automotive parts, has cut its common quarterly dividend to 25 cents a share, payable June 30, from 50 cents paid in previous quarters.
LOS ANGELES, May 28 (AP) -- City Councilman Pat McGee, a bitter critic of the city's Chavez Ravine deal with the Los Angeles Dodgers, today offered an alternative in a motion before the Council.
PARIS, Thursday, May 29 -- Gen. Charles de Gaulle left Paris early this morning after negotiations for his return to power in France had broken down on the obstacle of Socialist opposition.

LONDON, May 28 -- Two Oxford University students accused of having revealed British espionage secrets in an undergraduate magazine article were committed for trial today at the Old Bailey, London's central criminal court.
Four teen-age gang members convicted of killing Michael Farmer, 15-year-old polio victim, were sentenced yesterday to prison terms ranging from five years to life.
FROM New York, Kentucky, Texas, California and many other states come the objects in the Jewish Museum (Fifth Avenue and Ninety-second Street) exhibition of contemporary ceremonial and synagogue art.
SURBITON, England, May 28 (AP) -- Althea Gibson of New York and little Mimi Arnold of Redwood City, Calif., today gained quarter-final berths in the Surrey lawn tennis championships.
A strange postscript to a suicide was made public yesterday by the police.
INDIANAPOLIS, May 28 (UPI) -- Racing's fastest drivers made final preparations today for the forty-second 500-mile automobile race.
WASHINGTON, May 28 -- Neither a union nor an employer may abandon a multi-employer bargaining unit after the date for the start of bargaining, unless there are unusual circumstances.

Commodity futures closed generally higher yesterday on the New York exchanges. Trading was dull in most markets. Cottonseed oil, copper, zinc, potatoes, hides, rubber and soybean oil rose; sugar and lead declined, and price movements for coffee, cocoa and wool were mixed.

NEWARK, Del., May 28 -- The University of Delaware, boasting the best won-and-lost record (19-3) of any of the four teams named, withdrew today from the District 2 regional play-offs for the National Collegiate baseball championship. Lafayette was named to replace Delaware.
IN the opinion of home-appliance experts, three ingredients of a successful marriage are a coffeemaker, a toaster and a steam iron.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., May 28 -- The United States could move instantly to set in motion the world-wide attack on cancer and heart disease proposed yesterday by Dr. Milton S. Eisenhower, a Government spokesman said today.
WASHINGTON, May 28 -- A Midwestern broadcasting official testified today that rivals had told him before he got a television channel that eventually he would lose it.
WASHINGTON, May 28 -- President Eisenhower said today that he thought the recession had "largely spent its force."

There is nothing unimaginative about the oil industry. At the annual meeting of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) yesterday M. J. Rathbone, president, said "we are exploring many avenues." These include methods of using oil to melt snow at parking lots and airports, killing fungus on banana plants, control evaporation from water reservoirs and to cool homes in summer and the conversion of asphalt into building bricks.
MOSCOW, May 28 -- This was music-appreciation night at the Moscow Conservatory.
The number of workers drawing unemployment insurance here went up again last week. The upstate total declined, but the drop was substantially short of seasonal expectations.
WASHINGTON, May 28 -- The United States took a step today toward formal recognition of the Arab Federation of Iraq and Jordan.
WHITE PLAINS, May 28 -- Westchester County Democratic leaders completed a slate of candidates today for nomination in the August primaries.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 28 -- Frank Sinatra is returning to Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, where he spent many years of his career as an actor until 1951.
PARIS, May 28 -- Frenchmen showed a marked nostalgia for the napoleon today -- not the Emperor, that is, but the coin bearing his image.
WASHINGTON, May 28 (UPI) -- The Senate Commerce Committee approved a bill today to authorize the Federal Maritime Board to finance two huge ocean liners costing $188,000,000.
TALLMAN, N. Y., May 28 -- David Sive, a Pearl River lawyer, was named tonight at a Rockland County Democratic convention here as the party's candidate for Congress in the Twenty-eighth District.
The Latin-American coffee producing countries are holding large amounts of coffee from the market and it is expected that these holdings will increase sharply during the 1958-59 crop year.
CARACAS, Venezuela, May 28 -- New ministers were named in a reorganization of the Venezuelan Cabinet last night and today.
Delays or detours on the following major routes will affect motorists traveling in the Metropolitan area over the Memorial Day week-end.
PITTSBURGH, May 28 -- A new Protestant denomination was formed today in a street ceremony under pelting rain.
WASHINGTON, May 29 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture announced today that it would offer a subsidy of 6 1/2 cents a pound on cotton exported under its new paymentin-kind foreign sales program.

WASHINGTON, May 29 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture said today that last winter's freezes caused extensive damage to 16 per cent of the orange trees and 12 per cent of the grapefruit and tangerine trees in Florida.
CHICAGO, May 29 (AP) -- Corn futures encountered the strongest buying in weeks today on the Board of Trade and some contracts were bid up to new highs for the season.
ROME, May 29 -- The body of Samuel Cardinal Stritch, Archbishop of Chicago, left today by plane for its last resting place in Chicago.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., May 29 --Ah Air Force attemptI to l ah Atlas test missile Was postponed late today after the countdown had been completed and the rocket ignited.

Meeting of North and South American states was proposed yesterday by Cuba's Ambassador to the United States. He said the conferees should deal with common problems and meet the challenge of communism.

WASHINGTON, May 29 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture reported today that farm prices remained unchanged between mid-April and mid-May. This leveling off halted a sharp increase that started last October to pull farm prices 10 per cent above a year earlier, and to the highest level since the Eisenhower Administration took office in January of 1953.

PHILADELPHIA, May 29 -- A 3,300-room apartment building, with fifteen penthouses on the thirtieth floor, will be the next structure to rise in the $100,000,000 Penn Center development west of City Hall.

Cocoa futures tumbled as much as the 1-cent-a-pound daily limit yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange. The volume, 998 lots (30,000 pounds to a lot), equaled the largest number of trades for any day this year.

MOSCOW, May 29 -- Marshal Kliment Y. Voroshilov, Soviet chief of state, was quoted tonight as having said he thought the rise to power in France of Gen. Charles de Gaulle would bring "more harm than good" to France.
BUENOS AIRES, May 29 -- The precision of the New York Philharmonic last night dazzled an audience of more than 3,000
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 29 -- Tunisia asked the Security Council today to meet to consider "armed aggression" by France in Tunisian territory.

A new industrial building at 975 Close Avenue in the East Bronx has been leased by Domirdck CarnoVa to Complete Automotive Service, Inc., a eomIpany servicing new automobiles i for dealers. The lease was negotiated by the Joseph G. Platzner Company, broker.
The One William Street Fund, Inc., the first venture of Lehman Brothers financial management into the mutual fund field, is in business.

WASHINGTON, May 29 (UPI) -- President Eisenhower will nominate Charles C. Finucane of Spokane, Wash., as Assistant Secretary of Defense for Manpower, Personnel and Reserves, the White House said today.

There is a possibility that Jackie Gleason will return to television next fall as the star of a variety show on Fridays from 8:30 to 9 P. M. It would be televised over the Columbia Broadcasting System network.
WESTPORT, Conn., May 29 -- The unusually severe infestation of wood ticks already noted in Westchester and on Long Island has spread to this Fairfield County area.

Several of the nation's major oil companies yesterday denied charges by a Federal grand jury that they had conspired to violate antitrust laws by fixing prices of gasoline and crude oil. They expressed confidence that they would be cleared of the charges.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., May 9 (AP) -- About 400 National Guardsmen, the last remnant of 10,000 once ordered to active duty in the integration crisis at Central High School, were defederalized and sent home today.
DETROIT, May 29 (AP) -- Tommy Jacobs equaled the course record with an eight-under-par 64 today and grabbed a two-stroke lead after the first round of the $25,000 Western open golf tournament.

WASHINGTON, May 29 -- The United States cautiously maintained a policy of "no comment" on the French crisis today. However, it did deny reports of a possible change in the Western defense set-up in that country.
HAMPTON BEACH, N. H., May 29 (AP) -- A girl was swept out to sea and a marine drowned in a rescue attempt today when caught in an undertow in churning surf.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 29 -- The "Dotto" quiz program soon will be on both the National Broadcasting Company and the Columbia Broadcasting System.

Hundreds of careless and unlucky New Yorkers were jammed into courts yesterday to pay fines for littering the streets. Magistrates and attendants showed up at 8:30 A. M., an hour and a half earlier than usual, to handle the rush.
A Sunday blue law was used yesterday to flag down one of the nation's top sports-car races scheduled on a new Long Island track Sunday.
Things have become a bit complicated with regard to Actors Equity's triennial election for major posts next Friday at the Edison Hotel.

LONDON, May 29 -- The stock market took a turn for the better today. Many groups rallied under the lead of Government securities. However, price changes, particularly among industrials, were often irregular as the rally came too late to erase losses completely.
ALBANY, May 29 -- A special committee urged today that the state's century-old law affecting criminal responsibility of the insane be recast in a more modern and effective form.

PERTH AMBOY, N. J., May 29 -- Vincent Doyle has been supporting his wife and three children on unemployment insurance checks since he was laid off last January from his checker's job at a plastics manufacturing plant here.
WASHINGTON, May 29 (UPI) -- The Senate Rules Committee announced today the selection of artists to paint the portraits of the five outstanding Senators chosen by a special committee last year.

The House of Representatives has done the right thing in voting, 208 to 166, to admit Alaska as the forty-ninth state. History is repeating itself. The House did the same thing eight years ago. What remains to be seen is whether there will be another repetition and this bill, like its predecessor, will die in the Senate.

For all practical purposes Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr. received the Republican nomination yesterday to succeed himself. However, the step was taken over the objection of Thomas J. Curran, New York County Republican leader.
A strike threatened for Monday by 215 employes of the Brooklyn Borough Gas Company was postponed yesterday when their union agreed to extend the present contract to next Friday.

ALGIERS, May 29 -- The insurrectional Committees of Public Safety will continue to function here and on the mainland of France even if Gen. Charles de Gaulle comes to power, the vice president of the all-Algerian committee declared today.

ALGIERS, May 28 -- Brig. Gen. Jacques Massu said today that he believed the army in France was solidly united with the anti-Government movement here and with Gen. Raoul Salan. General Salan is the military ruler of Algeria.

NEW HAVEN, May 29 -- The New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad was ordered by United States District Judge Hobert P. Anderson today to continue service on its Old Colony Line pending another hearing on June 23.

WASHINGTON, May 29 -Senator Stuart Symington charged today that President Eisenhower was "handing military superiority" to the Communist world through indecisive leadership and a policy of "drift and dream."
WASHINGTON, May 29 -Major innovations are emerging here in United States policy toward the economic problems that have embittered relations with Latin America in recent years.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 29 -- Foreign Minister Charles Malik said today that Lebanon might ask for an international commission to police her borders with the United Arab Republic.
Paul Miller, president of the Gannett Newspapers and editor of The Rochester Times-Union, will become chairman of the advisory board of the American Press Institute at Columbia University on July 1.

A team of four "youngsters" that had never won a major bridge contest before early today eliminated one of the nation's top-seeded teams from the Curt Reisinger Trophy contract bridge tournament here.

International political conditions in 1955, as reflected in Paris, form the background of a first novel by Herbert Steinhouse entitled "The Time of the Juggernaut." The annual meeting of the Penn-Texas Corporation, adjourned once since May 5, will be reconvened on Monday, only to be adjourned again until June 16, Wall Street sources said yesterday. Not until then will the final results of a bitter proxy fight be known.

WASHINGTON, May 29 -- The number of workers collecting unemployment insurance declined in the week ended May 17, the Labor Department reported today. It was the fifth week in a row to show a drop.

LONDON, May 29 -- Britain will withdraw 10,000 men from the defense of Europe next year, leaving a total of 45,000 British troops in West Germany.
DETROIT, Friday, May 30 -- The contract between the United Automobile Workers and the General Motors Corporation expired last midnight without a new agreement.
WASHINGTON, May 29 -- Three American producers have underbid a foreign company on an Army Corps of Engineers order for four hydroelectric turbines.
PHILADELPHIA, May 29 (AP) -- Granny Hamner, 31-year-old infielder of the Phillies, probably will be out the rest of the season after an operation today to repair a torn ligament in his left knee.

PHILADELPHIA, May 29 -- To Al Klausman, a 26-year-old New York University outfielder, 13 proved to be a lucky number tonight. GLASGOW, Scotland, May 29 (Reuters) -- Peter Anthony Manuel was found guilty today of seven murders and sentenced to death. He was acquitted of an eighth murder.

JOGJAKARTA, Indonesia May 29 -- President Sukarno and Premier Djuanda participated here this morning in ceremonies marking the completion of the biggest single construction project so far carried out in Indonesia by a Communist-bloc country.
This city is not likely to lose its status as a distressed economic area before August, the Division of Employment of the State Labor Department predicted yesterday.
CHICAGO, May 29 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 29 -Midshipman 1/c John M. Poindexter of Odon, Ind., is the honor man of the United States Naval Academy's class of '58. This was announced today by Rear Admiral W. R. Smedberg 3d, Academy Superintendent.
PARIS, May 29--Gen. Charles de Gaulle agreed tonight to try to form a government, provided it received "full powers" to avert civil war and reform the French Constitution.
WASHINGTON, May 29 -Congress has failed to solve the mystery of just how much the globe-trotting of its own members costs the Government.
THE bush was set up and the beer followed immediately at a traditional roofing party recently in Armonk, N. Y. The bush, or tree, ceremony symbolized that the roof was on and the house was framed.
WASHINGTON, May 29 -- Democratic leaders are preparing to steer through the House an election-year bill to increase Social Security benefits.
A proposal to use the earth's or the sun's spherical shape as a giant lens to penetrate by telescope farther into space has been published by the American Rocket Society.
A series of cultural programs at a junior high school in Harlem had a new twist yesterday.

Frank Pace Jr., former Secretary of the Army, said yesterday he was ready to put up a medal should a golf match between Prime Minister Harold Macmillan of Britain and President Eisenhower materialize.
PARIS, May 29 -- The French Socialist party is playing in the Fourth Republic's current crisis the same central, dominant role it has filled in every political turning point since 1956.

An ultrasonic bath that uses sound waves to "scrub" radioactive particles from the shoes of nuclear plant workers has been introduced by Acoustica Associates, Inc., Mineola, L. I., manufacturer of ultrasonic equipment.

A memorial service, the first in three years, was held yesterday afternoon at the Overseas Press Club, 35 East Thirty-ninth Street. The names of Camille M. Cianfarra, David Seymour and Gaston Madru were added to the eighty-four on the library roll of honor.
Harlem community leaders were given some pointers on how to outwit dishonest merchants yesterday, to pass along to consumers.
TOKYO, May 29 (AP) -- Japan's track stars were slowed to a walk in the final events of the track and field program of the third Asian Games today, but her swimming tide rolled on.
Net free reserves of member banks were little changed on average in the week ended Wednesday, figures published yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York indicated.
LONDON, May 29 (Reuters) -The Big Three Western powers and the Soviet Union have agreed to keep their current series of pre-summit talks confidential, a Foreign Office spokesman said today.
Passenger service on the New York Central Railroad's Putnam Division died last night in its seventy-ninth year.

WASHINGTON, May 29 -- Twenty-nine oil companies, including most of the country's largest, were accused today of having conspired to raise and fix crude oil and gasoline prices after the Suez Canal crisis eighteen months ago.
TRENTON, May 29 -- The creation of a State Court of Workmen's Compensation Appeals was recommended today to cut delays.

More than a month ago Governor Meyner, recognizing the problems of the railroads and the urgency of improved mass transportation, expressed hope that the New Jersey Legislature would approve creation of a Metropolitan Transit District, with thirty-two members representing thirteen counties in New Jersey and New York.
WASHINGTON, May 29 -- The United States hopes to steal the show at the international atoms-for-peace conference by displaying working models of controlled thermonuclear research devices.
AS President of the French National Assembly, Andre Le Troquer stands as second man in the official hierarchy of the Fourth Republic.

CLEVELAND, May 29 (AP) -- The Cleveland Indians tonight released Mike Garcia, who will need surgery to repair a slipped disk in his back, and called up from San Diego 21-year-old Gary Bell, the pitching sensation of the Pacific Coast League this season.

WASHINGTON, May 29 -Moscow's suspension of credits to Yugoslavia has thrown a revealing light on the Soviet Union's contention that its foreign aid carries no political strings, the State Department said today.

WASHINGTON, May 29 (AP) -The Soviet Union has proposed to the United States that the two countries share research information on cancer and heart disease and form Soviet-American teams to fight malaria and smallpox in Africa and South America.

The International Harvester Company increased earnings in the quarter ended April 30 about 14 per cent above those a year ago, despite a 5 per cent drop in sales, Frank W. Jenks, president, reported yesterday. Both sales and earnings for the half year were less than those in the similar period last year.

WASHINGTON May 29 (UPI) -- Two Senators chided the House Committee on Un-American Activities today for having issued a subpoena for Cyrus S. Eaton, Cleveland industrialist. They voiced the hope that it would not be served.

Today's new film is "High School Confidential," a Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer drama, at Loew's State. Russ Tamblyn, Jan Sterling and Mamie Van Doren head the cast. Jack Arnold directed and Albert Zugsmith produced, from a scenario by Lewis Meltzer and Robert Blees. Miss Sterling is scheduled to make a personal appearance in the lobby at 2:30 P. M.

The editor-president of The Arkansas Gazette, 85 - year - old John N. Heiskell, accepted yesterday the first Columbia Journalism Award. He was honored for "singular journalistic performance in the public interest."

WASHINGTON, May 29 -- The President's "quick impressions" of the House committee's Pentagon reorganization bill and his mature conclusions were as different as the coo of the dove and the roar of the tiger. On May 16 he congratulated Chairman Vinson and the committee.

Led by Henry Korn, Archbisop Stepinac of White Plains, N. Y., yesterday took an early lead in the annual Catholic High Schools Athletic Association track and field championships at Downing Stadium, Randalls Island.

KUALA LUMPUR, Malaya, May 29 -- Malaya does not favor an international agreement to stabilize the price of rubber, an international rubber study group conference sitting in Hamburg June 9 will be told.
Indications pointed yesterday to a meeting next week between officers of the Trasnport Workers Union and the Motormen's Benevolent Association to work out merger terms.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., May 29 -- The Storm Trysail Club's thirteenth Block Island race, the East's first bluewater event of 1958, started off Larchmont Yacht Club early this evening. There was a record number of 101 starters from an entry of 114 cruising yachts.
I find it surprising that The New York Times should be so anxious to endorse whatever the Port of New York Authority proposes and to object whenever a voice in protest is raised.
SALT - WATER fishermen who intend to infest Long Island waters this long week-end had better not expect accommodations anywhere without advance booking.

THE Watusi tribesmen in Africa are tall enough to be basketball players since many of them are 7-footers. For decades stories have been emerging from the bush country that these long, lean and supple natives clear as much as 8 feet in the high jump.
WASHINGTON, May 29 -- A global build-up for Vice President Richard M. Nixon at the taxpayer's expense was charged today by Democrats.
As General de Gaulle undertakes to form a new government the National Assembly and the people of France have to make their choice between accepting him and inviting chaos.

The city condemned four and a half acres of the old Five Points slum yesterday. It resold the site and its decrepit buildings to a nonprofit corporation that will construct 420 apartments for middle-income families.
BONN, Germany, May 29 -- The crisis in France has touched off a new flight to the Deutsche mark.
Two New York unionists, accused by Senate rackets investigators of misusing funds and exploiting members, face a call before a county grand jury here next week.
PARIS, May 29 -- Much of the drama and comedy of a republic uncertain of how much longer it would live was played within the grimy and almost windowless walls of the National Assembly today.

There was good news for Casey Stengel yesterday on his arrival by plane with the Yankees from Kansas City. Bill Skowron, the Yankee manager was informed, will be in uniform today when the Bombers oppose the Washington Senators in a double-header at the Stadium.

A horse race comparable in spectator appeal to a fight between Carmen Basillo and Sugar Ray Robinson will be run at Belmont Park today. Bold Ruler, who campaigns in the silks of the Wheatley Stable, will oppose Ralph Lowe's Gallant Man. It will be the seventh time the horses have opposed each other.

Polish ships will get only a small share of the estimated total of $7,000,000 to be spent on ocean freight rates for cargo shipments from this country to Poland this year.

A 50-year-old physician who made $17,000 over four years by dispensing narcotics without prescriptions was sentenced yesterday by Federal Judge Edward Weinfeld to six months in prison and fined $5,000. He had pleaded guilty to income tax evasion charges.
WASHINGTON, May 29 -- The Department of Justice decided today to take no antitrust action against the merger of The United Press and International News Service.

The Unknown Soldier of World War I who will be joined today in Arlington National Cemetery by unknown service men from two later wars was selected in the French city of Chalons-sur-Marne at 10 o'clock in the morning of Oct. 24, 1921.

WASHINGTON, May 29 -- An Administration supporter told the Senate today it should not reduce the foreign aid authorization in "spiteful vengeance" for recent anti-United States demonstrations overseas.

WASHINGTON, May 29 -- The Columbia Broadcasting System and one of its affiliated television stations were sued on antitrust charges today by a competing station, which lost the C. B. S. affiliation this year.

LONDON, May 29 -- The first list of donations for the establishment of a science college at Cambridge to be named for Sir Winston Churchill totals 1,411,900 (nearly $4,000,000), it was announced today.

KUALA LUMPUR, Malaya, May 29 -- The United States Government has proposed an investment guarantee agreement to the Federation of Malaya to encourage private capital and protect investors. The United States Ambassador here, Homer M. Byington Jr., disclosed the plan in a speech in Ipoh tonight.
WESTFIELD, N. J., May 30 -- A business man here at the age of 54 is fulfilling a boyhood ambition to be a clergyman.

VILLANOVA, Pa., May 30 -Don McGorty of Manhattan and John Lawlor of Boston University set meet records in today's trial competition of the eighty-second annual Intercollegiate Association of Amateur Athletes of America track and field championships.
NEW ORLEANS, May 30 (UPI) -- A Federal judge ordered New Orleans today to remove racial barriers on buses and and streetcars, effective tonight.

LONG BEACH, Calif., May 30 (AP) -- Douglas Aircraft Company realized its jet age dream today as its big DC-8 jetliner, trailing billows of black exhaust smoke, roared smoothly into the sky on its maiden flight. The four engine craft, designed to carry 176 passengers across the nation in 4 1/2 hours, took off from Municipal Airport as smartly as though it had done so many times before.

SOMERVILLE, N. J., May 30 (AP) -- Art Longsjo of Fitchburg, Mass., averaged nearly twentyfive miles per hour today to win the fifteenth annual KuglerAnderson Memorial fifty-mile bicycle race. LONDON, May 30 -- The stock market here finished a quiet week on a more confident note than at the start. Most groups maintained the better trend begun yesterday.

WESTBURY, L. I., May 30 -Robert Metzner's Corsican set a world record for a 3-year-old gelding on a half-mile track tonight when he paced a mile in 2:01 4/5 before the season's top crowd of 39,480 fans at Roosevelt Raceway. The previous record was 2:02 2/5.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 30 -Pat O'Connor, one of America's most popular auto-race drivers, was killed today in an accident involving thirteen cars on the first lap of the 500-mile race here. The race was won by Jimmy Bryan of Phoenix, Ariz.

PARIS, May 30 (UPI) -- The Australian team of Mrs. Thelma Long and Mrs. Mary Hawton and the Mexican team of Rosa Maria Reyes and Yola Ramirez gained the final round of women's doubles in the French hard-court tennis championship today. Other scheduled matches were washed out by rain.

CAMDEN, N. J., May 30 (AP) -- B. A. Dario's Venomous scored her second victory of the season when she outgamed Harriet Robinson's Fall Wind to the wire in the $29,550 Colonial Handicap today at Garden State Park.
A building superintendent was stabbed to death in an East Harlem srteet last night and his wife was seriously clashed.
LONDON, May 30 (Reuters)--Most West European Governments withheld official comment today as Gen. Charles de Gaulle moved toward the helm of the French Government.
Fordham Prep captured the title yesterday in the thirteenth annual track and field championships of the Jesuit high schools at Van Cortlandt Park Stadium, the Bronx.

HONOLULU, May 30 -- A thirty-second warning saved eighty-two Navy men yesterday when the submarine Stickleback was rammed by the destroyer escort Silverstein. The accident occurred nineteen miles southwest of Pearl Harbor during a training exercise.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 30 -Jimmy Bryan is a rugged Southwesterner, sandy haired, ruddy from the sun and wind of the Arizona desert and the mountains. He stands 6 feet 1 inch and there is a pleasant cowboyish drawl in his speech, especially when he speaks of Luella. Luella is his wife and the mother of their year-old daughter Stephanie.

PITTSBURGH, May 30 (AP) -Outlasting Milwaukee in a see-saw slugging match, the Pittsburgh Pirates took the nightcap of a doubleheader, 12 -- 6, today. The Braves rallied in the ninth inning for a 7-4 victory in the opener.
The president of a Long Island sports-car organization asserted yesterday that races definitely would be held tomorrow at Bridgehampton, despite a Sunday blue-law ban on them.
TOKYO, May 30 (AP) -- Japan monopolized swimming, shooting and women's tennis today in the Asian Games.

NEW DELHI, May 30 -- The three foreign oil companies operating in India have announced a "substantial" reduction in prices of petroleum products. But the reduction will not be passed on to the consumer.

BEIRUT, May 30 -- The Lebanese Army moved tanks today against rebels in Tripoli. Other heavy weapons were moved up. Artillery was said to be in use, but up to tonight there had been no strong engagement.
Jan Sterling will make a personal appearance at 2:30 P. M. today in the lobby of Loew's State, where "High School Confidential," featuring the actress, opened yesterday.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 30 -- The Security Council was summoned today to meet at 11 A. M. Monday on a comlaint by Tunisia and a countercomplaint by France.

DEVON, Pa., May 30 -- Cameda, a bay gelding owned by Mrs. Winston Guest of New York City, captured the Bryn Du Farm Challenge Championship Trophy for young hunters at the sixty-second annual Devon Horse Show today.

BUENOS AIRES, May 30 -- A Federal judge upheld today a charge of treason against Juan D. Peron, making the former Argentine dictator ineligible for the amnesty voted into law last week by Congress.

This is the time of the year when the traveler along the highway about dusk learns the meaning of that highly scented phrase, the perfumed air. It is honeysuckle time almost everywhere in America from the valley to the mountain top. The perfume is delicate and may follow a traveler for miles, whether he takes the high road or the low road.

TIFLIS, U. S. S. R., May 30 -- If you ever travel to this mountain-girt capital of the Georgian Republic on business, don't arrange to transact it at lunch. Georgians have a special brand of hospitality that makes failure to transact business utterly painless.

SURBITON, England, May 30 (UPI) -- Althea Gibson and Mimi Arnold, rapidly rounding into top form for next month's Wimbledon championships, set up an all-American women's singles final in the Surrey lawn tennis championships today by sweeping to four straight-set victories.

New capital funds that became available to the economy in the first quarter of this year from life insurance assets totaled $1,342,000,000, the Institute of Life Insurance reported yesterday. This was an increase of $112,000,000, or 9 per cent, compared with the like 1957 period.

STAMFORD, Conn., May 31 -- The Storm Trysail Club's yacht race around Block Island, which had begun with a fine flourish of northwest wind Thursday evening, Was in the process of being completed today on a sour note of light airs.

Eight fishermen and a 10-year-old boy, who had gone fishing off Atlantic Highlands, N. J., ended up in the water yesterday when their boat caught fire. All were rescued by another fishing boat after forty-five minutes.

THE chairman of London Transport, Sir John Elliot, is a man with a hobby: to track down the actual relics of the French Revolution in the Paris of today. In his diligent quest of minute picturesque details, he reminds the reader of the historical writer, Georges Lenotre, and the artist, Georges Cain.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: May I congratulate you on the excellent article by Homer Bigart which appeared on May 25 in The Times, "New Law Is Slow to Admit Aliens." The facts reported are indeed accurate.
William R. Adams, a former star football tackle, is now grappling with the task of guiding the third largest company in the nation's fifth largest industry.

AMATEUR choristers like a demanding taskmaster, a conductor who drives them so hard they sing better than they dreamed they could. This is the experience of David Randolph, who is now rehearsing his Masterwork Chorus of Morristown, N. J., for its spring festival presentation of Bach's "Passion According to St. John."

SAN FRANCISCO, May 31 -- Next Tuesday will be a critical day in this political "year of decision" in California. It will mark the first officially conducted popularity contest between Senator William F. Knowland, Republican candidate for Governor, and Attorney General Edmund G. (Pat) Brown, his Democratic rival.
PARIS, May 31 -- If the streets of Paris were calm at 7:10 P. M. today, the garden of the Elysee Palace was not. A small "riot" was in full swing at that moment at the Presidential residence.

ST. LOUIS, May 31 -- Ken Boyer clouted Stu Miller's first pitch in the twelfth inning today for a home run that fashioned a 10-9 victory for the St. Louis Cardinals over the stumbling San Francisco Giants.

Son of an Irish-Protestant banker and a Roman Catholic mother, Desmond Stanley Farquahar is sent, by parental compromise, to Midhurst, an English Catholic school "where English monks would be careful to see that you acquired English, not Irish, ways."
CHICAGO, May 31 (AP) -- Chicagoans paid their final visits to Samuel Cardinal Stritch as he lay today amid familiar surroundings of high-vaulted Holy Name Roman Catholic Cathedral.

WASHINGTON, May 31 (AP) -- Western Union Telegraph Company and the Commercial Telegraphers Union agreed in principle late today on a new contract, averting the threat of a nation-wide strike.

ALUMINUM doors, windows, awnings and furniture have become increasingly popular because this metal does not rust or corrode like iron or steel. It can be exposed without having to be painted periodically.

THE North Shore Community Arts Center in Roslyn, L. I., announces the first Edward Weston Memorial exhibition, to open Friday evening and continue through June 26. Thirty original prints will be shown.

Thigpen and Dr. Hervey M. Cleckley, reported on it first in a clinical paper published in a professional journal.
YORKVILLE, N. Y., May 31 -- Gifted children in this Utica suburb will have a chance this summer to examine new fields of thought.

SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., May 31 -- Mount Holyoke College announced today the election of Mrs. Mare de Ferranti of Pittsfield as president of the Alumnae Association.

THE review by Arthur S. Link of Herbert Hoover's "The Ordeal of Woodrow Wilson" states that apparently no former occupant of the Executive Mansion has written about other former Presidents. John Quincy Adams wrote "A Life of James Monroe" in 1831 and "The Life of James Madison" in 1836.

DETROIT, May 31 (AP) -- Three former collegiate golfers -- Dow Finsterwald, Mike Souchak and Dave Ragan -- turned in blazing sub-par performances today and produced a three-way deadlock for the lead in the third round of the $25,000 Western open tournament.

A LINKING of the liberal tradition in religion with the democratic tradition in politics has been so much a part of our cultural history for so long that a challenge to it is almost shocking. The idea that man is basically good and is infinitely capable of self-improvement seems to some a necessary premise to the idea that all men share the "unalienable Rights" of Life, Liberty and the Pursuit of Happiness."
WASHINGTON, May 31 (AP) -- A private study published today said communism was threatening the West through an economic offensive characterized by hard-headed business techniques.

Discovery of two new hormones secreted by human glands, both of which may be found to play important roles in the chemistry of life in health and disease, were announced last week by workers in two American institutions.

Business executives who have discovered that they need broader training are going to school again to catch up. At the same time undergraduates who expect to become executives are taking business administration courses at a rate that has no equal in this country. It has been estimated that one out of every eight students in American colleges and universities is enrolled in an administration course.

Retail sales in the Kansas City area showed good gains last week compared with volume of a year ago, when business lagged. Gains ranging from 5 to 15 per cent were reported in a number of cities. Compared with sales in the preceding week, however, volume was down, owing to the Memorial Day interruption.
MOUNT KISCO, May 31 -- Every weekday John Metz throws an assortment of strange-looking objects into his blue station wagon and drives along the Post Road and its byways for a hundred miles or so.

Supplications rain upon the heads of harried travel agency clerks; brochures, maps and guidebooks clog office desks and add to the drag of the postman's sack; various destinations are examined, weighed for their fun-content, then stamped "approved for this year"

MOSCOW, May 31 (UPI) -- Premier Khrushchev left Moscow today aboard a Soviet TU-104 jet airliner for a previously unannounced visit to Bulgaria.

WHEN President Eisenhower last week signed the bill advancing certain postage rates, as legislated by Congress, changes became necessary in the stamp-issuing plans of the Post Office Department and the United Nations. Both Washington and the United Nations will be obliged to issue new postal paper.
WASHINGTON, May 31 -- Eight months after the first Soviet satellite caused this country to take stock of itself, little has been done to remedy the weaknesses in its educational system.
James C. Petrillo insisted yesterday that he would not yield to a draft movement at the convention of the American Federation of Musicians, opening in Philadelphia tomorrow.
CARACAS, Venezuela, May 31 (AP) -- A Cabinet minister said today Venezuela would ask the United States to turn over Marcos Perez Jimenez, former dictator of Venezuela, for trial as a common criminal.

The twelve-nation Soviet bloc went to great lengths last week to give the world a picture of complete and firm unity contrasting sharply with the West's evident confusion and disorder because of the crisis in France. The Association of Hungarian Students in the U. S., Inc., numbering more than 1,800 refugees, will hold its second congress June 8-11 at Purdue University, Lafayette, Ind. JAKARTA, Indonesia, May 31 -- The suppression of news organizations and arrests of newsmen have become so commonplace in Jakarta that these actions are taken almost as a matter of course.
Representatives of twenty-one men's apparel concerns, from as many countries, recently completed an exchange of fashion ideas and technical information in Germany.

THE resignation of John Nicholls as secretary to the British Board of Film Censors after only fifteen months in office came as a sharp climax to the controversy that has been boiling up over the functioning of censorship in general.

WARSAW -- A new hotel the Grand, has been built in Warsaw and some of the older ones have been refurbished in anticipation of an increase in tourism this year. Poland is aware that it cannot yet offer travelers the ultimate in luxury, but a good deal of effort is being made to show that visitors are welcomed.
Commencement week of the 204th academic year at Columbia University will begin today when undergraduates in cap and gown attend a baccalaureate service in St. Paul's Chapel on the Morningside campus.
LONDON, May 31 (Reuters) -- John Masefield, who is paid for singing the praises of the Queen but is famous for his verses about the sea, will be 80 years old tomorrow.

RADIO has not occasioned much excitement for a long time but it did last Monday evening. Van Cliburn's concert at Carnegie Hall was carried live for more than two and a half hours by station WQXR and it was the week's event, television or no television.

SIDNEY HOOK's review of Fred J. Cook's "The Unfinished Case of Alger Hiss" summarizes most of the contradictory evidence which has raised doubts, both here and abroad, as to Hiss' guilt, and then, without destroying any of it which is favorable to the defendant, arrives at what has all the earmarks of a preconceived opinion of his guilt.

PARIS, May 31 -- General Charles de Gaulle is bidding for power in France by constitutional processes he despises and will undobudtedly seek to change.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, May 31 (AP) -- Language riots raged in eastern and northern Ceylon today.

Deposits in the nation's 520 mutual savings banks increased $92,000,000 in April to $32,400,000,000, continuing the trend begun in December, 1957, the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks has reported. In the first four months of the year deposits have increased $811,000,000.

LONDON, May 31 -- Michael Foot, a Left-Wing British journalist, was expelled from France today on charges of having insulted President Rene Coty. He arrived here tonight.

WHITE PLAINS, June 1 -Merchants and homeowners here will have their first opportunity tomorrow night to attack formally a proposed multi-milliondollar shopping and business center near the Hutchinson River Parkway in the northeast section of the city.
Cutler-Hammer, Inc., Milwaukee maker of electrical control equipment, has acquired Airborne Instruments Laboratory, Inc., of Mineola, L. I., electronics concern.
The Village Independent Democrats, an insurgent club in the First Assembly District, announced yesterday that they would challenge the regular Tammany Hall candidates in the primary Aug. 12.
CHICAGO, June 1 (AP) -Traders in grain futures had their market hitched last week to weather reports and forecasts. No other influence in weeks has moved the prices so decisively.
WASHINGTON, June 1 -High ranking Army officials believe they are gaining ground in their advocacy of a policy of being prepared for limited war.
WASHINGTON, June 1 -- If Alaska makes it into the Union this year, much of the credit should go to Fred A. Seaton for keeping President Eisenhower in line.

Support for State Senator Walter J. Mahoney of Buffalo as the Republican nominee for Governor spread eastward over the week-end. Heretofore backing for the Senate leader was concentrated in western New York.
The steamship charter market was virtually nonexistent last week as two holidays, one on either side of the Atlantic, sharply curtailed activity.
The forty-first season of Guggenheim Memorial Concerts played by the Goldman Band, under the direction of Richard Franko Goldman, will open Wednesday, June 18, on the Mall in Central Park.

A medical research program equal to the Manhattan Project, which gave the United States the first atom bomb, was recommended yesterday by Mrs. Albert D. Lasker, chairman of the National Health Education Committee.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, June 1 -While the Ceylonese Goverment continued its week-old fight against communist riots and subversive elements, it decided today to transport about 12,000 refugees to their homes.

ALGIERS, June 1 -- Jacques Chevallier, liberal Mayor of Algiers, today endorsed a federal solution of the Algerian problem under the sponsorship of Gen. Charles de Gaulle. In doing so he gave a new turn to the term "integration," which has been publicized here as a magic formula for settling the issue.
The French Parliament is scheduled to be packed off on vacation by Gen. Charles de Gaulle amid general agreement that its departure will be an important date in the history o the Fourth Republic.

There are a number of enterprises in our community which by their very nature never show a profit. No one expects them to: hospitals, for example, or museums. And though this might surprise some people, symphony orchestras are among them.

SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., June 1 -- America's "cultural ambassadors" were praised today by Norman Cousins, editor of The Saturday Review, in an address at the commencement exercises of Mount Holyoke College.

Sales and earnings of Federated Department Stores, Inc., for the quarter ended May 3 were below those for the similar period of last year. But the figures for the fifty-two weeks ended May 3 showed gains, according to the report of Fred Lazarus Jr., chairman, issued for publication today.
LONDON, June 1 -- The French political situation and industrial unrest at home kept the stock markets subdued last week.
The cotton futures market firmed a bit last week. The New York Cotton Exchange was closed on Friday because of the Memorial Day holiday.
ROME, June 1 -- A group of archaeological experts working in a cave at Sperlonga are patiently piecing together more than 12,000 fragments of ancient Greek statuary.

IN March, 1949, "an insignificant physiotherapist from Simla" journeyed by train, automobile and sedan chair to Katmandu, the capital of Nepal. There in that isolated mountain kingdom Erika Leuchtag enjoyed the supreme emotional experience of her life. She had gone to give massage treatments to Her Majesty the Senior Queen Kanti Raja Lalshi, but it wasn't her professional ministrations that made her life exciting.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- Administration supporters hope to see the $3,068,900,000 authorization for foreign aid safely through the Senate this week. They will then concentrate on getting the five-year foreign trade extension through the House of Representatives.
Colorado plans to sell $5,000,000 of highway fund revenue anticipation warrants on July 1. The obligations will come due serially on Jan. 1 from 1960 to 1974.
Students on the Columbia University campus were told yesterday that America's primary needs were human sympathy and greater imagination in dealing with the peoples of the world.

The case for simplification and abbreviation of the New York State Constitution, now ten times the length of the charter that originally launched the state government on its course, is convincingly proved by a document published today by the special legislative committee on revision familiarly known as the Nelson Rockefeller commission.
BALTIMORE, June 1 (AP) -The Washington Senators scored three runs in the fifth inning and defeated the Orioles, 5 -- 2, today.
AJACCIO, Corsica, June 1 (Reuters) -- This normally quiet birthplace of Napoleon Bonaparte went wild tonight with the news that another military leader had come to power in France.

An electronic device to reduce a pilot's mathematical chores has been ordered by American Airlines for installation on its fleet of Boeing 707 jet airliners due to start service before the year's end.
Two pipeline companies building a 1,516-mile natural gas pipeline from southern Texas to Miami, Fla., have agreed to merge, it was announced yesterday.
PHILADELPHIA, June 1 -The strike against three metropolitan Philadelphia newspapers continued tonight with plans being laid for mediation of the disputes.

PARIS, June 1 -- Gen. Charles de Gaulle's fifteen-member Cabinet includes at its head four Ministers of State, prominent party leaders who will be acting as the Premier's top political advisers without having the responsibility for specific ministries.
Summer is coming and with it a splurge of strong color for city wear to counterbalance black.
LENINGRAD, June 1 -- Eugene Ormandy and the Philadelphia Orchestra tonight conquered the third city of their tour through the Soviet Union.

COMPIEGNE, France, June 1 (Reuters) -- John Rodgers, 33-year-old American-born garage manager, rested at home at Compiegne north of Paris today after having been beaten by two Algerian agents and spent the night bound hand and foot.
ALGECIRAS, Spain, June 1 (UPI) -- Former President Harry S. Truman arrived in Europe today and described Gen. Charles de Gaulle as the man to "save" France.

PARIS, June 1 -- Communist-inspired riots erupted in Paris today a few hours before the National Assembly voted to install Gen. Charles de Gaulle as Premier. The outbreaks started at 3 P. M. in workingclass quarters in northern, eastern and southern section of the city.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 1 -The most important churchman in Lebanon has stirred a new storm in the country's internal troubles. It is almost as if the Pope had stepped into a European political crisis.

New York all-star teams fashioned a notable "first" yesterday for local followers of Gaelic football and hurling. Competing against the AllIreland champions in the two sports, the New York fifteens whipped Kilkenny in hurling, 30 -- 15, and Louth in football, 24 -- 14.
An Australian adventurer returned to New York yesterday in an amphibious jeep called the Half Safe that has taken him around the world on a ten-year odyssey.
NEW HAVEN, June 1 -- Yale will seek $69,000,000 in the next five years in a series of drives to meet the university's most urgent needs.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 1 -- Dr. Wernher von Braun, the Army's German-born missile expert, will have his life dramatized in a film to be released by Columbia Pictures. The biographical drama is to be coproduced by Charles Schneer of Morningside International Productions, an American company, and Friedrich Mainz of Rhomas Films, a Germany company with headquarters in Munich.

CHICAGO, June 1 (AP) -- Twenty-one-year-old Stan Williams of the Los Angeles Dodgers, a 6-foot 4-inch righthander, turned his first major league start into a two-hit 1-0 shutout victory over the Chicago Cubs today. Williams, a native of Enfield, N. H., walked two and fanned three. He hit one batsman.

Youth won last night when the contract bridge team of Victor Mitchell and Jacqueline Gallaher, both of New York, won the Julian Goldman Cup. It was Miss Gallaher's first major competition and victory.
Retailers are paying their bills for merchandise and other supplies a little faster than a year ago.
Thornton Wilder's "Our Town" was pictured as a parable of the "eternity in everyday events" of the Rev. William B. Glenesk as a sermon yesterday.
AMSTERDAM, June 1 -- By adding to its gold stocks and converting dollars into gold, the Netherlands Bank's reserves have reached a new high.

Many non-Catholics fear the Roman Catholic Church because they consider it "a mysterious, totalitarian organization which binds the intellect of her members with chains of dogma," the Rev. Bernard P. Donachie said yesterday. He spoke at the 10 A. M. solemn mass at St. Patrick's Cathedral.

FINE weather yesterday afternoon brought to Washington Square a large crowd, for whom the Chamber Brass Players had the interesting idea of playing a program of "tower music" from the six-story tower of New York University's Judson Residence.
TUNIS, June 1 -- Tunisian troops fired today on three French planes that "violated Tunisian air space" in the Gabes region, a Government spokesman said tonight.
K. M. Kuenster's criticism in her recent letter on the Albert Einstein award to Dr. Edward Teller demands a reply.
PARIS, Monday, June 2 -Following is the breakdown of the National Assembly vote investing Gen. Charles de Gaulle as Premier.
CHARLOTTE AMALIE, V. I., June 1 -- Conrad L. Wirth, director of the National Park Service, will visit the Virgin Islands in November to plan the development of the Virgin Islands National Park.

The five-story apartment building at 2604 University Avenue in the Bronx has been purchased by Geisinger Germain, real estate operators, from the Erda Realty Corporation. Leonard, Levites Schiller were the brokers in the transaction.

THE ability to sew a fine seam will be worth $25,000 at a dressmaking contest being held this week at B. Altman Co.
The annual parade is on -- the parade of boys from 14 to 17 years of age asking "Do you know where I can get a job for the summer?"
BASTIA, Corsica, June 2 (Reuters) -- Col. Robert Thomazo, "governor" of this French island, said today public safety committees in Corsica had no power except to make recommendations.
A former Dominican Republic publisher has asserted that Dr. Galindez left that country because of Generalissimo Trujillo's wrath over his pro-labor activities.
TUNIS, June 2 -- Tunisia let it be known today that she was willing to make the port of Bizerte available for Western defense.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- A House investigation heard new testimony today of frequent behindthe-scenes contacts with Federal Communications Commission members on behalf of applicants for contested television channels.

The recently organized processing cooperative, California Canners and Growers, San Francisco, has purchased all the common stock of Richmond-Chase Company and the Filice Perrelli Canning Company for $19,000,000. The purchase price included more than $7,000,00 in working capital.
MONTREAL, June 2 (Canadian Press) -- The International Civil Aviation Organization has agreed to grant the United States a reduction in its annual contribution to the organization.

Plans to merge the Motormen's Benevolent Association with the Transport Workers Union moved a step closer to realization last night. The executive board Of the T. W. U.'s New York local gave unanimous approval to a tentative peace formula.
Early yesterday Audrey Beise, a blonde young woman from Duluth, Minn., ate a quick breakfast at the Grosvenor Hotel on lower Fifth Avenue and headed uptown to spend a fortune on clothes.

KIAMESHA LAKE, N. Y., June 2 -- Criticism of religious leaders of the major faiths for "failing to react with goodwill and tolerance" in meeting the issue of religion in public schools was voiced here today.
WASHINGTON, June 2 (UPI) -- A House Foreign Affairs subcommittee announced today that it would begin hearings tomorrow on the state of the United States' relations with Latin America.

In the conviction sure to have a sympathetic hearing from many fellow Republicans that "New York needs a new Governor," Leonard W. Hall of Oyster Bay, L. I., has announced his candidacy for the Republican nomination to oppose Governor Harriman.
A German shepherd dog was praised in court yesterday when a magistrate learned that it had captured a youth accused of breaking into a Bronx store.

Dick Chapman, a 47-year-old former United States and British amateur champion, set the pace with a score of 136 in the metropolitan district qualifying trials yesterday for the United States Open Golf championship.

Pearl Berger, soprano, made her New York debut last night at Carnegie Recital Hall in a program that ranged from S. Liddle's "The Lord is My Shepherd" to "Porgi amor" from Mozart's "Marriage of Figaro" and "Pace, pace" from Verdi's "La Forza del Destino."

OTTAWA, June 2 (Canadian Press) -- The Government to,lay linformed Parliament that it i would require $58,151,061 more in estimated expenditures for ,the current fiscal year, increas:ing anticipated outlays to a record of about $5,800,000,000. The Government also aslsed approval of $27,573,001 in new loans for the financing of CaInadian.wheat sales to Colombo Plan countries and for various i Canadian construction projects.
DETROIT, June 2 -- The Big Three in the auto industry reported normal operations today as auto workers put in their first regular day without a contract.

LONDON, June 2 (Reuters) -- The Bulgarian Communist party chief, Todor Zhivkov, lashed out at the "approaching threat of fascism" in France as the Seventh Congress of the Bulgarian Communist party opened today in Sofia.

LOS ANGELES, June 2 -- The citizens of the nation's thirdranking and most unpredictable metropolis will vote tomorrow on whether the city should repudiate the deal under which the Dodgers moved here from Brooklyn last winter.

Paul Green, weaver of patriotic spectacles, has come up with another one. The latest written by the Pulitzer Prize winner is "The Confederacy."

MANCHESTER, England, June 2 (UPI) -- Karol Fageros abandoned her controversial gold lame tennis panties for a conventional costume today and advanced to the second round of the Northern lawn tennis tournament. She defeated Valerie Stott of England, 6 -- 0, 6 -- 2.

The Smithsonian Astrophysical Observatory in Cambridge, Mass., has reported completion of its global network of twelve giant satellite-tracking cameras.

CARACAS, Venezuela, June 2 -- The Venezuelan petroleum industry, now experiencing a slight recession, made a net profit last year of about $829,500,000, an increase of $160,000,000 over 1956. Its gross income amounted to $2,450,000,000, a gain of about $390,000,000.

The Times of May 22 reported that the family of the 2 1/2-year-old girl killed by a lion in Washington's zoo plans to file suit. The grandmother stated, "Nothing will do us any good, but it will make the zoo safe for little children."

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- Officials of the International Monetary Fund, following custom, refused comment today on any impending transactions. However, they did not deny that Brazil would be allowed to withdraw an additional onefourth of her quota, making three-fourths in all.
WASHINGTON, June 2 (AP) -Legislation for a Federal dam at Hells Canyon, the subject of a private-vs-public power controversy, apparently was killed today for at least this session of Congress.
WASHINGTON, June 2 -Only one of fourteen corporation and bank executives responding to a recent Senate inquiry advocated an antirecession tax cut, it was disclosed today.
Good news concerning steel, base metals and unemployment sent the stock market up yesterday. Common stocks listed on the New York Stock Exchange gained more than $1,000,000,000 in market value.

The highway toll mounted sharply late Sunday night to set a record of 371 persons killed on a three-day Memorial Day week-end.
The nation's principal stock automobile liability insurance companies reported a 1957 loss of $147,000,000 yesterday.
Cocoa prices moved in wide ranges yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange. The market opened higher on speculator buying and trade hedge lifting, reflecting strength in London.

"THE DECLINE OF THE AMERICAN MALE" is perhaps the most stirring war book of the year. The war it dramatizes is the one that the incomparable James Thurber has called The War Between Men and Women. The authors, obviously veterans of many a campaign, bivouac and skirmish, are William Attwood, George B. Leonard Jr. and Robert Moskin.
Owners of lumber yards were warned yesterday by Fire Commissioner Edward F. Cavanagh Jr. to clean up their premises to guard against fires.
TRENTON, June 2 -- The Port of New York Authority declared today that the enactment of a pending Assembly bill would destroy its multi-million dollar highway and bridge construction program.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 2 -- Twentieth Century-Fox has decided to overhaul its television subsidiary, T. C. F.-TV, and put it under the supervision of Martin Manulis, producer of "Playhouse 90."

Sales of the eight major department stores in the New York metropolitan area were higher in May, on the average, than in 1957. Sales were 1 per cent higher than a year before, according to a survey yesterday by The New York Times.

Improved public transit is needed to relieve traffic congestion in the nation's large cities, Donald C. Hyde, general manager of the Cleveland Transit System, said yesterday. He addressed a regional conference of the American Transit Association at the New Yorker Hotel.

CHICAGO, June 2 (AP) -- A broadside of selling hit the grain futures pits of the Board of Trade today and prices sagged all along the line, some rather sharply.

Boy Scouts were briefed yesterday by Traffic Commissioner T. T. Wiley on the part they will play in the safety campaign starting Saturday. The session took place in the Commissioner's office at 100 Gold Street.

FROM such scattered points as Nigeria, Australia, Jamaica and Chile, eleven women gathered in a Columbia University test kitchen yesterday. Surprisingly, not one of them uttered an "oh" or an "ah" when they saw the sleek-lined refrigerators and the latest in kitchen ranges.

Columbia University's commencement will take place today, at 3 P. M. on the Morningside Heights campus. More than 6,000 students from fifteen schools and colleges of the university and its four affiliated institutions will receive degrees.

An important announcement has been made by the Lister Institute of Preventive Medicine in London. Its scientists have made a successful culture of the virus that causes trachoma, one of the world's most bitter scourges. This is the first essential step in the development of a prophylactic anti-trachoma vaccine.

ABINGDON, Va., June 2 -An award presentation party for Ralph Bellamy planned next Sunday by the Barter Theatre of Virginia has been called off because of lack of local support.

The executive committee of the Liberal party in New York County last night unanimously endorsed City Councilman Earl Brown for the Harlem Congressional seat now held by Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr.

Prof. William Caruth MacTavish, who has served New York University for fifty years, will perform his final academic duty tomorrow before retiring to become professor emeritus of chemistry. He will carry the torch in the academic procession of the school's 126th commencement on the University Heights campus.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange declined 6 to 33 points yesterday. The new October was weakest.
RIO DE JANEIRO, June 2 -The International Monetary Fund is expected to authorize Brazil this week to withdraw $37,500,000 from her quota to help meet her financial crisis.
WASHINGTON, June 2 -President Eisenhower is now "reasonably optimistic" that talks with the Soviet Union on ways to supervise a nuclear test ban can begin this month.
Bowlers shouldn't lose hope of bowling a perfect game. There's just enough room on the forty-two inches between gutters to change the approach and turn a poor session into a perfect one.
WASHINGTON, June 2 (AP) -The trend to bank mergers and the spread of branch banking continued apace last year, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation reported today.

"Darwin's Century," a new book by Loren Eiseley, will be issued June 27 by Doubleday. Subtitled "Evolution and the Men Who Discovered It," it traces the slow acceptance of the theory of evolution that had been foreshadowed two centuries earlier, Mr. Eiseley, head of the Department of Anthropology at the University of Pennsylvania, is the author of "The Immense Journey," which was published last year by Random House.
PARIS, June 2 -- Calm returned to Paris today and no one seemed to want to disturb the peace.
HANOVER, Mass., June 2 -A German-born student has been denied the annual Girls State Award for this town because she is not a United States citizen.
It was a rare day yesterday -- for June or any other month -- at the city's Marriage License Bureau in Room 258 of the Municipal Building.
Burglars ransacked the suite of an advertising executive in Hampshire House, 150 Central Park South, and stole gems valued at $40,000 over the weekend.
BERLIN, June 2 (AP) -- East Germany announced tonight that a Belgian Atlantic pact photo plane that vanished with its pilot last Thursday had been forced to land in East Germany.
WASHINGTON, June 2 (AP) -The Association of American Railroads today estimated the net income of Class I carriers in April at $16,000,000. This compares with $61,000,000 a year earlier.
ALGIERS, June 2 -- Brig. Gen. Jacques Massu, commander of the paratroops who control Algiers, told a crowd of about 3,000 persons today that he knew there was bitterness among Europeans here.

William Jansen was born in New York, the son of a cabinetmaker. He went to school here, and to Columbia University's Teachers College. He began teaching school as a substitute in the Bronx in 1908 land now, retiring soon after being Superintendent of New York City's schools for a decade, he will have given fifty years of his life and devoted interest to the school system.

The election of William K. Love Jr. as president of the New York Cotton Exchange was announced yesterday. Mr. Love is a partner in the brokerage firm of Anderson, Clayton Fleming. He is also a vice president of Anderson, Clayton Co., cotton processors and merchandisers, and manager of its New York office.

Half of the Yankees' halfdozen hits off Chicago's Jim Wilson were homers last night at the Stadium. Mickey Mantle clouted one and Hank Bauer belted a pair, taking care of the offense that beat the White Sox, 3 -- 0.
WISE old Long Island heads, particularly those around Montauk Point, were bobbing with sage satisfaction yesterday over certain developments of the Memorial Day weekend, to wit:
PHILADELPHIA, June 2 -James C. Petrillo, president of the American Federation of Musicians, kept his would-be successors guessing today.
BALTIMORE, June 2 (UPI) -- Albie Pearson singled home Clint Courtney from third base with two out in the tenth inning tonight for a 2-1 victory by the Washington Senators over the Baltimore Orioles.
WASHINGTON, June 2 -- An opponent of foreign aid said in the Senate today that the program was "undefined and never-ending" and "steeped in the threat of bankruptcy."
Twenty-one of the 300 former commuters on the New York Central Railroad's Putnam Division solved the problem of their first trainless day with a chartered bus.

A British-designed rubberized liferaft made its bid here yesterday for acceptance on American merchant ships. It was demonstrated here for the first time to high-ranking Navy, Coast Guard and shipping industry officials.
HAVANA, June 2 -- Fighting in Oriente Province between Government troops and rebels led by Fidel Castro has intensified during the last two weeks, according to reports reaching Havana.
Leonard W. Hall made it official yesterday that he is a candidate for the Republican nomination for Governor.

The Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) has announced the appointment of Dr. Siro Vazquez of Caracas, Venezuela, as head of its producing coordination department.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- The Supreme Court held today that a defendant in a civil antitrust suit was not entitled to a blanket look at grand jury minutes used by the Government to prepare its case. Continued From Page 1 matters because they have subpoena power and the Justice Department does not. Even though no criminal case results from a grand Jury inquiry, facts obtained are often used in a subsequent civil case.

PHILADELPHIA, June 2 -The Third United States Circuit Court of Appeals today denied Randolph Phillips' petition for an order restraining the certification of the Pennsylvania Railroad's slate of candidates for six posts on its board of directors.
The New York Chamber of Commerce yesterday asked the United States Government to seek cancellation of a "nationalistic" Cuban decree on marine insurance.
WASHINGTON, June 2 -- Representative Charles O. Porter charged today that the Ernst report on the disappearance of Jesus de Galindez was "biased" and unworthy of its author.
Sixty-six housing authorities subsidized by the Public Housing Administration plan to sell issues of temporary loan notes totaling $71,244,000 on June 10.
WASHINGTON, June 2 (AP) -The Supreme Court refused today to act on an appeal that challenged a law giving preference to veterans in Federal employment.

"The $64,000 Challenge" will be discontinued the latter part of September. The program, which made its debut April 8, 1956, is televised on Sundays from 10 to 10:30 P. M. over the Columbia Broadcasting System network.

ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, June 2 (UPI) -- Gene Andrews of Pacific Palisades, Calif., blasted par on the famed Old Course today to lead nine other Americans into the second round of the British amateur golf championship.
Eddie Lynch outfought and outboxed a stronger Jimmy Archer last night in a noisy welterweight bout at St. Nicholas Arena.
