It has been necessary to invoke stern measures to put down intercommunity rioting and disturbance in Ceylon. The Government is now going further than mere policing and is trying to transplant communities from sensitive areas into more favorable locations.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 2 -Diplomatic sources here expressed the View today that President Camille Chamoun had apparently won his fight against the threat of civil war.
CHICAGO, June 2 (AP) -- The report of livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

WASHINGTON, June 2 -Average wholesale prices in primary markets remained unchanged at 119.3 per cent of their 1947-49 level in the week ended last Tuesday, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

WHITE PLAINS, June 2 -- A public hearing was held tonight on a controversial proposal to rezone 162 acres in the Rosedale residential section of the city. The area would be used for a multi-million-dollar shopping and business center near the Hutchinson River Parkway.

ST. PIERRE, St. Pierre and Miquelon, June 2 -- The people of these tiny island outposts of France's colonial empire, off the Grand Banks of Newfoundland, learned last night of Gen. Charles de Gaulle's return to power in Paris.
PARIS, June 2 -- Gen. Charles de Gaulle appealed today to President Habib Bourguiba of Tunisia to help settle the "difficulties between our two countries."

The Atlantic, the American Banner Lines' entry into the North Atlantic tourist trade, was making good time in "fair weather" on her maiden voyage to New York, officials of the line reported yesterday.
A legislative committee joined organized labor yesterday in opposing the application of the New York Blue Cross for a rate increase.
Ruth Nichols, the aviator, who is field director of the National Nephrosis Foundation, said yesterday that a major research effort was being prepared to conquer kidney diseases.
The appointment of Dr. James M. Hester to the newly created position of vice president of Long Island University was announced yesterday by William Zeckendorf, president of the board of trustees.

PORT AU PRINCE, Haiti, June 2 -- Clement Jumelle, former Presidential candidate, and his brother, Ducasse Jumelle, were declared outlaws today. They failed to give themselves up within forty-eight hours of an ultimatum issued by the Ministry of the Interior late last month.

MINEOLA, L. I., June 2 -- A Nassau County patrolman resigned today after his cousin had been arrested on charges of stealing cash gifts from a wedding reception. The cousin's wife was a bridesmaid at the wedding yesterday.
Dr. James E. Allen Jr., State Education Commissioner, asserted last night that schools in this state have made concrete efforts to overcome shortcomings.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, June 2 -- One hundred twenty thousand mail votes hold the key to Sweden's next government.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 2 -- The Security Council began its discussion of the Tunisian-French dispute today, but broke it off in the hope that the two countries would be able to reach a settlement by direct negotiation.

A strong rally in the last few hands early this morning saved last year's championship team from defeat in play for the Curt Reisinger Trophy in bridge. With only twelve boards remaining in the semi-final match at the Park Sheraton Hotel, the team captained by Edgar Kaplan scored a 210-point victory over the team led by Charles H. Goren.

In recent weeks The Times has devoted considerable space to two important subjects: the upsurgence of anti-American feeling in Latin America which came to a boil at the time of Vice President Nixon's "goodwill tour" and the extremely friendly reception enjoyed by the New York Philharmonic Orchestra as it has traveled a similar route through our sister republics.

Steel production last week was at the highest level so far this year. Another increase is expected this week, reflecting continued improvement in orders -- some of which is believed to be the result of pricehedge buying.
WESTBURY, L. I., June 2 -Dick Thomas, the Nebraska-born reinsman who was the top driver at Roosevelt Raceway in 1954, has been having a poor season. He isn't surprised.

PITTSBURGH, June 2 -- The United Presbyterian Church in the U. S. A. will have placed before it, probably tomorrow, a proposal that its more than 11,000 ministers abstain from the use of alcoholic beverages and seek to "dissuade Christian people" from serving liquor at social functions.
WASHINGTON, June 2 -The House of Representatives approved today legislation creating a civilian agency to direct the nation's exploration of space.

As Premier Charles de Gaulle flies southward across the Mediterranean today he is heading straight into France's most critically urgent problem, and one in which the free world has a profound and immediate interest.
GREENSBORO, N. C., June 3 (UPI) -- Two public swimming pools, one for whites and the other for Negroes, were auctioned today in a public sale for the second time in two months.

A one-story office building on an eight-acre site in Paramus Industrial Park on Route 17, north of Midland Avenue, Paramus, N. J., has been leased by the Federal Electric Corporation, world-wide service organization of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation.
WASHINGTON, June 3 (AP) -A Senate Labor subcommittee tentatively approved today twothirds of a labor law revision drafted by Senator John F. Kennedy.

New York University will graduate 5,858 students today and grant honorary degrees to fight prominent persons at its 26th commencement. The ceremonies will be held on Ohio field, University Heights Campus at 181st Street and University Avenue, the Bronx.
WASHINGTON, June 3 -- The State Department expressed confidence today that the new French Government would continue to give strong support to the North Atlantic alliance and other treaty commitments.
Despite cuts in dividends and reports of lower earnings, stocks held well on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday and closed with respectable gains.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- Senate racket investigators will try to establish in hearings scheduled to start tomorrow whether several union leaders financed a spy system directed against the clean-up group in the labor movement.
RIVERHEAD, L. I., June 3 -The first of the Suffolk County "land grab" trials went to a jury this afternoon in an extraordinary term of the State Supreme Court.
James T. Pyle, Administrator of Civil Aeronautics, announced yesterday that he had named Ora W. Young, administrator of Region One, as his assistant for jet-age planning.
Piling up and managing an inventory is still a problem for many companies, the National Industrial Conference Board reported yesterday.

The State Insurance Department promised "expeditious action" yesterday on the application of the Associated Hospital Service, known as the Blue Cross, for increases averaging 40 per cent in its premiums.
LONDON, June 3 -- "Powerful Fascist-minded elements" will try to subvert Gen. Charles de Gaulle's Government in France and possibly overthrow it, Hugh Gaitskell warned today.

The Paramount Pictures Corporation, through its 90-percent owned International Telemeter Corporation, plans to install closed-circuit pay television systems in two communities in the United States and one in Canada around the end of this year.

PHILADELPHIA, June 3 -Dr. Abraham A. Neuman, president of Dropsie College, said tonight that the national Jewish leadership's survey of the place higher Jewish culture should take in American Jewish life augurs well.
WARSAW, Poland, June 3--Membership in the Polish United Workers (Communist) party was reduced by nearly 17 per cent in the mass "verification" campaign conducted during the last six months.

" I WISH I could figure out where this country is heading. Barricades? No, I don't think so -- but how can one be sure? There is increasing tension -- on the Left, on the Right. These remarks were not made last week, but three years ago and by the hero of a long, angry and only intermittently interesting first novel.
The Transit Authority and the B. T. Babbitt Company signed a contract yesterday to promote the company's products along with subway and bus riding.

A reliable source indicates there's a good chance of Paul Newman's returning to Broadway in Tennessee Williams' next drama, "Sweet Bird of Youth." Mr. Newman, screen star, who was last seen here in "The Desperate Hours," is impressed by the male lead, named Chance, in the new script.
TRENTON, June 3 -- New York collected $34,000,000 in personal income taxes last year from non-residents employed there, Assemblyman John R. Brook. Republican of Manhattan, said here today.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- Senator William E. Jenner charged today that the foreign aid programs were "riddled with inefficiency, stupidity, waste" and urged Congress to stop aid on the Mutual Security basis Dec. 30.

CHICAGO, June 3 -- L. Newton Thomas, president of the National Coal Association; today accepted John L. Lewis' proposal that the industry "speak with one voice." At the same time Mr. Thomas said it was "false" to call coal a "sick industry," adding, "The only thing the coal industry is sick of is being called 'sick'."

Avianca (Aerovias Nacionales de Colombia) leased two stores in the Goelet Building, 608 Fifth Avenue at Forty-ninth Street. The lessee is an airline operating between New York and South America. The leases are for ten years and involve rentals aggregating $500,000, according to Richard A. Denman of Cushman Wakefield, Inc., broker in the deal.

Bing Crosby and the American Broadcasting Company have signed a long-term television and radio contract. Under its terms the singer will star on various programs and become a partner of A. B. C. in the development and production of new television programs.
WASHINGTON, June 3 (UPI) -- The Senate adopted today a bill to authorize the loan of forty-three ships from the Navy reserve fleet to friendly foreign countries.
WASHINGTON, June 3 -- The Tennessee Valley Authority's board of directors called untrue today the contention that T, V. A. and its power users paid only token taxes.
Mayor Wagner said yesterday that New York was becoming "one of the cleanest large cities in the world."
CHICAGO, June 3 (AP) -- Rye and corn futures generally advanced today on the Board of Trade. Wheat and oats lost ground.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, June 3 (Reuters) -- Finance Minister Arnold Nordmeyer announced today that the New Zealand Government would issue tomorrow (N.Z.) 15,000,000 ($42,000,000) loan on the home market and might borrow more abroad.
Cooling off the contenders long has been a Yankee specialty. Now they're developing a refinement of the refrigerating process. They apply the deep freeze.
BOSTON, June 3 (AP) -- Dick Gernert's three - run homer helped the Boston Red Sox to a 7-3 victory over Cleveland tonight. Tommy Brewer scored his first pitching triumph since April 23.
WASHINGTON, June 3 -President Eisenhower met with the National Security Council today for a broad review of foreign and defense policies.

The thesis that much of the blame for the bidding for students rests with the colleges would have been correct if your May 25 article "Bidding for Brains Disturbs Educators" had been written five years ago. ALGIERS, June 3 -- All Algiers waited tonight for the visit of Gen. Charles de Gaulle, new head of the French Government, to resolve doubts and settle arguments about his policies for this troubled territory.

PHILADELPHIA, June 3 -James Caesar Petrillo made it official today. The president of the American Federation of Musicians carried out his announced intention to quit, in the face of a snake dance of convention delegates with placards pleading "Jimmy, Don't Leave Us."
SAN FRANCISCO, June 3 -Senator William F. Knowland trailed State Attorney General Edmund G. (Pat) Brown late tonight in California's Gubernatorial primary election.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 3 -- It is inconceivable that the recession will rival in depth or duration the one that began in 1929, United Nations analysts said today. The full effects of recent cutbacks in business plans for plant and equipment expenditures may not be felt until 1959, they conceded.
LONDON, June 3 (UPI) -The Soviet Union agreed today with a United States proposal that the Antarctic be restricted to international use for peaceful purposes.
WASHINGTON, June 3 -- The United States will begin arming its forces in West Germany with 200-mile Redstone missiles at the end of this month.

It seems like old times to have James A. Farley active in politics again. Often mentioned as a candidate for public office, but never in recent years a declared aspirant, he is the first to announce formally a candidacy for the Democratic nomination for the United States Senate seat being vacated by Irving M. Ives, Republican. It is hardly necessary to identify Jim Farley as a Democrat.
TUNIS, June 3 -- President Habib Bourguiba of Tunisia wished Gen. Charles de Gaulle the best of luck tonight.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 3 -- About 100,000,000 years ago a Kronosaurus queenslandicus sank to the bottom of a sea that once covered part of Australia. Twentyseven years ago the fossil remains were found. It has taken until now to reconstruct the fossil skeleton of the forty-two-foot marine reptile, which will go on display next Tuesday at Harvard University's Musem of Comparative Zoology.

We don't expect to see an advertising sign as lovely as a tree, and this is more true in the Times Square area than elsewhere. Therefore we consider it a particular pity that the Park Department, as spoken for by its executive officer, Stuart Constable, has hardly finished setting a few London plane trees to beautify Duffy Square before it agrees to chop off their tops to pacify outdoor advertisers.

The election of Ben R. Gordon as president and managing director of Stern Brothers was announced yesterday by B. Earl Puckett, chairman of Allied Stores Corporation, parent company of the New York department store.

VEGETABLES are now in their most abundant season. They are at their freshest, too, for many come from nearby farms in New Jersey, Long Island and in the Hudson Valley. They deserve a prominent part in the summer menu planning.

European shippers are displaying "considerable interest" in the effects the opening of the St. Lawrence Seaway next year will have on New York. This was reported yesterday by Donald V. Lowe, chairman of the Port of New York Authority.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- The National Education Association reported today that college employment officers all over the country "are literally 'priced out of the market' as they search for competent personnel."

James A. Farley announced yesterday that he was a candidate for the Democratic nomination for United States Senator. The former Postmaster General is the first in either party to declare his aspirations publicly in the race.
The New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program collected 11,629 pints of blood in May, it was announced yesterday.

A plea for cooperation by Roman Catholics with nonCatholics on civic questions such as church-state relationship was made yesterday by the Manhattan-Westchester Region of the National Conference of Christians and Jews.

WASHINGTON, June 3 (AP) -- Three House committee witnesses contended today that expanded Federal aid to education could lessen the interest of citizens in their local schools.

Fletcher D. Richards, Inc., has bought a half interest in the Tandy Advertising Agency, Ltd., with offices in Toronto and Montreal. It will operate under the name Tandy-Richards Advertising, Ltd., as a separate agency, with billings of about $3,000,000 a year.
LONDON, June 3 -- Britain warned Iceland today that she would check any attempt to exclude British trawlers from the rich cod-fishing grounds near Iceland.

A commanding lead of 3,920 points built up in the first half of the match enabled the defending contract bridge champions to win the Curt Reisinger Trophy early today for the third straight year.

LONDON, June 3 -- Hugh Gaitskell, leader of the Labor party, urged today a speedy settlement of the London bus strike.

Milwaukee, Wis., is planning the sale of bonds totaling $17,800,000 on June 17. The obligations will be dated July 1, 1958 and will come due serially on July 1 from 1959 to 1978.

PRINCETON, N. J., June 3 -A $3,500,000 expansion of Princeton University's athletic facilities was announced today by President Robert F. Goheen.

Cathedral College, a preparatory seminary of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, has purchased the fivestory building at 38 West Eighty-sixth Street for use as a resident hall for students of the college, which is at West End Avenue and Eighty-Seventh Street.

PARIS, June 3 -- Frenchmen are wondering how the de Gaulle regime will affect their private life. Many think the new Premier's name will become a byword for economic austerity.

TO the long list of shortcomings for which today's parents are continually being taken to task, a new one was added recently. Many parents, a leading clergyman told a teachers' group, rely on "a philosophy of excuse" rather than "a philosophy of effort" in bringing up their children.

Only $178,493, a comparatively light across-the-board handle, was wagered on the outcome of yesterday's feature at Belmont Park, where 21,274 turned out for the day's sport. The reason: A hurdle race is interesting to watch, but dangerous to bet.

MANCHESTER, England, June 3 (UPI) -- Five American women, led by the Wimbledon champion, Althea Gibson, and four United States men scored singles victories today in the Northern lawn tennis tournament.

LOS ANGELES, June 3 -The proposal to give the Dodgers a 300-acre baseball stadium site in Chavez Ravine appeared to be winning in Los Angeles' municipal election tonight.
PARIS, June 3 -- The French Parliament went away quietly today, leaving the republic to Gen. Charles de Gaulle.

PARIS, June 3 -- Although testy, impatient and authoritarian, Charles de Gaulle is no dictator. There is every reason to believe his assurances on this point. He has a profound, mystical belief that he not only represents the best in French tradition but that he is France.
MIAMI, June 3 (AP) -- The Los Angeles Dodgers will not be invited to return to Miami Stadium for next year's spring training.
Paramount Pictures has negotiated the sale of the last of its cartoons and short subjects for showing on television.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 3 -Lebanese rebel leaders appeared today to be in the position of locomotive drivers who have lost their air brakes.

GARWOOD, N. J., June 3 -A 72-year-old grandmother, Mrs. Matilde Johnson, received bicycle license No. 1 today, to pursue her duties as public school truant officer here.

Mrs. Henry Sears of Greenwich, Conn., swung her right arm down hard yesterday, and the bottle of champagne she held shattered against the bow mooring fitting of the America's Cup defense candidate Columbia.

LONDON, June 3 -- The stock market ended a three-week bookkeeping account today with underlying firmness fully maintained. Government securities improved further and most other share groups were steady, even though price movements were too irregular to show a definite trend.

ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, June 3 (UPI) -- Tim Holland of Rockville Centre, L. I., set an even par pace as nine Americans played through a cold rain whipping in from the North Sea today to reach the third round of the British amateur golf championship.
A new electronic "detective," said to eliminate virtually all errors in giant computers, was announced yesterday by the Minneapolis-Honeywell Regulator Company.

WASHINGTON, June 3 (AP) -The Federal Trade Commission ruled today that antitrust laws were not automatically violated by the merger of two companies that together held half of the market for a particular product.

One of the brighter spots on the domestic horizon is that provided by the rebound in steel production. Last week's output of 1,567,000 tons was the largest of any week since mid-December of last year.

WESTBURY, L. I., June 3 -Long-shot Players almost lost a big one at Roosevelt Raceway tonight. After Dynamite Direct, the 23-to-1 outsider, obviously had won the featured fifth race, the judges flashed the wrong winner on the board.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 3 (AP) -- The Milwaukee Braves, powered by five home runs, took first place in the National League tonight by beating the San Francisco Giants, 7 -- 6, before 22,934 in Seals Stadium.
AN INDUSTRIAL plan to encourage both sculptors and architects is the basis for the current exhibition at the Grace Borgenicht Gallery, 1018 Madison Avenue.
KIAMESHA LAKE, N. Y., June 3 -- An appeal that the United Nations grant individuals the right to petition it "for investigation" when human rights are violated was made here today.
Robert K. Christenberry, the Republican Mayoral candidate last fall was sworn in yesterday as Acting Postmaster of New York.
The chairman of the Board of Education's committee on buildings and sites declared yesterday that approximately $100,000,000 a year would be needed over the next decade for new school construction.
Dr. Grayson Kirk pledged yesterday that Columbia University would maintain and develop its adult education facilities as an obligation to New York.

RYE, N. Y., June 3 -- The senior golfer's slogan, "always venerable but never aged," seemed appropriate today. John Dawson of Palm Desert, Calif., led the fifty-fourth annual championship field of the United States Senior Golf Association at the Apawamis Club course with a 2-under-par.

CARACUS, Venezuela, June 3 -- Economic activity here is expected to return to normal, with the adoption on July 1 of a new budget of $1,260,000,000, Dr. Jose Antonio Mayobre, new Minister of Finance, said today. He said also that the question of borrowing $200,000,000 abroad would be studied again.

ALGIERS, June 1 -- The organizers of the Algiers insurrection of May 13 have been encouraged by their apparent victory to talk openly about how their plans were laid. It is an astonishing story. The following version was told to a correspondent by someone who has collaborated closely for the last five years with Leon Delbecque, the principal supporter; it has been corroborated by opinions from other reliable sources.
RABAT, Morocco, June 3 -King Mohamed V expressed hope today that General Charles de Gaulle would be able to establish free and fruitful cooperation between France and the countries of North Africa.
WASHINGTON, June 3--The Council of State Chambers of Commerce called today for a public outpouring of letters to persuade Congress to cut taxes this year as an anti-recession measure.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -President Juscelino Kubitschek of Brazil has written to President Eisenhower expressing concern lest recent incidents should obscure the basic LatinAmerican friendship for the United States.

Reflection of Man's Development The recent report from Yak, one of the Caroline Islands, that its famous stone money was withstanding the dollar economy making its way among the 2,000 islands of Micronesia recalls how money has been a historic reflection of man's development.
State Education Commissioner James E. Allen Jr., has called a meeting for Tuesday in Albany to work out a state-wide plan to combat juvenile delinquency.
CHICAGO, June 3 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., June 3 (AP) -- Mass suspension of student troublemakers would not have solved the integration turmoil at Central High School, the president of the school board testified today.
STAMFORD, Conn., June 3 -The Stamford Chamber of Commerce and the Yankee Division Veterans Association are at odds over the financing of the association's forthcoming national convention here.

RANDOLPH, Mass., June 3 (AP) -- Hal Connolly, an Olympic gold medal winner, failed tonight in an effort to set a hammerthrow record at the sixtyninth New England Amateur Athletic Union track and field championships at Memorial Field.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- The chairman of the Federal Communications Commission said today that the commission would await a formal, written opinion from the Justice Department before deciding whether to prohibit certain television network practices.
ROME, June 3 -- An American has been elected head, or Minister General, of the Order of Capuchin Friars Minor, better known simply as Capuchins.

LONDON, June 3 (UPI) -Brian London won the British and Empire heavyweight boxing championships tonight when he knocked out the defender, Joe Erskine, in the eighth round of their scheduled fifteen-round bout at White City Stadium.
JIDDA, Saudi Arabia, June 3 -- Sheik Abdullah Tariki smiled enigmatically and delivered an astonishing statement.
PARIS, June 3 -- Gen. Charles de Gaulle will fly to Algeria tomorrow to begin the vital task of re-establishing the French Government's authority over the French Army and civilian dissidents there.
New issues of corporate securities valued at more than $82,000,000 are being offered for public subscription today by investment banking syndicates.

WASHINGTON, June 3 (UPI) -- The Justice Department was reported today to be making a new inquiry into alleged Communist connections of Finnishborn William Heikkila, who was returned to this country after a hasty deportation in April.

UTICA, N. Y., June 3 (AP) -Notice of a $3,124,540 suit against Smith-Corona, Inc., of Syracuse has been filed in the District Court clerk's office by the Universal Business Machines Corporation of Middletown, Conn.
Prices of cotton futures declined 11 to 23 points (55 cents to $1.15 a bale) yesterday, with weakness noticeable in the new October option.
MINNEAPOLIS, June 3 -- Dr. Jonas E. Salk was reported here today to have said that mass use of oral polio vaccine could not be recommended now.
WASHINGTON, June 3 -- A leading Congressional authority on United States defenses said today that complacency was again hampering the country's efforts to meet the Soviet challenge.
WASHINGTON, June 3 -Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev of the Soviet Union sent a letter to President Eisenhower today urging an expansion of East-West trade.

GREENWICH, Conn., June 3 -- The Woman's Auxiliary of Christ Protestant Episcopal Church will sponsor a tour of terraces at eight private homes here next Tuesday. In case of rain the tour will be held the next day.

WASHINGTON, June 3 (AP) -- The Washington Senators swept a double-header from the Kansas City Athletics tonight, 5 -- 4 and 10 -- 9, and leaped from a sixth-place tie in the American League race to a deadlock for third place with Boston.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., June 3 (UPI) -- Ralph McGill, editor of The Atlanta Constitution, charged tonight that "too many newspapers have become unwilling to pay the cost which might ensue from engaging in controversy and debate."

Two new double-bill programs will open today. "From Hell to Texas," starring Don Murray and Diane Varsi, and "God Is My Partner," with Walter Brennan, are at the R. K. O. neighborhood houses. Both are Twentieth Century-Fox presentations.
A taxicab driver charged in a court suit yesterday that the Police Department had refused to turn over to him $30,000 in jewelry that he found in his cab more than a year ago.
WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., June 3 -- A visitor from Long Island won low gross honors today in the first one-day tournament of the Westchester division, Women's Metropolitan Golf Association.

MELBOURNE, June 3 -- E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co. has expressed interest in obtaining an option on high-temperature chromium alloy processes developed by the Australian Department of Supply in Melbourne.
The American Cancer Society is making plans to tell school pupils of the evidence linking cigarette smoking and lung cancer.

PHILADELPHIA, June 3 -The National Steel Corporation and the Crown Cork and Seal Company, Inc., today reported the completion of negotiations for the purchase of Crown's Cold Reducing Mill and supplementary equipment for the manufacture of electrolytic tin plate.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., June 3 -- John Patterson, State Attorney General, won easily tonight in his bid for the Governorship.
MOUNTAIN HOME, Idaho, June 3 (AP) -- An investigation is planned in the crash that killed Robert E. Bollinger, a singer, of New York, a decorated World War II flyer.
SEATTLE, June 3 (AP) -- The University of Washington quit the Pacific Coast Conference today after forty-three years to join California schools in a new athletic pact.

Commodity futures closed generally lower yesterday on the New York exchanges. Wool, cottonseed oil, coffee, the world sugar positions, potatoes, rubber and lead declined; copper and zinc rose, and price movements for cocoa and the domestic sugar contract were mixed.

SINCE Eugene Ionesco does not waste his genius on being intelligible, there is not much chance of making an intelligible report on his two one-act plays performed last evening in the Sullivan Street Playhouse.
Store failures in the apparel and general merchandise fields declined last month, but losses in terms of dollars rose.
Thousands of commuters on their way home from Grand Central Terminal were stalled by two mishaps late yesterday that caused delays up to thirtyone minutes.
DETROIT, June 3 -- The American Motors Corporation and the United Automobile Workers agreed today to an indefinite extension of their contract beyond the June 15 expiration date.
Eight persons were injured early last evening when a northbound rush-hour IND subway train came to a sudden stop as it was leaving the Fiftyninth Street station.
CHICAGO, June 3 (AP) -- The state dropped today its charge that James G. Cross, president of the Bakery Workers Union, embezzled $6,500 in union funds in 1955 to buy an automobile for his own use.
WASHINGTON, June 3 -Lewis L. Strauss is looking for a candidate to succeed him next month as chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission.
Many prominent persons were patrons for the celebrity cocktail party held last night for the benefit of the New York Arthritis and Rheumatism Foundation.
MARION, N. C., June 3 (AP) -Food poisoning swept Eugene Cross Elementary School here this afternoon, filling the school and McDowell County hospital with stricken, crying children.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 3 (AP) -- Yuba Consolidated Industries, Inc., of San Francisco is buying Judson Pacific-Murphy Corporation, steel fabricating plant at near-by Emeryville.

Today's new film is "Rooney," a J. Arthur Rank comedy starring Barry Fitzgerald, at the Sutton Theatre, The British feature was produced by George H. Brown and directed by George Pollock from a screen play by Patrick Kirwan. Also featured are John Gregson and Muriel Pavlow.

A new publishing venture in the field of American history has been announced by the Harvard University Press. Called "The John Harvard Library," it will be developed as part of the program of the Belknap Press of the Harvard University Press.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- The eleventh anniversary of the launching of the European Recovery program will take place tomorrow amidst new complaints and fears about the economic derangement of the free world.
LOS ANGELES, Calif., June 4 -- The Dodgers are headed for Chavez Ravine. But how soon they'll get there remains a question.
A maritime venture said to be without parallel in the Port of New York came to a successful conclusion in Hoboken last night.

MANCHESTER, England, June 4 (AP) -- Karol Fageros of Miami and Janet Hopps of Seattle joined Althea Gibson in the women's quarter-finals, but America's tennis forces suffered reversals today in the North England tennis championships.
The first offering of shares of the Chase Fund of Boston is being made to the public today.

MONTREAL, June 4 (UPI) -- H. V. Lush, president of the Canadian Manufacturers Association, said today that Canada should trade with the Soviet Union when it was "sensible." But he warned against Soviet attempts to undercut sensitive markets in a tactical trade offensive.
PITTSBURGH, June 4 -- The United Presbyterian Church in the U. S. A. turned down by a narrow margin today a statement calling for the immediate and unconditional cessation of nuclear weapon testing.
The city fireboat William J. Gaynor and the Circle Line excursion boat Liberty collided just after noon yesterday about 100 yards off the Battery. No injuries were reported.

PARIS, June 4 -- Paris was surprised and some political circles were highly disappointed by what seemed to be a full endorsement today by Premier Charles de Gaulle of Algeria's integration with France.
EPSOM, England, June 4--Hard Ridden drove through the ruck along the rail, swept past half a dozen horses and won the 179th running of the Derby Stakes at Epsom Downs today.
ALGIERS, June 4 (AP) -- General de Gaulle said that "ways must be opened that have been closed to many," and that means of livelihood and dignity must be extended to those lacking them.

The sixty-foot chrysalis will writhe with the birth of gigantic butterflies. Meanwhile, spectators will file through the enormous organism, gazing at skinned, faceless figures in a desert with flying trees.
PHILADELPHIA, June 4 -- Randolph Phillips scored a point today in his battle to prevent the seating of management's slate of six candidates for directors of the Pennsylvania Railroad.
CHICAGO, June 4 (AP) -- Short-covering sent most grain futures slightly to the plus side late today on the Board of Trade after earlier spotty weakness.
HONG KONG, June 4 -- The Chinese Communists intensified their attack on Yugoslavia's "revisionism" today.
ALTHOUGH almost any occasion is suitable for children's parties, there will be increasing requests for them with the beginning of summer when schools closed.
The barter in garters may soon be brisk at Tiffany's.

A moderately rising level of oil imports would benefit the American consumer, according to a report published today by the Petroleum Industry Research Foundation, Inc. The report said "domestic prices would undoubtedly be higher" if lower cost imported oil was not available to supplement domestic production.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 4 -- Jubilant Democrats rode high on a political tidal wave in California today.

HONOLULU, June 4 (UPI) -- A Coast Guard cutter today intercepted the yatch Golden Rule as she made a third futile attempt to sail toward the forbidden nuclear test zone at Eniwetok as a protest against current bomb tests.
Essays on "Respect for the Rights of Others" won $2,840 yesterday for 116 pupils attending public and parochial schools here.

The charts which were published in your News of the Week section of May 25 showed that most Latin-American countries are highly dependent upon a single commodity for their foreign exchange earnings and that this major commodity varies considerably from country to country -- sugar in Cuba, petroleum in Venezuela, coffee in Colombia, copper in Chile, etc.
VIENNA, June 4 (UPI) -- A 28-year-old American medical student said today that he had renounced his United States citizenship because he did not "care to fight for any country."
Following are the citations read by Harold O. Voorhis, vice president of New York University, for honorary degrees at the university's 126th annual commencement yesterday:

Oils did fairly well and pharmaceuticals did fairly badly in an indeterminate session of the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. Most stocks moved little and the general effect of the day was stalemate.

TEL AVIV, Israel, June 4 -- United Nations, Jordanian and Israeli officers scrambled for cover this morning when Arab sub-machine-gun bullets whizzed over their heads at the crossroads between the Israeli and Arab sectors of Jerusalem.

Chinks developed in the Yankees' pitching armor yesterday and the run-starved White Sox swarmed gleefully through them. When the infiltration was completed, the Chicagoans had a 7-2 victory, their first in five meetings with the league-leading Bombers.

The battle of Sutton Place entered a new phase yesterday. Five tenants of the fashionable fourteen-story apartment house at 25 Sutton Place moved in Manhattan Supreme Court to block eviction by their landlord, Stavros Niarchos, wealthy ship owner.
Two of New York's major business and civic associations are merging to work more effectively for the redevelopment of lower Manhattan.

The 310 Corporation, represented by Bing Bing, Inc., sold the fifteen-story and penthouse apartment building at 310 West End Avenue, southeast corner of Seventy-fifth Street. The house occupies a plot 102 by 63 feet and has sixty-six apartments.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- The Senate agreed today with the House of Representatives that more than 1,000,000 Government white-collar workers should receive a 10 per cent rise in pay, retroactive to last January. In February the Senate voted to hold increases to an average of 7 1/2 per cent.

The City College Alumni Association withdrew yesterday from the forthcoming conference of the American Alumni Council at the Lake Placid Club. The association charged that the Adirondacks resort "openly practices discrimination against minority groups."

A SUMMER replacement called "Sing Along" made its debut last night over Channel 2. This musical presentation is an electronic community sing in which viewers and members of the studio audience are invited to join the regular vocalists.
ALGIERS, June 4 -- Premier Charles de Gaulle arrived here today and pledged equality of voting for the French and Moslems of Algeria.

Cities in India, China and other less-developed countries are growing --- and so are their problems -- at a faster rate than New York, London and other urban centers in the Western world, a United Nations official said yesterday.

TUNIS, June 4 -- A spokesman here for the Algerian National Liberation Front said today that the revolt would continue. He termed ludicrous proposals made in Algiers by Premier Charles de Gaulle of France.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- The Federal Reserve Board reported today that the condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities showed that in the week ended Wednesday, May 28 there were:
RABAT, Morocco, June 4 -- "It is disastrous" was the immediate reaction of Moroccan politicians to General de Gaulle's speech.
MONTREAL, June 4 -- Merielle Pelletier, 7 years old, an unknown in show business until early this week, is today the talk of the Metropolitan Opera, currently on tour here.
DETROIT, June 4 (AP) -- Greater world understanding by the United States was urged today at the opening of the convention of the General Federation of Women's Clubs. About 3,000 were present.

Sinclair Robinson, president of Williams-McWilliams Industries, Inc., resigned from that position yesterday. The action came less than two months after the victory of his management in a proxy contest for control of the diversified concern.
Six-hundred thirty-one probationary patrolmen were told yesterday that they were vitally needed to cope with juvenile delinquency and preserve law and order in the city.
Cornell University Medical College graduated eighty-one new doctors of medicine yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 4 (AP) -- National Broadcasting Company executive declared today that Government supervision of radio and television networks "would mean regulation for the sake of regulation."

PHILADELPHIA, June 4 -- The baton that James C. Petrillo laid down yesterday was passed today to his hand-picked successor. By a margin of nearly 2 to 1, the convention of the American Federation of Musicians accepted Mr. Petrillo's advice that Herman D. Kenin be elected to take his place as president of the 264,000-member union.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 4 -- Completion of negotiations for the establishment of Julian Blaustein Productions as an independent unit at Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer was announced today by Sol C. Siegel.
A 45-year-old Utica, N. Y., stockbroker walked into City Hall yesterday and said he had hiked 800 miles from Chicago to New York between May 17 and Tuesday.

The bridge team of Edgar Kaplan, Alfred Sheinwold, Ralph Hirschberg and Richard Kahn of New York, and Norman Kay of Merchantville, N. J., won the Curt Reisinger Trophy for the third straight year in a fifty-six-board match that ended early Wednesday.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- Whatever may be the November portent of the much larger vote cast in yesterday's California primaries for Attorney General Brown than for Senator Knowland, it is another proof that in politics no reliance can be placed on the adage that absence makes the heart grow fonder.

JERSEY CITY, June 4 -- The United Fruit Company "interferes as little as it can" in management of the International Railways of Central America despite its ownership of 40.18 per cent of the voting stock, James McGovern, general attorney of the banana company, said here today.
WEST POINT, N. Y., June 4 -- Conflicts among the armed forces should be settled in the Executive branch and not in Congress, Neil H. McElroy said today.

ALGIERS, June 4 -- Gen. Charles de Gaulle came today to the city that had opened the door for his return to power, but the shouts "Long live de Gaulle!" were all but drowned out at times by cheers for Jacques Soustelle and Brig. Gen. Jacques Massau.
RANGOON, Burma, June 4 (Reuters) -- The Burmese Premier, U Nu, formed a new Cabinet tonight following the resignation of fifteen ministers in a dispute over leadership of the Government party.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- The Atomic Energy Commission presented to Congress today a long-range program designed to achieve economically competitive nuclear power overseas in five years and in the United States within ten years.

Premier Khrushchev's speech in Sofia dispels any doubt that may have existed about his personal position in the dispute with Yugoslavia. In this speech he virtually accepted the entire Chinese indictment against Belgrade, including even the thesis that the 1948 Cominform resolution, expelling the Yugoslavs was correct.

PHILADELPHIA, June 4 -- The new conductor of the country's biggest band, the 264,000 - member American Federation of Musicians, ended his own musical career when he was admitted to the Oregon Bar twenty-eight years ago.

The Mansfield Tire and Rubber Company has filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission covering a proposed offering of $5,000,000 of fifteen-year sinking fund debenture and $2,511,400 of fifteen-year convertible subordinated debentures.
WASHINGTON, June 4 -- A visit by Dr. Milton S. Eisenhower to six Latin-American countries has been postponed, the State Department announced today.
MACKINAC ISLAND, Mich., June 4 (AP) -- Dr. Frank N. D. Buchman, founder of the Moral Re-Armament Movement, told the group today that God was the answer to the modern world's problems.
YOUNG HARRIS, Ga., June 4 (AP) -- Byron Herbert Reece, 40-year-old Georgia poet and novelist, was found dead of a gunshot wound last night in his campus apartment at Young Harris College.
PAUL McCOBB, the well-known furniture designer has turned his master's hand to kitchen cabinets.
WASHINGTON, June 4 (AP) -- A man who has been imprisoned as a swindler heard his recorded voice today promising favors to employers of nonunion labor if they would advertise in a Yonkers publication.

LISBON, Portugal, June 4 -- Portugal's Presidential campaign formally ended today after twenty-six days of electoral "freedom." In that period several dozen persons have been hurt in riots and several score have been reliably reported detained by the police.

KIAMESHA LAKE, N. Y., June 4 -- Congress was urged here today to pass legislation that would "remove all doubt of Federal jurisdiction in cases of bombing and dynamite violence." This was a reference to the forty-seven recent bombings of houses of worship, community buildings and homes in the South.
WASHINGTON, June 4 -- President Eisenhower directed the Department of the Interior today to plug a potential loophole in the Government's crude of import curbs.

Deputy Mayor John J. Theobald conferred yesterday at City Hall with a committee of opponents of the plan to merge the High School of Performing Arts. The school would be part of the proposed Lincoln Square High School to be constructed at Broadway and Sixty-fifth Street.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, June 4 -- "Carousel," though derived from Molnar's "Liliom," is as authentically American in spirit as clam chowder. Transplanted from New York's City Center to the American Theatre of the United States Pavilion tonight, it brought something fresh and touching to the vast performing arts program of the Brussels World's Fair.

That college teachers in the United States are underpaid is notorious, as the latest National Education Association survey of salaries in over a thousand institutions documents again. Median salaries now run from $4,562 a year for instructors (about a thousand dollars less than coal miners) to $8,072 for full professors. Half of all the teachers in the colleges surveyed receive less than $6,015. The

ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, June 4 (UPI) -- Tim Holland of Rockville Centre, L. I., and 43-year-old Jack Penrose, a Miami insurance broker, were the only Americans to gain the fifth round of the British amateur golf championship.
Curves may be making a dent in the Dior "Trapeze Line," if what happened in London this week is a forecast of fashions-to-come.
TROY, N. Y., June 4 (AP) -- The Atomic Energy Commission plans to build here the most powerful atom-smasher of the straight-line type.
An order restraining 700 Trans World Airlines flight engineers from striking was continued yesterday in the Federal Court, Brooklyn, pending the outcome of negotiations in Washington.

Several notable firsts were recorded yesterday at Belmont Park, where the mature of the afternoon's racing was the nineteenth running of the Top Flight Handicap. Ada L. Rice's Plucky Roman, the only non-winner of a stakes race in the field of six fillies and mares, showed the way in the mile-and-a-sixteeth test for $25,000 added money.

Five runs in the last of the sixth inning gave Mt. St. Michael a 5-2 victory over its Bronx rival, Cardinal Hayes, yesterday and its first Catholic High Schools Athletic Association title. A crowd of 5,000 witnessed the championship final at Fordham University's Jack Coffey Field in the Bronx.
Jack Molinas, former Columbia University and National Basketball Association star player, has brought a $3,000,000 suit against the league because he has been denied reinstatement.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., June 4 (AP) -- Virgil T. Blossom, school superintendent, testified today that he did not know when the people of Little Rock would be willing to accept school integration.

WASHINGTON, June 4 (AP) -- James P. Warburg, former New York banker, said today that United States foreign policy was bankrupt and that its bankuptcy "endangers -- the survival of civilized life upon this planet."

The Popular Science Publishing Company, publisher of Popular Science Monthly and other magazines, has leased three floors in the office building rising at 355 Lexington Avenue, northeast corner of Fortieth Street. The lease is for fifteen years and involves rentals aggregating $3,000,000.
The first step in the reconstruction of the Brooklyn waterfront was hailed here yesterday by Mayor Wagner and A. P. Moller, Denmark's leading ship owner.
NEW DELHI, India, June 4 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru confessed today to a feeling of frustration at the growing rift between India and Pakistan.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 4 -- President Eisenhower told members of the United States Naval Academy's graduating class today that their most important function was one of "helping prevent war and of furthering a just peace."
Anniversaries stir memories. And Johnny Farrell has been doing a bit of reminiscing.
A new musical tracing the influence of the Negro in music and dance, from primitive origins to jazz concert music, has been scheduled for Broadway production early in November.
PIETRASANTA, Italy, June 4 (AP) -- Heroic sixteen-foot statues of Juan and Eva Peron lay in a marble works today, beheaded by order of the Argentine Government.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 4 -- The Security Council suspended today its discussion of the French-Tunisian dispute until June 18 to permit direct negotiations between the two countries.

Dr. Harry B. Marshall, president of the Ciba Company, chemicals and dyestuffs concern, yesterday categorically denied the company had violated the Sherman Anti-trust Act as charged by the Government in a suit filed in Federal Court last week.

The nation's primary aluminum industry will find it increasingly difficult to remain strong "unless the Government provides adequate protection for it against the competition of subsidized or state-owned foreign producers."
Racketeers and hoodlums were among eighteen persons arrested yesterday as members of a reputed multi-million-dollar-a-year narcotics ring.
Sixteen new-born deer, a baby raccoon and a nest full of adopted birds are frisky additions to the Bronx Zoo this spring. The deer, some about the size of a puppy, include...

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- The United States would not balk at the participation of Communist China in the forthcoming technical talks on policing a suspension of nuclear testing if this was made a condition by the Russians.

Futures prices closed generally lower in dull and featureless trading yesterday on the New York Commodity exchanges. Coffee, the world sugar months, copper, lead, zinc, hides, rubber, burlap and potatoes declined; cocoa and wool rose, and price movements for the domestic sugar contract and cottonseed oil were mixed.

WASHINGTON, June 4 (AP) -- The Department of Commerce reported today that sales of retailers and wholesalers increased from March to April after seasonal adjustments. Sales of manufacturers dipped slightly.
The National Industrial Advertisers Association will continue to operate in its present form for at least another year, rather than become the International Society for Industrial Marketing.
Two utilities and a propane gas company have made private placements of securities.
MENOMONIE, Wis., June 4 -- A tornado swept a four-county area of northwest Wisconsin tonight, killing eighteen persons and injuring at least 100.

WASHINGTON, June 4 (UPI) -- The strong Democratic showing in the California primary jarred the Republican party today. Some party leaders feared it might mean the end of six teen years of G. O. P. rule in the state next November.

Underwriters led jointly by Lazard Freres Co. and Goldman, Sachs Co. yesterday placed on the market a $50,000,000 issue of Owens-Illinois Glass Company 3 3/4 per cent thirty-year sinking fund debentures.

WESTBURY, L. I., June 4--Responding strongly under the urging of Clint Hodgins, Caton Hanover, a 6-year-old bay gelding, took the featured Champagne Purse at Roosevelt Raceway tonight. Caton Hanover paced the mile in 2:05 2-5.
MONTREAL, June 4 (UPI) -- Montreal, Toronto and Chicago used the New York Rangers as an unwilling fourth party in an attempt to maneuver a complicated switch of players today.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- The Defense Department has completed its studies of proposals for a space vehicle engine with 1,000,000 pounds of thrust. It will initiate production "in less than a month or two."
Thorough medical examinations are needed to prevent the mentally ill and physically infirm from obtaining driver's licenses, traffic court officials were told here yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 4 -- The Soviet Union would like large-scale credits from the United States to help finance purchases of American industrial equipment.
LONDON, June 4 -- Modest improvement in prices marked the opening of the new bookkeeping account on the stock market today.
WASHINGTON, June 4 -- With common speed, the Senate Labor subcommittee completed election today on a labor reform and sent it to the full committee.

MOLINE, Ill., June 4 -- Stockholders of Deere Co. will be asked at a special meeting July 29 to approve a "modernization" of the company's corporate, financial and administrative framework, the company said today.

The apparent stabilization of consumer spending is the most encouraging aspect of the business situation, the Guaranty Trust Company of New York said in its monthly publication, The Guaranty Survey, published today.
The National Urban League announced yesterday a nationwide guidance and assistance program to direct more Negroes into scientific and technical careers.

These menus, which appear each Thursday, use seasonally abundant foods and are moderate in cost. They are designed to strike a balance between appetite appeal and the convenience of the family cook. Dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe. Add bread and beverage as desired, unless specified.

Plans for a $30,000,000 industrial park for the Flatlands area of Brooklyn were approved yesterday by the City Planning Commission. The project would be the first large-scale commercial and industrial development of its kind in the city.
WASHINGTON, June 4 (AP) -- Advocates of a big army scored an initial victory today as the House of Representatives approved $38,409,561,000 in new funds for the Defense Department.
MOSCOW, June 3--The country-dacha racket, or as it might be known elsewhere, the renting out of an otherwise empty house, has about run its course here.
A five-member citizens' advisory committee called upon the Legislature yesterday to give "top priority" to legislative payroll reform.
WARSAW, June 4 -- Polish Communists think the Soviet leaders may have passed the point of no return in their renewed dispute with Yugoslavia.

CHICAGO, June 4 -- The executive board of the Amalgamated Meat Cutters and Butcher Workmen's Union met at the union's headquarters here today. It initiated two days of closed-door sessions to discuss Senate charges of corruption in the union's leadership.
TODAY'S books are "I Marry You,"* a fine garland of poems in praise of a happy marriage, by John Ciardi, and "The Affair," a subtle novel about an unhappy liaison by Hans Koningsberger.
ALGIERS, June 4 (AP) -- Following, in unofficial translation, is the text of the speech by Premier Charles de Gaulle from the balcony of Government House tonight:

SAN FRANCISCO, June 4 (AP) -- The Braves' pinch-hitting pitcher, Warren Spahn, singled home an eleventh - inning run that beat the San Francisco Giants, 10 -- 9, today. A crowd of 20,886 saw the world champions increase their National League lead over the Giants to one game.
WASHINGTON, June 4 -- A movement to gain for the South a possibly decisive voice in the 1960 Presidential election is taking shape. It won popular endorsement in Alabama's primary election yesterday.
A 43-year-old mother and her 5-year-old son were burned to death in a Brooklyn tenement fire last night. Her three other children were hospitalized.
CHICAGO, June 4 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

LILLE, France, June 4 -- As Gen. Charles de Gaulle was tackling the Algerian problem on the spot, the bronze plaque marking his birthplace here was adorned with flowers by unknown hands today. Slogans freshly chalked on house walls in the grimy suburbs of Lille urge: "Peace in Algeria" and "Negotiate with Algeria."
LONDON, June 4 -- The General Council of the Trades Union Congress, the federation of the unions, advised today against extending the Greater London bus strike to other industries.
RYE, N. Y., June 4 -- John W. Dawson of Palm Desert, Calif., retained the lead in the fifty-fourth annual championship of the United States Senior Golf Association today at the Apawamis Club.

BALTIMORE, June 4 (AP) -- The Baltimore Orioles defeated the Detroit Tigers for the sixth straight time tonight, coming from behind to win, 6 -- 4, on Gus Triandos' two-run homer in the seventh inning.
Acceptance of the United States plan for a conference on Antarctica was hailed yesterday as a step toward international control not only of Antarctica but of outer space.
INDIANAPOLIS, June 4 (AP) -- The ten American drivers who will compete June 29 in the Monza (Italy) 500-mile race and their car assignments were announced today by the United States Auto Club.

We quote from a news story out of Westchester County: "An automobile driver who swerved head-on into another car on the Cross County Parkway Saturday and caused seven deaths was found today to have been intoxicated. Dr. Victoria A. Bradess, medical examiner of Westchester County, said laboratory tests showed that his blood contained nearly twice the quantity of alcohol that indicated intoxication."

IS there a wedding guest in the house? If there is, and she is beside herself over what to wear to the wedding, she should cherish the advice offered by the store experts. The bride, they say, should be the focal point of the wedding. Not the guest.

The Port of New York Authority borrowed $35,000,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance improvements at the Newark Airport, Port Newark, the Brooklyn-Port Authority piers and the George Washington Bridge.
BOUND BROOK, N. J., June 4 -- In point of smoke density in the air Camden may be the smokiest place in New Jersey.
Rain in many sections of the nation held retail sales down in May, and volume as a whole failed to match the 1957 figure, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., credit-reporting organization, said yesterday.

The nation's gasoline stocks declined by 2,398,000 barrels in the week ended last Friday, the American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday. The decline put supplies below the year-ago figure for the first time since last September.
OSLO, Norway, June 4 (Reuters) -- Fisheries Minister Nils Lysoe hinted tonight that Norway might extend the limit of her territorial waters reserved for exclusive fishing rights to twelve miles.
HAVANA, June 4 -- The Cuban Government has begun a new effort to wipe out the rebellion led by Fidel Castro.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 4 -- Leading maritime countries have agreed to meet Jan. 6 in London for the first assembly of the Inter-Governmental Maritime Consultative Organization.
Two successive mechanical mishaps caused delays up to fifty minutes during the evening-rush hour yesterday. About 20,000 commuters were held up on their way home from Grand Central Terminal.
UTICA, N. Y., June 4 (AP) -- James N. Laino was cleared today of perjury charges that had led to his suspension as deputy police chief.
LAKE PLACID, N. Y., June 4 -- The counsel of the State Board of Equalization and Assessment questioned today the fairness of the state law that grants property tax exemptions to war veterans.
District Attorney Frank S. Hogan suggested yesterday that two union officers be removed from their jobs after they had declined to testify before a New York County grand jury.
JAMESBURG, N. J., June 4 -- Mrs. Marge Mason of Ridgewood increased her lead today in the third round of the Garden State Women's Golf Association round-robin tournament at the Forsgate Country Club.
Officials of the rival Transport Workers Union and the Motormen's Benevolent Association met yesterday to discuss a proposed merger of their organizations.

We are sympathetic to the New York City Transit Authority's revenue problems, and appreciative of the authority's efforts to increase income. But the authority's latest venture, in which the government-owned transit system would help promote a company selling soap and other cleansers, seems to us to raise serious questions of propriety. It also threatens to cause public inconvenience detrimental to the transit system.
MILAN, N. Y., May 31 (AP) -- A Brooklyn mechanic was killed instantly while hunting near here today when a companion mistook him for a woodchuck. . . .

BOSTON, June 4 (AP) -- Counsel for Alan Freed, New York disk jockey, today asked dismissal of indictments charging he incited a rock 'n' roll assembly to riot, destruction of property and other violent behavior.
ANNECY, France, June 4 -- There was hardly a ripple on the lake of Annecy today. The same serenity has prevailed throughout this vacation area since the French crisis began.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 4 (AP) Following is the text of President Eisenhower's address today at the commencement exercises of the United States Naval Academy:

Dr. James B. Conant declared yesterday that the American people should stop "trying to name the villains responsible for the alleged deterioration of our educational system," and instead should work to provide the best possible school programs.
Lieut. Gov. George B. DeLuca and State Controller Arthur Levitt were assured yesterday, for all practical purposes, of Democratic renominations for their present offices.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 4 -- Lebanese security forces and rebels engaged in a heavy exchange of small arms fire in Beirut's Moslem quarter today.
WASHINGTON, June 4 -- A $2,000,000,000 Democratic program of Federal loans for construction of local public facilities was approved today by the House Banking and Currency Committee.

The completely automatic electric power plant moved a step nearer reality yesterday with the announcement that Louisiana Power and Light Company had installed a new electronic operational information system in its Sterlington steam station.
WASHINGTON, June 4 -- The State Department announced today that all eleven nations invited by President Eisenhower to discuss a new treaty for Antarctica had accepted.
NORWALK, Conn., June 4 -- Something new in "post prom" parties is in prospect for this year's graduating class at the Norwalk High School.

Carmine G. De Sapio told the Tammany executive committee yesterday that he favored the use of voting machines in the primary contest between Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr. and Councilman Earl L. Brown, "if that is possible."

Jack Brause, realty operator, sold the four-story business building at 308 Fifth Avenue, near Thirty-first Street, to Gabriel Powers for investment The property of 24 by 100 feet was acquired by Mr. Brause from the International Business Machines Company.
Two hundred and five students of engineering, art and architecture were graduated last night at the ninety-ninth commencement of the Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art.

Our Washington dispatches reported yesterday that there is Democratic criticism of Chairman Strauss of the Atomic Energy Commission because "the chairman is skeptical of the feasibility of an inspection system [for bomb tests] and the reliability of a Soviet pledge."
MONTREAL, June 4 -- Canadian manufacturers heard a new call today for an "adequate tariff" to protect the Canadian economy.

BASEBALL'S Gay Caballero, Senor Alfonso Ramon Lopez, was singularly unhappy. His Chicago White Sox were dragging their heels in the lower echelons of the American League instead of challenging the Yankees for the pennant.

INDIANAPOLIS, June 4 (AP) -- Elmer Brown, a Tennessee mountain boy who went to New York, was declared president of the International Typographical Union today. He will take office June 15 as the I. T. U.'s first new head in fourteen years.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., June 4 -- World leadership is the only role open to the United States, Dr. Lewis Webster Jones, president of Rutgers University, told the graduating class tonight.

PORT - AU - PRINCE, Haiti, June 4 -- A special military commission unde rthe state of siege here has sentenced former Lieut. Raymond Chassagne to a year's imprisonment for plotting against internal security.

WEST JORDAN, Utah, June 4 (UPI) -- Joe Miceli spoiled Jay Fullmer's first adventure into bigtime boxing tonight, knocking out the Utah welterweight in the third round of a scheduled ten-rounder before about 2,000 fans at the West Jordan Arena.

For close on half a century the lofty Concourse of the Grand Central Terminal has been a crossroads in the heart of the city, used not only by travelers from far places and the daily tides of commuters but by New Yorkers going about their concerns of business and pleasure within the town.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- The Senate neared a showdown vote today on foreign aid. There were signs that the Administration planned to abandon a proposal for greater flexibility in providing aid to Soviet-bloc nations.

In The Times of May 26 there is an account of an interview with Civil Aeronautics Administrator James T. Pyle on a television program in which he is quoted as having said that "the record shows that planes have fewer fatalities than trains per passenger mile."
The number of persons receiving state unemployment insurance benefits dropped last week to the lowest level since mid-February, the State Labor Department reported yesterday.
RIO DE JANEIRO, June 4 -- The Soviet Union has offered Brazil 20,000 tons of crude oil in exchange for commodities such as cocoa, cotton and coffee.
A five-man interfaith group left yesterday for a goodwill tour that will include the Soviet Union. However, when the group enplaned two of the five still lacked Soviet visas.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., June 4 -- A healthy portion of Southern bone and muscle will clash with a similar amount of Northern brawn Saturday in the seventeenth annual North-South college all-star lacrosse game.

The Bank of Montreal and the Bank of London and South America, Ltd., announced yesterday the establishment of a jointly owned bank to serve the Caribbean area. The new bank will be known as the Bank of London and Montreal and will have an authorized capital of $20,000,000 (Canadian).

May I express the enthusiastic support of the English-Speaking Union for the proposal to establish and endow a new college at Cambridge University in honor of Sir Winston Churchill, the giant of our generation who has become a symbol of Anglo-American friendship.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved narrowly yesterday. The close was unchanged to 4 points (20 cents a bale) off. Business was moderate.

Volume XXXI No. 1 of the Bawl Street Journal, the dollar-a-copy satirical newspaper put out once a year by the Bond Club of New York, will make its 1958 appearance this afternoon. The publication is a comic overture to the Bond Club's annual outing, which will be held tomorrow at Scarborough, N. Y.
CHICAGO, June 5 -- Max Block, an executive of the Amalgamated Meat Cutters and Butcher Workmen Union, tonight resigned from all of his offices in the 350,000-member international union.

An official administrator moved yesterday to settle Federal income tax claims against Jesus de Galindez, missing Basque scholar, by paying $2,855.13. The Federal Government had claimed back taxes and penalties of $62,852.41.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., June 5 -- Microbiological research is being pushed on a large scale in the Soviet Union and no big city is without a group of microbiologists at work, a Russian scientist said here today.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- The Senate rackets committee heard from two of its investigators today that Maxwell C. Raddock had collected $310,000 from the carpenters' union for writing and publishing a book about its late president.

Socony Mobil Oil Company announced yesterday that it would reorganize its domestic marketing department on July 1. Vernon A. Bellman, director in charge of domestic marketing, said the department would be organized on a customer or trade pattern rather than on a product basis as before.

A United States insurance company will enter Great Lakes shipping for the first time tomorrow. The Edmund Fitzgerald, a 25,891-dead-weight ton bulk-ore carrier, will be launched at the River Rouge, Mich., shipyard of the Great Lakes Engineering Works.
Adolf A. Berle Jr., who was Assistant Secretary of State from 1938 to 1944, urged President Eisenhower last night to appoint an Under Secretary of State for the Western Hemisphere.
Excess reserves of Federal Reserve member banks declined $102,000,000, on average, in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

COLOGNE, Germany, June 5 (AP) -- Joseph Rosenstock, former director of the New York City Opera Company, has been signed as musical director of the Cologne Opera for the next two seasons, it was announced today.

Today's new film is "The Law and Jake Wade," a Metro-Goldwyn -Mayer drama in CinemaScope and color, with Robert Taylor, Richard Widmark and Patricia Owens, at the Odeon Theatre. John Sturges directed and William Hawks produced.
The work of the Mental Health Consultation Center of Bergen County will be furthered as a result of a benefit dinner next Thursday.

JACKSON, Miss., Jun 5 (AP) -- Clennon King, former Negro teacher, was in a cell tonight after having tried to enroll in the University of Mississippi. He conceded defeat in an interview. "I'm through with it," the 37-year-old former professor said at state patrol headquarters. "I just want to get out of here."

WASHINGTON, June 5 (AP) -- Attorney General William P. Rogers said today that "reckless criticism" of law-enforcement work was an insult to men and women devoting their lives to the protection of society.
WASHINGTON, June 5 -- The House of Representatives passed by voice vote today a bill to continue present corporation and excise taxes for another year.
ATHENS, June 5 (AP) -- Eleusis Bay is dotted with oil tankers that are laid up because they are too expensive to operate.
RIVERHEAD, L. I., June 5 -- A Supreme Court jury here found former Assemblyman John A. Britting guilty today in the first of the Suffolk County "land-grab" trials.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 5 -- The Sunday night line-up next fall on the American Broadcasting Company's TV network is going to be more strongly Western than ever with "Lawman" set to follow "Maverick," the hour Western now providing strong competition to the other networks.

Gorton's of Gloucester, Inc., seafoods packer and distributor, has announced the election of E. Robert Kinney as president. Mr. Kinney, formerly executive vice president, succeeds Frederick M. Bundy, president since 1946, who was named, chairman.
The Long Island Rail Road wants to abandon a horse-loading platform at the Westbury station on the ground that there is no longer enough equine-shipping business in that horsey suburb.

RANGOON, Burma, June 5 (Reuters) -- Armored cars and jeeps filled with troops and automatic weapons surrounded the lower house of the Burmese Parliament today as the Government faced a no-confidence motion moved by a former Cabinet minister.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, June 5 -- Dr. Suprapto, Attorney General of Indonesia, and Lieut. Col. Rusli, national Chief of Military Police, escaped unhurt from an ambush by Indonesian rebels six miles from Bukittinggi yesterday. The news was reported here tonight.
CHATTANOOGA, June 5 -- The appointment of John N. Popham as general managing editor of The Chattanooga Times was announced today by Ben Hale Golden, president and publisher.

More than a million dollars was contributed to Barnard College last year, Mrs. Millicent C. McIntosh, president of the college, told the Associate Alumnae yesterday. Nearly 600 members of the group held their annual reunion in the college gymnasium.
WASHINGTON, June 5 (AP) -The Senate-House Atomic Energy Committee has drafted safeguards to make sure its bill relaxing nuclear weapons secrecy cannot be used to create atomic powers.
RYE, N. Y., June 5 -- The second second, comprising 183 players, teed off in the United States Senior Golf Association championship at the Apawamis Club today.

Not long ago the head of the house attended a Father's Day celebration at a New England school. This school is situated in the country, a good many miles from such urban conveniences as commercial hotels. It also is far from home.

On one point during the French crisis there has been excessive agreement -- that the Constitution of the Fourth Republic needed revision in the direction of a stronger, more stable executive power. For Frenchmen to criticize and tinker with their basic law is, alas, traditional. But for so many Americans to join in the assault is too much.
CARMEL, N. Y., June 5 (UPI) -- The Putnam County grand jury indicted five persons today in connection with the sale of gravel to the Town of Putnam Valley.
The Army denied yesterday that noncommissioned officers were being downgraded in the realignment of titles and insignia that followed the enactment of the new military pay law.

BOSTON, June 5 -- A House subcommittee investigating influence peddling among Government agencies was challenged today to prove that Sherman Adams had ever intervened in behalf of a "dear friend" in Boston.
WASHINGTON, June 5--The Senate rejected tonight an amendment to the foreign aid authorization permitting the President to give expanded economic assistance to Communist bloc nations.
The Communist weekly, The Worker, said yesterday that it was overcoming financial difficulties, and hoped to resume daily publication "in the next six months."

MANCHESTER, England, June 5 (AP) -- Althea Gibson of New York, the queen of the amateur tennis world, romped into the women's singles semi-finals in the North of England championship today with a 6-2, 6-3 victory over Yola Ramirez of Mexico.

SEVEN candidates for bachelor's and master's degrees marched stiffly across the lawn of St. George's Chapel at Beekman and Fair (Fulton) Streets on June 21, 1758, in the first college commencement held in this city.
Senator Irving M. Ives suggested last night that Governor Harriman had vetoed a Republican labor-rackets bill because "one of his closest pals is one of the leading racketeers in the United States."

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- The third Levittown was charted today. Called Levittown, N. J., it will be on a 4,000-acre tract along U. S. Route 130 about half way between Camden and Trenton. Thus it will be a part of the Philadelphia metropolitan area.
SPOLETO, Italy, June 5 -- If the Festival of Two Worlds continues as bravely as it began tonight, it should become as popular as an established fixture.
DETROIT, June 5 (AP) -- The Detroit Tigers called up their first Negro player today. They are the fifteenth major league team to do so since Jackie Robinson joined the Brooklyn Dodgers in 1947.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 5 -- Lebanese authorities stepped up their armed patrols in Beirut today. This followed a clash here yesterday in which, according to these authorities, anti-tank weapons were used against Government forces for the first time.
Armour Co. and its subsidiaries, large meat-packing enterprise, reported yesterday a substantial increase in earnings despite a drop in sales for the six months ended May 3.
RABAT, Morocco, June 5 -- Ahmed Balafrej, Premier of Morocco, received Alexandre Parodi, French Ambassador, briefly before M. Parodi left by plane tonight for consultations in Paris.
WASHINGTON, June 5 -- The National Labor Relations Board refused today to set aside an employe election on the basis of union charges against Jackie Robinson, vice president of Chock Full O' Nuts.

How about a cruise next week to Nameaug? That's what the Indians called the popular yachting rendezvous. Early White settlers called it Pequot after it was settled in 1646 by John Winthrop Jr., formerly of fishers Island.
MINNEAPOLIS, June 5 -- General Mills, Inc., will open its new headquarters to public view tomorrow and Saturday.

PARIS, June 5 -- Political circles here were unable to agree today in what direction either the National Assembly or Algeria was headed following Premier Charles de Gaulle's speech in Algiers yesterday.
TRENTON, June 5 -- A group of psychiatrists, criminologists, law enforcement officers and state officials today urged the elimination of capital punishment in New Jersey.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- Since the power of union labor leaders was one of the most important tests in the California primaries this week, the political activists of organized labor were perhaps more gratified by the magnitude of their candidate's vote than the Democratic Congressional leaders.
Two streamlined, low-silhouette trains of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad have been taken off their New York-to-Boston run for economy reasons, the railroad said yesterday.

An issue of $20,500,000 of 4 1/2 per cent revenue bonds of the Tulsa Municipal Airport Trust, Okla., is being offered for public subscription by a syndicate headed by Blyth Co., Inc., and Lazard Freres Co. at a price of 100. The bonds will come due June 1, 1983.
AJACCIO, Corsica, June 1 -- It is now possible to piece together the day-to-day details of the brief and mild military dictatorship from which Corsica has just emerged.

ST. LOUIS, June 5 -- Virgil Akins, a product of local boxing rings, will fight Vince Martinez of Paterson tomorrow night for the world welterweight championship. They are meeting for the right to succeed Carmen Basilio, who gave up the 147-pound crown last September on becoming the world's middle-weight king.
BONE, Algeria, June 5 -- Premier Charles de Gaulle took his message of hope, conciliation and spiritual renewal to the Algerian hinterland today, and particularly to the Moslem population.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, June 5 -- H. C. Hansen, Danish Premier and Foreign Minister, confirmed today that his Government had proposed holding a North Atlantic regional conference to find a solution to the problem of extending sea limits.
The Board of Education announced yesterday that it would appeal an Appellate Division ruling that it could not discharge teachers who refused to identify others they had known as Communists.
MEXICO CITY, June 5 (AP) -- The Government is experimenting with "elevator" savings bonds, whose value would go up with general prices. The interest rate is fairly high, 7.6 per cent.
