Carrying 165 pounds, the highest weight of his career, Mrs. Ogden Phipps' Ancestor led all the way to win the two-and-a-half-mile Meadow Brook Steeplechase handicap at Belmont Park yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 5 (UPI) -- Mr. Weeks said the committee's bill endorsed language that has been used by the I. C. C. as justification for holding up the rates of one type of carrier to protect another. He also said the committee bill would not permit rate reductions to encourage competition between different types of transportation.
WASHINGTON, June 5 (AP) -The Senate Labor Committee rejected today 8 -- 5 a labor bill amendment that would have required a ballot before a union could stage a walkout.
WASHINGTON, June 5 -Lewis L. Strauss is retiring as chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission after five controversial years as the principal director of the atomic energy program.
LONDON, June 5 -- A health official of the Port of London cautioned today that thousands of tons of food would rot unless the wildcat strike of London dock workers was settled in a few days.

THE Yankees meandered around their clubhouse in various stages of undress before yesterday's double-header with the White Sox. Neatly attired in a towel, Mickey Mantle autographed baseballs at a table in the center of the room. Clad only in an oversized sweatshirt, Yogi Berra wandered from locker to locker in neighborly visits.

WASHINGTON, June 5 (UPI) -- James P. Mitchell, Secretary of Labor, proposed today a 50-cent-an-hour increase in the minimum wage in soft-coal industry work on Government contracts involving more than $10,000.
PHILADELPHIA, June 5 -The American Federation of Musicians scrapped today a much criticized constitutional provision giving dictatorial power to the union's president.

Ivor B. Clark, Inc., mortgage brokerage company, has leased large office space in the new Tishman Building at 666 Fifth Avenue at Fifty-second Street. The lease was announced by Alan V. Tishman, vice president of the Tishman Realty Construction Company, owner and builder of the structure.

LOS ANGELES, June 5 (UPI) -- The City of Los Angeles, certain now that the voters approve of the Chavez Ravine contract with the Dodgers, turned attention today to overthrowing three pending taxpayer suits.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., June 5 (AP) -- The head of a railroad brotherhood said today that sections of a bill before Congress would break the back of railroad passenger service.

The Times reported that the Board of Education of Syosset, L. I., removed a Russian patriotic song from a school glee club program. The teacher was reported to have admitted an "error in judgment" in introducing the song.

WASHINGTON, June 5 (AP) -A lead and zinc study group to seek stabilization of the industry is being planned, informed sources said today.
WASHINGTON, June 5 (AP) -- W. A. Patterson, president of United Air Lines, sharply criticized the Civil Aeronautics Board today for what he said was a failure to move to halt air collisions.
BONN, Germany, June 5 -- Barge traffic between West Berlin and West Germany swelled toward normal today after announcement here that the Government would pay the punitive East German waterways tax.

A 70-year-old Phi Beta Kappa will be among the 590 seniors at the thirty-third semi-annual graduation exercises at Queens College next Tuesday.
LONDON, June 4 -- A number of British insurance companies are reporting substantial losses on their underwriting activities in the United States.

WESTBURY, L. I., June 5 -- Jean Laird, the oldest entry in the six-horse field, equaled the season's best trotting time tonight as he high-stepped his way to victory in the $8,000 Burgundy at Roosevelt Raceway.
WASHINGTON, June 5 -- Edward N. Gadsby was reappointed as chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission today and was sworn in for a five-year term as a commission member.

WHEN a young person of college age or older still has trouble finding friends, his parents may be tempted to take a hand in his social development. From a Community center official comes a word of warning:
Purchasers of the June 21 issue of The Saturday Evening Post at newsstands will receive a bonus -- a Band-Aid.

A Manhattan lawyer moved in Brooklyn Supreme Court yesterday to have his three clients tried there on criminal charges. He asserted Kings County Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz had shown "bias and prejudice" to him and the defendants.
KUALA LUMPUR, Malaya, June 5 -- The United States team lost all four matches to Thailand in the first interzone semi-final of the world badminton competition in Singapore tonight.

WASHINGTON, June 5 (UPI) -- The Federal Trade Commission overruled today an examiner who dismissed charges that the Timken Roller Bearing Company had illegally barred its distributors and jobbers from handling competitive replacement products.
An estimated total of 120,000 children and adults from 450 Protestant churches paraded in Brooklyn's 129th annual Sunday School Parade yesterday.

Two six-story apartment buildings occupying a plot 125 by 90 feet at 515-21 West 122d Street were sold by Nathan D. Kessler to an investing client of Irving Bira, broker in the transaction. The buildings contain sixty apartments and are assessed at $199,000.
The General Electric Company announced plans yesterday for recapturing from Russia world leadership in the field of extra-high-voltage transmission of electricity.

The battle of Yonkers Raceway moved into the showdown stage yesterday. Two stockholders petitioned in Manhattan Supreme Court for an order blocking the scheduled meeting of the harness track's stockholders, set for Tuesday.

Dr. Theodor Heuss, President of West Germany, has come to the United States on an official visit. He is not here to make policy or to change it. He is here to express and to extend goodwill. It will be reciprocated.

ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, June 5 (UPI) -- Tim Holland of Rockville Centre, L. I., limped through the mist off the North Sea today to join three British Walker Cup golfers in the semi-finals of the British amateur championship.
CAIRO, June 5 -- President Gamal Abdel Nasser has begun to exert rigid controls on propaganda efforts here by the Soviet bloc.

The Port of New York extended its traditional welcome yesterday to mark the maiden entry of the S. S. Atlantic, the first United States-flag vessel specifically designed for the tourist-class passenger trade.
Corporate bond trading is perking up on the New York Stock Exchange. Much of the business results from arbitrage in popular convertible issues as a consequence of the rise in stock prices.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 5 (UPI) -- Eleven American and four foreign journalists have been awarded one-year Nieman Fellowships for study at Harvard University.
WASHINGTON, June 5 (AP) -The National Labor Relations Board told Congress today its "current fiscal posture is wretched" as the result of Congressional cuts in appropriations.
Alumni of two more colleges here said yesterday that they would boycott a conference of the American Alumni Council June 22 to 26 at the Lake Placid Club.
ST. LOUIS, June 5 (AP) -- Net earnings of the Brunswick-Balke-Collender Company in the three months ending June 30 will double last year's second-quarter net, B. E. Bensinger, president, said today.

A COLLEGE freshman assembling a wardrobe for her first year on the campus should do a little research on the modes and mores of life at her particular college. Although certain clothes can be worn with aplomb almost anywhere -- and these include men's shirts, sweaters and certain types of skirts -- what clicks in California may look weird in Connecticut.

WASHINGTON, June 5 (AP) -- The Senate Appropriations Committee approved today two bills providing more than $6,150,000,000 to operate numerous Government agencies in the twelve months beginning July 19.

The American Radio Association opened contract talks with East and Gulf Coast passenger and cargo ship operators yesterday. Included in its demands was a novel proposal for an employer-financed plan to improve safety through better radio communications.

We applaud Charles G. Bennett's thorough report in The Times on June 3 of Planning Commissioner James Felt's appraisal of the capital program of the Board of Education. We also applaud Chairman Felt for his courageous and outspoken statement of the city's fiscal situation.
DETROIT, June 5 (AP) -- A Montana woman today won the post that usually leads to the presidency of the 12,000,000-member General Federation of Women's Clubs.

KENT, Ohio, June 5 (AP) -- George Bowman, president of Kent State University, said today that twenty-nine students were being dismissed from the school as a result of a raid on two women's dormitories early today.
WESTHAMPTON BEACH, L. I., June 5 -- The old saw about not being able to teach an old dog new tricks has been knocked into a cocked hat by an Air Force sentry dog, the police said today.
WASHINGTON, June 5 -Dr. Theodor Heuss, President of West Germany, declared before a joint session of Congress today: "Never again in the future shall German and American soldiers fight each other."
WASHINGTON, June 5 -- The staff of the Congressional Joint Economic Committee painted a gloomy picture of the nation's economic outlook today.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- The State Department denied today published reports that the United States would agree to Communist Chinese participation in technical talks on a suspension of nuclear weapons tests if the Soviet Union requested it.
Lazard Freres Co. announced yesterday the filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission of a registration statement covering the initial offering of its new mutual fund, the Lazard Fund, Inc.

Lord Russell of Liverpool, one of England's leading jurists, who is the author of "The Scourge of the Swastika," has a new book on Dutton's list. It is "The Knights of Bushido: The Shocking History of Japanese War Atrocities.

The National Department Stores Corporation had a net operating loss of $556,891 on sales of $7,255,000 for its first fiscal quarter ended April 30, Frank L. Kellogg, president, told the annual meeting here yesterday.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., June 5 (AP) -- A New York educator expressed confidence today that he could successfully run Central High School on an integrated basis next fall without the presence of Federal troops.
" Your Hit Parade," currently televised by the National Broadcasting Company, will be back for the 1958-59 season in a new time period on another network.

To a man floundering in the blue Atlantic even a log can offer some comfort. And so it was that Al Lopez, affable skipper of the White Sox, did not regard his prospects in this year's American League pennant race entirely hopeless as he evacuated town last night.
The San Francisco Giants were-offered the use of Yankee Stadium to stay in New York, Dan Topping, president of the Yanks disclosed yesterday.
ALGIERS, June 5 -- A showdown here between Premier Charles de Gaulle and the Right-wing insurrectional Committees of Public Safety, or juntas, appeared to be close tonight.
The Freeport Sulphur Company disclosed yesterday how it planned to erect what it believes will be the world's largest steel "island," seven miles off the coast of Louisiana in the Gulf of Mexico.
WARSAW, June 5 -- Stefan Cardinal Wyszynski, Roman Catholic Primate of Poland, complained today that the Polish Government was preventing he building of new churches.
WASHINGTON, June 5 -- A leading rocket scientist denounced today as "stunts" some Government-sponsored space exploration projects, including rocket shots at the moon.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange advanced 5 to 14 points (25 to 70 cents a bale) yesterday.
PARIS, June 5 -- Premier Pierre Pflimlin's resignation was ascribed today partly to a naval commander's refusal to land forces in Corsica to put down the insurrection there last week.

SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, Friday, June 6 -- The party with a middle-of-the-road racial policy took a commanding lead early today in incomplete returns from Southern Rhodesia's general election yesterday.

LONDON, June 5 -- Industrials continued their advance on the stock exchange today. They were helps by good dividend and profit statements by two of the leaders, Courtaulds and Metal Box. Elsewhere, price movements were irregular, although the undertone remained firm.
ADEN, June 5 -- Aid from any Western power would be welcomed by the states of the Aden Protectorate if it was approved by the British Government, Sultan Saleh bin Hussein of Audhali said today.

Directors of Canso Natural Gas, Ltd., and Canso Oil Producers, Ltd., plan to consolidate subject to stockholder approval at meetings on June 30. To be named Canso Oil and Gas, Ltd., the merged company would have 3,262,016 shares outstanding.

Uncertainty has vanished concerning the local haven for "The Marriage - Go - Round," starring Charles Boyer and Claudette Colbert. The Leslie Stevens comedy, which Joseph Anthony will direct, is due Oct. 29 at the Plymouth.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 5 -Lebanon's sixty-six-man Parliament today was called to meet July 24 to elect a new President to replace Camille Chamoun.

LISBON, Portugal, June 5 -- Gen. Humberto Delgado, the only Opposition candidate in the coming Presidential election here, pledged today that if elected he would end the thirty-year-old dictatorship and dismiss Premier Antonio de Oliveira Salazar.

Commodity futures closed irregularly yesterday in generally featureless trading on the New York exchanges. Cocoa, copper, lead, rubber and burlap rose; the world sugar months, cottonseed oil, potatoes, zinc, hides and wool declined, and price movements for the domestic sugar contract and coffee were mixed.

A $50,000,000 reduction in borrowings by public utility and transportation companies was the major factor in a $105,000,000 drop in loans to business by the larger New York City banks in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.
BUENOS AIRES, June 5 -- A bill passed by the Chamber of Deputies today calls for reduction of the Army, Navy and Air Force Ministries to secretariats.

The High Authority of the European Coal and Steel Community yesterday registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission a proposed offering of $40,000,000 of bonds and serial notes. WASHINGTON, June 5 -- The Department of Defense has provided the basis for a first test of the Administration's regulation of oil imports.

STRIPED bass have made no dramatic entrance into Long Island waters this spring and there is nothing to promise week-end fishermen who like them. Yet stripers have been taken as far east as Montauk Point and they may appear in force any day now.

Ten high school students who represented the city at the National Science Fair in Flint, Mich., a month ago and won six awards were guests of the American Institute of the City of New York at a dinner last night.

WASHINGTON, June 5 (AP) -- Venezuela expressed concern today to the United States over measures affecting Venezuela's oil exports.

THE handwork produced by American craftsman today in small or large studios across the nation is directly or indirectly influencing mass produced products for the home.
The Aquarium opened to the public yesterday the first section of an expanded outdoor area that will considerably increase the collection of fish, sea mammals and aquatic birds.

Your editorial of May 31 and the letter of Constance Warren published May 29 complement the daily constructive criticism by Jack Gould and merit the warm thanks of all supporters of educational television.

WASHINGTON, June 5 (UPI) President Eisenhower took a personal hand in the decision to postpone a scheduled Central American fact-finding trip by his brother, Dr. Milton Eisenhower, the White House disclosed today.

The counties, cities and towns in the twenty-two-county New York metropolitan region are going to take inventory of their recreational grounds.

THE last half of the fifteenth century saw the twilight of feudalism. The Middle Ages were already waning in some parts of Europe and the fresh winds of the Renaissance were blowing briskly. But in certain out-of-the-way pockets the old, unchanging ways which had endured for some 500 years had not yet been noticeably altered.

The Teber Realty Company, represented by Philip Tzall, sold the five-story apartment house for twenty families at 970 East 179th Street, the Bronx, to Louis Abrams. The property is 44 by 115 feet and is assessed at $52,000. Nehring Brothers were the brokers.
COOPERSTOWN, N. Y., June 5 -- Law enforcement with the aim of "wiping the road clean of willful traffic violators" was called for today by the American Automobile Association.
ATLANTIC CITY, June 5 -Lieut. Gen. W. H. Tunner, Air Force deputy chief of staff, said today that Russian planes were flying within range of this nation's radar warning system daily.
WASHINGTON, June 5 -- The Hearst and Scripps-Howard newspaper organizations have denied discussing moves to reduce competition between their newspapers.

LONDON, June 5 (AP) -- John Fleming, a New York rare book dealer, said today he had bought in Scotland what he believed was the only portrait of William Shakespeare painted in the bard's lifetime.

ROME, June 5 -- The final results in Italy's national elections, made public today, show that the moderate, pro-Western Center parties had a slightly larger majority than at first relieved in both the Senate and the Chamber of Deputies.
A SPECIAL exhibition is on view at the Andre Emmerich Gallery, where artists who are also collectors are represented. And artists, it seems, often collect in unusual fields.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -Legislation for a 10 per cent increase for 1,000,000 Government workers faced a delay today.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- The Treasury received subscriptions totaling $2,570,000,000 for its cash offering of $1,000,000,000 of 3 1/4 per cent twenty-seven-year bonds, it was announced today. The total subscriptions were somewhat higher than had been expected.
The use of voting machines anywhere in the city in the Aug. 12 primary election was ruled out yesterday.

CHICAGO, June 5 (AP) --The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended last Saturday, totaled 529,547 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.

The West End Synagogue will move to the East Side on July 1.
WASHINGTON, June 6 (UPI) -- The Department of Interior announced today that the Government's long-range program to finance mineral and metal exploration would end June 30.
With the exception of cocoa and copper, trading was relatively quiet on the New York commodity exchanges yesterday. Trading was featureless in most markets.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, June 6 -- Indonesia is counting mainly on vessels from the Communist bloc and Japan to fill the drastic shortage of ships for traffic between the Indonesian Islands. The shortage was caused by the recent elimination of Dutch ships from the Indonesians' domestic shipping services.
Eight graduates of the Columbia University School of Architecture will study in Europe, Japan and Latin America this year on William Kinne Fellows Memorial Traveling Fellowships.
BONN, Germany, June 6 -- M. Couve de Murville is scheduled to arrive in Bonn Monday for talks with Chancellor Konrad Adenauer.

THE American West, so far as New Yorkers are concerned, begins on the other side of the Hudson. The numerous corrective measures taken since the recent shocking air collisions should not mislead the public into thinking that the problem of the collision hazard has been all but solved. The measures -- new flight rules, new airways for all-weather control, new restrictions on jet traffic -- are excellent as far as they go. But they must be viewed as the limited palliatives they are.

WASHINGTON, June 6--National unemployment declined in May by more than is usual for the month, the Commerce and Labor Departments reported today. It was the first more-than-usual decline since the recession began.

Under the motto "Linking Muddlety With the World," the Stroud's Creek and Muddlety Railroad operates twentyone quite important mainline miles in West Virginia. Over these miles the S. C. M. totes coal from track-side mines.

SWIMMING POOL -- these two words have a special meaning for thousands upon thousands of American home owners today. The "old swimmin' hole" has been glamoured up, filtered and moved into the back yard for all to enjoy.

THE most severe and costly of all the colonial Indian conflicts was King Philip's War, which receives bare mention in most modern surveys of American history. In this first comprehensive history of the conflict to be written since the seventeenth century Douglas Edward Leach, Assistant Professor of History at Vanderbilt University, points out that "In proportion to population, King Philip's War inflicted greater casualties upon the people than any other war in our history."

THE title of this disturbing book is deliberately chosen and skillfully chosen -- but in English it is ambiguous. "The Question" was a polite term used under the ancien regime in France to describe legal torture used as a means of producing evidence.
Dr. George Wolf, who resigned physician at the Raymond Street Jail in Brooklyn on Tuesday, said yesterday he had notified the Mayor's office that he was withdrawing the resignation.
WASHINGTON, June 7 (UPI) -- Representative Joseph W. Martin Jr., House Republican leader, threw his influence today behind President Eisenhower's drive to unify the military high command.

TO discerning readers of books (fiction) and short stories, the name of Bernard Malamud is familiar. The New Yorker, Harper's Bazaar and Partisan Review, among others, have printed his short stories, a batch of which recently appeared under the heading of "The Magic Barrel."
APART from foreign imports, mostly of American origin; the great successes of this season in Paris are to be found on the boulevards.
' Nine homes in Greenwich Village's ]V[acdougal Alley willI be open Wednesday from 4 toI 9 P. M, for the benefit of the1 camp fund of Greenwich House, I the settlement house at 27/ Barrow Street.

Five airplane mechanics were injured yesterday when a tire blew out on a Super-H Constellation cargo carrier in a hangar at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens. One of the men was reported to be in critical condition.

SINCE the discovery in 1940 in France's Department of the Dordogne of a series of fascinating prehistoric paintings on the walls of the caves of Lascaux, a situation of considerable irony has developed. Now that these works of Cro-Magnon man, which have preserved their freshness of color and outline for 15,000 years, have become accessible to scholars and tourists, there is danger that they may be obliterated.
LOS ANGELES, June 7 -- Anyone who has eaten fruit or vegetables or has used cotton may be indebted to a Mexican, even though the product came from the Western United States.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 7 -Al Worthington put down a Cincinnati threat in the sixth inning, then drove in two runs to clinch a 7-3 victory for the San Francisco Giants over the Redlegs today.

THE scouts, who are ever on the alert for the stuff out of which movies may be made, have not overlooked "The Visit." The German -language drama by Friedrich Duerrenmatt, a Swiss, which was adapted by Maurice Valency and has proved a hit vehicle for the famed husbandand-wife team of Alfred Lunt and Lynn Fontanne at the theatre now bearing their names, has deeply interested no less than four important parties.
The bewildering complexity of required tuition fees charged by state universities has been made the subject of a national study. There appears to be no pattern for the wide divergencies.
OTTAWA, June 7 -- Interest of a proposed Canadian bill of rights was revived this weekly a suit against Premier Maurice Duplessis of Quebec in the Supreme Court of Canada.

THE idea of pay-as-you-see television received a severe setback Friday night. The experimental toll system in Bartlesville. Okla., widely failed as a harbinger of video things to come, closed down for back of support.
KARACHI, Pakistan, June 7 (AP) -- Prime Minister Firoz Khan Noon charged today that India had curtailed river water to Pakistan canals, depriving five million acres of land of irrigation.
WYNNEWOOD, Pa., June 7 -Another memento was added today to the world-wide collection of curios in the living room of Mrs. William C. McClintock's home in this Philadelphia Main Line community.

FLY-ROD fishermen have been at it for a couple of months now and it is about time for them to change lines. There is nothing wrong with the lines they are using but every angler knows he can cast better with another line, a line of different dimensions and design.

THE only walled city in North America; a place where cars coast "up-hill"; a waterfall that flows in reverse; and some of the most unspoiled scenery in the world -- these are but a few of the reasons for the popularity of a motor tour of Canada's Maritime Provinces.
PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., June 7 -- William B. Campbell's Tonto captured Resolute Class honors today as the Manhasset Bay championship interclub series resumed.
The issue on fluoridation of our water supplies is not as complicated to me as Gerald Walker makes it appear in his article.
PACHUCA, Mexico, June 7 -This city of 60,000 population and its environs pose one of Mexico's severest problems.
Two spry octogenarians -leaders in their respective segments of the shipping industry on either side of the Atlantic -met briefly here last week.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 7 -The Rev. Dr. Billy Graham's crusade goes into its seventh week at the San Francisco Cow Palace tomorrow.
ST. LOUIS, June 7 -- Rip Repulski returned to torment the St. Louis Cardinals by driving in five runs to pace a 15-6 Philadelphia Phillie victory today.

SALADS, relished throughout winter as the ideal accompaniment for main courses, gain new stature when summer arrives. In markets, crisp greens are packed high, side by side with the year's most colorful and flavorful garnishes -- radishes, plump tomatoes, brittle stalks of celery, tender scallions, cucumbers, avocados and a host of fresh herbs.
The Eastern Regional Traffic Court Conference at Fordham University as reported in The Times of June 3 sounded familiar. Prescription: teach driver-training in high school, etc.

STATISTICS on bridge-playing are not very impressive to those who do not play bridge. The nonplayer is convinced that "nearly every- body plays bridge," and though he may divide the national population of 165,000,000 by a very conservative divisor he still arrives at a number that is far too high.
BOSTON -- In a motorized age of supermarkets and super-highways it is still possible in some parts of New England to slow down enough to see a general store and even an occasional horse and buggy.

BOSTON, June 7 (UPI) -- A missed shoestring catch with the basses filled enabled the Boston Red Sox to overtake the Chicago White Sox with four runs in the seventh inning today and gain a 7-6 victory.

ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, June 7 -- Joe Carr of Ireland, aided by two great successive shots, won the British Amateur golf championship for the second time today by overpowering England's Alan Thiriwell, 3 and 2.
ST. CATHARINES, Ont., June (Canadian Press) -- St. Catharines-area high schools dominated the Canadian Secondary Schools Rowing Association championships, which were completed today.
Barbara Terry, a soprano, made her debut at Carnegie Recital Hall yesterday afternoon.
Two New York auction galleries will be conducting sales this week for antiquarians of widely differing tastes.
LONDON, June 7 -- The first, faint signs of a revival of popularity for Prime Minister Harold Macmillan's Conservative party have been discerned in the British political scene.
The first contract for planning the new $74,000,000 Bellevue Hospital will be put before the Board of Estimate Thursday.

CINCINNATI, June 7 -- It is most urgent that order be established on earth before man sets out for other planets, Rabbi Harry J. Stern of Montreal told the graduating class of the Hebrew Union College-Jewish Institute of Religion at Rockdale Avenue Temple here today.

ST PETERSBURG, Fla. -Summer fishing will have a new dimension in the Gulf of Mexico off Florida this year as anglers begin to bait their hooks for sailfish and even marlin, species which up to now have been considered out of the reach of the average sports fisherman hereabouts.

MONTREAL -- Spread over a wide area in Quebec, from the Gaspe Peninsula in the east to the Laurentians in the west, are a number of parks which have a special appeal for tourists whose idea of a perfect vacation is to get as far from civilization as possible.

HARTFORD, Conn. -- New resort and motel construction, the new $464,000,000 Connecticut Turnpike that opened early this year, improved public and private recreational facilities and a heavy schedule of special summer events are among the items that enhance Connecticut's appeal for the vacationist this summer.
MISSOULA, Mont. -- At a recent meeting of the Dude Ranchers Association, one member mentioned an operator in Colorado who was installing tile baths and wall-to-wall carpeting in his guest quarters.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Colo. -- To wheel over the high, hot plains to the Rocky Mountains for a summer vacation can be exhausting, and possibly many Easterners go home wondering why they had made the journey.
More than 100 cruising-type sailing yachts of thirty-four to seventy-two feet, about 800 men and possibly a scattering of brine-steeped women will begin the Newport-to-Bermuda race next Saturday.

NORFOLK, Va. -- Another symphonic drama by Paul Green depicting an important stage of American history will be offered this summer in the Midsouth. It is the new play, "The Confederacy," and it will be presented at near-by Virginia Beach in a new outdoor amphitheatre there.

COOKBOOKS, like everything else, have taken on a new look. Gone or almost gone is the encyclopedic tome with its comprehensive collection of recipes for everything from appetizers to cordials, with lists of ingredients and paragraphs of instructions and a simple index where beef and bread were found under the letter B and cakes and cookies under C.

A QUESTION that has troubled this observer anent the new Lincoln Center of the Performing Arts that is about to rise in radiant glory on New York's upper West Side is why there will be no facility or acknowledgment within its scope for the great performing art of motion pictures -- or cinema, as it is artfully known.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 7 (AP) -- The Naval Academy has decided to do away with special classroom sections for football players. Starting next fall they will go to class with the rest of the midshipmen.

In recent months, numerous films have emerged from Hollywood that because of their unusually long running time, are presented on a time schedule comparable to the legitimate theatre. It is the inconvenience caused to the average moviegoer when there are no continuous performances available that prompts my concern.

KEENE, N. Y. -- Lying between Vermont's Green Mountains and New York State's scenic Adiondacks, Lake Champlain forms a narrow, 130-mile-long water corridor between the Hudson and the St. Lawrence River ship lanes.

The front steps of St. Patrick's Cathedral will bloom with thousands of flowers and plants Tuesday, when the Outdoor Cleanliness Association will hold its twenty-sixth annual benefit flower mart there.

FOR the last two months a man has been looking glumly at his hi-fi equipment, knowing that stereo disks were coming in and wondering what to do about the situation. Finally came the point where action could no longer be put off.
How to attract and retain high-type employes is an old problem for business. But one benefit program is said to be solving it for a big company.

In a picture layout entitled "Close-ups of the Pentagon" (May 18) you have captioned a photograph of classified waste paper, in part: "* * * it is chewed up and made into cardboard for cartons. The Pentagon used to burn such waste, but found this method a money-saver."
BOSTON, June 7 (AP) -- B. A. Dario's Dandy Blitzen scored her first victory of 1958 today when she captured the $10,000 added Pinafore Stakes by five lengths at Suffolk Downs.

MILWAUKEE, June 7 (AP) -- The University of Kansas, with A1 Oerter setting a meet record with a discuss throw of 188 feet 2 inches, tonight coasted to its third straight Central Collegiate Conference track championship.
PARIS, June 7 -- The first week of the new French revolution was a period of stocktaking and recovery after twenty days of excitement and strong emotion.

VIENNA, June 6 -- Marshal Tito has once again been read out of the international Communist movement, but in dealing sternly with the Belgrade heretic Nikita Khrushchev is not likely to succeed where Stalin failed.
HOW can Beatrice Lillie do what Rosalind Russell was doing in "Auntie Mame" about a year and a half ago? She can't. At least, she doesn't.

AS delicate as the finest silk are the flowers of the Japanese morning glory. The four or five-inch blooms come in exquisite pastel shades from blush white to imperial purple. They include such unusual hues as deep brown, old rose, cherry red and silvery gray.

A trans-Atlantic exchange of student views between the United States and Germany disclosed yesterday a difference of viewpoint on German reunification. The participating students agreed, however, that the exchange had contributed toward much-needed understanding of the problem.
PARIS, June 7 (UPI) -- Maurice Schumann, chairman of the powerful Foreign Affairs Committee of the French National Assembly, hailed Gen. Charles de Gaulle as the "George Washington" of France today.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., June 7 (AP) -- John Graves cut too many chemistry classes as a high school senior last year and could not graduate. It made him angry.

The principal speaker at the dedication ceremonies of the St. Lawrence Seaway locks will be Secretary of the Army Wilber M. Brucker, according to Lewis G. Castle, administrator of the waterway's development organization.

An automatic pilot will soon help fly commercial helicopters. The Sikorsky Aircraft Division of the United Aircraft Corporation announced last week that its automatic stabilization equipment had been certified by the Civil Aeronautics Administration for use in commercial rotary-wing planes.

Debutantes and post-debutantes on the junior committee for the free neighborhood concerts in Carl Schurz Park to be held this summer, will be guests at a luncheon tomorrow. Mrs. John Chapman will be the hostess in the Palm Court of the Plaza.

In June, month of roses and academic leave-taking, wistful graduates in caps and gowns take a long backward look at Alma Mater before each in his or her own way prepares to answer the absorbing question, "What commences at commencement?" For most, college graduation today is only the preliminary completion of a first important step in the planning of a career.

THE great oratorios have always presented problems to the record makers. The invention of the long-playing process eliminated the problem of length, but others still remain. This is so because a recording of an oratorio has to do justice at one and the same time to a chorus, a symphony orchestra and solo singers.

Last week here in the Palais des Nations, representatives of the United Nations, the International Labor Organization, World Health Organization, the United Nations Children's Fund and the United Nations Educational, Scientic and Cultural Organization met to review their problems and programs in rehabilitation.

A TIFF between traditionalists and modernists over how to behave on Sunday is rattling tea cups all over England. It reached the political heights when the Lord's Day Observance Society, an organization of clergy and laymen dedicated to maintaining what some foreign visitors call the dullest Sunday in Europe, reproached Prime Minister Harold Macmillan for attending a charity cricket match on a Sunday.

THE item in "In and Out of Books" may mislead some of your readers in its statement that an article by Dwight Macdonald in Commentary "pulled the rug" from under James Gould Cozzens and "generally was credited with carrying considerable weight in eliminating 'By Love Possessed' from the winner's circle at the National Book Award."

GREENWICH, Conn., June 7 -- The twenty-sixth event of the Greenwich Kennel Club, held today on the old polo field at Yale Farms, wound up with best in show going to an Old English sheepdog, Ch. Merriedip Duke George.

MOSCOW, June 7 -- The Soviet Ministry of Culture, which has an enviable record in keeping stage and screen fare pure, has decided to switch its attention to the off-the-job behavior of actors and actresses.
A member of the Harriman Administration charged last night that Republicans were trying to confuse the public on the issue of crime.

ADEN, June 7 -- The sudden return to Yemen from New York of the younger brother of Imam Ahmad, Prince Saif alIslam Abdullah, who had been in "exile" since 1955, has just become known here. At the same time it was learned that Crown Prince Saif al-Islam Mohammed al-Badr was soon to be sent to Cairo by his father.

Religious forces are aiding the needy overseas with goods and services valued at nearly $300,000,000 annually, according to an estimate released yesterday by the National Council of the Churches of Christ in the U. S. A.

DETROIT, June 7 (UPI) -- The United Auto Workers charged today that the Chrysler Corporation was trying to weaken or break the union, possibly to create a "company union" or leave the road open for another union.
CARACAS, Venezuela, June 5 -- A mounting crime wave here has caused the Ministry of Interior to announce a special campaign against thieves and gangsters.

THE growing use of art for office buildings is pointed up by a guest exhibition at the Downtown Gallery entitled "Portrait of a Building," consisting of ten paintings by artists who were commissioned but given an entirely free hand to present off canvas their reaction to a new lower Manhattan structure.

The make-up of the United States delegation to the forty-second annual conference of the International Labor Organization, now being held in Geneva, is an index of the growing recognition in this country of the I. L. O.'s importance to its eighty member nations. For the first time our Government has headed its delegation with a Secretary of Labor.
MANCHESTER, England, June 7 -- Althea Gibson of New York today defeated Maria Bueno of Brazil, 6 -- 1, 8 -- 6, to win the Northern England tennis championship for the third year in a row.

WHEN all critics turn thumbs down on an ambitious, costly network telecast because it got too bogged down in "gimmicks," there's one little group of headquarters workers that tries hard not to smile or show its gratification.

TRENTON -- The rolling hills of northwest New Jersey and the thickly forested pine belt in the southern part of the state offer the holiday or vacation-bound resident of the metropolitan area, who prefers the hinterland to the shore, a most pleasant and economical sojourn.
NORFOLK, Va., June 7 -- A show-down moved closer today on the racial integration of public education in Norfolk and Newport News.
SEATTLE, June 7 -- Hugh Entrop piloted his nameless little home-built speed boat to 107.821 miles an hour today on Lake Washington -- the highest speed man has yet attained in an outboard motorboat.
Sunshine broke out all over last week as buyers came to the city to look over the new fall and winter fashions.

Five Japanese biochemists report in Science, official journal of the American Association for the Advancement of Science, that they have isolated from several types of human cancer tissue a new chemical substance found only in malignant tumors and never in normal cells.

Gamal Abdel Nasser of Egypt in his quest for leadership in the Middle East, has used as a lever the powerful force of "pan-Arabism." He has proclaimed -- and all Arab states have repeated the refrain -- that "all Arabs are brothers."
THE tourist with limited vacation time must make it count. Therefore, he or she should also be selective.
WASHINGTON, June 7 -After forty-two years of wandering through the Congressional labyrinth in search of statehood, Alaska this year finally has a chance to find it.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., June 7 -- Adelphi College trustees have selected a 100-acre site in Southampton for the college's proposed Suffolk County branch. The first private liberal arts institution in the county, it will be on the sixty-acre Chisholm Estate on Millstone Brook Road and adjoining property.

Sixteen thousand persons, most of them teen-agers from the metropolitan area, filed into Madison Square Garden last night for an evangelistic rally commemorating the eighteenth anniversary of the Word of Life Fellowship, Inc.

BOSTON -- Sixteen northeast storms last winter very nearly did in one of the saltier summer attractions in Massachusetts. But links to the vigilance of the lists of Rockport, "Motif No. 1 has been saved, its list to award intact.
MOSCOW, June 7 -- The theory that Antarctica is not really a continent but a string of islands covered by a huge ice sheet will get some support from Soviet findings in the Antarctic region.
ATLANTIC CITY -- New Jersey's more than fifty coastal resorts last weekend officially opened what they hope will be a most successful and profitable summer season.

HAVANA, June 7 -- Constitutional guarantees of basic rights were again suspended throughout Cuba for a period of forty-five days by President Fulgencio Batista and his Cabinet tonight. Censorship of press and radio automatically continues.

WASHINGTON, June 7 (UPI) -- A vision of America in the year 2000 includes double-deck highways, urban streets reserved for pedestrians only, homes and factories deriving electricity from the sun, the skyscraper giving way to wide, low buildings with landscaped courts.
MOSCOW, June 7 -- The love fest between American musicians and Soviet audiences continues.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., June 7 -- Mrs. Hester Ringling Sanford and her son, Stuart G. Lancaster, said today they were resigning as director and vice president, respectively, of the Ringling Brothers and Barnum Bailey Circus in protest against its "mismanagement" by John Ringling North, president.

DESPITE an estimated loss of almost $700,000,000 on passenger business last year and despite many cuts in service, especially in the East, a look at the summer timetables shows that there are still plenty of fine trains ready to carry the vacationist to almost any point.
PELHAM MANOR, N. Y., June 7 -- Tom Courtney proved today he again is ready to take on all comers at 880 yards and 800 meters.

Two preview performances will open the summer tour of the Marionette Theatre's presentation of "The Shoemaker and the Elves." the Parks Department announced yesterday. The premieres will be held in Central Park on the lawn area west of the Shakespeare Gardens, east of the West Drive at approximately Eighteenth Street, Wednesday at 10:30 A. M and 3:30 P. M.

NEWARK, June 7 -- Four men, including three brothers who operate a smelting plant here, were arraigned today before a United States Commissioner in the investigation of the hijacking of $47,000 in tin ingots.

GUATEMALA, June 4 -- The Government will soon announce that passage from Mexico to Guatemala on the Inter American Highway is open to all travelers without restrictions.

ONCE upon a time when I was very young, I used to read books stretched out in a steamer chair with a medium-sized dog named Sandy asleep on my chest. That was during summer vacations, of course. Some of the books I read were by Harold Bell Wright and Gene Stratton Porter, and I liked them just as much as Ernest Thompson Seton's animal stories.

NOTHING fails like success. This epigram might well have been applied to Hitler's Wehrmacht at the height of the greatest conquest of modern history. For, after overrunning Western Europe in a few weeks of 1940 the conquerors did not know how to use their victory.

LISBON, Portugal, June 7 -- The Portuguese will vote tomorrow, at home and in the nation's vast overseas territories in Africa and Asia, for a new President to succeed Gen. Francesco Higino Craveiro Lopes.
New York and Pennsylvania have accepted Federal aid under the new Unemployment Compensation Law signed Wednesday by President Eisenhower.

THE rose gardens of the New York Botanical Garden and the Brooklyn Botanic Garden will be the setting for special events on Thursday. Amateur rosarians will be able to consult experts on cultural problems.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 7 -- The United States has offered to produce two traveling laboratories that can show the under-developed countries what can be done with radio-isotopes.
LEWISBURG, Pa., June 7 -- The laying of the cornerstone for Bucknell University's largest classroom building now under construction featured the observance of Alumni Day on the campus today.
PROVIDENCE, R. I., June 5 -- About 6,000 pages of testimony for and against a proposed $55,000,000 oil refinery in the town of Jamestown are under Federal District Court study here.

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- The Defense Department declared in a detailed report today that the Soviet Union's huge ground forces were capable of unleashing a major land war without resort to mass-destruction weapons.

KINGSTON, N. Y., June 7 (AP) -- State Senate Majority Leader Walter J. Mahoney told the annual convention of the Ulster County Republican Committee today "the only thing that can defeat us this fall is defeatism."
WHITE PLAINS, June 7 -- One of the state laws most generally violated by Westchester and many other counties is a 1909 statute concerning the District Attorneys.

Twice in the last two weeks the Soviet Union and its allies have indicated their keen interest in the disarmament issue. At the recent Warsaw Pact nations' Moscow meeting, Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev's recommendation that those nations unilaterally reduce their armies was followed by a decision that the East European countries would cut their armies by 119,000 men.

Starting at the bottom and working up has often been extolled. Winston V. Morrow Jr., 34-year-old executive vice president of the Avis Rent-a-Car System, suggests that it's quicker and more profitable to start at the top -- if one has the skill and the backing to stay there.

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- The Atomic Energy Commission has raised last-minute objections to a proposed agreement to promote the development of atomic power in Western Europe. The commission's objections center on the question of international inspection, an issue that was believed to have been settled in negotiations with the European Atomic Energy Community.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 7 -Lebanese sources said tonight that the army had broken an organized attempt by rebel forces to move on Beirut. This is the first decisive military success the Government has been able to claim since troubles began here May 10.

IN July, 1955, Lawrence Welk and his champagne music made their first nation-wide telecast. During the following year Welk's gross earnings climbed to the $3,000,000 mark. In what is frankly one of the folksiest bios of the year, Mrs. Coakley sets herself the task of explaining how "the rustic personality who plays corny music" achieved success.
WASHINGTON, June 7 -- Last Tuesday was a great day for the national Democratic party and for the political action committees of organized labor.

PARIS, June 7 -- For the good or bad of the republic, General Charles de Gaulle now wields power never before entrusted to a Premier of the Fourth Republic and rarely given to a head of government in French Republican history.

BROOKVILLE, L. I., June 7 -- Because he had got directions on how to cross Long Island Sound from a retired Navy admiral, William Zeckendorf today arrived fortyfive minutes late for graduation exercises at C. W. Post College here. He was to have presided.

Public libraries throughout the country are preparing their biggest free educational reading program. This is the well-known vacation reading program which gives library card holders an opportunity to pick their own library of books for extended loan from June through October, these books to be taken along with the family wherever it goes, to stay with them wherever they stay, so that no matter when the free time there are books to read.
Operators of inland water transportation are not ready to accept a revised version of Senate legislation that would affect railroad rate-making authority.

AT 66, Joyce Clyde Hall is a thin, shy, diffident man with the apparently apocalyptic notion that good taste is good business. As president of the fabulously successful Hallmark Card Company, he has brought such artists as Saul Steinberg, Grandma Moses and Cecil Beaton to his greeting cards.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 7 -- Princeton opened its quest for the Big Three baseball championship today by defeating Yale 10 -- 1, before a crowd of 1,200.

WHEN so many of us are looking upon missiles as the be-all and end-all of defense and offense it is a timely and sobering reminder to read Richard G. Hubler's well-packed treatise on the country's great military air arm -- the Strategic Air Command.

A slate headed by Patrolman John E. Carton, president of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association for the last eleven years, has been defeated in a mail ballot election. The present vice president, Patrolman John J. Cassese of the chief inspector's office is slated to take over as president for a two-year term on July 1, it was announced at P. B. A. headquarters yesterday.

Fordham University will confer eight honorary degrees at its 113th commencement exercises Wednesday. Governor Harriman will be among those honored.

NIAGARA FALLS, N. Y. -- One, and possibly two new observation platforms set high above the waters of the American Falls, are among the improvements scheduled for this famous scenic attraction in northwest New York State.

WASHINGTON, June 7 (UPI) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board took two more actions today to make flying safer.

A technique for identifying individuals through electronic computer analysis of skull measurements taken from standard X - ray pictures has been developed at the University of Pennsylvania in Philadelphia.

TULSA, June 7 -- The Professional Golfers Association champion, Lionel Hebert, shot a oneover-par 71 at the Southern Hills Country Club course today to set the scoring pattern for the nation's golfers on National Golf Day.

THE calendar says that suddenly it is along in June, so the publishing year now is reaching the end of the first half of its appointed course. Was the first semester of 1958 good or bad? On page 3 this morning.

Some 200,000 babies are stillborn annually in the United States. A large number of these stillbirths are the result of premature labor, due to the fact that in many cases of pre-maturity uterine contractions are not accompanied by a sufficient softening of the uterus or dilation of the cervix.
CONCORD, N. H. -- New Hampshire, which boasts more recreation facilities per square mile than any other state, is gearing itself for another boom in summer vacation business.

ENDICOTT, N. Y., June 7 -- The first buildings of a completely new campus for Harpur College, the liberal arts college of the State University of New York, are being finished in nearby Vestal, N. Y., for occupancy next fall. Founded in 1946, the college became a unit of the State University in 1950 and presently occupies temporary facilities here for its 610 fulltime men and women students.
Diamonds aren't the best friends of many importers. In fact, the industrial type is a great burden, dragging almost half of the diamond importing industry into insolvency.
It took Dick Savitt just an hour of powerful baseline play yesterday to retire one of the nation's oldest perpetual tennis trophies, the Terrace-Knickerbocker Bowl.

Attorney General Edmund G. Brown, California's Democratic candidate for Governor, came here yesterday for political advice from Governor Harriman. After a private ninety-minute conference they asserted that a strong Democratic tide was running in their respective states.

LONDON, June 7 -- The strident pace of world events has changed the casual get together initially planned by Prime Minister Macmillan and President Eisenhower into an important meeting at a time of multiplying difficulties for the Western alliance.

Sergei Prokofieff is dead, unfortunately, so we cannot savor the pleasure this apology must undoubtedly bring to Shostakovich, Khachaturian and the other composers condemned so bitterly ten years ago who are still alive today.
The Soviet Union is allowing Adlai E. Stevenson to visit some points off the regular tourist track, the Cosmos Travel Bureau reported yesterday.

PARIS, June 8 -- General de Gaulle's pronouncements on Algeria have so far been imprecise and even Delphic. Various parties to that savage dispute can simultaneously read into the Premier's spoken views much that may comfort them. But at the same time they must remain disturbed by his deliberate vagueness.

SKYSCRAPER designers draw aviation beacons, clocks and weather signals for city turrets, and townsfolk, always on the run, consult them. Marion Aigner, who lives high in an apartment tower in East Fifty-third Street off Second Avenue, has used them in her design for daily living.
The 1958 Lewisohn Stadium summer concert series will begin Monday evening, June 23, on the fortieth anniversary of the opening Stadium concert in 1918.

LOS ANGELES, June 8 (AP) -Johnny Podres scored his fifth consecutive victory in the Coliseum today, getting nineteen-hit support as the Los Angeles Dodgers routed the Milwaukee Braves, 12 -- 4, for a sweep of the three-game series before a crowd of 57,122.
St. John's University conferred undergraduate and advanced degrees on 1,423 students yesterday at its eightyeighth annual commencement.
DALLAS, June 8 -- An executive who entered advertising twenty-five years ago because she was "fascinated by words," has been named Advertising Woman of the Year.
Park Commissioner Robert Moses has warned Mayor Wagner of growing pollution that might contaminate permanently some of the city's bathing areas. If the present trend...
A smart new cover-up can do wonders to pep a summer city uniform, which this season will undoubtedly be a basic black chemise or last season's sheath newly eased at the waist.

OYSTER BAY, L. I., June 8 -- Walter S. Gubelmann's yawl Windigo of the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club in Class A, Philip F. Miller's yawl Glory from Indian Harbor in Class B and E. W. Stetson, Jr.'s, sloop Banda from Pequot in Class C were the winners of first-place prizes in the New York Yacht Club's spring regatta today.
BALTIMORE, June 8 (AP) -The Baltimore Orioles and Kansas City Athletics bunched their limited hits in economical fashion today while splitting a well-pitched double-header.

CANTON, N. Y., June 8 (AP) -The New York Stock Exchange will take a census of stockholders, G. Keith Funston, exchange president, said today in an address at St. Lawrence University's commencement exercises.

The Rev. Dr. Edgar Franklin Romig, pastor of the West End Collegiate Church, West End Avenue and Seventy-seventh Street, took issue yesterday with an assertion that spiritual healing was "fast becoming the most talked-about phenomenon in American Protestantism."

If past experience can be used as a guide, according to Geoffrey H. Moore of the National Bureau of Economic Research, the American economy will not return to its July, 1957, peak until some time in 1959 or possibly early 1960.

Yesterday's Central Committee resolution appears to have political as well as musical significance, although the full political implications are unclear.
CHICAGO, June 8 (AP) -Weather was the dominant factor in grain futures trading last week and it was mostly bearish.
HAGERSTOWN, Md., June 7 -- Never did a school term end with such a grand finale as it did here last week.
NORTHAMPTON, Mass., June 8 -- Senator John F. Kennedy said here today that the United States could no longer count on freedom's coming to eastern Europe by "a dramatic or violent revolt."

New Yorkers have the privilege of helping needy youngsters to enjoy two weeks of camping during the summer. The Catholic Youth Organization of the Archdiocese of New York, 122 East Twentysecond Street, New York 10, is now making its annual appeal for funds to send underprivileged children to the two C. Y. O. camps in Putnam Valley, near Peekskill, N. Y.
The Rev. Dr. Randolph Ray preached his last sermon yesterday as rector of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Transfiguration (the Little Church Around the Corner).

BERLIN, June 8 -- Eight officers and a sergeant of the United States Army's Third Armored Division were detained in Communist East Germany today after a helicopter in which they were flying had made a forced landing.
CARACAS, Venezuela, June 7 -- Former President Romulo Betancourt suggested today the possibility of modifying the present fifty-fifty arrangement with oil companies.

HANOVER, N. H., June 8 -Dr. Theodor Heuss, the first president of the Federal Republic of Germany, was awarded an honorary degree of Doctor of Laws today by Dartmouth College. He is on a state tour of the United States.
MEDFORD, Mass., June 8--Chances of avoiding nuclear warfare are "reasonably good," Erwin D. Canham, editor of The Christian Science Monitor, told the graduating class of Tufts University today.

Seven of the world's best tennis players, if not the seven best, fly into New York today for Jack Kramer's tournament of champions at Forest Hills, Queens. Tomorrow they start work-outs on the turf of the West Side Tennis Club, and the matches begin in the Stadium Saturday, with $15,000 at stake.

LEONIA, N. J., June 8 -- The chairman of the Northern Valley Commuters Organization today assailed the Interstate Commerce Commission for the manner in which it granted increases in ferry fares between New Jersey and New York.
EAST LANSING, Mich., June 8 -- Adlai E. Stevenson outlined today a broad program to meet the "creeping crisis" of the free world economy.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 8 -- Tab Hunter, on loan-out from Warner Brothers to Paramount, will play the romantic lead opposite Sophia Loren in "That Kind of Woman." He has just finished a co-starring role at his home studio with Gwen Verdon and Ray Walston in "Damn Yankees."
HALIFAX, N. S., June 8 (Canadian Press) -- A Soviet fisheries official said today that large Soviet trawlers operating off Canada's east coast were engaged only in "experiments and research."
WASHINGTON, June 8 -- One ear after the Supreme Court's decision in the case of Clinton M. Jencks the boundary lines of the ruling remain unsettled.
Governor Harriman, attending the dedication of a new building for youth in Hillcrest Jewish Center in Queens, cited reports yesterday of Soviet emnity to Israel.

A New York Times dispatch from Paris shows that while fortytwo Socialist Deputies voted for the investiture of General de Gaulle, forty-nine voted against him. It may be of interest in this connection to recall how France's most prominent Socialist in recent times, Leon Blum, Premier in crucial times, who died in 1950, sized up the General.
BEDFORD HILLS, N. Y., June 8 -- A threatened riot this week-end by 255 inmates of the State Prison for Women at Westfield State Farm was quelled before it could start.

Soap coupons for subway ride merely illustrates the low level of foresight and business sense of the City Transit Authority. Do these city officials believe that people who obtain coupons by the purchase of certain products will eagerly rush to redeem these for an exhilarating ride on the New York subway system?
EAST HAMPTON, L. I., June 8 -- Open house will be held tomorrow at the "lowly thatched cottage" facing the village green in which John Howard Payne was born 167 years ago.
FOR the girl with a love for sunshine who is preparing for summer life the application of suntan lotion can mean the difference between the appearance of a bronzed goddess and a grilled frankfurter.
A universal exchange of medical knowledge is necessary in today's "shrinking world," Dr. Edward Grzegorzewski, an official of the World Health Organization, said last night.

MAMARONECK, N. Y., June 8 -- In one of the keenest finishes seen on Long Island Sound in many a season, Bill John, with Dodger, won the International Class race today in the second day of the Beach Point Yacht Club's series.

A syndicate of investors has taken title to the fifteen-story apartment house at 2511-19 Broadway, comer of Ninetyfourth Street, that the group bought under the name of the Elect Trading Company. The syndicate, headed by Louis Sarisky, paid cash over mortgages of $1,275,000.

GRINNELL, Iowa, June 8 -Five honorary degrees, including a Doctor of Laws degree for Edward R. Murrow, radio and television news analyst for the Columbia Broadcasting System, were awarded today by Grinnell College at graduation exercises for 175 students.
" He who sells what isn't his'n, must buy it back or go to prison."

The National Commission on Money and Credit, whose membership was recently announced by the Committee for Economic Development, is frequently referred to as "the first monetary commission to be set up in half a century."
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, June 8 (Reuters) -- The defending champion, West Germany, sprang the surprise of the opening games today in the World Soccer Cup final series.
NEW HAVEN, June 8 -- President A. Whitney Griswold of Yale University made a speech today to the graduating seniors that illustrates a significant fact in the nation.
Proposed state regulations on the employment of older persons will be the subject of public hearings beginning next Monday.

PERTH AMBOY, N. J., June 8 -- The Perth Amboy police investigated a report today that some men were seen near the scene of a fire that virtually destroyed two lumber yards and two homes and damaged ten other homes last night.
MIDDLETOWN, Conn., June 8 -- Prime Minister John G. Diefenbaker of Canada suggested today a four-point program of economic cooperation between the United States and Canada.
LONDON, June 8 -- The labor situation again was the dominating factor in the stock markets last week.
Long ago Sir Arthur Conan Doyle referred to the interior of Venezuela as a "lost world." Things have changed.

I was impressed with your editorial of May 23 entitled "Thirty Cents an Hour." The problem of adequate or even somewhere near adequate compensation for full-time internes and residents of city hospitals is one which this and many other cities have not even dared to face.

Minor rate gains last week on coal, grain and lumber cargoes managed to halt the fourweek index slide in the steamship charter market. Volume was up only slightly, but the condition of the field continued poor.

POZNAN, Poland, June 8 -Poland's international trade fair, a mixture of profit, politics and a few sharp memories, opened today with a couple of Russian sputniks, a pile of American blue jeans and a chorus of "Yes, Sir, That's My Baby."

Millard Shroder Associates, New York realty investors, have purchased the five-story store and office building at 581 Broad Street, northwest corner of Central Avenue, Newark. The sale was made by Feist Feist, brokers, for the H-J Corporation. The structure was built for the Ludwig Baumann chain of furniture stores.
BOSTON, June 8 -- Chief Justice Earl Warren advised Boston University's graduating class today not to be fearful of atomic energy and other discoveries of science.

CLINTON, N. Y., June 8 (AP) -- Hamilton College conferred the honorary degree of Doctor of Laws today on Senator J. William Fulbright, Democrat of Arkansas, and the degree of Doctor of Humane Letters on Paul F. Sanders, president of the Foreign Press Association and United Nations correspondent of Het Parool of Amsterdam, Holland.

ONE of the fascinations of horse racing is that it embodies an element of uncertainty. Otherwise cobwebs would grow across all mutuel windows. It's a sport where not even the sure things carry the guarantee of satisfaction or your money back. It had seemed just before the running of the Belmont Stakes last Saturday that an investment on Tim Tam was as safe as a Government bond.
HARASSED Mrs. Harold Fryer of Levittown, Pa., writes that her son, aged 6, keeps his room in such disorder that the influence is spreading to his two sisters and beyond the walls of his home.
This country's bid to commission the world's first tanker larger than 100,000 deadweight tons is in serious jeopardy.

The Laetare Medal was conferred by the University of Notre Dame yesterday upon Frank M. Folsom, chairman of the executive committee of the Radio Corporation of America and a prominent Roman Catholic layman.
The City Housing Authority received a set of proposals yesterday aimed at removing the bad reputation given to some projects by problem families.
BOSTON, June 8 (AP) -- The Boston Red Sox unleashed a barrage of homers to defeat the Chicago White Sox today, 6 -- 5, in ten innings, and 4 -- 1 for a sweep of their four-game series.
WALTHAM, Mass., June 8 -Israel's Ambassador to the United States advised the great powers today against imposing a diplomatic peace on the Middle East.
ALGIERS, June 8 -- This city, which has been effervescing noisily ever since a mob sacked Government House May 13 and the army took over power, has settled back into a humdrum existence.

A vacant plot of land 100 by 100 feet on Mosholu Avenue, east of Fieldstone Road, the Bronx, has been purchased by James Pomeranz builder, for improvement with a six-story apartment house. It was sold by a client of James T. McCormick in a deal negotiated by John J. Reynolds, Inc., broker.
LONDON, June 8 -- Two 17year-old Russians, who will be the first representatives of their country to compete in the Wimbledon tennis championship matches, arrived by air today.

Clocks present one of the great shows -- how man responds to what interests him. Through the centuries clocks have fascinated man, and in them he has expressed his moods in wildest range -- the cuckoo popping out of his gable, Mr. Cozzens' timepiece with its "Omnia Vincit Amor," the hammer and anvil clang of grandfather on the stairs, and a thousand whimsies in between.
" The Telephone Hour" will ring no more after June 30. On that date the eighteen-year-old radio program of classical and semi-classical music will present its 935th and final concert.
Senator Jacob K. Javits said yesterday that his "normal inclination" was to support Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr. for re-election from Harlem's Sixteenth Congressional District.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 8 -- Our society is "Fundamentally more secular than we like to admit," Dr. Nathan M. Pusey, president of Harvard, told seniors today in his baccalaureate address.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., June 8 -- Howard Seymour's Mutiny, last year's champion, defeated James B. Moore Jr.'s Lure, the 1956 winner, for Resolute class honors today in the Manhasset Bay interclub championship series.
Soviet automation equipment goes on display today as part of the Fourth International Automation Exposition and Congress at the New York Coliseum.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., -- June 8 -- Snow Man, a 9-year-old gray gelding owned and ridden by Harry DeLeyer of St. James, L. I., won the open jumper championship with 19 points at the Sands Point horse show today.

A new organization dedicated to chamber opera and other intimate forms of musical theatre made its successful first appearance yesterday afternoon at the Ninety-second Street Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Association.
An "open-door" policy toward the mentally ill has stimulated a sharp improvement in their recovery, the National Association for Mental Health asserted yesterday.

BOSTON, June 8 -- The electric utility industry has demonstrated again its inherent stability in recession periods, J. W. McAfee, president of the Edison Electric Institute, said here today.

Calumet Farm's fine 3-year-old colt, Tim Tam, probably has run his last race. During Saturday's Belmont Stakes, in which he finished second to Joseph E. O'Connell's Cavan, Tim Tam fractured a sesamoid in his right front leg.
PARIS, June 8 -- Premier Charles de Gaulle was expected to turn his attention this week to the second major phase of his program for France -- constitutional reform.
J. P. Stevens Co., Inc., had lower sales and earnings for the quarter and six months ended May 3, according to the report of the textile company released today.

SPOLETO, Italy, June 8--The evening of "Ballets: U. S. A." presented last night for the first time at the Festival of Two Worlds in the Teatro Nuovo, was a rousing success. A gathering made up largely of Italians and other Europeans greeted it with a mounting crescendo of applause and bravos.

The Communists' employment of the Islamic institutions in the Caucasus, central Asia and western China as cultural show places in order to impress visiting delegations from the Moslem world has facilitated the Soviet political breakthrough in the Middle East and southeast Asia.

WESTHAMPTON, L. I., June 8 -- For the second time in eight days a racing company official has been arrested on charges of violating Sunday "blue laws" that forbid outdoor Sunday sporting events unless a local permissive ordinance has been adopted.
" WIDE Wide World" concluded its season yesterday over Channel 4 with a ninety-minute study of Western motion pictures and television shows.

Eighteen students were ordained as rabbis yesterday afternoon and forty-two others received degrees and certificates at the sixty-fourth annual commencement exercises of the Jewish Theological Seminary of America.

KIRYAT SHMONEH, Israel, June 8 -- Lebanese Moslems who were captured by Israelis this week-end while smuggling guns gave a variety of explanations today for carrying weapons from Syria to Lebanese rebels.

THOMPSON, Conn., June 8 -- Harry Carter of South Sudbury, Mass., won the main sports car race at Thompson Raceway today in a D-type Jaguar. Carter averaged 68.79 miles an hour for fifteen laps on the two-mile course.

THE older woman in search of a husband is confronted by two phenomena: An acute shortage of eligible men and a great deal of unsolicited advice. For every unmarried man in this country between 45 and 65 years old, there are two unmarried women in the same age group. Many of these men, moreover, look to younger women as matrimonial prospects.

An effort to preserve an "open-door" policy for public recreational facilities within the twenty-one-county metropolitan area is expected tomorrow when the executive board of the Metropolitan Regional Council meets.

SYRACUSE, June 8 -- The fifty-fifth annual American Bowling Congress tournament ended today with little ceremony and none of the pronouncements and speeches that marked its opening seventy-one days ago at the Onondaga War Memorial.

President Eisenhower has warmly endorsed Brazilian President Kubitschek's proposal for a "thorough review" and "comprehensive reappraisal" of inter-American relations in order to cope with the grave problems confronting all the Americas. These problems, which enabled Communist agitators to spark the explosive demonstrations against Vice President Nixon, are primarily economic.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, June 8 -- Dr. Rafael Angel Calderon Guardia, former President, received a tumultuous welcome from a crowd of 10,000 when he arrived by plane from Mexico today after ten years' political exile.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 8 (UPI) -- Don Hoak drove in three runs with three hits today as the Cincinnati Redlegs whipped the San Francisco Giants, 6 -- 3, before 22,396 fans. Despite the loss, the Giants kept their one-game National League lead.

FIFTY or more years ago, many American families had wicker rockers and ceramic stools, stained glass parlor lamps and hat racks made of rams horns, mirrors in "gingerbread" wood frames and Persian tables with mother of pearl inlay, "bamboo" beds and oriental carpets.

LISBON, June 8 -- A lean air force general, with hypnotic black eyes and a fringe of black hair brushed from the back of his head over his bald crown, has made political history in Portugal.

PITTSBURGH, June 8 -- The surge in steel orders that showed up ten days ago has continued, and further improvement is indicated this week. Some mills may not be able to ship all the tonnage they have promised for delivery this month.
THE newest coverings for today's walls are decorative motifs in cement, plastic, stone or tile.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 8 -- A reorganization of California National Productions, the wholly-owned National Broadcasting Company television film production and distribution subsidiary, is expected to be announced within a few days.

VIENNA, June 8 -- Chancellor Julius Raab denied today that the arrest last week of three Czechoslovaks who had forced the pilot of a chartered plane to land them in Austria meant that Austria would change her policy of granting asylum to political fugitives.

GREENCASTLE, Ind., June 8 -- An economic system for the free world as "interdependent" as the one that has evolved in the United States was urged here today by British Prime Minister Harold Macmillan. He said interdependence must be the "keynote of the second half of the twentieth century if the progress of humanity is to continue."

The national food bill was $16,000,000,000 in 1939, $75,000,000,000 in 1957 and will reach $79,000,000,000 this year and $100,000,000,000 in 1965, the National Association of Retail Grocers was told yesterday.
The Community Service has started a drive to assist children in families "disorganized to the point of chaos."
Rising costs, a dearth of good sales help and increasing competition were described over the week-end as the biggest problems facing retailers in the next six months.

Installment borrowers made payments more promptly in April, figures made public yesterday by the American Bankers Association show. In all classes of installment loans and in most sections of the country, bank delinquency experience improved over March.
PARIS, June 8 -- The major event of the Paris Stock Exchange in the last two weeks has been a strong showing by North African shares and Sahara petroleum stocks.

PARIS, June 9 (AP) -- Gen. Charles de Gaulle and Sir Winston Churchill, World War II allies who occasionally battled each other, exchanged warm messages following General de Gaulle's investiture as French Premier.

Passage of laws to regulate consumer instalment credit practices in the twenty-six states that do not now have them was urged yesterday by William L. Wilson, vice president of Universal C. I. T. Credit Corporation.
The United Parcel Service was slowed by a growing work stoppage yesterday that threatened to halt the company's operations by this morning.
A concerted campaign by all city departments against violations in problem buildings was urged yesterday to rehabilitate the Morningside Heights area.

DRIPPING can make all the difference to a woman who hasn't the time, talent or inclination to iron summer clothes. This year more than ever, the city girl who needs a summer wardrobe that requires little upkeep may choose from a wider, more diverse variety of fashions in dripdry fabrics.
The Bronx Zoo, the Hayden Planetarium and three large museums will be closed today by a one-day work stoppage of 700 employes.
During most of the recession pharmaceuticals stocks have been strong, with good reason.
The city will begin construction early in July of a $1,784,000 water main that will more than double the water supply of the Rockaway Peninsula in Queens.
LONDON, June 9 (Reuters) -- England today won the first of a five-match cricket test series, defeating New Zealand by 205 runs.

A scene of somber magnificence emerged recently from a large grimy canvas, long owned by the Hispanic Society of America. The painting, now rediscovered to be a deathbed portrait of the young queen of Charles II of Spain, is on exhibition in the society's museum on Audubon Terrace, off Broadway between 155th and 156th Street.
DETROIT, June 9 -- The American Motors Corporation is planning to increase production and hire 1,200 additional workers this week.
Construction workers are busy untying three major knots in the arterial road system in Brooklyn and Queens.
Sixty high school students from the metropolitan area are being selected to take college-level courses in science beginning in September at the Columbia University School of Engineering.

RIVERHEAD, L. I., June 9 -- A perjury indictment against former Inspector Francis D. J. Phillips of the New York City police was dismissed in State Supreme Court here today because of "insufficient evidence."
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 9 -- In a fit of extraordinary candor, Yugoslavia's largest newspaper has just admitted that its reports from Communist China were rosier than the facts warranted.

RIO DE JANEIRO, June 9 -- Roy R. Rubottom Jr., Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs, arrived here this morning with a letter from President Eisenhower to Juscelino Kubitschek, President of Brazil.

William Reid, chairman of the City Housing Authority, said yesterday that he and his two fellow commissioners would "undoubtedly" make some of the policy and administration changes proposed as a result of a six-month study by the Citizens Housing and Planning Council.
BORDEAUX, France, June 8 -- Looking out across a deserted boulevard today in this French coastal city the waiter at a sidewalk cafe declared: "This is the calm before the storm."
The first of more than 5,000 families will be relocated today from the Lincoln Square area as a result of yesterday's decision by the United States Supreme Court.

The annual benefit dance of the Junior Auxiliary of Planned Parenthood of Manhattan and the Bronx will be held at the Sheraton-East on Sept. 26. The proceeds from last year's dance were used to provide another Spanish-speaking social worker for the four local Planned Parenthood Centers.

ALAMOGORDO, N. M., June 9 (AP) -- The Air Force disclosed tonight that its Mace guided missile, using a new guidance system called Atran, had successfully resisted repeated attempts to "jam or confuse it."

For the eleventh time since passage in 1934 of the original program as proposed by Cordell Hull, the house is battling out once again the pros and cons of the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act. Only this time there is a difference.
DETROIT, June 9 (AP) -- The automobile industry's passenger car production is now more than a million units behind the year ago level.

BOSTON, June 9 -- The president of the Edison Electric Institute predicted today a brilliant future for the nation's electric utilities. And the chairman of the world's largest electrical equipment maker concurred, but warned that much would have to be done to achieve this goal.

A cache of arms, including a submachine gun, was found yesterday by detectives in a West Side furnished room. Two men who admitted ownership of the weapons said the small arsenal had been gathered here for shipment to Cuban revolutionary forces.
