Jerry Coleman, Donald Budge, Kyle Rote, Jinx Falkenburg McCrary, Lanny Ross, Alice Bauer and Marlene Bauer Hagge joined yesterday in making plans for a summer sports festival to be held in the lower plaza of Rockefeller Center in July.

The American Government has called on the Soviets to honor their agreements on Germany and return the nine American Army men and their helicopter, forced down over East Germany, which they had inadvertently penetrated.

BRIDGETON, N. J., June 9 -- Four farm workers were killed and three others were seriously injured early today when an automobile crashed into a tree and a utility pole in Deerfield Township near here.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- The Senate approved today a bill to authorize the construction and sale by the Government of two superliners, one for the North Atlantic and the other for Pacific runs. The bill is designed to increase American merchant marine prestige and provide for the speedy movement of thousands of troops in an emergency.
TRENTON, June 9 -- The State Assembly voted tonight to extend unemployment insurance benefits from twenty-six to thirty-nine weeks.
Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc. and associates are today offering $10,000,000 of New England Power Company's 4 per cent first mortgage bonds, due 1988, priced at 102.655 to yield 3.85 per cent.

Formation of the Hampshire Chemical Corporation was announced yesterday by Bradley Dewey, who will be chairman. Mr. Dewey is 70 years old. He founded the Dewey Almy Chemical Company, now a division of W. R. Grace Co., and the Bradley Container Corporation, now a part of the American Can Company.

The Government reported at the end of last week that the number of unemployed workers had declined more than seasonally between mid-April and mid-May. In terms of percentage of the total civilian labor force this was equivalent to a decline from 7.5 per cent to 7.2 per cent.
WASHINGTON, June 9 (AP) -Senator J. Allen Frear Jr., Democrat of Delaware, introduced today a bill to exempt from the income tax involuntary stock distributions required in antitrust proceedings.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 9 (UPI) -- Bob Purkey, Cincinnati's ace control artist, hurled the Redlegs into sole possession of third place in the National League today by blanking the San Francisco Giants, 3 -- 0, with a six-hitter.
WASHINGTON, June 9 -- Following is the text of the statement by James P. Mitchell, Secretary of Labor, opposing the Senate labor bill:
WASHINGTON, June 9 -Wilber Marion Brucker, the Secretary of the Army, is a stocky man of medium height with a jutting jaw and a ready smile.
WASHINGTON, June 9 -- Prime Minister Harold Macmillan and President Eisenhower began their talks today with a two-and-a-half-hour review of "every subject under the sun."

PURCHASE, N. Y., June 9 -- The race to make bigger and more devastating nuclear weapons was decried here today by Thomas E. Murray, a consultant to the Joint Congressional Committee on Atomic Energy and a former member of the Atomic Energy Commission.
A TELEVISION set has been developed that entirely separates the screen from the or cabinet.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 9 -- The Soviet Union exhorted the Trusteeship Council today to vote immediately against continuation of United States nuclear tests in the Pacific.
Insurgent stockholders lost a last-minute court attempt yesterday to block a Yonkers Raceway stockholders' meeting scheduled for 10 A. M. today.
A LEAN. bespectacled high school senior who successfully operated a stool-manufacturing concern in Des Moines, Iowa, was awarded a $500 college scholarship yesterday in recognition of his enterprise.
When Charles Eames set his luxury-priced easy chair on a swiveling pedestal base two years ago, he planted a design trend that is reaching full flower this year.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N. Y., June 9 -- Canada is "a little touchy" about being overlooked by the United States, Lester B. Pearson said today.

MINEOLA, L. I., June 9 -State Controller Arthur Levitt criticized the 1958 Legislature today for not granting home rule powers to towns and to villages with populations under 5,000. Towns and villages with populations exceeding 5,000 already have home rule.
The organization of the Hearst Headline Service was announced yesterday by William Randolph Hearst Jr., editor in chief of the Hearst Newspapers.
IT'S time to get into the swim again. Summer is upon us, and, just like lemmings, New Yorkers by the millions are plotting their seasonal rush to the sea.

Automation might achieve its greatest usefulness in helping solve problems of world peace, an American suggested yesterday at the opening of the Fourth International Automation Exposition and Congress.

WASHINGTON, June 9 (AP) -The State Department said today twelve United States educators and six American composers would visit Russia this year under the United StatesSoviet exchange agreement signed Jan. 27.

BONN, Germany, June 9 -The possibility of a meeting between Chancellor Konrad Adenauer and Gen. Charles de Gaulle was discussed today at a luncheon given by the Chancellor for Maurice Couve de Murville, new French Foreign Minister.
In a move designed to lessen the chances of air collisions, the Civil Aeronautics Administration ordered its fleet of ninety-two planes marked with fluorescent paint yesterday.

WHEN Jack Kramer and Ted Schroeder were the best doubles team in the tennis world, they were prodigious court-coverers. They haven't changed much -- except that they now do it conversationally. They warmed up with easy lobs yesterday as they discussed the Dodgers, Chavez Ravine and Tim Tam.

ROME, June 9 -- In the first secret and public consistories held since May, 1954, Pope Pius XII obtained today the consent of the Sacred College of Cardinals and of numerous archbishops and bishops for two canonizations.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- Six new warships were dropped today from the Navy's construction program. A halt was called, too, on plans for the modernization of three ships. High costs were cited for the action. The cost of the work was estimated at $500,000,000.
ONE of the astonishing things about hunters and fishermen is the nonsensical ways in which they sometimes break the law, and get caught at it, and pay heavily for it.

LONDON, June 9 (Reuters) -- The Presidium of the Supreme Soviet has decided to reorganize the Soviet Ministry of Chemical Industry into a government committee for the chemical industry, the Soviet news agency Tass reported today.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 9 -President Camille Chamoun assumed today the power to act against any Government employe involved in recent activity against the Government.

Forty-five waiters served a luncheon with special academic seasoning yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. It was their final test: after the coffee, they received their certificates marking the successful completion of an advanced course in courtesy and service.

In your issue of May 28 appeared a brief dispatch from Jackson, Miss., recounting the "turning back" by union pickets of a number of non- union workers seeking employment on a near-by construction job. Among the incidents reported in this brief dispatch were the overturning of a car belonging to one of the men seeking employment, the "roughing up" of its owner, the bruising of a newspaper photographer and the confiscation of his film.

WASHINGTON, June 9 (UPI) -- The House gave swift approval today to an emergency $665,700,000 money bill to finance extended unemployment payments for workers who have exhausted their regular benefits.
LONDON, June 9 (AP) -Russia's first two entrants in the Wimbledon tourney worked out today.

At least 14,000 New York-bound passengers were delayed eight to thirty-four minutes in the rush hour yesterday morning when twenty New Haven Railroad trains were held up by a relatively minor equipment breakdown.
WASHINGTON, June 9 (UPI) -- Three Cabinet departments endorsed a proposal today to extend the law under which hundreds of thousands of Mexicans are admitted to work on farms in this country.
OTTAWA, June 9 (UPI) -Canada's domestic exports in the first four months of the year were $1,441,600,000, down 1.4 per cent from $1,462,500,000 a year earlier, the Bureau of Statistics said today.
CAIRO, June 9 -- President Gamal Abdel Nasser has been confronted with the first serious challenge to his authority over Syria.

LIMA, Peru, June 9 -- Luis Gallo Porras announced today he had succeeded in forming a new Cabinet. It is to be sworn in tomorrow, succeeding the Cabinet headed by Dr. Manuel Cisneros Sanchez, which resigned May 30.
Grayson-Robinson Stores, Inc., which operates a national chain of ninety women's and children's specialty shops, is expanding into the photographic retail business.
The Hempstead, L. I. Union Free School District 19 is planning the sale of $1,845,000 of bonds on June 24. The securities are to come due serially on Nov. 1 from 1959 to 1987.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 9 -- Most television plays have fairly pedestrian histories. Through some mysterious alchemy the playwright gets the idea, struggles through several revisions, sees it televised and that's the end of it.
WASHINGTON, June 9 (UPI) -- The Senate passed today a bill to set up a $250,000,000 Federal revolving fund to help provide long-term credit and capital to small businesses.

R. H. Macy Co., Inc. attained the highest sales in its history for the thirteen and fifty-two-week periods ended May 3. Earnings, however, declined from last year's, primarily as a result of a strike at the Toledo, Ohio unit, the company said.
The Paris couture is busy boning up on the fashion habits of American women before establishing a beachhead on this side of the Atlantic.
WASHINGTON, June 9 (UPI) -- A 10 per cent increase in Federal pensions for 320,000 was approved by the House today.

In "normal" circumstances a Presidential election in Portugal would be dismissed by the world at large with a shrug of the shoulders. This time the election has attracted world-wide interest, thanks to the courageous campaign fight of Lieut. Gen. Humberto Delgado.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- James P. Mitchell, Secretary of Labor, declared today that the labor bill proposed by the Senate Labor subcommittee was filled with "imperfections, omissionsor loopholes." He said these weakened "the already pitifully ineffective legal protection presently provided by law to union members and the public."
A powerful documentary dealing with American prisoners of war in Korea was presented last night over the Columbia Broadcasting System radio network.
Downpours in the city yesterday helped bring on two serious accidents in which vehicles skidded into oncoming traffic. Eight persons were hurt.

The June 1 article of your Ottawa correspondent, Tania Long, about the Polish royal treasures now in Canada appears to show that there is a reasonably good chance to end the international controversy over the historic relics -- after twelve years.
GENEVA, June 9 -- New prospects for East-West exchanges on vocational rehabilitation of the physically hancicapped emerged from a rehabitation demonstration here tonight.
WELLESLEY, Mass., June 9 -- Wellesley College conferred degrees today on 383 seniors at its eightieth commencement. Master of Arts degrees were received by four graduate students.
CHICAGO, June 9 (AP) -- Wheat and soybean futures finished firm today on the Board of Trade but other grains were weak.

SYRACUSE, June 9 -- Baseball has its spitball used by pitchers who are rarely proved guilty after throwing the illegal ball. Bowling has its loaded or "dodo" ball, also an illegal gimmick but one that is usually detected before it is used in some major tournaments.
NICOSIA, Cyprus, June 9 -- About 10,000 British troops enforced a rigid island-wide curfew tonight following a renewed wave of violence between Greek and Turkish Cypriotes.
The People-to-People Foundation, Inc., formed to implement a 1956 proposal by President Eisenhower to promote international understanding has been dissolved.

The election of Vice Admiral Earle W. Mills and William T. Moore as directors of the Commerce and Industry Association of New York, Inc., was announced yesterday by Thomas Jefferson Miley, executive vice president.
WASHINGTON, June 9 -- The Supreme Court declined today to consider constitutional objections to the Lincoln Square redevelopment project in New York.
Assurance that New York State would remain the "Big Apple" of the country's thoroughbred racing was given by John W. Hanes, the president of the New York Racing Association, yesterday.

The regular college basketball season in Madison Square Garden next winter will consist of thirteen double-headers, the same number as last season. The schedule, released yesterday, also contained the Eastern College Athletic Conference Holiday Festival competition on Dec. 26, 27 and 29.

ATHENS, June 9 -- Cheers from all political factions greeted King Paul's references to Cyprus in his speech from the throne inaugurating Parliament today. The assembly was a new one resulting from the May 11 elections.
DALLAS, June 9 -- Believability and creativity in advertising received a thorough going over at the convention of the Advertising Federation of America today.
Something like the proverbial candle's beam that "shines like a good deed in a naughty world," may be found at International House, center at Columbia University for foreign students.

PARIS, June 9 -- Premier Charles de Gaulle read off to his ministers today a list of new appointments in a perfunctory Cabinet session reminiscent of those of Napoleon's day. The authority for this comparison was Andre Malraux, the distinguished writer who serves as General de Gaulle's and the Government's spokesman.
DIKILI, Turkey, June 9 -- This small community on the Aegean coast saw an amphibious force of the United States Sixth Fleet in training action today.

WESTBURY, L. I., June 9 -Al Burton, the Illinois-born driver, accidentally got into the harnessracing business after shipping draught horses for a friend twelve years ago. He enjoyed the most successful session of his career tonight.
WASHINGTON, June 9 -- The Supreme Court took the following actions today:
Three of four youths charged with the assault of a parochial school teacher in March were convicted yesterday in Bronx County Court. The fourth defendant was cleared.
Perhaps the most eligible bachelor in this town of eligible bachelors is a 32-year-old, blueeyed 190-pounder who is considered the leading high-school track coach in the East.
WASHINGTON, June 9 -- Gen. Maxwell D. Taylor, Army Chief of Staff, testified today that cuts proposed by the Administration would put the Army 55,000 men below "required minimum strength."
WASHINGTON, June 9 -- President Eisenhower replied today to Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev's counter-proposal on a meeting of technical experts to work out means of supervising a ban on nuclear tests.
CHICAGO, June 9 -- The Chicago Association of Commerce and Industry reported today that of 565 companies in its membership, 62 per cent expect 1958 business to be as good as, or better than, in 1957.

LONDON, June 9 (Reuters) -- Gen. Petar Panchevski has been dismissed as Bulgarian Defense Minister and dropped as an alternate member of the country's Communist party Politburo, the official Bulgarian news agency B. T. A. said tonight.

KANSAS CITY, June 9 (UPI) -- The National Collegiate Athletic Association today reported thirty-five baseball teams had been certified as meeting requirements under its new program governing participation of collegians in organized, non-professional summer baseball.
A benefit art show at the Knoedler Galleries has drawn protests from the Artists Equity Association and a group of New York galleries dealing in American art.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- The First National City Bank of New York told the Federal Reserve Board today that Department of Justice opposition to its proposed bank holding company is "entitled to no weight."

The recent revelation that the last freely elected Mayor of Budapest, Joseph Koevago, had learned the English language by reading the Encyclopaedia Britannica must be of much interest to a group of men meeting today in Chicago.
WASHINGTON, June 9 -- The chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee praised the reciprocal trade bill today as "a constructive bill that will accomplish much that is good for the United States."
HARRISON, N. Y., June 9 -Parents, too, are undergoing aptitude and talent tests in Harrison's public schools.
NEW HAVEN, June 9 -- Two members of the Yale "family" received ovations today at the university's 257th Commencement.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- The Supreme Court agreed today to review the conviction of Abram Flaxer, a labor leader, for contempt of Congress. He was convicted for refusing to turn over to the Senate Internal Security subcommittee a list of 35,000 union members.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 9 -- This country's 181,000 professional nurses will be asked to add a new dimension to their already expanded bedside care of patients. This concerns pocket-book care, for both patient and nurse.
POUND RIDGE, N. Y., June 9 -- The Women's Guild of the Community Church here has arranged a tour of modern houses and a tea tomorrow between 1:30 and 5:30 P. M.
RYE, N. Y., June 9 -- Twelve daughters of members of the Westchester Country Club here will be presented at the sixth annual Westchester Country Club Debutante Cotillion on June 21.
The crew of the submarine Bang has politely but firmly declined a measure of unification with the Air Force here simply because a submarine cannot use engine parts intended for an F-86.

WASHINGTON, June 9 (AP) -- The Supreme Court declined today to reconsider three recent decisions that the Justice Department said could cost the Federal Government billions of dollars in payment of state and city taxes levied indirectly against Federal property.

HONG KONG, June 8 -- The much publicized "big leap forward" projected by the Chinese Communist Second Five-Year Plan will include greater efforts to win stronger support from the masses and place more emphasis on a technical and cultural revolution.

Under a headline "Satellites Fail to Spur Schools" The Times reports on June 1 on some remarks made by the National Education Association's executive secretary to the effect that eight months after Sputnik I we have done little to bolster American education.
WASHINGTON, June 9 -- The Federal Communications Commission was accused today of favoring metropolitan areas and big city operators over rural areas in awarding television channels.
The owners of a substantial majority of ocean shipping operating under the United States flag have set their sights on a small sailing ship.
WASHINGTON, June 9 (UPI) -- The United States Court of Appeals ruled today that the Atomic Energy Commission may make public a heavy water process discovered by a former Government scientist.

BERLIN, June 9 -- An East German official said tonight the United States must open direct negotiations for the return of nine United States soldiers seized in Communist territory after their helicopter went astray.
WASHINGTON, June 9 -- A complicated thing known in economists' jargon as "insufficient international liquidity" is behind the sudden surge of comment about the economic problems of the Free World.

The $205,000,000 Lincoln Square redevelopment can now move ahead at once, the last legal obstruction apparently removed with the decision yesterday by the United States Supreme Court to refuse to review findings for the project by New York State courts. The State Court of Appeals had unanimously upheld the legality of the Lincoln Square plan on May 1, and on May 15 repeated its decision.

A CONSUMER'S disillusionment after an unfortunate experience with a drip-dry garment is sometimes her own fault and sometimes that of the manufacturer. This is the consensus of a group of spokesmen in the textile industry who produce drip-dry or so-called wash-andwear fabrics.

WASHINGTON, June 9 (UPI) -- The Senate approved two money bills today carrying more than $6,000,000,000 to run the White House, the Civil Rights Commission and a score of other Federal agencies in the fiscal year starting July 1.
LOS ANGELES, Calif., June 9 -- Col. William O. Davis, a leading figure in the Air Force's space research program, announced his resignation from the service today to enter private industry.
WASHINGTON, June 9 -Supplemental appropriations requests totaling $769,787,978 were transmitted to Congress by President Eisenhower today. They would finance a variety of Federal activities.

The $1,000 annual Chopin scholarship award of the Kosciuszko Foundation has been won by Marek Jablonski, an 18-yearold Polish-born student at the Juilliard School of Music. Honorable mention in the nationwide competition was given to David Norman Kaiserman of Paris, Ill., who is also a student at the Juilliard School.
The New York Law School conferred undergraduate and advanced degrees last night on 164 students at commencement exercises in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

MONTICELLO, N. Y., June 9 -- B'nai Zion rescinded a constitutional provision in effect for nearly twenty years by re-electing Nathaniel S. Rothenberg of Manhattan to a third term as national president today.

Today's new film is "Poor But Beautiful" ("Poveri MaBelli"), an Italian-made romantic comedy with English titles, starring Marisa Allasio, at the Normandie Theatre, Fifty-seventh Street west of Avenue of the Americas.
CHICAGO, June, 9 (UPI) -- Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowtiz of New York, recommended today the creation of a program for mandatory commitment of narcotics addicts to hospitals.

It was on July 1, 1858, that the original statement of the theory of evolution by natural selection was made public. To commemorate the centennial of that event, Cambridge University Press will publish on July 1 "Evolution by Natural Selection," by Charles Darwin and Alfred Russel Wallace, in a new edition.

VANCOUVER, British Columbia, June 8 (Canadian Press) -- The Westcoast Transmission Company, Ltd., showed a net loss of $2,500,000 in its first six months of operation as a distributor of natural gas, Frank M. McMahon, president, reports.
The stock market moved little yesterday. The uncertain action for the fourth successive day suggested that a change in one direction or the other might be imminent.

BATON ROUGE, La., June 9 (UPI) -- The Louisiana House tonight ordered the president and nine deans of Louisiana State University to answer question about "subversive activities" after two professors said they favored integration at the school.
WASHINGTON, June 9 -- The Supreme Court held today that the National Labor Relations Board could delegate power to an examiner to make a preliminary ruling on a party's objections to subpoenas.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange advanced 6 to 14 points yesterday. The rise equaled 30 cents to 70 cents a bale.
Nelson A. Rockefeller edged closer yesterday to declaring his candidacy for the Republican nomination for Governor.
LONDON, June 9 -- A wildcat strike of dockworkers was threatening today to paralyze this port.

WASHINGTON, JUNE 9 (UPI) -- The Supreme Court ruled today that the beneficiary of a life insurance policy might be compelled under certain conditions to pay the back income taxes of a deceased policy holder.

Employes of member concerns in the New York Maritime Association will give blood today at the Downtown Athletic Club, 18 West Street, to the Regional Red Cross blood program. Donations will also be made today at the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, 4 Irving Place.
THE following information on where to picnic in this city was inspired by the excursion, as exhausting as it was unrewarding, of two New Yorkers on the recent Memorial Day week-end.

Net income of the Ericsson Group, international telecommunications organization with headquarters in Stockholm, Sweden, reached a record total of $4,350,000. Stockholders were so informed yesterday at their annual meeting in the Swedish capital. In 1956 net income was 3,948,000.
Game, hard-punching welterweights turned in fine performances in the three ten-round bouts at St. Nicholas Arena last night.

The Manhattan Beach Air Force Station in Brooklyn is being converted into an eastern training center for Federal civil defense personnel. The $150,000 renovation job is expected to be finished by Sept. 1.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- Commencement addresses to the senior classes of the colleges, high schools and private academies of the United States are a fixed rite of this season. But only in exceptional circumstances is the interest of the audiences as inevitable: when the orator is sufficiently prominent to evoke it, at least for the opening of his remarks; or when he gets and holds attention for what he is saying.
One item -- the equalization of wages for extra longshore gangs -- has nullified a year's work on a seniority system for the port's dockworkers.
For the umpteenth time, New York is being promised a production of Jules Romains' French comedy, "Dr. Knock."

WASHINGTON, June 9 (UPI) -- Gordon M. Tiffany, former Attorney General of New Hampshire, was sworn in today as the first staff director of the new Civil Rights Commission. His family and President Eisenhower attended the ceremony.
WASHINGTON, June 9 -- A plan for gradual desegregation of public schools in Harford County, Md., was left standing today by the Supreme Court.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 9 -- Helen MacInnes' new novel, "North From Rome," has been bought for filming by Frank P. Rosenberg, independent producer.
The Ringling Brothers and Barnum Bailey Circus dropped a brother yesterday.

Sales of the Sperry Rand Corporation in the fiscal year ended March 31 totaled $864,330,491, second only to the record $868,987,021 in the preceding period. Earnings were down 44.7 per cent, according to the annual report issued yesterday by General Douglas MacArthur, chairman and H. F. Vickers, president.

Coach Donald Rose led the Columbia heavyweight rowing squad to Syracuse yesterday morning for the fifty-sixth regatta of the Intercollegiate Rowing Association. The races will be held June 21 on Onondaga Lake.
The Internal Revenue Service has confused taxpayers throughout the East by mailing them a form saying that it "appeared" an error had been made in their estimated tax.

"STARS ON JAZZ," which has won a number of local awards in California, became a network television attraction last night over the facilities of the American Broadcasting Company. It is one more sign of the growing national interest in jazz.

WASHINGTON, June 9 (AP) -- A Power Commission examiner held today that Tennessee Gas Transmission Company of Houston, Tex., should be granted permanent authority to build and operate $169,329,263 worth of natural gas pipeline facilities already being constructed.

"IF there is such a thing as a happy childhood, the children of Sigmund Freud enjoyed one." That is the verdict of Freud's eldest son, Martin, in his engagingly informal memoir "Sigmund Freud: Man and Father."

Directors of the Endicott Johnson Corporation yesterday declared a 40-cent dividend on the common stock, payable on July 1. The former quarterly rate was 50 cents. Francis A. Johnson, president, explained that the company's shoe sales had been down about 12 per cent in the first half of this year and that earnings for the six months ended on May 31 would be substantially lower than a year ago.
Steel production exceeded expectations last week and rose to the highest level since mid-December. Mill schedules indicate that output will continue to rise this week, too.
The Fund for the Republic has protested to the American Broadcasting Company about two deletions the network made in Mike Wallace's television interview with Sylvester L. (Pat) Weaver Jr.
The price of steel delivered in the Detroit area will be trimmed $2 a ton today by most, if not all, suppliers.
The Wheatley Stable's 2-yearold filly Lady Be Good, a second choice, defeated ten rivals at Belmont yesterday in the eleventh, running of the filly division of the $30,990 National Stallion Stakes.

BRISTOL, England, June 9 (AP) -- Ramanathan Krishnan, 19year-old Indian Davis Cup player, defeated Wayne Van Voorhees of Palm Beach, Fla., today in the first round of the West of England tennis tournament.

LEWISBURG, Pa., June 9 -- Gen. Thomas D. White, Chief of Staff of the Air Force, was one of six recipients of honorary degrees at Bucknell University's 108th annual commence here today. He received the degree of Doctor of Laws.

Threatening letters saying that "the Spanish have united" to war on Italians have been received by the families of two youths charged with the murder of a young Cuban last week. The killing took place in Jefferson Park, 115th Street and First Avenue.

RYE, N. Y., June 9 -- There was only one break in the seeding as two rounds were completed when Manursing Island Club's twenty-seventh Eastern interscholastic invitation tennis tournament opened today.
Minnijean Brown, a 16-year-old Negro student who was expelled last February from Little Rock's Central High School, said yesterday that she would like to return to the Arkansas school in September.

TOKYO, June 9 -- Joseph P. Crowley, former Yale football star, was indicted today on a charge of fatally assaulting T. A. D. Jones Jr., his brotherin-law and business associate in New Haven, Conn., while under the influence of alcohol here May 8.
TEL AVIV, Israel, June 9 -- Israel delivered fourteen Lebanese insurgents in chains to a Lebanese police unit today.

Futures prices closed irregularly lower yesterday on the New York exchanges. Cottonseed oil, wool, hides, rubber, lead and the domestic sugar contract declined; the world sugar positions, copper and zinc rose, and price movements for cocoa, coffee and potatoes were mixed.

ST. LOUIS, June 9 (AP) -- An American Airlines pilot said today he had to dive his DC-7 flagship with 53 persons on it in order to avoid a collision with an unidentified military plane about thirty-five miles northeast of St. Louis.

The nation's grocers had a taste yesterday of the foods of the day after tomorrow. They also sampled new methods of selling and distributing. They toured an exhibition of what the food industries and store fixtures concerns are doing to make a grocer's work easier, to tempt the American palate and to make a housewife's job pleasanter.
WASHINGTON, June 9 (AP) -- Spokesmen for the tungsten mining industry today approved the Administration's proposed subsidy plan for minerals. A representative of brass mills voiced opposition.
BALTIMORE, June 9 (AP) -Billy O'Dell pitched almost perfect baseball after a shaky first-inning start as the Baltimore Orioles whipped the Cleveland Indians, 5 -- 2 tonight.
CHICAGO, June 9 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
ALGIERS, June 9 -- Difficult military and administrative obstacles will have to be overcome if the elections Premier Charles de Gaulle has called in Algeria are to take place on schedule.
LISBON, Portugal, June 9 (AP) -- Gen. Humberto Delgado, defeated independent candidate for President of Portugal, declared today: "I was robbed."
"You'll see a 1:42 half mile and a 3:50 mile before too many years."
Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr. conceded yesterday he had made a mistake in warning two Tammany leaders to avoid the streets of Harlem.

Gone are the days when a man seen reading a financial magazine or financial section of a daily paper could be classed as a banker or broker, Gov. Abraham Ribicoff of Connecticut said yesterday. The occasion was the first annual presentation of the Loeb awards for financial and business writing.

The seven-story apartment building on plot 46 by 102 feet at 210 West Twenty-first Street has been sold by Marvin Fastenberg and Daniel A. Birnant in a deal negotiated by the L. J. Phillis-Wood, Dolson Company, broker. The property is assessed at $88,000 and was sold subject to mortgages of $130,000.

WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP) -- Senator James E. Murray, Democrat of Montana, who is chairman of the Senate Interior Committee, promised his full cooperation "in working out within the framework of the minerals stabilization plan a solution to the dire problems of the lead-zinc industry and other economically sick minerals industries which are susceptible to this approach."
Three monkeys and 500 men picketed City Hall yesterday. The men's labor dispute closed the Bronx Zoo, the Hayden Planetarium, the Cloisters and three large museums for the day.
WASHINGTON June 10 (AP) -- A bill aimed at easing the plight of the railroads was called up in the Senate today for action tomorrow.
Knoxville, Tenn., borrowed $3,000,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance improvements to the city's electric power system. The money was raised on revenue bonds due serially from 1959 to 1978.

WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP) -- Joey Giardello of Philadelphia and Franz Szuzina of Germany will box tomorrow night on a terrace abounding with petunias, with a fountain weaving softly lit patterns of spray in the background.

This morning George P. David will become Chief of the New York Fire Department. With his induction by Fire Commissioner Cavanagh, Chief David will assume supreme direction of a militant army of over 11,000 fire fighters deployed in no less than 230 engine and 128 ladder companies in the five boroughs of the Greater City, a formidable assignment indeed.
The New York State Athletic Commission yesterday said its action in revoking the licenses of the London Sporting Club and two of its officers had been affirmed by the courts again.
City College will award degrees to 2,733 graduates this evening at its 112th commencement in Lewisohn Stadium, Convent Avenue at 138th Street.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., June 10 -- Judge Raulston Schoolfield of Chattanooga was rebuffed today in his efforts to avoid an impeachment trial on twenty-four charges of personal and official misconduct.

The United States' most formidable entry into the tourist-class passenger trade, the liner Atlantic, was threatened by a labor storm yesterday. The flagship of the American Banner Lines was scheduled to leave her Brooklyn pier at Java Street at 11:30 this morning for Zeebrugge, Belgium, and Amsterdam.

The Regional Office of the Internal Revenue Service said yesterday that confusion over a form mailed out in error from the service's center in Lawrence, Mass., was less than appeared to be the case yesterday.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 10 -- A revised convention on the recognition and enforcement of foreign arbitral awards was completed here today, and signed by representatives of ten of the forty-five participating nations.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- The Administration faces a cut of at least $500,000,000 in its foreign aid bill unless it can break the grip of a bipartisan economy bloc in a House Appropriations subcommittee.
A 25-year-old woman bookkeeper was arrested yesterday and charged with taking $12,938.41 in cash from her employer over a period of two and one-half years.
LONDON, June 10 -- Leaders of the wildcat strike of London dockworkers agreed with officials of their union tonight to recommend resumption of work next Monday.
LONDON, June 10 -- Inertia appears to have overcome the Soviet campaign for an East-West heads-of-government conference, diplomatic sources reported today.
CHICAGO, June 10 (AP) -- Five Chicago home runs, two by Bobby Thomson, today produced all the Cub scoring in a 9-6 victory over the Milwaukee Braves and Warren Spahn.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 10 -- Indications are that the Soviet dairy industry will not be able to equall production in the United States in 1958 as planned by Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev. This was suggested in the monthly buleltin of the Food and Agriculture Organization issued today.
WASHINGTON, June 10 -- The Pentagon said today that there had been "no final decision" whether the United States would make its first "lunar probe" in August.
The price of clothing used by workmen is coming down even though raw cotton, a major ingredient in such apparel, is on the way up.

ALBANY, June 10--Elementary and secondary school principals met with state education officials and others here today to lay the groundwork for a broad community-level program aimed at preventing juvenile delinquency among the state's school-age children.
SEA-SIDE, mountain-side, around the town -- Gunt Jaeckel has summer wardro for all three.
LONDON, June 10 (Reuters) -- Following are excerpts from the text of a speech on disarmament made in the House of Commons today by Duncan Sandys, Minister of Defense:
New York called out its harbor welcome machinery yesterday for an unusual kind of guest.

Shipments of zincs to industry increased moderately last month, but with the Government zinc-buying program ended, production still out-paced demand and unsold stocks of metal rose to the highest level in twelve years.

Copper prices rose about 1/3 cent a pound in the third largest volume of the year on the Commodity Exchange yesterday. All positions climbed to a new high for the move and the deferred months hit a new high for the life of the contracts.
DETROIT, June 10 (UPI) -- A United Auto Workers local authorized a strike vote today at two Plymouth plants of the Chrysler Corporation.
PARIS, June 10 -- Saint-Germain-des-Pres, better known for its existentialist "caves" than for its history, started celebrating tonight the 1,400th anniversary of its founding.
WASHINGTON, June 10--The United States and Britain have completed arrangements to reinforce Iraq, Jordan and Lebanon with about fifty jet fighter planes.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 10 -- Conrad N. Hilton announced today that work would start this year on a $23,000,000 Hilton Hotel here.
MADRID, June 10 -- The first of the United States Air Defense Force personnel have begun arriving for duty in Spain, it was announced today.

SOMEWHERE IN WEST GERMANY, June 10 (UPI) -- The vital nerve center of the United States Air Force's air-atomic power in Central Europe is a vast underground command post that has operated in strict secrecy for four years.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, June 10 -- Events in Indonesia have moved during the last week in a complicated and uncertain interplay of political and military factors.
BOSTON, June 10 (AP)--Bill Norman said today he planned to keep all the coaches who served under Jack Tighe.

DOWNEY, Ill., June 10 -- A nation-wide study conducted in thirty-nine Veterans Administration hospitals has "definitely" established that at least two tranquilizing drugs are effective in treating some forms of mental illness.
WASHINGTON, June 10 -- The Treasury accomplished a further significant stretching out of the maturity schedule of the national debt in its recent financing, final figures showed today.
WYANDANCH, L. I., June 10 -- The eighty-two-year-old "Toonerville" Long Island Rail Road station for this community was razed today.

For many months some of our Canadian friends have expressed indignation about the tendency of many Americans to take Canada for granted. Our somewhat cavalier approach to the economic, military and other problems of our great ally to the north has troubled well-informed public opinion on both sides of the border.

The Securities and Exchange Commission has temporarily suspended exemptions from registration under the Securities Act of 1933 under Regulation A for seven New York area concerns. Regulation A provides a conditional exemption from registration with respect to public security offerings of less than $300,000.

A plot of vacant land, 56 by 200 feet, at Pine and Grove Streets in Yonkers has been sold by Armino A. Campagna, New York realty investor and builder. It was bought by Isaac Albert. The land adjoins the former three-acre estate of the late E S. Perot, which Mr. Campagna also bought and resold recently.
WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture reported today that spring-crop prospects -- with a wheat-crop estimate up more than a third from last year's -- were good to excellent.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- Democrats on the Joint Congressional Committee on Atomic Energy are drafting an expanded civilian program for pending nearly $1,000,000,000 on nuclear power plants in the next five to seven years.

Jose Antonio Sanchez Sr. came here from Puerto Rico three years ago with little baggage and much optimism. Now at the age of 23 he has a job, a wife and a 10-month-old son he calls Junior. He also has a new apartment in a city housing project, and some new worries.
Salomon Bros. Hutzler and associates today are offering $25,000,000 of Virginia Electric Power Company 3% per cent first and refunding mortgage bonds, due in 1988 at 100.977, to yield 3.82 per cent.

PARIS, June 10 -- A vital diplomatic question has been raised by France's change of government. Will Paris pursue the same basic foreign policy as in past years or will its new regime seek to modify the French role in NATO and such enterprises as Euratom and the Common Market?

CHICAGO, June 10 -- William Benton, publisher of the Encyclopaedia Britannica, said today that the University of Chicago had received $5,500,000 in royalties and "other cash payments" from its share of the profits of the enterprise since 1943.

A six-story building containing fifty-four apartments and occupying a plot 100 by 100 feet at 1455 Townsend Avenue in the Bronx has been sold by the Town Realty Company to a client of Joseph Shenker, attorney. The property is at the northwest corner of East 171st Street. It is assessed at $205,000, of which $35,000 is land value. Pearce, Mayer Greer was the broker.
State, city and voluntary hospital officials conferred yesterday on proposals under which the state would pay half the cost of medical care at outpatient clinics of municipal hospitals.

OCEANPORT, N. J., June 10 -- Everything was in a fog throughout the running of the $17,425 Oceanport Handicap at Monmouth Park today. And everything was in a fog about the official results for some time afterward.
WASHINGTON, June 10 -- The United States will deal directly with East Germany, if necessary, to obtain the release of nine United States soldiers held there, Secretary of State Dulles said today.

The first half year of Mayor Wagner's second term is running out, and we must say it is a period singularly free of visible accomplishment. In his first annual message of this second term, delivered to the City Council in late March, Mr. Wagner said: "There will be many hard and bitter decisions to make. I assure you they will be made." We are beginning to wonder when.

Barring unexpected hitches, President Eisenhower's latest letter to Premier Khrushchev seems to clear away the last obstacles to an East-West meeting of technical experts to consider the problem of enforcing a nuclear test ban. The President has agreed to make the meeting one of six powers rather than of two, and has left the door open for participation of neutral specialists if that proves desirable.

Henry M. Margolis, who heads a proxy fight against the management of the Elgin National Watch Company, said yesterday at the concern's head-quarters in Elgin, Ill., that his group sought three seats on the nine-man board and not control.

NIAGARA FALLS, N. Y., June 10 -- Three Tuscarora Indian leaders took issue today with statements by Robert Moses, State Power Authority chairman, that a majority of their people wanted to sell a portion of the reservation for a Niagara power project storage reservoir.
CHICAGO, June 10 (AP) -- Rye tures moved up as much as cents a cents bushel on the Board Trade today. All other gr@in@ dshed within minor fractions previous c@oses.

GREENWICH, Conn., June 10 -- Ralph Marron of Exeter Academy led the field after the first of two qualifying hands in the forty-second annual Eastern interscholastic of championship at the Greenwich Country Club today.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- Secretary of State Dulles said today the United States probably would want mobile inspection posts in Communist China as well as in the Soviet Union to check on any agreement to halt nuclear tests.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- The Soviet Union, after a period of amiable neutrality in the current French political crisis, has apparently decided to support the French Com munist party in a position of violent opposition to Premier Charles de Gaulle.

The Columbia Broadcasting System is developing a supernatural hour that will comprise two half-hour film shows -- "The Invisible Man" and "World of Giants." They will begin next fall and will be televised each Wednesday evening.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- Both a National Capital Center for the Performing Arts and a National Air Museum appeared assured for downtown Washington today through a favorable report from the Senate Committee on Public Works.
DALLAS, June 10 -- Action was taken at the convention of the 30,000-member Advertising Federation of America here today to shore up educational activities connected with advertising.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- The Administration switched position today on aid for the copper industry. It appeared to be another effort to win support for renewal of the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act, which is pending in the House.
FROM this day forward, Tailored Woman will be true to the autumn bride.
Your recent editorial with regard to the restoration of the Soldiers and Sailors Monument is to be commended for calling attention to the frequent procrastinations of the Board of Estimate.
Plans were made by social and religious workers yesterday to forestall the spread of violent racial incidents in East Harlem.
WASHINGTON, June 10 -- Maj. William A. Howell ferried two heads of government in a helicopter today.

If the French National Assembly had rejected General Charles de Gaulle as Premier, the result would have been "either a complete state of anarchy or a totalitarian regime," Ambassador Herve Alphand asserted here yesterday.

For decades now, Hollywood has made movies in which prize fighters almost always are cast as gangsters, hoods, bouncers or punch-drunk lunkheads who say "dese," "dem" and "doze." But in real life, as everyone knows, prize fighters are exemplary gentlemen of infinite charm.
NEWTON, Mass., June 10 -- The space age may transform education from a chore to an adventure, the president of Brown University said today.
BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., June 10 (AP) -- Litton Industries, Inc., has announced that it was acquiring Airtron, Inc.
WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP) -- A nation-wide inquiry into the voting, education and housing will be undertaken at once by the new Federal Civil Rights Commission.
Thousands of flowers brightened the gloom yesterday as the Outdoor Cleanliness Association held its twenty-sixth annual flower mart on the steps of St. Patrick's Cathedral.
Three heroic statues by Karl Bitter standing in the path of building wreckers seem now to have a fair chance of being rescued.
WASHINGTON, June 10 -- United States and British officials explored this afternoon new ways to stimulate free world trade and increase investment in less-developed countries.

THERE was no spring in his stride. Jimmy Demaret shuffled over the fairway, his body sagging, weighted by the burden of his years. His smile, the symbol of Jimmy's constant cheerfulness, had become fixed and meaningless. All of a sudden he was a 46-year-old grandfather trying to win a championship belonging to youth.
LOS ANGELES, June 10 -- Litigation over the City of Los Angeles' right to give land to the Dodgers for a baseball park threatens to take at least a year, City Attorney Roger Arneberg said today.
GREENWICH, Conn., June 10 -- The Metropolitan Regional Council urged the New Jersey Legislature today to reject a pending bill for the creation of a New York-New Jersey transit district.
MASON CITY, Iowa, June 10 -- Meredith Willson's dream of leading a band of seventy-six trombones and 110 cornets came true today in this town, renamed River City for the occasion.
PARIS, June 10 -- Gen. Charles de Gaulle was faced with defiance to his authority from Algeria today, four days after he had cracked down on the dissidents there.
HAMILTON, N. Y., June 10 (UPI) -- Two Cornell players advanced to the third round in the Eastern Intercollegiate tennis tournament today in the only action of the rain-marred tourney.

The Utrilon Corporation, a Delaware corporation, has been organized to manufacture injection-molded plastic shoes, it was announced yesterday by Leonard Rae, president. He said the company had improved on a basic polyvinylchloride formula first used in France several years ago.
Kings County Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz voluntarily withdrew yesterday as the trial jurist in three criminal cases that had brought an accusation of "bias and prejudice" against him.

BALTIMORE, June 10 -- Prime Minister Harold Macmillan renewed today his plea for a meeting of "five or six" leaders of the East and the West in the hope that they could move the world "out of a condition of stalemate into one of negotiation." The British leader spoke to 7,000 people attending commencement exercises at Johns Hopkins University.
BOSTON, June 10 (UPI) -- The Detroit Tigers today discharged Jack Tighe as manager and named Bill Norman, a man with "an iron fist in a velvet glove," to replace him.

Forgotten Man's Day is coming along pretty soon. It is better known as Father's Day, and its real original purpose probably was to give to dear old dad some of the recognition he failed to receive during the hubbub of Christmas.
MINNEAPOLIS, June 10 -- The Soviet Union's delegation to the eleventh assembly of the World Health Organization introduced a revised resolution on the peaceful uses of atomic energy today.

A THING has just occurred on the coast of North Carolina that makes the triumphs of de Gaulle, and even those of Willie Mays, seem trivial in the minds of the citizens of the Outer Banks. The big bluefish have returned in numbers not seen in more than twenty years.
WHITE PLAINS, June 10 -- Legislation enabling the state to acquire land at once for future suburban highways was advocated here today at a state hearing.

RIO DE JANEIRO, June 10 -- President Eisenhower has proposed to Brazil's President, Juscelino Kubitschek, that their two nations consult "as soon as possible" and approach other Latin American states for a study of joint measures to improve the hemisphere's welfare.

" Inside the Democratic Party," by Jack Redding, former publicity director of the Democratic National Committee, will be published next Monday by Bobbs-Merrill. It is considered an "insider's" expose of the 1948 campaign and election of Harry S. Truman and its effects upon today's political battles.

BENNETTSVILLE, S. C., June 10 (UPI) -- State Senator Paul A. Wallace was shot and killed tonight in the Marlboro County Sheriff's office, where he was watching the returns from today's Democratic primary election.

Queens College conferred 590 degrees yesterday in commencement exercises held indoors because of the rain. The ceremonies, planned for a spacious lawn, were held in the school's Army surplus gymnasium.
Textron, Inc., a diversified industrial company, has sold its Coquille plywood division to interests affiliated with Roseburg Lumber Company of Roseburg, Ore. Terms of the sale were not disclosed.
BERLIN, June 10 -- United States officials in West Berlin are awaiting instructions from Washington about negotiations with East Germany for the return of the nine soldiers and their helicopter.

Two new films will open today. "The Vikings," a period adventure drama in Technirama and color, with Kirk Douglas, Tony Curtis, Ernest Borgnine and Janet Leigh, will be at both the Astor and Victoria Theatres, Broadway and Forty-fifth Street.

A novel demand for protection against loss of jobs in case of transfer of a vessel was among the contract proposals presented yesterday by the Marine Engineers Beneficial Association to Atlantic and Gulf Coast passenger and cargo ship operators.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 10 -- Lebanese Government forces were thrown today into their most crucial military test of the country's month-long crisis.
WASHINGTON, June 10 -- President Eisenhower told Republican leaders today that he might go "to the country" to get all his ideas on Pentagon reorganization written into law.

In his letter published June 3 Paul Dolan writes: "Is there sufficient constitutionalism in France, deeply embedded in the fabric of society, to prevent de Gaulle or any responsible Frenchman from becoming a Hitler?" I don't believe that anyone with a knowledge of political history could see de Gaulle becoming a Hitler.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- House investigators introduced records today to show that a Boston industrialist had paid nearly $2,000 in hotel bills for Sherman Adams, the Assistant to President Eisenhower, and his family.

RIO DE JANEIRO, June 10 -- Dimitri Mitropoulos and the New York Philharmonic received standing ovations from the Brazilian audience that filled Rio de Janeiro's Municipal Theatre last night at the orchestra's first concert here.

COLUMBIA, S. C., Wednesday, June 11 -- Lieut. Gov. Ernest F. Hollings and Donald S. Russell, former University of South Carolina president, will face one another in a run-off election June 24 for the Democratic Guvernatorial nomination.
A "necklace" said to have a memory is being manufactured by the Radio Corporation of America at its plant in Needham Heights, Mass.
WASHINGTON, June 10--James P. Mitchell's sharp blow at the Kennedy-Ives labor reform bill fomented a first-class political rumble today. Senator John F. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts...

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- Dr. Lawrence G. Derthick, United States Education Commissioner, returned today from the Soviet Union, where he headed a ten-member educational exchange team. He predicted that its findings would make "a real impact" on American education.

F. Trubee Davison announced yesterday the formation of a Citizens for Hall Committee. Its purpose is to promote Leonard W. Hall for the Republican nomination for Governor and to assist in his election if he is nominated.
A settlement was reached last night in a wildcat strike that caused 100,000 undelivered packages and 15,000 pieces of furniture to pile up in New York department and specialty stores.
Net income of Swift Co. and all domestic and Canadian subsidiaries declined to $2,516,153 in the twenty-six weeks ended April 26, from $3,554,788 earned in the corresponding first half of last year.
NORFOLK, Va., June 10 (UPI) -- Nine negro children applied today for fall admission to four all-white schools here. The move could lead to the closing of all four.
Stocks yesterday capped five days of indecision with a definite move downward. Strength for distillers and coppers was not enough to rescue the general list.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 10 (AP) -- Three homers produced all the Pittsburgh runs tonight as the Pirates defeated the San Francisco Giants, 5 -- 4, for Bob Friend's ninth pitching victory.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 10 -- Central-American countries at a meeting at Tegucigalpa, Honduras, signed an agreement today that may set a precedent in its recognition of conditions peculiar to the twentieth century.

BONN, Germany, June 10 -- Maurice Couve de Murville, Foreign Minister of France, emphasized here last night his Government's intention to remain loyal to the Atlantic alliance though new methods might be employed in the conduct of the policy.
ATLANTIC CITY, June 10 -- A sociologist today discredited the image of Florence Nightingale as the tiptoeing, whispering "lady with the lamp."

Your editorial of June 5 in relation to the Westchester accident in which seven lost their lives does no cover one important element in this and like tragedies. It is well and good to point out the effect of alcohol on driving and the need for public education, etc.

Federal Judge Thomas F. Murphy has impounded the minutes and enjoined Government and defense counsel in the James R. Hoffa wiretap conspiracy case from revealing why a woman juror was excused a week ago.
The case of Dr. George Wolf was referred to the District Attorney by Correction Commissioner Anna M. Kross after she had identified him yesterday as a former mental patient using a different name.

Today the defenders in the House of Representatives of a liberal international trade policy for the United States will engage in a showdown battle with its foes, who have been conducting a campaign of creeping protectionism now for ten years.

MIAMI, Fla., June 10 (AP) -- A New York investor today accused Louis E. Wolfson, the industrialist, and his brothers of milking the assets of one corporation to strengthen their control over the Merritt-Chapman Scott Corporation.
WASHINGTON, June 10 -- Retails sales in May maintained the improved April levels, 3 per cent above the low point of the recession, the Commerce Department reported today.

MILWAUKEE, June 10 -- The Air Force will attempt to hit the moon with a missile in August, Lieut. Gen. Samuel E. Anderson, director of the Air Research and Development Command, said here today. General Anderson told reporters that three "lunar probes" would be made this year, the others in September and October.
There are many ways to miss the moon. Any error, except the slightest, in aim, speed or timing would send a rocket careening off into one of a number of alternate trajectories.

MANHATTAN landlubbers who find it difficult turning out souffles on an even keel should try it in a kitchen that has a little list -- say forty-five degrees or so. Although such sophisticated fare will undoubtedly not be served on board the vessels that sail in the Newport-to-Bermuda race next Saturday, three square meals will be the order of the day on most ships.

ALGIERS, June 10 -- The All-Algerian Committee of Public Safety assured General de Gaulle of loyalty to him in the motion set to Paris today but at the same time said it "could not accept any compromise on the goals" the members of the committee "had sworn to attain."

If all goes well, it soon may be apple blossom time in the subways. The Transit Authority announced yesterday that it had been experimenting for the last week with an air purifier of that scent. The deodorant has been placed in three "A" line cars of the IND division.
PRINCETON, N. J., June 10 -- Manuscripts of F. Scott Fitzgerald and Booth Tarkington have been placed on display this week in the Firestone Library of Princeton University.
CARNEGIE HALL has sheltered many expectant audiences but never any as authentic as the one that gathered there yesterday for a maternity spectacular staged by a baby-product manufacturer.
RONXVILLE, N. Y., June A stormy meeting of Yon-Raceway stockholders was here today to decide the of a controversial recapitalization plan.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- Following are texts of the letters President Eisenhower wrote to Representatives Wilbur D. Mills, Democrat of Arkansas, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, and Joseph W. Martin Jr. of Massachusetts, Republican leader in the House.
Flexible collection policies are helping the consumer credit industry in areas hard hit by the business downturn, the fifth annual Consumer Credit Management Program was told yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- Spokesmen for twenty-seven crafts at work in the New York Naval Ship Yard at Brooklyn faced Navy officials and officers today with blunt questions on the employment future of at least 14,600 skilled men.
WASHINGTON, June 10 -- President Eisenhower sent a strongly worded appeal to the House of Representatives today for passage of the pending reciprocal trade bill without change.
LONDON, June 10 (AP) -- The Soviet Union's bid for a place in the world tennis sun was dampened today, literally and figuratively, in the Kent championships on the suburban Beckenham courts.

Nineteen-year-old Prince Michael of Greece and Denmark, a minor under the law here but an adult by Greek law, received control of a $234,633 trust fund yesterday by a decision of the Surrogates Court.
BOSTON, June 10 -- The electric utility industry was told here today that it must step up its advertising and sales efforts if it expected to realize its growth potential.

First-quarter earnings of the United Artists Corporation increased 11.7 per cent to $636,000 from $569,000 in the first three months of last year, Robert S. Benjamin, chairman, told the annual meeting yesterday in the Rivoli Theatre here.
KIAMESHA LAKE, N. Y., June 10--Henry A. Wallace cautioned the Soviet Union tonight against forcing its way into a position of power in the Middle East.
The Board of Education expects to complete a billion dollar post-war building program in 1960 and start on another of similar magnitude over the following ten years.
WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP) -- The Senate approved today the appropriation of $10,000,000 to build five demonstration plants to convert sea water and brackish water for human uses.

Ralph Bellamy, who is impersonating Franklin D. Roosevelt in "Sunrise at Campobello," was elected to a third term as president of Actors Equity at Friday's annual meeting of the union. The announcement was made yesterday by Dick Moore, spokesman for the organization.
WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP) -- Following is the text of President Eisenhower's letter today to Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev:
EL DORADO, June 10 (AP) -- A tornado battered the southwest edge of this city late today killing at least eleven persons and injuring fifty. It destroyed or damaged 150 homes.
LONDON, June 10 -- Duncan Sandys, Britain's Minister of Defense, visualized today the creation of a World Security Authority under the United Nations.

THREE dishes especially suited to warm weather dining are suggested today -- a cold soup, a chilled chicken mousse and a black cherry mold that may be served either as a salad or dessert. Of course, serving all three in the same meal would be redundancy.
LONDON, June 10 (Reuters) -- American-born Maria Meneghini Callas brought down the Royal Opera house tonight during a gala 100th anniversary performance in the Covent Garden landmark.
Representatives of city agencies met yesterday at the office of Borough President Hulan E. Jack of Manhattan and agreed on a program for improving street lighting near large housing developments.
WESTBURY, L. I., June 10 -- Magic Trick was well rated by John Dailey to take the featured Lombardy Pace at fog-draped Roosevelt Raceway tonight.
LONDON, June 10 -- A contraction of volume unsettled the stock market slightly today and price movements were narrow and irregular.
A foggy drizzle forced commencement exercises at Manhattan College indoors yesterday for the first time in twenty years.
Mankind lives in increasing danger of self-destruction, Dr. Hugh L. Keenleyside, director general of the United Nations Technical Assistance Administration, said last night.
Five new harpsichords were destroyed yesterday in a fire that started in the back-room shop where they are made.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- Following are the texts of the statements issued today by the office of James P. Mitchell, Secretary of Labor, on the pending labor bill and a joint statement by Senators John F. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, and Irving M. Ives, Republican of New York:
The Liberal party announced yesterday its opposition to the proposed sale of the Transit Authority's power plants to the Consolidated Edison Company.

Your editorial of June 4 on "The City and New Schools" calls for further clarification of the capital budget outlook of the city. You suggest that the very limited funds which the City Planning Commission was able to program for schools in the next few years might be substantially increased by the sale of the Transit Authority power plants and negotiation with the Port Authority for waterfront improvements.
CHICAGO, June 10 (AP)--The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:...

NICOSIA, Cyprus, June 10 (Reuters) -- Turkish Cypriotes took advantage of a curfew break today to go on an orgy of looting in the main municipal market in the Turkish quarter of Nicosia's Old City area.

Carl Marks Co., generally considered Wall Street's leading foreign securities house, belittles British rumors that "Americans are bargain hunting in London." These reports have attracted some editorial comment in England, such as:

YONKERS, June 10 -- A Board of Education plan to put Roosevelt High School on double sessions this fall has created a new dispute here. The double sessions would be the first on the secondary school level here since the Nineteen Thirties.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- Chances that a Senate bill to curb the Supreme Court would reach the floor in this Congress neared the vanishing point today. The Senate Democratic Policy Committee did not schedule it for action.
Daystrom, Inc., makers of electrical and electronic equipment, reported yesterday record sales for the second successive fiscal year, but earnings for the year ended March 31 were down slightly.
Mrs. Anna Wentworth denied under oath yesterday that she told the State Crime Commission in 1951 that her son had been a collector of policy slips for the Dalessio brothers, Stater Island racketeers.

UNITED NATIONS N. Y., Wednesday, June 11 -- The United States strongly endorsed early this morning the complaint of Lebanon that the United Arab Republic continued to encourage revolt within the Lebanese frontiers.

RYE, N. Y., June 10 -- Drayton Nabers of Lawrenceville, the defending champion who heads the draw in the Manursing Island Club's twenty-seventh Eastern scholastic invitation tennis tournament, narrowly escaped being upset in the third round today.
BRISTOL, England, June 10 (AP) -- A temperamental outburst by Sven Davidson of Sweden enlivened today's play in the West of England tennis championships.
PHILADELPHIA, June 11 -- Judge C. William Kraft Jr., of the United States District Court, today set July 1 for completion of a hearing on Randolph Phillips' charges against the Pennsylvania Railroad.

The terrific timetable General de Gaulle has set for himself in revising the constitutional structure of France and her overseas territories directly reflects the urgency and the immensity of the problems he and all Frenchmen are now facing.
A committee of shipowners from ten nations has been established by deep-sea tramp owners to study possible tonnage retirement plans for increasing ocean freight rates.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 10 -- Norman Panama and Melvin Frank finally have resolved the problem of assembling a cast for "The Trap." They are pushing preparation for a July 7 filming start at the Paramount studio.
VENICE, June 10 (UPI) -- The gondoliers of Venice rebelled against motorized competition today.
LONDON, June 10 -- Household coal rationing, the last relic of Britain's World War II and post-war rationing, will be ended about the middle of July.
Two teen-aged brothers charged with manufacturing zip-guns for Bronx gangs appeared in Children's Court yesterday where they were adjudged juvenile delinquents.

PRESIDENT JUSCELINO KUBITSCHEK has been true to Brazil's traditional diplomacy in proposing and winning President Eisenhower's assent to bilateral consultations on the improvement of pan-American relations.
A machine called the "Atomonitor" has been developed by the Nuclear Corporation of America to inspect production-line assemblies to make sure concealed parts are present.
Charges of real-estate speculation were hurled last night as the Greenwich Village Association debated the location of a new village playground.

Steel production in May was 6,308,000 net tons -- the highest for any month since January, the American Iron and Steel Institute disclosed yesterday. By contrast, steel production in April was the smallest for any month in almost twelve years, excluding periods of major strikes.
WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP) -- Another nuclear detonation in this year's test series in the mid-Pacific took place today, the Government announced. It was the fifth explosion reported.

TOULOUSE, France, June 10 -- A member of the Toulouse Committee of Public Safety raised today the possibility that the special powers voted Premier Charles de Gaulle would be extended beyond the stipulated six months.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed 8 points up to 8 points off yesterday. One point equals 5 cents a bale.

For the seventh time this water-logged season, the Yankees were washed out of a home date yesterday. They waited hopefully through a persistent drizzle for most of the day, then called off their night game with the Athletics.

The Janacek Quartet, one of three string quartets that are partially supported by the Czechoslovak Government, will make its first visit to this country next fall. It will appear in New York as part of the Sunday Concert Society series in Carnegie Recital Hall.
WASHINGTON, June 10 -- Following is the transcript of Secretary of State Dulles' news conference today as made public by the State Department:

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- Secretary of State Dulles made a comment about trade with the Soviet Union today that illustrates the division within the Administration and the Western alliance on economic policy.

The coming week-end in motor sports racing will be a big one. There will be two days of sports-car competition at Lime Rock, Conn. Indianapolis-type cars will race at Langhorne, Pa. Stock cars will compete at the fair grounds track in Reading, Pa. Waiter Hansgen of Westfield, N. J., will try for his sixth straight triumph in national competition on Sunday at Lime Rock.

Yorkville's Pete Anderson, victory-starved since he guided Cavan home first in last Saturday's Belmont Stakes, registered an easy triumph with Mlle. Dianne in the feature at sloppy Belmont Park yesterday.
Spokesmen for a benefit art show at the Knoedler Galleries defended it yesterday against disapproval voiced by Artists Equity Association and eleven galleries.
WASHINGTON, June 10 (UPI) -- The Senate approved today a $1,012,886,000 money bill to operate the Commerce Department and a group of related agencies in the fiscal year beginning July 1.

ALFRED ALTMAN'S talk almost always comes in lactic flow, and for good reason. He ran a milk route before school hours in boyhood in Clinton, Mass., where he was born. For many years now he has been head of the National Dairymen Association, Inc., with offices at 17 East Sixty-fourth Street.

IN the last act of "Henry IV, Part II" Pistol says, "I speak of Africa and golden joys." Although the line has a nice ring, many a schoolboy has been baffled by it. What were the golden joys Pistol referred to? A wonderfully learned answer to this question may be found in "The Golden Trade of the Moors" by E. W. Bovill.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., June 10 -- Air-conditioning equipment was called the brightest spot in the durable consumer market today. Cloud Wampler, chairman of Carrier Corporation, made the statement and predicted retail sales of $3,000,000,000 in 1958 to a press group inspecting the company's new research and administrative facilities here.
WASHINGTON, June 10 -- Following is the text of the letter from President Eisenhower to President Juscelino Kubitschek of Brazil June 5 on Hemisphere problems, as made public today:

A reception and supper for boarding parents -- a group that cares for babies until they are put up for adoption -- was held yesterday at the new home of the Louise Wise Services, 10 East Ninety-fourth Street.

NEWARK, June 10--The three-time champion, Chet Sanok of Glen Ridge, and Joe Birofka of Galloping Hill shot one-over-par rounds to lead sectional qualifiers today in the forty-seventh New Jersey Golf Association's amateur championship.

LOS ANGELES, June 10 -- The possibility of husband-and-wife scientist teams voyaging through space and begetting children on the way was seriously cited today at a gathering of leading space scientists.

HOUSTON, Tex., June 10 (AP) -- A Polish captain who told newsmen his ship had been searched four times since reaching the United States said yesterday that the searches were "an unreasonable waste of public money."

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- Almost 1,000,000 doses of cholera vaccine and 23,000 pounds of medical equipment have been flown from the United States to Thailand, where an epidemic is raging. The Canadian Red Cross furnished 60,000 doses of the vaccine.

Some of the sorrow of having to leave old places for new neighborhoods was eased yesterday for nine former tenants of the Lincoln Square redevelopment area who received bonus checks totaling $3,021.61.
HASTINGS - ON - HUDSON, N. Y., June 11 -- A special summer school for superior students will open in the high school here July 1.
WASHINGTON, June 11 -The annual rate of personal income rose by $1,200,000,000 in May, the Department of Commerce reported today.
WARSAW, June 11 -- Poland's fast-growing Scout movement is being pulled between campfire and factory study circle, between hikes in the woods and lectures on ideology.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved up 3 to 18 points yesterday. The far months showed the most strength.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- The White House asserted today that Sherman Adams would prove as "completely false" allegations that his friendship had helped a New England industrialist to gain preferred treatment from two Federal agencies.

A Queens savings and loan association chartered by the Federal Government has been granted permission to establish a branch in Nassau County -200 feet west of the main office of Long Island's largest commercial bank.

ROME, June 11 -- A Government based on a three-party coalition of Christian Democrats, Democratic Socialists and Republicans seems likely to emerge at the end of this month from the present political confusion.

On June 7 you reported the terms of the agreement reached by 15,000 service employes in 2,100 Manhattan apartment buildings. I want to protest against the shocking and ridiculous provision of a holiday for each worker on his birthday.

CHICAGO, June 11 (UPI) -- Joe Adcock hit a first-inning grand-slam home run today, but it took a three-run rally in the eighth for the Milwaukee Braves to gain a 10-7 victory over the Chicago Cubs. Milwaukee snapped a five-game losing streak.

SPRINGFIELD, Mo., June 11 (AP) -- The teen-age set took over the second round of the twenty-eighth annual women's Trans-Mississippi Golf tournament today, with four of them gaining tomorrow's quarter-finals.

INDIANAPOLIS, June 11 (AP) -- A thousand residents of Peru were urged today to flee their homes as the Wabash River lapped near the top of a floodwall and threatened serious flooding as far downstream as Terre Haute.

SPOLETO, Italy, July 11 -The productions of the four chamber ballets choreographed by John Butler and presented last night at the Festival of Two Worlds were notable for their variety and freshness. It is not often that a choreographer has the advantage of so many collaborators gifted in the theatre arts.
IT will be interesting to see, this week end, whether the Long Island South Shore trollers make any sort of score on striped bass, as some of the wise old heads predict they will.

GREENWICH, Conn., June 11 -- Conrad Decker of Peddie won the qualifying medal in the Forty-second Eastern Interscholastic Golf Association tournament at the Greenwich Country Club today after pacing his school to its second straight team championship.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 11 -- A tapestry, fashioned from a pastel by Pablo Picasso, has been placed on display here. The tapestry was lent to the United Nations but officials here are hopeful that some private benefactor or government will purchase it as a gift for the United Nations.

During a period when the American public schools are criticized heavily it might be wise to point out that in our democracy we have the kind of public schools we have because we are the kind of people we are. The schools are probably more sensitive to our values and reflect national strengths and weaknesses more than any other institution in our country.

HANOVER, N. J., June 11 -- A high school teacher of English submitted her resignation today in the wake of protests against three student essays that appeared in the school's newspaper. The Board of Education voted tonight to withhold action on the resignation pending the completion of an investigation now in progress.

Ray Cowperthwaite of Bushnell, Ill., was elected president of the National Association of Retail Grocers yesterday. He replaces W. H. Crawford of El Monte, Calif. Also elected were Scott Detrick of Louisville, Ky., vice president; and F. N. McCowan of Moscow, Idaho, treasurer.
The two massive locks on the American side of the St. Lawrence Seaway are undergoing a five-day test.
The first step toward construction of the proposed $17,000,000 Police Headquarters building for Manhattan was taken yesterday by the Department of Public Works.

Casey Stengel, who had been perturbed at the malign effect recent double-headers have had on his Yankees, was a happier baseball manager yesterday after the Bombers, through murk, heat, fog and rain, had put together twin victories over the Athletics at the Stadium.

Oils and rails found reasons for optimism in yesterday's session of the New York Stock Exchange. Metals also retained a little of their Tuesday afternoon hopefulness, but the remainder of the list was generally soft.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- Senator John F. Kennedy again denounced James P. Mitchell today for the Labor Secretary's double attack on the Kennedy-Ives labor reform bill. The bill has been reported out to the Senate.
Service pins were presented yesterday to long-time customs employes at a ceremony at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens.

It is no secret that the spring has brought much rain. Week-enders have noticed this, as have their friends, the proprietors of resort hotels. Pedestrians in the city have noticed it, too, for no rain is quite so wet as that falling between the apartment door and the subway.
TRENTON, June 11 -- The Defense Department allocated $227,616,285 in contracts to New Jersey concerns in the first five months of 1958, Senator Clifford P. Case said today.
The National Broadcasting Company will discontinue operating its ultra - high - frequency television station in Buffalo in September because it is not succeeding "competitively" or "financially."
DALLAS, June 11 -- Too many recession-frightened companies are not spending enough on advertising, Don G. Mitchell, chairman and president of Sylvania Electric Products, Inc., warned today.
An 11-year-old boy who impassively admitted that he had pushed two younger playmates to their deaths in the Hudson River was ordered committed to a state hospital yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 11 -- The House of Representatives gave President Eisenhower a ringing victory today on one of the three "imperatives" of his legislative program -- reciprocal trade.

WASHINGTON, June 11 (UPI) -- The Senate Banking Committee approved a compromise omnibus housing bill today. It ignored an Administration plan to hold the line on public housing construction another year.
TULSA, June 11 -- A field of 162 golfers with assorted worries but with a single ambition are awaiting the start of the fifty-eighth United States Open championship tomorrow.
The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company is feeling the slump in the automotive market and the general business decline, its semi-annual report indicated yesterday.
