MOSCOW, June 10 -- Grave miscalculations in the training of technicians and consequent difficulties in their placement in Soviet industry were revealed here today.

Recent development in Austria of one of Europe's strongest, most stable economies makes her a fertile new field for private American investments, according to Dr. Wilfried Platzer, new Austrian Ambassador to the United States.

The danger that Lebanon might become a Middle Eastern Korea has been eased, at least for the present, by the gratifying decision of the United Nations Security Council to send groups of observers to that embattled country to stop interference in its affairs by President Nasser's Soviet-backed United Arab Republic.
FORT MONMOUTH N. J., June 11 -- Amateur radio operators who pick up moonbounced signals for satellite tracking tests now get cards to signify their special outerspace status.
Thirty-five years ago in Provo, Utah, Robert C. Kirkwood, a teen-ager with an eye on the future, took a job as a window trimmer in the local five-and-ten-cent store.

Copper prices rose sharply yesterday in this country and abroad, sparked by a Government proposal to stockpile the metal. Futures recorded the sharpest rise in several years on the Commodity Exchange.

Secretary of Labor Mitchell's attack on the IvesKennedy bill, issued last Monday while he was attending the International Labor Organization conference in Geneva, has set off a feud that is as unnecessary as it is unfortunate for the cause of sound labor legislation.

ANDORRA LA VELLA, Andorra, June 11 -- At least one thing is certain in this tiny land of vast complexities: the people of Andorra are resolutely opposed to anything that brings political trouble to France.
City officials plan to use $1,500,000 to $2,000,000 in Federal slum-clearance funds to help buy and rehabilitate brownstone houses on the upper West Side.
CHICAGO, June 11 (UPI) -- Gangsters are reaping huge profits from gambling, narcotics and extortion, Attorney General William P. Rogers declared today.
CHICAGO, June 11 (AP) -Grain futures traders waded right in today and bid all prices substantially higher on the Board of Trade, despite some influences that had been considered decidedly bearish.
WASHINGTON, June 11 (UPI) -- A customs official testified today that more than half a million pieces of Communist propaganda were sent each month to colleges in this country from abroad.
The Bronx Zoo and three large museums reopened yesterday after a one-day work stoppage by maintenance and protection employes, but the workers threatened to call a longer strike.
The Grand Union Company, food store chain, plans to raise $10,450,000 by the sale of convertible debentures, Lansing P. Shield, president, said yesterday.

JERSEY CITY, June 11 -Vincent B. Brown, former president of Local 1247 of the International Longshoremen's Association, died today while walking up the steps of his home at 764 Jersey Avenue. His age was 47.

Two brothers reported to have attended the gangland convention last Nov. 14 in Apalachin, N. Y., were questioned by the State Crime Commission yesterday and were served with subpoenas to appear in two Federal investigations.

FLORENCE, Italy, June 11 (UPI) -- Italian art experts announced today that they had discovered a six-foot marble statue of a nude Venus attributed to Michelangelo being used to fill a niche in a doorway of the ancient Pitti Palace, one of Florence's leading museums.
LONDON, June 11 (Reuters) -- Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev "does not reject" the proposal of President Eisenhower to hold a disarmament conference in Geneva but prefers that it be held in Moscow.

The hieroglyphics of three Pharaohs on the Egyptian obelisk in Central Park will be translated into English on four bronze plaques. The plaques will be placed at the base of the monument, which is behind the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

Giovanni Guareschi, author of four novels about the Italian priest Don Camillo, has written a new book that will be published June 23 by Farrar, Straus Cudahy Called "My Secret Diary," it is an account of the author and his fellow countrymen as unwanted men of World War II. Mr. Guareschi says:

CEDARHURST, L. I., June 11 -- Mrs. A. A. Ryan and Mrs. Laura Curtis, Creek, teamed with Mrs. R. M. Torgerson, Cherry Valley, and Mrs. Charles Leichner, Pine Hollow, to card a winning 34, 34 -- 68, five strokes under par, in the four-ball tournament of the Women's Long Island Golf Association at the Rockaway Hunt Club today.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- Lieut. Gen. Arthur Trudeau, the Army's research and development chief, reported today that Army troops in the field would be equipped with small atomic weapons able to knock out tanks.

WASHINGTON, June 11 (UPI) -- The Federal Trade Commission charged Westinghouse Electric Corporation and its subsidiary, Westinghouse Electric Supply Company, today with favoring certain of their dealers as to prices and advertising allowances.
BOSTON, June 11 -- Americans will hear more from the electric utilities in the future about the danger of socialism.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, June 11 (AP) -- West Germany's defending champions and Yugoslavia emerged from the second round of the world soccer championships today as the only teams with clear-cut leads.

PHILADELPHIA, June 11 -- A fourth meeting of union and newspaper representatives in the twelve-day-old strike of truck drivers against The Philadelphia Bulletin and The Philadelphia Inquirer recessed this afternoon until tomorrow.

THE styles as well as the skins make this year's fall collection of fur coats newsworthy. Women who plan to shop for a new fur this summer, be it a full-length ermine or a pouf of fox, will find distinctly new influences.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 11 -- The American Federation of Musicians made a major break with the past today when it drastically revised its trust fund policy as it applies to television film production.
LAKE PLACID, N. Y., June 11 (AP) -- The governors of the New York State Bankers Association agreed unanimously today that the recession was leveling off.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 11 -- The Lebanese Government has won its first real test of military strength against rebel forces.

RYE, N. Y., June 11 -- Mrs. Norman S. Woolworth and Mrs. Rudolph Montgelas of Wee Burn blended their shot-making at Apawamis Club today for a combined card of 37, 37 -- 74. They took a one-stroke lead at the half-way mark of the Women's Westchester-Fairfield Golf Association best-ball championship.

ALBANY, June 11 -- Robert E. Fischer, 40-year-old Binghamton lawyer, was appointed today as special prosecutor to investigate criminal activities in Utica and surrounding Oneida County. The appointment was made by Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz.
WASHINGTON, June 11 (AP) -- By order of the Marine Corps commandant today, "hats will be worn by men and women officers at all times while out of doors."

The Century Food Markets Company of Youngstown, Ohio, has purchased the Bailey Department Store chain which operates a main downtown store in Cleveland and three suburban branches in the Greater Cleveland area.

Chicago, Ill., borrowed yesterday $10,000,000 on tax anticipation warrants having no stated maturity. The issue was bought by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., at an interest cost of 1.63 per cent to the city.
A leading Roman Catholic authority on Puerto Rican migration called yesterday for "moral understanding" of family arrangements that "seem like moral degradation to us."
WASHINGTON, June 11 -- A member of the Civil Aeronautics Board has demanded the resignation of a board official for allegedly trying to "browbeat" United Airlines.

The New York Central Railroad appears finally to have obtained that "rainy day" financial protection it has been seeking for two month. The company is understood to have arranged a stand-by bank credit, reportedly for $35,000,000.
Benefit payments from voluntary health insurance programs amounted to $3,500,000,000 last year, or 20.7 per cent more than in 1956, the Health Insurance Council said yesterday.

Three families living in crowded two-and-one-half-room apartments at 6 West 104th Street said yesterday that they were confronted with rent rises of $170 a month each after their complaints had led to a $1,200 fine for their landlord.

Rafty enjoyed a crafty ride by Eric Guerin and won the first running of the Bowling Green Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday. There were eleven contestants in the mileand-three-furlong turf event, and for about half the race Guerin had Rafty in eleventh place.

BRISTOL, England, June 11 (UPI) -- Ramanathan Krishnan of India reached the quarter-finals of the West of England championships today by winning two matches, including a 6-4, 7-5 victory over Nick Carter of San Francisco.

WASHINGTON, June 11 (AP) -- The Washington Senators routed Chicago's starter, Bill Fischer, with four runs in the first two innings and went on to defeat the White Sox 5 -- 2, tonight behind the six-hit pitching of Russ Kemmerer.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 11 (AP) -- The Smithsonian Astrophysical Observatory released timetable data tonight for visible passages of the rocket carrier of Sputnik III for the next few days.

The trustees of the New York Racing Association and members of The Jockey Club were guests of John W. Hanes at an inspection tour of the Aqueduct track yesterday. Hanes, president of the association, was aided in his guiding task by John W. Galbreath, chairman of the building committee, and the architect, Arthur Froelich.
The General Electric Company may be field testing the possibility of a return to fixing of retail prices for small home appliances.

PITTSBURGH, June 11 -- The University of Pittsburgh conferred degrees on 2,958 graduates today at outdoor commencement exercises. The last part of the ceremony was held inside the Cathedral of Learning because of a rain storm.
WASHINGTON, June 11 -- Secretary of State Dulles will fly to Paris July 4 to see Premier Charles de Gaulle.
Strange things are happening in the subways. Last week it was announced soap coupons would be good for free rides. Tuesday it was cars doused with Apple Blossom scent in a deodorizing test.
NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., June 11 -- This city's "Cinderella" Manager was not quite sure today whether the glass slipper fitted.

BOSTON, June 11 -- Following is the text of a statement issued today by Bernard Goldfine, Boston industrialist, in connection with his relationship with Sherman Adams, the Assistant to President Eisenhower. The statement was released by Samuel P. Sears, Mr. Goldfine's attorney.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -White House pressure crumpled the once-solid front of the House Armed Services Committee today and improved President Eisenhower's chances for winning a victory on Pentagon reorganization.
NEW DELHI, June 11 -- A deepening foreign exchange crisis and deteriorating relations with Pakistan are giving the Indian Government serious concern.

The First Boston Corporation and associates are offering today $50,000,000 of 3 7/8 per cent general mortgage bonds of Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation, due in 1988, priced at 101.335 to yield 3.8 per cent.
Governor Harriman said yesterday that the United States, with God's help, "can and will lead the peoples of the world to man's highest aspirations of peace and freedom."

These menus, which appear each Thursday, use seasonally abundant foods and are moderate in cost. They are designed to strike a balance between appetite appeal and the convenience of the family cook. Dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -While the Atomic Energy Commission maintains secrecy about its current atomic test series, another Government agency is broadcasting public warnings about planned explosions at the Pacific proving grounds.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., June 11 (AP) -- A Chattanooga bondsman, who said he contributed to political campaigns, testified today that he had been the go-between for $1,000 paid to fix a case in Judge Raulston Schoolfield's court.

The Government completed its case yesterday in the retrial of James R. Hoffa and two other persons on wiretap conspiracy charges. The trial began May 20 before Federal Judge Thomas F. Murphy and a jury of four women and eight men.

CHICAGO, June 11 -- General Motors Corporation today added its predictions to those of E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., Christiana Corporation and Delaware Realty Corporation, that disposition of G. M. stock under a plan proposed by the Government would have a serious impact on the nation's economy.
HAMILTON, N. Y., June 11 (UPI) -- Will Scarlett of Lehigh powered his way to three straight victories today to gain the semi-final round of the Eastern intercollegiate tournament.

The New Mexico and Arizona Land Company, more than 50 per cent owned by the St. Louis-San Francisco Railway Company, is negotiating three oil leases, stockholders were told yesterday at the annual meeting in St. Louis.

ALBANY, June 11 (AP) -- The State Workman's Compensation Board has awarded $20,000 to the widow of a man murdered by his business associate. The unusual award was made on the theory that the slaying resulted from the victim's employment.

BATON ROUGE, La., June 11 -- Troy H. Middleton, president of Louisiana State University, told legislative investigators today that "to my knowledge no member of the L. S. U. faculty is teaching integration."

LOS ANGELES, June 11 (AP) -- The Los Angeles Dodgers erupted with four runs and a noisy dispute in the third inning and went on to down the Philadelphia Phillies, 7 -- 4, before 16,236 fans at the Coliseum tonight.
DEAUVILLE, France, June 11 (UPI) -- Tim Holland of Rockville Centre, L. I., who drew a first-round bye, gained the third round of the French amateur golf championship today without firing a shot.
PHILADELPHIA, June 11 -- Robert B. Dechert, general counsel of the Department of Defense, challenged today the "bleak view" that there were no new frontiers in the world.

The annual Mistletoe Debutante Ball, scheduled to take place on the St. Regis Roof on Dec. 23, is being arranged by a committee under the co-chairmanship of Mrs. Robert E. Coulson and Mrs. Charles A. Dana Jr.
MOSCOW, June 11 -- This capital broke its month-long silence today on France's governmental crisis but not the restraint of its comment on Premier Charles de Gaulle.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- Prime Minister Harold Macmillan reported today "fairly close agreement" with President Eisenhower on the conditions and prospects for a heads-of-government conference to deal with East-West differences.

The unemployment insurance rolls in this city rose sharply last week. The number of persons drawing state jobless benefits went up 14,500, the biggest one-week rise since the post-Christmas layoffs at the beginning of the year.
Construction of a new Manhattan morgue will begin in mid-July, if it is approved by the Board of Estimate today.
The nation's oil industry increased the pace of its operations in the week ended last Friday, according to statistics reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 11 -- Jack Cummings Productions, Inc., will affiliate with Twentieth Century-Fox to operate within the studio as an independent company.
RYE, N. Y., June 11 -- Three of the four top-seeded players reached the semi-finals in Manursing Island Club's twentyseventh Eastern interscholastic tennis championship today.

On June 4 the writer appeared as a witness invited to testify before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee in a series of hearings designed to lay the foundations for a serious re-examination of United States foreign policy.
NAGS HEAD, N. C., June 11 -- Sixty-six fledging fishermen and some post-graduates are getting fishing pointers here this week at state-sponsored classes.
PARIS, June 11 -- Premier Charles de Gaulle sharply called to order today the dissident All-Algerian Committee of Public Safety, which implicitly challenged his authority in a statement yesterday.
ALBANY, June 11 (AP) -- Governor Harriman gave the bi-state Waterfront Commission a pat on the back today as he approved its $2,093,391 budget for the new fiscal year.
PARIS, June 11 -- A plan to check inflation and overcome the foreign-trade deficit is expected to be drafted next week by Antoine Pinay, Finance Minister.
MANILA, June 11 (AP) -- Luis Taruc, former leader of the Hukbalahap rebels in the Philippines, received a life sentence today for the kidnapping and murder of a Provincial Governor in 1944.

PITTSBURGH, June 11 (UPI) -- Mary Patton Janssen, a native of Pittsburgh who makes her home in Charlottesville, Va., took a one-stroke lead in the second round of the fifty-second women's Eastern amateur golf tournament today.

Vincent Richards is a golf enthusiast by conversion. The former boy wonder of tennis is now vice president of the Dunlop Tire and Rubber Company and one of his jobs as head of the sports division is to make friends in the golf world.

BONN, Germany, June 11 -East Germany let it be known today that it had informed the United States Government of its readiness to negotiate the release of nine United States Army men whose helicopter landed near Chemnitz Sunday.
Billy Rose has purchased the National Theatre at 208 West Forty-first Street for $849,500.

Borough President James J. Crisona of Queens has called on Mayor Wagner to obtain special counsel in a move to set aside an agreement under which the city paid $1,496,564 for land in the Rockaways assessed at about $150,000.
WASHINGTON, June 11 -- Considerable concern was apparent in the State Department today over the size of the rebel attacks mounted yesterday against the forces of the Lebanese Government.

WESTBURY L. I., June 11 -- In baseball, 2 for 9 would mean a batter had an average of .222 for two hits in nine trips to the plate. He wouldn't go very far with so anemic a figure. In harness racing, 2 for 9 is a winning average that is robust enough to keep everyone around the barn -- the horse included -- eating regularly.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, June 11 -- The Soviet Union has offered unlimited credit to Indonesian private enterprises for the supply of Soviet capital goods or factory construction.
Hunter College will confer 977 degrees at its 113th commencement today on the Bronx campus, Bedford Park Boulevard and Goulden Avenue.

Copper futures registered the sharpest price increase in several years on the Commodity Exchange yesterday. The volume, 405 lots (50,000 pounds to a lot), was the largest since trading resumed on July 27, 1951, after suspension during World War II. Prices rose more than 1 cent a pound during trading.

WASHINGTON, June 11 (AP) -- President Eisenhower instructed the Agriculture Department today to extend all available Federal assistance in an effort to control the grass hopperinvasion of crops in Colorado, Kansas and neighboring areas.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., June 11 -- The hospital practice of using student nurses to work as regular nurses is increasing and threatens the health and welfare of the public, leaders of the American Nurses Association said here today.

Electric power production in the week ended last Saturday rose to 11,681,000,000 kilowatt hours from the revised figure of 11,155,000,000 in the week before, the Edison Electric Institute reported yesterday. The figure for the prior week was revised after late holiday returns.

BECKENHAM, England, June 11 (AP) -- Russia's international tennis debut ended in the first round today at the Kent championships, where top-seeded Neale Fraser of Australia paced the field through the third round.
IN "The Making of Moo," which opened last evening at the new Rita Allen Theatre, Nigel Dennis is being beastly about religion.
NICOSIA, Cyprus, June 11 -- Turkish Cypriote youths hurled firebrands into Greek Cypriote stores today and then stoned firemen in a fresh out-break of communal strife.

Six men, who allegedly cheated the Government out of $750,000 in taxes annually for eight years, were indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury in Brooklyn on charges of conspiring to possess, transport and sell untaxed alcohol.

BOSTON, June 11 -- Sixty years ago, when Bernard Goldfine began selling newspapers and shining shoes in the tenement districts of East Boston, he had the immigrant's dream of some day having money and many friends.

THE first man to reach the visiting team clubhouse at the Yankee Stadium yesterday was Harry Craft, the manager of the Kansas City Athletics. He took a quick look at his locker. His uniform was still hanging from the hook. No one had cut off his epaulets, snipped away the buttons or cashiered him out of the regiment.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 11 (UPI) -- Frank Thomas hit two homers and drove in seven runs as the Pittsburgh Pirates knocked the Giants out of first place with a 14-6 victory today.
A two-year contract that provides no wage increase for the first year was agreed to yesterday by union and management representatives in the New York lithography industry.

OCEANPORT, N. J., June 11 (AP) -- Brookfield Farms' Irate, under the clever handling of Sam Boulmetis, held off the stretch challenges of Brilliant Gem and Bully Bolero to capture the featured sixth race at Monmouth Park today.
MOSCOW, June 10 -- Soviet authorities have promised to send to Dr. Leona Baumgartner, New York's Commissioner of Health, hitherto unpublished Soviet health statistics.
A WOMAN from Lakewood, Ohio, won the Singer SewOff yesterday. Although she may not supplant Betsy Ross as America's most famous seamstress, she was much better paid. First prize was $25,000.
LONDON, June 11 -- Houseohld names in the theatre, literature and sports are included in Queen Elizabeth's birthday honors list issued tonight. The list contains 2,200 names, 300 fewer than in 1957.
WASHINGTON, June 11 -- The Senate Space Committee approved unanimously today a bill that provides for joint civilian and military control of this country's space exploration efforts.
IT'S either too much or too little on Father's Day.
With her captain bedeviled by other problems, the newly commissioned liner Atlantic left a Brooklyn pier for her maiden voyage yesterday late, unescorted and undressed.

PURCHASE, N. Y., June 11 -- Two guests, Bill Robinson and Ben Black, took the chief gross awards at the annual New York City Newspaper-Retail Dry Goods Association golf tournament at the Century Country Club today. Robinson and Black posted 82's.
State Democratic leaders are pressing Mayor Wagner to decide by the end of the month whether he wants to run for the Senate.

The owner of a parking lot in Greenwich Village denied implications yesterday that he had engaged in any manipulation to profit by sale of the land to the city.

THE "Armstrong Circle Theatre" presented a dramatization of an exciting true story last night and did it well.

Four graduates were ordained as Reform rabbis and thirteen others were invested as cantors last night at the thirty-second annual ordination and commencement ceremonies of the Hebrew Union College-Jewish Institute of Religion.

West Point and Annapolis sent new officers to the armed forces last week as their graduation ceremonies established milestones for a new military era. Sherman Adams, Assistant to the President and one of the most powerful men in American public life today, showed extraordinarily poor judgment if he allowed over $1,600 in hotel bills for himself and his family to be paid by Bernard Goldfine, a Boston textile mill owner and real estate operator who has had some difficulties with two agencies of the Federal Government.

PARIS, June 11 (Reuters) -Final agreement on compensation for shareholders of the old Suez Canal Company -- nationalized by Egypt in 1956 -- has been reached, the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development announced here tonight.
Dr. Henry T. Heald told City College graduates last night that educational vitality had become a decisive force in the struggle of ideas and ideals between the free and Communist worlds.
The city's basic real estate tax rate for the fiscal year starting July 1 will be $4.16 on each $100 of assessed valuation.
RIO DE JANEIRO, June 11 -- Government quarters reported today that a conference of Foreign Ministers of the American republics was being arranged to seek a new basis for Hemisphere relations.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 11 -- The Security Council voted today to send United Nations observers to Lebanon to insure against smuggling of troops or arms into the country.
In a switch on our peripatetic Hollywood film-makers, a German film troupe has settled here to capture New York locales for a German-language feature, "The Trapp Family in America."
LONDON, June 11 -- Stock market prices improved modestly on balance today, although most changes among industrials were insignificant.
ANKARA, June 11 -- The Turkish Government tonight disavowed responsibility for the recent disorders in Cyprus and blamed British policy.
RABAT, Morocco, June 11 -- For the third successive week a United States naval transport ship, scheduled to dock in Casablanca, has been re-routed because of difficulties with the Moroccan dockers.
LISBON, Portgual, June 11 (AP) -- Gen. Humberto Delgado, who vowed in his unsuccessful presidential election campaign that he would oust Premier Antonio de Oliveira Salazar, was dismissed today.

The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation and its subsidiaries had a record net income of $6,026,193 in the first quarter of this year, Edmond H. Leavey, president, reported yesterday. This was equal to 83 cents a share on 7,176,677 shares outstanding.
Dr. Joseph Uttal said last night he had returned his license and his narcotics permit, and had abandoned the practice of medicine.
Thirty prominent citizens urged yesterday that nuclear tests be continued because suspension might endanger the nation's security.

The passing of the Putnam division of the New York Central should not be allowed to take place without calling the attention of state taxpayers, as well as of the shareholders of the New York Central Railroad, to what constitutes a shameless waste of public money as well as of private investment.

Members of Ave Maria Council, Knights of Columbus, will give blood to the Red Cross today at blood program headquarters, 214 East Twenty-first Street.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- The motive for the sudden change of tone from temperately critical to denunciatory in the Administration's analysis of the Kennedy-Ives labor union reform bill is a matter of speculation. But the change itself, and its suddenness, are facts plain in the record.
WHITE PLAINS, June 11 -The Westchester Parkway Authority decided tonight it could not wait any longer to remedy the "extremely hazardous conditions" on the cross county parkway.

HUGH WILLOUGHBY'S contribution to the baccalaureate season is "Amid the Alien Corn."* It is a cheerful memoir of a young Englishman's year at an American university. Although the place is not named, it is in Indiana, and not far from the scene of Prime Minister Harold Macmillan's recent commencement address urging close ties between the United States and Great Britain.

Sales of the nation's major chain and mail order companies rose sharply in May, according to a compilation yesterday by The New York Times. Volume was 5.1 per cent above the 1957 level, compared with a rise of 1.6 per cent in April. May, 1957, had four Saturdays, against five this year.
SOUTHBRIDGE, Mass., June 11 -- The beginning of the outdoor season should dispel any notion that one needs to be an actor or a baseball outfielder to wear sunglasses.

LONDON, June 11 -- The North Atlantic Treaty Organization is being outflanked by a Communist challenge that is essentially Asian and African and more economic and social than military, Paul-Henri Spaak declared today.

The House of Representatives handed President Eisenhower one of the most important of his legislative victories yesterday when it voted to continue the Hull trade treaty program in effect for another five years. Though this legislation has been renewed for three years on four different occasions in the past, this is the longest extension obtained since the program first became law in 1934.
ALGIERS, June 11 -- Some civilian members of the extreme Right wing of the Committee of Public Safety remained defiant today in the face of a reprimand from Premier Charles de Gaulle.

The United States, the world's largest coffee consumer, was chosen today to preside over a permanent international study group being organized to help stabilize the world coffee market. Sixteen Latin-American producing countries, representing 80 per cent of world coffee exports, elected the United States to head the group at a formal meeting at the State Department in Washington.

DETROIT, June 11 (AP) -- The National Music Camp Band from Interlochen, Mich., is going to play after all at the dedication of the Mackinac Bridge June 26-28. Two bands of professional musicians will also play.

A preview performance of "The Marriage-Go-Round" at the Plymouth Theatre on Oct. 28 will benefit the New York City Mission Society. After the new Leslie Stevens comedy, which stars Charles Boyer and Claudette Colbert, there will be an after-theatre supper party in honor of the cast in the Columbia Room of the Astor Hotel.
EL DORADO, Kan., June 11 (AP) -- A tornado that left at least thirteen dead and fifty-seven injured struck here yesterday before a prearranged warning system could be sounded.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 11 (UPI) -- United Airlines said today that one of its planes had been forced to make a 500-foot dive when a B-52 jet bomber came within 200 or 300 yards of it over Modesto, Calif.
ALTHOUGH a cold, wet spring retarded the ripening of strawberries on Long Island, the season opened there officially yesterday.

ST. LOUIS, June 11 (AP) -- Ken Boyer of the St. Louis Cardinals hit a home run on the first pitch in the twelfth inning tonight to defeat the Cincinnati Redlegs, 3 -- 2. It was his eleventh homer of the year and it broke a 2-2 deadlock that had existed since the seventh inning.
LONDON, June 11 -- The Government renewed today its efforts to settle the wildcat strike of London dockworkers and the official walkout by nearly 50,000 Greater London busmen.

LONDON, June 11 (Reuters) -- Dmitri D. Shostakovich, Aram Khatchaturian and other prominent Soviet composers meeting in Moscow today unanimously approved a Communist party decree criticizing "unhealthy trends" in some recent musical works, the Moscow radio reported.
WASHINGTON, June 11 (AP) -- Joey Giardello gained ten-round decision over Franz Szuzina before an elite crowd at the Shoreham Terrace tonight.
The Daily Bond Crier, oncea-year tabloid lampooning the municipal bond business, is out today.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -Mrs. Agnes Chase, one of the world's topmost authorities on grass plants, will receive her first college degree this week at the age of 89. The University of Illinois will name her an honorary Doctor of Science for her attainments in botany.
WASHINGTON, June 11 -Britain has agreed, in an attempt to remove a source of friction in its atomic cooperation with the United States, to provide further information about its atomic power reactors.

GREAT NECK, L. I., June 11 -- Nineteen Great Neck High School graduates will receive financial assistance for college studies next year through the efforts of welfare organizations in this North Shore community.
KUD, Kashmir, June 11 -- The trial of the principal followers and close associates of Sheik Abdullah, all charged with conspiring to overthrow the Kashmir Government by force, began here today.
DETROIT, June 11 -- Walter P. Reuther, president of the United Automobile Workers, is taking over the direction of the union's Chrysler department.
Fire Commissioner Edward F. Cavanagh Jr. declared yesterday there was a need to determine why sick leave and light duty assignments affected 12 to 14 per cent of the 11,000 fire personnel daily.

WASHINGTON, June 12 (UPI) -- The House Government Operations Committee approved a report today supporting President Eisenhower's plan to reorganize civil defense because nothing could make the set-up "worse."
An 81 - year - old landlord pleaded guilty in Bronx Special Sessions Court yesterday to seventy housing violations in the last two years at the tenement he operates in the Bronx.
The Army announced plans yesterday for the early construction of two control stations to coordinate Nike anti-aircraft missile bases that protect the New York-Newark and Buffalo-Niagara areas.

WIMBLEDON, England, June 12 (UPI) -- America's tennis-playing women were 2-1 favorites tonight to beat the British Wightman Cup team for the twenty-second consecutive time when the series resumes tomorrow.
Those in the New York area who stay up into the small hours on Sunday morning -- or arise early enough -- should be able to see a low and brilliant pass of the Sputnik III rocket, weather permitting.
WASHINGTON, June 12 (AP) -- The Airways Modernization Board flew a bright orange helicopter into the busy traffic pattern at Washington National Airport today.

Your editorial of June 5 on "College Teachers' Salaries" merits applause. A salary today of $4,500 for an instructor or $8,000 for a professor is so inadequate that a deterioration in the caliber of the teaching staffs in the nation's colleges is inevitable.

GREENWICH, Conn., June 12 -- Conrad Decker of Peddie and Clark MacKenzie of Lawrenceville, who led the qualifying round, advanced to the semi-finals of the forty-second Eastern Interscholastic Golf Association championship at the Greenwich Country Club today.

Cyprus, which has long been one of the explosive spots on our turbulent globe, is erupting again. This time there is little reason to doubt that the Turkish minority and Turkey are to blame.
WARSAW, June 12 -- The Polish Government renewed its attempt today to convict two journalist newsmen on charges of collecting information constituting state secrets.
The weather gave up its first attempt at forcing summer and assumed a milder mood last night after two soggy days of record temperatures.

Incoming Broadway shows will test their potentialities once more in Atlantic City. After an extended gap, spanning more than a quarter of a century according to one theatrical historian, the seaside resort will resume its former status as a key tryout center on Sept. 15.
The last remaining man in the Young Women's Christian Association hotel, Eighth Avenue and Fifty-first Street, is living the life of Reilly.

MARBLEHEAD, Mass., June 12 (AP) -- Mrs. Marlene Bauer Hagge displayed a brilliant short game on the second nine today for a 10-point first-round lead in the $12,000 round-robin women's invitation golf tournament.
BOSTON, June 12 -- Bernard Goldfine, Boston industrialist and textile-mill owner, was named the defendant in a new legal suit today.

Commodity futures closed irregularly lower yesterday in generally dull and featureless trading on the New York exchanges. Zinc, copper, the world sugar positions, wool and potatoes declined; lead, rubber and hides rose, and price movements for cocoa, coffee, the domestic sugar contract and cottonseed oil were mixed.
Rose experts were prepared to concede yesterday that they had improved too much on nature after a visit to the rose garden of the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx.

LOS ANGELES, June 12 (UPI) -- Harry Anderson drove in three runs, including the winning tally, today to lead the Philadelphia Phillies to a 4-3 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers before 9,899 fans in Memorial Coliseum.

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- The Department of Commerce reported today that United States steel production, cut in half by the business recession, was only 28 per cent ahead of Russian steel output in the first quarter of this year.
WASHINGTON, June 12 (UPI) -- Admiral Arleigh Burke made an urgent plea today for more Navy funds "to provide adequately for future combat effectiveness."
Summer is good to yachtsmen. It stretches week-ends into playtime interludes of four days, from Friday into Monday. These are "bonuses," separate and extra from the annual vacation spans.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 12 -- Neil H. McElroy, Secretary of Defense, warned today that Americans must be prepared for greater sacrifice in the "cold war."
ALEXANDRIA, La., June 12 -- A youth with suicide on his mind piloted a light plane over two states today, finally losing Air Force pursuers it northern Louisiana.

A civil service unit of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters announced last night its determination to organize the uniformed police force, despite a ban on all unions by Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy.

LONDON, June 12--A battalion group of the Parachute Brigade will be flown to Cyprus to reinforce the security forces there, the War Office announced tonight. The dis-patch of a unit of the Army's "fire department" was necessitated by the rapid deterioration of the security situation because of the conflict between Turkish and Greek Cypriotes.
LAKE PLACID, N. Y., June 12 (AP) -- New York State is declining in its role as the financial center of the world, the retiring president of the State Bankers Association said today.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange declined 2 to 11 points yesterday on all months except in the new October delivery, which advanced 7 points. One point equals 5 cents a bale.

PARIS, June 12 -- The de Gaulle Government is reported to be seeking a settlement of differences with Tunisia on a basis similar to the plan submitted by a United States-British good-offices mission in April.
PARIS, June 12 -- Gen. Lionel-Max Chassin, who went underground at the time of the uprising in Algeria, reappeared here today to announce the formation of the Popular Movement of May 13.
AMERICAN fashion's capitulation to the chemise is now complete. The woman who is still doggedly holding out for a plastered-to-the-body sheath is going to have a hard time of it this autumn.
DARIEN, Conn., June 12 -- Water skiers and boating enthusiasts will have to watch their step in Darien Harbor, the Board of Selectmen has decreed.
The man of the house may be kept busier than ever this summer while taking his leisure.
WASHINGTON, June 12 -- Loadings of revenue freight last week totaled 612,715 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.
The fifty-fifty formula of dividing oil production profits between foreign countries and producing companies was defended yesterday by an official of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey).
LONDON, Friday, June 13 -- The Labor party retained two seats in the House of Commons and the Conservatives held one in the first results from Britain's "little general election" yesterday.
A high school sophomore who bested 12,088 entrants in the American Automobile Association's fourteenth annual Traffic Safety Poster competition received his awards yesterday from Governor Harriman.

PHILADELPHIA, June 12 -- Striking employes of the newsroom and clerical departments of The Philadelphia Inquirer are investigating the possibility of publishing a daily newspaper of their own for the duration of the walk-out.

WASHINGTON, June 12 (AP) -- Representative Francis E. Walter said today the country was being flooded with foreign Government propaganda. Mr. Walter is a Pennsylvania Democrat who heads the House Committee on Un-American Activities. He made his comments at the end of series of public hearings on Communist propaganda.
Slowly but surely railroad news is becoming more favorable. Congress is moving toward relief action. Carloadings are up to the best level since last December.
BUFFALO, June 12 -- A personable Republican can beat Governor Harriman this year, L. Judson Morhouse told a regional conference of G. O. P. county chairmen today. He is the Republican state chairman.

THE disappearing waistline in fashion is pushing the classic cashmere sweater into what may be permanent moth balls. In a field where new design has been limited up to now to minor innovations in trim or detailing, a major style change is under way.

The Sacramento, Calif., Municipal Utility District, of Sacramento and Placer Counties, sold yesterday $5,650,000 of building bonds due from 1959 to 1978 to Bank of America National Trust and Savings Association and associates. Reoffering was at yields of 0.75 to 2.85 per cent.

Today's new film is "Corinna Darling," a German - made drama, at the Seventy-second Street Playhouse, 346 East Seventy-second Street. Elisabeth Muller, Hans Sohnker and Hannelore Schroth are the principal players.

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- Joseph Curran, head of the National Maritime Union, discussed common problems today with leaders of the International Longshoremen's Association and the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 12 (AP) -- Pittsburgh's slim right-handed rookie, Curt Raydon, hurled a two-hitter today for his first major league victory as the Pirates beat the San Francisco Giants, 2 -- 1, sweeping their three-game series.

WASHINGTON, June 12 (AP) -- The Federal Reserve Board said today business profits before taxes in the first quarter of this year were about 20 per cent below the level of third-quarter 1957, when the recession began.

ALBANY, June 12 (UP) -- Dr. James E. Allen Jr., State Education Commissioner, today appointed nineteen school superintendents and principals to a committee that will advise the state on educational television. All are from the New York City area.

STAMFORD, Conn., June 12 -- Weatherly, an azure blue, twelve-meter yacht, had a coming-out party tonight, complete with an orchestra, fanfare, and cocktails for 750 guests along the dock of the Luders Marine Construction Company.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 12 -- The strike by Hollywood movie musicians spread today as the National Labor Relations Board Office in Los Angeles opened hearings on an application of the Musicians Guild of America, Independent.
Harold Carter is favored over Willi Besmanoff in their ten-round heavyweight bout at Madison Square Garden tonight.
ALGIERS, June 12 -- There are fifteen officers, including three generals and five colonels, on the All-Algeria Committee of Public Safety, which has seventy-six members in all.
ROSLYN HEIGHTS, L. I., June 12 -- Tremendous housing and clearance problems still remain almost everywhere in the state, Joseph P. McMurray, State Housing Commissioner, said today.
"THE MEMBER OF THE WEDDING," the Carson McCullers study of an adolescent girl, received a thoughtful and painstaking production last night on the "Du Pont Show of the Month" over Channel 2.

Two properties on the Brooklyn waterfront have passed to new control with the sale by the New York Dock Company of the Trade Facilities Building at Joralemon and Furman Streets and Building 10 on Imlay Street.

Delays of up to an hour affected about 45,000 passengers -- mostly commuters -- yesterday afternoon on railroad lines to White Plains, Brewster and points in Connecticut. The New Haven Railroad's Merchants Limited to Boston was held up thirty-five minutes.
VIENNA, June 12 (UPI) -- Eugene Ormandy and the Philadelphia Orchestra received a standing ovation tonight after their concert in the Vienna Konzerthaus.
A 15-year-old honor student at the Samuel Gompers Vocational and Technical High School in the Bronx lost his left hand yesterday when a firecracker that he was making blew up.

United States producers shipped 74,200,000 pounds of acetate yarn and rayon in May. This represented a drop of 13.2 per cent from the 85,500,000 pounds moved in May, 1957, but a rise of 5 per cent from April. The figures were made public yesterday by The Textile Organon, statistical bulletin of the Textile Economics Bureau, Inc.

Mrs. Mary Nelson, who will be 100 years old July 16, gave her prescription yesterday for living a long, happy life. She was one of a group of the city's oldest residents who were honored at a ceremony at the Department of Commerce and Public Events, 625 Madison Avenue.

Jimmy Jones, trainer of the Calumet Farm race horses, reluctantly and unhappily said Yesterday of Tim Tam, "I guess he's through. I haven't any hope that he'll race again. He's ruined, and I figure that all we can do is save him for the stud."

CHICAGO, June 12 (AP) -- Traders in grain futures still were of the opinion today that this is not the time to sell wheat and corn short. They took another hitch at buying back their commitments or extending long positions.

Vice President Nixon's tour of South America has brought to the forefront the problem of cooperation among the countries of the Western Hemisphere. The press, television, Government and Congress have been suddenly forced to face and analyze this vital aspect of our foreign relations.

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- Sherman Adams acknowledged today that he had communicated three times with Federal agencies on cases involving his friend, Bernard Goldfine. He denied, however, that he had ever sought or had got preferred treatment for the New England industrialist.
NICOSIA, Cyprus, June 12 (Reuters) -- Governor Sir Hugh Foot today clamped on drastic bans as Cyprus seethed with violence.
The McLouth Steel Corporation of Detroit cut the prices of its hot rolled steel products yesterday by $2 a ton to bring its quotations into line with those of competitors.
Two young Brooklyn men described by the police as "thrill killers" pleaded not guilty yesterday in Kings County Court to a first-degree murder indictment for the second time.

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- The capital is in its glory tonight. After being bored to death with the economic crisis of the Western World it finally has the kind of simple political personal conflict it likes: a partisan argument about who paid Sherman Adams' hotel bill in Boston.
OTTAWA, June 12 -- Prime Minister Harold Macmillan spent a busy day today in conference with the leaders of the Canadian Government.
TOKYO; June 7 -- Japan's long-standing controversy over simplification of her cumber-some written language seems headed for the Supreme Court.
Morningside Heights is on probation, it was warned last night.
WASHINGTON, June 12 (AP) -- A 10 per cent pay increase for 1,021,000 Civil Service and other Government employes was agreed on today by Senate-House conferees.
PITTSBURGH, June 12 (UPI) -- Mary Pat Janssen, self-styled "week-end golfer," shot her best round of the tournament, a two-over-par 75 today, to win the Eastern amateur golf championship with a 229.
Hunter College conferred 976 degrees at commencement exercises last night on its Bronx campus at Bedford Park Boulevard and Goulden Avenue. Four thousand persons attended the outdoor ceremonies.

NEWPORT, R. I., June 12 -- The biggest of the biennial Newport - to - Bermuda yacht races was in the process of being organized today. If no part of the picture was quite complete, the situation was entirely normal.

WITH summer here, city dwellers are now anxiously looking forward to visits at the sea, the mountains or the lake -- wherever their friends may be. Whether heading for Scarsdale or East Hampton, the search for an appropriate gift for the hostess is on.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, June 12 -- The Asia Foundation has been asked by the Indonesian Government to cease its operations in Indonesia. It will end its activities by July 1.
WASHINGTON, June 12 -- President Eisenhower was outmaneuvered by superior Democratic forces today in a Pentagon reorganization battle on the floor of the House of Representatives.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 12 -- In a letter to the Security Council today, India defended the recent arrest of Sheik Abdullah, former Premier of Kashmir, on charges of conspiring against the Indian Government.
MONTCLAIR, N. J., June 12 -- Match play in the fifty-seventh annual New Jersey State amateur golf championship got under way over the No. 2 and No. 4 nines of the Montclair Golf Club course today.
WHITE SULPHER SPRINGS, W. Va., June 12 -- The United States should challenge the Soviet Union to a longevity race, John T Connor, pharmaceutical and chemical manufacturer, said today.
Steamship conferences deprived of the protection of the dual rate system were compared yesterday to "a flock of poultry at the mercy of any predatory fox."

JOHANNESBURG, June 12 -- An investment trust proposing to offer shares in South African gold mines, gold bullion operations and industries to United States investors was registered in South Africa today.
A sudden strike by engineer officers held up the superliner United States -- this country's largest passenger ship -- for eight hours yesterday before she sailed last night.

The Baltimore and Ohio Railroad may soon open negotiations with banks for a stand-by credit for future emergency. The company has asked the Interstate Commerce Commission for authority to issue, but not sell immediately, $15,000,000 of first consolidated mortgage bonds, due Oct. 1, 1995.

"We all like to contrast the way things were when we were very young with the way things are now," Charles Poore observed the other day in his review of J. B. Priestley's "Thoughts in the Wilderness."
WARSAW, June 12 -- Warsaw and Artur Rubinstein have met again after twenty years and they have brought tears to each other's eyes.
STOCKHOLM, June 12 (AP) -- Sweden scored a 2-1 victory over Hungary tonight and became the first team to qualify for the quarter-finals in the world soccer championship.

William F. Knowland of California, the so-called minority leader and spokesman for the Republican party in the Senate, is once again demonstrating how ridiculous it is that he holds that august post in the party's hierarchy. Once again he is taking a position directly in conflict with that of the party's leader, President Eisenhower, and of the Republican Administration.
A trash-littered vacant lot in Harlem was transformed into a field of flowers in three hours yesterday by school children and the Department of Sanitation.

DEAUVILLE, France, June 12 (UPI) -- A strong team of Americans, headed by Tim Holland of Rockville Centre, L. I., today grabbed five of the eight berths in the quarter-finals of the French amateur golf championship.

After the Preusse report exploded the fallacy of the "yardstick" theory as an argument for the city's keeping its subway power plants we hardly expected to hear yardstick mentioned again. But the Liberal party has now revived the old slogan, and opposes sale of the plants as eliminating "the last public yardstick" to measure Consolidated Edison's "vast electric power operations."
LONDON, June 12 -- Britain's trade union movement rallied today to the support of Greater London's striking busmen.

Whatever other results the visit of Prime Minister Macmillan may produce, there is no doubt that it has raised relations between the United States and Britain to a high level of intimacy and cordiality. This relationship was made so evident that no official communique was necessary to emphasize it.
Unionized millinery workers have moved to safeguard their jobs by investing $3,000,000 of welfare and pension reserves in two towering loft buildings in New York millinery center.
Attorneys for the landlord and five tenants of luxury apartments at 25 Sutton Place argued all day yesterday in and out of court but failed to agree on "fair and reasonable rentals."
THE biggest news in the world of food this week was the descent of the price of coffee at certain outlets. One chain advertises its lowest coffee price in five years.
WASHINGTON, June 12 -- Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev of the Soviet Union sent President Eisenhower tonight a long letter, possibly on a summit meeting.
HUNTINGDON, England, Friday, June 13 (AP) -- A United States Air Force jet trainer and a Royal Air Force jet bomber collided in flight near here early today.
John J. Theobald, superintendent-elect of the city schools, said yesterday that the future depended on the extent to which youth would make the harnessed laws of nature work for society.
Textron, Inc., plans to enter the industrial machinery business through a proposed acquisition of the Waterbury Farrel Foundry and Machine Company.
The Old Guard of the City of New York will move to the firing line tomorrow for its annual engagement with the enemy of all men -- time.
Four directors of Penn-Texas Corporation said yesterday they would ask a Federal court to void ballots cast at the recent annual meeting and to authorize a new solicitation of proxies.
The copper industry spent most of yesterday talking about the possibility of a price rise by major producers.
The plan to establish a third Levittown "segregated like the others" is inflammatory and dangerous, the Rev. John LaFarge said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 12 (UPI) -- A Roman Catholic priest was accused of having been a "character assasin" today when he complained that imported Mexicans were being exploited as "slave labor" by big farmers in the West and Southwest.
The Board of Estimate dealt a heavy blow yesterday to the Greyhound Bus Corporation's recent proposal to construct a $10,000,000 terminal on Thirty-fourth Street, east of Eighth Avenue.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., June 12 (AP) -- Gov. Goodwin Knight, rejecting a friendly gesture by Senator William F. Knowland, declared today that he intended to conduct his own campaign, independent of the rest of the Republican ticket.

COLLECTING a house room by room is not the simplest project imaginable. But one couple, fanciers of things antique, built its home this way. The stairway was purchased before the plans were drawn. It determined the design of the entrance hall. Doors, moldings, beams and all the furnishings were acquired before ground was broken for the house.
WASHINGTON, June 12 (UPI) -- The House Commerce Committee backed a bill today to aid the nation's financially ailing railroad industry.
HAVANA, June 12 -- The Cuban Supreme Court removed four judges of the Court of Appeals of Havana and one municipal judge today.
TULSA, June 12 -- A former cattle rancher rode into the leaders' circle today in the first round of the United States Open golf championship.

RIO DE JANEIRO, June 12 -- One hundred and twenty Americans flew out of Rio de Janeiro early today after putting a resounding final touch to one of the most successful recent efforts at spreading goodwill for the United States in South America.
The spirit of rebellion has not yet been wholly stamped out of the American League.

EAST ORANGE, N. J., June 12 -- The cries of children at play resounded today in the home of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence C. Burr at 218 North Oraton Parkway. Marial and Marthal, 9-year-old twins from India, were making a quick adjustment to their new environment.

An automatic testing machine, said to aid in making Audio Devices, Inc., recording tape one of the most accurate, was announced by the company yesterday. The machine counts almost 12,000,000 tiny grains of magnetism on a 2,500-foot tape and rejects a defective reel.

THE Detroit Tigers will be visiting Yankee Stadium this week-end under the direction of a new manager, a stranger named Bill Norman. It has been twenty-six years since he wore a big league uniform, and even then he didn't wear it long enough for the suit to need pressing. This is the new trend in baseball, the promotion of minor league pilots to top command.
TOKYO, June 12 -- Nobusuke Kishi, pro-Western chief of Japan's conservative political forces, was re-elected Premier for another four years by the Diet (Parliament) tonight.

The American Stock Exchange yesterday suspended trading in the common shares of the E. L. Bruce Company, a Memphis, Tenn., hardwood flooring concern. The action may answer the controversial question of who really controls the company, its present management or the group that has been buying its stock.

ALBANY, June 12 -- The Joint Legislative Committee on Legislative Practices and Procedures agreed today to strive for promulgation of rules making all information on legislative employes available to the public in one central place.
The Kings County grand jury investigating crime in Brooklyn public schools handed up a presentment yesterday urging the Board of Education to change the designations of the "600" and "700" schools.
Food retailers were warned yesterday not to view progress in the industry only as physical expansion.

CHICAGO, June 12 (AP) -- Paul (the Waiter) Ricca, one of the few surviving members of the old Capone gang, was sentenced in Federal court today to nine years in prison and fined $15,000 for income-tax evasion.
WASHINGTON, June 12 -- The Senate Democratic leader gave strong endorsement today to renewal of the Reciprocal Trade Program -- one of President Eisenhower's "imperatives" for Congressional action.

Space for a street-level ticket office and for executives offices has been leased by the Irish Air Lines (Aerlinte Eireann-Aer Lingus) in 444 Madison Avenue at Forty-ninth Street. The lease was negotiated by the Cross Brown Company. It gives the lessee its first first permanent offices in this country. A Boston office will be opened soon.

Maurice M. Bernbaum, who accompanied Vice President Richard M. Nixon on his recent South American tour as a State Department representative, will participate in a discussion of "tensions" in South America on the Columbia Broadcasting System television network Sunday.

JEROME WEIDMAN'S "The Enemy Camp"* is an engrossing novel that seems almost as if it had been written in collaboration by two other novelists, Herman Wouk and John P. Marquand. It has the immense readability, smooth narrative flow and continuous entertainment punch of a Wouk novel.
The Board of Education's proposed 1959 capital budget request may be considered too high by some city officials, but hundreds of parents made it clear yesterday that they thought it was too low..
A rise in personal income, due in good part to increased construction payrolls, and a decline in new claims for unemployment compensation provided a springboard for stock market gains yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 12 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture today announced it would make special ninety-day "distress" price support loans on 1958 crop wheat for which acceptable storage could not be found immediately.
WASHINGTON, June 12 -- The First National City Bank of New York was turned back today in an effort to recover money it lost in Russia at the time of the revolution in 1917.
NEW YORK UNIVERSITY has changed the blinker arrangement on its 110-foot beacon pole on University Heights to make it talk.
SIXTY-ONE years ago a violinist and a pianist met in Berlin. The former, after having heard the latter play, said: "May boy, you have talent. Work hard and you will go far."

Three supporters of the Rev. William Howard Melish, ousted supply priest of Holy Trinity Protestant Episcopal Church in Brooklyn, barricaded themselves inside the church building yesterday and barred the way to a new assistant rector.

Tristan da Cunha is a forty-five-square-mile island in the South Atlantic and is about 1,200 miles from anywhere. It is inhabited by about 200 people who speak a mixture of Cockney and Southern Negro ,dialect. They are descended from a boatload of British sailors, who were stationed there with their wives in 1816.

The United Shoe Machinery Corporation and its domestic associated companies yesterday reported a net income of $9,803,835 for the fiscal year ended Feb. 28. This is equal to $4.08 a share of common stock and compares with $12,601,298 or 5.26 a common share earned in the preceding fiscal year.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 12 -- United States aid to underdeveloped countries through bilateral and multilateral programs is approximating more than $5,000,000,000 yearly, according to a compilation issued today by Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold.
A Federal action against the shipping interests of Aristotle S. Onassis, international Greek operator, was brought here yesterday by the Department of Justice.
PARIS, June 12 -- Premier Charles de Gaulle appeared today to have suffered a setback in his efforts to establish his unchallenged authority over the military and civilian dissidents in Algeria.
WESTBURY, L. I., June 12 -- Morris MacDonald, a Canadian driver-trainer, denied tonight having made remarks reflecting on harness racing's integrity.
IN this era of the "drip dry," the cotton bed-sheet industry is not asleep. The Pequot Division of Indian Head Mills, Inc., has developed no-iron sheets and pillow cases called Pequot "E-Z Care."

TRENTON, June 12 -- Assessors in 383 New Jersey municipalities will be subject to suits by local taxpayers next year unless the State Supreme Court delays its date for compliance with a century-old assessment law.
WASHINGTON, June 12 -- The United States took steps today to help India with the most perplexing problem of her economic development program, a shortage of foreign exchange.
New York City turned over more than twenty acres of its watershed lands to the state without charge in 1955 for construction of the State Thruway, it was learned yesterday.
The midtown section of Franklin D. Roosevelt (East Side) Drive be closed on weekends for two weeks, it was announced yesterday by Borough President Hulan E. Jack.

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- Following are the texts of a letter from Sherman Adams, the assistant to the President, to Representative Oren Harris, chairman of the House Special Subcommittee on Legislative Oversight, and a memorandum from Edward F. Howrey, chairman of the Federal Trade Commission.

Businesses increased their borrowings from the larger New York banks by $21,000,000 in the week ended last Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. The increase, the first since March 19, compared with one of $158,000,000 in the like week a year ago.
LONDON, June 12 -- Despite a slight reaction in the afternoon, the stock market continued its modest advance today.
The formation of a New York City Republican Advisory Committee of thirty members was announced yesterday. Bruce Bromley, former Associate Judge of the Court of Appeals, was named temporary chairman.
Plans of Surface Transit, Inc., to discontinue bus service over week-ends on one Manhattan route and ten Bronx routes were blocked yesterday, at least temporarily, by the Board of Estimate.
WASHINGTON, June 12 -- Private home-building activity rose above the 1,000,000-a-year rate last month for the first time since January, the Labor Department estimated today.

The world is Eugene K. Denton's oyster. And pearls are his passion. Mr. Denton, the president of Tailored Woman, may be seen any day of the week lugging bags of pearls up to his fifth floor office, where he ogles them as his blue parakeet, Mr. Peepers, looks on. If the pearls pass inspection, down they go to a basement safe.

I agree wholeheartedly with Gladys S. Cahn's concern about the House Committee on Education and Labor refusing by tie vote to report out the school construction bill. But I see no remedy unless the public as a whole, parents in particular, and even the children who are the victims, also feel a concern that begets action.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 12 -- "The Swiss Family Robinson," popular children's story, is being prepared as a half-hour television film series by the Walt Disney Studio.
Eight Negro pupils from Central High School in Little Rock, Ark., arrived in New York by plane yesterday afternoon.

A NUMBER of near-by states issued official warnings recently against the practice of meddling with baby wild animals. They do it every year, and every year kind-hearted people kill infant wild animals by taking them home or even by handling them.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 12 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold set up a three-man committee today to head the new United Nations observation team in Lebanon.
S. H. Kress Co., variety store chain, announced yesterday the appointment of George L. Cobb, who now heads a variety store chain in Canada, as president.
CHICAGO, June 12 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

Under provisional president James R. Hoffa's leadership the International Brotherhood of Teamsters is confounding the prophets who foretold reprisals by the A. F. L.-C. I. O.'s largest affiliate if it were expelled from the federation. Instead of breaking the web of mutual-aid alliances with other federation affiliates when the ouster occurred, and then raiding their territories, Mr. Hoffa and his colleagues have been doing everything possible to maintain and even expand their contacts.
WASHINGTON, June 12 (AP) -- Two Roman Catholic priests said today that the use of a new "birth control pill" was morally and perhaps physically harmful.

DETROIT, June 12 -- Locals of the United Automobile Workers have begun to take strike votes at plants of the Big Three auto companies. But there were no indications that walk-outs were planned in the immediate future.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- State Department and other specialists in French affairs are poring over a little-known volume by one of Gen. Charles de Gaulle's war-time associates for clues too his intentions in North Africa.
ATHENS, June 12 -- The British plan for a new approach to the Cyprus problem was studied today by the Greek Government. What it had to offer was not revealed but divined.
A trackless fifty-two-wheel train, suitable for power by either atomic reactors or conventional engines, has been designed by R. G. LeTourneau, Inc.

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- The prospect, advanced by the California primaries, that the Democrats not only will control the next Congress but will control it by the largest majorities since 1937 is not being viewed by the party leadership with undiluted elation.

A suit for $1,175,000 for false arrest, brought by Mrs. Anna Wentworth, was settled yesterday for $3,500. The suit was against the city, Herman Methfessel, a former Richmond County District Attorney and two detectives.
WASHINGTON, June 12 -- The Senate reshaped the Kennedy-Ives labor reform bill today to meet some Administration criticism. But the bill's bipartisan managers stood firm against most proposed changes.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 12 -- Diplomatic sources said today they thought the United Nations would have to send a force of several thousand men to bar Lebanon's frontier to interference by the United Arab Republic.

James Reston's dispatch of June 5 notes that Adlai Stevenson made a "remarkable and largely ignored speech at the University of Louisville the other day." The speaker, considering weaknesses of our foreign economic programs, said: "We are headed for a new crisis, one no less dire than the crisis of 1947 [the year of the announcement of the Marshall Plan], and no less certain to lead to catastrophe unless we act in time."
LEVITTOWN, L. I., June 12 -- Project Kayak is being rushed at the Wisdom Lane Junior High School here by a group of youngsters anxious to start their summer vacation.

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- Cyrus S. Eaton has had his first face-to-face brush with the House Committee on Un-American Activities. It occurred yesterday at a closed session in the office of Representative Gordon H. Scherer, Republican of Ohio and a member of the committee.
LONDON, June 12 -- There are two approaches to English weather: Ignore it or leave the country. Queen Elizabeth II, 1,700 of her household troops and thousands of spectators chose the former today.
ATLANTIC CITY, June 12 -- The United States was exhorted today to win the "cold war" with "warm hearts."

MOST graduation exercises end with the awarding of diplomas. When the China Institute courses in classic Chinese cuisine ended this week, the ceremony consisted of eating a fourteen-course meal. The menu did not run the gamut from soup to nuts; it ran instead from thousand- year-old eggs to eight-treasures pudding.
SYRACUSE, June 13 -- A member of the Harriman Administration painted a rosy picture tonight of the 1958 political outlook for the Democratic party.
Commodity futures closed mostly higher on New York exchanges yesterday. Copper, zinc, sugar, burlap, hides, wool and potatoes rose. Coffee, cocoa, cottonseed oil, lead and rubber declined.

BECKENHAM, England, June 13 (UPI) -- Bill Quillian of Seattle, the last remaining American, was eliminated from the Kent lawn tennis championship today. One of the day's highlights was the fine play of Russia's junior champions.
WASHINGTON, June 13 (UPI) -- The Senate gave its final approval today to a compromise bill for a retroactive 10 per cent pay rise for an estimated total of 1,021,000 Government white-collar workers.
THE United States pavilion at the Brussels Fair was the subject of some peppery comments Thursday evening.

HACKENSACK, N. J., June 13 -- Superior Court Judge Donald M. Waesche today appointed Warren Dixon Jr., a Hackensack lawyer, to examine the municipal garbage removal contract of Fair Lawn. He is to investigate for possible fraud.
WASHINGTON, June 13 (AP) -- Gen. Randolph McC. Pate said today 175,000 Marines were not enough.
SOMERVILLE, N. J., June 13 -- Somerset County, without a park at present, may get some play areas, if plans of the County Park Commission are realized.

TOKYO, June 6 -- Japan must give aid to underdeveloped countries as part of efforts to achieve a needed expansion of exports, according to an economic "white paper" issued by the Ministry of International Trade and Industry.

LONDON, June 13 (Reuters) -- Following is an unofficial translation of the text of the aide-memoire of the Soviet Government agreeing to a meeting of experts in Geneva to study means of detecting nuclear explosions, as distributed by Tass, Soviet news agency, tonight:

Led by the rails and domestic oils, the stock market pounded forward to new 1958 highs today in the heaviest trading since May 6.

An elderly nuclear physicist who has never received any compensation for a top secret invention he gave this country in 1941 received sympathetic treatment yesterday in the United States Court of Appeals.
The thirty-fifth annual commencement exercises of the Jim Jigs, an institution dedicated to friendship, charity and the card game of poker, took place Thursday night.

OTTAWA, Que., June 13 (Canadian Press) -- Canada's wheat exports rose to a five-year high of 219,400,000 bushels in the first nine months of the current crop year. The country was the only one of the world's four major exporters to show an increase over last year.

Public participation in the market for United States Government securities since last summer has given the market its greatest buoyancy and breadth since the middle 1940s, according to the First Boston Corporation.

A group of Swedish business men filed suit yesterday in Federal Court here against the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and subsidiaries. The suit seeks $54,900,000 in treble damages for alleged patent infringements, unfair competition and antitrust violations.

MEXICO CITY, June 10 -- Mexico City College will reach its greatest enrollment at the summer session, which begins June 23.

MORRISTOWN, N. J., June 13 -- Superior Court Judge Gerald Foley today granted Columbia University a summary judgment against Roy Jacobsen of Shcoley's Mountain and rejected his counter-suit against the university for $8,000.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- Apparatus patented this week is intended to take the place of the human nose, up to a certain point. It is designed to distinguish odors, telling apart, for example, the scents of wintergreen, lemon, pineapple and onion.

LEXINGTON, Va., June 13 (AP) -- Washington and Lee University, a one-time football powerhouse today quit the Southern Conference it helped organize.

PHILADELPHIA, June 13 (AP) -- Calumet Farm's Tim Tam will be operated on at the University of Pennsylvania's School of Veterinary Medicine Tuesday morning to repair an injured right front ankle. The colt suffered a fractured sesamoid bone during the running of the Belmont Stakes.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 13 -- Greece accused the Turkish Government today of having instigated the current riots and internal strifs in Cyprus.

WASHIGTON, June 13 (UPI) -- The Senate Public Works Committee unanimously approved today a compromise rivers and harbors bill to replace the "pork barrel" measure vetoed by President Eisenhower last April.

Twenty handicapped persons were honored last night for their efforts to become self-supporting. They received citations at the seventh annual awards night of the Federation of the Handicapped, in the agency's auditorium at 211 West Fourteenth Street.

PARIS, June 13 -- Premier Charles de Gaulle appealed to Frenchmen tonight to support his leadership of the nation on a bold, independent course in domestic, colonial and international affairs.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, June 13 -- Imagine a shiny sinuous dragon fifty feet long, with a gaping, fanged, flaming mouth. Imagine it on a darkened stage, slithering and coiling and uncoiling as it chases a ball of fire. It should be terrifying, but it communicates the innocent joy of the world of magic.
Lady Ribblesdale, former wife of the late Col. John Jacob Astor and the mother of Vincent Astor, left an estate of $3,000,000, it was learned yesterday when her will was filed in Surrogate's Court.
MADRID, June 13 -- The Spanish Government is moving increasingly away from isolation.

GRAND RAPIDS, June 13 -- The wholesale furniture showing that opened here yesterday has scooped the larger national showings that open next Monday in Chicago with a collection that establishes a new "American Look."

CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., June 13 (AP) -- An Air Force Thor missile roared into the sky today in a fiery display of power.

TULSA, June 13 -- Tommy (Thunder) Bolt, a former carpenter, put together another 71 today for the undisputed lead at the halfway mark in the United States Open golf championship. The 39-year-old-professional, who was born in Oklahoma, set the pace with a 36-hole score of 142 at the Southern Hills Country Club.

TOWNSVILLE, Australia, June 13 (UPI) -- Jon Konrads, 15 years old, set a world record for the mile, and his younger sister, Ilsa, followed with new marks for 800 meters and 880 yards today in the Empire swimming games.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- Secretary of State Dulles said today the latest letter from Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev "appears to be an effort to push us more rapidly and more certainly toward a summit conference."

MOSCOW, June 13 -- Premier Khrushchev's latest letter on a heads - of - government meeting appears temporarily to have interrupted the ambassadorial talks held here in preparation for a possible East-West conference.
MOSCOW, June 13 -- Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev has accounted for the absent members of the Communist party Presidium and denied rumors of top-level changes here.

GENEVA, June 13 -- The Swiss Parliament in Bern approved today a constitutional amendment to grant women the right to vote and hold Federal office. The measure must now be submitted to a national all-male referendum.

CHICAGO, June 13 (AP) -- Prices on grain futures were mostly steady to weak on the Board of Trade in chiefly speculative trade.

Harold Carter, who asserts he is influenced by the writings of Schopenhauer, Nietzsche and Shakespeare, seemed to be inspired by the works of Mickey Spillane last night as he pulverized a German heavyweight, Willi Besmanoff, in a one-sided ten-round brawl at Madison Square Garden.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 13 -- Striking Hollywood musicians employed by major movie studios will decide next month whether they want to be represented in collective bargaining negotiations by the American Federation of Musicians or its newly organized rival, the Musicians Guild of America.

The management of Williams-McWilliams Industries, Inc., dredgers, marine builders and pork packers, changed yesterday. The entire slate of directors elected at the recent annual meeting resigned and new officers were named.

NEW HAVEN, June 13 - The election of the Rev. Kenneth S. Latourette as president of the Yale-in-China Association was announced today. He is Sterling Professor Emeritus of Missions and Oriental History at the Yale Divinity School.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- The Eisenhower Administration lost the first major decision tonight in its Senate fight for a strong labor reform bill. Bipartisan managers of the middle-of-the-road Kennedy-Ives reform bill staved off, 147-42, a stiffening amendment sought by the Administration.

LONGVIEW, Tex, June 13 (AP) -- Airman Donald Keeton's "suicide" flight from Mississippi in a rented plane was traced today to east Texas. But there the day-old trail ended and there was fear that he had crashed.

RIVERHEAD, L. I., June 13 -- Long Island home-owners began to get relief this week from a lawn-splotching fungus caused by the cold, wet spring. They then had to turn their attention to an unusually heavy infestation of aphids and red spiders -- an indirect result of the cold and damp -- on ornamental plants and vegetables.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- Supreme Court Justice William O. Douglas has been asked to stay the effect of an injunction that prohibits four persons opposed to atomic tests from sailing into the United States testing area in the Pacific.

These attributes -- among others -- put him securely in the great main stream of literature. He splashes around there with enormous vigor and exuberance.
The Transit Authority announced yesterday that it had a claimant for the package of diamonds found Monday afternoon on an IND train in Queens.

HOBOKEN, N. J., June 13 -- For the third consecutive year the American Export Lines has been awarded the special citation of the United States Public Service for excellence in vessel sanitation. Cardinal Spellman has announced assignments for thirty-two newly ordained priests of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York.

WESTBURY, L. I., June 13 -- Friday the thirteenth held no terror for 35-year-old Ned Bower, who tonight drove Adios Day to victory in the $34,900 Hopeful for 2-year-old pacers at Roosevelt Raceway. A crowd of 26,731 was on hand.

WASHINGTON, June 13 (AP) -- A Senate-House conference committee agreed today on a bill authorizing construction of two giant ocean liners. The Government would subsidize 55 per cent of the cost.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- President Eisenhower proposed to Congress today the establishment of a Federal Aviation Agency to promote greater air safety. It would combine some civilian and military functions.

NEWPORT, R. I., June 13 -- The main business of the yacht race to Bermuda that begins tomorrow was done in a hotel room today.

The shopping center containing a supermarket and eight other stores at 79-02 to 79-24 Twenty-first Avenue, Jackson Heights, Queens, has been sold by the Jackson Avenue Holding Corporation to an investor. The deal was negotiated by Norman Katz of Ossip Associates, Inc., brokers.

NEW ORLEANS, June 13 (AP) -- A young City Hall draftsman was found guilty of assault today in the first incident since the city's transit system was integrated by court order May 31.

LINCOLN PARK, N. J., June 13 -- The new church building of St. Andrew's Protestant Episcopal Mission will be dedicated here at 6 P. M. Sunday by Bishop Benjamin M. Washburn of the Diocese of Newark.
