NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., June 13 -- Congratulatory telegrams, letters and nosegays arrived in City Hall here today for Mrs. Betty A. Meagher, the "Cinderella" city manager. But she was still uncertain whether she wanted the glass slipper.
CHICAGO, June 13 -- Maj. John S. Eisenhower, the President's son, was quoted today as saying that he did not discuss weighty subjects with his father around the White House.

LONDON, June 13 -- The stock market closed the week on a firm note today. Contributing factors were yesterday's rise on Wall Street and a further fall in the Treasury bill rate -- the interest rate the Government pays for short-term loans.

Three Coast Guard vessels and aircraft from three air bases took part yesterday in a fruitless search for Lieut. James D. Bowman. The lieutenant was piloting a F-86 Sabrejet fighter-intercepter, reported missing off the Long Island coast at 10:20 A. M.

LAKE PLACID, N. Y., June 13 (UPI) -- The New York State Bankers Association was told by a panel of economists today that the recession was drawing to a close. But the experts declined to predict when an upswing would get under way, limiting it to "possibly 1959 or 1960."

PRINCETON, N. J., June 13 -- The carnival atmosphere of Princeton University alumni class reunions will reach a climax here tomorrow as 5,000 costumed graduates march in the annual P-Rade to the 229th Princeton-Yale baseball game.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 13 (AP) -- Johnny Antonelli's five-hit pitching plus a five-run eighth inning carried San Francisco to a 6-1 victory over the Philadelphia Phils tonight and snapped the Giants' losing streak at five games.

WASHINGTON, June 13 (AP) -- The Senate Banking and Currency Committee approved today a bill to strip the Secretaries of Commerce and the Treasury of any voice in fixing loan policies for the Small Business Administration.

Delbecque roamed France to meet with Public Safety Committees there and chart the future course of the movement.

LONDON, June 13 (AP) -- Rare Roman coins -- a museum official testified that they could have been handled by Jesus and his Apostles -- became the object of an official inquiry today to determine their ownership.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- Average wholesale prices in primary markets declined 0.2 per cent to 118.9 per cent of their 1947-49 level during the week ended last Tuesday, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

DETROIT, June 13 (AP) -- The nation's auto industry assembled its two millionth car of the year last Tuesday, almost two months behind last year's comparable unit, Ward's automotive Reports said today.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- Dr. Lawrence G. Derthick today called education in the Soviet Union "a kind of grand passion" through which that country expected to achieve its chief slogan, "Reach and overreach America."

Park Commissioner Moses has sounded an alarm about prospective pollution of some of the waters surrounding New York City. He points out that completion of the current ten-year $300,000,000 program for pollution control plants is not enough to make all of New York's beaches entirely safe for bathing. For instance, he notes that there must be a change in sewer construction in the East Bronx that may cost up to $39,000,000.
A struggle in which a man allegedly tried to shoot a policeman ended with the man's arrest yesterday. The incident occurred on 124th Street, between Park and Lexington Avenues, shortly before 1 A. M.

NICOSIA, Cyprus, June 13 -- Six Greek Cypriotes have died of injuries sustained in last night's savage fighting near Geunyeli, a village north of Nicosia.
PARIS, June 13 -- Finance Minister Antoine Pinay announced today a new loan designed to stabilize France's finances.
RABAT, Morocco, June 13 -- After a week of consultations in Paris, French Ambassador Alexandre Parodi has returned to Morocco.

THE season is waning but there are still some exhibitions of professional quality in the galleries. One of these is at the Krasner Gallery, 1061 Madison Avenue, where five artists are exhibiting recent paintings.
LONDON, June 13 -- Delegates of the Greater London bus strikers adopted today a resolution saying that continuance of the strike "would not be in the interest of the members."

The Pennsylvania Railroad, No. 1 in the industry, makes no bones about the probability that it will finish 1958 in the red. "This is going to be probably the worst year" in the carrier's 112-year history, David C. Bevan, vice president-finance, said yesterday.

The Playwrights Company has become a partner of Gilbert Miller and Henry Sherek in the forthcoming production of London's new mystery-comedy, "Not in the Book." "Keep Talking," a new panel show, will fill a half-hour on Tuesdays instead of Fridays as originally scheduled by the Columbia Broadcasting System television network.

The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (World Bank) announced yesterday a loan of $37,000,000 for the Kansai Electric Power Company, a Japanese private utility. Funds will be used to help finance construction of a 258,000 - kilowatt hydroelectric project in the mountains of central Japan.

M. on Feb. 8, at the Royal Festival Hall in London, and midnight of May 10, in the Khayyam Theatre in Baghdad, four American jazz musicians -- Paul Desmond (alto saxophone), Joe Morello (drums), Eugene Wright (bass) and myself (piano) -- traveled better than halfway around the world and played above seventy concerts in Great Britain, Germany, Holland, Belgium, Sweden, Denmark, Poland, Turkey, India, Ceylon, Pakistan, Afghanistan, Iran and Iraq.

THE new Eumig C3R Continental, electric-eye tri-lens turret 8mm movie camera, is announced by Unimark Photo, Inc., 130 West Thirty-first Street. Fingertip control of the built-in electric eye "operates all the time, with all film speeds, all camera speeds, all filters," according to the importer.

MARBLEHEAD, Mass., June 15 (AP) -- Louise Suggs maintained a steady pace and withstood a surging comeback by Mrs. Marlene Bauer Hagge today for a 2-point victory in the $12,000 round-robin invitation golf tournament.

PITTSBURGH, June 15 -- Steel orders are expected to ease some this week, compared with last week's, while shipments and production will reach new highs for the year. Customers who have been scurrying around to get their steel before July 1 have had few chances to place orders for such prompt delivery. Mills are busy trying to get out the tonnages already promised for delivery before the end of this month.
Continued occupation of Latvia, Lithuania and Estonia by the Soviet Union was denounced yesterday at a Baltic States Freedom Rally at Town Hall, 123 West Forty-third Street.
WASHINGTON, June 15 (UPI) -- President Eisenhower's top economic adviser predicted today that the recession would end "very soon" and an economic upswing would begin next autumn.
WASHINGTON, June 15 (UPI) -- Hoyt Wilhelm relieved in both ends of 2 double-header today to save 5-3 and 4-2 victories for the Cleveland Indians over the Washington Senators.

Freight hauled by intercity trucking in April edged up about 2 per cent above that for March but was 5.4 per cent below the April, 1957 total, the research department of the American Trucking Associations announced today.

PARIS, June 15 -- The United States made a little-noted shift in its policy approach to the projected Summit meeting when it proposed East-West technical talks on nuclear arms next month in Geneva. The shift concerned the form rather than the substance of such discussions.
THE ideal way to travel by automobile would be in a caravan with adults, children and luggage in different cars.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, June 15 -- Government troops have landed north and east of the Indonesian rebel capital of Menado, on northern Celebes.

A cloud of uncertainty hangs over the Civil Aeronautics Administration's technical development center at Indianapolis. Virtually all of the equipment used by the nation's airways and air traffic control system has been developed or perfected there.

Max Block, accused by Senate racket investigators of misusing union funds and of other abuses, has withdrawn his resignation as president of two New York locals of the Amalgamated Meat Cutters and Butcher Workmen.

After much travail and some anguish, Pancho Gonzales and Lewis Hoad scored their second victories in the $15,O00 professional round-robin tournament of tennis champions at Forest Hills yesterday. They lead the field as night sessions begin this evening under Promoter Jack Kramer's high-powered lighting system in the stadium.

WASHINGTON, June 15 (UPI) -- Senator Mikes Mansfield, Democrat of Montana, said today that Government workers who sold United States goods abroad at black-market prices were partly to blame for recent outbreaks of anti-American sentiment.

ALGIERS, June 15 (UPI) -- Key units of the 400,000-man French Army in Algeria were authoritatively reported today to have gone on the alert for an offensive to smash the forty-four-month Moslem rebellion.

AMSTERDAM, The Netherlands, June 15 -- The payments balance surplus for 1958 is estimated at no less than 1,500,000,000 guilders or over 4 per cent of the national income, against last year's deficit of 342,000,000, according to Jelle Zylstra, minister of economic affairs.

TO shellac or varnish is the question in inquiries on wood floors directed to this department. A New York City apartment dweller recently asked about the durability and appearance of both these finishes.
LIME ROCK, Conn., June 15 -- Walter Hansgen of Westfield, N. J., won his sixth straight national championship sports car race today.

MONTCLAIR, N. J., June 15 -- Playing a bold and at times almost reckless game of golf, Lloyd Monroe, 19, gained the New Jersey amateur championship today in the final of the state's fifty-seventh annual tournament.

The American Broadcasting Company last night canceled Mike Wallace's filmed television interview with Henry Cabot Lodge, United States Ambassador to the United Nations. It said that the deletions Mr. Lodge had insisted on constituted "editorial censorship" in violation of company policy.
ENJOYABLE and authoritative baseball talk is to be heard these Sunday evenings on "The Baseball Corner" over Channel 7.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- A drumfire of political criticism of Sherman Adams, the Assistant to the President, continued today on the eve of new House hearings on his gift-filled friendship with Bernard Goldfine, a Boston business man.
WASHINGTON, June 15 -- National Guard spokesmen throughout the country are campaigning bitterly against cuts in their forces ordered by the Army.
MOSCOW, June 15 -- The sermon in Pravda this morning, as in meetings and at services around the world, was about morality and ethics.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, June 15 -- The performers deserted the theatres today as a lovely sunny day cast a spell of Mid-summer's Eve ahead of time on Brussels and its World's Fair.
WASHINGTON, June 15 (UPI) -- President Eisenhower returned to the White House today after having spent a quiet weekend with his family at his farm at Gettysburg, Pa.
DURHAM, N. H., June 15 (AP) -- Mark Van Doren told the graduating class of the University of New Hampshire today that a wise man gives the impression "he knows things that he cannot prove."

A vacant plot of land at Northern Boulevard and Cutter Mill Road, Little Neck, Queens, has been leased by the Cord Meyer Company to Louis Gellman. The deal was negotiated by Balter Greenberg, Inc., brokers.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 15 -- Army tanks were brought into action today as street fighting broke out anew in this crisis-ridden capital city.

CHICAGO, June 15 (AP) -- Continued tightening commercial supplies of wheat and corn influenced grain futures trading last week, with dealers inclined to back away from heavy short selling on the Board of Trade.
LONDON, June 15 -- Hugh Gaitskell, leader of the Labor party, declared today there still was considerable danger of an overthrow or undermining of democracy in France.
LONDON, June 15 (AP) -- A Royal Albert Hall audience of 7,000 gave Van Cliburn a standing, cheering ovation tonight at his first British concert.

The Brooklyn Chamber of Commerce is preparing a protest to the Interstate Commerce Commission on the withdrawal of so-called "free lighterage of lumber from New Jersey and Manhattan railheads to Brooklyn.
RIVER FOREST, Ill., June 15 -- White collar workers are the most faithful members of the Roman Catholic flock, the Rev. Joseph Fichter said today.
Three new films will arrive in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- The State Department published a 111-page account today of swiftly expanding Soviet trade and aid activities based on a massively developing So viet economy. In less than five years, it said, the Soviet bloc has extended about $1,900,000,000 in military and economic aid to fourteen "less developed" countries while its trade with such countries expanded 70 per cent.
OMAHA, June 15 (AP) -- Larry Rancourt and Jack Ringle walloped home runs as Holy Cross routed Clemson, 17 -- 4, in a second-round game of the national collegiate baseball tournament tonight.
WASHINGTON, June 15 -- The dispute over education bills is continuing in Congress in the wake of warnings of stiff Soviet competition by an exchange team of United States educators.
LOS ANGELES, June 15 (UPI) -- The Pittsburgh Pirates shelled seven Los Angeles pitchers today for a 12-1 victory before 30,752 fans in Memorial Coliseum.
CAIRO, June 15 -- There were ominous indications today that the crisis in Lebanon would spread and pit the United Arab Republic against the Western powers.
Jimmy Dean, country music singer, has been "traded" by his former employer to the Columbia Broadcasting System television network.

The Rev. Dr. Albert J. Penner preached his last sermon yesterday as minister of the Broadway Congregational Church at Fifty-sixth Street. Dr. Penner, who became the minister in 1949, is leaving for a denominational post in Boston.
IN this season of movie, radio, television and news achievement awards, a special classification may have to be invented for Representative Kenneth Barnard Keating.
TUNIS, June 15 -- A pending agreement for the evacuation of all French military posts in Tunisia except Bizerte has been blocked, at least temporarily, by the problem of radar observation stations.
WASHINGTON, June 15 -- Officials here were mystified tonight by the sudden departre of Ambassador Menshikov.
The huge rocket that put the ton-and-one-half Soviet Sputnik III into orbit made a spectacular appearance over the city in the early hours of yesterday morning.
The new rector of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Transfiguration outlined in a sermon yesterday plans to establish "a real parish family life" in the historic church and the community.
MOUNT KISCO, N. Y., June 15 -- Kirby Plaza, a $35,000 expression of the horticultural tastes of commuters, shoppers, merchants and the New York Central Railroad, was dedicated this afternoon.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 15 -- In the rocky, mountainous province of Badakhshan in Afghanistan, the Technical Assistance Program of the United Nations faces one of its sharpest challenges. There 100,000 persons, prohibited by law from growing the opium that has sustained them and their ancestors for centuries, are threatened with destitution.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., June 15 -- Richard S. Dirkes' Stowaway edged Nelson Macy's Typhoon by twenty seconds today to win Manhasset Bay One-Design Class honors in the interclub series sponsored by the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 15 -- President Tito accused Communist China's leadership today of counting on war to consolidate its rule in Asia.
Welfare Commissioner Henry L. McCarthy announced yesterday that the city's relief load had risen only 1,600 in May, against a monthly average of more than 8,000 for the preceding five months.
A MANUFACTURER has placed a new model toaster, coffeemaker and vacuum cleaner on the market. Each has refinements designed to increase the homemaker's convenience.
With the Communists apparently put to rout, the three-day Leftist "unity conference" here ended yesterday on a note of surface unity.

STAMFORD, Conn., June 15 -- Peggy Augustus of Old Keswick, Va., rode Waiting Home to the conformation hunter championship of the Ox Ridge Hunt Club horse show today with a 101/2-point lead over Mr. and Mrs. Henry D. Paxson's Chappaqua.
MINNEAPOLIS, June 15 -- Mrs. Sherman Adams was quoted today as saying her husband's opponents would seek to "hound" him out of the White House.
Whatever Bill Norman is doing to the Tigers -- some say he is feeding them raw meat -- it unquestionably is producing miraculous results.
LONDON, June 15 -- The good showing on Wall Street and further indications that the United States economy is recovering helped the stock markets here last week.
Many of the ranking tennis players are abroad at this time of the year, and it is not until Wimbledon is ended that our own tournaments are able to muster an entry with box-office appeal.

A $5,780,000 syndication plan for the twenty-five-story General Motors Building at Broadway and Fifty-seventh Street has been announced by Louis J. Glickman, an organizer of realty investment syndicates.
The training ship Empire State III is now equipped with a radio facsimile weather recorder. The New York State Maritime College said the recorder would be used by cadets on the vessel's 1958 cruise.

The authors of your recent pieces on the new fair trade bill (May 26 and June 1) deserve congratulations for highlighting the issues raised by this legislation. A question is raised in my mind, however, about the role great newspapers should play in leading public opinion and arousing it in time to be effective against clever lobbying campaigns.
Squirrels at the Bronx Zoo, with no belts to pull in; yesterday were among the most acutely affected victims of the two-day strike that has closed the city's zoos and museums.

A 9-year-old Queens girl and her younger sister were struck yesterday by an automobile that mounted the sidewalk in front of their Jackson Heights home. The older child was killed. Her sister suffered a broken leg.
WASHINGTON, June 15 -- The Supreme Court has been asked to consider changes in its long - established method of handing down decisions.
ABOARD COAST GUARD PLANE AT SEA, June 15 -- The fleet was speeding toward its destination tonight on the second day of the Newport-Bermuda race.

S. Kopel, Inc., manufacturer of leather products, bought the two-story factory building at 2145 Pitkin Avenue, in the East New York section of Brooklyn, from L. Seltzer. The building contains 10,000 square feet of space and was sold in a deal negotiated by the Don Lieberman Organization, broker.

LONDON, June 15 -- Busmen at four Greater London garages voted today to accept their union leaders' recommendation for a renewal of negotiations with the London Transport Executive in an effort to settle the six-week-old bus strike.

RIVERSIDE, Conn., June 15 -- Joseph Hunt's Inamorata, yesterday's leader, headed the Luders-16 fleet for the third successive time and Bob McCullough's Ajax gained a second straight Quincy Adams-17 victory today in the Combined Eastern Fleets Yacht Racing Association championship regatta.
The election of Sir Geoffrey Crowther and Lord Sinclair of Cleeve to the advisory board on international business of Chemical Corn Exchange Bank has been announced by Harold H. Helm, chairman.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 15 -- The American Federation of Television and Radio Artists has rejected the Screen Actors Guild proposal to have their video tape jurisdictional dispute arbitrated. It again suggested that the unions merge.
CHICAGO, June 15 -- The furniture industry was accused today of paying more attention to changes in style than to comfort, convenience and permanence.
Enactment of municipal ordinances to govern the use of color, building materials, landscaping, location and grouping of buildings was urged in a report made public yesterday.
A joint labor-management research foundation reported yesterday that many physicians were overcharging patients covered by union welfare funds.

RABAT, Morocco, June 15 -- The two leading figures of the Moroccan Government will leave Rabat tomorrow for Tunis, where North African leaders are expected to lay the foundations for a united states of North Africa.

OSSINING, N. Y., June 15 -- The dull tones of an ancient Buddhist temple bell signaled the departure today of fifty-one Maryknoll priests for lifetime mission posts in Africa, Japan, Korea, Formosa, the Philippines and Latin America.

In our search for security against the economic impact of the business cycle we have legislated into being in recent years a number of so-called built-in stabilizers. But in addition to these legislated stabilizers, there are others that rest, not on legislation, but, in a manner of speaking, on imputation.

LOURDES, France, June 15 (Reuters) -- Pope Pius XII sent a message today to 40,000 soldiers, sailors and airmen gathered at Lourdes on an international pilgrimage. The message, read at an open-air mass, said:
Edward Nazar Costikyan is a Tammany district leader. "Unlike Tammany leaders of old," a close friend says, "he not only can read, but he also can read music."
CINCINNATI, June 15 -- The 1,500,000-member American Baptist Convention found itself today in one of the strangest predicaments ever faced by a church body in this country.
LARCHMONT, N. Y., June 15 -- Eighty-seven boats, the season's top turnout, enjoyed perfect sailing weather today in the Larchmont Yacht Club's Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound program.

WIMBLEDON, England, June 15 (UPI) -- Mrs. Margaret Osborne du Pont, the captain of the first losing United States Wightman Cup tennis team in twenty-eight years, summed up today the reason for Britain's victory.
STOCKHOLM, June 15 (UPI) -- Four teams joined Sweden today in qualifying for the quarterfinals of the World Cup soccer series.

The lilt of Irish pipes and the clog of youthful heels resounded yesterday on the Bronx campus of Hunter College. Nearly 30,000 Irish-Americans turned out for the twenty-sixth annual feis of the United Irish Counties Association of New York.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., June 15 -- Slums that have been developing here since the era of the French Huguenot settlers are scheduled to be erased by a $36,000,000 urban redevelopment program. The City Council will begin the final step toward certification this week.

Concern about the relative quality of Soviet and American education has stirred discussion in this country for many months. This concern will probably be heightened by the first report given by United States Commissioner of Education Lawrence G. Derthick after returning from a month's study of Soviet schools. Dr. Derthick concludes the Soviet Union has a "total commitment to education."
MEXICO CITY, June 15 -- The New York Philharmonic Orchestra played the last of a series of thirty-nine concerts in twelve Latin-American countries here this morning.
RIO DE JANEIRO, June 15 -- Brazil's President, Juscelino Kubitschek, was represented today as believing that United States foreign aid had been a failure everywhere.
